description:
Good restaurant. Not the best sushi hut definitely busy

The whole place was hot but the bill was inexpensive for S.F.  Don't think I'll be back but it wasn't awful, just nothing to write home about
author: katelynn a.

description:
Came here for dinner before a concert at the Masonic. It was super lively on a Friday night. The food was disappointing tho - chicken karage lacked flavor and had a lot of breading. It didn't have the crunch I was hoping for since it's supposed to be like popcorn chicken. I got the dragon roll which was also bland and tasted a little dry. The avocado on top didn't look too good and I barely tasted the eel. My friend got the sashimi dinner plate and I tried a little bit of the salmon, it was not bad. Their raw options seem to be better than the cooked food.

Service was okay, not super attentive and it took a while for them to get us the check. 

It's a hip spot with dim ambiance & loud music and mediocre food.
author: Ying Z.

description:
I like to love and give high ratings for this establishment but unfortunately.....here is the review:

Good: 

1. One of the best, and delicious nigiri sushi in town.
2. Kewl, funky, underground music.


Bad:

1. Japanese food is expensive enough, their nigiri is expensive for what you get.

2. the sashimi once served is on the lousy side. Like telling you "we got tired of making your nigiri, here is best sashimi preparation we can do"

3. On summer days, it can get really hot and humid here only because its underground.

Overall - not bad of a japanese place. Try it once.

TIP: to avoid long lines, try coming in before 8:30p.
author: YelpIsExtortion N S.

description:
3.5 stars

Never saw a restaurant have a bouncer and a DJ! It's like a mix between a restaurant and a club. You walk in down the stairs and it wasn't filled with people waiting, but usually it is and then you write your name down on a waitlist.

It was not too long of a wait, around 15 minutes. That's also because we arrived after a movie around 10pm and I heart it's quite busy earlier. Not a lot of space for groups larger than 3, it's easy to find a table with 2.

Ryoko's is a lively sushi bar, it's sort of underground and has this bit of grungy vibe. I went with 4 people and we shared 4 different sushi rolls at various price points. It came out to around $12 per person, even though it seems cheap the rolls were a bit expensive. The rolls were pretty small though and we were satisfied but not close to full. We tried the sexy, pokemon, crunchy crab and spicy golden gate roll.

My favorite was the sexy roll it's a baked roll with salmon and cheese, even though I find cheese kind of gimmicky sometimes, it actually turned out well! The other roll I liked was the crunchy crab roll.

It took us a while to be seated, but the food came out of pretty fast.

The rolls were decent! But, it's too loud and I think it's pretty expensive.
author: Christopher L.

description: First time here. Walking in I was super skeptical. Walking down into a basement but once is at down it was a cool hipsterish spot. The ambiance is a bit loud and you have to sign yourself in. The service was great, our server was super attentive and nice. The food was fresh and delicious. It's a bit pricey but I can accept it. I would Def. Recommend you to experience it if you havnt been there before.
author: Jon T.

description:
What a bust. Don't be fooled by the good music, and long wait. Definitely not my cup of tea when it comes to Asian fusion dining.

Got the tempura, which was a big let down. Small portion for the price. Greasy.

Salmon roll: taste was okay.

Chirashi: are you kidding me? Too much mackerel and roe, not enough of the good stuff. Might as well call it the mackerel bento. You only get one slice of the good stuff, everything else is rice and cheap fish. 

This place is a joke. If the food was actually good, I wouldn't have mind the small portions. But you have less than average taste in food, and average quality. Would not recommend. There are better places in the city.
author: Lynn C.

description: The ambiance is literally a zero but the quality of the fish speaks for itself. The toro and the uni are the winners here! True sushi lovers will enjoy this, if your looking for a high end or sceney place skip this. I will be back. I enjoyed!
author: Shannon B.

description:
We had the fatty tuna, sashimi dinner and tuna roll. Everything was amazing!!!!!!!!!! Wow. I've never been so impressed by a sushi restaurant.

It has a really cool vibe and so much courtesy. All the sushi chefs greet you and thank you on the way out!

I would come again!
author: Rose F.

description:
Am I the only one that's not a fan? It opens late, has a DJ that plays hip hop, R&B music. Chill ambiance. 

Food is mediocre, expensive. The rolls are tiny like food for ants. For over $15 I expect them to be at least filling.
author: Debbie D.

description:
I like how it's downstairs in a basement-like kind of space compared to the ground floor sushi restaurants.  It makes it more Japanese that way and karaoke vibes available.  

The uni here was amazingly savory! 

Sashimi and sushi rolls were of the norm.

Tempura was nice and guaranteed satisfying.  

Dimly lit on the ambiance part.  They have pleasant hot sake! Clean and clear to my liking!

Ganbei!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Holy wait! I called Ryoko's to see if we could make a reservation for dinner but they said they didn't do reservations for Friday. We got here about 7 and waited for 45 min to be sat. When you enter, walk down the stairs and to your left there is a clipboard with a pen, sign your name and play the waiting game. 

Don't try and attempt to make your way through and take the bar seats without your name being called. It's not your typical sushi restaurant where bar is open seating. We saw multiple guests do this and the servers were so quick to notice and asked them to get up. 

Now to the good stuff, FOOD:

-Sake (Salmon) (4/5): Very fresh!

-Hamachi (3.5/5): Ok, didn't like the wasabi smeared into the rice.

-Beef oroshi (4/5): someone on yelp said this was Wagyu, but it's definitely not Wagyu. It tasted ok though. Not super chewy but just right. 

-Dragon (4.5/5): Delicious! Probably my fav roll here. The eel set the roll just right.

-Jumping unagi (4/5): Yumm!

-Hot tail right (4/5): Very fresh!

-Crunchy crab left: My friend ordered this so I didn't try it.

-Nigiri Sushi Dinner (3.5/5):  If you don't like wasabi on the rice please let the server know because authentic Japanese sushi restaurants serve nigiri with a little bit of wasabi on the rice. I'm not a fan of wasabi so this ruined it for me. It comes with a side of miso soup and a California roll. The egg sushi was not my fav.

Cheap and delicious sushi. Quick turn around time!
author: Trinh V.

description: For a lot of places where you want to have a good time, the food is bad and something you have to deal with. This place is an exception. A group of 6 of us went to Ryoko's for a birthday. Given that it was a birthday, we turned out to be a particularly raucous crowd. That being said our server was very kind and flexible. The cold sake was particularly good. For food I got a hamachi and sake nigiri which was decent but not exceptional. I ordered a spicy tuna roll with blue fin tuna which was truly exceptional. They have a system where they will increase the price on a roll if the fish that day if very good quality. I ended up paying $10.50 for a roll that was priced at $7. I definitely thought the fish was worth the price and the other nigiri which was not as good was charged as advertised. This is for sure the place you want to go to for a party atmosphere and the food is quite good considering the low price and the relative scale.
author: Sharvari J.

description:
I absolutely love this fun and yummy dinner/late night drunk munchies spot! :) I have sent many out of town guests here and all of them have loved it as well. It has a fabulous vibe with a Dj most nights and is open super late. The quality of food is exceptional, especially for the Price and you will not beat the vibe. Definitely recommended but get there early as the line can get long (don't forget to sign in on the notepad hanging on the hostess stand once you arrive) and check out the specials and live music if they have it that night. 

Great hole in the wall and good amount of seating/ambiance! A+
author: Ellie J.

description:
This is hands down one of the BEST sushi bars in all of San Francisco possibly the Bay. I have been coming here for years. HOWEVER, for the first time I tried a cooked item (Teriyaki Chicken) seems safe enough. Not only did it take almost 30 MINUTES to deliver, when I got it it was dry and totally tasteless. It was horrible. I will still come here for the sushi. Eat Sushi Nothing Cooked you'll be fine. It gets 4 stars based on past experience which have all been stellar.

Also: Its worth mentioning that I don't go to restaurants to be in a club. I'd support a change in music selection and volume.
author: S F.

description:
Simply the best. Seating can be a challenge and don't picky with where you sit. Look past it and you will enjoy your meal a lot more. Servers are so friendly and make the place a nice place. Don't overlook the specials on the board and if you don't know what it is, just ask the servers. Again, they are so happy to help.
Sake list and beers are awesome.
author: Gene L.

description:
Omg. I came here for dinner a couple nights ago and I've been thinking about this meal ever since. I'm pretty sure I dreamed about it too! 

Came with a group of 4 and we were ready to do work! The sashimi dinner here was sooo good. It came with salmon, yellowtail, saba, shrimp, scallop, and tuna. 2- 3 substantial slice of each! It is also served with miso soup. 

Although it's not on their menu, we got the hamachi kama. THIS WAS THE BEST. EVER. It was my first time having this in general and my mind was blown. Trust me, you gotta try this one here. The meat is so soft and just melts in your mouth! AAahhh I already want more. :P 

Toro here was also amazing. We got 2 servings (2 pieces per serving) and loved it so much that we ordered another one right away! It just melts away in your mouth. Seriously amazing. 

We also got 3 rolls to share: volcano roll, 49ers roll, and rainbow roll. We ordered the volcano roll because it sounded super interesting since it has peanut butter in it. We decided to give it a try anyway, and I actually really liked it. The peanut butter created a unique flavor combo with the shrimp tempura and jalapeno. Rainbow roll and 49ers roll were good as well.

I also really liked the ambiance here. Low light and underground. There are 2 TVs here as well if you're not tryna miss a game. I will for sure be back.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
We came here around 7:30pm on a Monday night and it was popping in here! They have a live DJ playing music in the restaurant. We walked in and down the stairs to place our name in the wait list that hangs on the left. It's not super clear to do that but we knew because of yelp but I saw a few parties that were annoyed when no one greeted them. They could benefit from having a sign at the bottom of the stairs to direct them to do that as often people stood in front of the wait list. 

We probably waited 15-20min for a table and once we were seated it probably took just as long for someone to bring us water/take our water. We ordered the chicken karrage, rainbow, jumping unagi, big mama and dragon rolls. The chicken karrage came out a few minutes after our order. Then the jumping unagi and dragon rolls a few minutes after that. And then the rainbow roll last. You would expect the rainbow roll to come out first because they don't have to dry anything. I just found it so strange that I got my food quicker than it took for a waitress to come to my table!

The chicken karrage was okay. It's fried chicken. The batter was light and it wasn't anything special. 

The jumping unagi was good but I wish it didn't come as one of the first rolls because it is so filling because of the fried tempura. I think this roll could have benefited from less batter. It was a bit much. 

The big mama was okay. I ordered it because I thought it was unique but it was too spicy for my taste. It overpowered everything else on that roll. 

The dragon roll was my favorite, by far. You could tell all the ingredients from the roll was fresh. It was probably the best dragon roll I've had. Everything from the fish, rice, seaweed and avocado was perfect!

The rainbow roll was equally as fresh and delicious as the dragon roll. 

I honestly would give this 4 stars if the service was better. The long wait to order was a bit ridiculous but it took even longer to get the check. JUST LET ME LEAVE SO YOU CAN TURNOVER THE TABLE TO PEOPLE LEAVING. We asked the waitress for the check multiple times and she knew we were waiting because she kept delivering food/ walking back and forth and we kept making eye contact with her. I would've give this place 1 star but that dragon roll was that good!
author: Maggie W.

description:
Definitely a divey sushi spot with lots of hype and overpriced items. Came with a group of 6 and was seated in the back room which was cool to be away from other patrons. 

But everything on the menu is overpriced with tiny portions. Got a 14 pc sashimi dinner for $40 and the pieces were super small and not worth it. The spicy tuna roll only came in 5 pieces. What a rip! 

The waitress was trying to upsell us on a bottle of sake that she claimed just came in. We didn't fall for that trick and just ordered off the sake menu. 

I probably won't be back. Parking is tough of course since it's the city.
author: James H.

description:
I don't understand the hype about this place.

My friend and I were nearby finishing up with happy hour and wanted to grab a light dinner before calling it a night. Luckily Ryoko's was right around the corner. It's an interesting set up, as the restaurant is in the basement, which isn't too common in SF. The music blaring loudly over the speakers was all top 40s / pop; I remember hearing Party in the USA come on at one point, which marks the first time I've ever heard that at a restaurant. But I digress...

We came on a Monday night a little after 9:30, and the place was popping. There was barely an empty table in sight! I was shocked. There were a handful of groups there, but Ryoko's sweet spot is really as a late night date spot. Everywhere we looked, we saw couples on dates. The dim lighting and the blaring music must help foster this environment...

We weren't too hungry, so we opted to share their sashimi dinner and a caterpillar roll. The sashimi set comes with 14 pieces and was quite underwhelming. For us, it included four pieces of salmon, three tuna, three yellowtail, three cooked octupus, and one piece of shrimp. Nothing tasted particularly fresh, and I couldn't believe this one tiny platter of mediocre sashimi set us back $40. The caterpillar roll ($14) was good, but it's a hard roll to screw up.

My friend and I agreed, we definitely won't be coming back here again.
author: Dianna H.

description: Seriously amazing. I'm not the biggest seafood fan(usually due to a lack of quality and freshness at other places) but this place is amazing. 10 stars out of 5. The vibe is awesome especially on the weekends. The food is beyond amazing. The servers make great recommendations when they have time and hear what you like. Drink selection is great. Soft shell crab. Beef dishes. Katsu. Sushimi. Rolls. Everything is perfect and incredible. Worth every penny and the tip.
author: Sean R.

description:
I really want to give them 5 stars, but I just can't because of the crazy waits they have here. 

I mean it's not their fault, with their perfect blend of New York style sushi dungeon and California creative menu. The drinks are a decent price, too.

I just find myself not going here because they frankly are just not that good to wait an hour for. 

There are plenty other options with decent sushi that have a fraction of the wait. 

HOWEVER, if you can beat the wait, no better place for nigiri. 

I will say this, if all the sushi places in town, and I've been to Every. Single. One. Ryoko's has the best sake nigiri I've had in SF, hands down, consistently. I think they use salmon belly because it's melt in your mouth. I spend $40 bucks on the nigiri alone every time I go here.
author: John W.

description:
One of G's favorite Sushi places. 

Came here Thursday night. 

I honestly don't care for the sushi here (it's not the best), but the ambiance is nice.
author: Lilian L.

description: Amazing place for sushi and seafood. I had the spicy tuna and spicy scallop roll along with the fried octopus. It was fantastic. I'll be back for sure!
author: jason k.

description:
Bad service. Not impressed.
Don't order the jumping California roll. I wouldn't even consider it sushi.
author: Song W.

description:
As my sister says, Ryoko's got total New York vibes!   Restaurant is almost like an underground basement as you walk down the narrow stairs at the entrance. The vibration of the EDM music and scattered overhead lights immediately sets the atmosphere of a good night out. Feels like a dance party except the party is in your mouth as soon as you taste the delicious food. Arrive early or do expect a wait!

The vibrant nigiri plate tasted as good as it looks! The scallops were shipped fresh from Japan and $12.80/piece. There was also fatty toro, lean toro, yelllowtail etc. As you can see I'm not familiar with the exact names since I left my sushi expert sisters to do the ordering. Luckily the staff is knowledgeable to recognize them from photos. Please see pics!

I'm a sushi roll kind of person, so the salmon skin roll was my absolute favorite of the night. There was a nice smokey taste and it was very simple. Can't go wrong with spider roll too.

Among 3 ppl, we ordered 5 rolls, a variety of nigiri (both local and from Japan) ~15 pieces, and the fried octopus appetizer. Will be back
author: Mandy L.

description:
Hand dinner off the special list. Fried oysters, wagyu beef and a 49er roll. 
All excellent. Service is quick and polite. 
I recommend Ryoko's
author: Dan R.

description:
Decent sushi. Garbage service. 

Waited over 30 minutes for a sashimi platter then finally tracked down the waitress to ask about it and was told it was "sold out".
author: Alex R.

description: This is my favorite sushi spot in SF. My husband and I love the ambiance here. The music is incredible and the sushi is fresh and delicious. We love the sake sashimi, unagi nigiri, and the featured specials. There is almost a club vibe with fun 90s-era hip hop. There is a live DJ. Lines can be long but sign in and head over to the owl tree across the street for a drink (or 3!).
author: Zinia G.

description:
My fave sushi restaurant. 
Everything is great. Shout out to their employee, Kevin, who has been there for as long as I have been going there - at least 4-5 years. 

Sashimi plate rocks. Rolls are fresh. The staff is nice. Lychee martinis are awesome. Good saki selection. The music is fun ( the have hip-hop and bass music). It's sort of like a nightclub - except you can't dance. Don't expect quiet. 

First come first serve wait. At 11p or midnight prepare to wait a while. This is the spot to be at and the wait is well worth it. 

I want to give it 6 plus stars. :)
author: Zita M.

description: I am sad that some reviewers did not really like this sushi place! I agree the atmosphere isn't that great and its kind of crammed. However I do love the sushis here, we all got sushi rolls and they were delicious! the salmon was nicely cooked that it melts in your mouth! I would definitely come back again
author: Nina Y.

description: Ryoko's is the Sushi place I've been searching for all my life. The moment you get there you are greeted by a security guard so you know it's the real deal, once your foot crosses the door to the restaurant the environment is unreal the night we were there, there was a live DJ who was phenomenal the rolls are amazing jumping tuna, orange peel and spicy scallops are a must. Ask for the house saki you won't regret it! I will go back.
author: Alex L.

description:
Great ambiance! Live dj! Lively place! I would have my bday party here late night! 

I could see myself coming more often as it's open so late! We ordered the chawanmushi special with spot prawn and mushroom, ume shiso maki, natto roll ( a must when I go to Japanese restaurants, I like to taste different natto among other funky fresh things) oyster tempura, and a spicy scallop roll. 

All was delicious and seemed fresh and "authentic" as I would know it to be. I love the natto it was much earthier and briny. The chawanmushi was delicate and rich but also extremely light. The ume shiso was good but missing something, the oyster tempura was good but the bread hurt the roof of my mouth and the spicy scallop roll was delicious! 

Overall, must check it out when in sf late night !
author: Megan K.

description:
Came here with friend for a late dinner and left very unimpressed. I'm actually quite surprised by the high ratings. Because for us, it was contrary to the high rating experience. 

The building of this place is more dated so when we sat down, we immediately smelled something moldy. At first, I thought it was the table next to us so I requested to move then after we moved, that smell continued to linger so it was the place itself. 

The food. I think the food was the main contributor as to why I was unimpressed. We ordered the sashimi plate, two rolls, and an appetizer. The sashimi didn't really taste fresh. Only the salmon sashimi slice actually taste good. The other fish either taste bland or wasn't very fresh. I don't know if it's bc it was a late dinner or Bc that's their fish. The special rolls tasted decent. They were cooked so I had a piece of mind. 

Overall experience was okay, not that great.
author: Ngoc P.

description:
5 stars for this place that made me, a non sushi-eater, actually enjoy my sushi experience. 

Love the downwards stairs that lead you to sushi heaven. The upbeat ambiance and authentic feel to a sushi bar brings a mix of excitement and adventure not too many places provide.

Ordered about 5 different rolls, the beef teriyaki, and some sake and I have no complaints. I'm a notorious non-sushi eater, so obviously seeing me enjoy my meal brought a sudden surprise to my date. Gotta keep em on their toes, am I right? Lol.

Service was efficient and polite, food was great, and even though the day started initially as a sushi-hopping adventure it pretty much started and ended here for me.
author: Paul H.

description:
First review of 2018 is for late night sushi with a DJ at the turn tables. Been here twice and I got to say it gets packed on the weekends, especially around 11:30pm. It usually moves fairly quickly, I think both times I got seated around 15-20 minutes. 

Pros
- open late
- music to entertain you
- fairly intimate but also suitable for groups, if you want to get seated quick I don't suggest coming here with a group over 4 people
- fairly good sushi for the price point, my favorite roll so far has been the jumping tuna, with my next favorite probably being the yellowtail based roll. Haven't had a bad roll yet.

I'd come to Ryoko's anytime I want some late night sushi at a reasonable price. Biggest selling point for me is that they're open till 2am.
author: Arezou A.

description: The worst philly roll and miso soup I've ever had! My gf ordered the roll and not only was it not rolled properly, it was cut unevenly with a huge piece at the end. It also tasted funny.. there was a weird aftertaste. The miso was fishy af!! Not good by any standards. Maybe since we got there late they figured they could feed us bath water and we wouldn't know the difference ... honestly i couldn't tell a difference between that miso and used bath water. Cool DJ though.
author: Melinda L.

description:
Fun sushi spot that's about a 10 min walk from Powell bart station / Westfield shopping center. 

Wait/Ambiance: Came here at 6:30 on a Tuesday, and had to wait 30 minutes for a party of 3 (luckily indoors). Inside looks like a divey bar - lots of black wooden walls, EDM and hip hop music (but not super loud). You have to go down a few stairs to get to the restaurant, and I don't think there is a wheelchair accessible route. 

Food: I got the 49ers roll, which was $13.50 for a small portion. The roll was delicious and fresh, but I needed an additional roll (spicy tuna) to be full. Overall, great sushi and rolls but at average/slightly above average prices.

Service: Quick, but sometimes a bit slow even for a Tuesday.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Fun late night spot. I dined around midnight on a Wednesday and there was a DJ providing great energy with a classic hip hop soundtrack. Service is very casual but effective and fast. 
Beverage menu is a bit limited for an izakaya, shochu cocktails are fun but garnishes were a bit old. 
Menu touches on the heavy expected hitters, Sushi bar seats around 10 for the one on one experience. Savory food was fast and cheap. Rolls for $5 and plates food under $10. Highlights were the classic items, tekka rolls, mackerel, Ika Yaki etc. 
overall fun late night eats and good value for the dollar but not refined in any manner.
author: Gary FX L.

description:
I would've given them a four stars for food if the service was better. The staff made a 90-year-old gentleman wait outside when they could've been seated downstairs. Also the music was way too loud. That fried cheese was underwhelming everything else was OK. Comparing it to the restaurants around the area this was only okay. The shrimp/ ebi tasted off... (food regret later tonight) everything else was decent. 

Again work on the customer service - don't make a 90-year-old gentleman stand outside when they requested if they could sit.

The fried cheese was also disappointing.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Stars: 3.5

I totally dig the vibes of this place! My party of 5 got there around 6:20pm on a Saturday, just a little after they opened. It was already completely packed, but thankfully we were at the front of the line and waited no more than 20 minutes to be seated. While we waited, we were able to order drinks from the bar and jam to edm. Untz untz untz!

After we ordered, our food came within 15-20 minutes. My boyfriend and I split 3 rolls. The rolls were small and just okay. The jumping tuna is deep fried and comes with sweet chili sauce. The 49ers is what you would expect. The sexy reminds me of lion king roll. It was tasty but the salmon was a bit dry and overcooked. And for some reason, we were charged extra for 2 rolls. We were charged $12 for jumping tuna and $15.80 for 49ers, when it said $9 and $13.50, respectively, on the menu. Too bad I didn't notice this at the restaurant, so make sure you guys check your bill before paying! Thankfully their beer pints and pitchers were decently priced. We all had about 3 glasses each for $10.50 per person. Yay for inexpensive alcohol!

Food was average, but service and atmosphere were great. Even though it was super crackin' in there, the staff was attentive and efficient. I had a good time!

P.S. Congrats to 49ers on their first win of the season lul
author: Lincy H.

description:
What to get: rainbow roll
Service: 4/5
Atmosphere: busy, casual
Wait: 20 mins (Tuesday 6PM for 3)

The Experience: [December 2016]
I can't say that I'm really versed in Japanese food in the City, but this place seems to pop up a lot when talking about sushi in San Francisco. I spent the day being a tour guide for people from out of the state, so we stumbled upon Ryoko's per chance. It was still around 5:30, but there was already a line. Really, you have to expect that of any place in the City that's popular.

Once you get in, it feels like you've won a small lottery prize! You go downstairs and sit at one of the small tables in this loungey looking place. With a deep house playlist playing, I felt as if I was about to pregame before going to some concert (perhaps another time). Really a vibe that you can't find in other parts of the country. Yes, I was finally home in the Bay.

The menu is pretty basic with not a lot of frills (which I appreciate). I get the rainbow roll since it gets me as much fresh fish as possible in one roll. Sorry I didn't get photos...the company with me didn't want to wait for my foodie tendencies. The quality of the fish was good, substantial. Nothing too unique or unconventional, so I wouldn't call it a gem so much as a solid sushi spot. I don't think it's worth a long wait, but if you happen to get a seat quickly, it's satisfying enough. I did get a photo of our dessert: mochi ice cream. Yum!
author: Ellyse L.

description: Went for dinner on a Friday night! It was pretty crowded as expected. Unfortunately they don't take phone numbers so we waited inside the restaurant about 45 min to get a table. We got soju cocktails and rolls: Alaskan, Alcatraz, spicy tuna. They were very good and worth the wait! Highly recommend checking it out!
author: Theresa H.

description:
Two friends and I gathered in SF for a week and on our very first night in town we were hardcore craving some sushi. There were tons of places to choose from but several were closed on Mondays... but not this one!! We found it quickly on Yelp and it was even in walking distance. Score!

We arrived at the front door and made our way downstairs. It was very lively with fun music on and the place was packed. It had somewhat of a grunge feel to it and I was intrigued. We were lucky enough to grab a table right before a giant group walked in. The table was really small, honestly only big enough for two people but we made it work. It did take some time before a server came over and took our drink order but we were lost in good company so it wasn't too bad. While my friends ordered a sake bomb, I opted for just water and food. I was starving after being on a plane all day long and I was ready to chow down.  We eventually ordered a variety of different rolls as well as a tempura appetizer. After waiting a good bit for our food to arrive, we dove right in, eating every bite of food on the table. Like I mentioned before, we were all hungry af! I feel like we should have ordered more though. For spending about $30 on sushi alone (remember I didn't get a drink) and not feeling full, I was a little bummed. 

Overall, this spot was just ok. The service was slow and the food was average so I'm not 100% sold on visiting again on my next trip to SF. I suppose it worked for my friends and I at the time and that's all that matters. As long as your expectations are set accurately, by all means, give it a try.
author: Jayme H.

description:
Mediocre experience for me, given the lineups -- perhaps I was expecting more. Came here on a Saturday night around 9PM and was still faced with a fairly long wait. Ordered a couple rolls and a chicken karage and was served food similar to AYCE quality in Toronto. So it wasn't bad, just wasn't as good as I expected. 

Fantastic vibes with good music and energetic crowd.
author: Lester C.

description: Sushi is BOMB here!  Best part is prices are pretty good too.  We just ordered a bunch of nigiri (toro, negitoro, uni, ikura, salmon, scallop), a Natto Roll and a veggie roll.  Good amount for two people, and the bill came out to just above $100 with tax.  The sushi quality is amazing but apparently there is always a wait.  We went for dinner on Labor Day and we waited about 45 min.  You sign in on the clipboard at the bottom of the stairs hanging on the host stand.  People like to sit on the staircase while they wait (I don't blame them, it's bloody freezing outside).  They had a DJ spinning some awesome throwback music which took us back to the 90's and made dinner that much better! We will definitely make this place a priority when we're back in SF!
author: Shawn U.

description:
I can describe this place in two words. Porta Potty. As far as sushi places go, I'm surprised this place is still open. Probably because the people in San Fran have no choice but to get used to the abominable service and the atrocious conditions this place and the city presents. 

First i had to put my own name on the waiting list because their hostess is all over the place. Lack or organizational skill is rampant in this establishment. Then, my date and i were sat in a table that had no suitable chair, just a rinky dink stool that looked like it was brought out from the bathroom. To add insult to injury, our table was next to the restroom which smelled like a porta potty was shoved in there and left open for all to smell. 

I decided to request for a better chair and the waitress told me "no" with a lazy, snobby attitude. I was glad someone stepped in and told her yes to get me something better. I should not have to wait to get into a debate before i get such a simple request taken cared of. In the end, i decide to switch tables. And continued to give them a shot. To my disbelieve, it only got worse, by my standards. I think this place has an unbelievable lack of standards. 

I have had sushi across the country and across the world when i travel. They don't stand a chance next to any place I've been to. The food was mediocre at best. The shrimp and bacon was oily, unnecessary and looked more like an experiment than a well thought out appetizer. The sushi rolls were ok at best, definitely not worth paying what they charge. I rather pay more for quality. The nigori that was brought out was weak at best, so many nigori options to choose from and they went with that. I recommend they change that menu option. There are better in the world.

The customer service was atrocious,  the servers looked like they were running all over the place like chickens with their heads cut off. 

The interior design was non-existent, the bright worn out blue on the walls looked like it was hidden under layers of wall paper before it was exposed, so you see what looks like tape getting torn off the walls. If that was meant for a design, they need to hire a new designer. The place looked messy and cluttered, smelled messy and cluttered too. The materials that make up the interior design look worn and torn. They should reinvest into this place an get abetter interior designer. 

I don't plan on stepping foot in this place again. Looks like the city that surrounds it. Messy, dirty and unorganized.
author: Angel R.

description: It's been several years since I last ate here and they just keep getting better!!!   The food and the vibe is phenomenal!
author: Blake B.

description:
So fresh and delicious!   Dark ambience, live music great food, friendly and efficient service! Eclectic clientele , but young and hip! What more could you ask for?   Had to put names on wailing list.  Waited about ten minutes but was able to put in drink order and was seated before drinks were even served!  
Had some vegetarian options like seared shishito  peppers, grilled shiitake--both tasty and fresh!   On to fresh sashimi--toro and uni--both tender and tasty.  Lastly , waygu beef and jumping tuna and tiger rolls.  Totally perfect!  Great food, great atmosphere, great evening all the way around!
author: Carolyn W.

description: The best kept secret in the TL. It's underground, authentic, fresh, and delicious. It's diveyness is it's charm: dark and intimate with pictures of music legends all over the walls. Find yourself here late night for some glorious bites. Try something more unusual, not at all touristy, really good food. Indulge in harder to find dishes like Tako Wasabi and Monk Fish livers. Love Ryoko's.
author: Dexter H.

description:
Such a strange little place to get sushi. We were out in sf one weekend and hungry. It was late. We had just flown in and this appeared on yelp. When we got to the location, we saw what looked like a funny little dive bar. Dive bar? Dimly lit sushi bar? Strange little tightly packed sushi serving nightclub with a DJ in a corner? Or a mix of all the above?

I see the bad reviews. I get it. There's a wait. It's weird. It's not cheap. Sometimes they're slow. I feel like it's run by some sort of asian mob boss lady. But honestly, we thought the sashimi was fantastic. Funny thing is the miso soup left much to be desired. I think we had some other items as well... Some tempura. I don't know what. But we loved the sashimi and nigiri. I thought their fish was quality stuff. The mackerel especially. And for that, we have returned more than a few times and will continue to do so.
author: Emily R.

description: Excellent hole in the wall Japanese food. Fresh and organic fish and ingredients. This has been my go to place for the last 15 years. Line is usually long but it is worth the wait. Staff is friendly. This is definitely one of the top sushi spots in the Bay Area. I'd recommend the volcano roll!!!!!!!!
author: Jimmy T.

description:
The sushi here is absolutely the best sushi I've ever had. The California roll is very cheap and very very good. Every time I have the California roll it reminds me of why I love this place. My gf and I come back for all the fresh rolls but every time we're here we have to get 3 California rolls and 2 other rolls with a few cocktails to make the night perfect. 

Recommendations is to come before 7-8pm so that you get sat within 10 minutes. Anytime after that you're going to wait around 45 minutes. 

Absolutely recommend it!
author: Paulo F.

description:
By no means am I a sushi connoisseur, but I can definitely tell when a sushi bar is lacking in quality. 

I have no idea how Ryoko's has more than 3 stars. I should've read some of the reviews instead of basing my dinner choice on their pictures.

Ryoko's is located downstairs--there is no wait area so everyone is waiting along the stairwell. It's packed, stuffy, and loud. Men's bathroom is downstairs and the women's is upstairs. I found it super tough to even get near the stairwell because there was no where to walk.

The wait was about 45 minutes for a party of 6 on a Saturday night. 

Right off the bat, their menu is comprised of 90% rolls. The only crab they offer is imitation. Basically all of their rolls are imitation CA rolls topped with a few slivers of fish. Portions here were also on the tiny side. 

I ordered the teriyaki chicken (appetizer) + a side of rice, along with the fried CA roll--both were very standard and average.

Our server was friendly throughout the night and was more than accommodating when we asked to split the bill three ways. Only complaint about service is that one of our dishes took forever to come out and it was a simple roll, not a dish from the kitchen.

Overall, 1.5 stars - cheap quality for a high price tag.
author: Shirley H.

description:
After grabbing some drinks with some friends nearby at Redford,  we all got a little hungry, so I decided to check Yelp and see what was nearby.  Fortunately, within walking distance was Ryoko, which was open until 2am on a Saturday night!!  We arrived just after 12:30am, but Ryoko was littttt.  There were a few empty tables, so we were luckily seated immediately.  Compared to my friends, I was pretty famished, so I opted for the chirashi bowl, but between my friends, they got a a variety of rolls.  Overall, the fish quality was pretty darn good, and the service was pretty fast and good considering how crowded the place was.  My chirashi bowl was a nice portion, and filled me up quite well.  Considering it's San Francisco, all the prices were also extremely reasonable.  

The ambience of Ryoko is still fairly intimate even though some tables are a bit close together, but the music in the background was bopping and helps to drown out voices from other tables, so you can still have your conversations without worrying about eavesdropping.  One of my friends freaking loved Ryoko and said she would take her next date there for dinner haha.  I am not sure if I would come here for a normal night's dinner, but for a delicious late night bite, especially after some drinks, I would totally recommend Ryoko's!!  The beef tataki and sashimi dinner really piqued my interest, so I would love to have a try of those.
author: Brendan D.

description:
Monday night in here felt like a weekend, had a great time. We really felt like we were in a happening spot with the live Dj and crowd.
This place has some very unique rolls that I've never seen before, such as the volcano roll that includes shrimp, jalapeño and peanut butter amongst other creations. 
This is a must try.
author: Ty T.

description: Wow  this place is a gem from the food  sushi  super fresh, salad  on point and service great! We will be back deff. And the fact that they are open late is also a huge plus!!!
author: Angiel S.

description:
Fun atmosphere. Sushi was stood but I wouldn't say the BEST. 
Service was great. Definitely order off the specials menu
author: Catherine B.

description:
This is one of my favorite sushi restaurants in San Francisco. It is in a basement and it does not have the prettiest decor, but the food is incredible and the service is above expectation in every way!

I decided to go to Ryoko's during my business trip. I know there is always a line at Ryoko's, but I  figured it would be easier to get a seat for one person.  It was a Tuesday night and there was a pretty good line of people when I got there around 7:30pm. Luckily, the line moved pretty quick. I think it is fantastic that I can order and drink beer while waiting.  Since I was by myself, I was seated at the sushi bar within 20 minutes.  While I was waiting, the hostess kept us informed of the wait time. Even though she was so busy running around trying to manage the seating situation, she was always pleasant and helpful (I don't know how she does it...)

For dinner, I ordered (Santa Barbara) uni, tuna tataki, ikura, ama-ebi, chu toro and hamachi toro. Uni was delicious as usual, sweet and creamy. Tuna tataki was seared and seasoned to perfection; just the right amount of shredded onions and sunflower sprouts in a bed of ponzu sauce. Ama-ebi was sweet and plump; the shrimp heads were deep fried and seasoned with the right amount of sea salt. Ikura nigiri was fantastic; the eggs were salted just right and the ratio of Ikura to rice was perfection. Chu toro simply melted in my mouth; it was heavenly. While I was enjoying my chu toro, the waitress regrettably informed me that hamachi toro were sold out for the night.  I was disappointed, but fortunately, I was distracted by how good the food was; I got over it pretty quickly!

Ryoko's did not disappoint. This will continue to be one of my favorite spots every time I am in town!
author: Catt A.

description:
Tldr - interesting unique sushi with a party atmosphere. This ain't low key or simple

Came here for some late night grub after partaking in some activities with the fellas back at the crib. 

The place's atmosphere reminded me of chubby noodle - nice EDM and hip hop playing with a live hype DJ overlooking the party. Pretty chill place to hang out and it's a great atmosphere for having some sake bombs or beers with food before going elsewhere.

Food itself was cool. There were tons of choices, it was pretty hard to choose. One buddy guy was vegetarian and he had more options than any other sushi place I seen before. 

Casual atmosphere. There was one couple there on a hella nice date like that dude was wearing a button up shirt and vest and all. They looked a bit out of place compared to erryone else.

Mochi ice cream yummy and like cut in to serving portions for sharing! But eat fast bc it'll melt.
author: Samraaj B.

description: When they served the nigiri, I was speechless. The portions were so small and the fish was not high quality enough to justify the price. I can't believe they call them-self a Japanese restaurant. What a disappointment.
author: Kevin C.

description: Crazy how people rave about this place. Loud music, smelly, and small rolls. Each roll is 5 pieces. My husband and I had to order 7 rolls to get semi full. I'm writing this review right now from another restaurant cause we need more food otherwise I'll get hangry later tonight. We had to yell at each other to be heard. Took almost 30 min for our second order and almost 20 min to get our check. I would think they'd want to serve us faster and give us our bill quickly when we ask to get faster turn around. There's so many people working, it's like a zoo. The place is decent with mediocre sushi. I'd recommend ordering to go and eating in the quiet of your room...or blast your favorite music for the loud music, open your trash can for the smell, and force yourself to wait 5 min between each piece to recreate the ambience!
author: Sharon C.

description:
Very disappointed for this meal.

3 stars for the environment (crowed and loud)
3 stars for the food ( just Ok, fresh but not worth the price)
4 stars for the services 

I just met my friend nearby，2000+ reviews with 4 stars and the good price ($$) made us toward here.
HOWEVER, it is not a $$ place as we know!!!
This place is really expensive,especially it didn't have any Michelin stars!!
It should be a $$$ or $$$$ place at the reality!!
We just ordered 3 items, it almost cost $100....
$19.99 for 2 pieces of Uni Nigiri. It tasted good,but just OK!! Which was like the one we took in Fremont, and just cost $9.99 for 2 pieces (looks like the same). 

Unagi  bowl (BBQ Eel) is in a small bento box, and it cost $28 before tax. It tasted good， but not worth for this price honestly.

The last one is Chirashi bowl,  it tasted fresh, but there were no premium sashimi  such as  sweet shrimp or uni, I felt so disappointing on it. Even it took $30 before tax, they still cut the sashimi into a little pieces. If you give $30 before tip/tax can get  much better chirashi bowl instead of this one. However, this item should be the best one I ordered tonight.

BTW it was so crowed and loud,  I don't think a traditional Japanese restaurant would like this.
author: Anny L.

description:
You want Japanese sushi? bere is a really good place. there might be a short line that you wait for 20 mins, but it is worth it.
the sushi was great, the  sake was great, the atmosphere was chill.
And the most imp thing is that it is open till mid night, Wow.
I am tired of having only a few late night options like burger or pizza. This solved the prob.
author: Iman B.

description: Definitely an interesting place to see for the first time.  Its on a hill and is actually underground which gives it a very unique feel some love and some dont.   Chef bar seating is usually full as is the rest of the restaurant.  I have seen lines out front a few times.  Sushi is delicious and sake goes down well as well.
author: Lillian D.

description: Fun, lively atmosphere. I sat at the counter. They were very busy, even on a Monday night. Service suffered slightly for this but not bad. Flying Unagi roll was excellent. I also had the seaweed salad, very fresh.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I've walked by Ryoko's countless times, but it wasn't until the hostess at another sushi joint recommended it (the restaurant she was working at was booked solid), that I finally decided to venture in. Upon entrance, it seemed like I was the only person who hadn't been in the know.

At around 6:30 PM on a weekday, the place was packed! To enter, I had to walk down some stairs which already had people waiting on them! Luckily, as a solo diner, I snagged the last seat at the bar with no wait.

That's not to say I didn't have to wait though, as it was quite a while between ordering my sushi and finally eating it. With only three sushi chefs, I'm sure orders get crazy backed up. In fact, I would even hazard that's why the wait is so long, rather than people taking their sweet time eating.

However, the wait (both to sit down and then to actually eat) is more than worth it. I ordered a variety of nigiri: uni from santa barbara, unagi, sake, hotate, and inari. All of them were fresh and the sushi rice beneath them perfectly vinegared.

For bar patrons, there is also a tv if you're sitting facing the wall to watch. This was a definite boon, as being slightly underground made my cell signal disappear.

By the time I left, the line covered my path out up the stairs. People are in the know-- the best bang for your buck in the city is here.
author: Angela C.

description:
No wait at 22:30 on a Monday. +1
Rolls untidy, wasabi a ridiculous smear, on a boring plate. -1
Rice in rolls & nigiri midwest shopping mall shushi-esque. -1
Verdict/Good for: those desperate and without sushi pride.
author: Joseph R.

description: I came here the other night for the first time with my mom and husband, and it was fantastic! The atmosphere is great, staff is super friendly, and food is amazing! The fish was super fresh and despite being initially skeptical the roll with the peanut butter was actually my favorite! The line gets long fast and they don't take reservations so get there early if possible. I will definitely be coming back!
author: Cora C.

description: I happened to drop by here late Friday night after flying in from the OC.  My hotel was walking distance and we were super hungry.  I saw on Yelp that they closed late so it was a bonus for us.  The environment reminded me of a rave since they played loud EDM music LOL Everyone was basically having a good time here! The sushi here was sooooo good. I was shocked that it was THAT delicious.  My friend enjoyed the sashimi and said they tasted fresh.  Overall, if I was visiting SF again, I would definitely come back here for my sushi needs!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
So damn good. Or maybe I was just starving but it was Delightfulllllly delicious. You have to wait
In line for a little and they don't take reservations - you just write your name down on a list. Always busy on the weekends but worth the wait. The employees are quick and the food came out fast.
author: T B.

description:
110 Dollars for one 5 piece roll and two sakes including a demanded 14 dollar tip for one person 
is ridiculous. There are much more reasonably priced places nearby that taste better with faster, friendlier service that are honest. Don't get taken for a ride. I'm pretty sure they just make up prices.
author: Brian L.

description: Has a nice atmosphere... had the fried oysters, rainbow roll, Japanese fried chicken....love the live DJ , he was on point. The service is great and the music loud... I'd definitely revisit...its 3.5 star pushing really..really hard to be a four-star!!!
author: Tony J.

description:
Went to Ryoko's for the first time last night based on raving reviews from friends.
The food was decent. Not a great selection of rolls for someone who doesn't like deep fried or imitation crab in the roll. The fish on the Nigiri was fresh and would have been more enjoyable if I could overcome the smell of the restaurant.
I had trouble overcoming the horrendous smell of urine/feces/chemical toilet cleaner as we sat down. Upon further inspection I noted that the men's restroom was located behind me and the female restroom directly above me on the second floor.
I highly recommend they rip out the carpet and deep clean the restaurant.
author: Venus D.

description:
I hate to be the person that writes bad Yelp reviews, but Yelp really let me down on this place. If you've ever eaten half decent sushi in your life, I'm sure you can agree that this place is highly overrated.

While visiting San Francisco, I was attracted to this place by its 4 star Yelp review and long line, which made this place seem like it was a hidden gem (small hole in the wall from the looks of it).

Reasons why this place was awful: 

Edamame might as well came from the freezer section at the grocery store, cold and flavorless.

The sushi was warm, and the sweet shrimp was mushy. Not to mention the sweet shrimp heads were overly deep fried (think deep fried carnival food). Quality sweet shrimp heads are fried, but not all breading like at this place.

The sushi hand roll was falling apart, mostly rice and with a small amount of cheap fish inside.

Between dinner for two which was very poor quality and parking, it cost about $200. If you still decide to give this place a chance, you'll soon realize that you made a terrible mistake.
author: Melissa W.

description: My absolute favorite sushi spot, and a must stop every time I'm in the city. The vibe is super chill, and it's obvious all the employees love their job. I've ordered damn near every roll and you can't really go wrong. My favorite has always been the sexy roll. Open late but it gets packed so be ready to wait.
author: Andre P.

description:
Absolutely awful and grossly overhyped. I've walked by this place a hundred times and there has always been a wait, so I figured the food must be amazing to justify a wait upwards of an hour. 

A couple weeks ago, I passed by on a random Tuesday evening and there was only one party on the waitlist, so we put our names down and the host noted that it would take about five minutes to seat us. Fifteen minutes later, we were seated (party of two).

As we went through the menu, red flags started popping up all over. There's a signature roll with peanut butter and a LOT of rolls on the menu with imitation crab, mayonnaise, and/or cream cheese. 

We ended up getting agedashi tofu, the tuna yukke, jumping unagi roll, hamachi kama, and one other roll that was so underwhelming that I can't even remember what it was or what was in it. I do remember that we didn't finish it.

So the tuna yukke is described as tuna in spicy sesame oil, garlic, ginger, sea salt sauce with shiso and is served with seaweed. It's served at market price, which we found out was $33 when the waiter took our order. We figured for $33 it must be amazing, so we went ahead and ordered it. IT WAS NOT GOOD. Really not good. Not $33 good, not $3 good. The ingredients don't go well together and it tastes like bland mush. 

The jumping unagi roll is deep fried and it's weirdly carb-y. Now, I love deep fried things, but it wasn't nice and crispy as one would expect. Once you bite into a piece, the rice gets overwhlemingly heavy and it was a bit sickening. I ended up eating the filling and leaving the rice and fried shell. 

Oh also, it took around 40 minutes to get our check. Why.

Kind of glad I went so that any desire to try this place is now long gone, but so disappointed by how terrible it was. Almost wish the wait was long that day so that I would never have had the opportunity to waste time and money on crap food.
author: Kimberly O.

description:
We came around 6pm, just in time to beat the rush. No wait for us and was seated right away. Yay!

For starter, we had some fried oysters along with nigiri and sushi rolls. All were decent, but I wouldn't say it's the best sushi rolls I ever had. The nigiri was alright, but I quite honestly didn't think it was all that fresh. 

Service was quick and fast. This is no high end sushi, but a casual sushi joint for a quick bite. 
If you want better quality sushi and better value, head to South Bay for the experience.
author: Owie N.

description:
I think this place was alright. Aesthetically, this place needs WORK. The blue painted walls makes the place look closed in. The paintings on the wall aren't cohesive. And it's suuuuper crowded. There's a live DJ which I thought was cool. There's no waiting area other than the staircase at the front and outside on the sidewalk. 

I say this place was alright maybe cuhz of what we ordered but  most of the rolls on the menu have the same ingredients with one additional different ingredient. (Check the menu, you'll know what I mean). Most of the rolls are kinda cheap. You can get them $5-$9/per roll. 

For starters, I really liked the fried soft shell crab and the fried oysters. The breading was light and not greasy. It came with two choices of sauce which is a plus. 

We ordered the Caterpillar roll with the cheese and after a while, the cheese hardens so it kinda gets chewy. We also ordered the Checkerboard and Dragon roll. The dragon roll is pretty safe, nothing bizarre if you like sashimi. Idk why anyone orders eel, it's so bony. Now I know not to order that anywhere else.

For a Friday night, it took us an hour to find parking and an hour wait time. So nope; I didn't think it was worth it. On the plus side, the servers are really nice.
author: Janine P.

description:
This is my go to place when friends tell me they like sushi. 

Everything tastes super fresh and they have a full bar. 

Always go for the ankimo if it's on the menu, and the grilled whole squid. 

Only con is that it fills up fast and there is usually a wait. Good thing you can order a drink while you are standing around !
author: Chu W.

description:
Came here on a late Monday night with a group of friends looking for a bite to eat. This place was crowded for a late Monday night so we thought we'd give it a try. Bad mistake.

Ok, I get it. Sushi, especially in SF, can be pricey...but even then I thought this place was just way too overpriced. The quality of the sushi wasn't even that much better than what I'd get at an ayce sushi place. They also have a dj, which is kinda cool I guess, but this place BLASTS their music. I thought it was funny to see so many couples on dates but it was so hard to hear what anyone was saying. We even had bit of a hard time ordering because we had trouble hearing and understanding our server.  

Overall, service and ambiance was meh. Food was eh. And the bill will make your wallet cry.
author: Kimsa N.

description:
Picture a basement sushi bar mixed with a dance club - including DJ, lights, and loud club music. Very interesting vibe.

Sushi was ok, but really not worth coming back. The peanut butter roll is worth a shot, but all you taste is (surprise) peanut butter. Spicy yellowtail was pretty good. The otoro nigiri came with 3 pieces for a non-modest $18.50 and must have been frozen/defrosted 3-4 times because it was pretty gross. They have cheap-ish pitchers of beer for $17.
author: Billy D.

description:
Ridiculous !

The price is not same as menu. ( Not the items states price adjustable as different season)


Never been in the restaurant like that.

Watch out the price.
author: Wen L.

description:
It's like eating sushi in a wet bar blending traditional Japanese chef shouting and loud music by a real DJ, very distinctive, only in US. Food quality is ok, not as delicate as in Japan/Asia but fancy and qualified.

https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mydKjdG8gJOcRQ9cZwkQpQ?select=Zxhw5egXqSHSce3PMIOLZw&utm_source=oshare&utm_content=photo
author: Chris P.

description: The sushi here was actually very good, but it is not worth the wait and the money. The restaurant atmosphere was fine with me, but if you're with older people, they won't enjoy it; the restaurant is dark and you will have to sit very close with other people. There's also rap and hip hop music playing loudly so it's hard to talk and engage in conversation. The restaurant was packed and again the sushi was veryyy good, but the atmosphere was not for me. Also, the service was pretty awful and you will probably have to wait awhile for the check & your drinks will probably not be refilled. I would suggest going at an early time or going when you have a lot of time to spare
author: Marigny L.

description:
The service was fairly slow here, but the concept was cool. I loved the underground sushi experience and was very impressed with the fish straight from Japan. Had I thought about it better, I would have ordered sashimi. Oh well..

My roll choices were eh. The hot tuna was tasty but only 5 pieces. The Pokémon roll was fresh, but way too much rice. I did like my house salad though, and the dressing was excellent. Lots of veggies in that dish. 

I think I would've enjoyed the food here if I had picked better options. Sad because I love fresh fish and sushi, so I'm kind of beating myself up about it.
author: Clara S.

description:
Always ha e been a fan of this place. In the heart of the Tenderloin it has always been my favorite sushi spot in the city.

Lively crowd, great food & drink with DJ mixing can't got wrong. Plus open till 2:00. That really has kept me coming back here over 17 years....
author: Dennis I.

description:
This place is like a 2.4/5. It's overpriced. $40 for sushi/sashimi dinners for some of the most basic provisions of fish. Two of the nine pieces of the sushi dinner was the same lean cut of maguro tuna - one of the most underwhelming things ever. If I had to price the fish that was served in both sushi and sashimi plates, the total should not have come out to more than $20 - seriously some of the most inflated prices I've ever had to eat. 

I've traveled across the country and borders to taste some good quality, freshly served sushi and sashimi and I've got to say Ryoko has just not provided the experience that the current ratings reflect. Ended up paying a little over $100 with tip and tax and I felt slightly ripped off and disappointed. 

Some of the reviews here claim it is good value -- I say, if you are willing to 
drop at least $40 for a plate of sushi here, you should take that money and go elsewhere to get a better bang for your buck. 

I've got to say that the only thing that possibly redeems this place is the tamago and good service. Good tamago nigiri and very warm, friendly, and attentive staff.
author: David Y.

description:
Get here early and be ok with loud. This place is popping. Long wait always. We came in at opening and four of us seated right away. Don't forget to check the daily special board. 
Because of the loud atmosphere it's highly likely the table next to you will be even louder be prepared. And please there is no need to be the loudest white person in the room
   Fish is on point. Service is fast, and servers responsive. Sake selection is vast. Can be pricey so make sure you understand what market price is if you are easily sticker shocked. My personal preference is for a quieter omakase style meal as d it's a similar price range. But ryokos does not dissapoint. Loud but uniquely Japanese sushi experience. A must try.
author: Dan W.

description:
Walking down into the dark, dungeon-like basement that is Ryoko's, you'd never expect to find good food in such a dingy, sketchy atmosphere. And yet, the place was packed when we came for dinner on a Saturday. This restaurant only offers small plates and sushi rolls/nigiri, but their takes on these dishes are slightly unusual and worth a try!

My group started with the Japanese octopus over seaweed salad and the chicken karaage small plates. The karaage was surprisingly good--I'm usually not the biggest fan of fried chicken, but the large chunks of chicken were surprisingly juicy, tender, and flavorful! We also had the grilled saba (mackerel), and you can't really go wrong with that. 

Then we shared a bunch of rolls--the pokemon roll was wrapped in soy paper instead of seaweed and came with plenty of fresh fish. The dragon roll was wrapped in unagi and avocado, the 49er was topped with bluefin tuna/salmon, and the jumping tuna was a delicious and creative deep-fried roll stuffed with spicy tuna and served with a sweet/spicy sauce on the side. Nice! The only disappointing roll I had was the spicy scallop, from which I got a strong hit of soy sauce/salt. Other than that, all of these rolls were creative, tasty, and delicious!

While pricey, the food at Ryoko's is worth a try, though don't expect much from the dingy atmosphere. Just go to enjoy the small plates, sushi, and drinks, if you're so inclined!
author: David K.

description: This place appears to be the perfect restaurant for Millennials; for those who rank restaurants based on image rather than substance. Overall this place is awful. Mediocre sushi presented in lackluster fashion in an overcrowded, cramped space with blaring music honestly doesn't equate to a good dining experience. Throw in disorganized service and tables that seem "sticky" and you end up wishing you had gone to McDonald's for a Filet of Fish instead. The sushi rolls we ordered were either so salty they were bitter; or so bland they tasted watery. You can't speak in a normal tone of voice here; you either scream at each other or you aren't heard. This has to be one of the most irritating dining experiences.  Like going to Chuck E Cheese's with an extremely overpriced menu. This place isn't pleasant, safe or accommodating.
author: Jim J.

description:
Stopped by after a show at the Masonic for two reasons: my boyfriend was craving sushi, and this was the first restaurant that popped up when I searched for food "open now" (after 10pm) 

Glad we came! Cool ambiance and delicious, fresh sushi. Usually I'm not even a fan of California rolls but they used shredded crab which made it tastier and more appealing. 

Drinks are strong! Beware ;-)
author: Sandra D.

description:
We came here while we're staying in SF. We both like sushi and we found Ryoko's. It was a very long waiting line. We had to wait for 45 minutes. We came there around 9pm. 
The bouncer was a very lovely man. While we were talking, time was flying.
After 45 min we finally got in. We ordered different sushis. They tasted very good. But in Belgium, more specific Antwerp, the sushi is maybe better :) 
The music was very loud. So talking with my bf wasn't practical. Although we really enjoyed the eating. The waitresses were very nice and super fast. Sometimes it looked like they were running :) ! We were glad we came here, it was a nice experience.
author: Evelien G.

description: We had an amazing dinner me and my boyfriend here! We ordered about 5 different rolls and their beef appetizer. Everything was SO GOOD. The only rolls we remember names of are the jumping unagi the dragon and the pokemon or pikachu? We also had a special roll off the menu and another one which we do not remember the named of. All were amazing. And I love their green tea and how they go around tables to refill it. I probably had like 3 cups of it. Loved it!
author: Vic K.

description:
Intimate if you are with a group.  Social if you are alone.  The best of both worlds.  Ryoko's is kind of a hole in the wall place, you walk in and put your name on the list if it's busy.

Lots of selection including sushi rolls, Nigiri, Sashimi, and fresh catch prepared as you like.  They also have teriyaki steak and great sake, hot or cold.  Not really good at sake bombs though, wrong kind of glasses.

Last time I went in I got their Pokemon roll and some Nigiri fresh catch, with a 22 oz Ichiban.  Then I got the teriyaki steak - it was enough for two.  Price is pretty reasonable for such great food.
author: Keith S.

description:
Great sushi bar! I've been here twice. Came back for the peanut butter shrimp jalapeño roll (Volcano Roll), it's the best!!! This visit I also had the Sexy Roll and the Big Mama. 

Small restaurant, I would keep your party smaller if you go. Love the DJ on site!
author: Courtney E.

description: What do you get when you mix fresh fish from Japan, sake and Biggie Smalls?  This place!!  Fresh beats...fresh fish... what else can a girl ask for???
author: Melissa T.

description:
Hmmm, the price per roll is about 10% less than other places, but the size of the roll is 40% less. Do the math, and it does not make sense.

Volcano roll was interesting - I liked the peanut butter. If it weren't for only 5 very thinly cut pieces, I'd order it again. 

Pokémon roll, per other reviews, was bland. Would skip. 


We were probably the best customers - ate the 2 rolls and left, within 20min, quickest turnaround.

There was a long line after we left around 7:15pm on a Saturday. Definitely not worth waiting for. 

I'd rather spend more for quality nigiri at nicer real Japanese places, or less for specialty rolls (or at least get larger portions).
author: Cynthia X.

description:
I would have never noticed this place nor found it if not for my friend's recommendation and literal guidance. It's a very dive-y basement sushi restaurant downtown--completely unassuming from the outside but super popular and packed inside.

I came with three friends for an earlyish Tuesday dinner (right around 6). We lucked out and were able to get seated right away in the back room--super cool room with a big table, benches, and mirror wall. We could see the line outside building soon after we had arrived.

We ordered a variety of different rolls--some fried ones ("jumping rolls") and some fresh ones. They were all pretty good but none of them really stood out to me. The jumping unagi roll (deep fried unagi roll) and spicy scallop roll were both tasty. I was actually pleasantly surprised at how big the scallop was in the scallop roll. I also ordered the amaebi (sweet shrimp nigiri + fried shrimp heads), which was okay here. It was fresh, but not as big or sweet as others I've had before at the same price point.

Service was good! They checked on us often, even though we were in the back room. It's nice to not be forgotten :)

Solid 4 stars for Ryoko's! The sushi and sashimi aren't *amazing* but it's good, and the restaurant is a very cool, hip place that's incredibly close to Union Square--worth at least one visit!
author: Leanne C.

description:
This is literally as good as it gets!! Me and a friend came here at 5:55 on a Saturday and there were already people waiting in line tryna get in. The restaurant is in a basement, it smells a tad weird and has loud club music playing, but that's the only thing that I have to complain about. The food, on the other hand, was a dream and anything I coulda asked for after a long day. Between me and 2 other friends, we got a carafe of sake (it was really smooth and kinda sweet - I totally forgot the name of it but it was $18 and reallllyyyy good!). The prices were actually kinda expensive - it was 6 pieces for $9? But literally every penny spent was worth it. We got the jumping california and the jumping unagi - I think the jumping part means the outside isn't just rice but is fried. It was literally cooked at the perfect temp where the inside of the sushi was warm but not mushy. 

My favvvvv part of the meal was their deep fried oyster! I'm not normally a fan of oyster, but holy shit.. this was soooooo amazingly creamy and everything just melted together. Truly one of the small peaks of my life. Would totally get it again. We also got the hamatchi, spicy golden gate and mackerel. Nothing notable to report on but honestly just really good.
author: Ashley S.

description:
There are lots of kinds of foods. We ate sushi like Nigiri and Maki and they were very flesh and delicious even though Im from Japan. Besides it, I love its miso soup. You should try if you want.

However, it is basically a bit expensive, nigiri is about 4-6 dollars and maki is about 6-9dollars.
author: Yuto Y.

description: Staff was very friendly. Restaurant itself is pretty beat up and dirty feeing. Could use a renovation. Loud techno playing the whole time. A bit aggressive for 6pm! Sushi itself was ok. 3 stars at best.
author: B B.

description: By far one of the BEST SUSHI place I've been too. Who would of thought this hidden gem was in this small basement, The quality of food is exceptional...This place is nothing fancy but boy how I love their Fresh, tasty, delicate mix varieties of sushi. I think I may of ordered way to many UNAGI but hey who's complaining! Make reservation or come early because you will have a long wait time. Which we learned that the hard way.. The atmosphere is awesome so yes its worth the wait!
author: zeenat s.

description:
Whenever I pass by here there always seems to be a long line but the experience was lackluster. 

The food was pricey and was in very small portions. Nothing really stood out. Service was good but we will not be coming back.
author: Es H.

description: The fish here is so fresh, it melts in your mouth like butter. When I come out to visit the coast, I want to make sure that this is how experience fish when I get sushi or sashimi, because living inland you just don't get this kind of experience. My friend and I were lucky there happened to be two spots open at the bar, and right after we sat it seemed like a crowd packed in. The restaurant is down a level from the street, and it's dark, yet bustling and energetic inside. We ordered a few sashimi and some sushi rolls. We had the mackerel and some smoked salmon sashimi, and I can't recommend the smoked salmon more. Make sure everyone you're with gets a chance to try it. We ordered the Sakepper, Jumping California, 49er, Checkerboard, and Rainbow rolls. The rice is very fresh, the flavors were great, and as I said before, the fish falls apart in your mouth. The rainbow roll is probably my favorite, but it was also one of the most expensive. There are plenty of rolls to choose from if that's the route you want to go, and there are cheaper rolls, and more expensive ones. if I get the chance, I'll definitely be coming back to try more. Probably some of the best sushi I've had during one of my many visits to San Francisco.
author: Haven W.

description: Fabulous sushi bar. Very fresh food and comes out quickly. The service was not great could be better. Gets busy very quickly so get there early for dinner. The fish melts in your mouth great quality!
author: Yael G.

description:
Update: After coming back here a couple more times, the sushi prices really can't be beaten. This place is an incredible deal! That being said, I'm never really blown away by the sushi. It's good, to be sure, but I haven't had a particularly eye-opening experience quite yet. 

The Ika Maruyaki (grilled squid) appetizer is incredible though, and is a must get when we visit. The flavor and texture is perfect and the presentation is beautiful. I love it!

I may end up coming back here when we have larger parties or want quick service and cheap sushi, but Sanraku is very close by and offers better sushi, in my opinion.
author: John B.

description: Went late on a Tuesday night. No line when we came in but there was one when we left around 1130. Sat at the sushi bar. Service was fast. Food was delicious. Fish is really fresh. There is a DJ so it is a little loud and crowded. But not in a bad way. It is an upbeat atmosphere. We got a few rolls and sashimi. Everything was so good. We would definitely be back.
author: Adrianna S.

description: Ryoko's is one of my favorite Sushi restaurants in SF. I've been to it multiple times. Knowing there's always a long line (expect at least 30-45min wait on weekend nights), I usually go when it opens at 6pm. They have a good collection of sake, comes in a bottle. Draft Sapporo glass for $4.50 is a plus. It's pretty dark inside other than the counter seatings. I usually sit at the chef's counter just so I can order quickly and interact with chefs. Nigiri are fresh- comes with good amount of rice, price can range from $4.50- $22.00 for seasonal or toro's. My favorites are: salmon toro takaki, hamachi toro, and otoro roll. Everything else is good too- rolls, nigiris and sashimi dinner plater. Agedashi tofu and miso soup are just basic, good for starter. This place is busy so getting the waitress/waiter to refill your drink or extra order may require some patience but it's definitely worth your wait in line!
author: Adel A.

description:
Sometimes I get those days where I leave work and think, I'm just going to treat myself to a nice dinner. Well, the other day was just that. After passing Union Square on my way home, I decided to take a different route and find a place I've never been too, eventually stumbling into Ryoko's.

Irasshaimase! That's the welcome greeting you hear as you open the door. Everyone in the restaurants yells it from the top of their lungs as you walk down the stairs into their main restaurant area. There's a small host stand with someone waiting, lots of table seating and sushi bar seating. I think there's also upstairs seating as I saw a staircase but at 6pm, no one in the restaurant so everyone was sat in the bottom area. I think overall, the staff is super efficient and cordial. One thing that got a little annoying was irasshaimase chant. It was for everyone, and I get that, however they yell it loud and if you're at the sushi bar, it's piercing. There were 3 sushi chefs in a small sushi bar area so sound traveled a ton. 

The menu was not overwhelming at all. It's mostly sushi. You'll have a specials board and some appetizers but what you wont find is a dinner menu filled with items such as rice bowls (except for chiraishi and similar). I like that. Focus on a few things and perfect what you have. On the specials menu, they offer the expensive fish. Mostly from Japan. My server Patty was hardcore with trying to upsell the specials. She almost didn't give me an option on the type of fish. For instance, I asked her for salmon nigiri from the menu. She instead suggested the Toki Salmon toro on the specials menu for almost doubled the price but said it in a way that really wasn't an option. "Ok sake toro is ok, yeah?" I had to stick to my guns and say no and that I'll just take the sake on the menu. It happened a couple of times; laughable but still a little too much. Speaking of food here's what I got: 

-Kai Miso Soup for $4.50. I started with this winner: you average miso soup with clams! I've had a similar dish at another restaurant and loved the element of clams, so this was great. 

-Sake (Salmon) nigiri for $6.00 and order (2 pieces to an order). I highly recommend just getting this salmon as opposed to the specials for $12.80 an order. This sake was buttery, melting in my mouth and didn't come with an overbearing fish flavor. I got 4 orders of this so 8 pieces later, I was treated to a great meal! Loved it. I also love that they shave their own wasabi! It was a great element and really made a difference

-Chu Toro (Fatty Tuna) nigiri for $16.80 an order. So this was one I didn't want to skimp on. I love fatty tuna. When I got the nigiri, it didn't look like other toro nigiris I've received. It was darker in color but OH-EM-GEE, it tasted exactly like a great Toro! This was buttery than the sake. I love how the sushi chefs really highlight the fish and not overpower the dish with lots of rice, just enough to enhance. HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

-Salmon skin roll for $7.00. Grilled salmon skin, shiso peppers, cucumber, burdock root and flying fish roe served with bonito flakes and mayo. It came with 5 pieces and it was good. At first, looked like your average maki sushi, the elements were there and worked well together. Not the biggest stand out but good overall.

What a great treat. I didn't feel overly full afterwards. I was content with the fresh fish and great flavors every bite offered. Ryoko's will definitely happen again for me! Go check them out.
author: Rockne H.

description:
Get here early if you want to eat here. After 6:30-7PM, the line is INSANELY long. It's under the basement, they play club-like music, the lights and mirror details and decorations make it a really nice ambience, with a mixture of divey-ness. 

Our group of 5 ordered 8 rolls, and we probably each had 9-10 pieces each. We got the jumping tuna, sunrise, dragon, big mama, scallop, and the pokemon rolls. We got the sunrise one twice, because it was just THAT good. I was a huge fan of the jumping tuna, sunrise, and dragon roll.
