Big scallop and big mama was alright, but pokemon was a strange one, and our group didn't like it. The sweetness of the mango was nice, but the cabbage really threw us off.

Overall, you can taste the quality and freshness of the fish. After each piece, we all savored the taste and each one of us said "wow... that was really, really good". That's how great this place is. We topped the meal off with mochi ice cream, which was really delicious. Highly recommend the mango flavor, it was sweet and refreshing. The skin of the mochi is also quite thick, so you get extra chewy goodness. 

Would come back and retry my favorites, and try other appealing rolls!
author: Ke C.

description:
I am not sure what to think about this place!!!
It has great reviews long lines, but the two times I have been here it has not delivered.

Place is a bit too loud to have a conversation with your party.

Sushi is served soggy and warm...both times I have been here it has been the same. 

With so many places to eat sushi and I not sure if this lives up to the hype of four stars.

Host and waitress are friendly, but its the food that really matters.
author: Alex M.

description: This place was just fine. We had some good, fresh sushi.  In a city full of great places to eat, it's a solid 3 stars...maybe a half star extra for the DJ!  We did wait for a table but service was good and offered drinks while we waited.  Their fish specials from Japan were good.
author: Michele B.

description:
Overrated! Expensive 
Went on a Friday night and it was packed
Not because of the fish but the fun atmosphere... YA I'll give it that! Young people, DJ spinning music... cool looking 
But the fish was mediocre- actually LOW QUALITY FARMED FISH!!! I would trade the atmosphere for better fish any day! 
Go to NEW NANGAMO SUSHI ON GEARY IF U WANT GOOD SUSHI!!!!
author: Roxy L.

description:
low key - semi hole in the wall establishment with some legit sushi, jamming music and friendly staff.  what more does one want from a sushi restaurant?

this place was recommended by a local bartender who said "if you just want legit sushi with actual Japanese guys behind the counter - this is the spot to go."  And disappointed we were not!  Upon entering the place walking down the stairs, there was Bob Marley jamming over the speakers.  The place was small and quaint but every table had folks sitting, eating, talking, laughing.  We were quickly greeted by the entire restaurant staff as we made our way to the bottom steps waiting to be seated.

Once we sat - our waitress greeting us with a huge smile and the shenanigans began.  We had everything from Otoro sashimi, to full on sashimi platters, chirashi bowls and a few hand rolls.  Not one thing was bad on the menu, everything was fresh and big cuts of fish - everything was devoured within 20 minutes and then came the rounds of sake bombs and beer, long island ice teas and mojitos.  I do wish they didn't only have 15 tracks on repeat throughout the night and the sushi itself is far from "cheap eats."

$600 later we had full bellies and tears rolling down our faces from laughing so hard we reluctantly left to find more things to enjoy only to realize that was the best night in town.  We will definitely come back next time we are in SF!
author: Nam N.

description:
I honestly don't understand why this place has so many reviews with such a high rating. Yes I get that this place has a great ambiance. This place has such an authentic, urban vibe to it. It's busy, it's loud, it has it's own DJ. It has that whole party scene going for it, but the food is extremely bland compared to it's lively setting.

My boyfriend and I got the the sake and eel nigiri to start off with. Honestly the only thing that stood out was the cut of the salmon. It was really fatty so there was a lot of taste to it. However, the rolls were the biggest disappointment of our meal. We got the Pokemon, 49ers, Spicy Golden Gate, and Dragon rolls. Do NOT get the Pokemon roll. You pay $10+ for four pieces of loosely rolled rice balls. Out of all the rolls the dragon roll was the best, but it wasn't amazing. I felt like I was eating sushi from Safeway.

Going to this place was extremely anticlimactic and you can DEFINITELY find somewhere cheaper, better, and less crowded than Ryoko's.
author: Janis G.

description:
"No one's ever ordered that much mochi before."

A direct quote from one of our visits to Ryoko's. In fairness, we didn't realise that each order of mochi would be more than plenty to share, so (in a group of 8) we ordered 16 mochi, thinking that it'd be 2 pieces each. It was more like 64... Oops. It was worth it.

On to the sushi: I've loved everything I've tried there, with the exception of the "sexy roll". They must have been playing the irony game naming that one. (It's got melted American cheese on it. It comes on tin foil?! Nightmare.) Ignoring that, highlights include Orange Delight, Hot Tuna, and Kentucky for me. Seriously though, it's all fantastic.

Love the staff--they work tirelessly and patiently, especially when you get the odd tetchy grump who feels they're entitled to a seat because got fatigued by the wait. (Don't queue when you're hangry, folks. Or bring a snack bar.) 

Lastly, I'm in love with the DJ. Yep--they have an in-house DJ. Any resto playing '90s dance remixes to eat your dinner to is a winner in my books.
author: Rowena H.

description: Some of the best sushi I've ever had. Definitely a hole in the wall kinda place, but didn't smell weird and had a cool vibe on the inside (modern music set to edm). Service was also very average. We started with the tempura which was very good, but only two shrimp and vegetables, all lightly fried and super crispy! We then had 2 orders of the salmon nigiri (melt in your mouth), yellow tail nigiri, red tuna roll, salmon skin roll, yellow tail roll, and the dragon roll. Everything was amazing! My personal favorite was the salmon skin roll, chalked full of flavor. My boyfriend preferred the dragon roll because the eel was so tasty. HOWEVER, make sure you get here early. We got here at 5:45 and were waiting outside as the line formed. After we were seated, the line was almost out the door, it was crazy, but honestly worth the wait.
author: Natalie G.

description:
This place definitely isn't the typical, quaint, Japanese restaurant in SF, so if you're looking for a quiet place, I don't think this is the place to go. BUT if you're looking for a place w/ a fun time and some GREAT sushi, then this is the place to go! The reason my family and I were able to get a spot was b/c we got there right before it opened, and thankfully the line wasn't too long, so we were able to be seated within 10-15 minutes. 

There's a small private parking lot next to the restaurant, but you have to pay about $20 for valet parking. There's also street parking available, but if you're not used to parking on hills or driving in SF in general, then I would just bite the bullet and do the valet. 

Let's talk about the food now. The choices are countless! Since there were 5 of us eating, we just ordered a bunch of rolls, some sake, and split accordingly. 

They sell fried shrimp heads! a rule of thumb from my dad -- you know a sushi place is pretty legit if they sell that here (i'm not sure what the japanese word for it is, but if a place has this, you gotta have it!) It's a crunchy, savory, briny bite that accompanies the meal well. 

They have your classic roll combinations, like Philadelphia and California, but they also have some unique rolls (pretty sure one of them had peanut butter in them, sounds weird, but trust me, it was delicious!) The quality of their raw fish was great - you can tell the fish was fresh and well maintained b/c it didn't smell fishy and the textures of each respective fish was nice and firm. 

I'm not too familiar with the other sushi options in SF, but I highly recommend this one!
author: Erica K.

description:
very busy place even you come to there late. so expect to wait a bit, but their turnover is pretty ok. we waited about 20 minutes to sit, the waiter did mess up our place in queue and we had to remind him. rather than that, the service was pretty good. 

food was excellent, very authentic and creative - unique combination. we ordered Pokemon, jumping unagi, jumping tuna, spider roll, Crunchy Crab, a few others. all taste very good.
author: Feng L.

description: Came here on a weeknight with a friend and our wait wasn't too horrible. The sushi was so good and fresh! It's a small little spot with good music and food. If you don't mind a wait, definitely try it out!
author: Lillian B.

description: I absolutely LOVE sushi, and I find it hard to find a good place to go. I had been wanting to come her for a couple years, and we finally went. It is a super cool and popular spot. There is security at the front door, and it has this cool under ground feel to it. They have a live DJ, which makes it even more fun. I highly recommend coming early if you don't want to wait, or if you're hungry, because there is a wait. Once you get seated, the experience is great. The music, service, quality of food, prices, everything! We had several sushi rolls and it was the freshest fish I have had at any sushi restaurant before. Their prices are excellent for the quality. I am jealous that I don't live closer to this place. Expect to wait, but also expect to have a delicious dinner and fun live music.
author: Jenn M.

description: Needed a chill sushi spot that could accommodate 7 ppl with various preferences: we had one Vegan, another liked dive bars, one was a sushi snob, I wanted a place where we can all just kick back after a long shift and let loose and lastly we needed it to be open late. Ryoko fit ALL of those criteria. We had to wait pretty long though because our group was sorta large and they had to push two tables together but as soon as we sat down it was smooth sailing from there. Food was awesome! MUSIC played by the on site DJ was bombbbbb. And the service was excellent. Added an 18% gratuity to all parties of 6 or more. We will most definitely return
author: Ash P.

description:
Bumping bass, phat tunes, sick dj.
And the food's good.

Peanut butta tuna sushi roll.
$13 drinks.
Fun little cave to eat sushi, listen to music and make out.

8 minute wait but seems much shorter as they look out for you.
author: Ian P.

description:
Ryoko's is one of my favorite spots in the Lower Nob Hill neighborhood. The atmosphere is fun, funky, and casual. It's a great place for a casual date or a quick bite with friends. Most of the menu items are reasonably priced and everything tastes delicious. 

I always order the Ika Maruyaki (whole grilled squid) and Chicken Karaage (fried chicken), along with a large hot sake. The squid is very flavorful, not overly fishy, and very tender. The fried chicken has a thick, crispy skin and the meat is very juicy/moist. The sushi rolls are also delicious and different from the typical rolls you might find at a chain sushi restaurant. However, you only get 5 pieces per order, so the rolls end up being pretty pricey for what you get.

The restaurant fills up pretty quickly, so I recommend arriving right at 6pm or after 9pm unless you want to wait in line for 40 minutes.
author: Helen P.

description:
Went here on a Sunday night at 7:30 and there was an hour wait. So this tells you how poppin it is! People love this place even though you can't make reservations. Great vibes and great food! Bigger than I expected it to be! Divey with loud music, so don't go if you're looking for a romantic date. Staff is really friendly! 

Sushi is good, not great but that's expected as it's not really expensive. Definitely good tho don't get me wrong. We ordered four rolls to split between two girls and finished it all. Their miso soup was also amazing as I love extra green onions theirs had a lot and very large chunks of tofu. Eel and spicy salmon was two fav rolls. 

If I'm ever back in town I would totally go again!
author: Allison B.

description: Did not know this place and was in town on vacation. We walked in and was seated right away,we were 9, the lunch special was well priced and the food was very good. The service was ok, some room for improvment but the food makes up for it.
author: Avi H.

description: Excellent place for dinner. Their sushi dishes are unique and delicious, which sets them apart from the competition. Their seaweed salad was also very original and real unlike most restaurants that buy from Costco, here they make it on their own. Their chicken kara-age is also juicy and crunchy. Highly recommend.
author: Kevin R.

description: Such a cute and fun little place. Seems like there is always a wait but it's a cool environment. When we went there was a DJ playing old r&b hits, and lots of people doing sake bombs. The price is right for sushi, but the servings are fairly small! Would definitely come back
author: Sarah S.

description: Fun sushi spot with really quick service. Rolls were decently sized but tasted excellent and we're all really unique! Would definitely recommend the hot tuna roll and the Pokemon roll.
author: Kevin N.

description: Good late night spot. Good fresh sushi. I hate how they put imitation crab on everything. But it's open late, the kitchen is open till close and they have great vibe. Definitely a good in between bar kinda place.
author: Andrew M.

description: On our trip to San Francisco we wanted to try a sushi spot and Ryoko's had impressive reviews. We were expecting a long wait but whether it was worth it, I'm not sure. I loved the vibe and the quick service but the sushi was adequate.
author: Lala D.

description:
I am allergic to fish but my boyfriend loves sushi and this is always our go-to late night sushi spot in SF. They are open until 2AM DAILY! Which is clutch when you have sushi cravings at 12:57am on a Tuesday night (if you come on a weekend, please be aware that they will likely have a line, but it will be worth it). 

They have a DJ so it can get loud, but it isn't unbearable and is one of my favorite features of the restaurant. Come here if you want to eat sushi while you nod your head to some hip-hop and r&b greatest hits/classics.
author: Attiana P.

description:
I've gone here a few times now. As far as San Francisco pricing goes, you can't beat this value. The quality for the price is great! 

A lot of imitation crab on the menu, however the other fish quality is pretty dang good. There are some great rolls and the nigiri has good cuts of fish. 

Fair warning... they play REALLY loud music and randomly all the workers yell. So if you're coming here expecting to have a heart to heart convo, it might be tough. 

Totally worth a visit if you are looking for great sushi but not willing to pay $$$$ for it.
author: Natasha P.

description: Sushi was delicious, worth the wait.  The service is friendly.  This establishment is very loud and I would not bring young children here.  That said, our teenagers enjoyed!  Hot tuna roll was the favorite!
author: Casey R.

description: Went here after researching where to eat in the city on a late Saturday night.. overall, great expierence and vibe with music, delicious food, and great prices.
author: Sophia B.

description: I love the food the service and the ambience, BUT various parts of the restaurant smell like urine. I think that if they just the time to wash the carpet or maybe just remove it, it would help a great deal. Fix this one problem and this place could have 5 stars from me.
author: Rick O.

description: Amazing find in SF. It was late on a Wednesday evening, past 11p and this was one of the only places open and close to our hotel so we decided to try it. So glad we did! One of the best sushi spots I've ever been to. The ambiance is super chill, they had a live DJ playing music. It was packed even though it was late, but we waited no more than 15 min to be seated. Their food is amazing! The Jumping Unagi comes with this sauce, it is delish!!! They Volcano Roll comes with peanut butter, it's definitely different but very tasty-I especially enjoyed it with soy sauce, sweet and salty combo! I can't wait to visit SF again and come here again!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Came by for a midnight snack, I was surprised that the place was packed. It was about a 45 minute for 2, but we didn't mind. Ryoko's has been on my sushi list to find the best sushi  around. They had a DJ that was spinning some tunes with the lights low which creates a nice laid back ambiance. 

We ordered a couple things...
*Amebi - Perfect, crispy, and the key to a good amebi is that it doesn't taste super fishy.
*O Toro - Melts in your mouth, for $20 bucks it better.
*Sashimi platter - I liked the assortment, the scallops were my favorite. The fish was fresh, not bad for $40

Service was speedy and attentive. 

I wouldn't say Ryoko's disappointed, but it didn't wow me. The DJ creates a unique experience and since they're open later than usual places I would come back. Doesn't make my top 5 sushi list but I would recommend eating here.
author: Arron E.

description: I was skeptical about this place, it seemed more like a party spot. But, I actually really enjoyed the food. I think the loud music and faux party atmosphere is totally unnecessary. But, sadly, it's the best value and pretty decent quality sushi I've found so far in the city, at least for downtown. I'd totally come back. I like the sushi selection/choices, prices are reasonable and the sushi is good. Be prepared for a wait though.
author: Marie D.

description: Been here many times. Fun place, great service, solid sushi and a decent price. Love it and have gone with large and small groups early and for last call.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Sadly made drinks with the equivalent finesse of a 16 year old who just found out what alcohol is at a high school party. 
Rolls were measly in size and underwhelming in flavor.
Nigiri was good. Tea was great, but no luck in getting any for of refill refill. 

Final thoughts: $70 later, I'm going to be looking for another sushi bar on my way home.
author: Calvin L.

description: Don't mess around here - order the sashimi.  Whatever is fresh on the board.  Amazing cuts!
author: Will C.

description: This place has a CRAZY long line but it moves surprisingly fast. The fish is fresh and incredible and we absolutely loved the rolls. Price is pretty steep but I think it was worth it. Overall a great SF experience.
author: Lauren W.

description:
Had some friends in town from Barcelona, they wanted sushi and I figured why not take them to Ryoko's!  I haven't been in a couple of years, but after Yelp-checking it was a gamble and risk I was willing to take.

Unfortunately I had to take the L on this one.

FOOD:  We ordered the sashimi dinner platter and a few sushi rolls to share.  Overall, the sushi quality was poor.  The sashimi platter was pretty pathetic - small, whimpy pieces; the texture was bad, you could tell it wasn't fresh.  And the fish itself was warm (ew!).  Menu said it was a 14 piece platter but they cut normal sized sashimi in two pieces, so you get half the amount, basically seven pieces... really?!  The sushi rolls were a bit better, probably because of the sauce it was doused in.  The rolls themselves never held because the rice kept falling apart, so instead of eating a sushi roll we were eating piles of what was supposed to be sushi.  Not to mention, the price was higher than normal for what you get.

ATMOSPHERE:  When we were seated, the music was at a decent level and you could carry a conversation easily -- totally A-OK with that.  Music selection was fun; they played top 40s pop, edm and rap music.  I'm not sure when or why, but at some point later in our meal the music was BLASTING.  And I don't have sensitive ears, for reference I take SoulCycle weekly so I know what loud music is and this was unbearably loud.  I felt myself screaming at the person next to me.  If you want to go to a dinner where you can only read lips and listen to loud music, this is the spot for you!

To top it off, once they cleared the table, they immediately dropped our check off without us asking for it.  Granted, some people like the immediacy so they can get on their way, but we felt very rushed just as we felt they rushed making our food.

All things considered, if you're paying a high price for the amount and quality of food you get - not to mention losing an eardrum for an evening, I would continue your SF sushi hunt and dine elsewhere.
author: Sharene B.

description:
Ambiance: Super loud dance music cannot hear each other speak (Probably to keep the employees energized). They pack u like sardines in there. If u don't mind sitting elbow to elbow with the person next to you then by all means go for it. If you're claustrophobic this place is not for you.

Service: fast and average

Food: small portioned rolls very little flavor. We ordered 3 rolls (6 pieces) 2 drinks for $47 and left still hungry but refused to order more. 

This place was around the corner from our hotel so the location was good for us and two-three blocks from the heart of Union Square.
author: Linda H.

description:
This is a busy restaurant in a small space. If you have a large party, there is only one room/table available as an option. They do not take reservations. Luckily, we arrived early enough to secure that spot. People who don't want to pay for valet are trying to secure a yellow zone parking after 6pm. I wouldn't do that if you're waiting for that room in the back. 

The restaurant has a loud fun vibe. There are stairs going down to the restaurant. The ladies restroom is up a flight of stairs. The spacing is crowded. Intimate. 

The food is 5 stars, the items from the special menu, at least. They didn't get shipments for the holiday weekend, so variety was limited. My favorites of the night include uni, aji, hamachi toro niguri and scallop sashimi. I rarely order uni because I usually don't like it. I don't like the taste of ocean. My friends convinced me that I will like this one and they were right. No aftertaste. Fresh = no after taste. 

You get two hours to eat and they will let you know when your last order will take place. The service was good enough. The servers were not always able to answer questions on preparation. Receiving the answering "sometimes," was not a good answer. So what you get isn't always consistent. Im not referring to omakase, where change is expected. 

Overall good experience. Fun atmosphere. Good vibe. Fresh fish. 4.5 stars
author: Dawn N.

description: Poor service, food small portions, I'm a sushi connoisseur and the quality of fish did not match the price. They sat us and forgot about us, and we had to remind them to take our order after 45 minutes of waiting. Could be a fluke, but I will not go again.
author: Angela W.

description:
I avoided trying Ryoko's for a while since I had the impression that it was expensive (even for sushi). I'm not sure where I got this impression, but it turns out I was misinformed: in fact, Ryoko's has pretty good quality sushi for decent prices. 

The environment is a little weird, though: you enter into an underground room and are met with a wave of noise - both the waiters greeting you loudly and enthusiastically (great!) as well as a live DJ and party atmosphere (not so great...). I definitely wouldn't come here if I wanted to have conversations with the people I'm eating with. If you're drunk and seeking some good sushi, it's absolutely perfect. Especially if it's after midnight and most other good food is unavailable (they're open until 2am).
author: Joe B.

description: I haven't had sushi in months and my craving was really starting to kick in. If I go too long without sushi I just get irritable and cranky. While visiting San Francisco me and my wife figured we'd give the sushi here a a shot how could we go wrong, right?. I researched for an hour on Yelp trying to find the best in town that wasn't going to break the bank. We finally settled on Ryoko's. We went on a Saturday night so I can't complain much about the wait. It took about 45 minutes to get a seat and the best piece of advice that I can give to you guys that is a self check-in you have to find the clip board by the hostess stand to write your name. I wasn't much impressed by the atmosphere it was decorated kind of odd and felt super cramped. We started with the pitcher of my favorite beer, Sapporo and some edamame. The edamame was ok. I usually like it to be salted but these were unfortunately plain Jane.  The service was quick but we felt super rushed and unwelcome the whole time kind of understandably because line was long out the door but still needs to be noted that you will get that friendly feeling. The sushi was okay but certainly nothing to write home about. We were a little hungry still but decided not to order anymore sushi. It's not that the sushi was bad it's just that it didn't deserve another go-round.
author: Eric S.

description: This place is awesome! Sushi is super tasty. Very crowded and long waits but worth it. And the service was great as well
author: Amanda O.

description:
This is officially my first-ever review on Yelp.. here we go!!!! Let's see how long I can keep this up! 
4+ stars on overall Yelp will mean - I will come again and try either the same or different things on the menu. BIG on service! 

*****Service and Recommendations- GREaT! 
*****Vibe/Music: yaasss ! (Hip Hop, old school R&B is obv. What te DJ was feeling like)
***Wait time: for 1 person on a Saturday night(9:11pm), I waited about 30 minutes. Not bad when you have a phone to entertain you. (Btw- you walk in and sign in to get a seat. First come , First go a.k.a. FIFO haha)


Things I would get again: 

*****Hamachi Toro (Sashimi)- Freakin' Amazing !!! 
****Beef Oroshi - if you like raw meat- go for this! 
****Lemon drop martini - good for a sore throats for sure. Not a big fan on lemon, but it was a pretty good drink. I'm down to try more cocktails from this place. 

Things I can do without: 

*IIDAKO (Fried Octopus) - Don't like this fried. 
**Sashito Peppers (not on the menu) - I've had better. Then again, I like mine a little more roasted (maybe I can make a special request next time..)
author: Jessica R.

description: I used to love this place but Friday we had a bad experience. We were ordering asked the waitress what is in the sushi bin that we could see and she said that's O'Toro but when they brought out the order she said it's blue fin. So then we asked for the change to the O'Toro and they took it to the sushi chef then he said it's O'Toro. It looked nothing like what was in the bin we said. He just said it's the same. We decided to finish our meal and go to the next sushi place we could find. Bait and switch from sushi chef.
author: Mike B.

description: Worst service- waited 45 mins to find out they were out of rice. Yes, that's right.. a sushi restaurant. Out of rice.  seems like something you'd mention BEFORE putting us on the waiting list.
author: Shelby H.

description:
This is the best sushi I've found in the city. The wait is long, and the waiting area is weird but its definitely worth it. 

The sashimi was very fresh, I would order one of the nigiri or sashimi dinners next time just to try more variety. We got the jumping tuna roll and the crunchy crab roll and both were awesome! The prices were on par with other sushi places and it was overall a really good experience. 

FYI most of the tables are for 2 so I think the wait could be even longer with more than 2, plus its dark and kind of cramped inside so I wouldn't recommend for groups.
author: Chelsea J.

description:
If you come to Ryoko's for dinner, be prepared to do a bang bang*. 

After seeing this place have so many rave reviews, I brought my friend from LA to check it out. I was warned from Yelpers that the portion sizes are on the smaller side, but I still wasn't prepared for how small it actually was! We ordered 4 rolls (orange delight, hot tuna, hamachi and I think alcatraz) and an appetizer (octopus) between 4 people and I doubt that the plates that showed up would even have fed 2 :( 

Besides the beef with the portion sizes, I did like how the sushi quality and taste. The hot tuna had this interesting hint of cumin in it but I'm pretty sure there wasn't any. Orange delight was really fresh. I also liked the octopus -- it had a nice grilled flavor and came on a bed of spring mix. 

Ambiance: As my friend put it, "not stuffy", and I agree. This is a good place to kick back after a long day walking around the city. They've got a decent sound system, and I could see this restaurant easily evolving into a bar-y scene as the night goes on. 

* when you eat your first meal and then follow it with a second full meal. Props to Louis C.K.
author: Julia Y.

description: Very disappointed in this place. Ordered the chirashi, golden gate and 49ers. Asked if the chirashi could be done without ebi or tamago and was told no. When I got the chirashi the pieces looked like I prepared the fish and beleive me, you do not want me to cut up sushi pieces for you. It was all mixed together like a poki bowl, but worst. The other two rolls were meh. The only decent dish was the beef oroshi. Service was pretty bad here, as in we had to remind them at least 2 times to get simple things like more tea, need more wasabi, and for our check. Overall, very disappointed in the items and overpriced for what you get.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Very good Sushi place. 

I was hungry after Football-Sunday and asked "yelp" for a nearby Sushi-Restaurant.
Ryoko's was around the corner, so it was a quick deal!

I got lucky, as I was a "party of one" :D and got a seat at the bar instantly, while the waiting line was quite long 
Entering the restaurant, there was no fancy-glossy-interieur and the people inside created a good atmosphere.

My order turned into Sushi quickly. I got Edamame, Spicy Tuna Rolls and some Nigiri (Sake and Maguro)
The Sushi price/value was good.

This is my new favorite to go when there is lust for sushi.
author: Ben B.

description: I keep forgetting that I dislike this place and coming back. The  fish quality is very mediocre for how overpriced it is. Plays loud music which is rare for a Japanese restaurant
author: Jessica S.

description:
It's small,messy and the menus are sticky...but the sushi is damn good ! I recommend it w a group of friends amd chow down!
We were in from out of town and we were told this place had character and it surely did. It feela like a dice,but the service is great and some of the dishes are very unique!
author: Hamm B.

description:
Ryoko's is my go to spot when I want really good fresh sashimi without breaking the bank.

Admittedly, most of the time that I eat Japanese food, it's at somewhere "average." *gasp* (Oh don't look at me like that, you know you all do it!)
But every once in awhile, I take a good look at myself in the mirror and say "You deserve better than this." In comes Ryoko's.

I almost always get the 14 pc sashimi plate. Each piece of fish is so fresh and so melt in your mouth buttery soft. I'm like yeeesss, I do deserve this!

Miso soup + sake + fresh sashimi + EDM... this is most definitely my happy place. Yes there can be a wait, but I eat pretty late anyway so by the time I'm ready to eat dinner the wait isn't so bad.
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: Went there in a weekday. Surprisingly popular. I ordered the Chirashi bowl which was ok.
author: Bin D.

description:
I would't say this place is subpar but it's definitely not a place I'd frequent too often. Very long wait on a weekday night. 

The service here is decent; felt rushed on the order, but once we ordered the service and wait staff was almost nonexistent, had to actually raise our hand for more water and to order more. We attempted to order Nigiri and rolls of the specials board but just about each one we ordered was fresh out. The waitress made suggestions for other rolls but would make suggestions that were nothing like we wanted to order before (e.g. we wanted Maguro Natto, she offered Negihama instead). No where near what we wanted, I might be a little uppity about it but it's just not what we wanted, especially if we already ordered plenty of rolls. 

Anyway, sushi was cool. Nothing special or a separator, especially since they didn't have what we wanted. Natto roll was probably the best thing we had, we ordered three Natto rolls.
author: John M.

description: I loved the sashimi platter here. It was very fresh with a wide variety of fish including yellow fin tuna. The ambiance reminded me of my time in japan with the typical greeting when entering and exiting. Not fancy nor divey. Just the right amount of edge and bar selection with amazing sushi.
author: Rebekah W.

description: I ordered sushi dinner and it seemed like not 40 dollars cost. I got 2 salmon 1 tuna 1tamago 1 unagi and other things. Never seemed like that cost
author: Philip J.

description:
When you walk in, the whole restaurant shouts a greeting at you. The seating is very tight. The waitress was very nice. She gave us her name and asked us to call her if we needed anything. 

Everything moved pretty quick. She brought our drinks, took our order and within ten minutes, we had five rolls on the table. 

The rolls were good. We didn't have any qualms with them. I'm not fond of bean sprouts, so that was a personal downside for me. Other than that, we enjoyed the sushi. Before we go back, I would probably check out other sushi in town first.
author: Carmen C.

description: Best sushi bar in the city. Cool, good prices, good variety, great quality fish! It's a great place to meet with friends and share a bunch of roles. The wait will get long later at night. The sushi chefs are insane! They must be chugging Red Bull's to keep up!
author: Jessica V.

description: This is one my favorite sushi places, it's super convenient and  it's open late in the city. The sushi taste fresh and the service is great. Can't get enough, definitely recommend this place to those who thought hey didn't like sushi, will definitely like it now from this place! Must try their Kentucky roll! It's bomb
author: Maryanna G.

description:
Most delicious Californian roll and Volcano it's certainly not just a fancy name. 

When we entered Ryoko's for dinner we felt a little disappointed as it looks more like a bar - night club than a sushi place. We could see the DJ, the people having fun, a busy bar but nothing about the food. Once we've been served the story changed: the music wasn't that loud anymore, the place not that crowded and the food a delight. We ordered about 3 sushi varieties and 2 sashimis and honestly we were more than satisfied. Left the place with a big smile on our faces wanting to return for lunch. 

One note: the green tea is actually match powder with water and not so great but seems that the whole US doesn't brew the traditional jasmine or green tea anymore. A little downer.
author: CatAlina A.

description:
Decent sushi overshadowed by long lines, pounding club music, and rushed service. Came here for dinner on a Thursday night. Arrived 10 minutes before opening and was the 5th party in line.

We ordered the house salad, angus beef, eel and avocado roll, rainbow roll, salmon skin roll, and jumping tuna. The rainbow, salmon skin, and jumping tuna were great. Nothing else stood out. The beef was a bit disappointing, simply a steak cut into thin pieces. Teriyaki beef may have been a better choice.

The lighting, tight quarters, underground location, and loud music made this feel more like a dance club than a sushi restaurant. Eating sushi to blaring EDM music is not a pleasant experience. Furthermore, there appeared to be only 2 or 3 servers for the whole restaurant, and they appeared woefully understaffed.

Definitely feel like this place is overhyped.
author: Tim X.

description:
Being that I have visited Japan every year since 1997, and have eaten in Tsukiji several times, I feel that I have a very good knowledge of authentic sushi and Japanese cuisine.

Ryoko's could not have been a bigger disappointment. The sushi rice was flavorless and some grains were hard. The fried oysters were dry and hard as well and tasted as though they were frozen. A few of the pieces of sushi I actually had were tough on the ends, and the uni was not fresh. It left a bad aftertaste in my mouth that lasted well after leaving the restaurant. This is a place to skip in a city with so many other options.
author: Ravi B.

description:
What a fun place! If you want good sushi, a DJ, and candy (they have a jar of candy for people to grab) for snacking at 11:30 at night, then you have come to the right place. I went here on my company's dime and ended up ordering the sashimi plate, hand picked by the sushi chef himself. It comes with miso soup and a California roll, so needless to say I was stuffed by the end of the night.

All of the sushi was fantastic and fresh! My server was very attentive, and the food came out pretty quickly. The prices were also reasonable too for the quality.

Overall, great experience! The only negative thing was that my server had forgotten to put in an order of spicy tuna which I had ordered earlier in the night, but at that point, it didn't matter because I had already eaten a small army of raw fish.
author: Avery B.

description:
Arrived at around 6:15pm on a Saturday night and there was no wait for a table for 2, and I saw that there were more than a few tables still open. However, the spots filled up quick, and by 6:30pm and definitely by 6:45pm there was a line for a table. You don't have to get here right when they open to snag a table, but I'd definitely suggest getting here before 6:30pm.

Ambiance is a bit dark and dingy, with loud music and cramped quarters. I had the agedashi tofu to start (piping hot and comes with 3 large chunks of tofu), and the Hot Tail (yellowtail, spicy sauce, shiso, and cucumber) and Jumping Tuna (spicy tuna, cucumber, and shiso, rolled and deep fried) rolls. Both rolls were tasty, but I was a little more partial to the Hot Tail roll. The rolls were reasonably priced, and were both under $10. 

Service was friendly enough, but a little bit harried and brusque. It also took awhile for us to get the attention of our waitress to request our check. Overall, a solid spot, but not awe inspiring.
author: Vivian L.

description: Had a great experience at Ryoko's! The staff was quick even during a busy time and the food was amazing! I will definitely be back again to try more dishes.
author: Katey V.

description:
It was good but it wasn't great. We came in pretty late but the place was packed. We managed to snag two seats at the bar. I ordered a hot sake and two rolls. 

Their prices are high for what you get. My rolls were very small. I pay less for more at my local place, but hey that's what I get for eating sushi in the bay, haha.

The sake was good, however it was a little small for a large. I think our bill totaled out to $36.00 with my three items being the only three on there.

Fun atmosphere but not that great for the price.
author: Brittany F.

description:
Came in on the Sunday evening of PRIDE weekend, and the place was packed! Wait was definitely longer than desirable for a party of 4. 

The food was great but for $9, you could probably find something more filling than the small (5-6 pc) rolls they had. I had the jumping unagi, which was delicious. Not worth the price in my opinion but I guess that's a gripe I have with sushi in general. 

Atmosphere was great and service was awesome. The chefs behind the counter always greet everyone that comes in with a lot of enthusiasm- thought that was great.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Very disappointing. I had high hopes after seeing people line up for Ryoko's open at 6PM. 

I walked down some steps, past neon beer signs for Japanese beers, including one that was broken or just not turned on, into a dimly lit entrance and techno music. I asked for a counter seat for one in Japanese, and then repeated myself in English when told by the host they don't speak Japanese. 

At the counter, I asked in Japanese what was fresh and recommended. Neither the sushi chef, nor the rest of the staff I interacted with, spoke Japanese, so I asked in English what was fresh and recommended. He pointed at a whiteboard and said, "These are our specials."

I ordered a few things from the chef, then had a waitress come over and ask for my order. I explained I'd already ordered from the chef, but asked for a hot green tea.  My hot tea arrived, and was drunk, before my order arrived. 

Instead of serving my order to me over the glass, the chef told someone else counter order seven was ready, and then they gave my order to a waitress, who then brought it to me. 

The fish was good, although for the price and portion size, I would expect to be at least good, especially in San Francisco.  The actual nigiri had a tendency to fall apart when dipped fish first in soy sauce.  For my six nigiri, I was given three slices of ginger. 

At no point was my tea refilled, and it was clear that it was going to be well over $100 pre-tip if I wanted to fill up on nigiri sushi.  I paid my bill and walked around until I decided to get a salad at sweetgreens that was the bulk of my dinner. 

I know I'm pickier than the average American when it comes to sushi, but I've had better sushi in Vegas, Atlanta and New York, all for less than what was charged here. 

Between the service, atmosphere and prices, I cannot endorse this place. 

I'm sure there's places to get great sushi at a fair price in San Francisco, but this is not it.
author: Eric P.

description:
The quality of the sashimi was extremely disappointing. I got a sashimi platter and the fish was bland and overall tasted old. For example, the scallop was not sweet at all and had a bitter aftertaste. The shrimp was absolutely miserable, dry as a bone. Tuna tasted like nothing. The only thing that was alright was the salmon, but you couldn't even find bad salmon if you tried. Also, they charged $2 for a cup of tea, which no real, traditional Japanese restaurant even does. On top of that, they charge $40 for a sashimi platter... If you want real sushi go to a place like Saru sushi instead.

Just don't come here
author: Kevin C.

description: We went first time last night. Really yummy and great vibe. Decent prices also. Had a few rolls and some Sashimi. Place was pleasantly packed but got table right away. They had a DJ that kept the atmosphere light and fun. Would highly recommend if you are in area.
author: Glenn D.

description: This place was sooo busy but worth the wait. Sushi was good and the place had DJ music so it was fun for a group. Not a fan of the roll with the american cheese on top. But I loved the Spicy Tuna roll, and a lot of the signature rolls. I expected the bill to be much higher than it was. The staff was super speedy and we were greatly accommodated. You can also do sake bombs here!
author: Alexis B.

description: Loved all the tapas. The tako yaki balls didn't taste like frozen ones that were reheated. Sushi was very fresh and sliced thinly. Service was fast.  The place is usually pretty packed and seating can be a bit tight.
author: Diane Z.

description: On a recent to trip to SF yelp directed me here.  Spot on sushi date gem in San Francisco!  The blue fun tuna sushi was like butter and completely out of this world!  Will be back hopefully very soon!
author: Sandra P.

description: Fish was very 'fresh' tasting and well developed flavors. Rice was well balanced - sweet, sour, and salty - and had a good bite. Nigiri's were well sized. Rolls were also great (had the spicy tuna, soft-shell crab rolls). Service was a bit spotty on occasions. Overall would go back again for the fresh fish.
author: Jo D.

description: Decent food but the ambiance is what really makes this place.  They often have a live dj playing sick throwback mixes in an environment that I can only describe as underground club meets dive bar vibe.  The sushi was fine but the most memorable thing was the octopus wasabi sashimi.  The service was quick and attentive.  This is a place you would go for pre game drinks and small bites.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Good food, loud music... 
We went after a show so it was quite crowded... The wait was about 20 minutes around 7:30 pm. We really enjoyed all our rolls... i would go back!
author: Gloria L.

description: My family of 4 adults and 2 young adults with only one sake wine, the total was $380. We enjoyed the food but pricey as compared with Sushi Zone.
author: Judy T.

description:
Came here late night around 12:30am. This place was busy and there was a good vibe going with the live DJ. Unfortunately I guess there was only 1 waitress there because it took a while to get our drink/order in. She sat us down and failed to tell us that their kitchen was closed so after looking at the menu for 10-15 minutes getting all excited, we were told we couldn't order any specials or any appetizers. 

Ordered the Toro Sushi - it was alright. I've had better. It was $18 for two pieces and I had higher expectations. 
Spicy scallop roll - not great at all - flavors were bland. 
Jerry Roll - probably my favorite out of everything we ordered. 
Uni sushi - decent
Salmon sushi - decent
Sexy roll - Overcooked and baked on cheap aluminum foil so the whole bottom of the roll was stuck on the foil. 

I probably would not come back here again. It wasn't very satisfying.
author: Jenny C.

description: This is one of the best sushi spots in the city!  There is usually a long wait on the weekends, so best to come in smaller groups and totally worth it! It is a fun spot with the dj spinning in the background. It can get loud in there, so probably best to leave the kids at home for this one. The fish is high grade and I've never ordered a bad item there.  Fish is super fresh, and the servers are all really nice too.  And I also appreciate the friendly japanese greetings when I enter and leave the restaurant. You can tell that the folks that work there really care about their jobs and about excelling in customer service.
author: Phan ..

description:
This place is perfect for date night but the wait may be about 30min-an hour depending on when you come. We got lucky with parking and saw at least 5 other cars on the same street leaving! While you wait, the servers come around asking if you'd like to order drinks! 

Truly a hole underground! Wonderful little spot! Very intimate and can be a little overwhelming if you don't like crowds. The food is spectacular! The menu items from Japan were extremely fresh and scrumptious. Each bite sent me to heaven and back. My favorite was the sake (salmon) and uni! We tried the amaebi (sweet shrimp). It comes with the raw body and deep fried head! The nigiri portion was way too soft and "melting in my mouth" texture but the deep fried heads were delicious!
author: Mark D.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE IT HERE!  I came in around 7:00 PM on a Wednesday night and the place was almost packed!  I was so glad my friend and I didn't have to wait - we were quickly seated.  We got the Tako Wakame-Su, Uni, Toro and Sashami dinner.  All our food came out VERY quickly and I was super impressed!

Tako Wakame-Su ($8.95) - thinly sliced octopus placed in a martini glass.  This was AMAZING.  The wakame-su sauce was so FRESH.  I highly recommend this!!!

Uni & Toro ($4.25) - my first time having uni and I fell in love.  It's super fresh!

Sashimi dinner ($39.95) - came with 14 slices of sashimi.  My favorite was the scallop!!!

Service here is pretty good as well.  Overall - highly recommend this place if you're around the area!!!
author: Racheal D.

description: Such an amazing atmosphere, great service, really good food.  Hands down my favorite sushi spot in SF.
author: Steve J.

description: Favorite hidden gem in the city. Amazingly fresh fish and cool atmosphere. Tends to have a lot of people waiting but the waitlist goes by quickly.
author: Danielle D.

description:
Open late! I was raining, we were hungry, wet and cold, they received us with a smile. They are extremely friendly and the food is good for the price. Again, the best is they are opened until 1am.
Thank you Ryoko's!
author: Ricardo S.

description:
Seevice was super slow. Sushi was fried, in mayo and smelled fishy. Tasted ok. I was nervous eating it...
Meh we won't be back.
author: Meghann M.

description: We are big time sushi lovers and found this little spot in San Francisco... definitely fell in love with the sashimi super fresh... the toro hamachi and toro tuna was so yummy. The place is very tight and tiny but it is worth the wait. We sat at the bar and the stair case was filled with people sitting down waiting to be seated. The sashimi is a must, they have specific items on the menu that you can't find in other sushi restaurant.
author: Mayela N.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE SO MUCH. One of the best sushi places I've ever been too. I love how it's open so late. Went here with my mom after a giants game and the food was more memorable than the game itself. Such a fun atmosphere. There was a Dj inside and security guard at the door. Location is kind of close to a scary neighborhood, but don't let that frighten you. There was also a long wait even at 12am, but ITS SO WORTH IT. Definitely not a super touristy place which is nice too. K
author: Kasey R.

description: This place really surprised me! I went to eat here after a concert around midnight and got a chirashi bowl. The fish was super fresh and had lots of variety of fish. I thought scallop sashimi was gross before this place. Now I know how the texture is supposed to be...haha. I would definitely come back to try more things!
author: Victoria L.

description: I had sushi tonight and it's ok food not that great but the Miso soup was the best . The place is small and no parking at all. Food is not bad and people who works there is good too. Lots of people and you have to stay outside and wait to be seated which I do not like of course some people don't like either
author: Mac P.

description:
This place I think is a bit over hyped. 
When you walk inside it's extremely dark and you're greeted by all the workers with the classic japanese phrase "irasshaimase" which means "welcome in". 
My husband and I were seated at this dimly lit table. When I say dim I mean I had to squint to see the menu and I saw people using flashlights on their phones to read it as well. 
Our server was nice but seemed not very talkative since it was busy. This place was filled up 20 min after opening so I suggest if you want to eat here come early. Parking is free after 6pm on weekdays so that's a plus too. 
The food was kind of meh. I  like the agedashi tofu a lot but there was only 3 pieces and I felt like that was kind of cheap. It's only tofu !!! The miso soup was ok but if I came again I would skip it. 
The ikura was not marinaded in mirin which was a huge disappointment. Tamago was good - pretty sure its made in house. The crunchy crab was a little too crunchy. Salmon nigiri was standard. Caterpillar was pretty standard. Nice thick cut avocado on the top. 
Overall it was a nice date night but would I come back? Maybe not.
author: Lily Z.

description:
If you see a line and you don't exactly know what the line is for, don't question it & just get in line before the line gets too long. That's how Cory & Shawn ended up getting a churro at WDW. 
Just a brief stroll away from Union Square, a small group of people were gathering outside of Ryoko's minutes before they were about to open. Mr. Joy & I joined them under the cylinder roofed doorway. We were seated pretty quickly with no problem. There is a sushi bar, but it seems like people will bump into you while you perch on the stools. Not long after, a large group had queued up on the stairs to the underground venue. I always thought underground dining was more of a NYC thing. Shortly after that, music began to resonate, loudly. As I took in the dark surroundings, the grand piano, and  the old time-y photos on the walls, I thought to myself, this should be interesting.

$39.95 Sashimi Dinner - 14 pcs. sashimi w/ steamed rice & miso soup:
The plate include 3 pcs. tuna, 3 pcs. salmon, 3 pcs. yellowtail, 3 pcs. mackerel, 2 pcs. scallops, and octopus. The amount seemed a bit sparse on the plate, because they were neatly arranged in such a tight formation, but there they were, all 14 pieces, complete with lemon slices, wasabi, ginger, and a little garnish. The fish tasted sweet and tender. The tuna and hamachi had meatier texture and the salmon was pretty silky. The scallops were seasoned with a bit of soy sauce. 
I also ordered 2 pcs. tamago and uni nigiri. The tamago was sweet, and tightly wrapped with seaweed down the center. It wasn't the best tamago I ever had. The egg could have been rolled neater and tighter. But I don't want to be nitpicky.
The imported uni was pretty pricey, but there were about 3-4 slivers of buttery uni in each roll. 

Since this place gets a reasonable amount of buzz for its rolls, we ordered a couple to fill up on. I'm not a huge fan of sushi rolls, because I find that a lot of times they all end up tasting the same, with lots of the same 'ol ingredients - avocado, tempura, sriracha, etc.
$7 Spicy Scallop - marinated scallop in spicy sauce, shiso, cucumber: 
Pretty good, not great. The rice was a little hard, but the marinated scallops were fine.
$13.50 49er's - crab & avocado w/ tuna & salmon on top:
This is kind of a dressed California roll with the tuna & salmon on top and nicely garnished with lemon slices. I quite liked it.

I wouldn't want to wait in line during peak times. It must be rather uncomfortable and awkward on the stairs. However, I can definitely see how the techno music/DJ aspect of it would be appealing to nightclub-goers. I mean, after a few hours of living it up, you can really work up an appetite and possibly need to eat some rice to absorb all the alcoholic drinks. For late night meals, Ryoko's is obviously way more appealing than gorging on snacks from a convenience store. The fish was pretty good, but the prices are a little steep.
author: Joy W.

description: Believe the hype! Ryoko's doesn't look like much but it delivers some of the best sushi in San Francisco. No reservations so get there early or be prepared to wait as space is tight. Daily specials are worth the adventure. I absolutely love this subterranean hole in the wall place. Don't miss out.
author: Joe G.

description: My girlfriend and I have been coming here for over a year. It is our favorite spot in the city. The atmosphere is that of a dive bar but the food and drinks are delicious! A must go to for anyone coming to the city for a night out and some sushi!
author: Justin R.

description: Average sushi and you are going to get sick.  We got the runs right after the meal.  We should have walked out as soon as we walked when we smelled the funky smell in the restaurant.   Definitely overrated.
author: Seth T.

description: Crowded, dirty, small, not good for seating large parties, over priced, noisy, low bar on the sushi.
author: Adriana A.

description:
I was really excited to try this place since it's really popular and has a fun atmosphere. The food itself was just okay (3 stars) but we had a terrible experience with the bill at the end of our meal.

Fortunately the prices are really reasonable so you can try a few different things. I really enjoyed the hiyashi wakame ($5) which is a seaweed salad dish. The shrimp and vegetable tempura ($9) and agedashi tofu ($5) appetizers were tasty but nothing special. The deep fried oysters ($7) were enormous so if you really like those I thought that was a good deal. For sushi we got the jumping unagi ($9) which was basically deep fried unagi rolls and the hot tuna roll ($7). I thought both of them were fairly mediocre quality but reasonable for the price.

Regarding the negative experience at the end, the server sat our party of 2 at a large table shared with other parties of 2 we didn't know. That in itself was great and helped cut the wait time for us. The issue was each separate party had ordered their own meals and drinks but when it came to the bill the server had put the entire table on one tab and wouldn't split it for each separate party. So our table had to figure out who ordered what and it got so complex in the end we just split the bill evenly across all parties which was really frustrating for everyone (and my fiance and I ended up overpaying our actual amount). After that entire ordeal it then took over 20 minutes for them to give our cards back. I rarely have had such a frustrating dining experience.
author: Linda X.

description:
Food: All of their rolls and nigiri are pretty fresh (including the uni), some fish is even straight from Japan. They also have unique rolls like deep-fried BBQ eel and avocado (called the Jumping Unagi). However the portions are really way too small for the price.

Don't get the karaage chicken. It looks big like there's a lot but it's mostly just fluff or batter, very little actual meat.

Noise level: really loud. You will need to lean in to hear or speak to the person directly across from you.

Parking: won't likely find any nearby.

Line: expect a 40+ min wait on a wed-sat night
author: Tom P.

description: All I can say is that Ryoko is not a bad sushi restaurant but I don't think I will ever return: 90 dollars (for two people) later, I walked out the restaurant half full. I was so hungry before bed time so I had to have some cup noodle before going to sleep. Service was good. Food was fine. Price is too high (to me).
author: K Y.

description:
This is by far my favorite sushi bar in the bay area! 

They are open late which is a huge plus! They have a good sake selection, they have very tasty Sushi and Sashimi and they have the best atmosphere. This place is always bustling with happy customers! The inside looks like a cozy house with various types of seating. You can sit at the bar, get a table in the center area or go into one of the rooms if you have a large party and want more privacy. They always have good music and very friendly waiters.
author: Kayvan M.

description:
This place is nothing but amazing. The sushi is very fresh and unique.

Unlike many other sushi placesou get top quality rolls for 10$. You can tell how much effort they put into it when you order tempura rolls and you taste the batter. It is very fresh and light

You will definetly have to wait in order to get in since this place is so popular. 

Highly recommended if you want to take friends that are new to the SF vibe
author: Daniel C.

description:
This is one of our favorite sushi places in town so far, the food is good, portions are very good. 

I recommend you having jumping tuna!! And beer!

Only thing that gets a 7/10 is that the place is a bit old inside and sometimes looks a bit bad but thats about it, food is amazing!
author: Rebecca F.

description:
Ryoko's definitely has a vibe of its own with the dim lighting, loud music, interesting seating arrangements, and sushi bar. I guess you could say it has character. 

This is a great place to chow down on Japanese food with friends while having some sake and beer. Being the leaf eater that I am, my options were somewhat limited. However, the rolls that I did get were pretty satisfying! I've had the Jumping Veggie, Vegetable Melody, and Humboldt roll and enjoyed them all. The rolls are pretty medium sized in terms of portion and you will most likely want to order 2 (or more) in order to be full. I have had the fried cheese appetizer which is really good, but a bit small.

I would highly recommend this place to my friends even though there aren't overwhelming options for me. Service has never been an issue here for me. 

The line outside does start forming a bit before the restaurant opens for dinner, but you won't face that long of a wait if you come within the first hour that they are open. However, if you show up after that, particularly with a large group, you may be huddled by the door or on the steps.
author: Lakshmi M.

description: I got tea, edamame, a big mama roll, and a Pokémon roll. The tea tasted like seaweed (maybe that's the point, but I wasn't expecting it). The edamame was cold and unsalted (cold I could handle but it just wasn't tasty).  The rolls were edible, but I wouldn't order them again. Service was meh. There was great music though! That's the only reason I didn't give it 1 star.
author: Reagan R.

description: I had an unplanned dinner here with friends visiting San Francisco; we beat the Saturday night dinner rush, which was fortunate because they didn't take reservations anyway. We ordered the futomaki roll, a Tahoe roll, a spicy golden gate roll, tamago, miso soup, onigiri with pickled plum, and the nigiri dinner. The vegetarian options are delicious, much more flavorful than most vegetable sushi because of their inclusion of burdock root and pickled veggies in their rolls, and some special magic in their eggs. The fish they use, in the rolls and in the nigiri plate, is truly very fresh and flavorful. Overall, it was a nice, unplanned dinner and we were all quite pleasantly surprised by the quality we got for prices that are quite reasonably for San Francisco.
author: Vickie Y.

description:
Went to Ryoko's with a couple friends to have some sushi and a couple drinks. 

I had a delicious drink with Japanese whisky - I believe it was some kind of mule drink, and I recommend it!

I ordered a hamachi roll and tekka maki. I don't have sushi very often, but my mom did successfully raise me to want kind of no frills raw fish in my sushi (though I DO love a Philadelphia roll, much to her chagrin), and that it's not "real" sushi unless it has raw fish in it (the snobbery, I know, I know).

So when I instead got a hamachi roll and a cucumber maki...I was disappointed. Cucumber isn't REAL sushi XD

Okay, no biggie, mistakes happen. When the waitress came around, I politely said that I had ordered a tekka maki and not a cucumber maki, and she just looked at me and said, "No, you ordered that." 

...um...no, no I did not...

She said she had repeated our order (there were about 6 - 7 dishes ordered among all of us). And totally fair, she had repeated our order, but this is also not a quiet restaurant. I understand how "tekka" could sound like "kappa" (which is apparently the cucumber one) on either side of our conversation, because I certainly didn't hear her say "kappa". Maybe it's because I know I had said "tekka" and that's what I was listening for.  

Had she said something like, "Oh, I'm sorry, I must have heard you wrong, I'll get you the tekka maki" then that would've been lovely and we would've been great.

But instead, she just said, "No, that's not what you ordered" and left.

Oh. I see.

In that case, I guess I will not be returning any time soon. The short haired tattooed waitress bummed me out. It would have been appreciated had she been accommodating in any way, but really was just like, "Not my fault" and bailed.
author: Naoko M.

description: Ahhhhhmazing!!!! The vibe, food, dj ...everything all around was 5 stars! We were visiting from LA and wanted to keep the night going and did not expect this restaurant to be what it was! Definitely will be our hidden gem
author: Jonae W.

description: Went on a Saturday night and waited maybe 15 min to be seated. Make sure to go to the bottom of the stairs to write your name on the list - don't worry about the line as people tend to wait on the stairs for their name to be called. The spot had such a lively vibe that it's impossible not to have a good time. The sushi was above average on quality/taste. My only major gripe was that I was discouraged to order directly from the sushi chef when I sat at the bar. I'm an avid sushi eater - I'm not talking about your "roll" kind of guy, I'm saying I eat the best at the best spots all over USA - and when I'm not able to interact with my sushi chef, it takes away from my experience. If I could do 3.5 stars I would, but I always round up. Go to this place expecting good sushi at a reasonable price, expecting a loud/party atmosphere. Drinks were solid too.
author: Paolo J.

description: Good sushi but expensive. For that price it's average to good. Had Uni and toro. Toro was good. Need oroshi was not good
author: Why-Tie Z.

description: Amazing sushi! Fried chicken! And it's worth the long wait! The live Dj gives it a touch? (But play better songs) over all a chill place to eat and try! Hands down my first place to have dinner at when coming to San Francisco!!! Try it!!
author: Alfredo G.

description:
While there is usually a really long wait to be seated, the fish at Ryoko's is worth it.

Seaweed salad: yum. Get it. No questions. Yellowtail with scallions: fine, nothing special. Citrusy and refreshing, the Pokemon roll was delicious. Despite the peanut butter in it, the volcano roll was super-interesting. Small sake for $5 with enough for 2 people is a big bonus.

The atmosphere can get rowdy sometimes: too many hipsters doing their first sake bomb or something, I guess.

With classic jams playing in the background, Ryoko's is a cool place to have some good fish.
author: CJ G.

description:
We went here for a late night dinner because there were not many options that night. When we arrived, they informed us that the kitchen just closed and that they were only serving cold items and sushi. We sat down right away because there were not many people there. They was a DJ playing some tracks but to be honest it was a little too loud. We asked the server what was fresh that day and she pointed out the menu items listed on the wall. We decided to try most of the items and got a cold sake. I was a little disappointed in the selections, but I couldn't be too picky. There were also some items that were not available and it was kind of weird because we thought that those items would come from the sushi bar. I would have to say that about half of the sashimi and rolls were decent. The rest of them did not taste very fresh. I am assuming they cater mostly to the drinking crowd, but drunk people still have some semblance of taste and it did not taste very good. The only thing that was really good was the sake that we ordered with our meal. Really overpriced for the quality of the meal.

Will definitely want to try out this place again, but maybe a little bit earlier in the night or day. If the quality is the same as this experience, will not be going back.
author: Camera P.

description:
I brought some friends here after flying in to sfo late one night. They LOVED it! Everything was so good. Fresh sushi, a DJ playing cool tunes and we made some cool friends on the stairs while we waited (totally worth the wait) 
The service was fast and our server was very nice. Can't wait to go back!
author: Miss L.

description: Great sushi, even cooler DJ. Lots of interesting drinks to choose from and it's got an awesome vibe.
author: Haishan Q.

description: Food and atmosphere was amazing. Otoro, uni and their teriyaki chicken is a must have.
author: D D.

description: Delicious rolls and raw fish options. There is a wait as this place is busy and doesn't take reservations. Totally worth it! Loved feeling like I was immersed into the underground bar culture.
author: Sveta S.

description: Great food drinks and amazing ppl. Was in town for the night and it was . A must stop
author: Moricco P.

description: Mediocre af. waited for over an hour. The food lacked flavor. There's really no need to come here
author: Alex S.

description:
One thing that stands out about Ryoko's is that it has a lot of space to accommodate large groups. This place gets packed around 7 PM, so I would always encourage you to come in early if you can. You will get seated right away. Overall, service is fast, food comes out fast, lots of cocktails to choose from, great food, good quality fish. 

So let me break down each component:
Service
The waitstaff is super nice. It seems like they have been working there for quite some time so they know their stuff. They are quick and accommodating. Anytime we ask for additional items for the table, they will never forget. I can ask any waitstaff and they will let our waiter know that we need something and he will bring it to the table. They even offered to take us a photo. 

Food
Price is $$. Lots of variety from appetizers, sushi, rice dishes, etc. I mainly judge a sushi place by the fish and I can say that they picked great quality fish. I don't know if it is because I came at 6 before the dinner crowd, but you can tell the fish is fresh. The salmon and hamachi were buttery. They cut the tuna thin which I like because tuna tends to have a tougher texture than salmon. We ordered Tako with cucumber, agedashi tofu, and edamame as appetizers. Sushi - sashimi platter ($39), rainbow roll ($20), spicy scallop ($7), pokemon ($11.50) roll, hotate nigiri ($9 for 2), live ama ebi ($15.99 for two). The sashimi platter is worth the money, if covers the basic fish you would normally get. They are thin cuts so its not the 1 inch piece you can get at other places. In addition, they add in shrimp, octopus, and scallops in addition to the fish. 

Food is good!

Cleanliness
I can't say its your nicest place, but it they keep the place clean. Tables are separated very well so that you can move. 

I would definitely come here again. Definitely recommend the pokemon roll, agedashi tofu, ama ebi, and sashimi platter.
author: Jackie N.

description: Sashimi was fresh and tasted fine.  Some of the other fusion dishes were over done with incompatible flavors.  Especially disappointing when the price point is high.  Ambience is cozy/chill.  Wait staff is average.
author: Arun P.

description: Ryoko's is great, especially if you arrive around 6pm. Easy to find a table at that time, no queue. Once you're done with dinner, your waiter doesn't kick you out. Affordable and cool.
author: Clémentine C.

description:
The sushi restaurant was a mistake...

Preface: In SF for my 23rd birthday and see this awesome restaurant with a lot of reviews on Yelp.

So first off we were already waiting for awhile, but there were people still before us and it began to get more packed with more people waiting as time went on. The hostess/waitress would call names; however, as more and more time progressed the hostess/waitress started to skip people who were waiting easily 45 minutes-1 hr before. So we complained that they skipped multiple couples that had been waiting the longest out of everyone along with other groups including us. After bringing this issue up, they began seating according to the actual list of names. The food was delicious until the check comes it's $101... needless to say we didn't order anything close to $101...we did the math items were doubled charged and over charged...the bill was mess. 

Moral of the story we really couldn't do anything so we rounded up a gave them 46 cent tip....before you all get offended on my pettiness. I work in the food service industry at a restaurant supply company throwing and lifting 50 pound bags of potatoes, onions, along with boxes of beef and chicken etc while walking 12 miles a day in steel toed boots and I don't expect a tip. If you can't do your job properly and give decent service, while under a little stress, you're a joke and new profession.

Conclusion: To end the sushi was good, but not worth the hassle.
author: Evan M.

description:
Ok. Most excellent sushi.  

Very fresh fish. Enthusiastic staff. 

Fried crunchy soft shelled crab starter. Yummy!

4 different rolls as recommended by the waiter.  All different and varied.  

The only negative is the very loud bad club music pounding away the whole time. Otherwise a five
author: Dave H.

description: Sushi was great ! This place is loud and busy ! Seems like it's full of locals which is great. The prices are good. This place isn't romantic and not for kids, cool little hole in the wall.
author: Thomas G.

description:
Ryoko's is definitely my go to sushi place in Nob Hill. It's a bit divey, open late, has rare sushi options, there was a DJ playing when I went - so you can't beat the atmosphere.

But if there were .5 ratings it would get a 3.5 because even for all that it is a bit pricey and you don't get the biggest slices of fish compared to other spots in the City.

My first time here was on a date where I was the first to get a seat, and we got a mix of nigiri and rolls and it was a solid meal if the check came out over $100.

This most recent trip, I had just ended a date at Benjamin Cooper and was craving something good nearby and I did want sushi. Being by myself, I quickly got sat at the bar and careened my neck to see what special, rare fish they had.

Again, one of the best things about this place is their rare selection. This night I got:
-Kanpachi (amberjack) - A big fan, even if this was pricier than other places and thinner cut.
-Torigai (Japanese Cockle) - First time trying these. Very chewy but with a great flavor.
-Kamasu (Japanese Barracuda) - MY FAVORITE of the night, seared giving it some extra umami that was similar to black cod. Sadly these pieces were also tiny and I had considered getting another 2 if not for their price tag.
-Karei (Flounder) - Big fan of flounder and these were the biggest pieces. A nice, light white fish.
-Hamachi Toro - Who doesn't love Hamachi? And who doesn't love toro? You got that nice, fatty flavor combined with hamachi's delicious flavor. Really good even if I would have preferred a thicker slice.
-Sake (Salmon) - The most basic, but I love salmon and the cheapest at $6.
-Sake (Hot) - I was taking bart, why not keep drinking something warm on a cold July night.

They had some other special fish, including blue fin, but considering this was already up to $60, I decided better stop while I was good. 

My server, who may have been the only server, was amazing. She was running around but knew who needed help and continually let us at the bar know if we needed something. The DJ was also great and complimented my Dragon Ball hoodie.
author: Michael C.

description:
I was excited to try Ryoko since it had so many great reviews and I am sad to say I was a little disappointed. The rolls lacked creativity and the quality of the sushi was average. I ordered the most recommended roll, the Volcano that included peanut butter. Although it was interesting, I found the spread to be super overpowering. I also had the Salmon Skin roll, that was good but a little chewy. I gave it 3 stars because the simple rolls that they have were good quality and fresh. It was ok, but I would want to try other sushi restaurants before returning. 

But there is no denial that this place is popular. They only open at 6, and when we got there at 5:50 there was already a line out the door. Since there is a flood of new diners all at the same time at 6, service is super slow. The waitress took a long time to take our order, and the rolls came out especially slow. An awkward thing is that the rolls would come out as they are made, with no sign of a working ordered system. One person had their rolls come out 15 minutes after everyone else has been served. This may not be a problem if you go later in the evening. The ambiance is super dark, which I did not mind, and they had upbeat and current music playing. But since this place is underground, it felt a little stuffy. There was different sized and shaped fans blowing. We actually had to turn the ones facing our table off because who wants a fan blowing in their face during dinner.
author: Khoi N.

description:
Great environment and great DJ in the heart of SF. A lot of choices and authentic Japanese cuisine. Would need to try more items on the menu to get familiar with overall quality. But I had California rolls and Ebi rolls which were solid except for one small thing.

I have eaten Ebi rolls at quite a few sushi/Japanese spots and never have they put wasabi between the shrimp and rice. Have eaten sushi atleast 50 times in many different establishments this was never the case. So once I bit into the Ebi I was quite surprised
As the wasabi exploded in my mouth. 

Once I made mention of this they stated this was the Japanese way of making the Ebi. Maybe I simply haven't eaten at enough spots to be aware, but I have eaten at a lot of spots and I was yet to experience this. Can someone chime in on this?

They didn't offer free refills either. Just had to mention this.

However, the DJ played some great tunes. Nothing like hearing Celly Cel "It's going down tonight" while having sushi. 

Security at the front door was very friendly and inviting as well. 

Definitely good late night spot with good late night energy.
author: Terrance S.

description: Get ready to wait a long queue to get seated. They say sth in japanese lodly sometimes. We thought like they do so once a high tip is giben, we tried it but didn't work
author: Erk E.

description: I definitely liked their Volcano and Spicy Scallop rolls but I dont think it is really worth so much hype. However the ambience is super casual and relaxed.
author: Arijit C.

description:
I would love to give Ryoko five stars. However, I cannot do that. The wait was about 20 to 30 minutes considering the place is really small there isn't much space to stand. I'm not one to complain but our server spilled my friends beer all over her coat. Then she walked off leaving the fizzy beer on our table. I would think she would apologize and know to get a new beer by herself but no. She instead looked dumbfounded when we asked for another since the one on the table was half gone and fizzy. This is not a fancy place, so I can understand that the customer service is not what you would expect but dam, at least offer to clean her jacket or a discount.

There was a live Dj that was nice and overall the prices are not bad.
author: Sara L.

description:
Recently went here and it was a Friday night-it came recommended by the hotel staff at the westin st Francis so my daughter and I went there.  It was a sort of long wait time.  However, you can write down the name and The size of your party on a
Clip board at the entrance, and they call you in the order that you check in depending on what kind Of table you want.  We were seated near the entrance at the sushi bar.  The service was very good.  

The miso soup was very good. My daughter is Seven  and only wants the broth and none of the little stuff that floats around in it.  They accommodate her requests.  I'm thinking this is a good place.  Then the sushi is served.  I like it.  They serve kanpyo maki (flavored gourd roll) this is a sign of a Sushi bar that really knows the subtle stuff.  They also have a good atmosphere and there was a DJ playing tunes which made it fun 

I will come back
author: James M.

description:
Price: unreasonable. $8.5 for 5 pieces of takoyaki. Not to mention other dishes. Definitely overpriced.

Sushi: below average. Ordered salmon, yellowtail, sweet shrimp, tamago, salmon roe and toro.
Sweet shrimp is the only one that's good.

Environment: really noisy and dark. 

The staff are nice and the atmosphere is relaxing and chill (DJ play live music). Maybe it's a good place to hang out with friends at night, but absolutely not an authentic Japanese restaurant to enjoy sushi.
author: In Ian C.

description:
Not great, but certainly not bad for a dinner for 2.  

Deep Fried Baby Octopus
