- absolutely delish, and lightly battered with a fine spiced flavor

Aka Uni
- my first time trying sea urchin - it was fishy and it melted in my mouth like butter.  i'd say i'm not really a fan

Salmon Toro
- super fatty and absolutely amazing, the tiny herbal garnish thing they put on top really compliments the flavor well!

Jumping Unagi 
- deep fried eel roll with plenty of avocado - deep fried is always good

Volcano Roll
- meh, it was like a roll with some peanut butter but not really memorable or spicy

Dragon Roll
- california roll with eel and avocado on the outside, pretty standard

Sexy Roll
- california rolls with salmon with baked kraft american cheese on top - the cheese is super processed and makes the salmon pieces stick together, but it's a unique taste 

the whole bill was $100, which initially seemed steep, but considering that there was a wide variety of things to try it was ok.  usually that kind of bill i would rather pay for either more substantial rolls or all sashimi though!

service was sparse but friendly

i wanted to see what all the hype was about, and it wasn't bad.  did it live up to the hype? certainly not.  would i come back?  probably not
author: Tina A.

description: This place was pretty fun! The service was pretty standard as was the food. I liked the ambiance and the DJ spinning, it put a nice little funky touch on the place. I wouldn't mind coming back and trying a few of their other options on a late night adventure.
author: Kanani S.

description:
Currently sitting here eating my dinner and felt the need to write a review asap.  Perhaps I can save you from wasting your time, your taste buds, and your money if you're looking at yelp tonight. 

I hate to leave bad reviews but I'd honestly give this place 2 stars at max. Yelp steered us wrong on this one.  This place is totally a tourist trap.  

Ordered four rolls: hot tuna, rainbow, their special Toro roll for the night, and some other deep fried tuna roll.  Only the Toro roll was decent imo, but none of them were worth the 30-40 minute wait.  I was happy that we only ordered 4 rolls and could leave to eat something else to fill up our bellies. 

Not sure how this place got so highly rated, but I'd highly recommend skipping the wait and going else where.  

**Nice wait staff though
author: Peggy L.

description: Meh - it's ok. Years ago when I first came to Ryoko's I thought it was super fresh and tasty. I came recently and did not think the same thoughts as before... if you're looking for a pretty legit sushi experience, there are other places in the city. The restaurant is kind of like a hole in the wall, since you have to go down into the basement level and then the tables are really close together. We ordered a pretty wide selection of rolls and sushi and the quality was a pretty wide-ranging mix. On the other hand, the fried tofu was really delicious, but it was fried so how could you go wrong? If there was absolutely no wait, I MIGHT come back again, but... it's not worth the wait.
author: Lily C.

description: This place is super crowded. Love the music that the Dj was playing tonight. The sushi were tasty and service was great, at least our waiter. So thank you.
author: Joana D.

description:
Ridiculous wait of 50 mins!!! What's that about?! 

Now, that I got that off my chest, Ryoko's is decent. But you do need that attitude that goes, "I'm so cool, I don't mind waiting 50 mins as long as I'm drinking my beer(s) coz this is THE best sushi joint in the area!" (not true)

Save yourself the headache of finding street parking and pony up for a garage space and PATIENTLY wait for delicious apps, fresh nigiri and jive ass rolls. I'm more of a sushi purist and simply prefer my fish over rice or by itself. But we had an out of towner with us so we ended up here. Locals, you will be one of the few SFers here since this place is tourist central and if you like the sound of foreign languages while you dine, this is the place for you.

The prices are (surprise!) higher than normal. Who charges $39.95 for 14 slices of sashimi with rice? I'm no sushi genius but unless you're giving me the whole fish, that is way overpriced. I did like the foods that we ordered (hamachi sashimi, spicy tuna rolls, edamame, wakame salad, etc) but you should order the ochazuke which comes with a generous chunk of salmon and rice in a dashi broth and it's only $6.50! Delish. 

There are far better options for sushi in SF without the obnoxious wait. Sayonara Ryoko's!
author: Janice C.

description: So, the great thing about the place is they are open late. However, the wait is always super long, the service is very slow. And talking about the food, the quality is so so. I wouldn't call their sashimi "fresh".
author: Alana P.

description:
Ryoko's holds a special place in my heart as its one of the first places I went to eat when I moved to the Bay many years ago. I remember thinking "this place seems really SF". And boy, was I right. Ryokos best described is an underground club-like sushi bar with fresh fish and great music and vibes.

Don't let the grungy super packed nature of this place fool you - the food is impeccable. They have a lot of fish flown in from Japan and their menu has lots of unique and delicious items. A lot of it is traditional - you won't really find much of the California-Fusion Japanese food here. A bit on the pricey side from other options in the area, but well worth the extra dough. 

You must try the fresh fishes of the day - a lot of them you probably want to Google since they are usually pretty obscure. I've tried glassfish here which is by far the weirdest thing I've had at a Japanese restaurant in SF. Aside from the nigiri and sashimi specials, I'd recommend getting rolls from their menu as well as appetizers. I love their takoyaki and their sunomono salad. I think a lot of their rolls are simple, but it really lets their usage of ingredients and fresh fish shine through. 

Service is rushed, but friendly, especially if you sit at the bar. Great vibes here - usually can strike some good conversations with fellow sushi-goers. Lots of locals come here frequently and the chefs are all super friendly. Great place for quick eats or for a authentic meal. There is usually a line however, but since the place is decently large and they flip tables fast the wait isn't that bad. Open super late so great option for late night munchies or bar hopping!
author: Kimberlie L.

description:
I'm originally from LA. After driving for about 5 1/2 hours and checking in to the hotel, I was starving for some food. Starving is an understatement. I was famished. I saw that this place had decent stars and 45 minute out the door so I was confident that this was a good place to dine in for dinner. 

We ordered tempura, dragon roll, and sexy roll. Never tasted anything so unswalloable. Dragon roll's unagi wasn't prepared well, with bones still intact 
And the unagi had extreme taste of fishiness. I have eaten enough of unagi in LA to know that this is not how unagi usually tastes like. We had to remove the unagi from the roll and eat the roll without it. It wasn't prepared well....

Then we waited another 20 minutes for the sexy roll. When it finally came out, OMFG. It was in a tin foil. The salmon was clearly over cooked and tasted like canned tuna.  I mean it was so dry and sauce was so uneven. The roll was so dried on the top and soaked in sauce at the bottom. This was even nastier than the dragon roll. 

Do not bother ordering drinks. We ordered one Sapporo and sprite. Both were flat. I might of have just ordered sugared water. Service is very mediocre. Nothing spectacular. 

I honestly DO NOT UNDERSTAND how this type of sushi restaurant had 45 min wait. Is this what SF thinks is good sushi? I was honestly so confused. Did I mention that this sushi place is much more expensive than LA? Maybe I have higher standards from sushi in LA but I just don't understand. Not my cup of tea.
author: Julia HR L.

description:
Thanks to Ryoko's for a really fun and honestly unforgettable birthday dinner earlier this month. I came here with a friend pretty late on a Saturday night, like 11:45pm late, after showing up to another SF sushi spot that had already closed its kitchen, but that turned out to be a blessing after all. There's a "bouncer" at the door (he was very nice) and it's a bit downstairs so it feels a little extra cool for a dinner spot. We had a bit of a wait, but only maybe 20 minutes.

We were seated right next to the dj (yeah there's a dj) which actually wasn't too loud like I was a little worried it may be. The dj "booth" is actually a closed grand piano.... which I can't decide if I love or loathe. I had a potted plant with me I'd bought earlier in the day - we were Ubering everywhere and hadn't been home - and we joked that the table was for 3; when we arrived at our table, there was a little stool for my plant (+1). Now, that actually makes a lot of sense when you think about it, since it frees up table space for more food and drink.

We ordered quite a bit to start and a bottle of sake for the two of us -- we also jokingly asked for a third shot glass, which they obliged (+2).

Miso soup: it was your standard miso soup, but I liked that it was more miso-y than just salty.

Steamed edamame: it was firm, not overdone at all, but it was served cool (or had been left out after steaming too long before making it to our table) and I'm not too about that.

Beef oroshi - seared premium black angus beef slices with grated radish and ponzu sauce: I love rare steak, as rare as I can get it, and I love me some carpaccio. This dish did not disappoint. The meat was caramelized on the outside and that combination of rich and a little-bit-chewy that a perfectly rare steak has. The ponzu dipping sauce was just the sweet and salty mix to balance the meat out.

Deep fried soft shell crab: I'm not the biggest fan of deep fried stuff, and soft shell crab can sometimes come out more fried-coating than crab, but the ratio was good here. The meat was flavorful (for crab) and it was surprisingly light.

Sake nigiri: this is always a go-to at sushi spots and how I assess if a place is worth getting fancier, like market price, nigiri later in the meal. Like traditional nigiri, wasabi was placed between the fish and the rice, so if you're like me and don't enjoy wasabi much, be warned.

Unagi nigiri: this was not your typical sushi bar unagi nigiri, this was the softest, most melt-in-your-mouth fish I think I've ever had, no chewing required (well, besides the seaweed and rice). We got a second order of it before even finishing the first. This is an absolute MUST.

I asked for toro (tuna belly) but they were out of it. My friend asked for sake toro, not on the menu, maybe on the specials(?), but they had it! We got two orders of nigiri, twice over the course of our meal. It was absolutely melt in your mouth. Salmon belly is my favorite nigiri and it made my belly very happy.

My friend also ordered hamachi kama (yellowtail collar), I think it might have been on the specials board? It was the best kama I've ever had, with much thicker (read: more) flesh that was super juicy and umami while still coming off the bone like butter. The meat itself isn't mindblowing (in general, this one was pretty tasty) but dipped in the ponzu sauce, it's an orgasmic experience. Just about every bite, I closed my eyes and smiled while I savored it.

The waitress recommended some bonito dish to us and we said, why not? I've never had bonito in any form besides flaked, so this was a treat. It's super meaty, like a tuna or mackerel; my friend ate most of it since it was dressed with too spicy a sauce for me. But what I did eat, I enjoyed!

When I was in the restroom at the start of the meal, my friend had mentioned to our waitress that it was my birthday, and she came and sang me happy birthday with some little mochi ice cream balls. They even put three toothpicks in (one for my plant!! +3).

My friend settled the bill but I know it was a lot -- this place isn't the cheapest option around by a long shot, but it's worth it for the quality of the fish, the fun environment and attentive, knowledgeable staff, and variety of offerings of specialty dishes and types of nigiri. It's a special occasion place for sure, but very special in my opinion.

There are some weird af rolls on their menu I'd be down to try with like, 6 other people so everyone can just have one bite if nobody likes it (peanut butter and flying fish roe on the Volcano roll??? American cheese on the Sexy roll?? wtf).
author: Keridwyn R.

description:
1/31/15:  First thing first: this place IS NOT TWO $.  It is easily $$$$!!!  I want to make that clear because we were really in for a surprise when we got here.  The reviews are great, and 2 $'s--awesome!  So we walked 2mi to get here through some REALLY rough parts of town, got seated, cracked open the menu... and WOW, this place is really expensive.  Trust me--if you're a guy, there's no way you will leave full without eating at least $60 worth of stuff.  Have no clue how this place could have gotten $$ next to their title.  We spent ~$200 for 3 and I can still eat about 2x what I got.

Moving on, it looks very friendly inside and cozy.  Small space with lots of happy people crammed in.  Doesn't look all that fancy, but is certainly done up Japanese style.  Big huge bar.  Lots of happy people.  Very casual.  Even a bunch of people sitting on the stairs waiting for a table.  Not something you would associate with $$$$ prices.

But alas, the place is definitely in the upper-tier of cost... say even competitively priced to a place like Nobu.  So, is the cost deserved?....

1. Namacho Honjozo Sake 300ml $25:  As the menu said, a little on the sweeter side, but not a "sweet" sake.  Was smooth.  Okay.  6/10

2. Fried Cheese $5:  Probably, other than the prices, the only real disappointing moment.  Just some cheese rolled into won ton skins and fried.  Like zero effort here.  Served with an unimpressive sauce.  Skip this, trust me.  2/10

3. House Salad $5.95:  Nothing fancy here.  Just a standard selection of greens.  Nothing Japanese about this one except maybe the dressing.  4/10

4. Hama Kama $17.50:  This would be the collar (rear section of head) of a hamachi fish.  And gawd, it is REALLY good.  I've had salmon collars, tuna collars, etc., at many places, and I think this one is the best I've ever had.  The meat is so juicy, so buttery.  Amazingly tender.  Totally melts in your mouth.  My only complaint is that the skin is not as crispy as it can be, but they serve it upside down, so I guess... whatever.  9/10

Alright.... so, now we are getting to the sushi.  Here's the deal: their pieces are small.  Much smaller than the typical sushi place in California.  Now, when I was in Japan I would say that they tend to make their sushi in a similar size and style, so it's probably the case that other places here make theirs bigger to seem a better deal.  But anyway, here, it is damn small.  If you're hungry you'll want to order 2x as much as you normally would.

5. Nigiri Sushi Dinner $39.95:  So here's the first example of their pricing.  It's nearly $40 for 9!!! pieces of nigiri, and some California roll.  Insane.  I need at least 2-3x of these to be full.  Again, these pieces are SMALL.

BUT............ OMFG it's GOOD SUSHI.  I think this is the most tasty sushi I've had since moving up to the Bay Area 2 years ago!  So fresh!  Everything was so flavorful and so clean.  Nothing overly fancy looking here, just really really really high-quality sushi.  So, again, ignoring my expectations from a $$ Yelp restaurant, and the uber casual environment, .... as a $$$$ place, keeping in mind even the simpleton California rolls was extraordinarily good.... 10/10

6. Masaba (Mackerel) Nigiri 3pc $8.95:  Man, that's some good mackerel.  So tasty.  Yet, does not have that gritty fibrous taste of the not-so-good ones.  Has a bit of that slight crunch, and just totally melts in your mouth afterwards.  One of the best.  10/10

7. Uni (Sea Urchin) Sashimi $15.80:  So, the sashimi uni vs the nigiri version only really differs in that the sashimi is served on a shiso leaf, and the nigiri is of course on rice.  Otherwise each "1pc" is made up of 2 chunky and short smaller pieces.  Typically the uni I've had is longer, but these are short and cute.  Zero fishiness.  Zero bitterness.  So.... clearly extremely fresh and high-quality.  However, I do miss some bite.  A little too perfect for me.  9/10

8. Uni (Sea Urchin) Nigiri 2p $15.80:  See #7.

9. Unagi (BBQ Eel) Nigiri 3p $11.25:  Beautiful pieces.  Great tasting.  But I think not particularly special, but clearly well cooked.  8/10

10. Hamachi Toro Nigiri 3pc $13.50:  The cheaper toro, apparently.  But still damn good.  Again, that crispness of ultra fresh fish is combined with that buttery sensation.  Divine.  And compared to the tuna toro, not too bad of a price.  10/10

So, the key here is to ignore your subconscious instincts to expect cheaper eats after seeing the $$ next to the title, and seeing the extremely casual surroundings.  Except to spend a fortune and then you will enjoy yourself a lot more.  This is some of the very best sushi I have ever found up here that does not have a Michelin star, and I'm sure you'd love it (as long as your friend picks up the bill.)

5/5

#japanese #sushi #sashimi
author: Dean C.

description:
Came here at 9pm on a Saturday night because the place I wanted to go to up the street was closed. The guy outside told me it would be a 10-15 minute wait since I was by myself. Took 45 minutes to get seated and the check in list was not being seated in order. 

When I got seated, a server came by quickly to ask if I wanted drinks. I ordered an Asahi on tap which was considerably cheap for the price. It wasn't until another 10 minutes when I finally waved someone down to place my order. 

I ordered the chirashi and man was it one of the worst ones I've had at any sushi bar that can maintain a 4-star at over 2k reviews. It was loaded with an assortment of low-tier fish that was most not fresh except for maybe the salmon but only when compared to the utterly garbage fish like the overly salty eel and dry eel. 

For $31 for the chirashi, there were no premium cuts of fish like sweet shrimp or uni. The cuts given were small and did not taste well together. Why there was asparagus inside the bowl is beyond me. $35 before tip/tax can get you a much fuller and higher quality meal elsewhere.
author: Raymond L.

description:
I used to come here pretty often, actually, and it was good. But my last time visit was such a disappointment . 

Good, because:
1. Bar 
2. Good environment 

Bad, because of : 
1.  Bad quality fish. It got worse, it used to be better. 
2. Very bad quality for rolls. Plain. 
3. Price - overpaying for the quality of items you order.
author: Jenna F.

description: Great food and great service! We yelped and found this place and satisfied  it's very busy place and no reservations, so better to get there before opening time
author: Ji P.

description:
I've came here for numerous occasions. 
It's definitely worth the wait I must say. 
I usually order their nigiri as the fish they have are absolutely amazing as fresh. 
The uni they use are also flown in from Japan.
Reasonably priced too.
I believe they serve food until 1:30am.

Probably the best sushi restaurant in nobhill.
Try to arrive as soon as they're open or if not perhaps later would be good.
author: Alui L.

description:
From the tongue of an Asian girl. 

A friend recommended me this place and the queue was long before the restaurant even opened. So I had high expectations of its food. I had NYE dinner here and it was a full house (lucky we lined up 10 minutes before it opened)! 

I didn't quite like it, the food was average. The portion was small and thus is pricey for its small serving! 

The service was not satisfactory because the server was in a rush (perhaps to attend other tables as well) and thus did not offer a good service. 

My orders were: 
VOLCANO ROLL - 2/5

CRUNCHY CRAB ROLL - 2/5

HIYASHI WAKAME - 3/5 - Typical wakame salad, - too small but its fresh!

JUMPING TUNA - 3/5 

SABA SHIOYAKI - 3/5 - Yummy and healthy but way too much bones (hurt me). 

TODAY'S SPECIAL FISH - 1/5 - Won't order this anymore, spent so much time trying to get the bones out and ended up swallowing some. 

IKURA, TAMAGO, TORO SUSHI - 3/5 - Typical

SALMON SKIN ROLL - 2/5

CHIRASHI - 3/5 - Fresh but too pricey for a low-key small restaurant. 

MATCHA ICE CREAM AND MATCHA MOCHI ICE CREAM - 3/5- Nothing special
author: Sharlene P.

description: Love the atmosphere. But for everybody though but really cool if you're looking for an up beat dinner and great sushi's.
author: Franck U.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night around 8pm as a party of two, got seated within 5 minutes. We were both starving and I was willing to splurge for our first sushi in a while.. 

We began with the seaweed starter ($5) which came out immediately with our waters. It was pretty tasty but unfortunately there was basically half a handful's worth, a theme that would continue throughout the meal. Our meal was several sushi rolls: the Alaskan A's (~$7), the Tahoe (~$7), the Golden Gate (~$10), the 49ers (~$13), and the spicy scallops...except we never got the spicy scallops as the waiter somehow didn't record it. 

First of all, our rolls arrived after a lengthy, probably 30 minute wait (meanwhile, the table next to us, which ordered after us, got their sushi before us, as well as their next order of sushi). And when it came, boy was it a disappointment. Normally I think of rolls as being at least 6-8 pieces...here the rolls are maximum 6 pieces and the cheaper rolls only had 5 pieces. The pieces were incredibly thin too, and cut in uneven shapes and sizes. Our chan-chan (college campus) sushi was better, gosh darn it! Basically, imagine a normal sized sushi roll, and cut it in half haphazardly, and that's what you get here. The sushi itself was solid if unspectacular. But the price for the quantity and wait is outrageously bad. Adding along careless order management (the table next to us also had a missing edamame order somehow so it seems to be an anecdotal trend) equates to a poor sushi experience.  

I was really disappointed, given the good reviews. We were still hungry after eating the impoverished rolls, and God knows how long we'd have to wait for the next order, so we ended up getting sandwiches down the street at Bite (which were phenomenal sandwiches btw). 

Bottom line: This place is a bar...that just happens to serve sushi. We won't be back.
author: Kevin G.

description: We happened to find this place trying to find food the night before Thanksgiving. The only place open around with good Yelp rating was Ryoko's. So we made our way from the Sheraton on Fisherman's Wharf to this place. Driving in San Francisco and seeing the hilly roads of San Francisco for the first time made this little trip very exciting. Once there, we took a few seconds to find this place as it is behind a little door on a practically empty street at night and this place is underground too. Once we entered, we knew that this was the coolest Sushi bar we have ever seen. There was music playing in the background and the place had a very casual setting. It almost didn't feel like a Japanese sushi parlor at all. We chose to sit at the sushi bar and got spots immediately however there was a huge line that kept building for tables even at 11pm in the night. The menu showed that they had a lot of eel rolls and we love eel. But they ran out of eel on that particular night so no eel for us! We placed our orders with some rolls. The food came in pretty quickly and it all tasted very good. I wouldn't say it was the best but not bad at all. And since this place is open till 2am, it makes a great hanging spot as a late night joint with friends over good food instead of oily bar food.
author: Oly M.

description: I've been here a few times. Great place! The quality of the ingredients is really good.
author: Rajveer S.

description:
This place was okay, in my opinion. Not fantastic, but not terrible. Overall, I would give it 3.5 stars. With all the great food in the city, I'm shocked that this place has so many reviews and so many good reviews. The service was pretty good for it being so busy, but I thought the food was sub-par.

FOOD: 3 stars.
Most people know that I am EXTREMELY picky when it comes to sushi, so take this with a grain of salt. The food was nothing outstanding. There's not a large selection of rolls to choose from and they were out of a few things that night, which sucked. We tried to "customize" a few things and they said they couldn't do it...I was so confused. There's only been a few other places that I've been to where they couldn't "customize" a roll. The quality of fish was really good, though. I just wish that overall, they had a better menu. *I continue to quote the word customize because my request for customization was placing salmon on top of one of their rolls on the menu* 

ATMOSPHERE: 2 stars.
So packed in here OMG. From the minute you walk in the door, there are people lining the stairs waiting for a table. It is extremely dark and super tight. I could practically hold hands with the table next to us. We sat at the table by the door which was really annoying because people were hovering right over our table the entire time. Not only is that gross, it's also super annoying. 

SERVICE: 4.5 stars.
Honestly the service was really good for how packed and busy it was. Although it took awhile, our server was really on top of everything. She wasn't too overwhelmed with all the chaos going on, which was pretty impressive. 

I don't think I would come back here - with all the sushi places in a one mile radius of this place, you could probably find a better place. Overall very average.
author: Zoe Y.

description:
love this place even though there is usually a really long wait for the table and food. We got the yellowtail with scallions, pokemon roll, a fried crab roll, spicy tuna roll and the volcano roll. We also got a small sake which is more than enough for two people and only $5!

The standouts were definitely the pokemon, spicy tuna and volcano roll! The pokemon is citrusy and so light and refreshing as is the spicy tuna with just enough kick. The volcano roll is super interesting and regardless of the peanut butter in it, I will definitely get it again!

Also love the ambience with the cool classic jams!
author: Rachel N.

description:
Came here the other week for dinner. 

Parking first off was awful. Parked at a garage and walked a handful of blocks but that's to be expected in the city.

Wait was about 25 minutes. If you see people standing outside that's a bad sign. Wait will be long. 

I had the chirashi bowl. Not impressed. But I also had the pork belly which was tasty and worth ordering. Shrimp tempura was average. 

Seating is very tight. I sat at the bar. Loud. 
Overall just okay.

Won't be back.
author: Jewelyn T.

description:
Don't arrive and hour before closing.  Their fryer was off and many items on the menu were unavailable.  Can't totally complain in a city where most restaurants are closed after the 10pm.  Also this restaurant does not offer take out.  I assume because of their large raw selection. 

Quirky vibe this place.  Security sits outside the door in the cold, feels a bit intimidating. Walk down the stairs and the music is pumping. Superb selection of music by the way.  Tribute to the musicians displayed on the walls. It's fun here!  

Sashimi was a bit bland but the sake did not disappoint.  I think the vibe is what is appealing here.
author: Jill D.

description: Anytime I'm in the area I go to Ryoko's! It's always busy so make sure to go early. The atmosphere is interesting with a DJ playing on certain nights. I always get the raw oyster special and shiitake mushroom miso soup. The rolls are all good!!! But I usually get the volcano and shrimp tempura roll.
author: Brina M.

description: Seemed like more of a locals spot, which was nice.  Less crowded and the food was pretty fantastic.  Quality of the fish was good and great service from the sushi bar. I'd go here again.
author: Anna S.

description:
Came here because I was shopping downtown and craving sushi. Ebisu is my go to spot and they were closed, so we thought we'd try this place out. I still prefer Ebisu though, they have more options there.

The quality of the fish was on point, but I just wish they had a larger selection of rolls. Watch out for the volcano roll- that thing is super spicy. We also ordered the dragon roll, pokemon, and spicy scallop roll. They were all delicious, but the portions are kind of small for the price that they charge.

I wish they had better appetitzers as well. Their menu was not very exciting.

I don't think I would come back here again unless I was downtown, otherwise I would just go to Ebisu.
author: Jessica S.

description: Nice vibe, good sushi, great location... Fun atmosphere, must try this place at least once.  Can be a bit of a wait at times but that only means one thing: people don't generally wait in line to eat at places that suck.
author: Josh G.

description:
Reviews are correct. You will wait 45 mins but it's worth it. The only weird part is there is no waiting room so people stand on the stairs watching you eat. Music was popping. Servers are running everywhere. It appears they are understaffed as the hostess is also a server for like half of the room too. 

Recommend the Volcano roll-peanut butter works! 
Pokémon wasn't as flavorful as I imagined. Other rolls were ok: jumping tuna and Alaskan. Jumping tuna is fried and served with a spicy sauce. 

Would recommend for the experience though.
author: Monique M.

description: The sushi is nice. It is kinda pricet. The beer we ordered was not cold and flat. Service was good and fun music. Overall a good place to eat at.
author: Phuong Rose S.

description:
Came here with my bf. We love sushi and we've tried plenty, but this place is over-hyped. The wait took a long time, small place, and service kinda slow. This place is a cozy little den down some stairs but it was definitely mediocre. If you're looking for something better, I suggest elephant sushi. We got the rainbow roll, and a baked roll, which was decent. I wasn't too impressed by this place. We sat at the bar, and service still took some time. They have alcohol here but when I asked for a mojito they didn't have that. 


The only plus is that this place opens later. 
I wouldn't come here again in the future, its one of those lets try it once and thats it kinda thing.
author: Amy Y.

description: One of my favorite Japanese restaurants food is fresh and amazing had the beef teriyaki tempura fried chicken and tuna roll everything on point.
author: Reynol M.

description: Very underground looking restaurant, but the sushi was phenomenal. Really good Red Sea urchin Sushi! Don't judge the book by its cover on this place!
author: Kelvin K.

description:
Probably the best Japanese food in a basement dive bar setting. If you're looking for very good sushi in a bar with a DJ setting, and not pretentious in the traditional sense, this is perfect.

+ Fresh seafood
+ Good service (for a bar setting)
+ Nice vibe

- missed in a few details
- presentation is ok

For both negatives it's not their schtick so it works!
author: Minh H.

description: Not sure why this place has such high reviews. I tried it out and not all the sushi was tasty. Waiters were in a hurry and I did not get the super clean vibe I would like from a sushi place.
author: Hassane S.

description: I have only ever been to Ryoko's when it was someone else's idea. I think it's a cool spot with fair prices, but the sushi really leaves a lot to be desired. Nothing was bad. It's just that nothing was really that good either. I get the same exact (if not better) quality sushi at Safeway, minus the rice being fresher at Ryoko's. I can't hate on much. I just can't love on anything here either. The space is cool. That's it. Good quality tuna. Terrible cocktails and desserts, complete with cheesy whipped cream and a maraschino cherry on top. Ryoko's is someone's cash cow. There's very little love put into the quality of the ingredients or the menu. Grab some Safeway sushi, turn off all the lights in your house, and put on some Spotify. There, you've got Ryoko's for 10% of the price.
author: Jared R.

description: The worst sushi experience I have ever had in San Francisco. Fish is not fresh, couldn't eat the sashimi at all. The rolls are plain and so loosely made that stuffs come out when it gets to our table. Presentation is absolutely ugly for such high prices. 2 stars for fast service and nice waitress. Can't recommend this place and won't ever come back.
author: Thao P.

description:
Coming from a huge sushi lover I was highly disappointed with this sushi place. I dont even know how their rating is so high. For a guy who dislikes mcdonalds or fast food in general I woulda picked to eat mcdonalds over this place anyday. My gf and i spent $120 for 4 rolls 2 drinks and 2 miso soups. I would have rsther spent that $120 at a fancy steakhouse or other restaurant. Lets just say I would have rather bought $120 dollars worth mcdonalds and pass em out to the homeless people.

Seating is crowded and it only holds up to 45 guest at a time. 

Dragon roll for $20 and was skimped

The raw fish wasn't as fresh as it could have been. Not really much of a variety in rolls. For a 4 star joimt id expected them to have bento boxes or some sort of food. This is more of a bar food like enviornment.

Miso soup was really salty.

Only thing i liked was the fried oysters.

The music was a little too loud, to the point where our waitress couldn't hear us and had to keep repeating ourselves multiple times. 

Would not recommend this place at all
author: SplitSecond A.

description:
The food was mediocre for my taste. It seems more like junk food Japanese since the atmosphere makes you just want to get drunk while you dine.

The live music by hongsolo ruins the pleasure of eating authentic Japanese food. 

His demeanor is that of a drunk perv, and should not be permitted.
author: Crystle D.

description: OMG.....hands down the freshest and BEST sushi I have ever had‼This gem is down in a basement and well worth the wait!  When you get there you sign yourself in and stand and wait in the way of everyone. It has a great hip vibe and they rush you a bit but the service was good. The most important thing for me is how fresh the seafood was. I will always get back there anytime I am in San Francisco. I had scallops and tuna....yummmm
author: Laurie L.

description: We were looking for a good sushi restaurant and we found a great one. There was a long line but no fears they have awesome staff that bring drinks while you wait. All the staff are attentive. Sushi is made with love. Fresh fish with no fishy smells.
author: Nina A.

description: I was in Sf around 11 pm. Most places were closed obviously, I came across Ryoko and saw it had good ratings so I had to try it out. When we first came the security guard outside was kind, same for the rest of staff. They were all helpful and really kind to us. I ordered miso soup, California roll, jumping california, and shrimp symphony. I did enjoy the three rolls but the jumping California felt a little greasy and I just got tired of it after awhile. Mind you each roll had six pieces. The more I ate the jumping California roll, the more my head started to hurt because I just did not enjoy the fried sushi style. I also notice about 80% of their sushi had mayo, so from a mayo hater I kind of just had to suck it up and eat the ones with mayo but I couldn't really taste it anyways so it was all good. My boyfriend ordered the Pokémon roll and Philadelphia roll. He told me that the Pokémon roll tasted pretty much like a sandwich and thought the Philadelphia was okay. Overall, the food was okay. It wasn't super amazing. I've just been to so many sushi places that were much better. I really did dig their miso soups though. Maybe I will be back again someday to try out different sushi.
author: Tanya D.

description: Great food, great atmosphere, fair warning that's it's crowded and cramped but the food is well worth it
author: Jacob G.

description: The fish here is soooooo fresh!!!! The sushi chef took really good care of us kept bringing us different things that weren't on the menu.. we will definitely be back here whenever we go to the Giants game !!
author: Greg B.

description: Went mid evening solo and sat at sushi bar. Very accommodating and friendly staff. Excellent rolls sushi, miso soup and seaweed salad. Will definitely return if I'm the area.
author: Jeff K.

description: I wasn't impressed with the quality of the sushi, nor the portion of the pieces. Thin cuts and small overall size. I had Nigiri, Blue Fin tuna, salmon and unagi. I left hungry.
author: Zareh H.

description:
Stopped in Sunday night; the place was packed at 6 pm.

This restaurant is located below street level and feels kinda cool; everyone was having a good time - the vibe was fun.

We were promptly seated in a nice cubbie hole place; kinda cozy!

We enjoyed various sashimi: standout was the Uni from Japan. Melt's in your mouth: creamy, silky, goodness with just a tiny bit of saltiness. Amazing. We each had our own order.

We shared the special shrimps, called Ama-Ebi : the main part is sashimi style and the head is deep fried in a beautiful way.

The scallop and mango roll was good and light.

The roll with BBQ'd eel and veggies was tasty.

We shared some Monk fish liver that was pureed; it was deeply creamy and rich.

Two House salad's; each was crispy, fresh and good. Chunks of tomatoe and fancy slivered persian cucumbers with a splash of nice dressing.

The hot tea was good.

Decor: basic+homey, retro 1970's disco, R&B tunes blare out.

Customer service: very good. 

Parking: none, you have to find it on the street or a multi-level. You could park at Union Square and walk ten minutes.

The feel good vibe here and fine quality sashimi is to be experienced.

For $149 without tax/tip. We left $175.
author: Bert K.

description: Superb Selection of Japan's finest fish and shellfish. I've been eating sushi for over 25 years and needed to google some of the selections. The vibe is loud, energetic and fun. The service well orchestrated and paced in this busy sushi joint. The standout special roll was shiso, uni, ikura...orgasmic
author: Lisa G.

description: I don't get why this place has such a high review, maybe because it's the only sushi spot open until 2 am. This place decor hasn't change since the 70s. Wooden panels on the walls and  old seats in a basement is what you get. There's a Dj playing hip hop music, more like a crappy underground club. The sushi is overly priced and very minimal, not tasty at all. If you're looking for sushi after the club and wanna smell and see all the drunks, who leave the club. By all mean, this is the place. For me it wasn't worth it.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Yes I am a fan, and here is why:
- open late night
- great sushi selection 
- not too expensive
- EDM playing in the background 

As I was enjoying my nigiri omakase, I couldn't help but notice how attentive wait staff is.

You do need to put your name down on the wait list by the host station so please don't be like me and just wait in line.

Also I recommend getting a toro salmon and toro tuna and skip regular maguro and sake.
author: Anelya S.

description: This was a miss for me. Not sure why this place is zagat rated but it sure went down hill. Restaurant is downstairs and has more of a dive bar atmosphere than respectable sushi restaurant. Walls were all blue and paint looked old and chipped, even under low lighting. Tables were old wood tables and was very sticky. Music was loud and the whole place felt really cramped. We ordered a couple of the popular rolls and some apps but nothing stood out.
author: Yenn T.

description: This place became a favorite of mine instantly! After a long day being in traffic being frustrated, we happened to come across this place and it turned my night around the delicious sushi and the fun conversations with the owner/sushi chef definitely made the atmosphere enjoyable. We learned a bit of the places history and it was nice to learn its in the family from mother to son.... i cant exress how enjoyable the place was but i will say that by the end of the night i had fallen in love with this place! And this place has become a standard for me when it comes to sushi!
author: Roxanna T.

description: Probably a reason this place was our second option when we couldn't get into the Yacht Club up the street. There's a bouncer outside for some reason like a club; wasn't sure why until I walked in and it sounded like Ibiza. I think there's a DJ inside, so it's definitely ear split-tingly loud in there. It's also seemingly in a basement with very few or no windows, so there's nowhere to escape it. Food was not very flavorful, and the chirashi was really disappointing: unevenly cut fish, small amount of rice for the quantity of fish you receive, and unwillingness to modify the order (we asked for no tomago or ebi; I get it if it's mixed in and you can't leave it out, but the eggs and shrimp were literally placed on top, inside the bowl...you can't just not place that on top at the end before you serve it? C'mon man. The rolls were uninspired and not very satisfying. The beef oroshi was the lone highlight; pretty sad when medium rare beef over some generic green salad is the best part of a sushi restaurant meal. You have to remind the staff frequently if you need refills or any other food items; I get it's busy, and I'm patient, but 20 minutes for some wasabi? The place isn't that big. Won't be back, very expensive for what you get, and memorable for the wrong reasons.
author: Dan M.

description: This was a fun place!!! Great atmphosere to let loose and enjoy a night out. It is small and packed but that adds to the atmosphere. One of the best Sushi I have had in a while. Fresh and a good selection with quick service and very attentive.  Prices are reasonable. Definitely coming back!
author: Stepan S.

description:
Interesting underground restaurant. 

Rolls and sashimi were fresh, however I felt really cramped. 

I may go again if I had a small group if 2, but couldnt eat comfortably with a group of 3 nearby the stairs and piano.
author: Claire W.

description:
This place was good. The sushi was well prepared. 

The toro, fried chicken, pork skewers and hamachi stood out to me. I wouldn't say the food is special but this place dos basic sushi and small plates well.
author: Ian C.

description: Amazing food. Had excellent reviews on yelp so I trusted it. Best meal I've had in San Francisco. I will be back up on my next visit to the city
author: Janine S.

description: Honestly i liked old ryoko better. Now its just too overpriced and becoming too basic. Casual and jazzy atmosphere but price is overly expensive. Might as well go to high end too japanese restruant where you dont have to wait 30-40 mins and that takes reaervation on the weekend.
author: Angela K.

description:
Great late night bite. We stopped in moments before last call and hurried to pick sushi. I settled on four rolls to share with my husband and was not disappointed. The food came out quickly and the quality was excellent. The shiitake sushi roll was an unexpected delight. Mushrooms have a natural meatiness, but their use as the star of a sushi roll was inspired. The tuna in the Tahoe roll was ruby red and flavorful. The spicy scallop was very fresh and rounded out beautiful by the addition of shiso. Finally, the sakepeper (or something like that) was a beautiful fatty salmon, capers and shiso. It was so clean and actually quite remarkable.

Service was prompt and just warm enough. The host wasn't afraid to mince words and let us know that we better hurry. I actually appreciate that candor at 1:30am. It was the perfect end of a VERY long travel day.
author: Lauren J.

description: Ryoko's is a cute little place in the basement and it comes with a live dj. The blue fin toro sushi, scallop sushi, uni sushi, spicy scallop roll, fried oysters, agedashi tofu, and the dragon were really good. It's definitely a good environment for a fun crowd.
author: Jessica Y.

description: We waited almost an hour for our table.  Was looking forward to good sushi. Unfortunately, the chirashi I ordered was the worst I have ever had. It was a bowl of left over fish, bad cuts, chewy and over priced ($30). The two ice teas were water down. Waitress was slow and forgetful, missed two items we ordered. On top of all, the restaurant has no air condition. Will definitely not return.
author: Erica L.

description: I ordered sasimi dinner. it was chef's recommendation dish. Yes, I really expected it would be the best dish!! But I found out a hair on sushi. disappointed
author: Shauna K.

description:
It's terrible.
Hair came out of sasimi.
And the chef who makes sasimi is smoker.
Until eating, I went to another restaurant.
Did ZAGAT evaluate correctly?
ZAGAT is also suspicious.
author: Richard J.

description: Sushi late nite is good, service at the sushi bar is terrible. Never received my drink order, service was no. Existent. After server acknowledged the poor service, I waited for a very long time for the check. No accountability, won't return!!!
author: Rick S.

description:
Totally worth the wait ! Amazing staff. Great ambiance.
Even on a late Friday night they got me and my friends in.
author: Cynthia F.

description: Great place. DJs is playing music, happy atmosphere and the food is awesome. Recommended if you are in the area.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
After reading the previous yelp reviews about the wait, I made sure to arrive early! I got to the scene at 5:40pm and was luckily the first person in line, which meant I was able to immediately snag a table when doors opened 20 minutes later. By the time we left, there was a line going out the door, so it seems that arriving early is definitely a must, as they don't accept reservations.

I ordered the Orange Delight and the Spicy Golden Gate and I found both to be delicious. The salmon was fresh and soft, which is my top concern when it comes to sushi. 

The music selection is definitely interesting; a lot of EDM and pop, which made me feel as if I were at a club instead of an izakaya joint. 

I do have to say that I am not used to SF pricing just yet, so the meal did feel quite expensive for my taste.
author: Allison T.

description: This place was full of charm and excellent sushi.  The sexy roll was my favorite chioce but all were wonderful.  The staff is hard at work keeping up with the crowd, which is a task, but they were so pleasant too.  The woman's  bathroom has one toilet and is tiny, which may have been annoying anywhere else. -  but here, it just adds to the charm.  In general it is a small and cozy place so if you dont like to be close to your neighbors  or need lots of leg room this place isn't for you.   They even have a DJ that starts playing at 9, which is fun but not too loud.  It was just a really cool place with really excellent food.  Can't wait to go back next time I'm in town :)
author: Celsa G.

description: We arrived after the Chinese New Years Parade with the rest of the world and so amazed at the service. We did have a 20-30 min wait but after we were seated the waitress was quick to take our order, so very polite/helpfull and the food came fast! In my home town the sushi chefs can learn a thing or two. Would definitely come back.
author: TinaMarie B.

description:
Music was too loud. 
The size of the rice in nigiri is too small. 
Tamago yaki is not supposed to be layered. It should have a consistent texture.
author: Yuhuan J.

description:
I've been to quite a few, and this is my favorite sushi place in SF. Food is 4/5, but the unpretentious late night weekend vibes with the live music/dj push it to a 5! Service is quick and pleasant. Best of all, you can afford to eat to your hearts content with almost any budget. Expect a long line but short wait, despite the smaller location size.

Bonus points for entry being down easily-missed stairs for the 'underground' vibe, hah!
author: Jason J.

description: Excellent... Visiting San Francisco for work stumbled across this sushi restaurant close to my hotel highly recommend.
author: Schnickel F.

description:
Excellent amaebi nigiri, eel/avocado roll, salmon/avocado roll, eel/cucumber roll 

Good tamago

Would not re-order yellowtail/shiso/spicy mayo roll
author: Peter C.

description:
Perks of them are they open late night. I'm from socal so everything on this menu was more pricy than normal for me LOL. If you want good sushi, come down to socal. You'll find super fresh and mouthwatering sashimi. 


The bathroom was dirty here and the sushi didn't look all that fresh, but I was hungry so.... thanks for being open. 3 kudos to you for opening late!
author: Cindee P.

description:
Always a great late night hangout. Good selection of drinks and the crowd is always fun. 

Food is good. Love the appetizers.
author: Matt L.

description:
After a quick Yelp search, I ended up coming here because they're open until 2am which is so uncommon/refreshing in SF. Unfortunately the food was FAR less than stellar. I ordered the orange blossom and the sashimi dinner. The roll was bland and full of cucumber and the sashimi dinner plate was not fresh at all - very fishy tasting.  For $30 I expected the sashimi to be excellent! With so many great sushi restaurants in San Francisco, I definitely recommend skipping this place.   

+1 star because the live DJ on Wednesday night was amazing!
author: Cameron C.

description:
I came here for a dinner party, heard many good things about this place. We arrived around 7PM and it was packed, the wait line was all the way up to the stairs to outside, we waited about an hour. 

We had a party of 7 and so lucky for us we got the private room, super nice and cozy, however due to the long wait, the waiter told us we only have a minimum for an hour and half to eat. Exclusive indeed. I ordered their chirashi bowl and it was fresh and delicious. Quality of the fish was high, their sashimi scallops were sweet, fresh and yummy, my favorite!

I would definitely come here again, maybe on a day when the wait isn't so long.
author: Natalie L.

description:
I would rate it 5-stars when they bring back California Roll with real crab. Keep saying it's "not available today" for the last 1 year!

Definitely my go to Sushi spot in the city.
author: Saad Z.

description: The fish was fresh here, but very expensive: $6 for two small pieces of tuna sashimi that you eat in two bites. The grilled mackerel was decently sized, but still $9, just for a piece of inexpensive fish, nothing else. I did not enjoy the atmosphere: blaring reggaeton music and the staff screaming hello at each person that enters the restaurant. Not my scene.
author: Felicia C.

description: I came here by accident two weeks ago an I fell in love I've literally been looking for a sake and sushi restaurant Ryoko's is that place they had a Live DJ his whole set was dope!!! The waitresses were awesome and cute!!! The food was excellent they make everything fresh!!! The Sake is perfectly hot and they keep it flowing!!! Restroom was clean and it smelled good! This is a place for friends great social scene!!!! You'll definitely come again!!!!!
author: Rolin S.

description: This place is open late so decided to stop by and check it out. They have a DJ inside when we came in. Place was packed when we walked in. Ambience is just ok and interior can be better. I ordered mizo soup and it was a little salty than the usual Mizo soup that I get some other place. I ordered two sushi and both are very small and also flavor was just ok. Place also smells like Lysol spray the whole time. Not sure if I want to give this place another shot if I'm around SF.
author: Desee R.

description: Phenomenal sushi tonight. Incredibly fresh and delicious! There was a short wait, but at dinner rush hour and for the quality and VERY reasonably priced food we got, it was COMPLETELY worth it! Would def go back.
author: Mark M.

description:
Came in around 11:30PM and left around 1 or so. There's always a line of people waiting so I didn't expect otherwise. I figured the wait was worth it considering the food was really good. I've been here 7 times or so... key things that kept me coming back was the ambiance, DJ/music and the random Japanese words being shouted between employees lol. It felt like a very alive and welcoming place to socialize with friends and even strangers... little did I know how welcoming this restaurant was until tonight lol.

Once we were seated, we ordered the following 

- x2 Spider Crab Rolls (Crunchy Roll)
- x2 Spicy Golden Gate Roll
- 4 waters & 1 coke.

After our bellies were full and we were ready to head back home, I decided I'd to head to the bathroom since we lived 40 min north of SF (Marin). I came back from the bathroom to my boyfriend smiling / laughing. I wish he didn't tell me until we left the restaurant... " I saw a RAT run across the floor." 

I did the believe him until I personally saw it run across the floor!!! 

Bill / check was paid and we bolted out of there. Welcome to the SF sushi restaurant that features Disney Pixar characters from Ratatouille !!!!
author: Christina L.

description: 3.5 stars. My friends and I were there at 6pm on a Sunday (right when it opened), so we were able to get seated quickly. Within half an hour, there was a line out the door. It's a fun atmosphere - with old school hip hop and rap playing in the background and the staff shouting greetings when a customer arrives. The drinks have fun names (e.g. I got a "Tap dat ass").  I got a chirashi bowl ($30) and my friends got  6 various rolls (that probably clocked in at around $20 per roll). The sushi here is not cheap, but it's decent quality. My chirashi bowl was not the most beautiful chirashi bowl I've ever gotten and could have used more rice, but overall, the fish was fresh and it was tasty. The bowl had slices of asparagus and the tomago was chopped up into tiny cubes, which is unusual, but I didn't mind. Overall a fun experience with decent sushi. If you're looking for a more traditional "serene" environment, this is not the place for you.
author: Annie L.

description: Beware: another overhyped restaurant! The sushi here is not worth your $$ and the long wait! We called in and they quoted us approximately 45 minutes at first, but that turned into 1hr & 30 minutes before our table was ready. We started off with some of their special rolls: dragon, salmon, and deep fried bbq eel roll. The rolls are overpriced and skimpy, only the bbq eel tasted good but not great. Their grilled mackerel was standard. The only good thing about this place is their fresh fish selections.
author: Thuy N.

description: Showed up right after opening and it was slammed. Told a 20-30 minute wait. The hostess was very friendly and kept our drinks filled. Food is so fresh, unique, fun and delicious! Had sake nigiri, symphony roll, tiger roll, seaweed salad, and Pokémon roll. All amazing. The drinks were also made well. The whole staff cheers whenever anyone comes in. Despite being a full house, once we were seated food came very quickly. Great atmosphere, worth the wait!
author: Miranda S.

description:
Sushi was great. THe only downsize was
How packed the place was and how crowded was the waiting area. Good music available . 
Good variety of beers on draft .
author: Nina M.

description: Amazing sushi but loud as a night club. The tables are also very close to each other. I can hear my neighbors screaming over the loud music more than I can hear my date sitting across from me.
author: Amanda K.

description:
After spending several days in San Francisco, we decided to visit several Japanese restaurants. There were Japanese restaurants operated by Korean, Mongolians and Chinese. Although these restaurants offered good food, the sushi making craft is and should always be an art. There were seafood messily places on top of loosely packed rice in different sizes. We really needed a change. Therefore we stopped by Ryoko on the last day. Although it is located in a basement of one of San Francisco's many buildings this restaurant was a jewel. The food was crafted perfectly. They had original treats such as, Hamachi Kama (Blue fin collar) and Chicken Karaage (Deep fried battered chicken). Ryoko also offered a large selection of hot  and cold Sake and Shochu. The music was very loud, but that just added to the atmosphere. The only down side was being offered jigger glasses for the cold sake. This was quickly remedied with a request for slightly larger glasses. 
We were truly sorry for finding this so late in our vacation, but also glad we found it.
When in San Francisco I hope you have the opportunity to satisfy you Japanese palate at Ryoko. It will be worth it. 
This is a hidden gem. 
Good job to the Ryoko staff.
author: Curtis K.

description:
The mixed drinks here are AWESOME! Expect a long wait because this place is tiny, but definitely drink while you wait! 

It's stuffy in here, which is questionable since they serve raw meat. i tried the chicken karaage which was more meaty than fried which I enjoyed. The sushi rolls were just average tasting and on the pricey side. They were not even nice enough to take photos of honestly... I tried the Pokemon roll and dragon roll. Service is alright. Seems like they were understaffed that night since they were not as attentive as I would have liked. Had to flag down the server many times. 

I probably wont come back here again because it gave me the runs and a tummy ache all night long :( I couldn't even sleep. And I eat raw sushi ALL THE TIME.
author: Leah A.

description: Amazing SLEEPER of a Sushi spot!   Terrific, old school fun vibe.   Delicious, carefully curated and served menu rivaling some of the better places in The City.   Don't go to Akiko's and wait in line for the snobbery and sneers.  Come here for cheers, great food and old-school service!
author: Max K.

description:
This is a weird and fun place to eat sushi as it is a combination of both a restaurant and a night club as the music is very loud and they have a DJ. 

There was a bunch of people waiting to get a table when I got there, but the line moved pretty fast. We ordered five rolls and a seaweed salad, and we only waited for about 10 minutes to get our food. The food was amazing and reasonably priced. 

I had a great experience and I'm looking forward to coming back.
author: Cristian H.

description: Good food, fun energetic atmosphere and super friendly & efficient staff...definitely recommend sitting at the sushi bar to see the chefs in action...peanut butter roll ftw!!!!!
author: Chad K.

description:
Cool little underground sushi bar with music. The toro, scallop and uni was amazing! It is shipped straight from Japan. I never really liked uni but I had to try it and I'm glad I did. The uni didn't have a strong sea taste which the others I've tried did. It was buttery and melts in your mouth! Yum. 

We also ordered salmon and yellow tail sashimi. Salmon was good but the yellow tail was tough. 

Seaweed salad and fried tofu was pretty basic.

Note: we came before they opened which already had a line forming. So come before 6 if you don't want to wait in line.
author: Sandy S.

description:
This place was quite interesting:

Fun and loud atmosphere. If you are a in your 20s this place is something you'd really enjoy.

Food is good, not spectacular. I'd like to say it's not anywhere close to be fine dining quality.

All in all, deserves 4 stars for the overall experience provided.
author: Mr. Food G.

description: Absolutely amazing experience. Recommendation from our concierge at The Handlery and we were so glad we tried it. Sushi was phenomenal and included options direct from Japan as well as sushi sourced from other areas. Very friendly staff and even though there was a short wait to be seated the check-in process was very easy and efficient. Great atmosphere inside with DJ spinning mashup of house music with R&B. Very reasonable prices, especially for the outstanding quality of sushi like then o toro, chu toro, sake, etc. Can't wait to go again during our next visit!!!!!!
author: Geoffrey W.

description: I have never had such low quality sushi ever before for such a high price. 12 dollars for a roll that's super small portion tastes horrible and they even couldn't get my order right of having no cucumber. Never ever coming back. As a sushi place this place is a definite no, by the way I got 3 all of the most popular rolls by recommendation.
author: John V.

description:
Boss. No seriously, boss. So much fun everytime i come. Maybe a bit too loud? But food is good (not amazing) and the ambiance is definitely fun!

Love the service. 4 stars only because its not quite my favorite sushi spot in town. Ut my second favorite for sure.

Best for late nights.

Bravo!
author: Oreo B.

description:
Amazingly, my friend had been living next to Ryoko's for several months...and yet we never bothered coming here until now. All I can say is...WHY??? Buttttt let's look at the positives...living close to the place means it's easy to get in with no wait right? Start staking a claim on the line 20 minutes before opening, you are solid!

Ryoko's is definitely more of a true sushi bar than other sushi spots that specialize in rolls. But if all you order is a bunch of nigiri, it's going to start costing a pretty penny. So with that said, the chicken karaage to start (very crispy!) and the Dragon and Checkerboard rolls. Although you only get six pieces with each roll, the fish is pretty fresh. 

With that said, the highlight though had to be the uni and toro we ordered. SO amazingly tasty with that melt-in-your-mouth texture. The only regret is that there was only one piece each for us. :( 

It's definitely a little more expensive than the typical sushi restaurant, but you do get the quality that comes with it. Dunno if I would wait more than 30-45 minutes for here though...I'm too old for that waiting in line biz these days.
author: Alexander Y.

description:
It gets busy quick so come early or prepare to wait. Sushi is on point. Servings are smaller than im used to but no matter. 

They play a gokd mix of techno ao id you are looking for a quiet night out dont come.

Over all we loved it.
author: Brandon M.

description: Had to wait a while but it moved quickly. The sushi is good and the server was nice. The atmosphere is a bit loud/cramped but that is what it is. No complaints, but wasn't blown away either.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
Now I remember why we never came back here. With so many better options especially in the city than here. Granted it is a place with a full bar that serves food late. The prices and the portion size are ridiculous. Spent over $180 for 4 people on food, 3 beers, 2 hot sake, and 1 cocktail.  I would understand the cost of it if it was worth it, but not really. Beef teriyaki was good but to ask for spicy option it is just sriracha placed on it. I am just glad the uni was good, sake sashimi was ok. Tako was over cooked. It is still cramped, but they do have a live dj to distract you from the stuffiness of the place. Sexy roll looked nothing sexy. It was burned that it was hard to get the roll off the foil. Roll would just fall apart from the tug of war. The other roll was just a crunchy exterior with crab and avocado, served with sweet chili sauce. Personally I would have just stuck to the sashimi and not even bothered for the rolls. 

Parking is street, so good luck. So if you are hungry and craving sushi late at night and would like to grab drinks, by all means come here.
author: Mary Ann B.

description:
You're waiting outside of a building, in a narrow corridor of steps, looking down at an obscure restaurant people suggest on a visit to San Francisco.  You slowly progress down and step by step you start to get a view of what the restaurant and atmosphere is like; You have arrived at Ryoko's.  And boy was the wait worth it.
  I'm not much of a critic, but I can be a bit of a rice snob after living in Japan for two years.  It's difficult to find a place that can touch any taste authentic taste of Japan, but Ryoko's has a unique blend of the old and a touch of a CA in a great blend of atmosphere and good food.  I could probably go in there alone and still have a well enjoyed meal.  It doesn't hurt to ask for a bottle of sake.
  It doesn't have your typical Sushi bar feel.  It really feels like you're walking into a bar you're going to meet your pals at on a Friday after work, except way better.  Inconspicuous as it may be, there's nothing hidden about it.  This joint was packed.  We must have waited about an hour, but the smells, atmosphere, and curiosity made the anticipation force me to stick around.  I was not disappointed.
  The service was good and the food was presented quickly.  You don't wait because the service is slow; You wait because people keep ordering.  The lights are dim and the look of the place made me feel like I was visiting some obscure, invitation only, chefs' layer in the docks somewhere with no cares other than the food.  I know it may seem at odds, but I enjoyed the sushi this way.  It actually made me want to keep pouring the sake and eat till I passed out.  
  Check this place out if you live in SF or just visiting.  It's a little surprise in an area filled with culinary delights.  To be able to stand out and put out great service as good as the food is delightful.  I would go there with friend, family, a date, or alone.  I'll be coming back to this joint next time I'm in SF to watch my Dodgers stomp on the Giants.  Sorry, had to throw that in there.  Thanks to their staff and everyone involved with this place.  Good times and memories for sure.
author: Carlos T.

description: Came here late night Friday. Given we had been to about three bars previously and we're feeling good- the sushi was great! Fun atmosphere, but the music is decently loud so probably not a first date
author: Moira S.

description: I cannot say enough amazing things about this place. We are from the east coast and stumbled across Ryoko's about three years ago. It was amazing then and we've been talking about "that sushi place" since. The fish is extremely fresh. The atmosphere is funky and trendy without trying to be. Hamachi sashimi was amazing and the few rolls we tried were all delicious . Don't let the wait deter you!
author: Jaimie S.

description:
You wouldn't expect to find such a cool, dive-y sushi place next to the most touristy place in SF, but surprise surprise. The wait wasn't terribly long for 3 but we went on a Tuesday night and it was still pretty packed!

Ryoko's is a hip place where all the young folks go to grab a bite and a drink after work. 
Chirashi ($40) -- Mixed sashimi over rice, my go to usually at Japanese restaurants (none of that fake roll stuff!); super duper expensive but good quality fish. Not sure if it was worth the price tag for the portion size though!

Grilled squid ($11) -- delicious, especially when paired with the creamy mayo sauce! You can really taste the squid, and it's very filling too!

Grilled saba ($10) -- I love saba and this one was no exception. Portion size was great and it was cooked to perfection. Careful of the bones!

Unfortunately the prices are steep if you want the yummy stuff but there are some good finds on the menu, especially during happy hour!
author: Sunny K.

description:
So I come to San Francisco a lot for work and have heard of this place on prior visits but never had time to wait for a table. So, this time when I was in town I made sure to make some time to wait for this supposedly delicious sushi. And let me tell you, the hype for this place is totally warranted! 

Yes, you have to wait a long time for a table and that's not the most fun thing in the world. My boyfriend and I got there at 6:15 PM and were seated at 7:00 because the table in front of us didn't show. Be cautious of waiting outside for a table since the do not go up and call your name up there. We waited on the stairs which was a bit uncomfortable as it filled up quickly but was worth it in the end. 

Our server was great and even though the menu said no substitutions she was able to get our sashimi and chirashi plates without unagi. THANK YOU!! The fish was spectacular. So fresh and just like the amazing quality I have received during my time in Japan. I wish I had gotten the uni and the toro but will definitely be coming back so I'm not too worried :) 

Definitely get to Ryoko's if you can!
author: Katie R.

description:
Was one of the best food experience  i ever had Belle waitress she was so nice !! 
, the tastes and the combination between different ingredients was amazing 
Also that service was fast and really good 
The place cool and fun 
But top to all of that the music was popin
author: Ray F.

description: Fantastic sashimi and great service.  One of three great sushi restaurants I visited while in San Fran but easily the best food. Tremendous attention to detail, great sake recommendation, and fantastic service.  The atmosphere is low key, but the sashimi was perfect.
author: Sashimi K.

description:
Went for dinner and was unimpressed with the food.  Ordered a couple of rolls, nigiri sushi and appetizers and a sashimi dinner (omakase).  
Flavor was good but portions small (even in Japan last December I got bigger portions). 
Service was good though but gave us the appetizers (agedashi tofu and iidako)last and did not admit that they forgot or the orders were lost.

Ambiance was loud and a "dive" kind of feel.
author: Vince M.

description:
Ryoko's have the quality of a more expensive sushi bar, with the fraction of the price. The vibe of this restaurant is very laid back and casual. Service was fast and efficient. Although the portion sizes were on the smaller side, the price made up with its quality.

I didn't have to break my bank to have a decent sushi dinner. Highly recommend.

Only negative would be how stuff/tight the spacing was. I turned my leg one way, to almost accidentally hitting the next table, the other way to the wall.
author: Jenna Y.

description:
Ah, a long over due review!

I visited this restaurant in March 2016 when I was visiting SF for business. And let me tell you, their 2,000+ reviews don't lie! 

They don't take reservations and it was a first come first serve. Doors open at 530, I think, and I was lucky enough to get a seat. They were SUPER crowded within the first 30 minutes of opening and this was on a Tuesday evening- yet the service was still spectacular. My server was extremely nice and knowledgeable about the menu and the fish that night.

The food was a 5/5 and if I could've fit anymore in my stomach, I would've ordered more. I had the salmon onigiri (2/5), grilled mackerel, spicy scallop roll, spicy yellowtail roll, amaebi with fried heads, hokkaido uni (best kind of uni), king salmon, and fatty yellowtail. Every piece of fish/shrimp was delectable! That was a lot of food for one person but hey, it's not everyday that I'm in SF. Prices I think were a bit on the pricey side for the portion that you're getting but it's ok. I was pretty stuffed. 

If you want a nice, quiet dinner, this is not for you. The chefs and everybody are really friendly and talkative and even though it's authentic, the ambiance is more "hip".

Can't wait to eat here again when I'm in the area!
author: Kevin B.

description:
The sashimi here is great!

If you go after 8 they have a dj or karaoke and it gets loud. It might be on a tour site because there are a lot of tourists here and it is almost always crowded. 

Despite all this the sashimi here ROCKS. Delicious. Fresh. Generous cuts. This isn't the best sashimi in The City but for the price it definitely deserves 5 stars. 

Full bar. Great service. 

Reasonably priced spot for good sushi / sashimi in The City.
author: Dave K.

description: Excellent sushi, fair prices, fun place to eat. They had a DJ on a Wednesday night which added to the ambiance. The sushi chefs call out whenever someone leaves. Presentation was solid and flavors were spot on.
author: Norman A.

description:
This is not a sushi restaurant...this is my heaven.

I've been here over 5 times within a year, I LOVE THIS PLACE.

I've been waiting for the perfect time to write a review because I have so many good things to say. You just can't go wrong with eating here. The only mistake so far is that you haven't tried it yet...

EAT HERE OR FOREVER BE SAD.
author: Samantha T.

description:
Ryoko's is my go to sushi spot in SF and I recommend it every time someone wants to get sushi. It isn't fancy but the fish is on point and it won't break the bank. 

They are busy every day of the week - so be prepared to wait - or come right when they open. 

They have a lot of rolls to choose from - some simple and some a bit more involved. 
Notable options: 
Hot tuna
Hot tail
Orange Delight: Avocado and cucumber with fresh salmon
Caterpillar: BBQ eel and cucumber with avocado and flying fish roe
49er's: crab with avocado and tuna with salmon on top
Checkerboard: crab with avocado and tuna and yellowtail on top

Service is always friendly, albeit a bit slow with the amount of people they are waiting on at one time but they can accommodate small and large parties (if you have more than 4 - come RIGHT when they open to grab a table).  

Ryoko's makes me happy :)
author: Shannon H.

description: Maybe we just made the right choices (simple rolls), or we haven't had sushi in a while, but this food was awesome! Fresh fish. Perfectly cooked rice. Fast service. Cool music. A supringly great dining exerience on a random Wednesday night.
author: Nia J.

description:
Ryoko's gets rave reviews on Yelp, and it's obvious that locals adore their sushi offerings. They do not accept reservations, and when we arrived there was already a huge waiting list to get in. We waited about 30 minutes before a table became available. We didn't mind.

The sushi rolls are average, in my opinion. I really didn't feel that they were anything special. We ordered and shared 8 rolls, all of which were decent, but nothing to lose my mind over. My favorite roll was the one that featured fried asparagus. So delicious! So good, in fact, that we ordered two of them. 

My dining companion ordered the fried chicken appetizer. I had a bite and thought it was too greasy. They don't offer gyoza, something I thought was strange for a sushi restaurant. 

One major plus is that they do have a full bar. Our waitress was very sweet and efficient, too.
author: Gary R.

description:
The night started out promising. I'm a seasoned sushi-goer and there was a line around the corner of patrons simply waiting to be let in at 5:40pm. I figured this was a positive sign. The place is very large inside and there is plenty of seating for at least 50 people at a time throughout the restaurant. By the time I left around 8pm the line was crazy long.

Maybe my expectations were too high after reading all the Yelp reviews... or maybe I'm learning that Yelp is not always made up of people with developed palates.. or maybe I went here on an off night. Whatever the case, coming here once was more than enough for me. 

I was sat at the bar, which I anticipated because I was solo. I washed my hands with the disposable disinfectant cloth and no one picked it up even 15 minutes later. Soon my chop stick wrapper was next to it and still no one picked the little pile up. This was the start of a night of me busing my own eating area. I ordered an Asahi because it's hard to mess up beer. It took about 15 minutes for my beer to show up and service was slow the whole night. 

Pop music was pumping loudly through the restaurant, which is an interesting choice for a sushi joint. To quote another Yelper, it's essentially a loud bar that also serves okay sushi.

On to food...
Oysters on the half shell were $3/each. I'm fine with that price EXCEPT for the fact that they were very small oysters and they were so fishy tasting that I couldn't finish them. I love oysters and I eat them in LA and NY, the places you know the catch will be good. I was so very, very disappointed in these. 

Then I was disappointed to learn they did not have albacore tonight. Really? I thought it's a staple at sushi establishments and it's my favorite fish. I ordered salmon and yellowtail sushi anyway.... and although the fish pieces themselves were good serving sizes and excellent, the rice under the fish was almost nonexistent! I've never see anything like it before. So bizarre. The fish was great quality and the price was very reasonable for that. About $9/two pieces. 

I moved on to the beef oroshi, which was decent. The meat was cooked as it should be (medium rare) but the ponzo sauce tasted really odd to me, so I stuck with soy sauce. Was nothing I'd order again. 

I finished with the Jumping California roll which was by far the best thing I ate, but it's also deep fried and comes with a spicy sauce, which tells you that it's not actually something I should be raving about at a sushi place. I could get that roll at PF Changs. 

All in all, it took the servers two hours to serve all of that while I was there, but the servers were all very nice in our interactions. They just seemed to be taking care of a lot of patrons. 

I ate most of what I ordered and I left for about $75 pre-tip for one person with a couple Asahi. Nothing to scream about.
author: Sarah G.

description: was very busy and we need to wait at line, but after that nothing to complain. Ryoko's Have a great  environment, great music, and the sushi was delicious.
author: Keyla V.

description: Craving some sushi and Ryoko's was one of the few sushi places open on Sunday.  Place is a hip Japanese dive bar. Overall, food was good but had a limited variety of combination rolls, and more americanized as they had peanut butter in a specialty roll, fried oysters, fried mozzarella wonton wrappers versus your typical japanese place with takoyaki, gyoza, etc. It's definitely a decent option if you're in the area and looking for something a bit later in the night.
author: Anh N.

description: Not impressed. I would have given it two stars but my husband convinced me to be nice and give it three. Walking in you're hit with a smell of old fried food, and the music is so loud. The coke I ordered was flat. We ordered the fried cheese as a starter which was pretty good. We also ordered a tiger roll, a California roll, and a Philadelphia roll. These were mediocre at best - kind of blah, like they were missing something. Overall this was a cheap, quick sit down meal, but I don't understand the ratings and the raving reviews. I'm from Michigan and our local sushi place has rolls that are 10x better than this one. Not to mention they bussed the table before we even got the bill, which was weird. Rather disappointing dinner - definitely won't be back.
author: Ashley G.

description:
Great Spot to eat late at night or morning
good sushi and sashimi
Domo Arigato
author: Charo S.

description:
