Ryoko is a top 5 sushi places in San Francisco for me. (I'm excluding the omakase places from this since that's a different experience altogether.)

The San Francisco sushi scene isn't fringe. We know how to do sushi here. That means that even mid-level quality for SF is pretty good compared to the rest of the country. (I'll double-down: There's no better city for sushi outside of Japan!) Thus, Ryoko only gets 4 stars because it's battling in the toughest sushi cage match in the nation.

The sushi is excellent. Their uni and tamago - the standards of good, fresh sushi in my book - are always great and their tako nigiri isn't rubbery. They have seasonal and special fish each night, and at least one of them each time will be worth the experience. They have a great assortment of rolls too.

Expect to wait to get in. There's almost always a line. Just put your name on the clipboard up front and wait on the stairs. The max I've ever waited was 20 minutes and that was when it was slammed.

Here's the magic thing about Ryoko though. Good sushi: yes. Great sake: yes But let's be honest ... Ryoko shines because it stays open late and has a great atmosphere. Don't come here for a quiet, romantic dinner. This place pushes fun, loud, close quarters and friendships. I've come here with a group of 6 friends and the comfort level we shared (over sake and great sushi) was so good you would have thought we were in someone's living room. Also, every time I come here on a date, my date and I end up making friends with folks at the next table (this is a great icebreaker for that first meeting, incidentally), one time even sharing sake and getting the married couple to agree to kiss if we did too. (I like to think we saved their marriage that night.)

Again, this is top 5 sushi in the city (minus the omakase places - I already said that!) so you're not losing the amazing flavor experience. But the atmosphere is the thing that brings it into the stratosphere.
author: Daniel H.

description: This place was full of charm and excellent sushi.  The sexy roll was my favorite chioce but all were wonderful.  The staff is hard at work keeping up with the crowd, which is a task, but they were so pleasant too.  The   bathroom has one toilet and is tiny, which may have been annoying anywhere else. -  but here, it just adds to the charm.  In general it is a small and cozy place so if you dont like to be close to your neighbors  or need lots of leg room this place isn't for you.It was just a really cool place with really excellent food.  Can't wait to go back next time I'm in town :)
author: Feed M.

description:
Delicious and super fresh sushi only a couple of blocks from Union Square. 
There is usually a line out the door, but it goes fast and it's worth it. 
Service was really quick and friendly, even though the crowd waiting for tables grew continuously, we never felt rushed. 
The place is noisy and has a lot of energy; so, not exactly romantic, but definitely fun. 
While it is in a very touristy area, unlike many other nearby places, most of the guests looked like locals. 
We will absolutely visit again when we are back in town.
author: Ricardo D.

description:
A lot to say about this place. I'm happy it got good reviews and high rated because the wait is forever and the live DJ plays house music. Took about an hour for our table and wait is about 20min extra because they bring all the rolls out at once l. Each roll comes to be 5-6 cuts. 

The atmosphere is fun and very cultural. It is underground so for T-Mobile carriers, don't expect reception. The other people in our parties with at&t and Verizon did not have a problem.

For a party of four we started off with 5 rolls and the tofu appetizer. It was not enough, we did not anticipate 5 rolls each and the tofu only had three pieces, so we shared one. It's good and they prepare it like takoyaki.

After the 5 rolls we ordered four more. I'll break it down to the ones that stood out. Total, we ordered the Pokemon roll, Philadelphia roll, volcano, salmon skin, golden gate roll, hot tail, hot tuna, Tahoe, and the sexy roll. 9 total for a party of four.

My favorite was the volcano roll because I love peanut butter and there's a hint in there followed by jalepeno so it can be spicy. That's a plus for me.

The Pokemon roll is the only awkward one since its wrapped in soy paper and has mangos in it. Very good chaser if your mouth is on fire. Its sweet and savory.

The sexy roll is baked with cheese and was made to perfection. The top had a layer of harden cheese but followed by gooeyness right under it. Reccomend as well. 

My boyfriend usually grades a resturaunt by how well their salmon skin roll is and this alone was probably 3 stars. My bet would be that it was sitting around before served to us cause it was more chewy than having a light crisp. 

Tips and headsup:
--Women's restroom is upstairs while the guys is towards the back. 
--can get hot since underground
--all the rolls are served at once so it can take a while depending on what you order.
--have good company cause there's a lot of free time
--waitress always wants to serve you more alcohol to kill time.

Overall awesome it closes late, not so awesome for the long wait. For a party of four, our total was $110. (9 rolls, appetizer, and two drinks)
author: Jackie O.

description: Good sushi for a late night fix. The sushi, drinks and service were all really good. This is a smaller restaurant so I can imagine how packed it can get - luckily it was virtually empty when we came in. Oh yeah, there's a live DJ which is pretty dope.
author: Mike Y.

description:
Ryoko's is a dictionary definition example of a hole in the wall. It's actually a hole in the wall and the floor, as you enter a nondescript door and immediately descend to a lower level cave of a sushi bar. But funky surroundings aside, the sushi here is really good. And fresh fish is what it's all about, right? 

I've been here a few times and sampled everything from the rolls to the sashimi to the salads to the hot dishes, and everything has been very good. However I think one of the more impressive things here is the simple quality of the fish. Fresh as can be. The rolls are a'ight, and the various non-sushi dishes are quite good, but definitely on the expensive side (especially for the environs). My 14-piece sashimi last night was a steep $39 while the slightly smaller chirashi is $30. Don't get me wrong - I don't mind paying for good fish, but this seems a little steep. The sashimi cuts aren't generous. 

That all said, I dig Ryoko's and will most definitely be back. I don't mess around with weak fish, and the fish here is very, very good. Oh, and the service is totally on point!
author: Don B.

description:
Ordered the Checkerboard and Pokémon roll with Karage Chicken! The fish is very fresh but I wish the rolls had more special sauce on them. The yellowtail from Checkerboard melted in my mouth. 
Pokémon roll was ok. The mango inside the roll was a bit to tangy. 

Overall, I wouldn't say "best sushi in SF." But it's in downtown so 

Love the music choice and atmosphere. If you get here right before it opens at 6pm, you won't have to wait long.
author: Christine C.

description:
Being a vegetarian, there are only a handful of Japanese restaurants that I've relished and this is one of those. The vegetarian dishes were really yummy! We got the agedashi tofu (you can ask them to not add bonito flakes if you're vegetarian), jumping veggie and the veggie rolls. To drink we had the iced barley tea and oolong tea. Both were good to wash down some really delicious Japanese food. To top it off the green tea mochi was out of the world! I am a big mochi lover and this one dish swept me off my feet.

You can see them make the food and occasionally they give out pep shouts which I though was pretty fun. The restaurant is sort of in the basement and is super cozy, kind of close to union square.  Parking might be a little hard though.
author: Swetha S.

description:
Friggin' great. Tasty sushi at really reasonable prices, and an amazing DJ that kept us here long enough to pay a second check.

Seriously, the sushi is enough to return, but the DJ has the perfect mix of old and new and reads the crowds head bobs to know how well he's doing... It ain't an easy job.
author: HB S.

description: Always packed but they have a sign up list.  Good sushi and service for the price and they also open later than most restaurants.  Sometimes they have DJs during dinner hours!  It does feel a little bit claustrophobic especially if you get sit at the table in the nook right under the stairs.
author: Jeannie C.

description: Don't be deceived by the way this place looks from the outside.   The sushi is awesome!!  DJ music and the atmosphere is good.   We ordered five rolls.   Our favorites were the Pokémon and Spicy Scallop.  Second favorite were the Jumping Tuna and Humboldt.  We also got the sexy...but the cheese was a bit much for me.   We will definitely be back!
author: Sheila D.

description: There were great aspects to this restaurant and its sushi. The Sashimi and Nigiri were fresh, well prepared, and delicious. The service was quick and accurate, but not particularly friendly, or charismatic for that matter.  The rolls were really where my problems were. There is this over abundance of imitation crab and mayonnaise. Maybe that's a thing, but it's not my thing.  My wife is allergic to eggs so this essentially evolved into an inconvenience when ordering around that. Additionally, we seemed to have ordered just as a fresh batch of rice was delivered to the bar because when we got our sushi it was noticeably warm. Again-a thing, maybe, but just not mine. This place has a dark, almost dive bar ambience with very loud music. I can appreciate that as a signature trait of Ryoko's. Mayonnaise, imitation crab and warm rice, not so much especially when spending the kind of money commanded by a reputable SF sushi restaurant.
author: Ray F.

description: GO THERE BEFORE YOU READ THIS. The fucking place doesn't deserve even one start! I've had $142 dinner for two and the fucking waitress charged us $24 tips! Fucking $24!!!!! And when I asked her, she said we had over $100 dinner. Tips are automatically charged!!! Did I tell her I'm not going to tip? No!!!! Fucking No!!!! They are just trying to get your money anyway!!!!
author: Kai T.

description: Went last week after work to get some take out, there was a wait for seating, and was told by the waitress they don't do take out. Really? Restaurants who don't offer take outside are usually high-end establishments and not dive places. Know your market.
author: N A.

description:
After our kinky show at the redwood room, we were starving and came here for sushi.

It's 12am and there's a DJ playing some biggie smalls. It's not too loud but it adds to the SF ambiance.

My bf bought the buy sushi chefs rounds of beer and sake just because. 

Loved the sushi. Will be back!
author: Aidan V.

description: Really good! We got there about 10 minutes before opening and there was already a line by the door but we were seated pretty fast so make sure to arrive early because the line definitely grows and waiting time can take a while. Initial observation as we got in was that it was a pretty hidden place, no fancy signs or anything outside so it can be easy to miss but once in, the place has a very urban yet classic feel. It was quite dark inside but that just gives the place its ambience, I can tell that a lot of the diners in there were local regulars. Service was quick and attentive so that's a plus. As for the food, we got the sexy, pokemon, orange delight, agedashi tofu, mixed tempura, and several orders of the salmon nigiri. The rolls were pretty good, kinda had the tendency to fall apart but maybe that was just due to the batch of rice that was made that night lol. Out everything that we ordered, the thing that stood out most to me was the freshness of the salmon. It had that melt in your mouth factor that just required very little chewing but had such flavor. I would definitely come back just for the salmon tbh lmao. Overall it was a great first time and I  would definitely recommend it to friends.
author: Leeana B.

description: I don't get the hype for Ryoko's. I wanted to do a celebratory dinner before I started my cross fit training and based on the stellar reviews, I chose Ryoko. The drinks and service were spectacular but the sushi was subpar. I'm not a major sushi snob so I'll eat sushi from different restaurants all across the budget spectrum but I do expect the price and quality to have somewhat of a correlation.  I expected more from Ryoko's, and for their price range, I would much rather eat at a different place. I'd come here for the drinks but that's about it.
author: Denise L.

description:
Nice sushi and good drinks selection but extremely noisy with loud music. The venue has an unusual shape in the basement which can make it interesting and the low lighting is part of the decor while a bit overdone in my opinion. 

Overall it's a good place to have good sushi and hangout with people who can shout.
author: Khash S.

description: This restaurant had very good food, but be careful with what you order. Overall, diner for four was easily $200, if not more. The sushi was probably the best sushi I've had, but then again, I don't eat sushi too often. The tamago nigiri was authentic and had a very distinct and authentic flavor. The sushi was super good and very flavorful. For most of the rolls, you didn't even need soy sauce. Overall, everyone at our table enjoyed the food very much, and were only disappointed in the price that we ended with, and some of the very disruptive neighbors that were seated next to us. Due to very tight spacing, we were able to hear every little detail of their conversation from everywhere, even in the bathroom upstairs.
author: Jannai W.

description:
The short of it:
- late night sushi
- good quality sushi
- reasonably priced
- Favs: California hand roll, crunchy crab roll

The long of it:
One of the many reasons I love SF is the abundance of food especially late night eats! Ryoko is a great hole in the wall sushi place that is open until 2am! Great for those nights after going out and wanting food that isn't junk food. Just be warned that the kitchen closes earlier (around 12:30am) so if you if you were craving any hot food like tempura you are out of luck. We got here just after the kitchen closed so we were only able to order sushi which was not a big deal since that's what we wanted anyway. My favs were the California hand roll and the crunchy crab roll. Everything tasted fresh and good. This would definitely be a go to spot for me if I lived in the city.
author: Kristin A.

description:
I LOVE this place!

I was first introduced to Ryoko's several years ago through my then roommate who found it while walking around the city. He quickly told me about it and we went there to eat quite often. 

Then I moved from the city and I forgot about this place until recently when I was meeting a friend downtown for dinner and he suggested sushi. My mind quickly pulled this restaurant from the archives and I almost yelled "I know the perfect place!!" 

We were there on Monday (President's Day) so I wasn't sure if they would be open but yes they were! And we arrived around 7pm, just an hour after they opened and the restaurant was crowded. Not a single place to sit. So we put our names on the wait list and waited patiently for a table, which was about 20 minutes. I guess we arrived at the perfect time because within seconds there were about four other groups behind us waiting for tables. 

We order some edamame and miso soups to start. I had a green tea (my throat was scratchy) and my friend had a beer. The soup was some of the best soups I've had! and the tea was grassy and toasty! Just perfect. 

We also ordered three sushi rolls. The Alcatraz, The Philadelphia, and the Jumping California. There were amazingly good that we devoured them in no time. 

I do think the rolls are a bit small, and the place is loud! Also, my friend pointed out something that I never noticed before: the only exit is the front door. We couldn't see another exit from where we were sitting. This made him nervous since the restaurant is in a basement! Where do we run in case of an emergency???
author: Ezekiel G.

description: By far the best uni and overall experience I have had in Such a long time  and Reasonable price ! They have a chefs special for $30! In addition, they have bomb fresh wasabi!
author: Khuyen D.

description: Craig, Sushi was so fresh and smooth!!! Can't wait to come back. Chi toro was excellent and from Japan. Oysters were excellent.
author: Jack C.

description: my friend found this place when I visited SF. you go down a set of stairs when you get in. place was packed, which is a good thing. the wait wasn't that long. it also helped that there was only 2 of us. definitely didn't disappoint. food was delicious and the prices were reasonable for the city. cute little place with low lighting and minimal japanese decor. they also had a dj who was playing all the jams (xtra pts). would come back again!
author: Chrissy L.

description:
I walked in here thinking 4 stars on Yelp but was disappointed - possibly because I had expectations for a Japanese restaurant with good sushi but ended up with a loud bar with fish. We ordered the 'tahoe' and '49'ers' rolls and the chirashi. These were $7, 13.50 and ~$30 respectively on the menu. I used to think paying $20 for a chirashi was expensive, but I've had countless decent chirashis around $20 and sadly this $30 one was worse. The rolls were very tiny for the price, and were not even fresh. The miso soup was at best typical, but in my opinion seemed a bit fishy.

Basically the 1 extra star here is for decent service, and what seems like a great bar. If you are looking for a place to grab drinks down town and maybe also snack on some Japanese food, then this is a good choice. If you're looking for some quality fish and sushi, you will need to look else where.
author: Alfonso C.

description:
Ebisu is better in all respects.  The sushi is good but not great.  The wait was just terrible even for sf.  The staff had to be flagged down constantly to get basic service.  Prices are deceptive as portions are small.  

Not sure how this place got to be so highly rated.  It's just middle if the road for San Francisco.
author: Joshua R.

description:
The sashimi is not worth your price for the quality you pay for. Since I was unable to go to a nearby restaurant for some ramen, my friend and I quickly chose this place as our alternative for some sushi. We noticed the 1900+ ratings with a 4 star.... Can't trust Yelp ratings. 

Let me warn everyone that likes legitimate raw sushi. This place does NOT serve GOOD sashimi. The tuna I had tasted like frozen fish. The mackerel I had was not even good. The sashimi was very underwhelming. Overall, I will never come here again. Pretty disappointed for such high ratings.  

I'm positive that this neighborhood has better food and for the price I paid. Which was $50. So... Think about it! You're probably better off with the cooked rolls, but I was not trying to eat fried, cooked, or baked rolls. Nonetheless, it is not even worth it in my opinion. There are better options around!!!!
author: Alyssa W.

description:
I was afraid that we were gonna wait in line for long, but luckily we did not. It was around 6:30pm, and me and my friend were waiting for our seats. The host lady was very nice, and she sat us down behind the piano in the back till our seats get ready. It was fun sitting behind the piano and sipping beers. 
I liked the whole atmosphere, the food, the service, everything about this place. I don't know why some people are complaining about its loudness or say this place is like a club. For me, the EDM music has really fit in the atmosphere. The food was delicious! The Uni was sooo fresh!!! I just wanted to try the uni and it really satisfied me. The rest of the food we ordered were delicious as well. The price was reasonable. I would love to come back to this place soon again!
author: Mona E.

description:
So so disappointed. Came in with a friend on a Saturday night around 7pm and we were seated right away. After seeing the mixed reviews about the chirashi dons my friend and I were hesitant to get it considering the price but we decide to treat ourselves and splurged. I also got the hamachi roll since the chirashi dons looked small.

Our chirashis were smaller than the ones pictured on Yelp. The layer of rice was very thin. The rice itself had good flavor and texture with the flavor leaning on the sweeter side. Unlike the chirashis pictured, our chirashi somewhat resembled bara sushi where they cut up the fish and put them on top. Our tamago, tako, cuttlefish, and saba were cut and scattered. I'm personally not a big fan of this style especially since the room is dark and separating the pieces was difficult. For $35 we got approximately 10 pieces + ikura (including the cubes) of a regular selection of fish such as hamachi, tuna, salmon, albacore, saba, etc. There was one more interesting fish that I wasn't able to identify that had a nice flavor but it was familiar enough for me to know it's not an especially costly piece of fish. I was hoping that with the high price we'd get some uni or at least some scallops. The quality of the fish was decent but not extremely flavorful or fatty. Besides the actual small cut cubed pieces, several slices of fish looked like they were hacked through with a dull knife. I'm not one to be nitpicky about presentation but for $35 I'd like to feel like I was eating something prepared by with a chef's knife and not a pocket knife. Honestly I'm not sure what luck we had to get this sad chirashi. The highlights of the chirashi was definitely the saba. I loved their pickling and I would rather have a bowl of just that. (2/5 overall) (3.5-4/5 for the fish quality)

My hamachi roll was a lot better. It was a decent light roll to have.  It's nothing particularly interesting but it was pretty tasty. (3.5/5)

Overall, between the tight seating, average service, and steep prices, I left extremely disappointed by this place after hearing so many good things about it. I haven't seen many reviews mention the problems I encountered but it's SF and there's safer options with more consistent sushi so I doubt I'll be back.
author: Vivian C.

description: This place is insane in the best way!  It is a sushi place mixed with a piano bar. Definitely a great place for a boozy night out. Wouldn't be the best if craving something low key. We walked in and only had a bit of a wait. The sushi is really quality and we had a blast. Definitely will be back!
author: Angela S.

description: This place was definitely captivating at first glance with their live dj and good atmosphere but this was certainly short lived upon receiving our food. We ordered multiple items including shrimp tempura appetizer (to our surprise this one included one piece) and a chicken entree , which was unappetizingly cold. Aside from the less than satisfactory meal, the staff was unapologetic and reluctant to provide a refund to the clearly cold food. Unfortunately, I will not be returning.
author: Ashley F.

description:
As far as divey restaurants go, and either homey and awkwardly comfortable, or uncomfortably awkward... This one sucks hard (and not the late night San Franciscan sort of way).
Seemed like a kick-ass place to eat from the word around-town, drunks shouting and wanting hugs and high fives as you walk in the door, a huge ass doorman not allowing all entry and exit, steep stairs deciding you and your group.

If you enjoy it where you get treated like shit, this is the place for you and your friends! Couldn't find any way to get a menu, asked waitresses multiple times, they told me to fucking move and head to the front door and wait, had young asian kid mixing hot beats and pumping record scratches off a serato.

Just tossed menus after finding 2 adequate pieces of sushi for starving Irish kids, and then proceeding to ask if we could place order and then being told to eat shit. So we split. End of story, this place blows in the bad kind of way.
author: Hobie H.

description:
This is honestly probably some of the best sushi I have had in a while, outside of the restaurants that sell just the authentic stuff.

Fair warning - it gets packed. I went on a Thursday night and, while there were tons of people waiting on the staircase down to the restaurant, the wait for two of us ended up only being around 30 minutes. The inside has sushi bar seating and then tables for the majority of the restaurant. It's pretty tight inside, but not very strange to find at a sushi restaurant.

They play great music (think top 40, hip hop, "hip" stuff) and have a fun atmosphere overall. There's a private room in the back which I assume you can rent out for large parties... maybe 10-15 people?

It was only $5 for both a glass of beer and a sake bomb, so you bet we got two each. For our appetizer, we ordered the Japanese fried chicken.... and I think I died and went to heaven for a bit. Had I not already ordered my sushi rolls, I could have ordered 3 more of these and called it a meal... + leftovers. SO GOOD.

I tend to go to sushi restaurants and ask the waitress what her favorite thing is, or the most popular dish, and order that. She recommended the 49er roll and it lived up to its expectation. I believe it was three different types of fish on top of the rolls - salmon, tuna and albacore (?). Regardless, so yummy!

Will definitely be coming back here next time I'm in the city.
author: Richa A.

description: Would've liked to have had my food a little bit slower but the ambience didn't allow for that. Food quality was nice. The small sushi rolls were all distinct and nice. I wanna say more but I'm tired right now. Will come back later. But yeah, this is a pretty chill Japanese bar to hangout with friends.
author: Ganesh K.

description:
3.5 Stars

I've been to Ryoko's a number of times now, and I've always thought it was just okay, until my last visit, which turned out to be good. 

First off, the restaurant is underground. It's downstairs of a building. I personally don't like the atmosphere because it feels kind of dirty. There was one time I had to move tables, because it smelled really bad (like piss) at one corner of the restaurant.

I ordered a lot off the specials menu during my last visit, which were all pretty good. I got the hamachi kama, takoyaki, and the ankimo. They probably have the best ankimo that I've ever tried. I also really like the beef teriyaki here, which they cook perfectly every time I come.

I personally don't think the sushi is that great and worth the price here. The sushi rolls are mainly rice with little fish. The fish doesn't taste bad, but it doesn't very fresh either.

Service is alright. There are days when our server is really attentive and friendly. There are other days when the service is whatever. There was one time the sever misheard my order, and tried to make it seem like it was our fault. 

Overall, I think the hot items on the menu are good, but when I come back, I will definitely try more sushi items also. The main reason why I come back is because it's open late. I would've gave this place 4 stars if it didn't smell so bad that one time.
author: Derek T.

description:
1 star for the environment 
1 star for have the courage to charge those price with this level of food.

Food are decent, fresh but not worth the price.
Very expensive for my taste. Maybe because we are from south bay and a high end sushi bowl might only cost $20 to $25 I had much more fresher uni in my life so $20 two piece of uni sushi are freaking ridiculous. I know why do I still order it? Because we love uni, but soooo not worth it. We can order a whole uni for only under 20 in other place. The nigiri is small, tiny and only three uni on top, I know in Japanese tradition those nigiri tend to be small but $20 two piece? what the heck? 
Chirashi bowl.... nah no thanks. Small piece, pretty fresh but small. $30 for a small portion and cut up fish. Uh... and not even high end fishes. 
Grill eel bowl.... $28. Taste well, also over price. 

And I might be picky, I order a coke. ( I don't drink alcohol, whenever I smell alcohol it make me wanna threw up. ) every single freaking cup have alcohol smell in it. I ask the waiter to change cup and willing to pay for one more coke, still a unbearable smell. The coke is overly sweet. I know it's from a soda machine and they might put too much syrup in it. 
It's just soda, how can you screw up a soda?!!! And please clean the cup, my whole dinner is ruin. ( I took my coke very serious, it's like when you order coke but turn out its Pepsi, ew. ) 

Anyway, after a hundred dollar bill, we went to other places to finish our dinner. Not even half-full. Don't get what's the hype, guess they paid Yelp. ( I worked in the business and I knew their little secret.) hmmmm....
author: Quinn J.

description:
Good drunken eats?! Yes please!

After bar hopping from Downtown to the Tenderloin (and then back to DT and back to the TL), we decided it was finally time to eat dinner. My girlfriend's brother had read about Ryoko's, so he suggested we go here.

August 2013
*Spicy chicken teriyaki http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ryokos-japanese-restaurant-and-bar-san-francisco?select=2DHOu4rlinnt-huB8VgtbA#2DHOu4rlinnt-huB8VgtbA
*Uni sashimi http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ryokos-japanese-restaurant-and-bar-san-francisco#88A8o0Jvq33d2LrIdrbqQw
*Beef tataki http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ryokos-japanese-restaurant-and-bar-san-francisco#892kVZ7d6q7Yzj94bpRAEg
*Grilled ika http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ryokos-japanese-restaurant-and-bar-san-francisco#XG12YWH1by6pprywZSEbKQ
*Rolls http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ryokos-japanese-restaurant-and-bar-san-francisco?select=pY2iRx-xlTfXEh5iliT-dw#pY2iRx-xlTfXEh5iliT-dw

I tried the uni sashimi and grilled ika. The uni was creamy and sweet. The ika was tender, but had a nice chew and char. I didn't try the rest of the dishes, but everyone seemed to like the rolls and spicy chicken teriyaki.

Service was good for late night. It didn't take long to get seated. But it was a Thursday night, so I didn't really expect a long wait, if one at all. Granted, I did have some alcohol goggles on at dinner, but for late night sushi, I enjoyed our meal!
author: Elena N.

description: Definitely a 4 1/2 stars!!!  The fish was fresh and loved their special nigiri and sashimi!  Their O-Toro and Chu-Toro were great!  Though if I had to choose, I'd go with the Chu-toro!  My friends and l loved it here.  The atmosphere feels like a little club/bar scene with music blaring.  There's definitely a long line here so come early.  We arrived around 6 and got seated right away but if you come later, there will be a line.
author: M. T.

description: This is the worst eating out experience I have ever had in my life. Not only did they run out of half the things on the menu, but also had terrible service. Each roll comes with about 5 very thin pieces and I asked our server for a fork about five times before she brought me one. We waited about 20 minutes to have our order taken. And at the end they charged us triple the cost we were supposed to. They also added a charge of 60 dollars for being 6 people without telling us. Lastly, they gave us a bill with one number and give us receipts with an additional hundred dollars to the bill. Never returning. Go anywhere else I promise you you'll have better service.
author: Stephanie H.

description: Terrible experience in the place. I came there with my wife and we ask some suggestions to the waiter. The waiter suggested something that was not on the menu and would cost 20 dollars more than what it should. She was not clear at all with the suggestion and when it came, we realized it was actually only 5 California roll with some fish on top which was "very difficult to find in Japan", which took the price from 5 to 25 dollars. The place is ok, but the experience with the waiter make us not want to go back there again.
author: Luiz C.

description: It's overhyped and be prepared for the long lines. When I tried the sushi, there were okay as in "I've had better". Service could be improved.
author: Kevin L.

description:
This place gets so much hype and it's ridiculously basic. I would compare it to an unkempt RA. It's a tiny basement with a bar, a DJ? (weird), and so many tables so close together even the waiters/waitresses can barely move around. We must have waited over an hour for a table when we were told the wait would be less than 30 minutes. 

I don't mind waiting for food... EVER. But Ryoko's is NOT WORTH IT. The quality of the food is below average. Flavors are typical. I really don't understand the 4 star 1000+ review rating. At all. Kinda mad I wasted one of my meals in SF on this. Please take my advice. Do NOT go here.
author: Elysse P.

description:
Pretty decent izakaya located conveniently in the Nob Hill district of SF. Came here on a Saturday night with 4 friends. The atmosphere of the place kind of reminded me of izakayas in Tokyo - located in a basement level of a building, quite dim, and quite busy and loud.

We decided to share a few things, and we started off with the appetizers:
- Octopus + Wakame: a few small pieces of raw octopus over a little bit of seaweed. Pretty good, raw octopus was fresh, chewy, and tasty. But tiny and not worth the price.
- Chicken karaage: highlight of the meal. Comes with 6 large pieces of chicken, which was very tender and flavorful. It was so good we decided to add another order.
- Saba (mackerel): cooked well, juicy and tender. Skin was crispy, which was great.

Then we shared five rolls: 49ers, pokemon, jumping tuna, spicy scallop, and dragon rolls. All of theme were decent but not particularly memorable. The quality of the seafood was pretty average. Especially the salmon, which tasted a bit stringy and not quite fresh. Also the spicy scallop was a bit saltier than I would have liked.

Price was a bit on the high side for the quality and quantity of food. Recommend a try if you are in the area. Also try to avoid the peak hours. At about 6pm, we didn't have to wait in line, but as we left at 7pm the line was very long.
author: Alvin W.

description: This place is amazing! Such a cool little gem of a sushi restaurant! Great service and great food. Try the Volcano roll with peanut butter! The baby octopus is amazing as well! Went back twice when we were there! Definitely going to be on our "go to" places in SF!
author: Dru D.

description:
What can I say? I love this place. I've been a regular since I moved to the neighborhood (almost 2 years ago) and most of the waitresses here know me, so they always make sure I get exceptional service.

The best time to come to Ryoko's if you hate waiting to be seated is literally 15 before they open. Any other time you will wait from 20 minutes up to 1.5 hours depending on the size of your party. Between 7 and 10p it's a definite hour wait for a party of 2, so don't come in starving!

Trust me, the food is definitely worth the wait. The fish here is extremely fresh, they use high quality ingredients, and their cuts are absolutely perfect.  

My go-to order is the Tahoe Roll, IIdako (fried baby octopus), Uni Sushi, and Oysters. I also love the Toro Sashimi and the Hamachi Kama--it's a great portion and the fish just melts in your mouth.

I always bring out of town guests here, and despite having been to some equally great sushi spots in the city, Ryoko's will always be my favorite.
author: Rafaella S.

description: Visiting SF from NY and after being denied by one sushi spot waited online for Ryoko's and it was well worth the wait! Dive bar atmosphere with amazing sushi and a live DJ playing great music. The DJ is a great touch as it really ties in the dive bar feel while allowing you to sip on a drink and it makes the wait go by quickly. Once seated, staff were quick and on point -- very fast and attentive service with a great sense of humor. All the sushi is amazing and loved that you can do pitchers of beer (Asahi/Sapporo/Ryoko's). We loved it so much we went back the next night and I will be back the next time in SF! Thank you for your hospitality and keep up the great work!
author: Joe C.

description: Underground Sushi restaurant in the city, it's got the street feel as you walk in the dimly lit place.  Tables and cleanliness are ok but not great.  The food is what's worth it though.  The food is artistic and flavorful at the same time.  They take pride in each dish and you can tell.  The miso soup is good, and the cocktail drinks fun to have while having the sushi.  Really fresh fish, high quality tuna is served here too.  Will definitely go back more often.
author: Sebastien L.

description:
4.5 stars from me! 

This place is awesome. The toro sashimi was seriously epic. The best piece of toro I've ever had. So buttery and amazing I cannot tell you how worth it that is!
Everything else we had was amazing also- salmon, hamachi, unagi, soft shell crab, and a few of the Americanized rolls were also good. This is the best and freshest sushi I've eaten in ages and can't wait to come back. 
It also was a plus the DJ spun some great house vibes and the service was great!
author: Jen B.

description: This is a great place. The sashimi is perfectly cut, fresh and wonderful selection. The staff is friendly and helpful with what's on the menu and the seasonal options. The big mama roll has a great spicy kick and just over all awesome. The Torro sashimi every time I'm there is the best I've ever had. If you love sushi and looking for a great little place...this is a MUST!!!
author: Meredith T.

description:
Wow I should have went with my gut. This place is all hype don't be fooled like I was people. This is overpriced, overhyped mediocre sushi at best. I will acknowledge the fact that I set the bar pretty high when I see so many good reviews, but wow I'm still in shock from the horrible service I just received, and keep in mind I waited almost an hour for my table. 

Case and point asked my waitress twice for extra wasabi and lemon never got it. When I went to the sushi chef and kindly asked for extra wasabi, he actually had the audacity to tell me that I did not need extra wasabi "it takes the flavor away from the fish"........ WHATTTT are you kidding me! This place did not get the memo when they said the customers are always right, or  I guess it did not apply to them. In any case I strongly advise my fellow yelpers to stay away from this dump. Such small weak sushi cuts and very overpriced and horrible service to top it all off!!
author: Eric A.

description: Don't understand the hype. Based on the constant lines out the door I was expecting something exceptional. What I got was an extremely loud, crowded, almost frantic experience. And this was on a Monday night! The staff is working hard, for sure, and they were nice, but they all look a bit wild-eyed. I would be willing to overlook the frenzy if the food was memorable, but it wasn't any different than what I've experienced at any hole-in-the-wall 2 Star places. And just to remind me of the frenzied nature of the staff, my miso soup was thrown in front on me, overfull and sloshed on the sushi bar ( and was just so-so) my sake and hotate nigiri was smallish (and again so-so) and my spicy tuna roll had a rushed, thrown together look, rolled loosely and heaped on my plate
author: Jeffrey P.

description:
We wanted late-night sushi, although they are open till 2am, you want to get here before 12:30am because they start to close the kitchen at that time and so only certain items are available after that.  They do last call around 1:30am.  

But, from the sushi items that we were able to order, they were good quality and their California hand roll was really good.  

I liked the bar/restaurant atmosphere that you get when you head downstairs to this place.  I was jealous of people eating some of the warm items and udon, but that's only because I came in here very late.

They have lots of different fish to try and are open late.  Fun place to check out.
author: Matt K.

description: It sucks and it closes at 12 but it claims to be closed at 2.. bad service and rude bouncer outside
author: Viral C.

description: Thank god my friends got here over an hour earlier to put our name down so that by the time I arrived to the city, it was ready. This place gets packed and I know why. I had a lot of their items like the chirachi bowl, salmon rolls and what not. The salmon was so fresh and delicious. The best one was for sure the uni. It was sooo damn fresh, maybe even fresher than Japan??? It gets really expensive though so for four people to fill us up including two bottles of sake, it was $215 before tip or so.
author: Amy H.

description:
There are countless sushi options in SF, but it was my birthday - :) - and I wanted a place that wasn't high dollar or stuffy but still had a festive energy. Jessica T rec'd Ryoko's and it was perrrfect.

Know that they don't take reservations, so walk in and write your name on the clip board and prepare for a wait. Order a beer from a bartender to help pass the time.

They feature a ton of rolls and apps, but don't miss out on the specialty fish menu posted above the bar - it's a fresh selection straight from Japan. The uni was my favorite of the night, along with the wagyu beef, and spicy hotate (chopped scallop).

Service was prompt, decor fun ... it's cool spot for a small group outing or just a 1:1 dinner with a friend.
author: Farrah A.

description: Fantastic. The wait time is a little on the long side, but it was worth it every time I came. Really cool hole-in-the-wall, cozy, hip atmosphere with excellent, excellent sushi. Have been there a few times and will definitely be back.
author: Jacob K.

description: One word: overrated. I get the whole underground and hip sushi bar vibes of this place, but my whole experience was just whatevs. My friend and I came here at around 6:15 on a Wednesday and it was already packed, which usually means the food is worth waiting for. We only ended up waiting for about 20 minutes because there was only the 2 of us, and we were packed like sardines in the back of the restaurant. Already starving and grumpy, we were happy to finally start our dinner. We should've gone somewhere else since we were so hungry. I get that this place is in San Francisco, but really?? $7 for a 5-piece tuna roll with avocado? That's a little ridiculous in my opinion. This is a place you go to knowing that you'll still be hungry after if you don't want to spend a mini fortune on dinner. The extra star is for the really nice waitress we had though who was super accommodating to my food allergy.
author: Cat T.

description:
For some reason, every time I come here, they're handing out free shots of tequila. Perhaps it's my luck? Perhaps they just like me? Eh? I dunno.

There is usually a wait, and it can get pretty long. The only time I've been that I had to wait for less than five minutes was shortly after they had opened. Any time after, and you'll probably be waiting for at least 20 minutes, sometimes up to an hour. But...the food is pretty great and not at all pricey. Service is always friendly. They have a great selection of rolls. Yum. I've not ever gotten something there that i didn't like.

Plus, they're always blasting prime time party music. Always. It's a riot in there. It's a great place to go before a night out to set the mood.
author: Kelsey S.

description:
I was not blown away by this place as much as others were.  I didn't mind the 45 min wait at 1030PM on Saturday.  I'm dinging this place on the value.  I was in a party of 1 and ordered from the menu as well as whiteboard.  The karaage was really dry, and the sashimi didn't make me buckle at the knees.  

Total bill for one unimpressed person?  $110.  If I blow that much, I would like to have my mind blown.
author: Crystal C.

description: We waited about an hour to get two seats, which were at the sushi bar.  Good selection to choose from on the fresh sheet including items like the raw octopus and uni from Japan, but the nigiri pieces were on the smallish side compared to other sushi restaurants we've been to, even in Japan.
author: Sarah H.

description: Great fun place. Super nice staff and sushi was perfect. Went at 6 when they open so I'd expect a wait if you go later. It's a lively  place. If you are looking for a quiet sushi place this may not be your thing.
author: Scott C.

description: Place is packed by 7pm and it gets worse by the time we left -- 8ish.  Fish is very fresh with topical Japaneses menu but portions are very small as compared to other sushi bars I have been.
author: Frances C.

description: Sushi and ambulance was awesome. There was a live DJ playing the whole night which created a very fun and energetic dining experience. The sushi was phenomenal, the only downside again would be the cost. But if you have the budget then this is an awesome place to take someone for a fun day.
author: Matthew S.

description:
Food here is good - especially considering the price, and proximity to Union Square. They offer a ton of rolls and a few grill items, as well as appetizers. The ambiance is really upbeat and fun (think loud-ish dance music, basement location, and dim lighting). While the fish is by no means Tsukiji fresh, it's definitely not bad. I've been here several times now, and the quality and service is pretty consistent.

On our most recent visit here, my boyfriend and I ordered the chirashi, grilled squid, agedashi tofu, and a roll (dragon? I think?). The chirashi on the whole was really fresh (with the exception of these super tiny cuts of meat they had included - not sure what fish it was, but definitely was not on par with the rest of the fish). Grilled squid was not bad, maybe a touch overdone, but squid is hard to make in general, and this was up there. Agedashi tofu was classically done, as well as the roll. 

This is a good place for sushi/roll night, but make sure to get here early! The line starts before 6pm usually.
author: Jamie S.

description: The vibe is super cool, they played remixed throwback hip hop and r&b song. They have some things on the menu that I've never seen and that tasted amazing and the service was very good, everyone was really friendly.
author: Alaia Z.

description:
We got there at 5:30pm even though they open at 6. Only because we've been here before and know that the waiting lines can get crazyyy. We were first in line and were seated right at 6pm. The waitress that served us already seemed like she was in a rush and was a little impatient.

I was starving, so I ordered quite a lot for myself. I ordered the edamame as an appetizer and then ordered the Tahoe, Big Mama, and Hot Tuna.

She brought out the edamame about 10 seconds after I ordered it. It was weird though because they had JUST opened and we were one of the first to order, but their edamame was soggy. Like it had been there for a long time.

The Tahoe is a sushi roll with tuna, avocado, and flying fish roe. I would have to say I liked this one the best. They are generous with the amount of fish they put inside their rolls. My mouth was stuffed with tuna, so I was surprised.

The Big Mama is spicy bbq eel, egg, shiso (sesame leaf), cucumber, and flying fish roe. The shiso tasted strong in most of the pieces I ate. Nonetheless, it was good, but I could've done without it. In my last piece of Big Mama, though, I got chunks of eel bones and they stabbed my bottom gums. The piece of shiso in the end piece was huge, so I could barely taste the eel.

Lastly, the Hot Tuna is marinated tuna with spicy sauce, shiso, and cucumber. I'm a fan of spicy foods, but even this one had a kick in every bite. It was decent, but again, I could've done without the shiso (sesame leaf). It made the sushi roll taste a little weird (in my opinion).

After one of the waitors had cleared our table and our waitress knew we weren't going to order anything else, we still waited about 10 minutes for her to bring the check to us. They were pretty busy already, but I wish she would've brought the check sooner. (There was already a line outside the restaurant).
author: Sunny O.

description: This place is pretty good in terms of quality but the wait is often long because they don't take reservations and you have to stand outside
author: Martha S.

description:
3.5 stars. It's pretty awesome to know that there is a late night sushi place in the city. I definitely plan to come back since there are plenty of clubs in the area, but it is by all means not the greatest sushi you can get.

I came with a group of friends and we ordered a few different roles. My favorite was the spicy salmon role and also a role that had salmon & tuna in it (forgot the name). Everything else was just okay.

I think the prices are pretty decent for sushi. That said, you are definitely paying for what you get quality wise.
author: Sophia H.

description: Damn it's a party in here. Looking for fine sushi open late? Dine in, bring a date. Quality fish, average sushi prices, portions a little on the small side.
author: Jakob Eats Alone ..

description: Everything is just mediocre. Spent $40 on sushi rolls/nigiri but feel like it's like $15's worth in any places other than SF. Music is too loud, and it smells like toilet at our table.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I have been coming here for 13 years. Even when madly busy it is still a home away from home for me. Atsushi is a great chef, always takes care of their guests and consistently serves some of the best fish in the city. 

There's a reason there's always a line. It's worth the wait.
author: Peter F.

description:
My friend had his birthday dinner here a couple of weeks ago. It's one of his favorite places.

I got to the restaurant a few minutes before 6 not knowing that they open at 6, yet there were people already waiting. My friend and everyone else were having drinks at the Owl Tree, I decided to wait at Ryoko to nab a table. I got a table in the back corner. It was a bit cramped and warm. By the time everyone showed up, the place was filled. I ordered the Orange Delight (Avocado, Cucumber, Salmon and Lemon Slices). The portion was small and the lemon slices were cut too thick. It only came with two so I ended up not having the other slice. I also got the Ryoko Roll. I don't remember what was on it because it had a lot of stuff on it and it was the best thing I had that night. It only came with two pieces, but it was worth it. My friend did share some of his food with me, which were also good.

I was there for 2 hours, but left to go to the Warfield. When I left, it was tough getting out because the stairs were filled with people waiting for a table. The fish was really fresh. Is it good enough to make me want to come back here? No, not really. There's definitely other places I can go to and get the same quality at a better price.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Unless you are a boring old fart, I don't see how you couldn't have a BLAST at this place.

EDM (techno for you older folks) blasting, though not too loud to have conversation.  Fun waitresses and of course...delicious sushi!  Their mule cocktails were very delicious.

Great place to start the weekend.
author: John H.

description: My husband and I were looking for a sushi bar and we stumbled upon this place. The sushi was decent but the restaurant was dark and so loud we could barely here our waitress. We ordered the nigiri platter and shared. It only came with one bowl of miso and a lack luster California Roll. Would be nice if a little brighter and less noisy.
author: Ruth H.

description: Really enjoyed their sushi. The orange delight was my favorite. Really liked their miso soup and the toro sushi. This place gets crazy packed on a Saturday night. Tonight, wait time for 2 people at 7pm was around an hour. That being said, they do take drink orders while you wait. Staff is very friendly as well. Definitely plan to be back
author: Meni M.

description:
It's kind of random but I love that they have their own DJ playing inside the restaurant! The DJ was pretty good too. 

Now this restaurant is small, crowded and there's almost always a wait to be seated. The food quality is good. The price is a bit high. But overall, I had a good time. I had a sushi roll and it was yummy but it was about $18. I forgot what it was called but it had salmon on it.

I would have given them 4 stars if what happened next didn't happen...

We got the check and they only accept a max of 3 credit cards so our party put in 3 cards to slit the bill. We get the receipts back, but only 2 credit cards are in there... but we get the receipts for the 3 cards which means they already charged us. We notify the staff right away and they begin looking for it. 

Now 20 minutes later and they're still searching. At one point, out waitress almost gives up because she comes to our table and says they searched everywhere. We were thinking "what the heck, we literally just gave you the 3 cards and you lost it" but we would patiently wait there all night if we had to. Luckily, another ten minutes later one of the staff finally finds it. I think they accidentally put it in someone else's black receipt book... I don't know how that even happens. But for that reason, I knocked off a star.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Great little sushi spot. Always worth the wait. I'm here at least once a week. Quality sushi at a great price. Severs a great and have worked here for a long time. If you get to know them they will always hook up it. The chicken karaage and fried octopus is a great way to start the meal.
author: Jason L.

description: Average food.  Good if you are hungry after 10pm when most places are closed in San Francisco. Long wait, not worthed before 10pm. Nice atmosphere, but again food very average and not worth the price. Better places in the vicinity
author: Mohssine K.

description: We had volcano roll, salmon sashimi, mushroom miso soup, fried oyster and every single one of them were excellent
author: Sandeep P.

description:
The line runs out the door, but don't let that scare you... the service here runs at warp 9.4. You'll be seated quickly and served before you know it. The nigiri is a bit pricey, but the quality makes the price worth it. One note, the atmosphere is *
loud*... Don't plan on a quiet romantic dinner! I'll be back.
author: Stephen H.

description: Ordered the special Spanish mackerel plus the salmon as well as the unagi roll. Wash down with a draft of asahi beer. The sushi was great but the unagi was only so so. The in house dj play some nice music so if ur into music n dine this is a place. Served by kelvin who is really helped me on the menu orders. Cheers kelvin. See you again
author: Jeremy K.

description: Awesome basement sushi joint. We got there at 6 which was right when they open and there was already a little line outside. Any fish you get here will be amazing. We tried countless rolls and I wasn't disappointed with any. Get the saki too! Fun place and gets busy fast.
author: Laura H.

description:
Pro:
Good ambience

Cons:
Poor customer service, waitress keep bugging you for any new status and recommend their new high cost.
Their menu are over priced for all their food.
Not tightly wrapped, Yes Loosely wrapped.
This place have an odd smell, smells like toilet room is widely open next to you, and full of ammonia smell plus bleach.
Getting a stomach ache from their Wakame-su. Their chef refused to take it off, insisted it is Chef Style.
Chef do not care if I get sick.

Will I Recommend?
No, unless you like to get sick and sue them.

This review is not a Joke.
author: Andy W.

description: My favorite land area. The fish is fresh, and there are always good dishes. I'm usually not a big fan, but there are great options for me. Definitely a place to check if you are in the area.
author: Maeve M.

description:
Ok, I will preface this by saying it's hard to rate this restaurant since it's so perfect for what it does, but a 5 star rating is to be reserved for when the food is melt in your mouth AWESOME. So on that note:

Food: 3.5-4 stars
Atmosphere: 5 STARS if you're looking for a bumpin' party sushi place. Don't go here if you're just looking for a place to take your parents. Or your Mormon aunt.

Sake bombs? Check. The best sushi you've ever had? Err. This place definitely knows its strengths, which is group dinners with your friends on a Friday night if you want to pretend you're in New York and about to go dancing. Although the sake bombs are so in play here, you'll probably end up like me and go to bed promptly after eating here. Definitely worth it, just make sure to put your name in an hour before you actually want to eat - that line gets pretty long!
author: Reyana F.

description: Great music, fresh tasting fish, one of the best tempura plates I've had. The ambiance is romantic and intimate but also provides a comfortable non-pretengious space to eat. And they're open until 2am! Would definitely return
author: Lydia D.

description: We ordered karaage, kai miso soup, umeshiso maki, salmon onigiri, spicy tuna roll, tiger roll, spicy salmon roll, the whole squid BBQ wit kewpie (we hit the mayo with shichimi tougarashi), Sapporo and onigoroshi sake (cold of course). The music is loud but good - there is a DJ. We waited approximately 30 minutes for our table of 4 on some drafty stairs - atmosphere is fun. It is a strange mix on the menu of comfort food to some of your standard American style rolls...all of it was done well but the okay was executed really well. If they had offered the onigiri yaki I think it would have bumped this to a five for me.
author: Saori T.

description: Really good sushi! Was highly recommended by all the people at the place I was staying at. I had food in Japantown and honestly this sushi was way better. Please save on Japantown and come here for the Japanese experience!
author: Payal P.

description:
Great sushi. The atmosphere is nice too in a basement. Fish was fresh and the staff was friendly. Get there early or you will be waiting. Worth the wait and a must to go to if you are in the SF area. A must for sushi lovers. 

The staff offers great suggestion for specials and we tried all and were great. Cant enough good things to say.
author: Erdal A.

description: Would give it 6 stars if possible.. This place rules. Wan't sushi, drinks and a great time? Go to Ryoko's. You'll have to wait for a table but it's worth it. Trust the process.
author: Michael A.

description: Amazing food, can't wait to go back. Really fresh fish and a good sake selection. Be aware there is a bit of a late and its a bit crowded but the food is worth it. Possibly the best sushi I've ever had.
author: Kelly P.

description:
This place never fails me. Never been disappointed with anything on the menu.

So, as long as you know to expect the wait and plan accordingly, this place is great.
author: Pat C.

description: I decided to eat here because it seemed reasonably priced and had good reviews. We arrived as soon as they opened and were seated immediately. However I did notice they got very busy quickly after so I would recommend getting there early. The food was fresh and did not have alot of frills like other sushi restaurant's. However with that being said depending one what your used to you might be sorely disappointed. I enjoyed the simplicity, although I did feel the portions were very small even considering the reasonable pricing.
author: Heather S.

description: Came here a while back. The sushi is fine. The service is Ok. Not my first choice. Their Miso soup is to die for!
author: Mary N.

description: Truly the best sushi I have ever had (& I've had my share of some great places)! The white toro was absolutely amazing! Drinks were great & the DJ played all the best mixes! More than just a great restaurant! Definitely a must go!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Dude, did I just stumble into an episode of Anthony Bourdain? 

I swear we were just bar hopping, sipping whiskey, minding our own, not too thrilled about the usual pizza slice to end the night, when we happened across this sushi spot serving till 2 AM?

Interesting! The group votes yes. Let's end the night on sushi! 

We show up and notice its got a door man on the sidewalk and the entrance is downstairs into the belly of an old downtown city building. My eyes are greeted with strange decorations, colorful lights, a stuffed blowfish hanging from the ceiling, a feng shui nightmare of scattered furniture and a DJ booth in the middle?

So much for ending the night folks!

We order up more drinks, food, and just ride out the fun evening.

Thx Ryoko!
author: R J.

description:
First impressions are everything and the service left a bitter taste in our mouth when we saw one customer pay the waiters to get seated ahead of us. Also, every other time we tried calling our waiter, she told us she'll get back to us later. Don't wait this many tables if you can't handle it! She even told another waitress to not assist our table even though she had just said she couldn't help us out several times. 

The pokemon roll was terrible. I've had Safeway sushi with more structure and substance. This roll tasted cheap and was too weak to hold the ingredients together. For more than $10, we were given 5 warm, floppy, bland pieces.

The chicken teriyaki was bitter. The tempura was average. The tempura sauce tasted more like boiled soy sauce. The chicken karaage was decent but there were only 5 pieces so the one good food item was not enough to balance the rest of this hot mess.

The interior of the restaurant was neat and the music set this place for a cozy atmosphere. For a intimate evening, this would be perfect but don't expect to be treated kindly.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description: I would give this spot 3.5 stars, but I don't think it warrants a 3 star review so I will give 4. I thought this was a solid sushi spot for the price. They don't take reservations so I lined up at 5:45 for their 6pm opening and was only the fifth person in line (given this was a Wednesday night after all). I imagine the weekends people start lining up earlier. I took a seat at the bar since I was dining solo, and all of the staff yell a greeting at you when you enter. I liked the divey-ness of the restaurant which could turn people off, but I appreciated the non-pretentiousness of it. Unlike other yelpers, I found the service to be pretty quick and the fish to be tasty. I only ordered off of their specials found written on the board and thought everything was well prepared.
author: Justine H.

description:
This place is special for me and a close friend. It's a bit hard to find and the waiting can be pretty crazy, so get there early, put in your name, and take a walk around the block instead of waiting on the stairs blocking the entrance (please don't do that thanks!). Ryoko's is also great if you're going alone for a quick dinner and they can usually accommodate you quickly at the bar.

As for the sushi, it's fantastic. If they have blue fin toro on the specials list you need to try it. In fact the specials menu should be your go to, then the regular menu. Everything here is fresh, all the fish and ingredients are super high quality, and the presentation is beautiful. I also recommend trying out some of the side dishes, appetizers, and grilled squid. They also serve some really great sakes for those that enjoy them. Prices can be a little high but for the quality of the fish you're getting a really great deal compared to other high end sushi place in the city.
author: Alex S.

description: One star here for the service because we didn't even get a chance to try the food. After waiting over an hour and a half, two same size parties (party of 2) who arrived after us were seated before us even though the hostess told us we were next.
author: Tina L.

description:
At first glance, you notice how busy it is. Then you notice that the place has this cool-divey vibe to it. Well, the wait is ridiculous, because a) lots of people show up at once around 6-8 for dinner and b) there really is nowhere to wait. So, essentially while you're there, hoping for your name to be called next, you're feeling really awkward as people move past you in all sorts of directions to enter into/leave from/wait at the restaurant. 

We ordered sushi. I wish I could remember what their names were, but I remember thinking it was pretty okay; I remembered the salmon sashimi and tamago were good? The server came by every so often to make sure we had enough tea and water, which was nice. Another server put down our check before we could even ask about ordering more sushi or desserts.

 All in all, just not something I'd want to wait for or something that I'd crave for the next time.
author: Sarah L.

description:
This place is popping!! Like seriously- rave music, crowds, underground vibe. OK, it's literally underground, basement style but it's definitely got that SF quirkiness about it. There's pretty much always a wait. If you're looking to eat NOW, move on and find another place with good reviews. If you can wait, you wont be disappointed. 

I had the Sexy roll, which if you're not into completely raw fish, is a good choice because its baked! With cheese. Mmmm. A great roll in general and one that I put in my mental notebook to have someone try if they are new to sushi.

My other roll was the Jumping Unagi. It's a fried roll which I am normally a fan of but it could've used a little less breading. The flavor was there but i had to work around too much breading to get to it. Somewhat my fault- I ordered a fried roll, what else can I expect?

My friend ordered a Big Mama roll. Great flavor but it is spicy. Not excessively but if you're not a fan of spicy, just avoid it. 

My seaweed salad was good but it is NOT the normal stringy seaweed I've had everywhere else. Perhaps this is more authentic (idk??) but its more like chopped up strips and nuttier/earthier in flavor. But paired with the pickled cucumbers it comes with, it was still quite good. Not what I expected but good.

Sake bombs were $5 a pop. I was happy :)

I don't think i'd recommend this place for a first date bc it's loud with the rave music (i wasn't kidding), somewhat cramped seating and yelling between the servers (it was their system, but hey, it got me my food pretty quickly). But to come and have great sushi, yes, do try!!
author: Joana Z.

description:
On the one hand, I'm not sure why Ryoko's is so popular.  Based on what we had, there's nothing about the food that distinguishes itself from what any other legit sushi spot can offer.  Yet, at the same time, I'm sure the bulk of what we ate didn't represent the best Ryoko's has to offer.

For my friend's birthday, his wife was able to snag a reservation for the mostly private back room.  Our party wasn't exceptionally large (there were ten of us), but it was nice having a slightly quieter space to ourselves (the restaurant can get quite noisy).  Plus, with the way the place fills up on weekends, reservations are just generally a good idea (though I hear they may not take them anymore?)

To make things easier, my friends decided to order a bunch of rolls for the entire table to share.  Unfortunately though, several of them ordered a lot of Ryoko's cooked and fried varieties, like the Jumping Tuna, Jumping California, Jumping Unagi, and Kentucky (with multiples of some, as well).  Nothing I would order for myself, and nothing particularly inspired (fried chicken in a roll?  Really?).  It didn't help either that, amazingly, all of the "Jumping" rolls tasted the same (batter and oil).

While all of the cooked rolls were highly underwhelming, I will say a couple of the fresh ones weren't bad.  Although it was a little too saucy, the Spicy Scallop Roll ($5.50) was pretty tasty, and I thought the Tahoe Roll was great all around (Tuna, Avocado, and Tobiko, $7.00).  However, the highlight for me was the Hamachi Nigiri ($6.00) I was able to snag for myself - big, quality cuts of deliciousness.

Since Ryoko's does a significantly better job with its sashimi and nigiri, and since I really didn't get to check out much of it, this review might be a little low.  That said, the cooked rolls we had were not all that authentic or delicious, so perhaps the three stars is appropriate.  In any case, I'll give Ryoko's another shot one day.  It helps that they're open so late every night, even though parking in the area can be a beast.
author: Mike L.

description:
We stopped by for pre-dinner snack.  Glad we found this place in city block filled with sushi places.  Love the vibe from this place.  We were immediately greeted as we walked down the stairs.  We sat at the sushi bar - watching the sushi chefs in action. 

We were served complimentary edamame.  The server gave us a couple moments to look over the menu.  We ordered fresh oysters, ala-carte sashimi items (tobiko, uni and sake) and sashimi platter (came with yellowtail, tuna, salmon, mackerel, octopus and scallops).  We were pleased with the assortment, quality and presentation.  One of the sushi chef notice how much wasabi my hubby was using (he tends to use a good dollop with each piece of sushi) and offered some condensed wasabi paste which had a stronger kick.  

Service was great - the server came by to check on us frequently without being intrusive.  

As we were heading out - the place was already pretty pack with a little line out the door and that was on a Monday evening.  Guess we found the right sushi place! =)
author: Sylvia C.

description: Disappointed with experience. Food was ok. Food would be a 2.5 star at most. EXTREMELY small portions for rolls and not great quality ingredients. Overall, great outside appearance. We got excited thinking it was a hidden gem. However.... highly disappointed. No menus when we sat. People sat after we even had our waters waitress went to them took their order first. Miao soup tasted plain and smoky. Manager very unprofessional and we were overcharged. However, too tired and disappointed to sit there and fight over $10. Don't waste your money or time here
author: Daniella B.

description:
We enjoyed our dinner here. It was a saturday evening so it was expected to be very crowded with a long wait time. I think we waited maybe 30 mins, but it was worth it because we had a great booth table, tucked away in the back. Service was decent, and it was cool that they let us order a few dishes at a time (for like 2-3 hours while we were there). They had a decent selection of beverages, and mostly priced fairly. The total on the bill did surprise us a little (came out to about $50/p for our group of 3) but we did order a good amount of food (in small increments at a time) and had a few rounds of sake bombs/other drinks. It felt really authentic being in a cramped basement and the atmosphere was on the loud side, but it was fun.

We ordered a variety of appetizers and sushi rolls, and everything tasted decent. Nothing really stood out. I would come back just for the authentically Japanese ambiance.
author: Rita L.

description: A great restaurant! There was a DJ, full bar, and amazing food. If you're in the neighborhood come here, and make sure to order the cheese sticks yummm.
author: bina q.

description:
We came here since we were craving fresh sushi. This was the closest sushi place to our hotel. The restaurant is very distinctive and unassuming. You go down the stairs to a dark room and we were led to a tiny table in the corner. Holy cow this place was packed!!!

We ordered drinks, sashimi and the 49er roll to share. The sushi is fresh and presentation was beautiful! Delicious!!! Our service was great, given how busy it was.

Definitely will come back when in the area. It's located in the tenderloin so be mindful of your surroundings!!!
author: Maria C.

description:
If your in the city and want the best sushi of you life come here. We have tried just about every roll on the menu and are yet to be disappointed. We love this place with a passion is worth the long wait to get a table. 

FYI - Our all time favorite is the volcano roll. It has peanut butter in it. Who would of thought of that!! But it is delicious.
author: Julio E.

description: Came here late, so we could only order things that were cold. Overall, it was okay. Sushi seemed very average/not enticing. Service was good.
author: Sao B.

description:
The food is always great, the service could use a bit work. But I can't complain after being in line to get it at 5:45 pm. 

I've been coming here for years. The best place to visit for Japanese food around Union Square.
author: Kia K.

description:
Ryoko is fresh, simple, quality sushi that anyone would be proud of. Ryoko is not one of these places that will make a roll and dump a bunch of mayo and sauce on it to cover up the fish. You can taste the quality and the care that goes into preparing the sushi.

The restaurant has a very cool vibe. The house DJ spins tunes as you consume the tasty dishes.

I had the miso soup, tempura, Unagi sushi, spicy scallop roll, and the Hot Tail roll. Everything was delicious and expertly prepared. The soup was flavorful. The tempura was seasoned perfectly, crunchy, and not at all oily. The spicy scallop roll and hot tail were great. The fresh fish was the star in both, as it should be. The hot tail had a little too much rice for my liking however still good. 

The service was attentive and very friendly. 

If there's ever a wait, make sure you sign your name on the waiting list at the bottom of the stairs directly on the "greeter's" podium.

I will definitely be back!!!
author: Ron R.

description: There was a huge long wait on Friday night. It was over an hour wait. There are many young couples and young folk here, not lots of families or old people. It is kind of like a bar/club/night life place. There is edm music. The sushi chef shouts "Sake!!" when he's done making stuff. The lady who seats people is really nice and friendly! The bathrooms are only 1 person bathrooms and there was a huge wait. I couldn't find the bathroom because it was upstairs. We got the Pokemon, Dragon Roll, fried oysters, and green tea ice cream mochi. They were all very delicious and I loved them very much. The Pokemon has yummy mango inside. The mochi has whipped cream and a cherry on top. There are free lollipops and hard candies!!
author: Amanda L.

description: The steak teriyaki was for sure cooked perfectly, the tuna roll was good, the Japanese fried chicken, the miso soup was good, but all in all I was not blown away...SF food scene is not what I anticipated it to be; however I will keep trying places...:|
author: Emily D.

description:
If you want quality sushi at a late hour, (open until 2 am) this is your place. The atmosphere here is pretty nice- they have their own DJ spinning hip hop music, and the sushi is good and made fresh, for average prices. The only downside is that the rolls here are small!! And it can get crowded especially on Friday and weekend nights. They don't take reservations, so you just have to bear with the wait.  

Food I tried:
-Takoyaki: $7 for 5 pieces. Must have!!!  It's so flavorful and delicious. It wasn't listed on the menu when I went, but the waitress mentioned it as a special.
-Orange Delight: $13, deliciously fresh salmon roll. Probably my favorite so far. Must have for salmon lovers.
-Volcano roll: $13, fried shrimp, jalapeño, peanut butter. Pretty good roll with an interesting touch.
-Alcatraz: $6.50, unagi and avocado, pretty good as well.

Service here was good, and I would definitely come back.
author: Corinna T.

description: This was a good spot for sushi near union square. Very loud with good music so if you're looking for a quiet place this is not it. Rolls were good. Very different from other spots, one was a Fried Chicken roll that was good. Like was out the door when we left.
author: Kristin L.

description: Horrible place... the waiter was so rude. Overpriced but the food was not that good, it was all about presentation and plating.
author: Danica P.

description: Great sushi! Some of the best I've ever had. The Jumping Tuna, 49er roll and rainbow roll were so fresh and flavorful. Great hot green tea as well. Not ideal if you want to chat with your table. Very loud music and the wait can be brutal so get there right when it opens!
author: Alix F.

description: Great special roll tonight with jalapenos on top holy shit powerful in a good way.  Funky DJ starts at 9 that i could do without. Super nice server very sweet.
author: Mark R.

description:
THEY WANNA FORCE YOU TO TIP. 
Soo i come here very often and i've recommended many friends to this place, however i got very dissappointed from this one waitress. I did not tip her and she decides to come after my friend and tell her that i always tip her cheap and that next time she will automatically add a service charge. And keep in mind every time we're here its a party of 2. A tip is a tip its not forced. So adding a service charge to the bill is not acceptable and i will not pay it. Now .. you do not ask for how much to be tipped, i will tip based on the service I received; And the manager should talk to this waitress and tell her off. I come here way too often but with waitresses like that the restaurant could be losing money. Shame on you waitress coming after people for forced tips
author: Koko B.

description:
Love this place! I'm one of those people who will give up comfort for taste...so you'll find me in a lot of hole-in-the-walls! Not to say that Ryoko is a hole-in-the-wall, but the space is definitely small and cramped! The sign on the wall says max capacity is 88, but it was obvious there was wayyyy more than 88 people inside (not to mention the line of ~15 people standing by the door). Whatever. I don't care because the sushi here is fresh and so dericious!

Make sure to get here early so you'll get to eat during the first seating. Otherwise, be prepared to wait anywhere from 30 mins to an hour. The good thing is, if you do have to wait, they'll take your drink order so you can have a beer or cocktail while you wait.

My friend and I split the nigiri dinner (9 pieces of Chef's choice nigiri, a CA roll, and a miso soup), 1 order of salmon nigiri, 1 order of amaebi nigiri, 1 Alaskan roll, and 1 Salmon Delight roll. The fish is fresh, but the sushi rice here is mouth-watering good! The fried fish head from the amaebi was also to die for! I have never eaten the fish head that comes with amaebi, but they battered it in tempura and fried it so crispy that it was just irresistible! 

The waitress/hostess was really friendly and attentive. She was all smiles despite how busy and crowded they were. Our server was also very fast and friendly. Our total including 2 ice teas came out to ~$75 plus tip. Strictly street parking as with most of the restaurants in the area, but luckily it was a quick walk from our hotel in Union Square.
author: Nancy N.

description:
Every restaurant that bakes and fries sushi as if they invented it should cower in fear when they find out I love Cha Cha Sushi in San Jose, because NOBODY does it better. Yet I can't help but go into this type of restaurant every time expecting a Cha Cha-level experience.
