Unfortunately, this place just can't compare. The rolls are priced similarly, but that's where the similarities end. The rolls are much smaller, and the WOW factor just isn't there. My dining partner enjoyed the Kentucky Roll, which has fried chicken -- but I mean, how wrong can you go with fried chicken. I enjoyed the creamy Sexy Roll. The Fried Cheese appetizer was also decadent. 

The service was extremely friendly, and unlike most places in San Francisco, this place is open until 2 AM. If I'm hankering for untraditional sushi and in the city, I would probably go to Ryoko's again. But if I want a truly amazing dining experience, I'll make the trek down to Cha Cha in San Jose.
author: Mark C.

description: I decided to come here for a late night snack. I was seated fairly quickly since I was by myself. I was seated at the sushi bar which was right next to the DJ which was unpleasantly loud. The portions were small and definitely did not meet my expectations I got from yelp. The service was fast but expect to wait awhile for your food.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
I'm in love! Food there is too good, forgot to take most of the pictures! I would never imagine that place, so simple outside, open so late, could be THAAAAAT amazing! It's a pure happiness in your mouth! 
Arrived pretty late, about 1:30 am on Tuesday night with couple friends, yet got sits and super nice service, no rushing, no "ohhhh screw you" faces! 
Unfortunately, most of the items were sold out, so we had to chose from very few (still, taste like heaven!!!)  
Finally got a chance to try fresh monkfish liver!
This place is going to be my new addiction! Can't wait to go back and try super fresh uni!
P. S. Absolutely axing 12 y/o whiskey! Wish I took a picture of the bottle to remember the name!
author: Asiyat T.

description:
Unimpressed. Small portions, meh flavor, and overpriced. 
I've had much better sushi at other sushi joints. The sushi here did not seem super fresh and was lacking flavor. 
Please go else where if you are craving sushi! Save yourself from the long wait. 

The only thing that was good here was the DJ, but I came here for food and not for music.
author: Kathy N.

description:
How do you top off riding in a parade?
A " Yes yes yes" to my kind friends who took me here on a wild Friday evening.  Coming after the Warriors' parade which coincided with the mayors' conference which coincided with the President's and Hillary's visits which coincided with the centennial celebration for City Hall... well, you get the picture as traffic was a cluster.... that day!  My friend wisely dropped off his wife while he and I drove through the maze to my office to carpool there.  Running about twenty five minutes late, we struck gold in scoring front door parking... as in, I could roll a penny down those stairs!
My friend's wife ordered several items so our wait was relatively short for food.  
Here's a summary of what we had:

Highlights:
1.  Ama ebi heads (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=7w0OswvyXjQ-pPgrDykcHQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Deep fried crispy, not greasy.

2.  Fried octopus (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fdje9MQOJe7m9Fol6RvUSg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Wasn't planning on ordering, but every table around us did.  Yummy and tender chewy good.

3.  Fish sashimi - Everything was visually and texturally on point.

4.  Bluefin tuna (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=xiwKQxTJdhrtA1avcAEq9A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Great presentation and that egg really mixed well.

Not so much:
1.  Uni - Not that it was bad, but our conversation centered around where the best uni comes.  Didn't stand out.

2.  Chicken karaage (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=RDVCRgc1s84JLvztHTGoTA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - A bit dry, just okay.

3.  Agedashi tofu (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=kgdLfxTU7aZU-RjTSBMLLQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Simple and flavors didn't really shine.

The beef tataki was solid but needed a bit more ponzu sauce.  Very solid meal as my hosts obviously knew what they were doing mixing whiteboard specials with familiar menu items for them.
Seems that this literal hole in the ground is equally about the food and atmosphere.  It is a bit dark and kind of reminds me of basement bars in Chinatown that used to be packed.  We left as the DJ was warming his groove on and the stairs were lined with people snaking to Taylor Street.  Our waitress and servers were attentive and accommodating as we ate at a relaxed pace.  If you come on warm days (read 'hot'), it does get a bit warm in here as, being in a basement location without windows, there is not much ventilation; fortunately, our evenings aren't THAT warm here.  Thanks to my generous and knowledgeable hosts for inviting me to a unique experience and a view of where the "hip" part of the City hangs.
author: Mike C.

description:
3.75

Went to Ryoko's for a late dinner last Friday night and thought it was great! You would think that at 10pm there would be no 30 minute-wait for a table, but for a place like Ryoko's in a city that doesn't offer much late night eats, 30 minutes wasn't too bad in my book.

Overall I would this place has great value. Sushi on the east coast tends to be marked up a little bit. Everything on Ryoko's menu was moderately ranged, with the occasional specialty rolls maxing at $15 per roll.

For a table of three, we had ordered a total of 4 rolls (from the $8 - $13 range), 12 pieces of sashimi, a hot appetizer, and a large bottle of unfiltered Sake. The Salmon Sashimi was super buttery (in a good way). My favorite roll would have been the VOLCANO. For our hot appetizer, I chose the DEEP FRIED BABY OCTOPUS and could have not picked a better choice, it was so crunchy! 

PROS:
+ Fish quality is very very good.
+ Full bar

CONS:
- Sporadic server presence. No one was there to refill our water cups. When we were ready to order, to ask for drinks, to get our check: no one was around.
- i got a whiff of old carpet and basement smell for a hot sec when I was first seated.

SIDE NOTE:
I wasn't used to one-sized sushi rolls for all the different prices ranges. Each roll we had ordered had the same amount of pieces per roll, the same size in diameter, and all the rolls were rolled with the rice on the inside.  With that said the quality of the ingredients were really why the prices are different, which how it should be anyways.

Food: 4.0
Service: 3.0
Ambiance: 3.5
Value: 4.0
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I absolutely love this place! We got there just in time before the rush, but we still waited about 35-minutes. However, the servers were so nice. They took care of us while we were waiting and let us order hot sake shots, which made the wait bearable. 

The food was delicious. We ordered the Chirashi, which is the chef's selection of fish. This was good and the fish was very fresh. The rice was perfect. Make sure you order raw wasabi, which enhances your sushi experience. 

The best things we tried were the orange delight and the uni. By far, hands down, no doubt about it, best uni I have ever tried in my life. The unagi was great as well. Service was fast and friendly. Love the atmosphere. Food was great. Overall, I would definitely go back.
author: Janet T.

description: Food is decent. This place really gets an extra half star for staying open so late. Great place for that late night sushi craving. Be prepared to wait a lot of the time. Love the vibe and music they play. Sushi rolls are a bit basic but good.
author: Rebecca S.

description: There was a 2" piece of glass in our sushi roll. We were told it was a fish scale. My friend almost choked on it. I was greatly disappointed by how this restaurant handled the situation. No apology, nothing. Awful experience, awful service. Wouldn't recommend it.
author: Elysa S.

description: I wasn't too impressed with the sushi, maybe it was because we were the last customer of the day on a Thursday @ 1am who knows. I typically like my sushi cold to reflect the freshness & it was kind of room temperature. I'm very particular when it comes to raw fish, but aside from that we had some cooked rolls that were pretty good. I have to say the best part was the DJ! Asian dude had some jams all night, or the last hour & a half we showed up at least.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Last time I came here was apparently in 2014. Idk why it took so long to come back, but I need to be here more often! Came through at about 1:30am on a Saturday night. Still a group of customers, full kitchen. However the hot kitchen had already closed. Doesn't even matter, the sushi and sashimi was all we needed and it was the BEST. Also, major thanks to the staff for bringing out a surprise dish of mochi. It was a friend's bday and thought it'd be cool to have something like that. Originally they said there wasn't anything they could offer, but later surprised the whole table with the dish--came with even a candle! (no singing though, which is for the best). 

Finally, just want to reiterate that I'm a person that doesn't even like seafood. Let alone sushi. This place actually changed my mind and taste buds. Haven't come across any other place that compares.
author: Gabi H.

description: This place has great food and a fun hip atmosphere. Great place​ for date nights or a night out with friends. We got here at 5:50 on a Monday and 15 people were already waiting for them to open the doors. Definitely worth the wait.
author: Lauren J.

description: Have you ever been in the club and went man... I could really go for some sushi right now? If so, then this place will make your dreams come true. While not the best sushi ever, it's good for the price and the environment is hysterical. I came alone and sat at the bar and had a good time. I would recommend it for friends meeting up more than as a date spot. The music is loud and can make intimate conversation hard.
author: Straker C.

description:
My husband has spent a lot of time in San Francisco for work over the past several years.  He found Ryoko's and was hooked.  He'd talk about Wataru and how great this place was.  Our daughter and I were finally able to join him on this last business trip and I just HAD to get here.  

My daughter, who is a picky eater, LOVED it and so did I!  My husband usually stays near so it never dawned on him that walking to this place from the pier would be tough.  LOL!  But, it was worth it, for sure!  The sushi was great!!!  I also ordered teriyaki chicken and it was really good - we shared it and we all enjoyed it!!!   I ordered, at least, five different sushi rolls, and we all had drinks - expecting to pay well over $100, I was pleasantly surprised that it was barely over $100.  In SAN FRANCISCO?  Really?  We left the place stuffed and very happy!  

The ONLY reason I'm giving it four stars is for the noise level.  We were there about 1/2 after opening, got seated right away (with a perfect table), and then could barely hear each other.  That's okay - the food and service was well worth the noise!  :)

Thank you!!!!!!!
author: Ali K.

description: Decided to try this place since it was close to my hotel and I have to say I'm glad I did!! I came here on a Friday around 11pm and the place was pretty busy, I guess it's a popular spot. I put my name on the wait list and stood around for a few mins and the hostess found some room and seated us right away (party of three). Order a ton of food and a pitcher of beer, I thought the tab would be up there but it turns out that the pricing is very reasonable and fair (only 200 for 3 hungry guys). I would recommend to anyone who's in the area and craving some sushi.
author: Matt P.

description:
Quality late night Japanese food?  YES PLEASE.

Their extensive menu lists a variety of hot and cold appetizers, soups, sashimi, sushi rolls, salads, and drinks with reasonable prices.  It's a fun ambiance, especially because there's a DJ spinning while you're eating.

We ordered: chicken kara-age, Ryoko's salad, ochazuke (with salmon), spicy scallop roll, jumping tuna roll, and volcano roll.  The food arrived in a random order, but everything was tasty nonetheless.  My favorite dish was definitely the ochazuke, especially I haven't had really memorable ochazuke in awhile!

The service was spotty, but it was pretty busy for 1AM.  You should add Ryoko's as a definite go-to after a night out!
author: Annie P.

description: Expect about an hour wait when you come here. It's small, a bit cramped, but they make it happen. The fish is fresh, but this is definitely not the best sushi I've had in  San Francisco. Started with edamame and split probably 6 rolls and 4 orders of sashimi with a coworker. The smoked salmon is outstanding. The tuna is OK. Service is great, and there's a unique atmosphere with a fun vibe.
author: Bianca H.

description: Great, friendly authentic sushi place.  Ate alone at the bar and the service and food were excellent.
author: Karen S.

description: Yelp! Thanks for the recommendation! We got a seaweed cucumber salad, fried oysters, and six rolls with tea for $60. They were so good! The spot was fun, quaint and busy with good service. I would absolutely return!
author: Brigid P.

description:
i went early, by myself, and was able to get quickly into the bar seating. i tried to go on my last visit to SF and there was some crazy 2-hour wait. erhm, no thanks! this place is really tasty, and that offer some great daily specials. i would recommend going, but just don't be silly and wait 2 hours. there are too many restaurants to choose from to wait like that. it wasn't THAT good to wait 2 hours. 

bottom line: delicious sushi, but don't wait 2 hours for this.
author: Tammie E.

description: Place has gone down the toilet.  A couple years ago great.  Food is horrible now.  Ordered a couple rolls that looked like they had been prepared a week ago.  Disgusting.  Atmosphere nice what with the music and the screaming of staff when someone walks in the door.  Ordered a glass of wine and after 3 HANDFULS of ice (I like it cold) it barely made half a glass.  Wait staff cocky and abrupt.  Sad.
author: Lynne P.

description:
Chef Atsushi, Amazing Sushi concoctions, Live DJ

I love this place. Chef Atsushi is brilliant. He is also extremely polite and friendly. He always makes sure people are being taken care of and enjoy their food. He always comes up with unexpected sushi concoctions that is completely mind-blowing as long as you are open-minded and willing to let him experiment. One plate that gave me a foodgasm was this wagyu tartare dish topped with a quail egg that he made. It was exceptional. I still dream about it from time to time. 

Other times when I ordered off the menu the food was good and consistent. My friend who is a vegetarian loved it.

The only thing I would change is how popular this place is. On saturday nights there's at least an hour wait and there are people who go there and just order a beer and sit for hours. argh... go across the street there are a million bars. 


TIPS:
1. To avoid the wait arrive at 6:00 pm or after 10:30 pm.
author: Jennie C.

description:
We were looking for a sushi place near by and we came across Ryoko, I obviously scoped it out on Yelp and noticed some of my fellow CM's had reviewed it 4 and 5 stars so we thought we'd give it a whirl! 

You can't make a reservation at Ryoko so you have to hope the wait isn't too long. When we walked in there was a queue all the way out the door with people camped out on the stairs to get a table. Don't be put off by this, we only waited about 10 minutes. 

Once my name got called we were sat at the sushi bar which in my opinion were the best seats in the house. We got to watch the master craftsmen delicately slice and dice fish close up. 

We ordered a sharing platter and the volcano, Pokemon, Kentucky and tiger rolls. Our eyes were bigger than our bellies because we didn't get close to finishing the feast. Out of all the dishes the Kentucky was my favourite. Deep fried chicken deliciousness. 

This place is a little more expensive than other sushi bars but you pay for the relaxed vibe and the quality food.
author: Stevie M.

description: Such a great place time and time again. The sushi is quality and the servers are polite and know how to work efficiently. The lines to get tables tend to get long but they move quickly. Last time I went they had a live DJ which made the vibe that much greater. The ambiance is incredible. I always try to eat here when I visit.
author: Danielle S.

description: Great price value. If you like it noisy and electro music you will fall in love with this place. Better book a table on weekends or you might have to wait under the speaker in a stairway, which isn't the best way to start your evening.
author: Marc S.

description:
I love this place. I come here often wth my boyfriend to enjoy the woderful food, great environment, and the enjoyable DJ. 

We have been here about four times now and have yet to have a roll or dinner item we don't enjoy. 

Staying open late is the biggest plus for us, once we are both students and work odd hours. Sushi at 1am? Hell yeah!
author: Tatiana N.

description:
Can't believe this place has 4 stars. If you are an experienced sushi goer, don't go here. Fish quality was blah. 

This was the first time that I sat at the bar and was not allowed to order sushi at the bar! What's up with this place?! I felt disrespected. 

After an hour of disappointing dish after disappointing dish, I ended up paying $160 for myself!!!! I couldn't have been more disappointed. 

4 stars? Nope. The 2 I gave you was a bit much.
author: Stephen N.

description: Hidden at basement level - an absolute gem! Some of the best sushi I've had in my life. DJ played music, line out the door so quite a wait, worth every minute. Sending all friends traveling to SF here - will definitely be back!
author: Julia S.

description:
WHAT THE HECKKKK.... this aint no sushi. i don't know what this is...

i went last night. awkward wait on the stairs... waited about 30 minutes then got seated, which is totally fine

my problem is the food. WAY OVERPRICED for the quality. asians definitely know their sushi and the quality of their sashimis. when i went, it seemed like me and my boyfriend were the only asians there. makes a lot of sense, cause there's no way this place could have made 4 stars for quality. 

non-asians seem to think that california rolls are considered "sushi"... but nope, they're not. anyone can make california rolls... heck, even i can... sushi is sashimi and the sashimi here sucks. they serve you the cheapest ones for 5x the price. 

nuff said.
author: Alex C.

description: Love the place! Great service, great ambience, music was on point, and so was the food!
author: Winnie K.

description:
Pros-

Quickly seated
Drinks refilled without asking
Quick service 

Cons-

It didn't feel like the A/C was on. Very warm in the restaurant 
Everything I would've liked to order was not available. It wasn't out of season it was simply because the chef wasn't available to make it..... odd.
The tuna didn't seem fresh

I like to try different places when I come to the city so I'll just cross this one off the list and move on.
author: Lulu R.

description: This place gets lot and busy fast! I got there right when it opens at 6, so 2 of us got seated l, but as time goes by it gets pretty noisy (aside from lot pop music they play) and when we left there's a line at the door. The food here is fresh and tasty, but in a rather small portion for its price. So it's not a typical underground Japanese bar I'd compare to in NYC, usually those places has food in pretty good portion.
author: Julia Z.

description: For a late night sushi spot . This hits the spot when you are really crashing some Japanese rolls . And yes ...... it is pricey but it's so good when it 1 am in the morning .
author: Ro C.

description:
Went to Ryoko's for dinner.  Based on the reviews, I was very excited to try this place!  

Ordered the sashimi platter, uni, ankimo, a sushi roll, and agedashi tofu.  Maybe I'm just spoiled by Hawaii and Japan sushi, but I'm sorry..I don't see what all the hype is about this place.  

The ankimo was served without ponzu.  Maybe this is a Bay Area way to do it and only a Hawaii/Japan thing, but it was pretty bland without it.. 

The uni was probably the only thing I enjoyed from this dinner.  The sashimi was not very good..it didn't taste very fresh.  The sushi roll was okay, but then again, if you mix ahi with spicy sauce and mayo, it's bound to taste not as bad.  

The miso soup they brought out before the sashimi platter was lukewarm.  I was extremely hungry I just drank it quickly anyway.  But I ordered a second one at the end of the meal and asked the waitress to make it very heat hot, like nuke it in the microwave if they had to.  It came out lukewarm.  I'm sorry to not pick but it wasn't even busy..

At this point I was like eh, I give up.  Maybe they were having an off night, but overall quality for that price was not worth it at all.
author: Sasha L.

description: Great rolls. Lots of vegetarian options which are all pretty cheap. Also the beer pitchers are $15, which is pretty good.
author: Nitesh D.

description: Takes a while to get in, but the atmosphere is amazing. The servers and cooks were fun and moving fast. Would recommend for anyone looking to get a great SF food experience.
author: Jake F.

description:
It is not a quiet place, but everything else are splendid.

-do not need to wait for your order ( but be sure to stop by early. This restaurant is really popular)
-sea urchin is recommended
-I like how they place sushi on plate. It's art.
author: Dingding Sherry W.

description:
There are no Japanese workers. Totally fake Japanese restaurant.
Hall stuff had no education, that's why they don't know how to handle the people and tables, I was forced to wait 1 hour because of their terrible management.
author: Kotaro O.

description:
Went here last night with my friend for the first time after the wait at Elephant was over an hour and a half. We put our name on the wait list and were told it would be 30 minutes. True to her word, the waitress seated us almost exactly 30 min later. 

My biggest issue was with the prices. I usually try to get a sushi dinner assortment at a new sushi restaurant because it's generally the best deal and is a good tell of how high quality the fish is. The sushi dinner (9 pieces of nigiri and a 6 piece California roll w miso soup) was $40. Insane!! Even more insane was how TINY the nigiri was. They were no bigger than the width of my middle finger (for reference that's pretty tiny). The California roll was probably the highlight of the whole meal because it was made with real crab and was closer to a normal portion size. The rest was extremely disappointing. 

Admittedly the quality of the fish was pretty good overall, but it was definitely not worth $40. Not going back.
author: Maia R.

description: Sooo Ryokos was chosen by my girlfriend for her birthday dinner. This restaurant does not take reservations so we had to wait a good hour to grab a seat. After waiting an hour we were seated in a private room with another group which was a not so good decision. We ordered our drinks food etc. it took about 30 min to get water and the bday girls food arrived but not anyone else's. So then my food arrived and my other gf waited another 30 min for hers. The food in general was just so beyond inconsistent it was ridiculous. The waitress would only drop off the orders then u would never see her again in the steam pot of a room, all we had was a fan. The hype about this place is just a bit shocking considering there was not even anything crazy about it the sushi was just bleh, I wanted to order her a birthday dessert but after waiting so long some people being full more than others and the company we were over Ryokos and decided to dip out asap! And go to another restaurant.
author: Gabriella S.

description: Yeah. Don't get the hype of this place. Cute-enough basement venue. Pretty average sushi. Prices kind of on the high end. Seating/space cramped. Slow service (waited ten min for check). Not impressed. My neighborhood (Castro) is known for mediocre food, but I've had better sushi at least 4 places there. I mean, if there's a band playing here you like, I get it. Wouldn't go for the food though.
author: Sean B.

description: Some of the best sushi I have ever had!  The jumping tuna was so amazing!  Techno dance music was blasting which I thought I was going to hate, but it was so fun once you got into it.
author: Steve C.

description: 4 stars. The plate temperature was just right, warm enough to hold it to my face but not hot enough to be uncomfortable. Sushi was good, service was nice, and there was a FUCKING DJ. Would enjoy again.
author: Winston S.

description:
As soon as you head downstairs to enter the restaurant, you already feel like you've traveled somewhere new.

The sushi here is so reasonably priced and so well crafted. You can expect your standard rolls to be available here, but believe me, they are going to be better than you've had it. 

Aside from the sushi, the tamago is light and at room temperate the way it's supposed to be. The onigiri with salmon is tastey. And just for those out there who care, tamari is available! 

This place does get crowded pretty quickly so if you get here right at 6 you're set. Otherwise I've heard that you should show up at 10:30.
author: Alice H.

description: This place is gold, Jerry, gold! Strongly suggest the Golden Gate and the Jumping Tuna rolls. They both come with shiso and the latter is deep fried for a hot minute before being sliced. I wanted to drink the sweet/sour sauce it came with. Wash it all down with a Tokyo mule.
author: Jason V.

description: If you can wait 35 minutes on a Saturday to sit with your lady and have a food party this is the spot for you.  The price is standard for good sushi.  Everything in this place fits.  It's a perfect gem.
author: Cory F.

description:
A friend and his business partner were in town and asked about sushi near his union square hotel. I love in a different part of town, so I wasn't sure what to recommend. I used Yelp and filtered for at least 4 stars in Union Square, and this was was of the top 2 choices. Literally a hole in the wall, looks and feels like a dive bar, the sushi was super tasty, service was excellent, and pricing, well I have no idea, my buddy's business partner picked up the check.

We had unagi from Japan, and it was like a foie gras melting in my mouth. The sake and beer was good. Will certainly go back/recommend it to others.
author: Jordan C.

description:
The ambiance is really great, the decor is top-notch and the music is great.

The food, specifically the chirashi bowl, was quite gross.  The sushi was sticky and the first time I couldn't finish sushi.  This may be because I went about 45 minutes before closing time, but the sushi was just really terrible.

I'd have to go back again to check for sushi and fish quality.  Everything else was great!
author: Minjian W.

description: Busy little sushi spot. Be prepared to wait awhile if you come at peak hours. Food taste/quality is 3.5 stars certainly not the best sushi I've had, and not the worst. Service is 4 stars, they work hard there and are friendly. Ambience/location is 3 stars. Value is 4.5 stars (for the area.) I would return if I was in the mood and in the area.
author: Mermski C.

description:
Food is whatevers. The only thing good about this place is that it serves sake and pitchers of beer and is located in union square, so it's close to nightlife.  But don't come here just for the food. I'm warning YOU tourists!!!

PROS:
1. Location close to Downtown SF
2. Sake (XL $10) and pitchers of beer ($14) 

CONS:
1. Mediocre food 
2. Expensive price per value 
3. Long wait
4. Poor service

APPETIZER: 
* Tuna Yukke $14 (3 stars, I was expecting some delicious sauce, but none for $14?!)
* Yaki Onigiri $2.50 (2 stars, I was expecting some type of fish inside, but it's literally just a grilled rice ball :( 

ROLLS: 
* Crunchy crab $10 (3 stars, only 5 pieces?!)  
* Spicy scallop $5.50 (2 stars) 
* Jumping Unagi $8.50 (3 stars, only 6 pieces) 

OVERALL: I wanted this to be a place to pregame before nightlife in downtown SF...but the food will not get you full or satisfied :(
author: Raquel Y.

description: Great Place for SUSHI! This is always my go to spot after a night out on the town ! Atmosphere is always up beat and the DJ on the weekends is AMAZING !
author: CINDY B.

description: I would say this is a SF must see! Great atmosphere, amazing staff and a good mix of traditional and novel sushi at good market prices. Grab a pint and a seat at the bar to watch all the action!
author: Kirsty S.

description: My go to place for some reasonably priced sushi. I stick with the rolls here are quite good and the sushi/sashimi is a bit overpriced, but still good. The wait however is extremely long especially if you go on a weekend night.  The ambiance is hip but quite loud.
author: Jimmy T.

description: First of all place was very crowd, all tables are super close to each other, we were waiting for about 20 min in line which is ok it's Friday and we couldn't find a sushi place who open till later then 10pm, once we were seated we had to wait 15 minutes till waitress showed up and said "I will be right back to u guys", in about 15-20 minutes yea she got back but I don't get it if I'm at the table how come 30 minutes no one could take an order, and the next table couple were really mad about their order delay as well, so our waitress couldn't speak English at all, we barely placed an order, sushi were very tiny , pricy..... I'm really picky when it's time to eat sushi, so still it's so sad that I couldn't rate it higher, most likely I will never go to this place
author: Vladimir S.

description:
Very impressive by the over 2000 4 star review but I am actually not that impressed.

To summarize, good place to have a drink with friends but really not a great place if you are like me, just want to have a good dinner and chat.

I know it is a music venue and I am the kind of person who sometimes loves to go to a loud bar but still the music is deafening. 

The fish is fresh and the rolls are great. There are traditional thin rolls but also fusion rolls.

We also ordered the grilled eel plate but I would definitely NOT recommend anyone to order it. The eel is too thin and overcooked and the rice is too mush and does not taste like sushi rice. And the price (29.5) is on the high end compared to other dishes here.
author: Charlotte Wandai L.

description: Had dinner here last night.. first sushi awesome just had sashimi, nigiri, & hand rolls. Drinks and liquor selection great , I could have something other than sake and beer.  The atmosphere was,  to best describe it, alive everything was fun, they even had a dj playing mainly hip hop. Wait line was supposed to be 30 mins we where seated at the bar in 10, but if you do wait they will bring you drinks to get you nice and sauced up.  Service was ok and green tea ice cream tasted like frozen wheat grass ..  I will definitely be back and highly recommend it .. and I recommend getting any specials they have especially blue fin torró. Thanks for listening
author: Javier H.

description:
The vibe of this place is so cool. Loved the music the other night, hip-hop/R&B throwbacks. No reservations, so just plan to come early and chill, the sushi bar however, is first come-first serve, so try to snatch a spot there! 

We got an assortment of nigiri, a quite a few rolls. All the fish was super fresh and our server was MY HERO! I don't know how she did it, but she was successfully serving and hosting the entire place. 

Oh yeah, and it has a full bar! Me likey.
author: Mally S.

description: Great sushi love this place ! Always gotta stop by when I'm in the bay! Will be there this Sunday to give them a recent review !
author: Mike W.

description: I love this place and the DJ is dope as hell! This is the right before the club, let's get tipsy and full of sushi spot. Really good prices and a menu with more selection than you would think. The fact that there's a live DJ with real skill is a super plus. Watch your step if you are over 5ft 9in like me the ceiling is low and the floor is not as flat.
author: Joi M.

description:
I came here before it was open, and there was a line already.  That's a good sign, right?
I came with a party of 4, and we decided to order an appetizer and then 4 rolls.  The rolls came out and we were all surprised by how small each roll was.  5 pieces each, barely enough to fill us up, so we had to order more.  For the price of each roll, we were expecting more than 5 tiny pieces.
Aside from the small portions, the sushi was delicious.  We just weren't very full.
author: Karen L.

description:
I had just left a YEE and was a little Hungry.So I rolled my Whip Old Blue to Ryokos Japanese Restaurant . I was able to park right in front.

The placed was packed.. I put my name on the Wait list . 40 Minutes later I had a table. I ordered a Coke while I perused the Menu.

The DJ there is pretty good .  Played some Hip Hop.

I ordered  the Soft Shell Crab and the Sashimi Dinner . 

I liked the Vibe and the Atmosphere of the place . I also had an interesting conversation with some French Girls at the next table. Very Amusing.

My Soft Shell Crab Arrived it was very good. 

My Sashimi plate arrived. Disappointing very small portions , High Price Yikes

Service was good .

Paid by Discover Card and Rolled out.
author: Eugene L.

description: We knew they were playing the nba finals here so decided to come here and eat great food and watch the game. If your looking for a place to watch the game.. Definitely a pass because they have one small tv and it's hard to see. But definitely come here for amazing food and great music. Some of the best hibiki I've ever eaten! So fresh and full of flavor. The waitress recommended striped jack and it was the last order unfortunately but we were so glad to try it. They offer a full bar here also so we were faded and full!
author: Linh T.

description:
This restaurant was one of the highlights on our trip to San Francisco. It was well worth the 45 minute wait. The sushi chefs are brilliant and know what they are doing. The ambiance is very nice - a hole in the wall but yet cozy and intimate. 

We had the sashimi dinner, clam miso, regular miso, squid appetizer, tomago roll and the seaweed salad with kelp. Everything was fresh and amazing. The best sushi I've had in my days. I highly recommend this place. We couldn't stop smiling after we left - it really gave us an impression.
author: J. C.

description: Nice loud environment and warm sushi. I'm not a fan of this place. Meh at best... It's not bad, but not great.
author: aaron t.

description: Ended up here due to a missed reservation at Gary Danko because of an hour delay traffic and this was the only spot that was open very late until 2 am. The wait was super long and we tried to order most of the items on the special board, some were not available and Not impressed with the quality of fish here.
author: S T N.

description: Amazing! Hip atmosphere! Fresh, well played and very tasteful dishes all around. Murdered some sushi here tonight!!!
author: wayne y.

description:
Meal - May 2015

So glad to have stumbled upon this place. The queue was about half an hour when we went at around 21:30 but it was totally worth it. The food was fresh and perfectly done. The price was reasonable for the quality of the food. There was an in-house DJ spinning anything from house music to 80s RnB/Soul without making it feel out of place.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Delicious and reasonably priced sushi with high quality ingredients. There was something for everyone, from basic sushi to Japanese specialties. 

The music was loud, there was a line and seats were given at tables or the sushi bar, depending on the availability, so you need to be in the mood for this. 

The staff was polite and friendly and overall a very recommendable experience.
author: Mariona B.

description: Fun takes on sushi rolls (Kentucky), but all the classics too. Great quality. The food was amazing - try as many specials as you can but anything in the menu was also great.  Fun atmosphere with good music and friendly staff.
author: Alaine D.

description: This place is the worst when it comes to customer service, their wait time is ridiculous and just the overall service was terrible. They lack in understanding and making sure that their customers are happy. They are never able to answer any questions for their customers, their waitresses are rude and talk to the customers any way they want. I watched a server yell at a customer, in front of other people. Just an overall terrible experience and I never plan on going back!
author: Princess H.

description:
You come downstairs into this hidden gem.  There are lots of tables and multiple rooms to the rear of the restaurant. Ryoko's is an excellent choice as compared with some of the more modern or chic sushi bars in the area. It offers very affordable salads, rolls, sushi and sashimi. 

It is typical to wait a few minutes before being seated. However, while you wait, you get to watch the knife-wielding sushi masters hard at work. 

I was seated after about a 10-minute wait. Almost as soon as I sat down, the waiter brought water and a complimentary bowl of edamame. Score! They satisfied my immediate thirst and hunger. 

I chose their sashimi dinner, which is about 18 pieces of chef choice fish for $30. Yum! Fresh! What a joy to have stumbled across this spot! 

Plan to wait a few minutes for a table. You'll be glad you did! Plus, they don't do carry out orders, so relax and enjoy the whole Japanese experience.
author: Tamia G.

description:
If you're looking for a fun, energetic, somewhat sensibly priced sushi and don't mind waiting in line for app 30 mins, Ryoko's a good choice. 
It feels exclusive, hidden and off the grid, but there're actually quite a few tourists here. 
Great for late night eats too
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Doesn't take reservations.
Wanted to see what the hype was about, so we waited 44 minutes to be seated for two. 
Miso soup- salty and tastes metallic. (Complementary with sashimi dinner) 
Sashimi dinner($40)- OMG SO WORTH. Melt in your mouth, such fresh cuts. 
Sake(salmon)- sinfully delicious, mouth watering. 
Sweet shrimp($8)- so fatty 
Service- since it's packed, understandably slow and inattentive. But kind when they're at your table. 
Def worth the wait!
author: Christina O.

description: Came here about 11 on a Wednesday night and the place was packed. Great Kikusui special for 18$. Sushi is best if you keep it pretty basic, but we had fun and good food and drinks.
author: Andrew M.

description:
We were staying at a hotel near by and wanted to check this place out. Luckily we arrived at 6pm and got seated, because after that there was a long line for tables! That is a good sign I guess. 

The food is good, reasonably priced. We ordered a few specials from the menu of fresh fish imported from Japan. We got scallop and toro.. it was so delicious. The rolls there are pretty good too, my favorite was the spicy scallop and the one that has peanut butter in it.

The staff are also fun and they work hard to keep up with all the tables.
author: Shaun N.

description:
Sushi bar in the basement. When there's a wait, people wait on the stairs. Loud music playing from the DJ. Friendly sushi chefs greet you when you come in. 

When I first came here, it did not look like there were that many people. But we did end up waiting about an hour to be sat, probably even longer. This was due to the fact that they also sat what seemed like the two girls that supposedly worked there before everyone else. They did not have to wait at all. UNDERSTANDABLE... 

but it seemed like the wait got messed up because some ppl that came after us were seated first. Weird. 

The food was good. My favorite was the takoyaki and the toro! 

The server mistook my boyfriend for a girl and she accidentally greeted us by saying "how are we doing ladies!" HAHAAHHAA. It was funny. 

Place is also a bit cramped but hey, it's SF, I get it. I don't think they have AC on in there because it felt like the heater was on blast when we came in. We sat right next to the stairs where people go up and down to use the restrooms and luckily there was a cheap little fan across from us :) 

Prices were expensive but the plates are very presentable. I would recommend the 49ers, toro and the takoyaki (my number 1 faveeee) 

Would I come back here? Probably not. I don't think it is worth the wait!
author: Alina T.

description:
Probably some of the best sushi I've had in a LONG time. It was so fresh and delicious! The vibe of the place was casual and busy. I only had to wait a few minutes for a seat at the sushi bar, but there was a line out the door after I sat down. It fills up quickly! 
I loved the atmosphere and the staff was so friendly. Service was a bit slow since they were so busy, but I wasn't in any hurry so I didn't mind taking my time. I personally prefer that over getting everything all at once and being rushed out. 
I will definitely return next time I am in town!
author: Justine S.

description:
This place is great! My party got there a few mins before they opened and there were already several groups waiting outside of the door and this was a Thursday. 

I had the Jumping unagi roll, tempura and some sashimi. Everything was delicious and the fish was fresh! 

The service is great and I would certainly come back!
author: Deanna B.

description:
The sushi chefs were great, making us everything we could order before closing time. Some of the selections were out since it was 1:30am on a Tuesday but what they did have was stellar. Did not expect to find this place with such great cuts of fish.

The Sockeye Salmon was nice and fatty, the flavor was amazing. Big Eye Red Tuna was outstanding, deep red pieces. We had a number of rolls but couldn't remember all the names although I do remember having the 49ers Roll being in San Francisco. It was simply gorgeous and delicious slices of fish that was anything but mediocre.

I wanted the Yamazaki 12 but it was also out! Had to choose the other 12 Year Whiskey instead (I know, it's terrible!) We ended up ordering 6 glasses of that, which is the reason I can't remember the brand. The service was great. They checked to make sure our waters were filled and we had everything we needed. Didnt pressure us to order but did tell us when last call was. Can't wait to go back next time I roll into town.
author: Dawen H.

description: Small portions. Mediocre service. The drink was ok but it's hard to mess up a mai Thai. Also the Dj music was a fun touch for a late night dinner. Snide waitress, gave me a hard time about the simplest requests including asking her to change out a twenty so I could tip her out, out of all thing? Will try somewhere else next time.
author: C M.

description: We were recommended this hole in the wall sushi joint for dinner close to our hotel near Union Square and we were not disappointed!! There was a line about 5 groups long when we got there around 8:30pm on a weekday but we filled our name in on the clip board and were seated within a few minutes of waiting.  It's a small place but they turn tables quick! We got the fried cheese, scallop roll, yellowtail sashimi, Jumping Tuna, and Cali roll! All of those were outstanding and the price is on par with most other sushi places so around $5-$9 for most 6pc rolls. If you're in town and want some great sushi up until 2am then this is a solid choice!
author: Kyle B.

description: Love this place. Very unassuming basement sushi spot near Union Square. Friendly service and house music make it a very eclectic environment. Tuna Party is my choice when they have it. If you are looking for a fun hole in the wall sushi place in the city, this place checks all of the boxes.
author: Darren G.

description: Ryoko's is the place for you if you're looking for Japanese comfort food, yummy sushi and a boisterous energetic meal. This used to be a favorite place when I used to be in the city a lot so we wanted to check it out on a quick weekend trip to SF. After 8 years, it's still exactly what I remember. Delicious rolls, perfectly cooked karage and a decent size selection of great sakes coupled with fun music and energy. Wish I could find a Ryoko's style joint here in LA.
author: Patty O.

description:
Cutest, sushi place I've ever seen. From the decor, to the music, to the to the young and fun atmosphere. The specials were very good and tasty. This by far is going to be my favorite sushi place. Makes me want to to fly to SF just to have sushi here . 
All around it was very nice. 
I'm definitely coming back. 
Thank you
author: Danny S.

description:
Unimpressed.

Profit over service. Hostess runs around like crazy barking at staff and customers alike. Menu thrown down and asked 3 times in 3 minutes if ready to order. Food also thrown down in front of me without any care or politesse. At one point the hostess put the food down so aggressively she knocked the soy sauce bowl over - when I pointed this out she just looked at me - no apology, no check to see what needed cleaning. Ho

Food is fine, average for sushi in SF. Expensive of course but that's SF. Served too quickly with all dishes arriving within 2 minutes of each other. Not especially creative.

I appreciate a little service and care for my $100. This place does not deliver and I would recommend heading around the corner to Sanraku where the service is friendly, the food excellent, the ambience more sophisticated and the chef very talented and caring about what he serves.
author: James P.

description:
This is probably the best example of American Japanese food ive ever eaten, bar none. Whats American Japanese food? Think, like, American Chinese food (orange chicken? Baked cha siu?) but then i want you to withdraw all negative thoughts of divey chinese take out spots and panda expresses, whats left is pure gluttonous awesomeness of flavor and texture thats hard to find in many other establishments. 
The Koraage is deliciously crunchy and tender at the same time, the tea is delicious (if youre into that) and the beer is... Well, they have beer, isnt that all that matters? 
Id call it more izakaya than sushi for certain though, a unique display of which my very white, bearded, texan, comedian friend calls "kentucky" which is the koraage in a sushi roll and is what defines my description of american japanese food. 
The tomago, which i will try at any restaurant that serves it, was underwhelming, however.
Ive always been told that a restaurant may be famous for the truffle and foie and caviar but anyone who actually knows what theyre talking about will make all judgements on the humblest of dishes, the egg, if the egg dish, whether it is an amuse, app, entree, main, passe, dessert, whatever, if it isnt correct then what is the value of adding all the expensive flavorful crap on top? Tomago should be purely creamy yellow and a piece that is as cohesive as a slice of tofu, with little to no browning and a fluffy, airy texture that melts like butter, and sorry guys, but ive had better, so take some time and practice, so i can come back and give the egg star back!
Overall though, ryokos is a san francisco mainstay for sure.
author: Cameron Y.

description:
"...This place sucks" 
-Kazunori Nozawa

"F#?k that place!" 
-Nobuyuki "Nobu" Matsuhisa 

Anyone who loves real sushi should skip this spot. 

It's open late and that's about all it has going for it. The menu is totally "basic bitch", look at it. Go ahead, check it out. It's 2 pages of bland, tasteless, whack ass options. 

Make a drive to Mission, take a flight to a different city, but don't bother coming here unless you want to be overcharged for crappy sushi and poorly made drinks. 

**avoid the way overpriced $25 special "Manning roll". Shrimp is listed as an ingredient but wer'e pretty sure they just threw old shrimp tails on the ends. 

Whomp whomp
author: Manuel B.

description: Awesome sushi! we loved this place and glad we decided to seat at the bar! Service could be better but judging by the waiting crowd and all the customers, I can understand the delays in service. Food was great and one of the best that I have ever had. Highly recommended.
author: Kamran N.

description: Oh man, this place was fantastic. After a long day of exploring San Francisco with my friend, we were both in the mood for some great Japanese food and we were definitely not disappointed. First of all, the atmosphere was great. It was lively, everyone was having a great time, and it was just a great experience overall! We got there right before the line got really long so expect a wait if you come during rush times. My friend wound up getting two sushi dishes and I got chicken teriyaki and tempura dishes. All of the food was really delicious so there were no complaints there! We were both just in a really good mood throughout the dining experience because the place was so lively and if you're looking for good Japanese restaurants close to Union Square, Ryoko's is definitely the place.
author: Michael L.

description: My friend and I passed this place and saw a long line and was thinking that it must be good! After the John Pence gallery, we went there and put our names down. Took about a 30 min wait...there was about 20 ppl in front of us...I think no one wanted the sushi bar, better for us! We ordered 4 rolls and all of the them were really good! Because my friend and I took advantage of the art gallery's free, yes free, wine, we were alrdy buzzing so I do not remember the rolls. It was just 49ers, big momma and two others! Superrr good! They had a live DJ playing top 40 music so the vibe was pretty cool. I'd def come again and recommend!
author: Isabelle C.

description:
Came in here late on a Tuesday and the place was mostly empty, which made for great service. Food was there quickly and promptly.

It's just the food was just fine. Nothing special, which is a little disappointing considering the price. I got there rolls, including the spicy salmon and the 49er. The spicy salmon, at nearly half the price, is the better choice.

My one gripe is that the place does not allow takeout. If you're looking to stay in, you'll find a nice place with good music music that plays to a young, attractive crowd.
author: Mike V.

description: Overhyped gimmicky sushi joint. Perfect for a group trying to get turnt/chug sake and beer and eat above average rolls, but as far as actual quality of fish goes - you can get much better in SF. They have a DJ blasting edm and the location itself is in a dive-bar looking basement. If you're looking for a party accompanied by mediocre sushi or refined late night munchies this is your spot but if you're looking at food first, this is a hard pass.
author: Charles W.

description: This place is so cool if your visiting San Fransisco you should try this restaurant. When you get in the restaurant everyone saying hi to you together like heeeeeeeey  it's so funny, and the food is amazing I tried couple roll and all of them were good. They are very fast. When you order your food they gonna bring it for you less than 10min. And don't forget to order Muchi for dessert
author: Amir Z.

description: LOVE IT!!! This place doesn't open for dinner until 6PM and will fill up within first 5 minutes and they don't take reservations so you may have to wait. But once you had their food, it is so worth it. I got all nigiri: hamachi, toro, sweet shrimp, salmon and other items. The quality of the sushi is very fresh and everything was delicious. Price is not too bad for San Francisco. It's about $7 per sushi order, which is pretty good for the quality.
author: Quyen H.

description: I've been to so many sushi places over the years, and Ryoko's sticks out in my mind as very interesting place. They have a wide range of fresh fish to eat and something new every few weeks.  It was pricey, yes - but oh so worth it. I would highly recommend this place.  Incredibly fresh, the sauces perfect and the service extremely friendly.
author: Adam P.

description: The sushi here is amazing. Everything we tried was super fresh and melted in your mouth. From sweet shrimp, fatty tuna, hamachi, unit and the tasty rolls, this place was winning. You would think by the speed of delivery of the food to our table that there would be a sacrifice in quality...but there was NONE!  Plus we had a DJ spinning cool beats. I'm definitely returning on my next trip to SF!
author: Kelley S.

description: This place is the real deal. We only had to wait about ten minutes, but the line definitely grew behind us. I would recommend getting there before 7pm for shorter lines. The Toro was amazing sashimi
author: Jared L.

description: Ryokos, what would otherwise be a hipster sushi place with its basement apartmentesque entry way and 2 hour lines is saved by what is arguably some of the best sushi in town. You know it's delicious because despite also being frequented by hipsters, drunken club closers, and foodies, there are a surprising number of native Japanese willing to brave the crisp San Francisco winds for some fresh off the boat specials. And I cannot say I'm surprised as this place has something for everyone to love: with monkfish and mackerel, as well as other Japanese delicacies, to fried soft shell and philly rolls. The ingredients are super fresh and the service, while not speedy, is plain good.  As other reviewers have noted, this place isn't cheap but for SF it's on the better side of decent for cost and definitely a value in quality. Not the best neighborhood, but such is the spice of life. This place remains a go-to staple for me when I find myself in SF.
author: Adina P.

description: I wrote a review in 2013, and here is my 2017 update. A few years ago I was a regular at Ryokos, but moved and this would be my first time back. Sadly this spot has become very touristy and boarder line cluby. Maybe that part of the review is because I am getting older. However, the sushi rolls are not the same either. The rolls I order were cut unevenly, huge piece at the end so you have to cut it to fit it in your mouth. And when I walked out I looked at the sushi bar and they had pre-cut salmon sashimi​, that was all piled up and not looking very appetizing. Isn't that the point of sushi, how you slice it when ordered?! Sorry Ryokos but that was no bueno, not to mention over priced.
author: Erin J.

description:
The food was good, we ordered the checkerboard and volcano roll after 2 miso soup, well great after the miso soup.
It was not  specified in the menu it was 6 pieces for the price of 12. And because we were still hungry we ordered the sexi roll and sashimi.
I'm going to say that while you can really taste the peanut butter in the volcano roll, and the checkerboard had three different kinds of fish, the sexi roll was the best.
Not only we came to a decision it was an interesting kind of roll, but we actually saw the cheesy roll ( ingredient mentioned on the menu)  melt on the teeny tiny oven across the sushi bar, being brought over to us afterwards. Surprise !
author: Ale B.

description: The sushi was pretty expensive for small portions, even by sushi standards. Service was alright (not rude, but hard to contact server), perhaps due to being in a secluded room. They had some interesting east-west fusion style combinations, though the taste was also alright. You pay for the atmosphere and decor, so if you're into the whole underground/dimly lit/dirty-but-not-quite aesthetic, this is your place. Don't be fooled by the wait- people tend to eat slowly and chat/celebrate here, as evidenced by their 2 hour time limit. Overall, if you have money to blow, I still suggest you find somewhere else.
author: Linus C.

description: The dragon roll, jumping eel something and the beef teriyaki made my day complete! Kevin was awesome and the ambiance was cool! 5 star all the way!
author: Melo R.

description: It's so fresh and so good! This is why I can only be pescetarian and not vegetarian. The ambiance is so bustling/hip/fun and I love how it's underground, like speakeasy style. The best. My favorites were toro sushi & spicy golden gate roll, but my friend loved the salmon & scallop sashimi. The jumping tuna roll is meh, not very flavorful at all but it's fried so people love that shit. Rolls are really small, it's definitely not about quantity here. The hostess/waitress serving everyone is super sweet and funny too :P
author: Vivian W.

description:
This place has some good sushi, not amazing 
Their prices are relatively fair for SF
They get really busy, and it took us 45 minutes to get our sushi. We then waited another 30 minutes for a waitress to get our other order.

It's a good place to go if you don't Mind the wait.
author: Jad A.

description:
Mr. NSS: "Who's Atsushi Matsuda?"
Me: "Huh?"

Mr. NSS: "Atsushi Mastsuda...it says, 'call me' with his name on his business card."
Me: "Uhh, why are you snooping?!?!"

Mr. NSS: "Your purse fell and a wad of business cards came out."
Me *Grabs business card*: "Ohhhh, he's the sushi chef at Ryoko's. He said to call him beforehand if we want to do omakase so he can have the specialty fish in stock."

Mr. NSS: "Are you sure you just weren't drunk again?"
Me: "No, it's not what you think. I always get random numbers...remember last week? I asked for our taxi cab driver's number so we can hook up L."

Mr. NSS: "Yes...but baby, you're not Patti Stanger so please stop trying to play matchmaker."

It's been nearly four months since I been to Ryoko's but what better reminder than last night's incident for me to finally write a review.

First things first, don't come to Ryoko's without a reservation. We had reservations for the sushi bar for Sunday night at 6 pm. We walked into a half empty restaurant only to later have a swarm of tourists and foreign exchange students anxiously waiting on the stairway gawking at us as techno music blared in the background. Definitely feels like eating in an underground 90s club with cramped tables and a wobbly staircase to the bathroom upstairs. Needless to say, this is not the best date place unless you plan to get your date drunk with sake bombs and take her to the nearest Motel 6. 

Don't be surprised if you're the only local here which may explain the pricier than usual menu (e.g. Rainbow Roll is $20).

I've said this a million times (or at least it feels like it) but the only way to go at a sushi restaurant is omakase or order from the "White Board Specials": http://bit.ly/11Qa3KI. We requested that Atsushi-San, our awesome sushi chef create an Nigiri Omakase ($50 minimum) for us and gave him a budget of $60 a person.

For the Nigiri Omakase, we each received 10 pieces consisting of Hirame (Fluke/Flounder), Mebachi Maguro (Big Eye Tuna), Hamachi Toro (Yellowtail Belly), Wild Sockeye Salmon, Uni (Sea Urchin), and Tamago (Egg Omelet): http://bit.ly/VGzZ4j. Additionally, we received Aji (Horse Mackerel) w/ Fried Carcass: http://bit.ly/14VjGaH, and Amaebi (Sweet Shrimp): http://bit.ly/YWDcDf w/ Fried Heads: http://bit.ly/WRov1r. 

The nigiri was good but not spectacular especially for the price. All the fish was fresh and the shari were nice bundles of seasoned rice but each mouthful was not *eyes roll back into your head* orgasmically buttery. However, my favs of the night were the sockeye salmon (the buttery-est of them all) and sweet amaebi with accompanying deliciously crunchy heads. I didn't care for the watery guacamole-like wasabi though. 

I'm not a fan of jive ass rolls but we ordered one as a filler since we were still hungry. The Orange Delight Roll ($13) was f*cktastic: http://bit.ly/VZMNVx. Atsushi-san was kind enough to top the avocado and cucumber roll with fatty slices of salmon belly (instead of regular salmon) which made each bite sublime. Silky, and intensely buttery, this was the BEST roll I've ever had and definitely made our visit to Ryoko's worthwhile even though we initially came for the omakase. 

The staff was super sweet and you won't find a pretty solid sushi place that's open till 2 am so 4 solid stars for Ryoko's. Side note: If you're looking for the best sushi in SF (Japanese owned), head over to Ino (J-town), Koo (Inner Sunset) or Okina (Inner Richmond). 

Be forewarned though, Ryoko's is NOT a place to come drunk because you can easily run up the tab to $100-$150+ a person or end up with random business cards/numbers like "some" people...

*Embarrassingly hides face with jacket*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I'm really not sure why this place has a line outside.
This is by far the most disappointing, mediocre and overpriced sushi I've had in the city. Not impressed by any dish, with some rolls cut so sloppy it felt like an insult.
author: Ofer G.

description: Amazing Japanese food and almost authentic with Japan itself - loved it here and will definitely come back!
author: Corinna P.

description:
Very special and nice place / atmosphere. 
Had plattern with different kind of sushi - it was sooo good. 
When we return to SF we definetly visit them again!!
author: Thomas H.

description: Best Sushi I have ever had. VERY fresh ingredients allows for naturally tasting GOOD food, Oh la la. Try the fried cheese, Philadelphia, chicken karage, lightly seasoned mackerel, hot tuna... rainbow, miso soup, seaweed salad...everything!
author: Michelle F.

description:
Very lovely bar except that it was too dim.
Didn't manage to get any alcohol because of presence of minors, but the food was fine.
The lighting, although too dim, was particularly good for food pictures.
Loved the sushi, but the oysters were only so-so. I mean they are good, but too small (a type of Kusshi oysters, I think. I am just too greedy.) 
The sushi rolls were fine, but I am not a fan of sushi rolls anyway, and they are slightly over priced. 
That lands this place with 3 stars instead or 4 or 5.
author: Monica Z.

description: Crazy good Sushi and priced right. Long lines, sit at bar and have a draft!
author: Chris G.

description:
Some of the best Sushi in town.  Do note that there is always a long line, so if you are in a rush or with a large group, you'll have a long wait during high peak times which starts at around 7:30ish.  It is a bit pricey, but there are some things in life you do go cheap on and that is Sushi.  Also understand that you are in San Francisco and you are getting some of the freshest sushi in town, that doesn't come cheap.

Also, some of the other Sushi places in walking distance are good also, so again if you are in a rush and show up with a line, don't hesitate to find another local Sushi place.
author: Kyle D.

description: Very good sushi and at a good price! Awesome ambient, the food came out on a timely matter! I had the jumping tuna and jumping California both great plates I will defiantly recommend for anyone visiting or staying in San Francisco to come try it! You might have a little wait time because how popular it is and the small space.
author: David C.

description: It was def worth the wait!! I went with my friends and we def enjoyed ourselves. I've never been to a sushi bar with a DJ! I'd recommend this place to anyone who hasn't been. The sushi was AMAZING. 5 stars for me
author: Theresa B.

description: The sushi rolls are very tasty. Try the fried rolls. I also loved the chicken teriyaki with steamed rice. The waitress was very nice and attentive. Great DJ.
author: Janelle M.

description:
I'm confused as to how this place is so highly rated.  I must confess being from LA I'm somewhat of a "sushi snob" but other than their Traditional sushi it left much to be desired. 

The specialty drinks tasted like watered down bar mat slop. 

The rolls lacked flavor of any kind.  Came in after SuperBowl and they had a manning roll special which they thought was worth $25 due to shrimp tempura being in it.  I never tasted and shrimp only saw the fried tails which is probably the only shrimp involved and showed in the end. On a plus side the chefs skill with decorating a plate with mayo and siriacha so it looks like a mess of period blood and cum was decent
author: Steve A.

description: Pretty good sushi and a lively environment. A great place to go with a group of friends, but I wouldn't recommend it if you're trying to have a quiet dinner.
author: Mona L.

description:
I came here near midnight for some late might sushi snacking. The venue is in a basement with hip decor and pretty good EDM music. This restaurant is known for it's creative sushi rolls, like the jalapeño peanut butter volcano roll and the salmon mango avocado Pokemon roll. Delicious. However, if you're looking for simpler classic rolls for a nice dinner, you might want to look elsewhere. If you want creative rolls up until 2am, this is your place!

I was greeted by Jenny, a lively lovely Thai waitress who sat me at my table and took my order. When I asked for some recommendations, she suggested I start with the fried baby octopus (Iidako) and suggested some rolls, including the special for tonight, the Eli roll which is the regular tiger roll (avocado and shrimp tempura) but with spicy tuna on top. My reviews of the rolls are below:

The fried baby octopus was crispy and chewy and not too salty, so it was nice that I could add as much soy sauce and lemon (which it came with) to flavor it how I wanted it.

The Pokemon roll has avocado, salmon, and mango in it but somehow the flavors didn't work together super well. I think the salmon was fresh and the mango was sweet but possibly not ripe enough. Still not bad.

The volcano roll that so many others have mentioned makes the jalapeño peanut butter combo work really well, though these are the strongest flavors, whereas the shrimp tempura and roe are still more subtle in the background.

Next was the flying Tuna roll which is totally tempura'd on the outside. It's a really savory roll with lots of flavor from the grilled tuna and japanese mayo in the middle, which finishes with a crunch from the tempura. I think the outside could be a bit fresher though.

The special Eli roll was really aesthetically pleasing and packed with flavor. Even without the sriracha mayo sauce on the side, the spicy tuna was really fresh and flavorful and worked well with the shrimp tempura flavor and avocado. It was a filling and enjoyable combination of raw fish and tempura shrimp.
author: Simon Z.

description:
I wanted to like this place, it had a lot of really good things going for it like an awesome dj and the fact that it's in a pretty cool venue but I left feeling disappointed.

Going in to the venue was awesome. There was a dj spinning some awesome tunes and I felt myself jamming to it a lot during the night while eating. The crowd seemed like a lot of young twenty to thirty somethings about to go to a night out and that's usually a sign of pretty good food. We didn't even wait too long to get seated which is surprising for a Friday night. 

As for the food, I got a sashimi dinner and my boyfriend got the chirashi bowl. Maybe because it was late on a Friday night after im assuming the dinner rush just left but the quality of fish was not good. Even the rice that they gave me with the sashimi dinner had an odd taste to it so I asked for sushi rice instead. We also got a toro sushi since my boyfriend never got toro before and I was hoping that it would at least be worth the price but sadly it was not. 

I really don't like giving okay reviews but I left this place feeling pretty disappointed for the price I paid so maybe next time I visit San Francisco and if we decide to go to this place again well go earlier in the night to see if it lives up to the hype. 

Or just for the tunes. Either way it's a solid 3 for the service and venue. :)
author: Gaita H.

description:
4.5 I want to say.

What I like about Ryoko's is decent sushi for a good price if you stick with the cheaper rolls. They are better than many places and they do not cost as much. Take for instance the spicy scallop roll. It costs $7.00, but the quality is quite good for what you get. I also like the Pier 39 roll - imitation crap wrapped with asparagus. It only costs $5.00 and is pretty filling.

The ambience is loud, party like but it's fun and exciting and is a good way liven up a Friday night. 

Lastly, Ryoko is open late and is a welcome option when everything closes so early.
 
So come to Ryoko's if you crave sushi and are out late at night. It's a fun experience and pretty decent if you buy the
right things.
author: Anthony N.

description: So delicious.  Best sushi ever.  The wait was worth it.  Don't leave though.  If they call your name and you aren't there, you lose your place on the wait list.
author: Lisa S.

description: Great place.  Turn up sushi joint especially  on the weekends.     Sushi is absolutely fresh and delicious the crowd is good in the music as well.
author: Chris S.

description:
This place was great. On a Friday night, my buddy and I wanted to get sushi and we came upon this place on Yelp. This was great. We had to wait about 25 minutes to get our seats but the waiting staff got us our drinks when we were on line so that was awesome. 
We got the edamamne and octopus to start. I got the mackerel sashimi which was pretty great.Then I had something called the 'sexy' sushi roll which was a crab and avocado combo with melted cheese and that was excellent. 
My buddy had the Alaskan sushi roll which was salmon and asparagus and that was definitely the highlight of the meal. Definitely getting that next time. 
The atmosphere was pretty rad, the restaurant was underground and pretty dark. But the place was hopping with business and a bit loud. Sometimes the waiting staff would scream out in unison something in Japanese so it was fun. However, it was a tiny bit pricy and I would definitely go back and maybe the next time I would get a bit better selection. Excellent place though!
author: Jisan Z.

description:
Awesome sushi place in SF!

Ryoko's is a little whole in the wall located in a basement in Lower Nob Hill. It's very understated, so other than hearing the crowd when the door opens or reading reviews on Yelp, it would be easy to walk by. 

On a Monday night, my friend and I waited for about 20 minutes to get a table. You can tell the servers work to get everyone in and out as they are non-stop running between tables - very impressive.

Sometimes deep fried rolls can be too much for me. However, you can hardly tell the Jumping Tuna is fried! The sushi here is so fresh and rolls are pretty inexpensive compared to other SF locations.
author: Emmy Q.

description:
LATE NIGHT DELICIOUSNESS
(4.25 stars)

Yummy food, DJ, hip hop, hilarious conversations.

- FOOD, crackin
- PRICES, affordable
- SERVICE, good
- AMBIANCE, hmmm the basement

I found my new favorite "hole in the wall sushi joint". I hear HIPHOP?! and see a DJ spinning on the piano. Interesting! variety on the menu, maybe we ordered too much. Our bill was heavy, nearing $250 but well worth it. 

HEFFER STATUS

* ANKIMO (8.95) - monkfish liver. we had several orders of this and i was skeptical to try it. liver? i just dont do. BUT WHY WAS IT SO CREAMY AND GOOD?! that was interesting. 

SASHIMI (several order of)
* UNAGI ($7.50) - ate so much, can't remember what i ate
* TORO (seasonal) - ate so much, can't remember what i ate
* SHIROMAGURO ($4.25) - ate so much, can't remember what i ate
* HONMAGURO (seasonal) -  ate so much, can't remember what i ate

ROLLS (several orders of)
* SPYICY SCALLOP ($5.50) - marinated scallop in spicy sauce, shiso, and cucumber. WOW seriously? This was so good. yummy.
* TAHOE ($7.00) - tuna, avocado, and flying fish. my favorite roll of the night. something about it was just so damn delicious. i coudn't stop eating it.
* CRUNCHY CRAB ($10.00) - deep fried soft shell crab, cucumber, and mayonnaise. this was pretty good too.
* PHILADELPHIA ROLL ($6.50) - Smoked salmon, cucumber, and cream cheese. not much of a fan of this one. wasn't feeling the cream cheese in the roll.
* BUNCH OF OTHER THINGS I LOST COUNT OFF - all were good

Will I be back? Yup. I think this could be an every Friday evening spot for me. Love it.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description: The sushi was so delicious and so fresh! The atmosphere is fun and hip, great for parties. I took one star off as the menu was a little small! Otherwise, awesome and well worth the wait!
author: Niamh M.

description: We went to check this place out today and the food and service were good even though they didn't have the crunch roll we originally wanted. Overall, very nice place. Come quick because we got there less than 10 minutes after opening and it was already packed.
author: Gil D.

description:
I would give this place 3.5 stars, but have to round down to 3. Came here on a crowded Friday night and had a good time. It was a happy, slightly dim atmosphere with bar seating and tables. 

My friend and I ordered:
salmon 
white tuna toro
pokemon
avocado 
unakyu
Alaskan

Overall, the sushi was alright and reasonably priced but didn't blow us away. The wasabi was a bit overpowering in the salmon and white tuna, and the Alaskan roll was way too salty. The Pokemon roll seemed like the roll to get. The soy paper and mango combination was interesting. Another thing I noticed were that the rolls were very unevenly cut. Nonetheless, if I'm downtown and craving sushi, I will be coming back here.
author: Christina G.

description: So this is a hidden gem of a place; people lined up constantly to be seated as i sat by bar to eat.  Delicious sushi and wonderful place.  The guys making the sushi say some japanese chant and the wait staff responds, so it's fun.  Lovely place; i'll be back. Had the unfiltered cold sake, delicious.
author: Neveen B.

description: This place is really good and extremely popular. I arrived around 6:00 pm and it was already full. While I waited for a table in a matter of 5 minutes the line stretched out the door to the sidewalk!
author: Jerome O.

description: Really nice sushi, great customer service too, very fast service. I really liked their attentiveness and refilling water without being too overbearing. Overall I thought it was fresh, delicious and will return soon.
author: John D.

description:
Great sushi. 

Came here late at night when I was stuck by a carving for sushi. I was bracing myself for the worst as I haven't really found a sushi place I like in the city. 

This place is great. Awesome friendly service, great music and the sushi was awesome. 

You can tell it's good when you don't need tamari tho give it flavor. The avocado was on point, tasted fresh. 

Coming back here often :)
author: Paula R.

description:
Terrific sushi and decent izakaya that attracts quite a crowd!  If you are patient enough to get seated, most likely the food will not disappoint.  This place is underground and will transport you to Tokyo (or NY) with its ambiance.  Intimately lit, tightly packed, Ryoko's offers the nice glow of warm chatter.  Beers were always cold, and sakes always warm.  Sushi itself was standard quality for SF, definitely competitive with surrounding shops.  There are better options around for izakaya.  I like that this place offers everything in one stop, so there is something for everyone whether its alcohol, sushi, or hot plates.  Service was terrific, and even though it was crowded it never felt short staffed and we never felt pressured to leave.  Really enjoyed the experience here, not just the food.

PROTIP:  Try the monkfish liver.  Incredibly fresh.  Foie Gras of the ocean.
author: David C.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of this humble late night sushi spot near Union Square. I was out drinking with friends and thought of coming here and was blown away by their fish quality, presentation and overall efficiency.

The wait definitely spoke to their reputation because there was at least 20 people waiting for a table. 

I'm going to be honest and tell you I dont really remember what I ordered but even drunk I can tell you that I have a discerning and sometimes obsessive palate for sushi being the ornery annoying white person that I am .

If you're downtown and want a late night sushi fix I highly recommend Ryokos.
author: Max J.

description: Only good thing about this place was the live DJ and fast service once seated. Didn't like the food. The raw fish seemed sketchy. Won't be back.
author: Roya K.

description: Great prices but not great sushi. It shows from the lack of attention to detail. The Sushi rolls have a huge piece at the end that is twice the size of the others. The quality of the food is also so so. The prices area great. I don't think this is a bad restaurant but not a 4 star. One
author: XI X.

description: I live on the east coast but Ryokos is one stop I make every time I'm in the city. Great sushi, great atmosphere, and great service. The Volcano Roll is great and very different since it is made with peanut butter. The hot tail is another of my favorite, although I preferred when it was made with fresh jalapeño instead of spicy sauce. The pot stickers are also great. I've taken many co workers and friends here when visiting the city and no one has ever left disappointed.
author: Ben K.

description:
Probably the most lively atmosphere I've seen in a bar/restaurant. A little west of Union Square, this sushi bar is simply the best of its kind in the Bay Area. 

My group stepped down a row of stairs to be promptly greeted in Japanese by ecstatic shouts from the employees, which was downright awesome! We then sat down while our excited waiter came up to our table to bring us waters and later took orders. We got the Pokémon Roll and a few others, but the Pokémon Roll was the best. The sushi was packed with flavor and inviting us for more so we proceeded to order more rolls. The music and the attitude of the staff was especially a great way to end another night in San Francisco.

Upon leaving, I noticed that there was quite a large line waiting to be seated around 7:30 PM. Be sure to come early to avoid this, as I came around 6:15 PM!

TL;DR:

Pros:
-Unmistakingly flavorful and fresh sushi
-Highly welcoming staff
-Wide variety of alcohol and sushi rolls

Cons:
-Line after around 7

Final Verdict: 4.7 STARS (rounded to five stars)
author: Edmund Z.

description: The atmosphere is adorable and quaint, with small tables cramped up against each other. The sushi is okay, and the servers are extremely friendly. The place has declined in quality, maybe in part due to the departure of their chef who went to go open his own place in Sunset (so goes the rumor). It's still popular, and the wait can be quite long.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Came to the city for a conference and found this place on yelp.. bad mistake! After taking a long walk to get there, got seated in a private room in the back. It was fine, but we received the worst service ever! At one point, I told the waitress to leave the pitcher of water so we didn't have to hunt someone down. It also took her awhile to take our order and for our food to arrive.. The sushi was good and not terribly over priced.. but overall, would not recommend!
author: Prashil C.

description:
