So, I don't want to be that guy who complains about waiting in line for a popular restaurant because, as we all know, popular restaurants will have long lines. We should except that. 

What I didn't expect was being shoved into a hot corner of the restaurant with the only ventilation being a portable fan... the type of fan you buy at Walmart... not even a legitimate ceiling fan. Suffice to say, I was sweating profusely in no time, and the food hadn't even arrived. 

Despite the seemingly pointless wait amongst people who probably didn't know any better, the food was not altogether bad. I mean, it probably beats your average fast-food sushi joint in terms of preparation and freshness. The usual characters like Salmon and Yellowtail were reasonably fresh, but not mind-blowing. I could also sense a bit of inexperience with the flavoring of the sushi. A skilled sushi chef will preseason the sushi slightly and recommend the manner in which the sushi should be eaten. I could somewhat detect an effort to flavor the sushi.. but it wasn't significant enough to comment on.

As for everything else... well, the roll sushi were pretty generic. I mean, a lot of non-sushi eaters tend to gush about how delicious the Dragon roll was, etc etc, when the fact of the matter is that basically all Dragon rolls taste the same due to the large amount of spicy mayo that is used to essentially mask the flavor of the fish. I suppose the only way to really screw up a Dragon roll would be to actually mess up the recipe for the spicy mayo...

At the end of the day also, the price tag was a bit steep... granted, I understand that we ARE in San Francisco, and that we should expect these prices. I'm just saying, we could probably have gotten a much better product in Japan-town LA for a bit less.. and perhaps with better ventilation. 

All in all, an OK experience... though you won't find me going out of my way to come back here next time I am passing through SF.
author: David M.

description: Sushi is solid and The place def has a nice ambiance. The waiting time/line can be a bit intense. I recommend getting karaage appetizer and a few rolls.chirashi wasn't as good as I was hoping for.
author: Anant P.

description:
We came here last night and had a great time. We got 5-6 different rolls, and they were all delicious and fresh. My favorite was probably the peanut butter roll (I forget the name, but there's only one with peanut butter ;) -- soooo delicious and weird and good. BF's favorite dish was the sweet shrimp with deep fried shrimp heads. The place was PACKED, and yet somehow our waitress was very calm and sweet, and took time to explain menu items to us, and didn't rush us at all.

I'd give it 5 stars for the food and service, and 3 stars for the decor and the loooonnnggg wait (about 1 hour on a Saturday night). We will definitely be back :)
author: Sam C.

description:
Do not order any sashimi or nigiri here - rolls only

Why?

Because we ordered their salmon toro special which was 2 small seared pieces of salmon for $15. Because we ordered kanpachi and it was equally as small and $12.

Their rolls (especially the vegetarian ones) are medium sized (5-6 pieces, but not huge), but a lot of the sub-$9 rolls are really delicious and an amazing value. 

We got:
- 2 pieces salmon toro nigiri
- 2 pieces kanpachi nigiri
- salmon skin roll
- 2 orders of vegetable melody roll (it was so good we ordered it twice!)
- futomaki roll (vegetarian)
- big mama roll 
- 49ers roll
- the special appetizer which was AMAAAZING - pork belly with kimchi. Seriously so good and only $14 which was a steal compared to the fish specials
plus 2 drinks

total came out to ~$117 after tax, pre-tip. 

This place is not cheap, but the quality is great. If you're willing to drop cash, order whatever you want because it'll all be worth it. If you're trying to have a reasonably affordable sushi date, stick to the rolls.
author: Amy Y.

description: Awesome low key sushi spot in the heart of San Fransisco. Long lines at busy times. Super authentic and can't wait to go back.
author: Igor B.

description: Stumbled into this place after an event and were so pleased with what we found! Not much to look at from the street but once you go down a small stairway you are in a small basement restaurant. Even at 9:30 at night, there was a line to get seated (it moved fast) which is a sign of how good this place is! We got the nigiri dinner and sashimi dinner and the fish was so fresh and so tender! Only room for improvement is how long it took to get the bill - had to ask a few times. We will definitely be back to this little place!
author: Martha E.

description:
Plain and simple: if you have time to wait for a seat then you should wait. The food here is incredible and I believe everyone should at least try this place out once. 

There is a DJ that plays on the weekends but the music isn't overbearing. The music is actually quite nice and gives a completely different vibe from any other restaurant, it almost feels like an upscale Vegas restaurant (as far as in an audible sense).

The restaurant itself isn't fancy or big in space. It is designed to be very functional and have as many seats/tables it can possibly fit. If you don't mind a smaller space then you're all set.

The quality of the food is hard to compare to any other sushi spots. I really enjoyed their sushi and the presentation they come served with. The pricing is a bit higher but not so high that it makes you think twice about the worth.

If you are visiting San Francisco and in the Union Square area, this place should be on your list for dinner.
author: Brandon F.

description:
I love this place! Great daily specials and staffs.
So crowded and should be wait for more than 30min but great service, decent drink prices and excellent food  
I go to SF downtown nearly monthly for a business and go back to spend an evening at the place every time. 
Hidden gem, but why not this place can't be five star yet - might be long lines of people then get there early like 6:30pm.
author: Bart S.

description:
This place was awesome for a late night dinner and drink. Cool vibe with good music (DJ was awesome). 
Food was great and a really good price for sushi.
author: Adam L.

description:
What a fun spot!  Izakaya style! 

Embark down a dark stairway into a Japanese party.  EDM pulses in the background. Sushi chefs and wait staff bid you welcome as you squeeze by the tight fitting chairs, sushi bar and packed diners/drinkers. I feel transported. 

The sushi and accompanying bites of rice balls,  salads, miso soups and other izakaya fare are delicious and very fairly priced. 

My buddy and me had all of the above plus a saki and a beer for about $100. Not bad for being a stones throw from union square. 

I will return when I want to get some Japanese style izakaya in this basement party house.
author: Dusty B.

description: Fantastic place! The food is awesome, so FRESH! The service great! Can't beat the atmosphere. And the prices are unreal.  I come here as often as I get the chance when traveling to San Francisco. The only draw back is the wait. Expect at least 30mins if you arrive after 6pm. But it's worth it! Just grab a beer from the bar and chill with your new buddies on the stairs!
author: Zachary B.

description: Love this place food is always amazing no matter what you order!!!!! The atmosphere is great... and staff makes you feel welcome
author: Jennifer M.

description: Three stars for great service and good food. -2 Stars for wanting to charge my credit card a 15 dollar minimum. I only wanted a snack! I will not come back because of that.
author: Beyoung Y.

description: For some reason this place is so popular there was a line for the restaurant 10 min before opening. The sushi is pretty good and they serve a bunch of combination rolls, but it's nothing out of the ordinary.
author: Jess C.

description: Wow! This place was packed and still had great friendly service during peak hours! Ordered some sale while we waited and even requested a song from the Dj and he played it like 5 minutes after my request. The sashimi was good, one thing I didn't like was the baby squids on the plate, they didn't taste good. Everything else was sooo sweet and buttery, the fish tasted soo fresh:) glad I came here, I enjoyed every bit of service provided
author: Stephanie P.

description: Some of the best sushi in the city in a really fun environment. We had been going regularly for years. However, we've noticed that the portions have nearly halved in size, so we're paying the same for much less sushi. The wait staff also seems very new and inattentive - they've lately forgotten sushi orders we've placed, and looked at us like we were crazy when we requested Sayuri - a sake that we've been ordering here for years, at the recommendation of one of our favorite waitresses! I no longer feel like this is a worthwhile place to get a stomach-full of sushi and am going to be hitting up some of my other favorites instead.
author: M. M.

description: Restaurant is in underground and relatively big.  Crowded for weekend night. No complaints on the sushi. My special one is jumping tuna and sauce was perfect to the fried sushi. Also You can find westernized sushi with some mayo and cheesy touch to the finish. More than food, background Dj score was perfect for the late night sake dinner.
author: Karthikeyan T.

description: Came here one year ago while visiting on a work trip and I've been thinking of this place ever since! Yes, there's a wait, but it's so worth it. The sushi is so fresh, great staff, great atmosphere and good drinks! Can't go wrong with this place and I'm so excited to come back here when I'm in SF next week!!!!!
author: Brittany D.

description: Super fun place. Not every sushi place has a DJ mixing tunes which made this place unique and fun.  The guys preparing sushi yell every time someone comes or goes which I found amusing. Even without the cool atmosphere, the sushi and sushimi was great and worth going back for.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Always a bumping Japanese restaurant!  There is so much energy.  You are greeted immediately by the chefs and waitresses.  

Try to get there as soon as they open because you might need to wait for a bit depending on the night.  Just a heads up, the seating will feel a bit cozy since you are underground. 

Service was friendly and efficient.  

Rolls are tasty!  (Try the Sexy, Orange Delight, and 49ers) 
Sashimi are fresh and good slices.  
Enjoy this with some hot green matcha tea.  

Also, I have noticed that they have a good selection of whiskey.  (Hibiki 12, Macallan 12 and etc).  

Come here with a few of your friends for a wonderful and fun dinner.
author: Deborah C.

description: Great atmosphere and the vibe is very welcoming. Decent prices but the sushi just isn't great. Fish is decent. Mediocre but fun with a group, gets loud and there is always a wait. Get there right when they open!
author: Stephanie S.

description: I am a huge sushi fanatic, this place is one of the best places I have eaten at!  Visiting from Miami.  Don't let the small entrance fool you.  Hidden Gem'
author: Natasha V.

description:
This place sure is YUM! Don't come here expecting some fancy schmancy place. If you like a low key sushi place, this place is for you! Came in on a Sat night and they had a live DJ playing songs so good I couldn't help but dance in my seat waiting for my order to arrive. 
Like I said earlier, no FANCE in your Pants. This place is pretty straight up. Rolls are pretty simple but delicious & fresh! The rolls we had had 6 pieces, so to fill up, you're going to have to be spending more than a pretty penny.
To Try: The Pokemon, the sushi pieces, the Orange Delights (ask for lemon slices too!)

The service was great. Our waitress was incredibly polite and the staff could be seen joking and dancing along to the music despite the fact of having to work on a Sat night--I love that!
author: Sarah N.

description:
This place opened up right on time.

The food was subpar at best. Service was busy and rarely paid attention. But they were nice! The price is quite a bit more than what was expected, given then portion and quality. 

Have been to better ones before.
author: E.J. V.

description:
I ordered omakase, turned out to be a total of $113 + tip.
The amount would be reasonable for a good omakase, but there are a few Cardinal omakase rules that this place broke -
1. This place didn't ask me if I have any allergies
2. They gave me all of my nigiri sushi ALL AT ONCE. What's the point of sitting at the bar then?!
3. They didn't ask me how much I can eat. Another reason why omakase is delivered course by course is so the chef can interact with the guest, adjust based on the guest's feedback and appetite. So when they gave me ALL OF MY SUSHI AT ONCE, I felt extremely upset, like someone forced me to make a purchase I didn't ask for.
4. Finally, repeats. Real omakase menus should allow you to taste the highlights of a restaurant, not to stimulate your diminishing returns. Each nigiri sushi came in pairs... If I knew everything was going to be "by the menu" why did I need to "makaseru"?
5. You did what to the (hotate) scallop?! One pair of the nigiris I got had scallops on it, but it was marinated with miso..... So the scallop had a rice wine and fermented soy after taste that really killed the natural sweetness of scallops. I suspect the scallops were marinated to muffle the lack of freshness.

The only highlight was the uni, tofu, salmon roe cocktail. That's the only thing I considered omakase.
author: Melody K.

description: The worst service I have experienced in a restaurant, they brought our meal in 3 runs, each time it took them so long, the food was not good also.
author: Mina G.

description:
Don't take any of their suggestions... Seriously unless u have deep pockets and don't care .   If they don't list the prices .. Ask.. It's $$$$$$..  I do remember happening   The last two timeS I came here .. You end up with a surprising bill.  Their quality has gone down big time .  My one roll and three nigiris looked like a 1st grade cooking project .  I also want to say nigiris are literally half the size of any other place .. If You don't believe me. Read other reviews .. 

I'm glad I said no to an alternative to shiramaguro.. Which is listed at $5.. Waitress suggested the maguro.. I couple minutes later I saw the price on the board to be nearly $18...  I was looking at the menu and saw the unagi donburi was listed at nearly 30.. Really??!.  I noticed half thier nigiris are "seasonal".. Ask for the price.. It's about the same price or more than a hand crafted cocktail..  

I should of went with plan A .. 2 dollar tacos in the Mission..
author: Demanding T.

description:
Got here right when it opened and it was already half filled. By the time our food arrived there was a long line, and when we left the restaurant the wait was ~40 minutes. I came here with higher expectations, being that I saw many authentic Japanese dishes and rolls on the menu before I ordered and also because of the good yelp rating.

The chicken karaage was pretty good but it was a small serving of five pieces or so nestled next to lots of cabbage. I also enjoyed the kanpyo maki (gourd) as I can never find this in American sushi restaurants! But this too was a small portion: a thin roll with four long pieces, I don't get why they couldn't cut it like the other rolls.

I got a hamachi tori nigiri that was on the daily specials board, since I figured that would be SPECIAL...like it said. But instead it was bland/thin and the rice fell apart with one touch. It also came with SUUPER thin lemon slices on top, wtf?!?

The spicy golden gate roll (spicy salmon, shiso, cucumber & roe) wasn't rolled tightly enough so it also fell apart but it did taste good. The final roll I ordered was the Alcatraz (eel and avocado with sauce on top), pretty basic and gaijin oriented lolol. But both of these came with 4-6 pieces, if I remember correctly,

Disappointing experience, I will not be back here. Maybe if you need a really late sushi bite you should come here, hopefully you won't have to wait long...
author: Hana S.

description: Amazing sushi restaurant. It is packed and small. Expect a long wait. Try to grab a seat at the piano so u can drink and pretend your playing to the crowd. Also schmoozing with owner is a must cause she will give you some great recommendations. We tried her suggestion for saki and the chef special. All really fresh and tasty. Now I know why the wait. Also no a good place for a big group or kids.
author: Kim H.

description: Arrive early if you're not a fan of waiting! The service is quick paced without feeling rushed. And the food is amazing! The sushi is "gourmet", you will find non-traditional special rolls which many of which are downright delicious combinations! There's even a roll with peanut butter! I've tried this place on two date nights and both occasions did not disappoint!
author: Josselyn D.

description:
Stopped by to see what yelp star 4.5 in SF. I was fortunate to have sea urchin just aired in from Hokkaido and it was delicious. Raw oyster from Kyushu was OMG so fresh that I got wondered what have I been eating far away from Japan. 

Do not be intimidated by a long line if you are a group of two. It seems a table for two turn around quite quickly, as we were seated immediately but larger group was still standing when we're leaving.
author: Sa B.

description: This place has phenomenal sushi!! Music loud techno / dance but even that didn't take away from the overall experience!
author: Sunny N.

description:
We saw a show and had a late dinner here. We decided to come here because it was open late and close. 

The service was mediocre at best. The sashimi dinner is such a rip off. 14 very small pieces for $40 and it wasn't even the freshest or best. If you do decide to go here, stick to the rolls. They were decent. 

It was $100 for 2 people and felt like such a waste. 

This is a tourist trap disguised as an authentic Japanese restaurant. Save your money and go elsewhere.
author: Dflipsyde S.

description:
Went in with a large group (5 people) and were told there was a 2 hr limit on the table, which wasn't a big deal. The food was fantastic but the service was terrible. Took forever to get our checks and they refused to split our checks up separately. This WAS kind of a problem since we were all in town for a conference and needed to expense our bills. We finally had to go to the bar to tell them we needed our checks. 

In the end even though the sushi was great, it wasn't worth the hassle of dealing with the limitations when there are plenty of other places in Union Square to go for great sushi.
author: Mitch G.

description:
AHHH-MAZING!  Yum yum and oh did I mention... YUM?!  Ryoko is definitely a must go-to place if you are desiring some of the freshest fish and sea creature meat out there!  Definitely come early right when the door opens as there is always a line out the block and around the corner!  We got there 5 min before the rope drop opening on a Saturday night, and there was already a good 20 people waiting outside.  Come ready to drink, eat, and fest!

Ryoko has an ever changing selection of specials, some of which are imported all the way from Japan (supposedly)!  From uni (sea urchin) to fatty tuna toro (belly), these guys will definitely guarantee the freshness in your food!  We barely even bother looking at the menu, as we were hypnotized by such unique selection on the specials board.  We pretty much said give us two orders of everything up there!  Without a doubt, no regrets!  So fresh you can taste the ocean!  I am sure if you ordered from the menu itself as well, it would be just as good, but since we wanted to experience the full traditional Japanese shebang, we stuck with the traditional nigiri sushi and shashimi.  The rolls did look appetizing, so I will definitely have to come back and give those a shot.

Fully loaded and stocked bar have quench your adult inhibitions!  Order up some sake-bombs and let the party begin!  Place can definitely get routy and poppin toward the late night hours.  Definitely a next level sushi experience with some bumpin' music, good food, and good booze!  Its an awesome sensory overload! :D

The restaurant is quite small and quaint as it is located in a basement.  Very cozy, and not the most spacious, but definitely will suffice for a nice unique ambiance.  Careful as you keep an eye out for the store front as it is just a small door with a light on the Ryoko sign.  Very easy to miss if you are not looking for it.  Super friendly and traditional staff, making sure your beer glasses are filled and sake shots are ready to pour at hand!  I will definitely be back for more ocean creature goodness! :) NOM!
author: Peter C.

description:
First night of my one month SF trial and it seems SF might bit nyc for fresh unassuming sushi! This was a random choice while walking around that neighborhood with a friend which turned out to be pretty good! It's more 3.5 but the place is being run kinda by one hostess/waitress and is pretty busy! So the experience is kinda rushed.

But again I happily recommend this place!
author: Tina Z.

description:
I guess i set myself up for this. I had passed by this place for a couple years. I had always been against waiting in lines but i do love sushi. I waited forever then finally decided to try the place a couple months ago. I guess It just couldn't live up to the expectations. 

This place is always crowded. It opens around 6pm and stays open late. You should be able to get a seat after 10pm or before 7pm but that is about it. If you are coming with a group larger than two prepare to wait. 

You are greeted by the entire staff when you enter but after that it seems like you become just a number. This place is crowded and it is a very small basement area. You will be right next to your neighbor and intimately in their conversation. I was able to get a table without waiting in line but I can't imagine waiting over an hour to get into this place. They are so busy no one stays with you long enough to ask questions and you are rushed to get the next group of people into your seat. 

The other part is the actual sushi itself. There was nothing to write home about. i ordered several of the basic rolls and I have had better at many places in SF. I just don't understand why this one is so popular and every seems to want to go here. I would never recommend friends to go here especially if you want a lot of sushi because you will be paying an arm and a leg. 

It is a decent sushi spot but that is really all it is. I don't understand the hype but if you feel like going through the motions for decent sushi then this will be worth it. Otherwise just do a quick search of sushi in north beach and thank me later.
author: Nick R.

description: Food was really good but the atmosphere felt more like a club than a restaurant. The wait was VERY long. Prices are pretty high relative to portion sizes.
author: Jamey G.

description:
This place is just about as good as it gets. Perhaps it's not the very best sushi I've ever had (close though). However, the combination of personality, service, music and menu offerings make it a must-check-it-out venue. 

No reservations allowed and there is almost always a wait so plan accordingly. That in itself speaks volumes. 

Will return and will recommend!
author: Martin S.

description: Love this restaurant. I've been here a few times and the food is fabulous. If I just rate the food it's a definite 5 star but it's often crowded and you have to wait a good bit for a table. It's also a little loud for my taste because the people are packed in. But if you are going for the food, you will be happy.
author: Janis P.

description:
Some of the best sushi I've had in awhile. The wait can be long, and they don't take reservations, but you can always get a round of drinks while you wait. 

Try the fried cheese for an appetizer - Jack cheese wrapped in wonton and deep fried, and comes with delicious Japanese mayo sauce with a twist. It's also great to dip the sushi in!

The chicken teriyaki was great - chicken was moist and tender.

Ryoko's has really tasty, fresh nigiri. If they have it, I always get the tuna belly over rice.

For sushi, I recommend any jumping roll, and any roll that is fish over California roll (49ers, checkerboard, etc). The crab in the California roll is very creamy, and occasionally they let you substitute real crab if they have it. The sexy roll keeps me coming back!
author: Liz J.

description:
Loved the atmosphere. Chef chose what to feed me from the bar. All he made was amazing. The rolls I ordered were good but his choices were better.
I was first in line to get in. After I came in the line was out the door.
Apparently this happens all the time.
Very glad I got to experience it.
author: KrisCina J.

description: believe the hype this place is dope! everything from the food to the drinks and atmosphere really makes it a memorable experience. GET THERE BEFORE 6:15! or you will  have to wait to experience this rad place
author: Lorena H.

description: Honestly it's the best sushi place in San Fransisco! I'm from LA  so I have my usuals I go to here. But wow their fish wish amazing  pricey ish for some plates but well worth it!
author: Dillon R.

description: Amazing!!! Live music! Dj!!! In basement w/ amazing sushi!!! Def. try roll w/ peanut butter! Yum!!! &&& fireball shots! The best philadelphia roll out there!!!
author: Monica G.

description:
Ryoko's is one of my FAV spots to drink at in the city. Literally obsessed. I suggest going with a smaller group (4ish people) or a larger group (9ish for the private back room!) the space is pretty small so you'll feel slightly cramped but it's soooo fun. And what better to satisfy your drunchies with than good quality sushi?!

Sochu with calpico and sake bombs :P
author: Bianca W.

description: First and last time eating here. I came here because I wanted Sushi, was in the area, and it had a 4/5 star review on Yelp. My friend and I waited fifteen minutes to be seated. We thought, why not get a beer or sake while we wait? Turns out you cant do that! Dont think of doing it, unless you want the employees to yell at you for trying to do so! Moreover, we get seated, the waitress takes a really long time to attend to us. When picking out what I want on the menu, the waitress keeps telling me "today we only have this kind of fish; so it'll be an additional $10 on top of the menu price, is that okay?"  (She said that for 3 different rolls) That kind of annoyed me. The food was very mediocre, i've had way better sushi and sashimi and at a lower price. I pay by card, leave, then the waitress chases my friend and I outside? It was embarassing because she made it seem like we skipped out on the tab. She's telling us she cant find the merchant copy, which i clearly put in the book? She tells me she needs me to sign another receipt or go back in the restaurant and help her look for it. I give her my receipt, complete the total, give her no tip this time. She says "you forgot to include the gratuity!" i told her "you doing this just lost your tip, no gratuity, goodnight". Overall, poor service, low quality food, uncomfortable to eat at. There are a bunch of other sushi places better than this one located in SF!
author: Andre L.

description:
Another fantastic SF experience in a basement. This awesome sushi place gets packed, so we spent a good 20 minutes waiting in line on the stairs going down with several other groups. But, as is often the case, that was half the fun. The staff is great about making sure everyone waiting has a Sapporo to drink while waiting, and everyone's kidding around, so it's lots of fun.

The sushi is excellent. We had one called the Pokemon that was good, plus salmon skin and crab. They have good saki too, though you get the whole pitcher if you ask for some, so keep that in mind.

The edamame was also worthy of note, better than probably any other I've had. Then again, maybe it was the beer on the stairs that made it seem so.

It's a cool, funky atmosphere--dark, with lots of romantic nooks and crannies. Great service, too. They pack 'em in and out, but have it down to a science.
author: Greg M.

description: Came here on a Sunday night around 9:30 and the line was long. We waited about 45 minutes to get seated. It didn't take too long for the food to come out though, so that was a plus. We ordered a couple of appetizers, two rolls, and a grilled fish. Overall, dinner was fine. Nothing really stood out in a positive way. No wow factor. We stayed away from ordering raw fish due to some recent reviews of fish not being fresh. The rolls we had contained cooked fish/soft shell crab. A negative point was that the music was blaring, which just seemed kinda unnecessary. Why do I need to scream to be heard? Oh one major letdown is that they don't serve ramen or upon. I've never been to a Japanese restaurant that didn't serve at least udon. Anyway this place seems average at best, so I can only give it 3 stars.
author: SP T.

description:
On our recent trip to San Francisco, my hubby and I decided we wanted to do a Japanese dinner.  We arrived on a Saturday night around 8:30PM and there was a bit of a line. We put our names down and waited. About half an hour later we got two seats at the bar. We looked over the menu and their specials on the white board.  We wanted to order the Hamachi kama but they were sold out. A bit disappointing but we went ahead and ordered the edamame, Hamachi and salmon sashimi, saba shioyaki, Alcatraz roll and upon the waitress' suggestion, the wasabi tobiko (hubby likes tobiko). For drinks we ordered a bottle of cold sake. 
Our food didn't take long to arrive. The Hamachi sashimi was okay.  It was fresh but not as smooth of a texture as I'm used to back home. I enjoyed to saba shioyaki as it was grilled very well and seasoned nicely with salt. The wasabi tobiko didn't taste any different from regular tobiko and just cost more. We added another order of regular tobiko sushi to compare and didn't notice any difference. The roll was a bit of a miss for me.  There was sauce drenched on it and too much rice on the roll. 
The food was just okay for me and I thought the prices were a bit expensive for what it is.
author: C C.

description: Not the best Sushi place. But the place is happening with live music and great service. Usually pretty crowded and open till late. Over all good place.
author: Yuvaraj R.

description: Luckily when I got to the "hole I'm the wall" there was no wait . It was my first and last , the California roll from the second I had it in my mouth I knew I was going to be sick. Sure enough seconds after I knew I just had to get it from there . Like what do I do to get some decent sushi out here in SF . Over it
author: Max M.

description: Basement sushi joint with a lively atmosphere. Food was good but the atmosphere was too hole in the wall for a date night IMO. Lots of choices nearby so I'd skip.
author: Eric M.

description:
This was a great find. Small, little spot but the sushi and cocktails wee delicious. Started with the fried oysters - but in from NE and these weren't quite as good as in used to. However, the Alaskan A roll and the Hot Tuna were excellent. 

We were a part of 5 on a Friday night and we didn't wait very long--all in all a really good find
author: Veronica W.

description:
We ordered sashimi and sushi rolls after seeing amazing reviews on Yelp. We were sorely disappointed.

The sashimi arrived first and tasted pretty standard. The fish was fresh, but the portions were underwhelming. I would stay away from the homemade eel which tasted nothing like eel, and more like some baked flounder. 

The rolls were downright abysmal. We ordered the spicy scallop, orange roll, and the eel special roll (forgot exact names). The rolls were around $14 each which is standard for rolls, but tasted like $3 rolls at the local grocery store. One bite of the scallop roll and all you'll taste is cucumbers which feel out of place in the roll. 

All in all, this place is severely over hyped. Rolls were the worst rolls I've ever tasted. However, I have to say the ingredients were fresh. So if you're looking for some overpriced sushi and underwhelming rolls, Ryoko is the place to be!
author: James P.

description:
Great suggestion from our concierge for late night sushi. We had flown in late and were starving. I was really holding out for sushi at least once while in San Francisco and the hotel pointed us down the hill to Ryoko's. 

The entrance is a step down into a dimly lit narrow room. There is a good amount of seating at the bar on the left and then maybe 8 or so tables on the right. It felt like an izakaya, or essentially a japanese gastropub. We sidled up to the bar and got to ordering. 

We tried an assortment of sushi, rolls, and tempura dishes. Everything was very very good. We were both impressed by the freshness of the fish. Furthermore, behind the sushi bar on the wall was a white board of specials flown in same day from Japan. Sushi chefs were very interactive and friendly. They spent time showing us a few special fish and crabs they received from japan that day, including a hulking sea monster crab that I didn't recognize. 

For those reviewing this place as a "sushi restaurant" where you're expecting a certain well lit aesthetic and presentation, I think you'll be disappointed. If you want to eat somewhere that is more reminiscent to a late night drinks and eats place in Japan, you'll be right on target.
author: Drew K.

description:
Spicy beef is really good. So good I had it twice with my friend.

Sushi was great. I recommend the volcano. Hot sake was bomb as well. 5* stars.
author: Kevin T.

description:
I love sushi so I was very excited to try out Ryoko's. It was recommended to me by someone who lives in the city, touted as "the best sushi place in San Fran". I did read the reviews on Yelp so I wasn't sure how my experience would be.

The restaurant was just around the corner from my hotel which was convenient. It was approximately 7:30 pm on a Sunday evening and I had to wait for 20 minutes for a table. You walk down a set of stairs and loiter about until it's time to be seated. It's kind of chaotic and the hostess is trying to seat people and lets the name sign-up sheet float around. It looks like a basement, I mean it is a basement, but it's dark and cramped, kind of had a musty odor where I sat. They had bumping music blaring from the speakers because they apparently only have the DJ on certain nights. 

I sat for about ten minutes before anyone came over. I ordered a beer and that took another ten minutes to arrive and the server didn't even take my food order, he just flitted away. He did drop off a small bowl of cold edamame with my beer which was on the house, apparently. It was alright, nothing special. The beer was a draft, cost $4.50 which isn't unreasonable at all.

Finally, after I flagged him down another 10 minutes later, I placed my order. I decided to play it safe and order a few things to see how good it was. I had the Flying California roll, two orders of salmon sushi (4 pieces), and an order of gyoza. The Flying California Roll came out first, much to my surprise. I thought the appetizer would come out before the rolls. It was deep fried, with crab and avocado on the inside. It was okay, the tempura batter wasn't too thick but there wasn't much avocado.

After I finished that, my salmon sushi came out. They were so small, like the size a freaking carrot stick! Three pieces had no wasabi underneath but one piece had a shitload of it. I had to scrape it off because it was overflowing from underneath the fish. Then ten minutes later I get the gyoza. They were small and greasy, nothing special. 

This place was very disappointing, we have better sushi in Michigan. The service was abysmally slow, the food wasn't good, and it was way too expensive for the tiny portions they give you.
author: Megan K.

description: One of the absolute best sushi places in San Francisco! It is very pricey sushi, but truly worth the price and excellent. The fish is incredibly fresh and the nigiri has the perfect ratio of rice to fish. I was very impressed with this place and will absolutely return.
author: Roxanne A.

description:
Ryoko's is delicious. Really delicious, however it loses a lot of points based on their service and their outrageous prices.

I came one day on Saturday at 12:45 am to miss the dinner crowd. It still took 15 minutes to get seated (plenty of bar + table seats open). Then it took another 30 minutes to get my sushi when the place was pretty empty.

I also came in with a friend around 8pm once. After we got seated, it took about 35-45 minutes once we ordered to get sushi. Unfortunately we got more hungry from waiting so long, that we ordered additional sushi. That took another 35-45 minutes to get.
author: Eric H.

description: Very indifferent about this place. The sushi was good I guess. The freshness of the fish was actually great, but the presentation was terrible. I find it over priced for what you get.
author: Will C.

description: Sushi were great, the cost doesn't high on respect of quality, the advice come to the place before because waiting can take time around 15 min till 1 hour.
author: Jane C.

description: Food is ok but it's way overpriced. I tried both of the rolls on the review highlights in Yelp (Volcano and Jumping Tuna). The Jumping Tuna is pretty good tastes like your typical deep fried roll, but nothing too special. I imagine the Volcano roll would be great for spicy food lovers, but at a $13 price tag, it's not my cup of tea. Speaking of cups of tea, those will run you an extra $2.
author: Richie Z.

description:
I LOVE this place.

Came here on a Tuesday evening, and yes, it was packed.  And yes, we waited an hour to be seated for a party of 2.  But yes, it was worth it!

We put our name down around 7:30pm, and was about to head to Sanraku up the street to see which place we would have better luck at.  As we were about to get seated at Sanraku (they will give you a call when it's your turn to be seated, but Ryoko doesn't), we checked our name on the Ryoko list and saw that we were 2 tables of 2 away.  Alright, we're going to wait it out.

I ordered the sashimi combination and Oh My Goodness, the sashimi was so fresh!  For about $30 (I think?) it came with 15 pieces of sashimi, miso soup, and rice. OH man, I want to go back right now.  And you know what, I can!  Even though it's almost 11pm since they open until 2am!
author: Joyce C.

description:
This place is pretty cool.
My group and I strolled in at around 11:45p. We bumped into security before we go to the door. My first thoughts "whoa this place is serious".
As we enter through the door, some of my favorite club jams is blaring through he speaker of the live dj.
Although a restaurant its a really chill laid back atmosphere. Perfect for a date or pre-gaming wit friends.
We ordered about 7 different sushi plates and shared them all. After a certain time they stop selling entrees and just do sushi (including raw & deep fried rolls.) We had 3 bottles of sake (hot/ cold) then we did sake bombs. The waitress was so fun and the whole restaurant participated. It was overall a really fun experience.
Can't wait to go back!
author: Nicky V.

description: Prices are great food was hands down best sushi I have had in SF. My co workers and I stumbled across this this place and were so stoked. It's open late with a happy welcome and great prompt service.
author: Dana B.

description: Long waits on weekend nights. Service was decent but coming from Vancouver the sushi was mediocre and very expensive for the price. Won't be coming back.
author: Jason C.

description:
This place has a lot of charm.  

Great place to take someone on a date, the drinks are good - and the sushi tho not spectacular, is pretty tasty.

The fact that this place is open very late as well makes it a great after hours destination when out and about in SF.
author: Y B.

description: Amazing sushi! Although there is usually a wait it's definitely well worth it. We ordered the onigiri which neither of us has ever had, it is a rice ball with pickled plum inside, yum. We also loved the spicy golden gate roll, and the jumping unagi. Order anything with the BBQ eel!
author: Natalie S.

description: I should really give 3.5 and based on other reviews I'm sure it's really a 4 but I did omakase and it was not worth it. Ordering a la cart would have been better and less expensive.  Too busy for the real omakase experience. Selection of fish was decent but not the best I've had.
author: Chi Z.

description: This place has delicious sushi. All my orders were fresh and melted in my mouth.  Come early on weekends. They dont take reservations. Very small restaurant, large parties is not ideal for this place.
author: Ellen K.

description: Terrible service. Walked out after being ignored for a significant amount of time, especially after being seated next to the smelliest guy in the bar. Gross.
author: Kristin L.

description:
The concierge where I work recommended this place so I knew it would be good and I wasn't disappointed. Be prepared for a line but it wasn't a terrible wait and it's totally worth it. 
      I guess I don't have a lot to say except this was just really good sushi. I've never had better uni anywhere else. They had some good vegetarian options which was great for my date who doesn't eat meat or fish. This is definitely my go to sushi place in the area from now on.
author: Mark D.

description:
My post is going to be rather...succinct.

Best sushi ever!
The freshest seafood ever!

Only 4 stars because well, I've had to wait a ridiculous 30-45 mins to eat the best sushi ever!!!

PS: You can read through the 45743554 reviews below to figure out what to eat, because they don't lie :)
author: Ranjani S.

description: Best sushi spot in the Bay! Awesome music. Fairly priced for great quality sushi  don't be afraid of the crowds it's worth the wait.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Small entrance leading to a downstairs - how Japanesey of them! The food was good, the line was long (9pm on a Saturday), and the service was up to great. 

The only frustrating thing is since this place is so small, there's not much room to wait and everyone is cramped in. Once we got seated, a waiting gentleman's behind was in our faces for quite some time, although, him and his group did give us some sake shots :)

I'd definitely recommend this place. They even have a dancing DJ!
author: Angela L.

description:
People wait 30 minutes before this hole in the wall opens.  The fish is fresh especially those, such as hamachi toro, imported from Japan.  The menu offers a variety of appetizers, entrees, rolls and other options.  Although nothing stood out on the list of rolls, I enjoyed the evening with good food in good company with a good vibe.  

The staff is friendly, attentive and responsive.  Parking can be tough on the street.  However, it's within walking distance to public transit and nearby garages.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I am a sashimi kinda girl.  ;)  And this place had amazing sashimi!  I enjoyed their rolls and I felt the hot sake was not bad and not expensive at all (10$ for the xtra large pot).

I also like the fact that they were open so late so that makes it a great option for an after party meal (if you don't party too hard, of course!)

However, it was rater small and that made it pretty difficult to dine comfortable.  Service was not great, but it was not bad either.

Would definitively go there to take my guests when they come visit SF.  :)
author: Lucia M.

description: Sushi was great! Atmosphere was very relaxed, with EDM music playing often. We went at 9pm on a Sunday and it was packed with a line, but we didn't wait long. They were also very accommodating when another friend joined us and we had to move tables. Staff are very friendly! Very fast service. Will go here again, no question.
author: Ryan S.

description:
This place gets super packed right when it opens. We got there 5 minutes after it opened and by 15 minutes the stairs started to fill up with people waiting to be seated. Once you're in though it's rad. They yell something out loud when a customer comes in, I had no idea what though. The yelling brings the place together and I was a big fan of the server too. She made me laugh multiple times.

So when I first got in I was pretty high and I knew right off the bat I liked the music that was playing. The nigori sake was chill. The sushi was on point though. The plating was great I thought. Most sushi spots I've been to don't add the mint leaves to the ends of their roles. I really liked their BBQ mackerel more than other places. I don't want to give the impression that the rolls aren't great, but I think overall what really separates this place is the atmosphere. I can imagine it being a loud fun place to stop by late night...if you can somehow get a table!
author: Jim B.

description: This place is one of the places to go to if you're craving sushi at night because it opens really late. The line gets pretty packed too so I recommend to go early if you decide to eat at this place. This place isn't the place for you if you're looking for sushi like lion king roll or any specialty , only for the nigiri or the raw fishes! The fish is fresh and doesn't have that ocean taste but the this place is a bit pricey. Must try out.
author: Johnny L.

description: Am a big fan of this cozy place that has an awesome atmosphere and amazing Sushi to enjoy every bite. Thank you so much guys !
author: Di H.

description:
I don't know how this place has 4 stars.  3 star is generous enough!

The sushi is fresh, but it's hard to enjoy when you have UNTZ UNTZ UNTZ music blaring. Don't even think about having a conversation with your friends, it's not going to happen.

That aside, the food is great.
author: Angelica C.

description:
I was in town for work, and did a little yelp research before going to find a good sushi place, because lets face it we've all heard that the best sushi can be found on the coasts, right?

I found this little place with raving reviews, within a couple blocks of my hotel and decided if I got the chance I was going to have me some amazing west coast, San Francisco sushi! Well the opportunity arose, and myself along with a coworker and a couple guys from our conference ventured on over for a little late night snack somewhere between 10 & 11pm ISH.

The place was packed, with a short wait.  GOOD SIGN?  I thought so... 

First Impression: small, divey, dark, not dirty - but dingy? (if that makes sense), could use some TLC

Now, let me start by saying. It was all good sushi - I just wasn't blown away or amazed by anything we had.  To be honest, I felt like it was similar to what I can get back home in the Midwest, which left me a little disappointed.. 

We ordered a couple rolls, some sashimi, and of course a couple bottles of Saki.  The staff was very patient with us, as we seemed to be chatting more than deciding on what to eat.  The food came out in a weird order - we ordered the saki and a roll right away while we perused the menu a bit more, the Saki came right away, but that original roll came last out of everything we ordered... which was odd seeing we ordered it probably a good 15 minutes prior to ordering any other food.

Now the burning question... Would I go back?

Sadly... probably not.  If i lived in the area I might, but seeing as I don't make it to the SF area often, I will probably look elsewhere next time I'm in town.
author: Andi P.

description: Seriously best sushi bar !!! Music is so fun screw the conservative sushi bars this one is energetic with and passionate customer service I tipped my set $80 for the fast efficient service and friendliness !!! Ling was my server!!! Fun music, GREAT FOOD, GREAT PRICES!!! Ugh the best I swear Try it !!!
author: Keanu V.

description: It's was worth over an hour wait. The sushi was great and great music. The environment is chill with a good mix music  I will make a point to return on my next S.F visit.
author: Simon Q.

description: Not as good as I remembered. Loud and the sushi chefs are not really friendly or fun. Fish was warm too. Sashimi dinner was not super fresh and pieces just didn't taste good. Dragon roll very small. Average at best so keep looking for the perfect sushi in SF
author: Brad M.

description: I used to love this place. The owner/owner's daughter is sweet, rolls and sushi are good & they are open late. However, the last two times I've tried to come here 30 minutes prior to closing the bouncer has turned us away because they are 'almost closed'. It's really a shame. I make a point to not come right at closing but 30 minutes prior and turned away both times. Poor service. Don't give them your money.
author: Angie D.

description: This place is just ok. The ambience is fun and a big place with a dj. Clubby sushi time. The rolls are decent but the sashimi and nigiri wasn't great. The ankimo was not the best as well. Usually signs that its not the freshest seafood around. Fun to go with a group but this place is always packed. Expect to wait up to an hour for a table if you come after 6. Would recommend only if you're downtown and want a fun place to eat.
author: Daniel P.

description: Super noisy....Like seriously I wouldn't come back here again,poor service,sat right in the corner,ended up the bill was like 130,the most fuxked up part is....My Sapporo is hot!!!!
author: Glenmorangie S.

description:
LONG WAIT FOR AWFUL SUSHI THAT IS OVERPRICED

Ordered two salmon rolls and to my horror, it was not sushi grade salmon, but smoked salmon that I would find on a bagel. I have never tasted that kind of salmon in a roll, and it was foul. Some of the rolls specified that they had smoked salmon in them, but I deliberately chose other salmon rolls. However seems like cutting corners is a thing at this restaurant. I wouldn't be so upset if they were priced for what they were, fake sushi rolls. But this place is pricey. 

Waited around 45 minutes for a table, but service seemed to move at a good place once we got seated.
author: Kendall F.

description: Great service- super fresh fish. Salmon and Hamachi- rolls not overly creative with superior flavoring. Sat at the bar and had a blast. Only pitfall was the oysters were tasteless. Even in its natural state. They responded by taking them off the bill. No reservations and it's not a corporate card type place. It's cool and edgy. Perfect place around Union Square
author: David S.

description: Ryoko is a cool sushi joint that I love! It's underground so it's pretty dark inside, but it all just adds to the vibe. I guess they start playing music at some point but this review is for the sushi only (it was still pretty tame when I went, I guess haha). I've tried a couple of their rolls and they've all been tasty and fresh... the dragon roll and 49ers roll are good! Sadly I tried going back here a couple weeks later and there was a looong wait. They don't take reservations so come early!
author: Connie Q.

description:
Very solid rolls, especially the tempura "jumping" rolls. The raw rolls are good too, we had salmon skin, tekka, and tahoe. All were excellent. A bit of a wait but it was bearable. 

This would be an easy 4 stars if the entire interior of the restaurant did not smell like a urine-soaked Honey Bucket. And no, the strategically-placed fans did not alleviate that. At least my nose acclimatized to it before our food arrived.
author: Dylan L.

description: Since we're on vacation for the next 8 days, I'll refrain from writing long reviews for the time being.  Ryoko's seems to be quite a popular sushi joint here in SF.  They opened their doors at 6pm, but by 6:30pm, all but one small table were taken up.  Only the sushi bar seats were available.  Lucky for us, they sat the 4 of us on the small table, but then moved us to a bigger table once it was available.  The food here is excellent......not the best I've had, but nonetheless still very good.  All the fish was of high quality and was very fresh.  The sushi was very well made.  Good presentation and perfect fish to rice ratio!  Prices were slightly on the expensive side, but was well worth it due to the quality of both the food and the attentive service.
author: Steven L.

description: My stomach doesn't like imitation crab.  I know it says it clearly on the menu but, given the price points, I would think Ryoko would use actual snow crab in their rolls.  The spicy tuna roll was good but smallish portion.  Big city eating I suppose.
author: Push U.

description:
Sushi tastes good, but is small for the price, dimly lit place with tables close together

I came here with my boo, this place has great sushi rolls, but is not a good place to get full, it's more of a snack. We ended up going here because some other place that we wanted to go to were full or had a long line/wait. the food we had tasted great: fresh, and tasty. We had the Volcano 5 piece spicy crunchy roll which was great and the 49er roll was good.

There is not much room in this place to walk around the tables are placed closer together than they should be. When I got up to go to the bathroom I realised how dimly lit it really was. It was hard to see. The bathroom is located upstairs and there was only one for the women's bathroom. 

This place was pretty full on a Saturday night. There was mostly people aged 25-35 here. Some people there for birthdays, catching up with buddies, and dates. Because the tables are so close together it's hard to not hear peoples conversations, the table near us the guys were talking about things guys would usually not talk about around girls. I certainly didn't want to hear that, but there is not much choice when the tables are so close together. A dimly lit place could offer an intimate setting for a couple to have dinner but romance is lost when the tables are so close together, and everyone can hear each others conversations. Personally I think it's more comfortable to be able to eat with my boyfriend and feel comfortable to have an open conversation. I notice that we both talk less in places where people can hear everyone's conversations, but maybe that is just me.
author: Tiffany Michelle L.

description: They overcharged my credit card. Look through other reviews-- not the only instance of this happening. Sushi is OK. Definitely only get the rolls.
author: Fernando G.

description:
Chef Atsushi is a sushi artist! The sushi is so fresh, flavorful and presented so nicely when served. I don't think I ever ordered anything I didn't like. You have to keep an open mind when you come here and don't order the usual defaults of spicy tuna or salmon.

The line and wait can be quite long so you should come early and/ or have everyone in your party there so you don't miss your turn. The service is good considering they do get busy.
author: Dana L.

description: Dance music and sushi.  Love it.  If there's a long wait - go to Owl Tree around the corner to grab a drink.
author: richard d.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi places in the city. If you're looking for a more upbeat cluby feel this is your go-to. There is a DJ plying music around 8pm or so, and it's not too loud that you can't hear the people with you. There normally is a bit of a wait, but the line moves fast and you'll be seated in no time! My favorite rolls are the Volcano and the Sexy, so good!!
author: Katelynn F.

description: I chose this place because they have more than 1000 reviews on Yelp when the other sushi restaurants have only around few hundreds. And this place is really awesome , 5 stars for service and so delicious sushi for good price ! It was coasted around 100$ to make super full and supper happy me and 3 my friends
author: Vladislav S.

description:
Just like other reviews stated, the place is overpriced and the food is so so. I ordered a first course with beef ($14-15) and it was alright. And then 9 pieces sushi + California rolls ($40): the salmon was not that great and the rest of other fish types were just average. 
If you want a fun place to hang out this might be for you but I would not suggest it in term of food quality.
author: Lilly J.

description:
Great hole in the wall for Sushi. My female friend said that alot of restaurant workers visit this place after work since they stay open late.  We made it to the line a couple minutes after 6pm and the line started to extend out the door.

For appetizers we ordered the edamame, the chicken yakitori and the grilled shitake mushroom. All very flavorful.

Ordered the Blue fin sushi, hamachi sushi, oshinko rolls and the smoked eel.
The blue fin cost a $2.00 more but it was truly worth it. All of the fish was very fresh and flavorful. The pieces were large too!

Acourse had to have the Nigori sake..milky not like the clear sake. 
I had read some bad comments about the service but I thought the service was very good.I wondered what this place is like at 8pm. Definitely returning to this little Japanese sushi restaurant in the Tenderloin.
author: Jim D.

description: Food really good. Service fine. Crowded, noisy -- but lively and fun atmosphere -- longish wait for a table (no one waits that long for bad or mediocre food). Interesting, maki you don't see elsewhere. We'd come back next time we're in that area.
author: Leyla H.

description:
Ryoko's is one of the best places for sushi I've been to in the city thus far. 

Upon entry we were greeted by the chefs, as is tradition with most good sushi joints.

The wait was long, but I relate wait time to customer satisfaction. I can assure you, it was worth it. 

We showed up with a large group of people, waited roughly an hour to be seated, but were served beer and offered appetizers while we waited (stood towards the front of the business). When it was our time to be seated we were given a back room with lots of privacy, which we had not requested, but I think was the best seat in the house. 

Round after round of sake bombs, with great sushi, and good atmosphere made the evening a very enjoyable experience. 

I would recommend Ryoko's to any sushi fanatic that hasn't been here yet. 

Pricing is what you would typically expect for an upscale and popular joint of this type. 

Will be returning
author: Brian A.

description: We went here at 11pm on a Monday, was still packed. Ordered the beef tataki which was fantastic, the other dishes including the sushi were so-so. Felt the service was quite poor, especially at the end when I asked for a receipt, the waitress said we don't give receipts to customers, I then asked but I would like one, she replied you can take a picture of it if you want, I told her no I would like a receipt, she walked away with a disgusted look on her face. Later I received the bill from what I assumed was the manager with guestcheck stamped on it which is what I assume they provide guests. This encouter really put a bad experience for me at this place so I will not be going there again.
author: David W.

description:
I tend to rate a place based on how I felt while there; and this place gets my five stars. 

Great tasting food, the basement setting sets it apart from the other restaurants, price is relatively cheap (by SF standards), gentry comprises of young professionals kicking back with their friends over some fresh sushi and drinks. Service is great. 

I'd go again in a heartbeat.
author: Shobhit G.

description:
Ryoko's was supposed to be the reward for a day filled with dry-heaving walking uphill and hysterical crying on downhills in San Francisco.  Given the grunge, basement vibe, I thought this was going to be a hit.  Everything about it looked promising because the place was nearly full when we arrived shortly after they opened.  Nevertheless, we both had the come hell or high water mentality of eating our weights' worth in sushi when we sat down, certainly so after having our tits handed to us on on the trek there.  

Unfortunately, the best roll I had was the Fried Chicken Roll, which is very much the scumbag poser of any food that is wrapped inside rice.  Everything else ranged from average to tasteless, even more so than any stale wafer made for teething infants or pigeons.  The Scallop Roll had so little meat content and flavor that even a die-hard vegan would eat it.  

The seaweed salad appetizer that we ordered was one of the most depressing things I have experienced this year.  It didn't hold that much flavor and they put cherry tomatoes piled on top of wilting seaweed.  What a dick move.  Putting cherry tomatoes on a seaweed salad is kind of like rubbing alcohol into a laceration that is on my ass.  

The second runner-up to the Fried Chicken Roll, and I am honest to god cringing at that sentence, was perhaps the sashimi platter that we ordered.  None of the fish were spectacular but they weren't spoiled, sandy, or poorly butchered.  You know, not a girl, not yet a woman.  Mediocre at its best.  

Perhaps the cherry on top of it all is that our server moved us to another table because we were in the way of them making more money.  That's all good except then I was in plain view to watch and listen to a scrawny, tattooed crapper--whose ego is insurmountable and know-it-all expertise is as sought after as a venereal disease--blabber on and on about his pathetic life.  Yeah, I'm judgmental.  

This place has a little something for everyone and for that I can appreciate.  However, the menu is exceedingly lengthy and confusion arose out of trying to differentiate one platter from the other and one roll from the other.  It made me momentarily feel like a dumbass and this is why I will likely never visit again.  I also never pass up a chance to showcase my undesirable traits like my misplaced righteous indignation.  

For how hungry we felt, this place did not hit any of the right spots.  I'd also rather eat at a conveyer belt sushi place than to pay $13+ for unimaginative, uninspired rolls.  Each roll had about 6 small pieces, regardless of the price.  Total dicks.
author: Whitney B.

description: So I read all the reviews and this place sounded great so while I was in the city I made sure to go. It was a Friday night we put our name on the clipboard at the bottom of the stairs- make sure you do this- and waited. The hostess will ask if you want a drink while you wait randomly throughout the evening but you're going to be waiting for a bit. We waited an hour to be seated another 15 to get water and then about 25 minutes after ordering to get our food. Yes the fish was fresh and yes the sushi rolls I ordered were good but nothing that blew my socks off. The sashami was excellent but more costly than I have paid at most places and the rolls were cheap- about 5 or 6 pieces each but was it worth the wait- hell no. Not sure what the fascination with this place is- maybe everything else in the area sucks when it comes to sushi but I wouldn't bother.
author: Debbie P.

description: Outstanding sushi, very fresh and prepared to the highest quality. I thought I was back in Japan. Takoyaki was very good as was the tempura. Had a great time sitting at the sushi bar and visiting with the chef / owner.
author: Art P.

description: I work in the service industry so I'm extremely lenient when it comes to service, but I have to say this place had the worse service of any restaurant I have ever been to. Sushi was good, but the rudeness from the serving staff does not make up for it.
author: Joseph N.

description: Ryoko's, you're a late night institution...  How I adore you.  Fast, friendly service and some of the tastiest damn fish ever - props for the super epic fatty tuna (and fatty other fish when you run out of toro).  In a basement.  With a live DJ.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Absolutely delicious! One of my favorite places in SF! Jumping tuna was my favorite! Not a lot of appetizers/starters. Lots of rolls and sushis!

There is always a line to be seated. Obviously weekdays are not as crowded as the weekends.
author: Asena U.

description:
Ambiance is excellent here and if that matters more to you than quality this become your fav spot!   

I was not overly impressed with the freshness of the uni nor the way that sashimi was served.   If you are looking for high quality sashimi try elsewhere, I sampled almost everything on their list as sashimi and it seems this is not what they do best.  

My friend ordered rolls and those looked to be very creative and flavorful.  The atmosphere inside is great, and just for rolls and beers I am sure this place rocks, just not the place for sashimi.
author: Kristine K.

description: Love this place.  Probably the best sushi in the Bay Area.  Everything I had was super fresh and I understand some of the items served are imported from Japan!  Top notch restaurant, amazing service, and reasonably priced.  I ordered some unique sake this last visit and was impressed.  I rate them A++
author: Martin C.

description: Came here a few nights ago around 10 pm. Place was hopping. A bit of a wait. Ordered several rolls and all were good. Not spectacular. Server was very attentive. Thought about coming back again, but decided to try different restaurants while we were in town.
author: Al C.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday on Fri 3/28/14 - party of 10. Got seated in the back room. Extremely stuffy, with no ventilation whatsoever. Eh, whatever right? We ended up finding a fan in the room, so that solved that problem.

Food was decent...but nothing special. We ordered a bunch of stuff. I shared the Nigiri Dinner, Jumping Tuna Roll, Spicy Tuna Roll, and Alcatraz Roll. 

Our server...well, she was horrible, actually very disgruntled. Not sure what her problem was, but she obviously didn't care because why? Gratuity automatically included since we were a table of 10. Might as well recommend one of the most expensive sakes on the menu right? Well that's exactly what she did. Thai lady, hair was tied in a bun, you know, the one who didn't smile even once.

Anyways, not worth the drive across the city considering the ok food, crappy service, and no where to park. 

Will I be back? Probably not. First and only experience here. Can you say, tourist trap?
author: Erica L.

description:
This is my favorite place for sushi in the City. Excellent sushi with some creative twists to play with your palette and make you smile. Set in an underground lair with chill out tunes from the DJ - it's the kind of sushi bar you could see yourself at after a fun night of dancing. Underground Kyoto sushi bar with a taste of the Ibiza vibe, but without the sand and sunsets.
The chefs and staff are all Japanese, which lends extra credibility to the authenticity of that third round of sushi you already ordered because your mouth was demanding more. おいしい！^_^
author: Tricia B.

description: They were able to seat our group of 8 in a small room with a 2-hour max occupancy time limit. Service was OK, food was good. Definitely nowhere near the best sushi, but if you're in the neighborhood, could be worth checking out.
author: Judy C.

description:
In the past years, nothing has drawn me to the Tenderloin past sundown. Despite it's appetizing name, the sheltered little Asian girl inside of me has prevented me from venturing it's seedy streets once the stars are out. But tonight, that all changed thanks to Ryoko. Because of Ryoko, I might even consider moving to the Tenderloin. 

I don't know their reservation policy, all I know is is that they told my boyfriend they don't do them (despite what Yelp says). They open at 6. We got there at 6:25 and it was already at 90% capacity. It's set up in an old house, so quarters are tight, ceilings are low and the music is loud. 

Luckily we were just a party of 2 and got to sit at the bar. The beginning of our meal here started off HORRIBLY. We sat there for 20 minutes, completely unacknowledged. The sushi chefs gave us the customary nod upon sitting down, but they were so swamped that they just kept their heads down and hands going. Since we sat there unacknowledged for so long, I noticed my napkin was already used. Gross. Finally a lady instructed our waiter to actually pay attention to us, and while we were ordering we were interrupted THREE TIMES but other servers. The intrusive servers didn't even apologize for being so rude-- they literally stepped in between us and our waiter and started talking to him. I really couldn't believe it. I decided right then and there that service there sucks. They are nice people but incredibly oblivious, like many of my Asian peeps, when it comes to customs regarding interrupting conversations.

The saving grace of Ryoko is the food. OH. MY. GOD. The fish is stupid fresh. It's like the sushi chefs (who are actually very nice and social when the incoming tickets start slowing down) went out into the marina and sang the fish to sleep only to slaughter them later for my culinary pleasure. They have a menu, but they also have a white board informing you what fish they have fresh from Japan. Unfortunately, the 'good things come to those who wait' bullshit holds true here, because we waited a solid 30 minutes for our food. Prepare to wait longer if you get anything baked or fried, as there are only 3 sushi chefs who do all of the prep and work involved in the sushi.

We decided on the sashimi dinner ($30.25), chu toro/fatty tuna (2 ps/$13), white tuna toro (2pc/$6.95). Both the nigiri MELT IN YOUR MOUTH. I couldn't even handle it. I nearly fainted. It was THAT good. The fat content would make even Paula Deen swear. The sashimi dinner was INCREDIBLY fresh, I was even stoked about the tuna, which normally doesn't tickle my pickle all that much. We were also drunk by this time thanks to the large Sapporo ($6) and large hot sake ($7) so I was on cloud freaking nine. We ordered an additional dinner of another large Sapporo and sake, Ryoko's Roll ($15--special roll), shima aji (2 pc/$9.30) and hamachi toro (2 pc/$9). I didn't know you could go beyond heaven but apparently ou can. The shima was firm and reminded me of hamachi, and the hamachi toro was nothing short of orgasmic. The Ryoko's roll had cucumber and pickled daikon on the inside, fatty tuna and red onions on the outside. SHUT. UP. YES.

I think I've found my new favorite sushi spot in The Bay. Next time I will be lining up at 5:30 to secure my spot in this hidden gem. Oh and they're open until 2 AM so you know where you can find me until then.
author: Christina D.

description: Loved it! Sushi is fresh. The place is kind of loud, but we did not mind. Service was great. Will come back!
author: Marion B.

description:
Great sushi. Kind of chaotic and very bar-like, but is expected for a late night eatery. Good place to eat if you don't mind the smell of booze and hot musky atmosphere. 

P.S. The soy sauce is really salty!
author: Nik N.

description:
This is not your traditional, top of the line sushi joint, so go ahead and get that out of your mind.

It's pretty straightforward. The price is right when you're looking for that quick sushi fix. I come here for the rolls - I'm not going to come here expecting a delicious cut of sashimi. na' mean?

But, its super fun, open late, and yummy oh so yummy. 

A-OK!
author: Mayra M.

description: Came here for a beer and ended up staying for the food! Average sushi, great beer and even better live DJ! Tables are a bit too close to close to each other
author: Anna C.

description: The sushi was great! The jumping role was insanely delicious!
author: Hannah F.

description: Great vibe and great music.  Tons of energy and fun to go around.  Solid vegetarian options for the non sushi crowd as well.  Nice hangout for small groups of friends.
author: Draft M.

description:
Came to this place with a friend because we saw how highly reviewed it was. However, neither of us were honestly that satisfied. The plus side is that we didn't wait too long since we got there right at 6pm when the restaurant opened. 

The other plus side is that the sushi was pretty good and very different from your traditional rolls. The down side? We both thought it was a bit pricey for how much we got. The even more down side was the attitude of the waitress. She basically gave us the eye-roll a few times when we asked for things and wasn't too attentive. 

All in all, good place to try creative rolls but I don't think I'd recommend this place.
author: Jessica X.

description:
An excellent underground spot that resembles a Japanese jazz bar slightly hidden off Post and Taylor. Fun vibe and great music that adds a lot of noise but good energy to the dining experience. Excellent, fresh sashimi, especially the sake which is prepared slightly seared on top. The whole grilled squid is a personal favorite at Japanese restaurants that serve it back in NY. 

A fun, upbeat spot that is open late and not overpriced is definitely an attractive option for the younger crowds.
author: Nelson W.

description: Service was really good. The place was so busy! And I went on a Wednesday night right when it opened and the line was already out the door! The sushi was nothing special, nothing made it stand out from other sushi places. But it was good and that's why I gave it 3 stars. I really enjoyed the spicy golden gate roll over the deep fried one I got. The spicy golden gate tasted fresher and had interesting elements like lemon in it.
author: Brianna F.

description:
Pros: 
-Cool hip spot
-fun ambience 
-good service 

Cons:
-tiny portions 
-over priced 
-no salmon 
-no albacore 
-unauthentic 


Never again
author: Nayef A.

description: Fun environment with very fresh sushi. Service is horrible though. But I'm glad this place stays late because I came here with friends who were out of town and they were starving at midnight. The music is on point and the place itself is fairly clean. Ordered the chirashi bowl and it came in a small box and it was decorated so beautifully. Fresh slices of fish were melt in your mouth.
author: Anne M.

description: Good sushi, better than a lot of the other sushi places. Reasonable prices, got myself a lot rolls for a low price considering other places that have it 1.5 times expensive
author: Charlie G.

description: Really great food, nice atmosphere. Only downside it's extremely busy, but I guess good food comes with that territory
author: Saada N.

description:
Where does one even begin?
For the most part, skip those traditional rolls and order the white board. The freshness of the fish will bring you back here again and again. Feel free to experiment with unfamiliar fish here. The hostesses know what's up so go with them !
Grilled mackerel was superb!
author: Kunal K.

description:
Very clean, fresh fish executed wonderfully. They are a little takai (expensive) but this is one of the best places I've had sashimi/sushi ever. Their menu has unique offerings that a typical sushi restaurant lacks. The dishes are simple and to the point. If you're a fan of sushi, and willing to wait a bit for it, this is the place.

For those not looking for loud music, this is not the place for you.
author: Derek I.

description:
I took one star off because the music was too loud. Some people like it that way but I am not one of them. I prefer being able to have an audible conversation while dining. Hard to enjoy my food when straining to hear what my dining partner is saying. 

Food was five stars. Ordered salmon, yellowtail, and salmon roe sushi, and the Alcatraz (eel & avocado) roll. All delicious. One complaint is that my roll came out long before my sushi did so I basically had to eat them consecutively vs if they were served at the same time. No biggie, just my preference to have them all served at the same time. 

Got there 20 minutes before opening and there was a very long line by the time they opened. I don't like to wait in line which is why I got there early. Suggest you do the same unless you don't mind the wait. 

Good, attentive service.
author: D L.

description:
So i found the roll that actually delicious!!( I only order rolls to fill my hungry stomach so the bill won't go crazy with nigiri bill. Lol) 
Order "sexy" !! With melting cheese on top, it tasted sooooo goood!!
author: Mii L.

description: My boyfriend and I decided on Ryoko for dinner after reading so many good reviews. The restaurant had a good vibe and a live dj. Our waiter approached our table and asked my boyfriend what he wanted to drink and immediately leaves without asking me. I gave her the benefit of the doubt thinking maybe she's busy and forgetful. Well she came back with his drink and asked him if he was ready to order. Of course, she skip me again.. And I'm really confused at this point. My boyfriend had to ask her to bring me a water. The rest of the dinner, I was ignored like I don't exist. She didn't say a single thing to me the whole time and only placed the food on my boyfriend's side. The food was okay but wasn't memorable. All I can remember is that the miso soup had this burnt taste like it was left in the pot too long. Overall, dinner was a huge disappointment and probably one of the worst dining experience of my life.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
sf people seem to really love this place.  huge line and wait.
the sushi was ok.  nothing spectacular, though.  overpriced as well.
liked the chicken karage.  waitress was nice and fast.
author: Brian K.

description:
I want to give this place a 3.5, but I don't have that option. First of all the customer service there was not that great. I did not feel greeted at all and on top of that, the host didn't even bother to give me the sign in board to write down my name. If you're going their for dinner, know that you'll be waiting for 45 mins on the stairs. 

This place is overhyped. My friends and I ordered the VOLCANO ROLL, SALMON AND EEL SUSHIMI, TOFU SALAD, and SPICY TUNA ROLL. There was nothing special about this place. Yes the food was good and fresh but it was pretty average to me.
author: Kathy N.

description: Not impressed at all with this place. The sushi was actually the worst I've ever tried.
author: Ely B.

description:
I was in need of a little food and drink splurge after a long week at work and came across this little sushi spot. A girlfriend and I stopped here for dinner on a Thursday night and it was the perfect pick-me-up!

My favorite dishes:
+ TAKOYAKI: one of my favorite dishes of the night. It was basically eight large takoyaki balls and they did not skimp on the octopus. The overflowing pile of bonito flakes on top made this a very aesthetically pleasing dish too.
+ ANKIMO (monkfish liver): mmmm...this is a truly decadent Japanese dish that is different from your typical sashimi, rolls, udon, etc. The scallions and ponzu sauce paired well together with the richness of this dish. My second favorite of the night!

Honestly I would come back again just for the two dishes above. We also tried a few rolls and the toro (fatty tuna), but they were a bit more on the lackluster side. I would recommend coming here for either the chirashi bowls (if you feel like really splurging) or for a quick bite of the takoyaki and ankimo. 

Things to note:
- Come here early!! This place definitely already had a line at 6pm when we first arrived. However, you will be seated earlier if you choose to sit at a bar instead of a table.
