author: Bonnie Z.

description:
The only reason my gf and I went here was because it was one of the few sushi places open this late on a Tuesday. There was a nice vibe when you walk in, very friendly staff. there was about a 20 min wait ( for 11pm Tuesday) , so I'm thinking, " dam must be popping and lockin in here then". And then....

No.

disappointment was had. Okay, to be as unbiased as possible, there was 3 sushi chefs working and 4-5 servers waiting on roughly 30 people. We had to wait 40 minutes until we finally got our first plate - two piece sake sashimi.... lolwut?

It did look like there were a few regulars there who may have gotten preferred treatment, but I duno. All of the problems with wait times, i can understand if the place is busy. that can't be helped. But what also was misleading was the actual prices of the sushi. most of the signature rolls were 7-15 dollars, which I thought was pretty standard. but snap, the portions were tinnnyyyy (5 regular size pieces). 

This place was def not going up on a Tuesday.

If you place more value into a trendy dinner atmosphere and nice vibe, check this place out.

If you are looking for more bang for your buck, I recommend somewhere else.


Food Presentation: 2/5
Taste: 3/5
Price: 2/5
Atmosphere: 4/5
author: Steve D.

description:
This is my favorite goto place for Gyoza and Sushi at 1am in the morning.

For late night munchies with a good atmosphere this is hard to beat.
author: David T.

description: Honestly, I didn't think the food is too memorable but the vibe here is great! Located underground..watch your step down the flight of stairs. Great place to go to since it opens until late at night but expect long wait times. Often times at night they'll have a live dj here too which is a plus!
author: Sheila B.

description:
Got the Omakase since it looked so AMAZING from pics....it was the most disappointing Omakase ever. Nothing special about it and my Amebi was not fresh. The Uni was not the best. Maybe I came on the wrong night but that was the worse Omakase and I've had and I've had a lot in my life. 

$135 and my friend only had 2 small roll. One is just a cucumber roll too.

Staff was not that friendly. My next table complained about their food and got free stuff but I didn't bother.

Never coming back
author: Amy L.

description:
Great food, excellent vibe.  Come early so the specials will still be available.

Everything was nicely prepared, and with some interesting pairings for apps and rolls.  Sushi/Sashimi super fresh.  While I like any types of Uni, I am particular about Santa Barbra Uni, so was initially disappointed that they didn't carry it.  But after trying the Japanese Uni they did carry I am not disappointed at all.  

We came here a few times now, and never a disappointment despite them always running out at least a couple of things like Mirugai and such that are my staples.  There are plenty of other interesting choices on the menu to keep any meal interesting.

Been to wide range of Sushi places across the US from standard fair to ultra high end, and frankly this is the only place that I actually liked the way the monkfish liver is prepped.

And can't beat that somewhat dive bar ambiance.
author: Yi S.

description:
Great sushi.  Great staff.  All other reviews about wait time are right. We got there at 5:50 pm so only had to wait 10 minutes to get in and get a seat.  By 6:20 pm it was easily a 45 minute wait.  
Fresh. Tasty.  Reasonably priced.  And also loud music.  Loved it.
author: Four P.

description:
Spent some time in San Fran and managed to drop by this pleasant surprise.  It was recommended by a friend, and we decided to try it out.  Located right on Taylor St. you walk down a steep flight of stairs to get to the hostess stand (it wasn't that bad, it was actually a nice unique touch to the ambiance)---just watch your step.  As soon as you enter, the entire staff shouts...I'm assuming welcome or hello in Japanese (I'm assuming).  The tables were all taken, so we decided to take two seats at the bar.  We chose a perfect time to arrive before the dinner rush, because once 7pm hit, the place was packed and people were actually sitting on the stairs.

Now to the food.....the sushi was up to par, and very fresh.  We ordered an array of...tuna, eel, salmon roe, and more tuna---all delicious.  I pretty much judge a sushi restaurant on their soup and tuna.  You'd be surprised how many restaurants ruin simple miso soup.  I digress....the tuna was good.  So enjoy, watch for the stairs, and order some sake with your meal.
author: Luarnie B.

description:
Mediocre 

The pictures on yelp and long line outside made us think that this place was going to be really good! The food was not bad but really mediocre. I was debating whether I should order the sashimi platter or nigiri sushi platter for $40 but my bf stopped me. I am so glad for that because someone at the table next to us had the nigiri sushi platter after and it looked so disappointing-really poor presentation and selection. 

We ended up ordering several (grilled & deep fried) appetizers, rolls and a la carte nigiri.  Of course, it was obvious that this is not a real traditional Japanese sushi place seeing all those "special" rolls on the menu. Still I had hoped the food would be really good even if catered to Americans. Nothing was really great or memorable. For the nigiri, I ordered the fish from on the black board (specials from Japan) which costs more than the fish choices on the menu and it was not great. My bf said he could not taste the fish and asked me if I thought maybe the fish was frozen? I really do not know and will never crave anything that I ate at Ryoko's. 

Maybe it is just us? - I am really picky and we've both had a lot of great Japanese food before.
author: Vicious G.

description:
A little over priced for such small rolls. 
Grilled squid was delicious. 
The volcano roll was unique ... Shrimp tempura, jalopeno, and peanut butter. A must try!!!!
author: Ashley M.

description:
Uh, this was horrible. The sushi was small and sour; definitely not at all fresh. It was edible so normally I would give it a two star except for the fact that the waitress gave us uni instead of the toro that we ordered, then tried to blame us for the mistake. Seriously? Sigh. I think I know the difference. And if you were wondering, the toro was the worse we've ever had.

Don't fall for the hype and the line; go elsewhere and be happier.
author: Joseph S.

description:
Great sushi near downtown but very noisy and staff very irritate while I have to order

Food 
Grate food 
Location 
Close to commercial area
Price 
Cheap / Expensive depend on what u Oder 
Staff 
Irritate me
author: Chef Tickets S.

description: Meh. Such a long wait, so expensive, just average sushi.
author: Sarah D.

description:
To be honest, I am actually surprised to see how many reviews this place got. I expected the roles to be very delicious and filling, but I definitely left feeling unsatisfied. The fish did taste fresh, however, they were really small. I was really disappointed by the Sexy roll because of how small it is, and it literally had a slice of American cheese just placed on top and not really melted at all. Their jumping unagi tasted like an egg roll to me, especially with the sweet and sour dipping sauce that was paired with it. I think the dragon roll was the best out of the ones I've tried, but it is definitely not the best roll in SF unfortunately. 

I do like the service that was provided. The waiters are very attentive, making sure our water is constantly refilled and coming by to pick up our plates frequently. Not sure if this is a place that I would wait a long time for in the future however.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Very good and fresh sushi, fast service, always expect a wait but once you sit down the servers are very attentive and friendly.
author: Custo A.

description: Couldn't believe how busy this place was so late at night. The moment that we hit the door went downstairs and heard the music pumping, we knew that this place was going to be great. People were friendly, sushi was delicious and it definitely hit the spot. Highly recommended.
author: Jay s.

description: We went there on a Wednesday night around 9:30. Their food is NOT worth the hour long waiting. Sauraka down the street serve equally good sushi.
author: Kaya Z.

description: Phenomenal!!! The vibe is freakin great, the food is freakin great, the DJ is freakin great!  Had a blast with my friends and made some new friends with the people next to us! Will be back again and again and again!!!
author: Steven M E.

description:
I got there around 6 and there was no wait! Awesome! 

This seems to be a very busy place as I was sitting near the kitchen, but food & service were very good. They gave us free edamame to start, which is nice.

Sushi was pretty decent and their salmon sashimi was insanely fresh thus good. 
I also ordered tuna tartare and the portion was huge. The tuna was not ahi tuna, but it tasted equally good with all the seasoning and sesame seeds.

I left around 7:30 pm ish and there was a line forming at the door already, so arriving early definitely helped.
author: Ruxin H.

description:
Ryoko... came here on a thursday night.  We were lucky that night, there was no wait around 7:30 for three people.  The line started to build up 10 minutes after we sat down.  The owner seems pretty cool and nice.  There waw a dj spining across the sushi bar.  I do not recommended for large party or biz dinner.  

Sashimi:  all the fish were fresh and nicely prepared.   If you're looking for exotic fishes, this might not be the place for you.  Akiko has more imported fish from japan and all over the world.  I am pleased with the freshness of the sashimi and the rice portion is just right.  

sake:  they carried my favorite sake : yuki no bosha: great with sashimi

Rolls:  I am not a fan of rolls except for tuna maki.  I tried the infamous valcano roll and the soicy scallop roll.  The valcano roll is okay, I am not very fond of tje peanut butter in the roll.  The spicy scallop roll is good.  

We drank two bottles if sake and couple beers.  The bill was around $350 for three people.  Not a bad price for good sushi.
author: Wasabi L.

description:
Been wanting to try this sushi joint for the longest time and finally did when my cousin visited the city! Be prepared to wait! We came in at around 9PM on a Sunday and there was a pack of people on the stairs waiting already. The wait goes by fairly fast though if you don't have a preference for bar or table. We were seated at the bar within 20 minutes. 

We ordered the chu toro (fatty tuna) from the white board, agedashi tofu, orange delight roll, dragon roll, and some sake and inari on the side. I was looking most forward to the chu toro and the melt in your mouth goodness but it didn't deliver as I expected =/ I had better chu toro at Sushi Ota down in San Diego. However, the rest of the dishes were superb! I enjoyed the dragon roll the best. Service was amazing and the atmosphere is very laid back! Would definitely come back if I'm craving sushi next time I'm in the city :)
author: Josephine C.

description:
The wait was long on Friday, about an hour if you go around 8.

The monk fish liver is really great, definitely try it!!!

The sashimi dinner was fresh, however the oyster was just okay.  Due to its location, it's a quite pricy restaurant and expect to wait for an hour.
author: Jannela X.

description:
The hostess was incredible, she was taking names, filling water, taking orders, clearing tables, and the whole time with great attitude and a smile all while being quick and promt. 

Sushi was incredible, simple but well thought-out and tasty. 

Prices were fair and felt worth the value.

Yes we had to wait a bit to get a couple seats, but if you plan ahead and give yourself a little extra time to wait you won't be disappointed!

Enjoy!
author: Nolan M.

description: Just had to drop a 5 star for the awesome food and service. I had miso ramen that hit the exact spot late last night. Definitely going back.
author: Yuwan L.

description:
Positives: Good music (DJ in the middle of the restaurant) and yummy rolls.

Negatives: There was no hostess. We were standing by the podium waiting for the hostess which never showed up...  Someone walked right in front of us and signed the wait list...
How was I supposed to know that I should sign the wait list and not wait for the hostess???

After signing the wait list, we sat down on the stairs and waited for about 1 hour to be seated. 

Food was super over priced. It was 4 of us and the bill was $210.00...  
We pig out at my favorite Sushi restaurant here in Miami and it comes out to half of what we paid here...
author: Melba B.

description:
Inviting atmosphere.

Food (and drinks) come in small portions, and do not match up with photos in the menu.

Service is fine. Wait for food is very short. Water is refilled in a timely manner.  

I probably won't be back unless someone else I'm with REALLY wants to eat here.
author: PaHoua L.

description:
Ryoko's was a good experience (once we were finally given a table). Maybe because we went on a Friday, or maybe it is like this all the time, but the wait was long and painful. The stair down the place was full with people waiting for a table for periods of 45min to an hour before their/our names were called. 

This is not a fancy place, but who needs fancy when the food is great. Down the stairs you first see a regular sushi bar with chefs preparing their delights. Wooden small tables and simple decorations are dimly lit, and a mix of indie and electronic music serve as background to the loud crowd. 

The food was delicious. I had the grilled mackerel for appetizer. For entrees, my party and I had delicious sushi rolls which names I can't remember but definitely fresh and tasty. 
Service was on point and the food definitely satisfying and worth the wait.
author: Rocio P.

description:
I love Japanese cuisine and I am always looking for new places to try. Ryoko's has been on my list for a while but somehow I only made it in last night. 
I love everything about this place: its authenticity, ambiance, food. We tried most sashimi, some nigiri, and a couple of rolls: everything was absolutely divine.
A couple of things worth knowing:
1) this place is small and fills up fast. Unless you plan ahead, be prepared to wait.
2) this place is loud and busy: do not come if you are looking for a romantic candlelit dinner
3) it is not cheap but it's definitely not expensive: I've spent a lot more on similar meals (hello, Akiko!)
4) they are open until 2AM!
author: Maria N.

description:
Top sushi! The eel, makeral and shrimp tempura are the nigiri rolls to go for 

The music on the night was awful, but hopefully just a one time thing
author: Seffa A.

description: It's definitely not a $$ side restaurant if you want to be full. You probably have to spend about 40-50 to walk out of the restaurant if you want to feel full. However the food is very good and the fish is very fresh. We had sushi rolls and nigiri. The scallop nigiri was my favorite it melts in your mouth. Also the beef is very good. It's also pretty crowded so prepare to wait. Would come back but just need to make sure what to expect.
author: Teresa C.

description:
I was in town on a work visit and tried this place with a good friend of mine. We sat at the bar, ate Omakase, and proceeded to destroy the place (in a good way). We spent about 3-4 hours eating and drinking 3 pitchers of Sapporo.

Turns out one of the Chefs was from LA and lived in SD for a bit and overheard our conversation about food scenes in SD/LA/SF and we chatted it up. The restaurant itself is tiny but it had a really comfortable vibe to it. Good ambiance, good company, good service, and good drinks. None of the above was the highlight of the night though...

The Uni was.

So sweet, so soft, so perfect. After our eyes rolled back in ecstasy, the chef explained that it was imported from Japan and I wouldn't be able to order this at most places. We ended up trying a bunch of other house special rolls and even the stuff I don't normally like (baked rolls for example) turned out to be amazing.

My only gripe is that I was too slow on ordering halibut and scallops and they ran out. We ended up eating from 8~ to midnight and the chefs were calling out fish that ran out as the night progressed. For a place so popular you think they'd order some higher quantities!

We ended up dropping like $350 but I don't think this is typical since we drank and ate probably enough for 4 people. I'm a huge fan of this place and if I make the move up to SF or visit again I'll be back for sure.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Now... This is the one sushi spots I will never forget. 
My first time I went on a Friday and the vibe was upbeat and they even had a DJ. Great spot for dates.. You just have to have a little patience . There seems to always be a little wait and it's worth it.
The fish was fresh and the rolls are creative if you choose. I highly recommend this sushi spot to all my friends!
author: Mira P.

description:
Awesome Japanese restaurant in SF!!! THe ambiance isn't really there but the food is right on!!!!

When I went there, there was a DJ in the back ground who was playing some pretty awesome original mix. 

As for food... you probably won't be loosing and it doesn't matter what you choose 

They pair the sake pretty closely to what your palet is so ask the server what is good! 

So if your looking for japanese and not sure, you won't loose with Ryoko.
author: Sam H.

description:
This place had excellent sashimi but to be quite honest.. The hype didn't meet up to its reviews. 

I came on a typical busy Saturday night. 
The first thing I noticed was the quick greeting from all the workers! Very welcoming must I say. 

Sashimi combo $30.95 
3 slices of sake, maguro, hamachi, ike scallop (the best)

Spicy tuna roll $7.00 
Huge chunks of sashimi and fresh organic cucumber 


Pros: fresh fish, decent price, organic local vegetables. 


Cons: service was horrible..., portions were on the light side, this is not a 4.5 star restaurant.
author: Nate H.

description:
When we first arrived to Ryoko's we saw that was crowded out the door. I took this as a good sign, especially for a place serving raw fish. 

The hostess was nice and very accommodating for our large group. She had a large private seating area ready for us when we were called. The ambiance is that of an authentic japanese sushi bar+restaurant. 

As for the dining experience I was left underwhelmed. The waitress taking our order was pressured on time and hesitant to answer questions about the food. Service was slow even for a Friday night.

The sashimi combo and chirashi combo were both smaller than expected. Of the two, I'd recommend getting the chirashi for the sushi rice. The ochazuke (soup+rice) dish was hearty and filling. The quality of the food was about on par with most mid to low-tier sushi restaurants. Unfortunately, nothing really stood out here. 

Pros: Fresh fish, location, back rooms excellent for large groups
Cons: Crowded, relatively small portions, service.
author: Andrew K.

description: Fresh sushi and very good toro! The place is always packed when I'm there (around dinner time)
author: Sui N.

description: Excellent sushi. We got this cozy table under the stairs. Intimate and perfect. The server was attentive and prompt. The food came out at a nice place allowing us to enjoy a disk before the next one came out. The only negative is the lack of variety in terms of Japanese food. I would have liked to se tsukemono or shisamo or ankimo other than the standard sushi fare.
author: Jay K.

description: Cool little place. Don't forget to just head straight downstairs to sign up on the list, especially if there's a line. The fish is really fresh and the food is well prepared. Portions are a little to small for me, bit it was great for the kids.
author: Nicolas C.

description: This is my favorite sushi spot in San Francisco!!! I always try to send a friend early to put our name on the waiting list, but it's totally worth the wait if there is one when you get there.
author: Eugene P.

description: Ginormous fan. Food is really good and the vibe rocks. Super convenient that it stays open til 2a. Always get a totally randomly mixed crowd. Been coming here for years and not slowing down.
author: LoVe F.

description: It is a very cute place.  The wait was very long.  But we still wanted to try it.  Thought sushi was okay -- portions are very small, nothing spectacular in our opinon..  But raved about the chicken karaage and the smoked salmon collar -- those were GREAT.  Will try again if in the area and when it's not so busy.
author: Mitzi W.

description: I am kind of confused why this place is so so popular. The price is more than $$. I had the sushi rolls called Pokemon but had no idea why it's called so. Kind of disappointing  because it's listed as only $$ but not true!
author: Rufeng C.

description:
Decor: 3/5
-Loud yelling, which I understand is the culture however it was a bit too much while trying to enjoy dinner

Service: 4/5
-sign the clipboard for the waiting this as Ryoko's fills up fast
-the food comes as it is prepared though it didn't take terribly long to get our food
-you can split checks into multiple credit cards

Food: 4/5
-Fried baby octopus was my absolute favorite. The flavor was just mouth-watering addicting. I would highly recommend ordering two. Solid 5 out of 5.
-Whole soft shell crab needs some work. If they used the same batter as the fried octopus for the soft shell crab, that would be a winner. 2 out of 5.
-Alcatraz (bbq eel with avocado) and Sexy (crab with salmon and melted cheese) were both on point and a solid 4 out of 5.
author: P H.

description: I work late so pretty much everything is closed by the time I get home. I was specifically searching for late night sushi and couldn't believe this place was open until 2am. They were well rated, but I assumed they didn't serve food past 11 so I rolled the dice. They were still serving food! We had the meguro and hamachi nigiri, agedashi tofu and one of their sushi rolls and everything was great. The service was quick. They were very attentive. It was all around a great experience.
author: Miranda P.

description: I'll keep this short and sweet: this place is unfortunately all hype.  I enjoy the ambiance, from the resident DJ that doesn't overpower you with bass-heavy top-40 hits, to the mixed crowd of patrons which, at any given night, include out-of-towners, young 20-year olds, and middle aged couples.  However the service was just okay, the sushi was also not very memorable or tasty, and the selection of fish was disappointing given all the reviews I've read.  Ryoko's tries to build a chic decorum, however it doesn't come across that way, and instead comes off a tasteless with out of place fixtures.
author: Anthony R.

description:
It's okay-- we went saturday night and it was very busy.  We waited about 30 minutes, but service was decent once we got in.  

The ambience is very noisy, and the food was decent-- nothing too memorable about it though.  Their fresh fish game (sashimi, nigiri, the like) is not strong, so stick with rolls or something.  Prices are fair for where it's located.
author: Alice S.

description:
What a disappointment! I had a lot of expectation from this place considering its reaching close to 2k reviews and 4 stars. My bf and i were craving sushi after having drinks at Press Club and we yelped was what good in the area and we saw this place. The place itself reminds me of  a tiki bar. The wait wasn't too long considering it was still packed pass 10pm. We ordered sashimi and the popular orange roll. From our first impression when the food arrived we knew it was not going to be good. First of all, the food came and it looked nothing like in the pictures, totally deceived! The miso was super salty and service was terrible. It took a while before we were able to get our servers attention. WILL NOT COME BACK OR RECOMMEND. 

GO TO EBISU :)
author: Rose P.

description:
We were in SF this weekend for a babymoon. On our last night, we were trying to figure out what to do for dinner, and this came up on Yelp that was nearby our hotel and also had great reviews. The restaurant opens for dinner at 6, and that is about the time that we got there. So we did wait about 40-45 mins for sushi bar seating, but that was understandable as it was a full-house and we got there as the first patrons were seated and began their dinners. The waitress/hostess was very nice, though, and took drink orders for the parties waiting for a table. 

When we got seated, the same waitress/hostess was very prompt with giving us water and taking our orders. She recommended their special for the night, which my husband thought was delicious. Because I am pregnant, I unfortunately couldn't try any of their sashimi or raw sushi rolls :( but everything looked really fresh! Also, the cooked items that I did order did not disappoint! I had the miso soup to start off with, which was very flavorful. I also had their deep fried baby octopus. So yummy! The octopus was cooked perfectly and was not rubbery at all. The batter also was not too thick or bready, which I appreciated. I also ordered the tiger roll (shrimp tempura roll). I didn't expect too much from it, but it was really good! 

Great service and great food. The service was also really good! Definitely recommend!
author: Michelle A.

description: FIIIIIIIRE! I'm a really picky eater, they had no problem customizing my sushi and whipped it up perfectly. pricey, but it's worth the food and vibes.
author: Anthony K.

description:
Good ambience, not too loud and not too quiet either. The food was good, the same could have been better. 

The service could have been better, the servers were a little too busy and had a difficult time understanding what we wanted. The drinks were too expensive, food was completely value for money.

Would recommend for a casual dinner or just to hang out with friends, not for a romantic dinner.
author: Dhruv M.

description:
I came to this place in the spur of the moment late at night. One of few sushi spots open late. 

Dimly lit and very small. There's a DJ playing during the late hours. Prices are high for 3 pieces of sushi!! 

3 stars for the quantity of sushi compared to the price. They need to be a bit more generous.
author: Jenna T.

description: Great sushi, and perfect for people who like a meal with fun music playing. One of the best sushi places I have been to!
author: Jack S.

description: Been here about 8 times now (in about 5 weeks- we live near by and it's good food, what.) and it's super great! Food is consistently good, prices aren't outrageous, and the vibe is wonderful. It's a really casual sushi bar, and while it is possible to rack up a large bill if you gouge yourself out on the sushi it's equally as possible to eat well for ~20-ish too. Their salmon onigiri is a decent to generously sized (depending on the chef on duty) rice ball with a good chunk of a grilled salmon fillet inside, and I order two of these along with a meat dish for a good time. Be sure to get here at 6 when they open if you don't feel like waiting though- after the first 20 minutes this place gets PACKED all the way up the stairs to the door! Service staff is friendly if not a little absent minded at times when it gets super full, and the food is delicious.
author: Sora M.

description:
Why 2 stars? Because this was a rare San Francisco disappointment.

   ---   ---   ---

Just about every meal I have in SF is wonderful, but this was far from it. The only reason we went here is because it was open late. The saving grace was that the employees were very friendly and tolerable of our Wario, Macho Man, and Tiger Woods costumes. 

But this sushi was very low-grade. Low-grade and expensive. The worst combination ever. I didn't enjoy any roll, and the bill was the capper.
author: Brett N.

description:
This place was recommended by a coworker for a recent visit to San Fran...and thank goodness because I'm not sure we would have found it otherwise!

Overall, five stars all day. Let's break it down:
Service: incredibly friendly, everyone greets you when you walk in. It was very attentive and food was served quickly. 
Atmosphere: a piano used as a menu holder and a sign in sheet where the hoards of people that were waiting put their names? Yes please!
Food: so delicious that we even ordered two of one roll-- the Golden Gate roll. I love that their prices are low, and the rolls are smaller (like 5-6 pieces each) so you can get more variety.

I'd definitely go back--would recommend to others for sure, just go early--there was a line out the door by the time we left!
author: Anne C.

description:
2 stars only for the service. 
First off: the wait was sooo long! I think my boyfriend and I waited over an hour! 

Secondly: it's just way too loud in their, I guess they're trying to make it like a "club" or "lounge" type of thing but I think it was just a little too much for me to take all in. 

Third: mostly everything was sold out so I didn't really get my "favorite" types of fish! 

Recommend: ikura was delish! I think it was the best thing I orders

Oysters, for San Fran it was low quality, didnt have a fresh taste. 

I was really disappointed with the quality of the food in general! I won't be coming back again. The wait def wasn't worth the food here.
author: Kayla R.

description: Mmmm! Good food and really cool spot.. I love how they play house music and it's in an underground type area. Really cool atmosphere and the sushi is great. Order the sexy roll..it is delicious!
author: Arielle S.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night...I know I know you aren't suppose to get sushi on a Sunday night..but I took a chance on Ryoko's!

Fish was still very fresh even though we walked in around 11:45pm. Place was busy but there was no line ( unlike usually..this place gets bumpin' so get here  early..or late).

I order the Hot Tail roll and my friend ordered a huge selection of nigiri. 

Service wise: the staff here are very friendly and accommodating. However I felt that the nigiri came out just a tad bit late. We waited probably around 20min after ordering and we sat in front of the chef. They were busy and it was late so it wasn't a biggie. 

The rice on the nigiri was just a little bit off..maybe because end of night?

I ordered a SoChu drink and the drink special of the night. Both were very tasty and they definitely did not skimp on the alcohol :P

Our bill came out around $90 not including tip.

Will definitely come back & hopefully earlier to see if rice/service is different :) I would say this is more of a 3.5 vs 3 star rating. 

Thank you Ryoko's for a great late night bite!
author: Selina W.

description:
Where to start.. 
Got to the place and was told the wait would be 30 min. Ended up being an hr and 15 min. Bad start. Ordered uni, toro, sweet shrimp, scallops, hamachi kama, and checkerboard roll. All tasted like SHIT. Food took less than 5 min to come out. Check took 10min. Never got our napkin or extra plate we asked for. First time i've ever left ZERO tip and i dont feel bad about it.
author: A.S K.

description:
One of the best sushi places in town!
The atmosphere with the deep house music is awesome, and the food is absolutely great! 
Highly recommended  !!
author: Michael J.

description: Great Sushi in SFO!  Could not get much better and an authentic experience.  The nigiri is exceptional and all of the special rolls are a great value.  Will return!
author: Ryan Z.

description:
Mmm! Great late night option.  Open til 2 AM! Had to come here after a Giants Game! Had good food and it was a very nice staff! Our waitress didn't understand us well so she was a little put-offish.. But we worked through it. Fun food experience. Will go back. Got to meet a member of the family that owns it. She was very nice and wonderful to talk to.
White Tuna Toro was AMAZING. Very bummed that I couldn't get Ama ebi.. she said they were out, but I don't know... And the whole grilled squid was awesome. But I would have liked it to be served with something else than mayo.. I'd rather some wedges of lemon and shoyu. Can't wait to go back when I'm in the city.
author: G. F.

description: This place is good for what it is, kind of like a late night suishi bar. First off, this place gets really busy and they don't have a full time hostess so everyone is expected to write their name and the number of people in their party on a sheet right by the bottom of the stairs. The wait was long but the suishi is worth the wait. Although we were standing the whole time, we did get some good people watching in and enjoyed their martinis. They have a full bar and a dj, who played some really good mixes. We had their pork belly special which was very good, it was like a stew so the pork was very flavorful and good to share between 3 or 4 people. The suishi rolls were good, but nothing amazing. What I would highly recommend is their nagiri and sashimi. You can tell the fish is of good quality and if I come back I would just order a plate of that. This is a cool place to visit and eat at!
author: Jezelle P.

description:
This place exudes cool. You think you're walking down into a dark, dingy dungeon when you first enter. And you kind of are. But it's cool, because the food is amazing, the vibe is chic, and even the music is fun. It's young and hip without being trendy or pretentious. Score!

Toro (fatty tuna) - simply the best. you must order this if they have it. Check the board
Spicy scallop - simple but delicious. supple texture
Hot tail - spicy sauce, well balanced
Checkerboard - creative, beautiful, yummy
Volcano - inventive, but wasn't my favorite. Hubby loved the peanut butter

There were no leftovers. The price was right. Service was adequate and friendly. And the DJ is set up at the front of an old piano. I mean come on, it doesn't get any better!
author: Tal T.

description:
The sushi here is excellent, period. The restaurant is dark and relatively small in the basement of a building on a hill, but the food is great. The staff is very friendly; they treated the kids very well, giving them ice cream at the end of the meal. 

The Dragon Roll is highly recommended, with eel over a crab and avocado roll. Try the Orange Delight roll too, which is a bit smaller, but very fresh and flavorful.

My daughter said the Chicken Teriyaki was the best chicken she ever had.
author: Christopher L.

description: I didn't care for the sushi as there was nothing special about it, just plain boring rolls with interesting names, but I loved their alcoholic drinks. I got the shochu with calpico and my friend got shochu with peach. I enjoyed mine more though because it was sweeter. We came because we heard there was a live dj you and watching while eating sushi but maybe we came at the wrong time because I did not see the dj though there was electronic music playing on and off. The setup of the restaurant is pretty poor. It's dark and underground and the restaurant itself is small. I was surprised to see they even had a private room for bigger groups in the back. The waitstaff was poor. They forgot to bring us water and left us waiting in the back corner.
author: Karyn G.

description: Food is good. Not the best sushi I've ever had but pretty good. They get BUSY on weekends so unless there's only two of you, be ready to wait. The staff was really attentive and nice even though they were slammed. They play fun pop music so it's a fun spot to come with friends. I'll come back but probably not with a large group.
author: Heather G.

description: We got there before 6 pm there are already more than 10 people standing, the place was just like a 80''s bar food were so so so good even as Japanese we were supposed .we definitely recommend
author: Summer R.

description:
I think anyone in the area needs to try this place out!  We come to San Francisco every year and we make this a definite dinner stop each time. 

The volcano roll is awesome!  It has a shot of peanut butter in it which melts in your mouth!  Also the Jumping rolls which are large tempura rolls are really good. 

Try this place out. It is worth the price. 

TIP - They open at 6pm. Get there at 6pm! If you are there at 6:15 you will be waiting for a table. They get busy. We have always gone when they open the doors and have never waited.  If you are looking for a quiet place, this is not it!  The atmosphere is exciting, fun, and friendly!  They yell hello (in Japanese) at every person that walks in the door. 

Great food, great people, great place!
author: Aaron P.

description:
Ick: Totally ICK.

So, why so icky? The place STANK of fish. All the sushi looked several days old. It was a Tuesday, there shouldn't have been issues with freshness.

But it didn't stop there. The fish did not taste fresh either.

Then my Uni, for example, had nori flopping about because the chef either didn't bother cutting it the right length or didn't wet it properly.

If that wasn't enough the cutting of the fish was shitty.I got sashimi and three of the pieces weren't solid, as in they fell apart as they were picked up, and not in the good way.

Go to Akiko's Restaurant (Not Akiko's Sushi) if you want good sushi. Skip this place.

Also would agree, this is NOT $$, not even for a sushi place
author: H B.

description: My friend brought me to that place , she said it should be good because of yelp reviews. We were waiting like 40 min before seated ( which is understandable it was Saturday evening ) . Seat for 2 people was terrible . I felt like I am sitting in the bart after football game . From my understanding sushi restaurant should be more relaxed atmosphere . Costumer service is so so. I got starters after my sushi rolls . My friend ordered miso soup and never get it ( but of cause they didn't forget to include it in to my check ) . We spend $89+ tip and we left starving .. It was just 5 small rolls and taste of it wasn't that great.  As a result I don't think I will be back to that place .
author: Alisa L.

description:
Went with a friend around 1130pm last night. I mean it is nice that it is open till 2am, but for what we got and the price, it wasn't worth it at all. We got a crunchy crab, amaebi and sake nigiri, and a chirashi totaling to about $60 (crazy). It wasn't the usual slices of fish over a bed of rice- it looked more like bara chirashi where they were just leftover scraps of fish all tossed into a bowl- a very messy presentation and expensive ($31). The amaebi head tasted better than the shrimp itself..which isn't supposed to be the case. The salmon nigiri was ok. I will admit that the salmon was  buttery which I liked, but I don't appreciate my fish being luke warm like it was popped in a microwave, prior to being served to me. Crunchy crab didn't look appetizing- looked as if it was just cut up and messily thrown on a plate. Wasabi looked/tasted very old to the point that it was starting to turn a bit hard and brown (gross)

The space inside is very cramped, so for people that are kind of claustrophobic, it would probably give you anxiety. We sat at a table and were only about 3 inches away from the couple next to us- really awkward and uncomfortable. Pretty dim inside but that is about it.  It is for the younger crowd so it isn't really a classy place, it was also cool that they sorta placed electronic/ house music (yay)

Service: waiters were pretty oblivious to your needs unless you flagged them down. It was also hard to get them to refill the cups. 

I was planning originally on 2 stars, but this made me bump to one. When they sat us and placed napkins on the table for us, there was in insect that was crawling around. I know it's not a cockroach but that is the first thing i thought of when I saw it scurrying. I am grateful they smooshed it right away....but that makes me seriously question the sanitation of the place.
author: Eva L.

description:
So I was really excited to come to this place because of the raving reviews on Yelp. I was a little disappointed.

Yes the atmosphere is really cool. There is cool music, you get a Japanese greeting from all the staff when you walk in. There is lots of space, and the service is great.

I tried the dynamite roll and it lacked flavor. The sexy roll was warm and tasty. But for the small size of the rolls I thought it wasn't worth the hype.
author: Jeremiah Z.

description: Great quality and great service for such a CRAZY BUSY PLACE ! all the servers were great and super fast. The sushi was exceptional. My first time here and I'll definitely come back when I'm back in the city
author: Marcela P.

description:
It's long line, long wait, but food quality is superb.

We are sashimi lover, so we usually order sashimi, so for the portion of sashimi, I will give 3 dollars sign $$$, portion is pretty is small, but everything is super yummy.

But the aura is pretty confusing, really? is this Japanese restaurant? People work there looks Thai.

everything is above average, just eat something before you go or eat a salad and drink a soup in the nearby sanraku restaurant, while you put your name in the list.
author: Rabbitar N.

description:
My favorite sushi restaurant. 25+ visits over about a decade maybe.

I used to think I only liked it so much because of the late hours. I seriously have never been here before 11pm. Now I haven't been everywhere, but after eating around, regardless of the time I still enjoy Ryoko's sushi more than anywhere else so far. 

To me, the quality of the nigiri and rolls are better than other places. The way the fish is sliced, the quality of that fish, the size of the nigiri rice, etc., all contribute to my kind of sushi experience. They're not big fat rolls, or thick slices of fish. I like that. In the context of sushi I prefer smaller and delicate than heavy-handed technique and portions.

Because it's a smaller place, they don't have a huge variety of fish. The usual suspects and a few "specials" on their board. I always make an effort to try things from that board but often by the time I get there they're sold out. At the hours I frequent it's understandable. 

In my sushi experience  (albeit limited), it's been the best o-toro, chu-toro, and Hamachi toro. One night it was fun to try regular hamachi, hamachi toro, and wild hamachi toro side by side by side. Sometimes the have kobe beef tataki, sometimes the guys will make something not on the menu. I rarely have had something there I don't like. 

It's not cheap but sushi isn't cheap. Typical dinner for 2 when I go:

Beef oroshi
Rice
6-10 pieces nigiri
4-6 rolls 
Gyoza

$90-$130 before tip. Doesn't include drinks because I rarely drink there. I think given where we are, the prices are on the expensive side but I'm happy to splurge on something so good.

Maybe if you're a sushi geek/conniseur this place might be too pedestrian. But for me, it's top notch.
author: Dash_Rendar _.

description:
Haven't eaten here, but have heard great things. 

They used to take reservations for parties larger than 8, but apparently that policy has changed. I wanted to bring a group of 12 people here for my birthday dinner. The lady who answered the phone was polite, but suggested we walk in. Too bad- 12 people doing sushi and sake is a lot of business, but I can't risk walking in with that large of a group.
author: Vinitha R.

description: I love Ryoko's! My parents took me here back in October and I just visited again this past weekend. The music is very upbeat and fun, which is different from most japanese sushi restaurants. There is also a line that forms in front of the restaurant about 15 minutes prior to opening, so I recommend you get there a little early. The restaurant filled up in about 30 minutes from opening.
author: Yui H.

description:
This place is absolutely remarkable. I'm not even a big sushi fan, but this place changed that for me. Everything was fresh and delicious and having the chef prepare his choice for us didn't disappoint.

If you're in SF, you MUST eat at Ryoko's!
author: Travis Q.

description:
Great food. Fresh and tasty
Love sashimi plate and eel plate.

Music are loud for people who like loud music. Pop and rock. 

Minus one star for no AC
There are electronic fans but AC is necessary for a bar I think.
author: Jie M.

description:
This was a very interesting place. It's an underground sushi bar. Each room has its on character. You have to sign in on your own and you wait on the stairs. 

The chicken teriyaki was so tender and very tasty. The sushi was really fresh. The jumping unagi was so good with the special dipping sauce. The dragon roll was really fresh. The mochi balls for desert was really good and delicious. This place was so good. I loved it. The wait was worth it.
author: Doug T.

description:
We went here for an early dinner before our show which was a good idea as they got pretty busy when we left around 7pm.  Service was prompt and friendly and the atmosphere was relaxed as good music was playing in the background.  

We ordered the 49ers, Volcano, Golden Gate, Jumping California, and a few other small dishes.  The sushi was delicious! Wished the portions were a bit bigger but overall our experience was great! 

Would definitely come back!
author: Joy H.

description:
I've heard such raving reviews from friends and of course from Yelp, but oh was I fooled!  I'll never go back, the food made me sick and the service was a joke.  

A group of 6 of us got seated pretty quickly.  We got tons of beer and sake, which was the best part of our dinner!  Each couple ordered different items:

- Sashimi dinner combo:  Wouldn't allow us to sub one item, we both didn't like mackerel but she wouldn't let us even remove it.  We just didn't want to waste the fish, but oh well.  The dish came with a bowl of rice and miso soup, we only ate 6 pieces of the fish when it came with 14 (maguro, sake, hamachi, tako, hotate, and mackerel)
- Nigiri:  Amaebi (mediocre, the fried heads were so greasy it made me sick), Salmon (a little fishy, but manageable), Maguro (flavorless and tough texture), Mackerel (couldn't even eat it because of the smell), Uni (not terrible, but the size of your thumb), Hamachi (I spit it out because the texture freaked me out and it tasted fishy), Tobiko, Tamago, and Unagi (tasted like eel sauce).
- A couple rolls: No comment from me because my other friends got them, but they said they weren't very good

My friends were so shocked and embarrassed, they were convinced that it was a new chef!  We asked the waitress and she immediately got defensive and just smiled and said, "Management has not changed, sorry you didn't like food."

That's fine, not her fault and we don't blame any of the waiter/waitresses but the last lady that came in to check in on us.  I can't even explain how... rude she was.  She kept saying, "Oh yeah I don't know, so sorry.  So so sorry." With the most sarcastic tone I've ever heard... AND I'M SUPER SARCASTIC! LOL

We all left starving because we barely touched our food, we went to Jack in the Box after spending $400 at this place.

So, if you want sushi go to:  Wayo, Elephant Sushi, Sanraku (around the corner) for a better experience and better food!  Good luck...
author: Jackie O.

description: There's a hostess stand but no hostess. You are supposed to write your name down on a clip board to get signed in. Seems they could put some signage about that. We had to wait a while and before we realized we were not on list. Food was okay.
author: Mathis W.

description: The plus is that it is open until 2am. The minus is that the food is awful. Pick your poison.
author: David Y.

description:
Don't want to misuse Yelp here, but I tried to eat here this week at 11pm but left with some bad energy. Ryokos was packed...cool music, food looked killer, everyone clearly enjoying themselves. Stoked! Yelpers have thankfully set expectations about wait long times and I've got plenty of time to wait for a table. Looking forward to great food and a cold beer.

With ~10 people camped on the stairs, guessing a 30min wait. 15min go by and servers are busy with tables so haven't talked to any staff yet. A couple walks in and takes a stair behind me. Server walks up and takes a couple to their table. After 20 minutes a guy walks in, nudges himself down the stairs and takes a clipboard off a hook (that I couldn't see past the people in front of me) and writes his name down (?) and stands by the clipboard. The other people waiting seem to notice see this and go back to their conversations. Okay...

'Hmmm, maybe I'm supposed to add myself to that list...". At this point of enlightenment another group walks in, and one of their party squeezes down straight to the clipboard and starts writing. Server walks up, takes clipboard, checks list and asks who is (fill in name) and begins scanning for a table for them.  Now I realize that both me and at the couple behind me are 1) clueless to the 'locals only' self-service clipboard and 2) will not get a table before midnight due to our ignorance. That's fine...live & learn.

The epiphany that automatically compelled me to walk out and find another sushi spot was knowing that the ~8 people that were on the stairs when I walked in didn't bother to speak up and suggest that I might want to grab the clipboard and put my name down.  Wow 

I'm a 35-year Californian and moved to Idaho 10 years ago. I miss the food most of all. While we have nothing like Ryokos in Boise, our locals do remember how to pass good energy to strangers. All things being equal...had I walked in to the same Ryokos in Boise on a crowded night, someone would have tapped my shoulder and pointed out that clipboard.  

Sorry there's no food review here. I wish I could have tried the sushi...but no thanks San Francisco. Peace.
author: Jim H.

description: More closer to a 3 and. Half but I was generous. They're open late and I have a lot of great memories here. The idako alone are the main reason me and many friends keep returning.
author: mel l.

description:
Came here for a late night snack since we already had dinner earlier that evening.  Saw that this place had delicious looking amaebi so we were sold.

Got there, four people were waiting at the bottom on the stairs. We put our names on the clipboard.  Two assholes walk in and just stand there.  Then when the waitress calls us for our table, they had the nerve to say they were there before us but just didn't put their name down.  These assholes were not waiting outside, as there was nobody outside when we came in.  Regardless waitress decided to honor the assholes.  Not that pissed since i didn't want to be at the bar anyways, but just saying there are plenty of ramen places in NY where those stupid clipboard lists are treated like gold.  Not this place apparently.

Ordered the amaebi which was delicious.  Order other fish, nothing spectacular.  Tried some oysters, they could be fresher and better seasoned.  Ordered the checkerboard roll just for kicks, but I feel ripped off.

Not that special.  Service was bad, took forever to get our waitress to get us the check.  Food came in random order.  How do you get your Amaebi heads before you've had amaebi?  Rolls come before Fish?  Having been to like every fancy sushi restaurant in NY, this horrible service and lack of decorum  would put the Japanese people to shame, but wait, I don't really think they are Japanese here.
author: Tina Y.

description: A decent sushi restaurant - not quite as good as Sakana. Located in the basement. Its decor is dark. Almost like a bar/pub atmosphere. The staff is young. Not what I would call a traditional sushi restaurant.
author: Straight N.

description:
Downtown in SF and hankering for sushi? This hidden gem has great quality sushi in a deceptively large basement room. 

We had tempura (hot, lightly battered, perfection), as well as a mix of specialty rolls and nigiri. Everything was tasty and came out well presented. 

As always my complaint about SF sushi is that it's just too damn expensive (as opposed to Vancouver - I'm spoiled), but if you're hankering for some then this is the ticket.
author: Colene C.

description: 0meeeps. i havent been to ryoko's in forever, so decided to stop by last night and fulfill my sushi craving! there is usually a line out there door on friday and saturday nights, and it's a really divey for a japanese restaurant! wait for two on a wednesday evening at 7 30 was 10 minutes for a table, not bad.  we ordered - 2 pitchers of sapporo (such a deal at $15 a pop), 4 rolls - including the orange blossom, lots of eel and salmon stuff. in hindsight we should've just ordered nigiri because the rolls were really disappointing and had poor execution - i mean they werent even cut evenly! i wont be returning in the near future...
author: Christina L.

description: Super yummy and fresh sushi. Long wait sitting on the stairs, but it's worth it. I've been to lots of sushi places and this definitely tops.
author: Marc B.

description: The sushi is just okay. There's a strange flavor in a lot of rolls, which I think is taco powder. Really odd. Doesn't go with the fish at all. To make things worse, they haven't labeled their menu about which one of the rolls have this weird "sauce".  The service we got was also terrible.  There are a ton of good sushi places in SF.  Don't waste your time, waiting in a long line for this mediocre one.
author: Sarah A.

description: I came here with my boyfriend for my birthday and I was pleasantly surprise by the cool hip vibes. The selection on their rolls are huge and the fish is super fresh. The waitress recommended the uni and oh my goodness it was heavenly! This place is a destination spot! Definitely come try.
author: Jessie S.

description:
I will happily jump on the bandwagon here and say that this place was awesome. And popular, so get there early! Plus, I think the largest tables seat 4 so it's probably not the place to bring your family reunion.

My co-workers and I went for dinner on a Monday night. We arrived a little after 6 and got in no problem but by the time we left every table was full and there was a good number of people waiting.

We ordered a bunch of sushi and rolls. Everything was delicious. My favorites were the eel for the sushi and the California roll, of all things. I know it's probably lame to say that the California roll was the best but no joke out of the 5 different rolls we got one of my co-workers and I both ordered more California rolls! When it's good, it's good, what can I say?

I would definitely go back next time I'm in the area.
author: Holly R.

description: Lots of good memories here for late night soirees and general fun and mayhem.  Ok, this place it a bit of a dive, but the food and drinks are pretty good and it's lots of fun with friends.  Love to bring friends here even for a late night.  It's not for business meals with clients. If you come in with a big group (like 8-10) they have a private room in the back!
author: Clyde V.

description:
Happy happy joy joy.

Sabagari and spicy scallop nom nom.  Both had unusual and distinct flavors and high quality fish.

Green tea and miso soup were Sooooooooooo deliciously steeped.

The ambiance is great.  Cosy and secretive.
author: Lucy G.

description: Super crowded and a LOOOOONNG waiting line, since this is the only place opened til late hours. The ambience was okay, crowded. The food was okay, but not the best. I had upset stomach the next morning, maybe its because of Ryoko's.....but its not a bad place to go for late night sushi!
author: Heidi L.

description:
Craving for sushi near home but, don't want to go any where far from home. So, we found this place which was only 0.2 miles from our home. 

My son went there at 6PM. They were packed. He order what was on the menu list which we check on their website.  After he placed the order and paid with the CC the person told him that its going to take an hr for his food to be ready. He was shocked. Damn, good thing we didn't live too far so they offer to call us when the food is ready. 

The sushi and rolls are very delicious.Fresh salmon and my son had Ika without the rice. Which was really nice and beautiful presentation. I believe that the California rolls were made with real crab meat (If my son was right) and not imitation. Which made my son very happy.  Two orders of  Salmon Onigiri was good. Down side was the chicken Teriyaki. It was cold and was not enough sauce. Other  than that we were satisfied with the food.

My reason for three stars. An hour wait for take out. As our first timer there, they should of mention how long the wait will be before we paid with our CC. So that minus a star. Another thing was cold Teriyaki that's another star taken off. But, I will definitely  willing to try it out again and this time make a RSVP or phone order (If that is acceptable there). Maybe on my next review it will be 5 stars = )
author: An C.

description: The tuna sashimi was fresh and delicious. The yellowtail was juicy and sweet. Awesome cold sake. Chinoroku or something like that. We were walking through the tenderloin and happened upon this place luckily. This made our first impression of San Francisco a good one.
author: Alex S.

description: It was decent. There was a long wait which didn't surprise me on a Friday night in San Fran.  I thought the food was very bland.  Edamame was cold and didn't even have salt on it.  I was surprised it was so popular considering the food is not that good.   Chairs are extremely uncomfortable.
author: Alexis M.

description: Looking for late night drinks and some food to fill your belly? This is the place to be. With a live DJ taking requests, can't beat it. Staff was super accommodating, food and drinks came out quick. You can make it a chill night or "other".
author: Huy N.

description: My favorite place for Sushi! Worth the wait even at midnight :) Just a perfect place for midnight sushi hunters!
author: N B.

description: I don't know what the hype is about. Yelp suggested this place and as it had what looked like fabulous reviews my sister and I wait about 35 minutes for a crammed corner table with horrible lighting. It is sad to say, but the alcohol and club-like scene probably helps to tune out the mediocrity of this place. The food was definitely not $$ it was more like $$$. Uni was $17.80 and we got overlooked two halves of shrimp for our chef's choice sashimi at $40... Will not be coming back. Would NOT recommend.
author: Nina V.

description: Good value restaurant. We waited 30minutes but that was worth it ! Incredible sushi roll and groovy music!
author: Proulx C.

description: Amazing . Everything was super fresh and delish I can't believe I havnt been here before ! Loved it
author: Valerie P.

description: We stumbled on this joint mostly because the sushi chefs and waitstaff HIYA at you from the basement when you walk by. Sushi literally called to us. The food was good and reasonably priced and the staff were all super friendly and efficient. And...if you closed your eyes the music took you back to a strip club circa 2009. It's not everyday you get to eat great sushi and listen to beats like that.
author: Dajsa F.

description: Love this place. Use to come here all the time when I lived in SF. It has a really homey feel and the sushi is phenomenal. Highly recommend
author: Orli D.

description: Ryoko's food was decadent. When you walk in, the place doesn't look like anything and there is a wait, but it's worth the wait. The food is amazing: Tahoe roll & yellow tail were amazing. We can't wait to return to this gem.
author: Julia L.

description:
Came to Ryokos after watching Elf at the Curran around 10:00PM.  We walked in and the place was packed.  I put our name on the list and we were seated about 30 minutes later.  

There was a DJ spinnning a whole bunch of "classics" (90's hip hop) so my wife and I were enjoying the jams while waiting.  Service was a little slow but still very acceptable.  Our waitress was super friendly, nice and always apologetic about the slow service.  

We ordered 5 items

Agadashi Tofu
Sexy Roll
Jumping California
Philly Roll
Orange Blossom

EVERYTHING was delicious.  Although the portions were not that big we still left full and satisfied.  The prices are very reasonable and the food was great!
author: Henry S.

description:
Went here for dinner with the BF while in town. Lots of sushi places in this area right near our hotel but concierge recommended this as her fave...

Looks like a hole In the wall from the outside but go in and down the stairs- it's quite cosy and cute. There were a line of people crowding the stairwell waiting for tables. You write your own name and number of people on a paper at the hostess stand- a waitress comes and calls people when tables or the sushi bar open up. It's popular and crowded here so be prepared to wait...probably not best for families or large groups. 

Once we were seated though the experience was just what we were looking for. Attentive wait staff, good drinks, fresh and fun sushi. We got on the house edamame to share, and both ordered flavors of chai-hu cocktails (which we had never had). Yummy! Next, miso soup which was rich and delicious, piping hot. And finally the sushi- we got multiple rolls including shrimp tempura, crab and avocado, spicy yellowtail, and a spicy BBQ eel ("big momma"?) roll- all had cute names I can't now remember...but all were delicious and filing. I wouldn't say the best I've had anywhere-DC still takes that cake- but certainly quality.

Price was very appropriate especially in this area, HUGE sushi menu to choose from, and yes it is small and can get crowded but once we were seated we really didn't notice and I felt had appropriate space in a restaurant this size.
author: Farheen Q.

description: Went on a busy saturday night and had to wait for a while. It is worth the wait! The sushi was really good, especially the fried crab one. The atmosphere is unlike other sushi places, actually really cosy and not typical as we know it, and good music!
author: Christy V.

description: We went there at 5:50pm and we have to wait until it was 6pm but it was really funny because there were coming around 10 other peoples too. It was a really cool place with really good music and the sushi was special but it was really expansive over 100$ for us two for some pieces of sushi and two cocktails but for this place it was okay we would come again :)
author: Stefanie F.

description: The Uni was really good. Others are alright, not very amazing. The waiting is a bit long compared to the food quality. The chirashi bowl was so disappointing! Don't order it.
author: Vera W.

description: I came here last night right after landing in San Francisco, I needed something open, and I came to the right spot. I love how they are open late. Very friendly staff and great service. The seafood was fresh and delicious as well. The reason for the four stars is the portion sizes, the seaweed salad was small, the oysters were tiny, and the rolls were small as well. Overall a good experience though.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Just fantastic.  Be prepared to wait for over an hour..don't be a jerk about it.  You'll be waiting on a tiny staircase and getting to the bar isn't totally easy, but this food is WORTH IT.
Peruse the specials, order sake, tip well!
author: M H.

description: The wait was unnecessarily long, could totally be shortened if they were more organized. Food was decent but a bit expensive (at least $$$, but $$).
author: Carla L.

description:
Tucked off the main street, enter down a steep staircase into the darkness... and you're going to start your foodie journey!

TIP: Check the daily specials behind the sushi bar.
Come here for quality sushi, an intimate venue, affordable sushi and beer, and an escape from the hustle outside.
author: Regina D.

description: The rolls were small and overpriced. The interior is kind of cool and divey, but we sat in the little area past the main bar area, and it smelled like pee in there. It was definitely not worth the hour's wait to get in. If you want delicious rolls that are a good size and a fair price, try Elephant Sushi.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description: Perfect late night high quality sushi. We enjoyed the jumping tuna (yum), 49er roll, hot tuna roll (Japanese basil in this roll was not my fave but a huge hit at the table). My favorite was the sea perch sushi which I had never had. Hamachi toro sushi and salmon sushi was solid. Will def recommend and go back. Great service too.
author: Nilo K.

description: My favorite sushi spot in the city! I highly recommend this place to all my out of town friends!
author: Brandon P.

description: Wait time is typically said to be "45mins to an Hour" but most of the time you'll be seated within 20 mins. You can order drinks while you wait. Amazing fresh fish, order everything you want in one shot, because it can take awhile to get any additional things you might request. Chill cool traditional Japanese vibe with a DJ.
author: PNUT M.

description:
This is THE best sushi I've had in San Francisco.
My boyfriend and I arrived around 7pm on a Tuesday and the place was already packed. We added our name to the list at the front and were told that there were tables that had paid and were just waiting to leave and then we would be seated- I really appreciated the communication! We were seated within 10 short minutes.
Everything we ordered was so fresh and delicious!
The uni special was heavenly, the tuna roll and spicy tuna roll (which were called something different- I just don't remember) were INCREDIBLE. The tuna practically melted on your tongue. No soy sauce needed. Even the California roll was great and I'm not usually a fan. We also had a pitcher of Sapporo, miso, edamame, and the fried cheese. Delish. Everything was great. 
By the time we left, there were many people waiting for tables and yet we never felt rushed to leave. 
Tip: Woman's bathroom is upstairs.
author: Rachel M.

description: Sat at the bar busy place.  They all yell to great you when you come in. We had good sushi one had shrimp and jalapeño and peanut butter it was so good. Food was good and. Service was quick and very good
author: jessi s.

description:
There are many sushi restaurants in the city, I would like to give 3.5 star for the foods and extra 0.5 for the mood of restaurant.

we order edamame, 12 pic sashimi, uni, amaebi, ikura nigirzushi, one sushi roll, miso soup and saba shioyaki. Those were pretty fresh and yummy. 
If you are looking for very fresh and traditional japanese sushi restaurant, it wouldn't be the first choose of the city. BUT if you are looking for $$ yummy japanese restaurant, it will be a very nice choose.
author: Wendy O.

description: High energy sushi chefs, haha! Small place with a long line. Rainbow roll was ok, but not fantastic and didn't look like the crab was real so not worth the $20 price tag. Shiitake roll was good as well as their miso soup, but I don't think it's worth the long wait tho.
author: Tony R.

description: Amazing food and amazing atmosphere. I've driven here all the way from San Mateo twice and it didn't disappoint either time. You most likely will experience a 25 minute MINIMUM depending on when you come in, but the food is worth it! Last night during our wait, one of the servers offered a free shot of Patron to everyone who was waiting. Such a kind gesture! Also, they have a DJ playing great music which sets a very chill vibe. I would definitely recommend this place for a date night or if you're just out with your friends.
author: Corinne U.

description:
Down a flight of stairs, a very dimly lit dining room with a bar, next to a bar.
Yep, that's an alcohol full serve bar, next to.... a sushi bar, that is. Definite dive bar atmosphere, and with a Japanese trio behind the counter churning out appetizers, nigiri, and jive ass rolls. The incessant influx of crowds coming every few minutes after the restaurant's 6 pm opening, the place comes alive. Some of these peep$ are sitting on the stairs, waiting their turn to boogie up and down. No Reservations? Bourdain, please. Gotta make it a few days before. This ain't the French Laundry.

Ryoko's is otherwise a fairly small space with bar seats that accomodate around 10 or so. All stools at the bar, so think about where you might want to stash that jacket if you have one. There's even a piano in here, although I didn't stick around late enough to see drunktard tourists (or hipsters posing as tourists) downing sakee bombz standing on top of it and professing their love for spicy tempura peanut butter "volcano roll", and the handsome charming and uber cool ponytailed head chef Atsushi Matsuda (yes his name really contains "sushi", how awe$ome is that! Wonder if he has any relation to Seiko Matsuda?). Should there be female fans in attendance who are quite inebriated, might mistake him for Takeshi Kaneshiro from Sleepless Town 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ycevahHdZCM

and fall prey to potential drunk ordering (which can be lethal on the wallet) as he recommends in perfect Japanese accented English, white board $pecial$ that will be like seductive words of sweet luvins after some shots and bottles of Sapporo (probably from Canada).

Prime real estate location with a chit ton of foot traffic (especially tourists and out of towners, and of course those people who cannot live without sushi), plus the fact that this place closes at 2 am (last order circa 1:45 AM)...being the only place in NorCal that I know of at least, where you can get non douchey sushi past midnight, is not too shabby otherwise, and thus the rounded up 4 rating (~3.5 for the food). Just don't expect Koo, Kazu, Aka Tombo, Ino, Sebo, or Murasaki and you will do just fine.

The food? Oh yeah:

Shirauo (appetizer) - this was listed on the white board but they didn't offer it as sushi. Shirauo is Japanese ice fish, kind of like conger eel larvae, thin little transparent white swimmies (no not THAT kind) with dotty black eyes. A typical and classic Edomae sushi topping (either steamed in a little salt water, or served raw with ginger and a little scallion in gunkan form). N00b a$$ me for ordering this when peak season is Mar - May... Atsushi-san garnished this in a cocktail glass, a little ginger, scallion, and....a raw egg yolk?! After mixing it together, it didn't taste so good.

Ankimo appetizer - a few very mushy soft slices of monkfish liver...in fact a bit too mushy on the edges, with some mixed greens on the side. Ino and Sebo have nothing to worry about.

Assorted nigiri, chef's choice, aka "let the chef sock it to me baby surprise". 

Aji (horse mackeral, with enough pairs ordered to use a whole fish, with carcass salted and deep fried)
hirame konbu jime (kelp marinated hirame)
mebachi maguro (big eye red tuna)
hamachi toro (aka farmed yellowtail belly, seared)
wild sockeye salmon
uni (sea urchin gonads)
tamgoyaki (egg omlette)
amaebi (raw spot prawns with fried head on the side)

Better sushi rice than most Chinese and Korean run sushi places, but still not my quite my style.

And for the helluvit, Orange Delight roll ....seared farmed salmon (with skin on) over an inside out roll of cucumber and avocado. I have to say this is one of the smallest and most expensive jive ass rolls I ever had, but it was actually tasty for what it was.

Decent spot for hanging out with friends late night and having a craving for raw fish over rice. Izakaya Mai in San Mateo has "sushi" at $1.50 per piece that opens till midnight on most nights, but it's run of the mill stuff and nowhere near as good...whereas it's a bit more extreme here in terms of price...where you pay a premium here for real estate and late hours.
author: Ken K.

description: We were recommended this place by locals and sadly disappointed. The rolls were so small hardly any fish used and priced fairly high for the little amount of a roll that you get. Overall the wait is too long and the food is overpriced for what you get.
author: Sabrina S.

description:
My favourite random find whilst in SF. 

You line up at the top of the stairs and look down into the basement sushi bar and think "I want to be in there". The vibe is so cool. Sounds and looks like a hip underground drinking den, but tastes like sake and tuna sashimi.

Cheap and so much better than cheerful.
author: Claire H.

description:
On our last night in San Francisco, I was hankering for something other than Katana-Ya. Don't get me wrong, as much as it was delicious every trip, I wanted a bit of variety to my meal! Just down the block was Ryoko, a sushi bar, and what seemed to be a local favorite after my constant search for what to eat on my trip.

Once you enter, you walk down into a basement suite of pop music, loud laughter, and boisterous orders being called between bartenders. Although not specified anywhere, I definitely consider it an izakaya, a Japanese "pub" where food is to go with sake and drinks. We were tired from the day's trip and the atmosphere of the restaurant definitely elevated my mood!

Complimentary edamame beans  started the night off in the right direction. Boiled fresh and generously salted, I was addicted and ordered another dish ($3.50 the second time around), which was considerably larger than our first plate.

Joe had developed a habit of ordering seaweed salad at every Japanese restaurant we went to, and it went the same for Ryoko. Although it wasn't the crunchy one he preferred, it was well seasoned with sesame dressing.

The appetizer menu looked delicious and suitable for sharing over a round of drinks, but I was hankering some sushi. Ordering the salmon, red tuna, and hamachi served it's purpose for me. Fresh cut sashimi, adequately portioned for the rice, with a hint of wasabi in between - win! The rice is something to comment on although I'm not quite sure what to say of it. It's different from your regular sushi rice, with a hint of light brown coloration. Perhaps the marinade is different because I didn't think it was anywhere close to brown rice. Other than the color though, the rice was slightly warm and cooked perfectly for sushi.

To go with our nigiri, we also ordered a spicy scallop, hot tuna, and jumping tuna roll. With two full pages of rolls, the selection is extensive and ranged from your basic keppa rolls to elaborate deep-fried maki. The jumping tuna roll was my favorite, spicy tuna, cucumber, and shiso rolled and deep-fried in a light tempura batter. Usually fried rolls are made larger to hold its shape, but there were perfect bite-sized pieces. The spicy scallop and hot tuna were done in the traditional roll style and were delightful. Loosely rolled (some may prefer a tighter package to prevent spills), the highlight of the roll was definitely the use of fresh seafood and lightly seasoned marinades.

I absolutely loved this place, both for atmosphere and for the food. Reasonably priced, great service, and great food - all I can ask for! We were there on a Monday night so the wait was a mere couple of minutes, but it was a hot spot nevertheless. I would presume you would need to come early on Friday and weekend nights and don't expect reservations as I noticed a clipboard where you wrote your own name and table size up at the front. With a live DJ on Friday and Saturday nights, a piano right in the middle of the bar area, and open late 7 days a week until 2 AM, no wonder locals love this place!
author: Cindy N.

description: It is definitely a good sign when you see a large Asian customer base at a sushi restaurant -- this tells you the food is legit! There are no reservations; you sign in on a list and wait to be called. We waited about an hour and a half, but it was SO worth it. The music playlist was awesome (urban contemporary), the sushi melted in your mouth, and the vibe was on point. This will be my go to sushi spot whenever I'm in San Fran!!
author: Melba P.

description:
"Real" California style sushi was another thing on my list of things to try in SF. Ryoko's was very close to where I was staying and seemed to have good reviews.

Ryoko's is located in a basement. It's sort of dark and mysterious, I loved it! Very unusual vibe for a sushi bar. Soft house music playing and dimly lit.

I took a place at the sushi bar and watched the sushi chefs at work. Everything looked fresh and I was getting pretty excited.

I told the chef I wanted to try a couple rolls and a few pieces of sashimi. He helped me select 2 pieces of yellowfin tuna and 2 sushi rolls:

Pokemon roll - Salmon, mango, avocado, green lettuce wrapped in soy paper

Tahoe roll - Tuna, avocado and flying fish roe

Everything was delicious and presentation was beautiful.

A bit pricy in my opinion (bill came to $30), but this seems to be the going rate for sushi in SF
author: Lauren M.

description: Really good! We are from the east coast and are used to really fresh fish. This place did not disappoint. The squid was amazing. Also got lots of sushi and 3 rolls. All of the fish was fresh. We got one roll (can't remember the name but it has melted chews on top) that I could have done without. But overall was very tasty.
author: Cheri E.

description:
Most of us have tried hot or cold sake Ryoko's also has Shōchū a Japanese distilled beverage like vodka made from either rice, potato or barley which is best savored straight up or on the rocks.

For starters I recommend the deep fried oysters and deep fried soft shell crab served with soy vinaigrette.  I sat at the left side of the bar so I could look at the white board for today specials. I worked my way through the sashimi list of fresh fish. I tried the Halibut, Big eye red tuna, Mackerel, Yellowtail, Smoked Salmon and Uni.

If you sit at the sushi bar Ryoko's sushi chefs create all the sushi rolls and hand them to your waiter at the bar. So there is not much interaction between the customers and the sushi chefs. But I did not mind because the food was coming out at a nice steady pace.

Sushi rolls recommendations.

Alacatraz
Tahoe
Spicy Golden Gate
Hot Tuna
Hot Tail
Pokemon
Orange Delight
49er's
Caterpillar
Dragon

NOTE: For all you drunk ass bitches eating sushi and you know who you are!! You must be really high to try these crazy ass sushi rolls with chicken, peanut butter for god sake and cheese!! What is wrong with you people LOL

Kentucky Roll
Deep fried chicken, green leaf lettuce, and tonkatsu sauce

Volcano Roll
Deep fried shrimp, and jalapeno, with peanut butter, cucumber, and flying fish roe on top

Sexy Roll
Crab and avocado with salmon and cheese on top (baked)
author: Mi C.

description:
Late night eats and SF aren't words you see together very often. This is a city where things usually close up by 10pm. Not Ryoko's! This place is just getting started, serving all the way till 1-2am. 
But if you want the good stuff come early as the fish runs out quick. When I went around 12, they wouldn't do the sushi special but only the chirashi. 
Fish was amazing, but I feel it would have been better represented as sushi or sashimi. It's a shame they weren't able to do it that way. 

Another cool thing about this place is that it plays 90s rap and hip hop. Really departure from your normal Japanese restaurant, it's refreshing and definitely a nice place to hang out.
