Came in for dinner on Monday around 8pm and there was about a 15 minute wait.  While we were waiting, the server asked us if we wanted anything to drink, which was very nice of her.  
The food was good - we enjoyed the Chicken Karaage, Checkerboard, Orange Delight, and the Hot Tail and they offered a good selection of drinks.  Throughout the meal, the servers were attentive and prompt despite the restaurant being at capacity.  I'd definitely recommend it, especially for smaller groups.
author: Gloria N.

description: Very overpriced for "alright" sushi. Stay away from ordering sashimi dinner, where they choose 14 pieces for you. The chef will choose the cheapest kind of fish. You can tell what kind of place this is by the selection of sashimi they serve you. Not worth paying 100 dollars. Better to just choose the fish yourself for 7 dollars per 2 pieces.
author: Noah W.

description:
This place re-ignited my love for sushi! Have the chef put a plate together for you. I promise, the sushi is so fresh, you won't be disappointed...even if you get things you've never had, heard of, or have been afraid to try before. The grilled mackerel was outrageously delicious. Simple but tasty. Although it's an appetizer, the portion is big (two big pieces just under the size of a normal filet...6 oz.), it could be a main dish. Have it with a side of rice.

Try the needle head fish. After eating the fish, they will fry the head and bones and it turns into a crispy piece of goodness. It sounds odd, but trust me on this.

Along with the normal pickled ginger and wasabi, they also serve this spicy, finely ground kimchi (I believe it was kimchi), which I could eat by the spoonful.
author: Tearle C.

description:
Ryoko's is an interesting place to review. On one hand, I didn't think the restaurant was worth the 900+ raving reviews; but on the other, there were a few dishes that really blew me out of the water. In the end, I settled with 4 stars, because there is some spectacular food served here that you can't get anywhere else, (i.e. TOFU!!!).

The Good:
1. Agedashi tofu: lightly fried, served with just the right toppings
2. Yakitori: though I thought it was a bit too salty for my tastes, my Japanese friend said the flavor was "right on"
3. Yudofu: some really amazing tofu! Haven't had such good tofu since Eiji or EN in NY
4. Chawanmushi: looks plain but has great flavors!

The Bad:
1. Portions are too small
2. Prices are a bit high for the quantity (and quality of sushi)
3. Wasn't too impressed with the sushi. Rolls weren't particularly inventive or tasty, and definitely didn't make up for it in portion size.

The Ugly:
1. What self-respecting Japanese restaurant charges $2 hot tea? Should've at least told me up front.
2. Decor is... weird.
3. Why do women have to climb up to the 2nd floor for the ladies' room?
author: Sherry L.

description: Fun place. Sushi was good. Great late night spot. Nice atmosphere. Pricing was high but that's the deal here.
author: Devon M.

description:
While visiting the beautiful city of San Francisco we stumbled across this joint. Being night owls, we arrived a little past midnight and felt no rush to order or to eat. This was great because after eating everything we had ordered we re-ordered, the sushi is just that good! Everyone raves about the volcano rolls, and yes it's good, but explore the menu. Any choice here is a right choice. At $2 you can order an oyster shot and cheer with your mates, guaranteed freshness.

The fact that this sushi restaurant is in the heart of SF I expected nothing but the best, and that's exactly what I got. Sushi meets hipsters. The ambience was upbeat and the music was bumping. They had a dj spinning records but the music wasn't loud, I was able to chat with my table without having to yell into their ears.

San Fran locals, I envy you all. Best sushi I have ever had!
author: Shelly M.

description: Total tourist trap.  I tried ordering  tuna and they were sold out.  I tried ordering albacore and they were out.  All of their rolls are almost identical and the quality is just okay.  The place is dark, dirty, and it stinks.  I would never go there again...ever.
author: Justin R.

description: Very friendly environment. The restaurant itself was a bit small so our wait was about 45 minutes, but the food was definitely worth the wait. Freshly prepared and service was quick. Live DJ in the back played light music keeping the atmosphere fun and light. Our waiter was amazing! She was the only one in our section taking care of 5-6 tables at once and doing great. She was incredible! It was a bit old and dingy in there but It was the perfect Friday night dinner!
author: John N.

description:
Positives: small and cozy little place, very
Inexpensive, they seat you with a little edamame teaser, AND they have $15 bottle of wine, $15!!!! That's GREAT! 
3 stars because the sushi isn't anything to write home about. Although the one sushimi we just left up to the chef was really good. We really should remember to always leave it to the chef! The rolls though we're lacking.
author: Tazia S.

description: A friend recently suggested this place and it is, quite possibly, the best sushi I've ever had. Don't be discouraged by the long wait time or sometimes chaotic facade, this place is a hidden gem.
author: Lindsay N.

description:
I've had fabulous sushi before but this place is beyond fabulous!!! It's kinda cool and dark and comes along with a good crowd. The staff are very friendly. Sit at the bar and enjoy the scenery!!! 
Their fish is very fresh and melts in ur mouth. The rolls are awesome too. Make sure u try the clam miso soup, it's goooood!! Will definitely go back when I'm back I'm town. No wonder it has such awesome ratings.
author: Negar M.

description:
Came here at 1:30am and found reasonably priced sushi. The tuna tasted a little strange but may just be fresher than I'm used to. We had the XL hot sake which was pretty nice, though in retrosppect we should have gotten 3 larges perhaps because the XL did seem a little small.

The volcano roll had peanut butter which was an interesting and enjoyable twist. Tekka roll (tuna) was nothing special. The teriyaki beef was a little tough, but drunk at 1:30am, there are bigger priorities than worrying about the toughness (like getting it into my stomach).

They were friendly and jovial, and the DJ played decent background music that was not disruptive.
author: Steven R.

description:
Came across this place on Yelp and decided to try it out. Lively ambiance and tasty sushi rolls.

Quick points: 
1. Decent priced rolls but they are smaller than most other places so you may spend more than anticipated ordering extra food.
2. Came here half an hour after opening on a Friday and it was already packed. By the time we got seated there was a line out the door. 
3. Quick service quick turnaround. 
4. If its busy when you arrive- order a drink while you wait!
author: Rebecca F.

description:
LOVED the monk fish liver and takoyaki,  honestly I wish I had forgone the rolls and just stuck with their appetizers.

The monk fish liver was soooooo fresh and creamy and slightly sweet and went perfectly with the slightly tangy sauce it came with.

The takoyaki was perfectly cooked and huge and came with a mountain of bonito flakes!  So fantastic.  We also got the fried baby octopus which was seasoned well and not overlooked at all.

We then got the toro and scallion roll, spicy salmon roll, and eel and avocado roll. 

Honestly the rolls were nbd, should have just stuck with more appetizers or straight up nigiri.  The rolls were kind of small and not really garnish well.

But despite the lackluster rolls I would go back in a heartbeat for the monk fish liver alone.

Plus the staff was super friendly and the service was fast.  Luckily it was just the two of us and we beat the dinner rush by getting seats at the bar.  PERFECT.

Excited to have found this place!
author: Michelle L.

description: awesome atmosphere and the DJs 's music set rocked my world. The service was below par and that's the reason for the 3. Food was good but nothing spectacular or different. The two of us ordered the grilled squid plus drinks. Waitress came by table every 10 minutes to see if we wanted anything else but we were still looking at the menu and needed more time. Every time she stopped by she would ask if we wanted anything else besides the squid. Anyhow...45 mins go by and my man asks the waitress how much more time til the squid was done. She goes and check and blames kitchen for forgetting the dish. I don't blame the kitchen. I blame the waitress. It's your job to make sure things run smooth between the kitchen and your customer/table. Make sure your customers have drinks and the food they ordered in a timely manner and then proper checkout. Use that notepad sister! And maybe check in mentally when you're at work.
author: Minh N.

description:
Yelped this place and we fell in love!

Very chill vibe with amazing food, service and music! 

The sushi chefs were SO nice and the DJ was spinning Snoop Dogg (LBC baby haha). So it was a great experience. 

Food wise, it was delicious! My favorite has to be the 49er roll...YUM!
author: Jinny S.

description:
So glad I discovered a sushi place near my place. Ryoko's sushi is very fresh and the prices are relatively decent. I probably would not recommend this place for a first, or even second-fourth date because it's very loud. The night I went, they were playing house and trance music - which is cool, but I had a hard time hearing the person I was eating with. It is pretty dim too. 

I'd definitely come back, though. The service is also very friendly and quick.
author: Lin C.

description: Very average. A big let down after looking at the ratings. If you are from a city with good sushi you will be disappointed.  The rolls are wrapped so loosely that even if they were good, which they weren't, they would fall apart before they got to your mouth.  The sashimi was average. Thirty places in ny that are local and low ratings that blow this place away.
author: Brad H.

description:
Party of 12 girls and we were seated rather quickly (Thank God for reservations). Before seating us, the waiter tells us abruptly: "Two hour maximum!" Got it buddy! Service was quick once we started ordering so it wasn't a problem.

What I swallowed:

FRIED OYSTERS: These were really good and flavorful. Juicy middles with great flavor. I could have ordered another whole plate.

CATERPILLER ROLL (Shared): The fish was impressively fresh. Rolls were a bit smaller then most places but the fish was delectable so it more than made up for it.

HOT TAIL (Shared): The hamachi was really fresh and so buttery. This was well put together but too bad there were only five small pieces.

CHICKEN KARAAGE: I ordered this as my two-some dishes above still left me hungry. This chicken was really tasty. The outside had a good flavor, the edges were crispy and the insides were moist and juicy. So addicting I ate the whole plate.

Great place to spend with a group of friends. Service was nice and quick and they were very responsive to our requests. They even offered the buttday girl a fried banana (?) ice cream sundae, complete with candle, while we sang out loud to our heart's content. Good thing there was a really good DJ spinning so we could be as loud as we want and we blended right in.

Overall great place, great service and great time.
author: Vivian A.

description:
I'm pretty sure Ryoko's is an underground haunt as downward stairs come to mind... but then again, I did have quite a few drinks in me when I was here as it was my last night in town for a wedding.

After roaming around the city from over-packed bar to over-packed bar, my two bros and I decided to just head somewhere we could sit, eat, drink and relax. Sushi and sake seemed like a good idea and to Ryoko's Japanese Restaurant & Bar the boys took me.

We were seated instantly at 11:45pm on a Saturday night and everyone was having a good time. Music was loud and energy was still high. Since last call was soon we hurriedly rattled off a long list of items to order. Of course we got the two standards, hot sake and Sapporo. Three bottles of each to start off with come to think of it. Then the food- spicy tuna rolls, dragon rolls, tempura rolls etc. etc. I also ordered some kanpachi and sake nigiri since I always judge a sushi restaurant on these two types of fish. Also, I'm convinced from past experience that California always has the most flavorful salmon and kanpachi. It still held true here! The maki rolls were deliciously fresh although definitely not the best rolling jobs I've seen. Still, it was yummy so who cares if the seaweed wasn't even or sticking together all the way around?

Ryoko's also has daily, flown-in sushi specials which I love. I want my fish fresh and recently killed, you hear? Great atmosphere, service (loved our waitress!!!) and food. I honestly don't need anything else.
author: Leslie D.

description:
Yum. That's how this review starts. Yum.

My number one suggestion- get here early. They open at 6pm and there is a line even before the doors open. 

This is a very trendy sushi restaurant. My favorites are the marinated yellowtail and spicy scallops. I love the fact that they readily refill my tea without me even having to ask.

Prices are average for Ye ol sushi spot. $7 for simple rolls and about $13 for the fancy ones. I suggest order a bit more than a roll per person (roll has about six pieces).
author: Viktoriya Z.

description:
This is definitely one of my favorite sushi places.  I go here when I have the time and money. Be prepared to wait for a table and spend $$ if you're eating to get full. The venue is below street level and they usually have a dj playing deep house music to get you in the sushi eating mood. Very chill 

Favorite thing to order is the ami ebi. 2 pieces of nigiri with deep fried shrimp heads for $8. Sooooo good! Definitely something worth trying if you've never tried it. Staff is always very attentive and friendly.
author: Anna M.

description: Nigiri is a little pricy but the rolls are where it's at. The volcano roll is so bomb it has peanut butter, fried shrimp, ebi, cucumber, fried jalepeno. Also their spicy tuna and spicy hamachi roll is also a favorite. I love that they are open late. What is there not to like? just the business on the weekends and parking is horrible.
author: Santoki A.

description: The HOT TUNA roll was awesome, but don't order the "Jumping Tuna" as I has to wait 30 more minutes to get and our meal was done already. The "Jumping Tuna" had a bad fish taste too (not a fan) :( . Beyond the bad experience with the "Jumping Tuna" roll I thought the overall experience was quite good.
author: Wade P.

description:
Loved this place. We missed our reservation by a lil, and they were able to squeeze us in for the next open spot.

The vibe was great and service was good even though the place was waaaayy crowded. They even have a DJ spinning. 

Sat at the bar, can't remember what we ordered but it all tastes great. I do remember the salmon sushi to be just fatty enough. Nothing was over complicated and we were very happy with food and service.
author: Cyndie L.

description: Overrated. Definitely not what I was expecting from a 4-star restaurant with over 1800 reviews. The price should be at least 3-Dollar signs. Portions were small for the price. Menu lacked specialty rolls and many of the rolls had this weird taste to it from some kind of vegetable they added, I'm not sure what it's called. Tried this place twice but most likely won't come back. We had to wait 30 minutes to sit and kept getting skipped since we wanted a table for 4 people and the restaurant seemed to cater to parties of 2 people. The service was good though. Cool vibe and played music which made it stand out from other sushi places.
author: Judy N.

description: Party of 8, really slow service for us. Food was decent.
author: Sonny S.

description: I'm not from SF BUT this is the best sushi ive ever had. I branched out and tried things I'd never try and no lie, I dreamed about the jalapeño peanut butter roll last night. Great drinks too. And the fatty tuna is something I'll never stop thinking about!
author: Tanna D.

description: Amazing food, affordable price, great atmosphere- close to union square. Would definitely come back!
author: Brittany B.

description:
Our group of 3 came here last Friday night just before 7pm and it appeared we had just missed the long string of people soon lining the stairs down into the restaurant's basement space. 

It's a cozy space but tables are arranged in such a way that made us feel like we still had our personal space (they have support columns and various nooks going thru the space that gives each table a little privacy). Plus, there was music playing in the background that was just loud enough to drown out the conversations from neighboring tables, allowing us to talk without having to scream at each other. That, along with the fairy-lit space, made for a cool vibe. There's also considerable sushi bar seating and a grand piano.

We enjoyed our orders of dragon roll, flying unagi roll and fried oysters. The waitress was also helpful with sake recommendations and never rushed us despite all the people waiting. 

It's not easy finding above average food options in the Union Square area so I think this is a fun pick, a very short stroll away. Would love to check it out again when they have live piano music playing.
author: Nadine D.

description:
I can't see myself coming back here, unless I get a raise. I really think this place is overpriced and the portions are small, BUT the food is exceptionally fresh. Despite some comments about bad service, I have to defend the restaurant on that one. Service was impeccable, they were so attentive that I thought I was in an Asian country. That's how good the service is. If your glass was half empty, they fill it. If they've seen you made a mess with the saki bombs, they come running with napkins. 

I had about 3-4 appetizers shared with my group of 5 and shared one roll, and uni nigiri pieces. I seriously had less than 10 bites during that whole meal and I ended up paying $42. Definitely not worth filling my belly, and ended up hurting my wallet.

However, if you have the funds, and you want some FRESH sushi and want to witness true customer service, then this the place to be.
author: Minette C.

description: Late night bite for the most part! This place is always full even at midnight. That's the time I tend to go with co workers. The only con is the rolls are pretty small for the price.  bombs are the best!
author: Myra C.

description: Although the roll we got (jumping California) was heavy (fried) the atmosphere the prices and the appetizers (fried cheese and tempura) were delicious
author: LaDasha M.

description:
Great sushi spot, though at first a little intimidating to get a seat. We got here with a party of 2 around 6:45 pm on a weekend and had to wait about 40 minutes. You write your name down yourself on the clipboard. I didn't think it was all that bad for a popular location on a popular night. Most people crowded around the stairwell area, and that could get stressful, but my date and I opted to get drinks at the Owl Tree across the street while we waited and that worked out perfectly.

The inside is fairly large for sushi place. It was spacious, but they could seat a lot of people. Compare this to Sakana across the street, which is a lot smaller, and they told us we'd have to wait at least 45 minutes there.

The service was very nice, though we did have to wait a little long for our food. We got the 49er roll, negihama roll, Tahoe roll, California roll, and Tiger roll. They don't skimp on their portions and the piece were cut quite large. My favorite was the Tahoe roll because I love tuna and the cucumber gave it just the perfect amount of crunch. 

It was also not that pricey for a relatively nice place. The rolls ranged from $9 to $13. Seems like it'd be good for groups, too, because they had enough tables to seat larger parties. Because it's also a bar, though, I could see how things could get a little loud and roudy.
author: Jamie C.

description: Good sushi. The sashimi was thin, not worth it for the bucks. It's fun to watch people drinking sake bomb
author: Vy T.

description:
1. One hour waiting list. No phone reservation. 
2. Edamame... Delicious! Ask for 2nd portion...is free! 
3. Sweet sake 12$ ... Try it! 
4. Live Dj...a lot of people... Noise but cool! 
5. Food... Ask for sushi...no rolls! 

Enjoy!
author: L Camille C.

description:
Let's see...open late at night after the theatre/symphony is done? Check.
Good food? Check.
Alcohol? Check.

Great hang out place, but can be a bit crowded at night if you have a group more than 4 people. Their fish is fresh and delicious, and their rolls are priced reasonably. They might be a bit slow at night, but considering how crowded they are, I'd suggest that you get a drink and just be patient.
author: Alice C.

description:
This is a terrific and very quaint sushi restaurant. Small, somewhat low key, authentic, and very delicious. 

The rolls are really creative and quite tasty, and the sashimi and nigiri are super fresh. This place tends to get really busy and hectic, so arrive early and be prepared to wait. Not a place to go with family, but great for a casual business dinner or a meal with your significant other.
author: Sam Z.

description:
It just wasn't as good as I expected. I compared mostly everything here with sushi restaurants in LA and it wasn't hitting the right spot. The service was nice, but mostly all sushi restaurants are. The ladies restroom was at the top of the stair case and soo tiny! If you have a phobia of falling down stairs, beware! (lol). The soft shell crab was ok, the sauce didn't help. Everything else was ok, we ordered mostly rolls. I wasn't impressed with any of them. The drink I ordered was the Peach Tea Shocu... and it was nasty! I had to down it as fast as possible. 

Overall, I probably wouldn't come back. I'd definitely want to check out another spot.
author: Christina V.

description:
I am filled with mixed emotions on this place and ill list out why with pros and cons: 

Pros: 
1) Deep fried soft shell crabs! (First time having it and this place made me love it!)
2) Torro! Didnt think much of it, but boyyy that fatty tuna was good!
3) Underground vibe was pretty cool

Cons:
1) sketchy neighborhood
2) long wait for sushi. Not consistent at all. Waited 20 minutes for my order of torro that was $14 for 2 pieces essentially of tuna slapped on top of rice. Disappointed me in the turnout. 
3) overpriced and small quantity
4) subpar sushi 
5) staff tends to be overly attentive and constantly bugging us (annoying to an extent) and then when we needed them, nowhere to be found

Overall, id come for the soft shell crab, not sure about anything else...

Prepare for a long wait though if you have more than 3
author: Kevin W.

description: This place is a solid choice for sushi if you are downtown. Do expect to wait for at least 45 minutes. I give it 4 stars becuase it's good but not mind blowing.
author: Elba A.

description:
Honestly, I do NOT understand the hype around this place.

Last Friday we came here with a group of 6 excited to try it out after reading all the yelp reviews.

We waited about 30 minutes for a table, they DO NOT take reservations which is irritating. 30 minutes around 11 pm is a bit crazy for not good food.

We sat down and ordered because we had waited so long we got a chance to look at the menu and know what we wanted right away.

I got a tiger roll...excited based off the description. For $8, I only got 5 pieces. Benihana gives more pieces than that and is about the same price!
The roll wasn't even that great...sub par and not worth my time or money

Everyone else was disappointed with their meal as well.

The only saving grace of the restaurant was Vern, the host at the front who was so nice and accommodating. Other than that, I am never coming back..

Oh and to top it off, there was a HUGE fight outside the restaurant when we were leaving...no thanks!
author: Annie C.

description: As soon as you open the door, you are greeted with a hello (in Japanese i assume)..something like the cheers episode when Norm walks thru the door. Very impressive seeing how the tiny basement place is packed..literally. ..barely enough walking room. I was told by the parking attendance at my hotel how good the sushi was. The guy was right. I ordered the "sexy" and a simple California roll. The sushi was very fresh and absolutely delicious. Ryoko has my vote and i will definitely return.
author: Chrystal Q.

description:
After loitering inside Candlestick Park for the final 49er's home game of the season and forever at that stadium, we realized we were hungry. Pulled up the trusty Yelp survival app and searched for something nearby our hotel in Union Square. 

This place came up with sufficient amount of reviews and stars. I'm a sucker for stars...multiple stars. Is it sad I base what I eat and do off of the amount of stars a place has?   Yikes! 

The restaurant is underground, small place and a bit stuffy cause it was underground but they do their best to keep the fresh air flowing with ceiling fans. Signed in and within 10 minutes, got called in for seating. Sat down, ordered water...lots of water. We were thirsty, dehydrated, about to faint from lack of liquid, you catch my drift? 

I wanted to try their gyoza but nope...they ran out. Must have been really good to run out. So instead, we got the beef teriyaki ($14.75) as a starter but it didn't come out until AFTER our rolls were out and we ate them all. So keep mindful of that "starter". It's a lot of beef. We had to order a side of steam rice to eat with it.  We had the 49er's sushi roll. Yep...that's right. They had a roll called 49er's and it had crab, avocado with tuna and salmon on top ($13.50). Pretty delicious. We also had the Pokemon sushi roll which had salmon, mango, avocado, and green leaf lettuce, wrapped with soy paper ($11.50). Have to say that this was my favorite. That mango did the trick and I love soy paper wraps over seaweed wraps. We didn't order too much. This was a good amount of food for two people. The rolls were about 6 or so pieces. 

I recommend this place. It's open late night and the service is good. Even on a busy Monday night. MONDAY NIGHT!
author: Lisa M.

description:
TINY portions. Tiny! I think our whole party was disappointed for the surprisingly small amount of food we got. I got a Pokemon Roll ($11.50) which consisted of just five pieces, with a tiny sliver of mango, a 1mm thin slice of avocado, and the rest stuffed with lettuce (LETTUCE!).

We also got the Jumping Unagi roll. While it tasted pretty good, it was also very small. None of the rolls were able to put a dent into the stomach of anyone at our table.

While rated as a $$, the price is more like a $$$. Each dish may cost between $7-15, which is reasonable for sushi, but if you wanted to get a real meal out of them you'll end up spending $25-30+.
author: Kailin H.

description:
Wow, just came back & I must say...never again!

I wish I had as great an experience here as everyone else, but I didn't.

I got to share this lovely experience with my sister.  The night actually started off well.  The waitress was attentive as we ordered & we didn't wait too long for the food, but once we got out food, it was like we didn't exist.

There was no soy sauce on our table so we waited for our waitress because we thought it may be rude to grab off of other tables & replace with empty containers.   Nothing.  Finally we are able to flag a different waitress down & we get our soy sauce.

We eat and we finish with a couple of items we wanted to take to go.  After almost 30 minutes of waiting,  another waitress finally approaches us.  I asked for a to-go box and the check.

We watched all the waitresses assist other tables - fine, we're leaving anyways.  We even see them fraternizing by the bar for a really long time.  After about 30 more minutes a different waitress from the three before asks if we are finished.  This was the last straw for me!  After telling the waitress I waited over 25 minutes for my check, they finally put some fire under their asses and moved quicker.   I paid & left - didn't even take what I intended to take to go.  I wish I could justify this behavior by saying it was busy, but it was not.  & to see all the waitresses doing nothing, but chit chat at the bar...seriously?  I'm really big on customer service & these women are obviously oblivious to that concept.

I will never come back.
author: BizzyLizzy K.

description:
Crunchy crab roll = the best thing i have ever eaten in my life!

I can no longer enjoy sushi at any other place, nothing tastes as fresh!
author: BIGBOB K.

description: Was here 7/29/16 . Nothing special. We waited about 30 mins for our food which is very long consideringthe food we ordered are all raw.
author: Cindy B.

description:
This is a sneaky awesome sushi place with some crazy fun nighttime entertainment.
Sushi is great.
Saki is great.
Not too pricy particularly for the area.
I've been on 3 separate occasions, solo and with coworkers during visits to San Fran.
I recommend.
author: Tom A.

description: Great sushi.  Awesome vibe and solid menu.  There's always a line to get in so be prepared to invest the time to get in and enjoy your meal.  The volcano roll and the orange delight rolls rock.  The prices are $$$, but it's worth it.  Enjoy!
author: Wendy M.

description: Great place, underground and they play good music. The service is great, and for appetizers, 2 rolls and dessert we paid a pretty cheap bill for great quality, would definitely bring more friends to this place
author: Jenny M.

description: Good sushi, low prices. Gets very packed. They ran out of oysters and Hamachi toro around 7 pm
author: George L.

description:
Beware those place is crowded. We put our names down for a party of 5 and had to wait more than an hour and this was after 9pm. 

The salmon skin roll was delicious! My friend ordered this roll that had peanut butter in it,  interesting and tasty.
author: Tiffany S.

description: I went with my boyfriend right before the dinner rush. They are not kidding, there is a long wait. The line process is not very efficient however the food is amazing. The salmon is so fresh and I personally fell in love with the Saba and tuna. We had many other dishes but those two stood out but all of them were really fresh and heavenly. The servers, chefs, owners, and bartenders are so kind even under so much pressure and customers that have no idea what they are ordering or care about how much they are taking up their time. USE GOOGLE IF YOU DONT KNOW WHAT A FISH IS. And if you don't eat fish or at least some kind if sashimi, I don't suggest you come here. This place is not cheap if you are just going to get ramen. It is in union square so it is a little pricy but it is absolutely affordable. Small area and limited seating. Barely any parking so taxi or walk there.
author: Angel L.

description:
Pleasantly surprised!!

We came in to the city around 11:00pm and we wanted something good to eat that was opened late night. I had already bookmarked this place based on the reviews and since it was one of the few places open past midnight, we decided to check it out.

Ryoko's is a true definite of a hole in the wall. We passed by it once bc we didn't notice how dark and hidden the restaurant was in the corner. Depending on what time you go, parking can be hard or easy. We were fortunate to find parking very easily around the vicinity.

Once you step in, you can't figure out if Ryoko's is a dive bar, restaurant, sushi joint? Which is it?! It does NOT look like your typical sushi restaurant. Nothing inside screams Japanese or sushi. However, the bf and I went in with no judgements ready to start out night and got seated right away.

Even though Ryoko's does not look like your typical Japanese restaurant, the menu looked pretty authentic. They had a variety of sashimi and sushi and we ordered an array of food. 

Something's we ordered:
-Tofu salad
-Sweet shrimp
-Sexy roll
-Spicy scallop
-Jumping tuna
-Soft shell crab

The sushi here was very clean and fresh. Nothing was overdone with sauce or rice. I really enjoyed eating the Jumping tuna, spicy scallop and sexy roll. All were so simple and clean and most importantly, good fresh fish. The bf always orders a sushi of sweet shrimp and the fried shrimp heads were ginormous and also some of the freshest shrimps he's eaten. 

Nonetheless, even though our meal was very satisfying, what made our night was the top notch service. The ladies here really made our experience even that much better. They always kept coming by to check on us, refilling my beer from our pitcher to make sure our mug is never empty, and always asking us for anything else.

Overall, I had a great start on my trip here at SF thanks to Ryoko's. I was very pleasantly surprised with my late night dinner and definitely will come back if I want some sushi 1:00 in the morning!!
author: Hanna P.

description: The first night i was in town i have been here and was an unexpected experience! The restaurant was in the Basement of the building, the space was hype and casual at the same time! The coolest thing of this place was the fact that they take the last table at 1.30 am and you have a dj playing music all night long!! The food was delightful, i had the pokemon roll and it was fresh, tasty, and light, then I had a lot of others things, but i don't remember the names!anyway i highly recommend this place!!
author: Lucia M.

description:
This is my second time here and I love this place. The sushi isn't by any means the best that I've ever had, but it is tasty enough.

It's a bitch to get in to though and there is always a queue. We put our name on the list and asked how long the wait would be. We were told 45 minutes, so we hopped back outside and down to Owl Tree for a beer. We were less than half an hour by the time we got back and they had just called our name. I felt pretty smug because it looked like I just walked in and got a table. The power of past experience because I HATE queuing for anywhere.

It is quite loud in there, not a calm zen environment, but that was OK for a late night saturday dinner date when we'd been drinking all afternoon. I've got a big thing for prawns at the moment and the Shrimp Garlic helped sate the craving. We also had the gyoza which was delicious. I'm not sure what else we had because I was pretty drunk, but I remember thinking it was awesome and I felt full.

Oh and beer pitchers. ^__^
author: Hannah B.

description: Great food and energy!  Yes, it's a bit dive-y and service is well-intentioned but spotty but overall, it's a blast. It has the energy, informality and crazy good food of a izakaya in Kyoto.
author: Michael F.

description: Do not waste your time or money here.  There are many other sushi bars in SAF with much higher quality - You are paying for the late nite gig here  ....OK, busy as hell with nowhere to stand.  Very astute personnel working there who will herd you to a corner.  Get your table and get hurried along some more.  Food is OK, but not a pleasant experience. The waitress was no less than a btch.  Again, food is OK.....  Time to pay,,, all checks on one bill and cannot separate.  Dont miss that 18% tip they add on if over 6 people..... Restrooms were from hell with no maintenance at all. Dirty!! .  Could not wait to get out of this place and paid way too much for this ordeal.......AGAIN - Stay TF  away!!!
author: Selena23 Q.

description: I thought I knew good sushi before coming here. This place has opened my eyes to a whole new level of quality sashimi. My new go to sushi spot coming from Palo Alto.
author: Paul P.

description: My friends and I love coming here. The sushi is delicious. Sometimes the wait is a little long but it's definitely worth it. Everything from appetizers through salads and the full sushi menu are delicious. The servers are pleasant and the sushi makers are entertaining. A fun place to eat.
author: Anne H.

description:
This is a great place to go out ! The music is awesome and the atmosphere ...
Perfect for a date !
author: Alex B.

description:
NYC meets SNL vibe. Tiny inside, delicious sushi. Worth the wait.

Order the 49er roll.
author: Danielle T.

description:
As with most good SF restaurants, we had to wait about 45 minutes before getting 2 seats at the sushi bar counter. Since I get my fair share of good, traditional sushi and fresh sashimi at home, I was really looking for a sushi bar that does American style sushi well - you know... the fried/baked/cheese covered stuff that on paper seems easy to construct but is actually very difficult to execute well. 

Ryoko's fit that box perfectly. We had the wakame salad and ankimo (monkfish liver) for starters. The salad leaves and seaweed were fresh and dressed in a slightly sweet orange dressing. None of that sweet ginger dressing crap you find at most Japanese restaurants run by Chinese.  Monkfish liver was new for me and while I thought it was only available in winter, there it was on the menu. It tastes like a cross between a foie gras pate and otoro and comes with ponzu sauce and some grated stuff (ginger or daikon I think). On the scale of seafood delicacies, I probably would have substituted this with uni but that's just personal preference.

We had the Jumping Unagi, Volcano and Sexy rolls as mains, and the grilled ika because it came rather late in the meal. All three rolls were orgasmic. Just enough of a hodge podge of ingredients to bring out the fish and fatty goodness of avocados or cheese. The Volcano roll has peanut butter in it and I thought, "wow this really works well". Kind of strange, unexpected like the jalapeno, but it just works. I thought the Sexy roll could have been baked better because some of the salmon was cold, but it still blew my mind in it's 3/4 done state. 

Finally the grilled squid. Oh em gee. In Cantonese we have a term called "wok hei" to describe the wok's breath on great stir fried dishes. Here I could taste the grill's...breath (?) on the squid. It was perfect. Not the same as the grilled squid you'd typically get in the Mediterranean, but great Japanese style smoky grilling. Major chopstick fighting til the last ring was consumed.

I had the Ryoko's pilsner while my other half had Asahi. Our server (who's name I unfortunately forgot) was a little flustered because it was a very busy Saturday night but she explained the dishes, recommended a great dessert (I should mention, tempura ice cream is... just order it) and was attentive. Our night was made excellent but the insane trip hop being spun/performed by the DJ. Did not expect it and both of us were contemplating whether to be creepy at the end of our meal and ask for his playlist. 

Ryoko's has a great combination of the hole-in-the-wall sushi spot experience, with a very energetic yet laid back vibe, great food and very good music. You almost wish there was a dance floor at the back so that you could work off all the fish and rice you're imbibing. We had a truly great evening and it is one for the books.
author: Clara L.

description:
I was visiting SF on Valentine's day and wanted to find a chill fun place for dinner where they wouldn't have an overpriced pre fixe menu. This sushi spot came up and was super close to our hotel. 

I knew the wait would be long and they don't take reservations so we put our name down and went to a near by bar for a quick drink. Came back 45 minutes later, right in time for us to be seated. 

Everyone is seated really close to one another and we actually ended up making friends with a couple that had the table next to us. Could have been awkward though as you can hear other people's conversations. 

Lots of sushi roll options. We got a few and they were all good. 

Miso soup was a bit too fishy for me. Not what I am used to. Didn't really like it.

DJ was awesome!
author: Lina K.

description:
Maybe it's the name of the restaurant. No, that wasn't all. Fish was fresh, nigiri was properly sized in relation to the fish, very delicious food served promptly and courteously. The sake selection was good too. I like how the server checked back on us - but not excessively - so we can order additional sake and sushi (because my husband and I have infinite space in our stomachs for this).

Four stars only because I haven't visited SF enough to try other sushi restaurants to say Ryoko's is the best of the best. But we share a name. I'll be back!
author: Ryoko K.

description:
GOOD LUCK WITH PARKING HERE. Otherwise ... definitely a fun place for a decent eat and good times with a nice atmosphere.

OK sushi (just keep drinking?). HORRIBLE parking (anywhere in SF really ...), and just a great time if you manage to get in with friends. Enjoy!
author: Joseph L.

description:
Hello Yelpers,

I'm very picky when it comes to sushi. I only go to one place in OC and I don't usually put it on blast because I'm selfish and don't want it to get over crowded. Haha jk. Not really. Anyway, during my SF visit, my friends and I wanted to try some good sushi. I Yelped nearby sushi restaurants and Ryoko was the first to pop up with over 1300 reviews. That impressed me already but when I got read the reviews, i thought wow, I must try! Ok so to give you the low down...we ordered...

Uni, BlueFin Tuna, Albacore, Sweet shrimp, Monk Fish Liver, Salmon Skin Handrolls.

All fresh. All amazing. All slowly melted in my mouth. The End.

Enjoy!
author: janet d.

description:
This place was super fun for a Friday night date. DJ was awesome, food was hella good. Get the GRILLED SQUID! It's so yummy.

Young, hip crowd here.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
If you're starving and just happen to be in the area, this isn't the place for you. The wait time is super long and you will be forced to wait awkwardly on a flight of stairs, trying not to make eye contact with all the food that is passing by.

The environment is fun and laid back so it's not a bad place to have a casual dinner with friends. In terms of food though, I don't think there's anything particularly memorable, authentic, or amazing. 

TL;DR-Good if you just want to grab sushi with friends. Bad if you are starving upon arrival, be prepared to wait. Keep looking if you are searching for sushi that rivals your study abroad trip to Japan.
author: Yanni L.

description:
Wow, what an amazing sushi restaurant! At first I was scared we weren't gonna get a table. The line was huge, Saturday night at 8pm. But I put our name down and then after that the server was getting drinks for everyone waiting at the door. Amazing, by doing that it really made the time go by fast. After about fifteen minutes, we were able to get a table. 

The food was really great, maybe not the Alcatraz. That one was a little less flavorful. But all the rolls after that were amazing! The Jumping California was the best sushi roll I've ever had. Just ridiculous how good it was! 

The one problem and reason why it's not five stars for me. There were a few flies flying around. This is something they need to take care of immediately. I will come back again and hopefully next time there will be no more flies.
author: Erik H.

description: The best best nigiri in sf downtown. It's pricy but totally worth it. Small dining area. Better make a reservation before you go there.
author: Tina H.

description: Okay sushi....items advertised that weren't actually on the menu...aka fried ice cream (which is the whole reason we came here for)
author: Geraldine S.

description:
Food is decent, but much more expensive compare to other sushi bar around SF. 

-open late. 
-loud music (con for me)
author: Nova C.

description:
I was looking forward to this place due to the reviews but I feel this place was overhyped. The sushi was average and some of the rolls I got didn't really have much flavor. This could be that I arrived around 10 but I don't think time had any effect on the quality of the food. I can honestly say though that I've had better sushi at many other places. The staff were friendly despite the place being packed. Still, this place was a complete let down since there were not any sushi rolls that really stood out above being mediocre.

Update: the green tea is cloudy. I have never heard or seen green tea that is murky like the bay.
author: James Y.

description:
Love this place. I've been here a few times now and their food is consistent. Their sushi is delicious and fresh, especially when you order from their specialty board. I love their hamachi toro and Uni sushi. They also have some creative rolls. Top it off, they got a good selection of Japanese tapas like fried oysters and clam miso soup. 
I would suggest getting here early to put ur name down bc this place always have a line, often over a hr wait.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Back again for another bday celebration and Ryoko's did not fail us! With a large party of 12 girls, they gave us the infamous blue room.  Cramped seating but it'll do.

Sushi were semi pricey for small, bite-size portions but I have to emphasize that the food is so worth it! The tuna is oh-so fresh, light, and melts in your mouth.The fried chicken appetizer was nicely seasoned and  utterly delectable!  With a 2 hour max, the service was on par.  Our server was well attentive with our multiple orders of sushi and saki. And lastly, the special bday girl was surprised with a candle lit, fried ice cream as her guests warmly sang her Happy Bday! What a nice touch!

A lot of head nodding this particular night as the DJ blazed 80s and 90s beats!  

Great music, great company, and great food!  Love this spot! I'm a fan!
author: Diana M.

description:
One word: Overrated.

While Ryoko's serves perfectly respectable fresh sushi, from what I can tell, the hype is all about the ambiance. The ambiance is...crowded and loud. The night I was there, I felt like knee pads and glow sticks might have been appropriate attire, as rave beats were being piped through the speakers as dozens of people (mostly under the age of 25) hollered at each other in the stairwell. We showed up at 10 minutes to 6, and were the last ones seated at the sushi bar. The wait was over an hour long within a few minutes of opening.

The sashimi, sushi, and creative dishes were decent, but lacked the flair, elegance, and delicacy of flavor that one might find at most higher-end sushi restaurants. Overall, it was unremarkable.

The service was quite good, which is impressive considering the crowds packed into the place (I guess San Fran has lenient fire codes), but good service, mediocre atmosphere, and okay food do not a 5-star review make.
author: David K.

description: Grilled squid is a must! Try the Alcatraz and Tahoe rolls. I make a point of dining at this place every time I am in San Francisco. It is consistently good. My friends and I go at 6pm and wait outside in line for the restaurant to open. It gets really busy later in the evening. Love this place!
author: Elif B.

description:
This is a better than average Japanese eatery, offering an extensive menu even late at night. We weren't that hungry and only tried: $5 agedashi tofu was okay; $5 spicy chicken yakitori was good; $3.50 stinky natto=fermented soy beans is an acquired taste; $3.50 edamame; $7.50 jumping veggie roll was surprisingly good; $8.95 grilled saba plate was huge; $5.50 spicy scallop roll was good.

It is below ground and so definitely feels like a cozy bar. It gets an extra star for opening until 2AM (though you have to order food by 1:30 and alcohol by 1:45). Four stars, but the final star is for our cute and friendly waitress Joop. Will return, yea.
author: Peter L.

description:
All I can say is.... WHAT?! The servers are super nice and attentive, but I really didn't enjoy the food. Maybe I just came on a bad night? I came here one night with a friend and I was expecting delicious fresh sushi. I was wrong. 

We ordered Hot tuna, Dragon, and the crunchy crab (at least I think so). I've also ordered the volcano roll on a separate occasion, but the all the sushi I've had there was kind of just... BLAH. it was plain sushi, nothing special. 

This place is wayyyyyy to overpriced for quality of sushi they bring out. $7 for a plane spicy tuna roll that they renamed "hot tuna"..... SERIOUSLY?!

 people just come here because it opens late, which is a plus, but this place was overcrowded, it was difficult to find parking (but it's SF.. lol it's ALWAYS hard to find parking), and the food was borderline disgusting. Definitely wouldn't come back.

$15 for the volcano, $10 for the crunchy crab, $13 for the volcano roll? Overpriced & nasty?

No thank you
author: Sandra L.

description: Definitely a great place for nigiri lovers. The nigiri was mouth watering. It's a casual bar setting restaurant great for late night hang outs. Some of the fishes were out, but it's understandable since I didn't eat here until 10pm.
author: Sylvia C.

description: Beware. This place is not worth it !!!!!!!!!!!! Definitely not a 4 star place !!!!!!!!!   This place are over priced.  Portions size are tiny !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Place are super dark and super loud fast music !!!!!!!!!Not worth the trip !!!!!  Yelp you have failed me dearly !!!!!!!!
author: Jerry S.

description:
Best sushi I've ever had! 

We stumbled across Ryokos while in San Francisco this past week. We were having a drink at a bar a few blocks down and asked our server where her favorite place to eat after she got off was and she suggested Ryokos.

We were very impressed with the quality of the fish. Everything was delicious. We had to wait about 20 minutes but it was WELL worth it! 

Fried baby octopus appetizer - very good! 
Blue Fin Tuna Sushi - Best I've ever had!
Sweet Shrimp - Creamy, fresh and delicious. The fried heads were also the best we've ever had. 
Uni (Sea Urchin) - Absolutely amazing. We've only had uni one other time in Las Vegas. I can confidently say after this experience, I don't think I will ever have better. 
We also shared a roll that had spicy eel and egg inside. Different but also very good. 

Overall, amazing experience. We will definitely go to Ryokos every time we visit San Francisco.
author: Hannah C.

description:
Ryoko's is definitely a fun place for a bunch of friends who are looking for a place to have mediocre sushi and drinks after work. Though this place is good for groups, you'll have to wait forever to get a table that fits a group of 4 or more.

The sushi is definitely not fresh and the pairings of garnishes on the sushi is quite strange, i.e. mint, peanut butter, and mango-- these didn't really work well for my taste buds. The price is relatively decent-- not too high and not too low-- although, I wish the prices were lower for the quality of sushi provided.

After coming here 2 times and waiting over 30 minutes each time... I don't think I'll be back. I just don't think the food is worth the wait. The only reason I'd be back is if I were in the downtown area and really hankering for sushi (and didn't want to pay for quality sushi) and couldn't find a way to travel to another sushi place. All of this would definitely have to be in play before I go back to Ryoko's-- which means there's a slim-to-none chance I'll be back.
author: Julie H.

description:
I have been here a couple times and I can now finalize it is one of the BEST SUSHI restaurants in SF. 

Their sushi rolls are extremely satisfying. Each roll you put in your mouth bursts heaven and peace. We've tried many rolls and always go something different every time and it never disappoints. So stating a specific roll to try isn't necessary.

They have one of the most fresh sashimi and nigiri. They serve it fat and thick so it oozes in your mouth making you salivate for more.

Their prices are reasonable and their drinks come extremely cheap.

It's a great place to gather co workers or friends. 

Arrive early and you're sure to leave late with a stomach so re freshly full. You'll leave dreaming of this restaurant.
author: Ladonna A.

description: Amazing sushi. Well worth the wait. If you sit by the counter, ask one of the itamae to please you. You will not be disappointed.
author: David C.

description:
Very sarcastic, but pretty and cute servers. This is the place to go for some straight up authentic japanese sushi and sashimi. We gad a part of 10, and they were able to accommodate us, given the limited seating in the restaurant. 

Will be back! :)
author: One L.

description:
Just came back from dinner here and overall it was 3-star, A-OK sushi. It was a Wednesday night but still pretty crowded. My friend and I had to wait but the staff was visibly working hard to get everyone seated right away. We sat at the bar (which was fine) and our server gave us the choice of moving to a table when one opened up a few minutes later. They did mess up our dessert order and then kind of look at us like it was our fault...  but oh well.

Ordered the volcano roll with peanut butter for the novelty of it but it was surprisingly tasty. Probably the best thing we ordered.

I'd avoid the spicy tuna. It was thick and really mayo-y :(
author: Sheera G.

description:
Had the dragon and volcano sushi rolls, and toro kushi - 4/5 stars.
Also had the ryoko salad, beef oroshi, fried ice cream - 3/5
Whilst service was friendly waitress forgot our one of our beverages and the fried ice cream took ages to come out (~15mins). Also whilst collecting dishes waitress splashed soy sauce on my jeans - 2/5.
I've had better Japanese dining experiences but the sushi roll and toro kushi saved them this time.
author: Ed P.

description:
I've been here twice now, and the first time was with a big group and we were seated in a back room which was really cool!

The 2nd time I cam with just my husband and we sat at a small table somewhat close to other couples and small groups. Both times, the food was good. I wouldn't say its great although I was impressed with the Spicy Golden Gate roll which is spicy salmon roll with mint or basil and fish eggs. We also got the pot stickers and the tempura and a pitcher of beer. It was nice. Nothing tasted bad but their spicy tuna, I think has a mayo sauce and I HATE MAYO and spicy tuna is my favorite roll, so I now avoid it at this place. 

Great atmosphere and can get very busy and loud!
author: Brittini S.

description: RYOKO oh RYOKO i love it. I could eat this everyday if I could. Wait seems longer then it really is. Toro is a must if it's season. I forgot what night it was but it was the weekend and there was a DJ that came and played and played good music. Every roll we got did not disappoint. It's a must if you like sushi.
author: Roberto M.

description:
Huge fan of Ryoko's. It's yummy, affordable, and has an awesome fun vibe to the place. If you're coming with a party large than 2, I definitely recommend coming here way in advance to put your name down for a table since they don't take reservations. I came here with 5 girls on a Saturday night, and we came at 8:30 and our table was ready for us at about 9:30pm. (On average, the wait time is about an hour.) 

We ordered a bunch of stuff - hot sake/beer, chicken satay, sashimi, edamame, and about 5-6 rolls to split among all of us. Everything was fresh, and they brought stuff out pretty quickly. I especially love the spicy tuna roll and the philly roll. The sashimi was super yummy too (got the yellowtail), and we ordered so much beer/sake that we were sufficiently drunk by the end. After tip, tax, etc, the total was just about $35 a person, which is a steal in my opinion. Aything you order will probably be pretty good, so don't fret about that! Love this great go-to place :)
author: Priya G.

description:
I would give this place a solid 3.5 stars.  Food is about a 4+ - very good sushi, fresh tasting and creative at a really reasonable price. However, the crazy long wait definitely sours the overall experience of what seems like a pretty cool place w/a good vibe.  

Actually the wait would have been more tolerable had I had faith in the wait list.  However, there is no host/hostess per se, you have to put your own name down on the list and indicate whether you want bar or table, and unless you are waiting on the stairs listening very carefully for them to mispronounce your name when they remember to check the list, you are SOL! 45+ minutes for a party of 1 willing to sit anywhere just doesn't seem reasonable for a Monday night.
author: Miranda T.

description: Queue half an hour prior to opening? Must be good! The one and only in business for 30 years. No franchise no other. Everything so fresh. Service excellent. Ate and drank like queens for a little over a 100$. Elli was informative and friendly. Highly recommended.
author: Lisa B.

description:
I came here with some friends because we were craving something of moderate substance at 10PM.  We walked downstairs into a dimly lit, somewhat stuffy place (it was busy), but for some reason my brain wasn't saying "turn around and leave right now".

The ambiance is actually pretty cool here, their music selection is on point, and the furnishings give the spot a retro pub/lounge feel.  It's hard to describe the atmosphere without making it sound bad, but I guess I'm just into eclectic places.

The food wasn't amazing, but it was fairly priced for the serving and the quality, and the fact that it's authentic Japanese food that's open late is also a bonus.  Probably wouldn't be my first pick, but I definitely would not pass over it.
author: Hideki F.

description:
I really wanted to like this, but the service and seating was disappointment. Seating arrangement is tight and awkward. 

After a 40 min wait for a table for 2, we were finally seated.  Each of us ordered an appetizer, and my friend ordered Sashimi Dinner; while I opted for a spicy yellow tail roll.

Fast forward 30 minutes.  A plate of what we thought was his sashimi dinner arrived.  The platter was placed directly in front of him, and as famished as he was, he devoured his dish in 10 minutes. LOL My roll?  Oh it never came.  Finally, when I could no longer stand waiting because my eyes were crossing and I was about to faint, I asked the waiter where my order was.  He then realized the chef had combined our orders into one plate.  Really?  Why'd you do that and not say anything when you serve your customers?

Ok, mistakes happen.  But if you are running a sushi bar/Japanese restaurant, and there is kitchen snafu that keeps customer waiting 50 minutes, you apologize profusely (we did get one apology) and send wine or appetizer to keep them content. 

According to my friend, the food was good, but not worth the wait. I should have walked out.
author: Margaret W.

description: I'm a fan of Ryokos it's a quintessential sushi spot in SF if there were. It's crouched up on a hill and usually has a wait. The folks are good but the gyoza is delicious - so crunchy and soft. It can be a little slow which can get annoying. Overall, it's a good spot.
author: Priya S.

description:
Funky, late-night vibe sushi joint. The music thumps while four probably-not-Japanese twentysomethings man the bar -- very slowly. Slices of fish are respectably large and a large pour of sake will go a long way. We rolled into this place at around 11, 11:30pm and were seated like it was 9pm. And the place was damn full for the time.

So, definitely not a traditional sushi place, but has average food at decent prices with bonus points for extended hours. It's a solid 3 for me.
author: Josh K.

description: So good. I recommend getting the spicy rolls. Both Tuna and Salmon are really delicious. Just be ready for a long wait, about 45 minutes for a party of 2 on a Friday evening
author: Julius S.

description:
This is hands down my favorite sushi restaurant in the bay area!

The sushi is fantastic and very reasonably priced. (Try the checkerboard and volcano rolls... they're the best!). The staff is very friendly and quick once you have a table. If something is running slowly, they let you know and check on you (they dont just leave you sitting with no idea of whats happening). While they have traditional rolls, they also have very creative rolls (which I love). The volcano roll that I mentioned has both penut butter and jalapeño! 

On top of the great sushi and staff, the atmosphere is very fun and unique. It is kind of quirky, in a good way... but im not even sure how to describe it... you'll just have to see for yourself! 

The only downside... this place is so awesome, you should usually expect a wait. Unless you go very early, there are always people waiting on the stairs/outside. The good news is... the quick service helps to move people along and open tables up relatively quickly... so put your name on the clip board and go have a drink at Owl Tree... just remember to keep checking in because they wont call you.
author: Jess K.

description:
I like sushi... But not THAT much. I have to say, though that this place gets points for creativity. For example, the Volcano roll was FANTASTIC and is made with a smidge of peanut butter! Don't miss the jumping tuna roll or the veggie melody; both awesome.

Great portions as well. (read: a bit smaller than most) 

The only thing holding me back from 5 stars (it's not the food!) is the ambiance. A bit smaller and cozier than most sushi places -- but also a little more decrepit. This is a world-class sushi spot in a 3rd world setting. If loud and cussing (aka drunk) patrons and well-mixed hip-hop music doesn't bug you--head down NOW! Otherwise, expect excellent food in a sub-par atmosphere.

Also: the Otoro sashimi was amazingly fresh and tasty, don't miss out on it!
author: Chris B.

description: Great sushi. Like, seriously great. The hot food is awesome too, it's like being back in Tokyo. Including the prices, but it's SF so you gotta expect to be roughed up by the check.
author: James M.

description: After researching a ton of different places we settled on Ryokos. Long story short the research paid off! We had an awesome meal! We started off with the seared beef appetizer - perfectly cooked. She had the jumping Californian and I ordered the checkerboard, volcano and spicy golden gate. The golden gate was the cheapest but very good. I love spicy rolls and it had some good kick to it. The checkerboard also had great flavor and I recommend. I was excited to get the volcano based on previous reviews but was a little let down. For the price it's not very big but the peanut butter gave it a different feel and fun to try. You can't go wrong here.
author: David S.

description: Great sushi. But the Uni was over priced. Place gets really hot inside but there are fans. Loved the music.
author: Claudia B.

description: Very solid menu but more importantly this place wins on atmosphere. Great music, serves late night service. Fish is very good but definitely not the best in town; but if you want a fun place to hang out for the night while having a really good dinner.. This is your place.
author: David B.

description:
A sushi place that has pumping electronic music, great sushi and stays open till 2am? Yes such a place does exist and it is called Ryoko. 

The music is spot on....all of our group was super chatty because the beat just keeps you pumped up the whole time. Talk about mood music...

The food was very good. The sushi was fairly pricey, the rolls were more reasonably priced. 

Service is efficient and effective and they cheer you as you leave. Oh and there is a big bowl of random candy to help yourself to on the way out the door.

All in all a very fun dining experience. If you prefer something more quiet and stuffy choose somewhere else ;)
author: Paul H.

description:
3 stars for the food; an extra star for rad hours.

A group of us stopped in here after my brother's wedding reception, probably around 1 in the morning.  We ordered a wide range - tofu, tempura, edamame, nigiri, rolls, sake, etc.

I felt like most of the dishes were competent, but nothing blew me away.  The nigiri did include wasabi between the fish and the rice, which is a nice change of pace from the way most sushi places these days are skipping that step.  The fresh wasabi was also a nice change of pace from the paste that everyone else seems to be using.  

The rolls on the other hand were a bit lacking - good fish in them, but they were a bit loose (meaning that even looking at them on the plate, I knew that they wouldn't hold together).  Not sure if that's a product of getting in one of the last orders, or if that's the norm?

We were the last group in there, and they were putting up chairs and cleaning up as we were leaving a little after 2 AM.  Service was good in that they didn't say anything to us about us needing to get out of there, and still being friendly and saying bye as we left.
author: Ernie C.

description:
I love that this place is open late. I came here a few years ago but forgot. Now that I've come again....

It's pretty good.

=]  That's all I can say!
author: Susy C.

description: Long overdue review but came here on a busy night with a total group of 4 people. Small cramped and not good sushi. Idk if sf locals are used to this but I certainly wasnt. I expected the traffic and location and the cramped restaurant but not the average sushi. Ive had much better over in my area. Service was bad. No one paid attention to us. Got 2 rolls cant remember the names the one in the foil was slightly better but none of them satisfied me nor amazed me at all. Very disappointed.
author: Seneca K.

description: Be prepared to wait!  We were told a half hour but we ended up waiting about a full hour.  The sushi is very fresh and worth the wait.  And the tempura was very good... It's more along the lines of what you'd find in Japan, as opposed to the thick batter that some Japanese restaurants use.  The cool part is that they'll let you order drinks while you wait, even if you're sitting on the steps waiting!  Helps pass the time.
author: Debbie L.

description: Loved this place... Total hole in the wall- the BEST salmon!  We had a short wait and then we were seated at a small wooden table with wooden stools.  Definitely added to the experience.  I had the salmon rolls and they were amazing!  One difference with the edamame is that it is served cold.
author: Christina F.

description:
Need a late night place? Put Ryoko on the list!

This is, by far, my favorite casual Sushi restaurant. For higher end sushi, I prefer Akikos. 

We usually sit at the bar and do the Omakase. Bill comes out to be around $100/person. Not bad for great sushi.
author: winnie t.

description:
Be prepared for a wait! But I must admit, after all was eaten and drunk, no regrets!

I was not too impressed with their rolls - they were nothing special and not great. We got the Big Mama, Hot Tuna, and Spicy Golden Gate. To be honest, the best was the hot tuna and that was just ok too.

What stood out and what we probably should've just ordered in the first place was the nigiri. I'm becoming somewhat of a sushi snob, and tend to only go for nigiri at sushi restaurants now. Ryoko's offers fresh fish and a refreshing selection of sashimi to choose from. My favorite is the ika (squid). But we also ordered the white tuna, salmon, and tobiko nigiri. The salmon nigiri was the best I've had in a while. The salmon was so fresh and tender.

My date got the asahi and I got the sapporo - both on draft and both $4.50.

Service was good and although the wait was a little over 30 minutes, I definitely intend on coming back!
author: Junel S.

description: Great atmosphere, good prices, super busy, strong drinks, my only complaint is it took awhile to get the rolls after ordering. But once the rolls did get there they were delicious. best sushi i have ever had, and a free order of edumame. The Pokemon roll was absolutely killer, and so was the jumping unagi. I will go back next time i am in town.  :-)
author: Eric G.

description: This was the best sushi I've ever had. Ever. And sushi is my favorite cuisine. I ordered the eel and avocado roll, hamachi and scallions, and tuna, avocado, and tobiko, each with 5 pieces, and they were absolutely perfect. I also tried hamachi toro nigiri for the first time at the encouragement of my server, which was the belly of the yellowtail (it was divine, and melted in my mouth). I came right at opening time, 6pm, on a Friday night, and there was already a very long line waiting to be seated; it was clear the place was a local favorite. I sat at the bar, and both the chefs and servers were incredibly nice, checking on me to make sure everything was to my liking. I am so sad that I'm only visiting for a few days, but the next time I'm in SF, I am absolutely making a trip back to Ryoko's.
author: Devan H.

description: Besides the snobby waitress, everything was off the hook at this place. We stumbled in...ordered sushi rolls and drank it down with some hot sake. The quality of the sushi was grade A in my books. My fave was the unagi and fatty tuna. The plus part was the fact that they were open past 2am and had a DJ turning it up. Good times!
author: Leah C.

description: Having been to Japan, it's hard to find good sushi in the US. However Ryoko's is the closest I've come so far. I highly recommend the Nigiri combo, as it comes with the best California roll ever conceived and a great assortment of fish. I had to knock a star off because of the price though. Nine pieces of Nigiri and a CA roll for $40 is a bit nuts, even if it is the best sushi this side of the Pacific.
author: Brett D.

description:
No uni? Really?! That's an automatic one star deduction right there. After many laborious hours of cafe-ing, Jason C. and I were ready for some late night sushi. When our waiter informed us they were out of uni for the night, our hearts shattered into a million pieces. My mouth had been dying to fornicate with soft, sweet sea urchin, and the unfortunate news kicked my tastebuds into blueballs-mode. The restaurant had run out of many other items on their menu as well; whatever Jason wanted to order, they did not have. What a tease! Ryoko's can have their fourth star when they clean up their act and keep ingredients in stock.

Here's the breakdown of what actually did end up on our table:

Edamame - One of the beans popped out of a pod I was holding and hit the sandal-adorned foot of the woman at the table next to us. Drunk bish didn't even flinch.

Chicken Kara-age - Crispy on the outside, hot and juicy on the inside. Perfection!

Ankimo - My first time trying this - crumbly-soft and delicious

Toro - Normally my favorite but the slices lacked freshness

Sake - Standard, but again, could have been fresher

Ikura - Had a strange soapy flavor

Isaki - Yum!

Pokemon Roll - Strange combo of mango and salmon wrapped in a mystery yellow skin that tasted surprisingly edible and refreshing

Scallop Roll - Why did they have to ruin a perfectly good roll it by tucking in mint leaves?

Fried Ice Cream - Shell could have been crispier, but novel and a yummy way to end the meal

You won't find the best sushi in San Francisco here, but the menu is huge with plenty of creative concoctions. The ambience is energetic with loud upbeat music playing in the stuffy dungeon-like space. Heck, it's like a rave up in here; why isn't there an MDMA roll on the menu? 

This is where I'll be getting my grub on when I'm craving sushi at 1 AM. Wow, only one sexual reference in this review. I think I'm going to go take my temperature now.
author: Suany W.

description: Good food. But not the best value. A bit pricy. But it is Union squire I guess. For the location, not bad. Long line and many Japanese fish selection!
author: April W.

description: Fantastic late night sushi joint. Sushi was good if not exceptional, was more impressed by a great playlist of golden age hip-hop. Prices reasonable by SF standards, but drinks were on the pricey side.
author: C. eric D.

description:
We had waited on the stairs for 30 minutes because we arrived at Ryoko's on friday evening at 8.30 and it was full. The restaurant is not so big so I think is normal to see a queue on the stairs full of people waiting to eat in this wonderful japanese!
Quality of food is great, the kindness of the customers even greater. The presentation of the meals was absolutely amazing. And there's also a DJ that mix music in the middle of the restaurant. So maybe I should say is more for young people rather than families or middle aged people. But definitely if you want a good japanese, you really have to go to Ryoko's.
author: Alex F.

description: Some of the best sushi I ever had. The staff is friendly. It's not a quiet place but it is enjoyable.
author: Amber C.

description: Delicious! Volcano roll was AMAZING! We will come again! Out of all the sushi we have had in SF, this is the top of the list! We came at opening on a Tues night. So happy because the whole place filled fast. Service was fast and efficient.
author: Mousey T.

description: My favorite place to go out to eat. The sushi is delicious and the green tea is AMAZING- just the tea totally justifies a trip here. Plus, open late... Perfect!
author: Shay T.

description:
I am not a sushi fan, and sashimi?  Forget it.  So when my husband wanted Japanese, I silently groaned and found a spot for us.  I figured, well there's always teriyaki and tempura.

On glancing at the menu, I panicked because I was only seeing sushi and sashimi dinners, but then I noticed the starters and ordered gyoza and tempura.  Both were quite good.  However, in my haste to find a roll I would eat, there it was...THE JUMPING CALIFORNIA ROLL, crab and avocado DEEP FRIED.  Who knew anyone had ever thought of deep frying a roll besides the folks at the state fair?  Not only did I eat it, I LIKED it.  And for good measure, I tried a bite from my husband's unagi plate.  While he raved about it, I was good with just one bite.  Less than one would have been better.

So Ryoko's gets a solid four stars from me for showing me I can eat sushi after all.
author: Heather C.

description:
Two words: fly infestation.

The manager acknowledged a fruit fly infestation in one of the private rooms and took the drinks off our sushi dinner, but there were flies ALL OVER our meal. She didn't seem surprised that we complained about the infestation. Our party of 8 is very disappointed with cleanliness of this restaurant.

The meal itself was average: lukewarm takoyaki, slightly over-cooked oroshi, small chirashi. Rolls are mostly deep fried; nothing that innovative. Tea was tepid.

Wouldn't come back again for the food, definitely wouldn't come back because of the flies.
author: Vicky G.

description: Without a doubt the worst sushi I've ever choked down. We were seated, then moved by our sever to accommodate a bigger group. It was all downhill from there. The middle room we were moved to smelled like sewage and we were essentially forgotten about. After about 20 minutes, the sever finally stopped walking by us long enough to take our order. We ordered two rolls. They were served about 20 minutes apart and both were terrible. The group beside us had a similar experience. I guess this place survives on some sort of hipster dive bar ambiance, because the food and service were bottom of the barrel.
author: Tom F.

description: This place is great. We were going to order three different rolls but when the waitress told us about the chef  special we changed our minds. It was worth it. Can't even tell you the name of it because I forgot. Starts with an S. Staff was extremely nice, fast and helpful. If you don't like this place, you must smell like pee.
author: Jorge M.

description:
Small place, small water glasses, great sushi.

While I could stop there, that would be doing Ryoko's an injustice. A colleague and I waited about 30 minutes just to grab a seat on a Wednesday evening around 8:30 pm. If that doesn't speak for the quality of the food, I'm not sure what does. 

Regardless, after signing in at the paper reservation sheet and waiting around, we sat at the sushi bar and snagged a few rolls to accompany our gratis (small) bowl of edamame...here's what we enjoyed:

Checkerboard: 4/5: Crab and avocado with tuna topped with yellowtail. The fish was quite fresh, the rolls were generous but not too large and the flavor was great. 

Pokemon: 4/5: Salmon, mango, avocado, lettuce and wrapped in soy paper. While salmon isn't my favoritest fish, the mango and avocado worked really well and I fully enjoyed this roll. Nom. 

Tiger: 3/5: Shrimp tempura, cucumber and mayonnaise. Meh. It was fine. It was more like a kitty than a tiger...next time I would ask them to add some spice! 

Overall, the rolls were fresh, service attentive and prices affordable. I can see why this place was hoppin' on a Wednesday night!
author: Nicole W.

description: Over priced for mediocre food. I like to come here on Friday and Saturday night for drinking and having small bites. Fresh fish but nothing special about their rolls.
author: Atinut K.

description: Really was not happy with this place. The waitress was rude and when we asked for spicy mayo, she told us they ran out. A minute later, my cousin asked another employee and she immediately gave us spicy mayo. Why did she lie to us?? Also, the edamame was cold and tasteless. The worst edamame I've ever had. The sushi wasn't good either. Overall I was not satisfied with this place and won't come back again.
author: Hasti J.

description:
I stopped here for dinner while in town for work. We were staying in Union Square, and we had attempted to visit Tsunami Sushi, but we ended up walking through a less than savory part of town, so we headed back to our hotel. Upon doing so, we stumbled across Ryoko's. 

We arrived around 5:30, so we were earlier than the dinner rush on a Tuesday night. We were seated immediately. We started with the deep-friend tofu, which was delicious; tempura; and edamame. The edamame was cold, which I don't think I have had before. 

For sushi, I ordered two vegetarian rolls - the Futomaki and the Humboldt. Both were delicious. My colleagues ordered a couple of rolls, and from what I can remember, one got a Pokemon roll and the other a roll with peanut butter in it. They both enjoyed theirs, as well.  

The service was attentive. The restaurant has plentiful seating; though, there was a line at 7 when we left. All in all, I'd be back. It has a good atmosphere and delicious sushi.
author: Ashley V.

description: Great spot. Love coming here! There's always a wait list but definitely worth it. Food is good..fish/seafood always tastes so fresh. Would recommend the fried cheese...soooo good!! The restaurant and servers are always busy but very quick and never rude. If you have a bigger party, I recommend requesting for the back room. It is a comfortable spot and not as loud as the main seating area. Overall good food and good vibes
author: Briana M.

description:
Food is delicious, the fatty tuna is a must try!! 
Great service, ambience, food, the only negative is the close proximity of the tables, but not a big enough reason to give them less stars.
author: Ellie O.

description: I don't live in San francisco but over the years I always stop in to Ryoko a couple times while in the city.
