Before coming on this trip I was suprised to see a flurry of bad reviews, I'm even more suprised after going there last night.  The music wasn't load, the service was super friendly and efficient, and the food was great.  I have been to a lot of sushi restraunts that try to swish up the interior, this is not what you will find at Ryoko, the interior space is not glamorous in any way, in fact bits of it feel like the basement of a college frat house, but this is not what I base my reviews on.  If your going out for an aniversary in a suit and dress, and want a piano man, and an intimate quit setting, don't expect it here, come here for good quality sushi that will not cost you a fortune, with friendly service.
author: Zachary S.

description:
Can't believe this place is like four blocks from my house and in the Loinnn. It's a below-ground restaurant dishing out solid sushi. I've had the nigiri combo twice and it's always been a fresh mix of nine nigiri pieces and a California roll. Big Mama roll was also tasty, though shiso was a little strong.

Somehow I've always gotten seated under the stairs, Harry Potter style, but it's a cozy nook with just enough lighting, so it has worked out. 

Always seems like there will be a wait, but the line moves quickly. 

And they do pitchers of Japaneezy beers!
author: Kevin L.

description:
Saturday night out
  Searching for a sushi place
  Short wait for a seat

  Sapporo on tap
  What? DJ in the corner
  Inari was good

  I might come back more
  Fun night out with a scene
  My haiku review
author: Monica R.

description: This place was awesome. Good service, EXCELLENT food, cool underground location. The Hamachi Toro was the best sushi I have ever had anywhere.
author: Drew B.

description:
Yummm, on a random thursday night, the bf and I decided to make a trip to SF for some sushi. Thinking that it was a Thursday night, we were hoping that there wouldn't be much of a wait.... we were wrong. 

Luckily, the wait wasn't as bad as it could be - about thirty minutes? It helped that lots of people on the list before us left, ahha. Anyways, it was good time to observe the restaurant @ work. It's a really small UNDERGROUND shop - so no reception for you here.... 

The sushi was actually really yummy. We ordered a basic california roll, the sexy roll, the volcano roll, and i think the jumping tuna roll, along with some fatty white toro. 
Out of all the rolls, our favorite was definitely the sexy roll - yummm.. crab, avocado, baked salmon and cheese on top. One of the rolls, I think it was the volcano roll, was SUPER SPICY .. but it might have been our low spice-tolerance. It comes with its own dipping sauce, which was interesting and pretty good.

Service was spotty, hard to get someone's attention because they are extremely busy. But when we did manage to talk to someone, he/she was usually polite.

For the price (reasonable) and quality, I could definitely see myself returning to Ryoko's!
author: Ashley N.

description: Slow service when crowded (took forever to get my sushi), and sushi is good quality but on the smaller side.
author: Andrew S.

description: I chose to eat here based upon the Yelp reviews; however, I was less than impressed with their sushi.  Overall it was average at best. The fish was fresh although the temperature of the fish was fairly warm.  Portions were small, restaurant was not as clean as I like when eating sushi!
author: Timothy M.

description: It was solid food. Long wait but worth it- the service was very friendly. I really liked the rolls but it wasn't earth shattering- just solid. The amberjack sashimi and the Tobiko were the faves of the night. Good but would probably try another spot just bc there is so much good sushi in SF.
author: Amanda L.

description:
After a barely ok "quick" meal at Sanraku...we walked down the block to Ryoko, where we should have gone to from the start.

Walking down a flight of stairs, you are in a dim joint with the sushi bar right in front of you and some tables to the side.  There's no doubt this joint was once a bar - it feels like a bar, looks like a bar...no wonder we feel so comfortable and fit right in!   There is a list where you put down your name...when the hostess came to us, she asked if we want the sushi bar, sure!  

We were seated at the last 2 seats at the bar, not quite in front of the sushi chefs but right in front of the bartender!  Our waitress was friendly and attentive (most are Thai?) - the menu is quite extensive, as well as the special menu board.  Everything sounded good and surprisingly reasonably priced.  The chefs are Japanese and very nice/attentive - all good signs!

We had small hot sake that got refilled regularly.  We had the oysters, they were so good - we had repeats of that too!  Since they don't have a computer print out of what we ordered, I don't recall - we ordered mostly from the special menu - there were fish from Japan, toro...every single one was super delicious - so flavorful and melts in the mouth.  

A DJ starts around 8pm, good spins with pops mixed with some 80's and such - the place is hopping.  If our tummies didn't give up, we would have stayed and partied on!

LOVE this place!
author: Gloria H.

description: Great spot . Read some reviews on yelp and based on that we decided to try it out. We waited about 20 to 30 mins to be seated , not bad at all. They had music playing, the vibe was good. We loved it!! The place it self on point. The service was great busy but still came and check on us. The sushi was delicious. Definitely a place I will come back to.
author: Yuridia A.

description: I was really looking forward to trying Ryoko but honestly, the experience was a complete letdown. Maybe we were there on a off night but everything we ordered seemed unnecessarily "fishy". Those of you who love sushi as much as I do will know that raw fish isn't worth eating if it's not the freshest...we ordered a grilled squid appetizer that tasted like it hadn't seen the ocean in a few months/years. The our rolls were also a bit on the meh side. And they fell part apart when I tried to pick team up with my chopsticks. New sushi chefs in the kitchen? Oe last comment, we got a table right away (yay!) but the service from then on out was horrendous. It took us at least 45 minutes to get our two rolls. Yes, really.
author: Erin W.

description:
I had a great experience here last night! Finding street parking was a bit difficult, but there's a parking place near the sushi place, like in this alleyway, that you just have to pay for if you don't mind paying. Didn't see how much though. Anyways once we got in we put our name on the wait list. The guy behind that podium, I guess security? was pretty funny and cool.
Eventually we got seated after 35 min, which isn't too bad of a wait. The tables are all pretty close together, but it's manageable. And once I tried to sushi I decided it was completely worth it! We got the Sexy and Jumping California rolls. AMAZING!!!! Ridiculously fresh for being so late on a Friday night (like around 10ish). The Sexy roll came with a yummy dipping sauce I don't know what it was but it was sweet and tangy in my opinion and definitely PERFECT for the roll! The Jumping California has cheese, which I've never tried in a sushi roll but it was BOMB! I like cheese just as much as the next person and I still thought it was really good, just that my obsession lies with the Sexy roll :) 
Definitely coming back next time I'm in the city and craving sushi :) 
Oh! Also, there's a live DJ on old school turntables playing a pretty sick hip hop mix on top of a piano. My favorite parts of this place were def the sushi, the DJ and the pricing wasn't too bad either. When we got the bill in my head I was like that's it?? I expected more lol. Makes up for the parking struggles and bumps my rating up to a full 5 stars!
author: Kusi P.

description: Good food. Had the Chirashi. We showed up at 6:30pm and had to wait about an hour to eat. Be sure to sign the list at the bottom of the stairs because there is no hostess. Always felt rushed by the waitress.
author: Zach B.

description:
Did I give this place four stars? No, I meant to give it one. That's right, don't go! Back off! There are too many people waiting on the steps for a table as it is!

Seriously, these guys are great. The sushi chefs are very friendly and, importantly, thoroughly Japanese. The selection is not stunning, but everything is of very high quality. I often finish a meal with ikanatto (I won't tell you what it is, because it may gross you out.) It was topped with the most perfect, orange raw egg yolk I ever did see.

Last visit, I went with a group of eight, and they put us in one of the private rooms in back. Loved that room! It made me feel like a rock star.
author: Cory K.

description: Doesn't worth the time and money. The quality is ok, the variety is low, and the service isn't that good. The only positive thing about this place is you can get late night sushi! In general I don't recommend this place.
author: Sara K.

description: This is the first time we've been here and we definitely will come back the next time we're in SF. The food is decent price and AMAZING. The toro was soooooo good. Some cute looking chefs too. ;) we tried the Spicy Golden Gate roll, Agedashi tofu, Negitoro, salmon toro and shiromi roll. All were super awesome.
author: Giang P.

description:
I was expecting a quiet little sushi joint, but when I walked in just before midnight on Saturday, the music was bumping and the house was packed! 

While we waited to be seated, the server took everyone's drink order. I opted for a shochu cocktail ($4.50). Our sushi and sashimi platter ($30.95) was fresh and tasty. Sashimi is generally a good indicator of a Japanese restaurant's quality because the freshness is a dead giveaway. So given that it was after midnight in a packed house, I was impressed that the sushi was as it good as it was. The crowd was lively - lots of large parties. Not great for a date but it's the perfect place to end a night of bar hopping since they stay open til 2am.

While I went to the restroom, I came back to find a makeshift mochi ball birthday cake with a candle, marachino cherry and whipped cream! How awesome is that?
author: Mariela D.

description: The sashimi dinner here was outstanding. YUM. When you go out to eat here, it also feels like you are in Club Sushi--meaning that you should be prepared for loud techno music to be played while you're noshing on your sashimi. Cool if you're in the mood, otherwise--maybe during the weekdays they use that nice piano that's in the dining room?
author: Mel G.

description:
I was so happy to find this on a whim. Two guys, 1 girl, 3 hungry bellies. After shopping around Union Square, my buddies and I came across this place. 

On the menu, $12 pitcher of beer ( we got Sapporo) $10 for a large hot sake, $12 for Nigori. We only planned to stay for drinks but the sashimi looked so good we each ordered something. I had teka maki. The tuna was fresh. Even though it wasn't happy hour, I thought the alcohol is pretty cheap! Well priced and pretty damn good! I'm definitely coming back here!
author: Angeline H.

description: Great sushi for the price.  Fun atmosphere and open super late.  If you're looking for a romantic sushi date spot, skip this.  Come here to eat great sushi with your friends and listen to some good music.  DJ spinning on the piano on the weekends. Awesome.
author: Dakota K.

description:
(See pics)

Ryoko's continues to be my #1 sashimi with its most fun, underground atmosphere.

Every time I come here, I got excited with its imported fish, the excellent and solid skills of Atsushi and his super friendliness. I got mesmerized just by seeing his filleting and slicing that is precise, clean and perfectly without anything left on the blade.

I don't recall how many pictures I have taken of the fish but there's in no way to describe the taste, the texture and the tenderness of the fish.

I totally love the underground semi-club style music, a piano station, a TV that shows games.

Always sit at the bar for the real action, to see each and every kind of the fish of the evening.

You don't have to be hungry to eat. Craving is what you desire when you are not hungry. Your yearning is what makes this place great because you can have everything in sashimi style.

This evening they put all the sashimi on top of a huge bowl of ice underneath. Sashimi is best at its slightly chilled level. Kinmedai (golden eye snapper), Aji (striped jack), toro, mirugai (my absolute favorite crunchy geoduck since I was a kid.)

The uni and amaebi (sushi style) were perfect to come afterwards.

I even had 2 orders of cold sake. Note they have some on the menu but a few more on their books that they serve.

Totally rocking me 5 stars best ever.
author: T L.

description:
Hands down, one of the best sushi places I've been to in San Francisco! The food and the vibe here is wonderful! If you go at the right time, they actually have a dj playing music in the middle of the restaurant. He plays the bombest and trendiest music. (Love him!) It does get too loud to the point where you can't hear yourself talk.

Although this place does get packed easily, it's best if you call to make reservations.

None of the sushi options have disappointed me (yet).

The grilled squid is my favorite here. They grill it just perfectly. It's not too dry where it gets to hard to chew. It's perfectly chewy! The taste is best when drizzled with some lemon, dash some chili powder on top, and dipped with kewpie (basically mayonnaise).

You have to try their Beef Oroshi (mouth-gasm indeed!). When I first tried this, it was the only dish I wanted more of! Me and I friends actually ordered one more of this dish!
author: Annie H.

description:
pretty nice atmosphere...if you're claustrophobic, then then isn't the place for you.  the restaurant is located downstairs and it's super dark.  we sat at a table on stools...pretty uncomfortable cause the place was super tight already and the table was super low to the ground.  i felt like i had to bow everytime i grabbed a piece of sushi. 

the fish was fresh...they have a board out front with their specials of the day...but overall, i thought the sushi was a little too foofie for me.  i like my sushi traditional with an occasional roll here and there.  but i can see how this place works for the neo-sushi generation crowd.  

the prices were pretty inflated...the music is super loud so you can barely hear the person sitting across from you.  service is slow...and the bathroom light decided to blow right as i was popping a squat.  wonderful.

overall, it was an ok experience for me...the highlight was the freshness of the fish.  other than that, i'll pass and probably won't be coming back here again.
author: Jen W.

description: This place was well worth the wait. Packed late night but service was quick and the food was incredible. Love the unique atmosphere!
author: Christiana H.

description:
Best sushi bar in the city in my opinion.  Great atmosphere, friendly and knowledgeable staff and skilled chefs.  I have never had a bad experience here.  Wait time can be daunting at peak hours, but the experience can be enjoyed with a drink from the bar on the stairs meeting new friends.

Sushi selections here are fairly wide ranging from the typical kitschy roll combos like the volcano roll with peanut butter to the more traditional fare of nigiri and sashimi offerings which are all fresh and flavorful.  I recommend the omakase offerings to allow your chef's choice which I have never been disappointed with. 

You gotta love a sushi place in the heart of San Francisco in a basement, on the outskirts of the Tenderloin with a DJ playing music.  Classic.
author: Mark D.

description:
Dis ... dis ... disappointed!  I went here because of the four stars on Yelp and because it's a block away from the JW Marriot I'm in at the moment.  How could I miss?  Easily!  Considering the location on the north edge of the tenderloin, the prices seem a little high.  The music is way too loud, and between the manager and the waitress relentlessly asking if I wanted to order anything else and refilling my glass from my Asahi bottle, it really seemed rushed and as if it was all about turning the table.  The food?  The nigiri was good and decent size but the roll was pretty small.  I ended up ordering chicken teriyaki after all that because I was still hungry.  The cut up fish behind the glass waiting to become somebody's dinner looked like it had been there long enough to have already have made a first try at being somebody's lunch.

Just like Captain Picard in "Chain of Command" ... "THERE ARE THREE LIGHTS" ... the fixtures over the sushi bar made it feel like an interrogation was about to commence.  Way, WAY too bright at the bar--as in blinding.  Damn those Cardassians!  I wasn't there for an interrogation.  All-in-all, I left with a headache.  Maybe it was that they all felt compelled to yell "Irrasshaimase" every thirty seconds during my visit ... seriously.  Enough already!  Not at all relaxing.  Won't be back. 

Live long and prosper.
author: John K.

description: Excellent service, nice atmosphere and great food. We ordered a bunch of sashimi, some apps and a ton of rolls. The volcano roll with peanut butter was particularly tasty. Highly recommended!
author: Mike H.

description: Oh my gosh!! You have to wait awhile to get in (for us at the RUSH about 1.5 hrs) but it is well worth it! Yummy! Order the salmon and the miso soup--best I've ever had. The mocha ice cream is something we will always order here as well. Excellent prices and service. A first rate experience. Thank you!
author: Amber H.

description: Hour wait, food was great and so was the DJ. Great service . Order drinks while you wait
author: Jadda S.

description:
Very unique sushi... most of their dishes had a touch of a mint-like herb that brought all the flavors together. Added a nice kick to the golden gate roll... pleasant flavor resonates on your tongue for many minutes after swallowing. I couldn't quite put my finger on what the herb was. I was tempted to ask the sushi chefs, but felt a bit too inhibited and refrained. 

All of the sashimi was incredibly fresh. My favorite was the hotate-- melted in my mouth like butter. The pan-seared fish (not sure what kind) was very unique as well. Never had any fish with so many delicious, stringy muscle fibers visibly stretching from meat flake-to-meat flake. The garlic mash flavored with bright orange-red shrimp innards was deliciously umami.

The grilled squid was okay.. A tad overcooked, but not bad.

Overall: Fun, intimate vibe, fresh and delicious seafood... would definitely come back.
author: Colleen W.

description:
I don't think this place is worth the hype. It did not meet my expectations, it was just ok. 

We (as a party of 3) got:
1) Tofu salad: the sesame dressing was delicious. For $5.95 though, I should just make my own tofu salad at home. 
2) Salmon sashimi: 2 pieces for $6?! It was fresh though at least. 
3) Unagi nigiri sushi: 2 pieces for $7.50. It was good, but not $7.50 for 2 pieces good. 
4) Jumping tuna roll: the tuna was not spicy at all and didn't taste very fresh. 
5) Volcano roll: has peanut butter in it, which is surprisingly not bad and pretty creative. It's just 5-6 pieces though (as is the case with most if not all of their other rolls).
6) Orange delight roll: salmon on top was fresh, but 6 pieces for $13? Yikes. 

They have a DJ every Thursday, Friday, and Saturday night from 8 PM to 2 AM. We went on a Sat night 1/25 and whoever was DJ'ing that night was good. The music is loud so this is not the restaurant to have a quiet romantic dinner at. 

All in all, it was ok. I feel like I can get more quality and quantity from another sushi joint elsewhere for the same price.
author: Maki K.

description:
When it's not our first choice, this place is our backup when other nearby restaurants have too long of a wait or are closed for the night. The menu has variety, including the roll with peanut butter, but not enough personal favorites for me to do something like plan an evening around having a meal here. Either way, set a bowl of edamame in front of me and I'm pretty much set. Only last time I went they'd just run out. Behind the sushi counter is a cool specials menu that I can never read clearly from our table.

There's a unique ambience going on. It's a Japanese restaurant adorned with small posters of old-time blues and jazz musicians. Walls are rich, Rococo blue with gold trims. There's a woodblock style hanging Japanese triptych. A collage of famous people is next to a grand piano which (talented) patrons are welcome to play. During our October visits, skulls and candy were atop the piano, and our most recent visit saw a compu-DJ doing his thing with his equipment laid out on the piano.

Service is friendly, even when I accidentally blow out the candles (somehow, this is something I do at restaurants). Perhaps they're friendly enough to carry a wheelchaired person down the relatively steep entrance steps.
author: Dan B.

description: First off... I'm confused about the great ratings for this place. 2 stars for the good drinks and 2am closing time. Fish wasn't that good and I would not return again based on the food alone.
author: Tracy M.

description:
How does this place get such praise!? Oh wait,  I know, they stay open til 2am serving sushi.  So we walked over from the telly and had to come down some stairs, man I felt like I was in a basement.  So a minor wait no big deal, instead of these loud way to old to be this loud group of vanillas talkin about Obama and some other topics that made people at the sushi bar cringe LOL.  So service is spotty. When you ask for a little time, they give you waaaaay too much time to figure it out. 

   Ordered some semi weak cocktails. Started with the seared beef , that was pretty good actually. Scaled the menu some more and nothing really jumped out at me.  I kept it simple and ordered my usual various nigiri and a sushi roll that I don't remember lol. The sushi sushi was fresh and tasted fine but this place didn't blow my mind. 


  Again I only came here since it was our first night in San fran on a weekday and I was tooo tired to walk. LOL
author: Alexis B.

description:
I was in SF for work recently and was looking for a fun sushi place to dine solo. The guy at the hotel sent me here and I'm glad he did! I had no trouble getting a seat at the bar but I must have come at a good time cause right after that place got PACKED! The bar was lively and I was entertained watching them make everyones meals. 

The sushi was FRESH and the rolls were solid. Amongst other things, I ordered the Uni and it was probably the tastiest I've ever had. 

BIG UPS to Ryoko!
author: Eve B.

description:
1) they handed me the check as soon as I finished eating my food , even though I still had my alcohol beverage.

2) once they handed me the check , each waiter that passes by asked me if I'm ready with the check,

eventually I just paid it and went away.
sushi is pricey IMO , you pay a lot and get 5 pieces roles , in addition  , it wasn't that good... I've experienced better for sure.

2 stars instead of one because of the on the house Edamame
author: Rotem S.

description: My girlfriend and I showed up to San Francisco late on Thursday night from L.A. and by the time we checked into our hotel and got ready it was 11 p.m. and almost every restaurant near union square was closing and every bar we'd show up to had already stopped serving food but lucky for us we saw this place already after midnight and while it was pretty happening after a 15 minute wait we were seated and went on to have a great dinner and an over all great time. It's busy, it's loud, and crowded but it was fun. Good to know next time we're looking for a late dinner we can count on this place to come through. Adding to my original review returning to this place a couple years later and it's still a great spot.
author: Adolfo V.

description: Obviously we went to Royoko's because of the already amazing reviews. And obviously we weren't disappointed. I as a vegetarian started with the Fried Cheese ($5) and then had the something something fried Asparagus roll and the Jumping Veggie Roll. Absolutely delicious!
author: Martin K.

description:
This time I tried non-sushi options. My boyfriend and I really loved the gyozas the first time we tried Ryoko's so this time we ordered 3 orders of gyoza. It was wonderful! 

We also tried:

Tofu salad
It was okay. It was very small, but the sesame vinaigrette dressing was pretty good. I would skip this.

Chicken karaage (Japanese fried chicken) - $8.50
The chicken was soooo soft! It's probably the best fried chicken I've ever had (and I don't really like fried chicken..) It was pretty delicious with a lemon wedge.

Chicken yakitori (chicken skewers) - $5
This was okay. It tasted pretty much like chicken teriyaki. Each order comes with 2 small skewers of chicken and scallions.

Tip: try the gyoza!!!!!!! : D
author: Monica T.

description:
A very busy and cool sushi restaurant. They've got a piano inside but the DJ is bumping his music on top of it. It was very crowded on a Saturday night. The seating is a bit cramped but it's not so bad. The service is pretty attentive. I ordered a good amount of food this evening. 

The food here is very good. The fried cheese wrapped in a wonton was great stuff. The uni was nice and creamy. The salmon melted in my mouth. The gyoza was lightly fried just right. I had a bunch of other dishes that aren't popping up in my head because of all the sake I drank. I really had a great time here. Fun place to eat and drink.

Recommendation: If you want sushi and to drink in a fun atmosphere then give it  a try!
author: Andy N.

description:
Thanks to yelp for pointing us in the right direction for late-night sushi!  It was a bit more of a walk than I'd anticipated & a little bit sketchy but we had a group of six of us walking together so we were fine.  We got there right around 1AM, they seated us right away, service was fast & attentive, they brought us complimentary edamame and everyone was happy with their various rolls & nigiri & tea & sake & miso soup.  Of note - the background music was good (mostly funk) - when going out with a bunch of musicians, that can be hit or miss proposition - happily, they hit it that night.  Will definitely keep this place in mind for future late-night sushi adventures in SF!

FYI - they automatically added gratuity (I'm guessing because we had a party of six?) which is fine but I hadn't seen it written anywhere
author: Zinnia S.

description:
A basement Japanese restaurant in Nob Hill with a good number of Izakaya style small dishes for around $4-10 per dish.  Many of the dishes, like shirasu oroshi and shishamo, are items that do not really require much of a skill.  I did not find their decor to be that interesting, but it rather created an unappetizing atmosphere.  I saw an employee enter the restaurant carrying a large fish in his hand and dropping it on their filthy floor --- perhaps they should use the back door to move the ingredients.        

FOOD:  Their homemade square gyoza was not as good as I expected it to be.  I don't think they should get so much credit for folding dumplings into a square...is that so innovative?  I liked their Kaki-Fry (Fried Oysters) which was nice and crispy.  Their Chirashi looked impressive, but overall, it was amateurish.  It didn't even come with slices of maguro (tuna), but rather just shaved chunks of tuna which is leftover pieces often used for spicy tuna rolls.  I even bit into something hard, which turned out to be a piece of scale.
author: トモ T.

description: Fresh tasty sushi, creative combos of ingredients, fair prices and decent services. Except for the 10-15min wait, we enjoyed our dining experience here. Worth the wait!
author: Sorrel G.

description:
Pretty good sushi, kind of fun atmosphere, decent service.  Nothing spectacular though, and they can be kind of skimpy on the fish, considering the prices here.

Still, I like the subterranean vibe and will probably come back again.  The fish was very fresh.
author: Mara S.

description:
oh my, one of the best sashimi in town. it's so fresh it literally melts in your mouth..
 We ordered the 12 piece sashimi. Not too large of a plate for $30.00 a bit steep for sashimi, however it is GRADE A! The rice is so perfect..

We also had the fried okra, that was delicious. We had the A's roll, which had asparagus and salmon, it was good. 

Pro: Fresh fish, talent chefs hip atmosphere, very professional and nice staff. sit by the bar to watch all the action!!

Con: a bit steep for prices, 

tip: its a bit crowded (if you come by 8 pm, you will probably get at least 15 people waiting in line by the steps watching you eat). Parking is a  HUGE pain in the butt. there is an expensive lot next door.  The atmosphere is more like a midnight i'm starving lets go eat sushi type of atmosphere. Semi-hole in the wall, really dark and dimm. could use an update. If i feel like a sushi spluge ~$30 a person, would come back here just for the grade A sashimi
author: Juan C.

description:
Ryoko gets the prize for the most unique roll I've ever had. We tried an interesting combination of peanut butter, jalapeno and shrimp tempura. The peanut butter made for an interesting flavor profile, and while I ordered it to be adventurous, I would order it again. It was unique AND yummy. The other rolls we tried were tasty and the prices were reasonable.

Atmosphere-wise it was kinda dark, and the tables are a little close together, and it's pretty busy, but I loved the retro mix the dj was playing and the wait staff is pretty quick and friendly. Ryoko also gets extra bonus points since I got to rub elbows with a former Top Chef contestant who was seated at the table next to me (for those of you who are wondering, she really liked the sushi and gave it a thumbs up).
author: Dani D.

description:
Was pretty good!

GET THERE EARLY!!! 
We showed up 10 minutes after they opened and got the 2nd to last seat. Good prices, good service and delicious food, cant ask for much more.
author: Glenn G.

description: This sushi place was okay. We waited very long to get seated, I mean about an hour and a half. There is not a waiting area, you wait at the stairs while people are entering and exiting. We decided to wait because of the rave reviews. Once we were seated we ordered the edamame and miso soup. Nothing special. We then ordered a roll with mango, that roll was good. We ordered a few fried rolls and they were all tasty but nothing too amazing. I really love sushi, so my expectation is pretty high when it comes to rolls, I feel like this place is over priced. It's great that it's open late. I wouldn't recommend it for big groups as it was only 3 of is and the waiting took forever. They do have a "specials" menu which has some yummy items you can select that's fresh.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Good quality fish with generous portions when ordered nigiri. Uni and roe were fresh and not overly fishy.  Nigiri rice had too much vinegar and was not proportionate to the fish (too little). 

Arrived at 615 and place was almost full, packed with a wait by the time we left. Good prompt polite service. They bring out your sushi in a specific order so not to overwhelm you all at once.

Would go back and take friends here.
author: thomas p.

description:
I know this place has a ton of great reviews, but I just had to add mine to the mix. This place is great! Very authentic, to the point that they yell 'hello' and 'thank you, goodbye' to you in Japanese when you arrive and leave. Stepping down in to Ryoko's is like stepping out of San Francisco and in to Japan, what I remember of it anyway.
Their food is always fresh and really quick. The teriyaki steak is the best we have ever had...anywhere!
The sashimi is excellent and practically melts in your mouth. There is not a single thing we have had here that we would not recommend or order again.
The drinks are also all wonderful and worth the $$. They are a bit more expensive than I prefer, but they are not all watered down or light on the alcohol, so you get what you're paying for.
All around this is an excellent place to eat. But get there early, because they get VERY busy VERY fast, even on Sunday.
author: Emily B.

description:
Ryoko's is currently my favorite sushi restaurant.  I love the vibe of the place, the music, the downstairs atmosphere.  Secondly, the sushi is pretty good, especially the sushi specials, for which there are usually 3 to 4 fishes imported from Japan.  There's also about 20 appetizers of various forms, such as agedashi tofu, that are all delightful and a nice change from just fish-fish-fish-fish-fish-full.

One thing people remark about is the lack of reservations here.  This is actually a plus for me, since I never know when I'll be able to convince my girlfriend or other friends to go get a big pile of sushi.  The fact that I can just go here, get good sushi, and wait just as long as everyone else is a huge plus.
author: Jon E.

description:
Amazing! The best sushi I have ever had. 
They have no problem taking custom orders and making sure it's perfect.

The service was quick and although they were extremely busy out waitress took her time to talk us through the menu and make sure we got what we liked. The sushi was ready in less then 15 minutes, and they were slammed. We got a few rolls, all of the fish was fresh and delicious.

The atmosphere was perfect. We sat at the bar and there is nothing I would have changed.
author: Ali J.

description: I tried this place around 7-7:30, as a party of two on a Thursday. The wait wasn't too bad, it was just about 10-15 minutes for us. This is a lively place, had a DJ there which I didn't pay too much attention to, because the place was already very lively from the chatter of the restaurant patrons. Seating is a little cramped but we didn't mind it, because the sashimi was so good. We had the sashimi dinner which had 14 generous pieces with a side of rice for $39.95 and two other rolls, which we enjoyed. The highlight of my dinner was the Saba sashimi. I am a lover of Saba, and this is the best Saba I've ever tasted. It was creamy and the salinity was perfect; it melted in my mouth. I love that this place give finely chopped scallions and diced almost to a pulp pickled radishes. The wasabi was particularly spicy! Much better quality than any other place I've been to. The salmon was also very creamy, and went down like a dream~ I didn't have to dip my sashimi in soy sauce like I normally do. It was perfect just the way it was cut and served to us. I enjoyed putting some garish on my sashimi that was provided. But I didn't need to, because sashimi just stood out all on its own. Love this place. Definitely quality!
author: Audrey A.

description: Hot Tuna, jumping Tuna and the Tahoe roll also ordered hot green tea.
author: Peter S.

description: Good sushi. Great vibe. The staff is awesome. Came here alone during a work trip but it seems like a great date night spot. Will definitely be back.
author: Teree H.

description:
Catie C. swore by this sushi place and boy was she right, except for the waiting part. After working a 12 hour day at a conference, I was exhausted, cranky and VERY HUNGRY. My cousin from New York and his girlfriend from Jersey was in town for the weekend so I meet up with the group around 9:00pm. As soon as we got to Ryoko's, the place was packed and said the wait would be 1/2 hour. 1/2 hour turned into 1 hour and 10 minutes and I was loosing my mind and patience. We were waiting for this party of 6 to leave but they took their sweet ass time leaving. Finally, they left and we got to ordering some sushi. We ordered the following:

2 Rounds of sake
Agedashi Tofu
2 orders of Tempura
Philadelphia
Hot Tuna
Kentucky
Tamago
Jumping Tuna
Dragon

Just by looking at the menu, I figured it was going to be your average looking sushi rolls but the presentation of how the sushi rolls came out was just over the top and everything we ordered was excellent especially the atmosphere in this place, I mean a DJ right in the middle of the restaurant playing some 80's songs, what else more can you ask for? I'd definitely come back here again. Oh, and it was also fun watching people coming here on first time dates. Sure helped pass the time while waiting for our seats.
author: Jocelyn T.

description: I was visiting San Fransisco for business trip. I found this sushi bar via yelp and decided to give it a chance. I loved the sushi but didn't like  the chicken teriyaki! Never order chicken in a sushi bar! I'd still give this place 5 star for it's delicious sushi.
author: Arman P.

description:
Very very solid 4 stars for absolutely attentive but not  overly slavish service for our big party of 7 who ordered in fits and spurts and kept running out of tea.

 The sushi rolls were excellent, the place is small but very comfortable and the noise level very conducive to a large party being able to hear each other, which is awesome. We tried a number of the rolls and I liked them all. I'd love to come here again. Parking nearby can be a bit of a pain.
author: Henry Y.

description: The food was amazing! Great atmosphere (DJ was on point), drinks were ok. Couldn't stop eating even after I was full! Service was a little on the negetive side. It was almost like they were irritated we kept ordering more food. Overall it was good but would probably avoid it if you're not a local.
author: K W.

description:
Ryoko's left something to be desired for me. The ambiance was great and the sushi service was speedy (although we did have to double check with the servers that they hadn't forgotten our appetizers, which arrived well after the rolls). However, for a restaurant that serves something called a POKEMON ROLL (oh can I please) and has over an hour long wait, I expected the best.

Probably want to skip that pokemon roll. Despite having such an inviting description (and name!), it tasted like nothing and was a poorly executed sushi-representation of my childhood happy place.

What WAS good was the jumping tuna. My group got a bunch of different rolls to share and that was the only one with memorable quality. Overall I say skip it, there're more place with more hits on the menu and much larger portion sizes for the price.
author: Katie V.

description: I thought the sushi here was very yummy and the prices were fair. My friend and I went around 6pm, so we didn't have a wait, but there was a large crowd waiting when we left, so I'd recommend going early. I wouldn't say it was the best sushi that I've had, but I was pleased with my dining experience there.
author: Emily D.

description: Best sushi I every visited. I have eaten in sushi places all across the USA and Ryoko is the best thus far
author: M M.

description: There are definitely better sushi restaurants in SF, but late night in a pinch it does the job. This is a hole in the wall joint, but the staff are very friendly and food comes quick. The prices seem a little high for what you get, we only had 2 people and 4 rolls were the right amount of food.
author: Allison A.

description:
I just visited SF for a week for a conference and we rented a house in nobhill and found this place by accident.
But i got one of my best sushi I ever had. 
On a Sunday night, this place was packed, which for me coming from OC it was surprising,
for a group of 7, they seated us in less than 30 minutes and our server was super friendly. We got two combination platter, a couple of edemame bowls, beef teryaki, and added some other rolls.
My favorite was the roll with peanut butter, and their philadelphia was also amazing.
The beef teryaki was very tender and we had an amazing time.
author: Sepide S.

description:
If you're looking for cheap sushi, this is not the place.

If you're looking for quality sushi at a good price for the quality you're getting. This is perfect for you.

We got the Pokemon, volcano, flying tuna and shrimp symphony rolls. All were great. I think my favorite was the volcano, my friend's was the flying tuna.

I tried their house Pilsner, definitely good.
author: Chelsea M.

description:
I... fell for a "standard" that still is pretty damned good on its own.

And I...  live inland now.  It hurts to say that.  And living inland can legitimately invalidate any "sushi" review.

This place was good.  Young chefs serving up what they want.  Music, etc., but ultimately the chefs kept it going.  And not like the idiotic boat thing.  They know.

Ok.  It was monkfish liver.  I admit it.  But still, yum.  And not the only, um, seafood available here.  But the best I personally could manage was what the chefs served up pretty frackin' well.  (Note: Solo diner, alas, so I didn't have to wait.)
author: Jason R.

description: My m.yelp  tablet application directed me to this sushi place around the corner from my hotel.  This is the last place anyone would randomly enter in downtown SF.  It is in the basement of some  old building.  It was fantastic.  Take a look at the pictures other yelpers have posted--1200 reviews--you can imagine what it takes to breakout with sushi in this town!  Place was packed at 6pm on a weeknight.  Excellent service and a very cool place.  The sushi and the cooked food was all excellent.  We loved it
author: AV G.

description: Very good fish, but a bit expensive. 14 sashimis (tuna, salmon and octopus), one miso soup and a green tea for 50 dolars (tips and tax included).
author: Thiago G.

description:
Love this place! I was a little hesitant on account of all the hotel-out-of-towners forming a line around the block any time after 7pm.  Despite that trepidation, I braved the line and after a measly 30 minutes I found myself at a table all by my lonesome with an expansive view of it all.  The atmosphere was lively club music and everything was set to a dull roar even on a Tuesday! Good people watching! Young hip crowd, Art Institute types mixed with a spatter of the hotel referred. The people sitting next to me were among the aforementioned out-of-towners and were even wearing pajamas... I can never keep up with these suburban fads...

My waiter Eddy was a cutie-pie, pleasant and helpful even though they were slamming busy and I asked way more than a few questions.

I had the Tobiko, Unagi, Tamago, Nigiri, and Volcano Roll, which has peanut butter in it and was surprisingly good though I rarely go the untraditional route. Everything was fresh and delicious. I'll definitely be back...probably next Tuesday.



The hostess and I'm assuming owner both stopped by to check on me
author: Summer S.

description:
Wow -- this place is AWESOME and DELICIOUS! They have a DJ playing top 40 tunes all night, and the ambience/atmosphere is friendly and lively. 

The rolls are very creative and delicious. The volcano is to die for - don't be scared when you read it has peanut butter as an ingredient (the flavor is subtle but has a huge impact). The veggie melody was also delicious, the best for vegetarians! The jumping tuna - deep fried and with special sauce; not my favorite of the three we ordered (other two listed above), but still good! We also tried the tuna otoro, and I wasn't a fan but my boyfriend loved it. Personally, it tasted like a big slab of fishy butter.

Overall, LOVED this place and will definitely go back when I'm back in San Francisco! Wish this sushi place was back home!
author: Sara S.

description: Rather than detail the entire saga, here's the bottom line.  We waited about 30 minutes for a table (no problem, we were fine with that).  We waited an hour for our sushi to arrive.  An hour.  Received tiny bowl of edamame "on the house" for waiting so long (as if that was some big gesture, BFD).  Extremely tiny portions of very mediocre sushi that looked like an amateur had rolled it.  We left hungry.  Terrible.
author: Mylene v.

description: This is my favorite sushi place to visit when I travel to see my sister in San Francisco. The pokemon rolls are my favorite, but every one that I tasted was terrific. I usually like to pair it with the red house wine or the warm sake. And the appetizers are fantastic and are reasonably priced. I look forward to my next visit!
author: Jessica A.

description:
I arrived tired and hungry after a Deftones show at the Warfield last night. The fact that this place was open until 2AM was AWESOME. It was one of the few establishments open that late, and I'm happy we found it doing some creative yelping. 

I tried the fermented soybeans. The sushi chef suggested mixing a quail egg to the contents. It was definitely not for everybody, but between the unusual taste and texture I was hooked. I finished the entire serving.

I also had white tuna toro sashimi. Mmmm. Melt in your mouth HIGH quality sushi. 

We also enjoyed the spicy hamachi and tuna rolls. They were amazing. They had almost a smoky heat combined with a citrus like flavor. Incredibly balanced with texture and flavor, I was impressed. Our sushi chef struggled a bit with English but his sushi game was IMPRESSIVE.

The checkerboard incorporated several different types of fish in a checkerboard pattern with avocado. BOMB.

They were bumping dance music, but with my ears blown out from the concert it sounded distant. At the bar were two other people who came from the show. 

I most certainly will be back, when I'm not hoarse from screaming but still hungry. This spot is a great late night spot in a region of California not known for its late night scene. Bravo Ryoko's.
author: Carl I.

description:
It's surprising how hard it is to find real good sushi in SF.  I can get by with most places, but I've never had a "go to".

However, Ryoko's is a contender.

Right away, I was sold on the place.  It's a quick walk from Nob Hill, and when you arrive, you head straight down a flight of stairs where you are vocally welcomed by the entire staff in Japanese.  (Note:  If it's your first time, and you hear all of the employees shout something in unison as you're making your way down the stairs...yeah, they're talking to you)

For a Saturday night, it was a short weight, maybe a little less than 30 minutes.  But the place was packed, always a good sign.  We were seated at the bar, given a complimentary bowl of edamame and away we went.

We had a grilled rice ball come out, which was shortly followed by our Hot Tuna, Alcatraz (Eel), and a couple more simple selections.  All very fresh, all very delicious.  No soy sauce needed (but I have to dip sometimes for some wasabi bite)

I love the setting inside, the super adorable and friendly staff, who's service is excellent.

OK yeah, I'm convinced, this is now my go to sushi spot...
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Check in before you walk in. It's downstairs so your phone (at least on ATT) will have 0 bars. I switched to Edge and got like 2.

Anyhow, food. Good.

Lots of fried rolls which the white guy in me loves. The Tamago was tasty and a little sweet like I like it. The Eal was... well I've had better, but they're stingy with the sauce so that might be a party of it.

I dunno that'd I'd go back right away, there's a lot of sushi to be had in San Francisco, but I'd go back eventually.
author: john W.

description:
It's a sushi restaurant and bar, but in reality it's much more like a sushi dance club and bar.  The persistent deep penetrating thumping of club/house music playing throughout the restaurant could probably cause an arrhythmia during mid-bite of some hamachi sashimi.

The restaurant is also deceptively large.  The small, rather nondescript entrance leads to a steep flight of stairs to descend into a divey cavernous area with a main dining room and bar area as well as a number of private rooms.  I always somehow end up sitting next to the drunkest and loudest parties in the restaurant for some reason though.

The food has actually been surprisingly quite good however during my visits (especially the quality of the sashimi), despite everything else.  Items I would recommend -- tuna and hamachi sashimi, monkfish liver, checkerboard roll and shishamo.

Overall, 3.5 stars.
author: Erich D.

description:
Went here on a saturday night with my wife and brother because we heard really good things. We got there and there was no host/hostess. There were 2 women at the stand who didn't even work there telling people to put their names on a list and it'll be 45 minutes (we didn't know they didn't work there). It took an hour to get a table for 3. Once we got a table it took awhile for a server to get to us and when she did stop by she was there long enough to take an order and leave. A total of about 30 seconds. We each ordered 2 rolls for a total of 6. They brought 2 out which left one person with no food at the table. I found the sushi to be very wet as if the rice hadn't been drained properly. The knife work wasn't great as pieces weren't always cut all the way through. 

Besides that there must have been something wrong with the food b/c after eating my meal, it made me sick enough to visit the bathroom before we even left.

Needless to say I won't be back.
author: Matt J.

description: The place was crowded on a Friday night.  The wait moved at a decent pace.  Sushi was very good.  Price is a little on the high side.  The issue was the noise level.  The music is so loud, it's like a bar/club vibe.  Not how I like to enjoy a nice sushi dinner.
author: love n.

description:
Pros: the food was fresh, service was speedy when we sat down. 
Cons: the wait is loooonnnng. had to wait 1 hour on a friday night but just kept grabbing drinks at the bar
must try:  volcano roll & jumping unagi
author: Rocky C.

description:
This is one of my favorite sushi places in the city! Every time my friend visits SF, he requests that we go here and I never complain.  The fish is extremely fresh and for the quality, the prices are reasonable. 

Sometimes there's loud music playing but it's never annoying--just something to think about if you're looking for a quieter dinner setting. Think hip/lively restaurant (vs. classy and sophisticated atmosphere).There's also usually a wait but if you go with under 4 people, I've never had to wait too long. 

The rolls are really good, but when we go we like to order a lot of nigiri and oysters. Again, so fresh. Depending on what you order, sometimes you'll get real wasabi! (yes, most places don't offer the good stuff but they have it here behind the counter).
author: Stephanie A.

description:
"Irrashaimase!" 

Yeah, that's what they DIDN'T say when my party of 5 walked in. However, they happily shouted that to everyone else who walked into the restaurant after we entered. 

A group of us were the first people to walk into this restaurant on a Friday night. 

Rather than greeting us as we were seated, our server told us, "This table is reserved at 7:30. Will you be done by 7:30?" It was 6PM. 

That's exactly what you want to hear when you enter a restaurant: "When are you going to leave?"

My group and I were seated in a cramped booth in the corner by the storage room. We were surrounded by empty tables. Why were we seated in the only booth that was reserved? I'm not sure. It didn't seem like the entire restaurant was reserved in the first two minutes they opened.

It didn't help that it took a really long time for us to get our food and that tables sat after us received their entrees before we did. The time we spent waiting for our food wasn't a huge deal. You know how it is: When you're with a group of friends, you sometimes get caught up in conversations and time flies. 

The big deal was when we tried to order more food we were declined. We had to leave by 7:30. 

What? You don't want our money? Okay. You won't ever see it ever again. We don't want your mediocre food anyway.
author: Sarah G.

description:
3.5
we put our name down and walked around for a bit.. since they called our party while we were still out they gave us the back room just for us 3! 

ordered:
-garlic shrimp
-edamame
-gyoza
-chicken teriyaki: standard
-deep fried soft shell crab: yum
-grilled mackerel: so good
-specials: barracuda; and some other fish with deep fried shallots.. love!
-fried shrimp heads: mm head 

sushi/sashimi: 
-toro: 2 types
-salmon
-mackerel
-halibut
-eel
-scallop
-uni
-yellowtail
-albacore
-sweet shrimp

there was prob 1-3 other things i forgot we had

everything was good and i'd come back if i was in the area

notes:
-lines are always long
author: Raquel T.

description:
I like how it is walking distance from Union Square. About a 10 min walk if you parked in the garage at the Macy's lot. Came here with a party of 4 around 615 and we were seated right away. It's advisable to come here for an early or late dinner. Anywhere from 7pm-830pm gets really crowded and there is a long wait, so plan accordingly.

It has a pretty cool 'underground' feel to it. Seating-wise, it is not too cramped. Here's what was ordered:

----------------------------

Appetizer:

Deep Fried Oysters - it has the mushy, gushy taste. You can definitely taste the chunks of oyster. It was a bit over-fried for me. Comes with 4 pieces. I don't recommend this

Saba Shioyaki - the mackerel was grilled to perfection. The skin had a light crispiness. This was very very tasty.

Rolls:

Hot Tuna + Hot Tail - had the same ingredients with the exception of the fish. There was a nice little spiciness to it and a bit of a mint flavor which was actually refreshing. Pretty good, but this wasn't the best thing I've ever had.

Nigiri:

Hamachi - generous piece of hamachi. Buttery, melts in your mouth. Fresh. This was freaking good.

Halibut - I typically don't eat halibut, but this was pretty good too. Light taste.

Tuna - tuna is tuna. Don't really care about it.

Unagi - pretty saucy. Not bad, but I've had better.

Tako - perfect firmness, not crunchy. Big pieces of tako!

The rice was a little warm which was a plus. It didn't crumble and held itself together pretty well with the fish.

-----------------------------------

Overall, this place is pretty good. I recommend getting the hamachi, tako, and saba shioyaki. Service was impeccable. Constantly refilled waters and took away plates as needed. I didn't have to ask or anything. They were very attentive. I wouldn't mind coming here again if I'm at Union Square.
author: Desmond T.

description:
While not a bad place, color me unimpressed.

Food- 4 Stars
Fish was good not great. Mostly I was annoyed that the server let me order some specials without warning me one was a crab that was super tough (like chewing on a pencil or plastic pen almost).  She knew I didn't have any clue about it but didn't bother to warn me even a little. They did have a bunch of more unusual items which was cool.

Their tempura was awesome.

Atmosphere- 3 Stars
Loud and dark inside, kind felt like a college bar to me. 

Service- 4 Stars
Server was very nice outside of aforementioned non-description of crab.

Drinks- 4 Stars
Good cold sake if not a little overpriced.

Value- 3 Stars
Not worth the money given the bar like atmosphere.
author: Alexi A.

description:
This is a great place to pre-game before a night out on the town.  When you enter the place, you walk down a flight of stairs where you can put your name in for a table.  Usually you simply write your name on a list.  Since there can often be a line here, the waitress will bring you a drink while you wait for your food.  The music is mixed by a DJ and is usually upbeat.  The crowd is on the younger side with smaller tables.   Probably not a great place for large parties.  

The Sake is cheap and goes down like water.  Sushi was delicious and fresh with decent sized proportions. I would recommend for a casual date or to pre-game with a small group before hitting the town.
author: Tyler B.

description: Delicious sushi.   Highly recommended.  I had a roll with salmon on top. Great stuff.
author: Jeff S.

description: Huge wait on a Friday night. My only real complaint is how small our uni portions were.
author: S. A. K.

description:
Ryoko's Japanese Restaurant and Bar is a cuisine sancturary where SF City can close the gaps of differences and turn them into magic. If you have jisa boke = time difference and get hungry in the middle of the night, well, don't worry, they are open to late. I recommend sushi diners from beginners to advanced. They can entertain you at any level; all the way to Omakase.

History: The founder of Ryoko's Japanese Restaurant & Bar has an extensive background in traditional Japanese hospitality and night club level customer service. Yes, her name is Ryoko. I have invited high quality Japanese, Korean, Chinese, Taiwanese, European, Russian, Middle Eastern business affilation here a day before I close a business deal. Ryoko Mama was always there to give the dinner and drinking experience an elegant magical touch. Ryoko Mama believes in prosperity, family wellness and universal sustainable peace. Her children that also help her business have been raised here in USA with Japanese hardcore tradition and ethics. This family believes in family and community bonding, harmony, resilience and unconditional compassion. When any employee had a chance to work here for a period of time, they were all exposed to these values through this family one way or another. Ryoko Mama has been open to serve and employ a vast diverse population that seek excellence. At one point, there was an Itacho, Senior Sushi Chef who was a piano player. That is why there is a beautiful piano there today. The reason why they have live DJs is from that kokorokubari and kikubari of making sure that your dining experience is full. Yah, Dubstep and Sushi. 

Neta = Sushi materials. Abundant and extremely fresh. Ryoko's Japanese Restaurant & Bar has a high service rotation cycle. Which means they have to keep supplying fresh batches of neta all the time.  

Serving of Sushi. Generous portions and clean traditional cuts. Ryoko's Japanese Restaurant & Bar's chefs are trained from a clear lineage of Japanese itamae. Their fish meat are cut thick, clean and in proper angle with a very well sharpened sashimi traditional knife. The surface of the cut fish or shellfish is shiny and slippery. That is why the best of the fragrance and texture is guranteed. Cutting the fishes and clams is not belittled here. You can try their Akami (the deep red part of the maguro = tuna) and you will see how it feels.

Atmpsphere. Uplifting, good vibe, energy flowing, healthy, upbeat, fusion culture, diverse diners, young and not too young are all there, highly addictive atmosphere... I think. It makes you want to go there again and again. The biggest element of sushi is not the food. It is your interaction with the chefs. They are meant to be Iki ga ii. Lively and good luck. Well, you got the real thing here. Ah, fire your therapist and dine here 5 days in a row. You will pop out of any gloominess!

True Meanging of Sushi. Sushi stands were once found all over the busy parts of cities and towns where people that were not properly clothed or washed could just drop by and grab, then get back to work. It was meant to be Iki-ga-ii = very lively. Nijo bukai = deeply compassionate and down to earth. So, the root to sushi was a common food, very much like hotdog stands here in USA. As the price of seafood went up, sushi became a posh luxury food as it got integrated with kaiseki. Ryoko's Japanese Restaurant and Bar has kept its original meaning of sushi. 

I will upload some photos. Ask me any questions :)
author: Yuki T.

description:
Food was decent service was bad. No reservations are accepted. So we Waited for more than an hour for our table. Very Loud inside with a DJ and the volume turned up too high to enjoy the dinner. Hip hop music was cool tho. 

Understaffed. There was only one waitor I saw and it took a long time to take our order appx 25 minutes to take our food order  .  The waitstaff did not bring the plates out at the same time. In fact it was one at a time. There was one person at the table who ordered chicken teriyaki and it came out 20 minutes after everyone else was served. 

The men's restroom was small and could be updated and a mirror installed. Otherwise he restaurant was clean and comfortable. 

The prices are inexpensive which was nice. Rolls are between $5 and $15. $5 beers. $2 cokes. The fish tasted very fresh. Ordered spicy tuna and scallop roll. Very good.
author: Doug M.

description: Just excellent! Great booze and sushi. Excellent place to go. Next time I'm in town, I'll be there.
author: Joseph P.

description:
Arrived at Ryoko's right at 6 PM on a Monday night and were seated right away. The restaurant filled up within a half hour though, so come early or be sure to make a reservation. The underground restaurant isn't too visible from the outside, but inside the place is massive! 

We got the beef oroshi as a starter, the sashimi dinner, and the Hot Tail roll as well as white tuna toro nigiri. The beef oroshi was solid although not the best I've had, but it was a solid portion for what it's worth. Our sashimi dinner included tuna, salmon, yellowtail, white tuna, octopus and mackerel. Everything was fresh and delicious. The Hot Tail roll was also very fresh, but there were only six pieces so don't expect to get full after one roll. 

Service was very prompt and our food came out very quickly since we were early. There were separate people just to pour water so our glasses were never full. 

Will definitely be back! Very good vibe, looks to be a good place to drink and relax with friends.
author: Carolyn Y.

description:
Best Sushi in town. During the weekend it is a long wait. Not recommended for claustrophobic people. I like to have a sit at the bar and see how they make my sushi. Salmon and tuna are super fresh super good! 
See you soon Ryoko s
author: Alex R.

description: This is definitely the best Sushi I've tried. The restaurant is very charming but very small which is why the wait is long, but OMG! it was so worth it waiting in line for 45 min. :)
author: Karla D.

description: Yum! We were visiting out of town and totally fell in love with the fresh sushi and good combinations. From the street it looks like a whole in the wall, but inside it is nicely decorated and the staff were very friendly. We got there right when they opened at 6 and when we were leaving it was packed. Loved the checkerboard
author: Anne M.

description: Decent quality fish. Skip the rolls and get sushi or sashimi. The rolls went overkill on the mayo and spice. Good wakame salad. Miso was so so. Get here early and with a small party or forget it.
author: Khalid N.

description:
Not sure how this place gets 4 stars. We're from LA and know good sushi. The fish here was not fresh and the rolls are not authentic. For example, they have a 'sexy roll'.

This seems to be a local fun place for Americans to have sushi and drink. A mixed crowd. So I can see the fun there.

A 4 star, this doesn't make it. :-)
author: Chris L.

description: This place had the most terrible service I have ever seen in all the restaurants I've ever gone to. My friend, bf and I drove to SF and got there pretty late and ryoko's happened to be the only Japanese place opened around 11pm so we decided to give it a try. We didn't mind the wait but when we realized that someone cut in front of us and crossed out OUR name making us wait even longer than we should've. Terrible service because 1, the hostess or server NEVER called out our name and the person who was after us had a table for 2 and we had a table for 3. They sat them at the bigger table and once we confronted them about the mistake they sat us in a tiny little corner with only two chairs and brought a stool for my bf to sit on. A STOOL. What is that?! Like seriously. The table was crammed with our food and on top of it all we ordered everything from this waiter and later another waiter came and served us and I ordered the chicken teriyaki to add on. That took more than 45 minutes, by then my friend and my bf was already done eating and our first waiter passed by taking someone else's order and when my bf was trying to get her attention she was like "hold on! I'm working!" Talk about bad customer service obviously you are working. After that she said "ok I'm done what is it?" And he said "we ordered another chicken teriyaki from another waitress and it's taking a while..also can we get 2 forks?" And she said "if it's from someone else then wait it's not me. And ok 2 forks" she NEVER came with the forks -.- by then we didn't even need them anymore. Never again will I come here. One star because food was actually good but when we got the check I was still eating and saw a piece of black hair on my teriyaki plate and just left.
author: Jessica P.

description:
INCREDIBLY CROWDED on a weekend night! Overall, the sushi was pretty good. Nice solid presentations, a but pricey, but hey - it's SF. 

some of the BEST uni i've ever had. Sweet and creamy, yet light and incredibly fresh! I don't know if we came on a night if Uni was having a good day, but I would definitely be tempted come to this place again just for the uni.

Recommended.
author: Christina C.

description:
4 out of 5 stars Yelpers? Really? Based on what? Certainly not the fish quality. Or the service. Or the wait. This place is just not that good. I have already had and expect much better from San Francisco.

I'll give 2 stars because they are open late and, yes, having a DJ is cool. But with the low quality fish here I can't justify more. No need to return to this joint with so many better choices available.
author: Paul G.

description:
Wasn't too impressed with the rolls at this place. The sashimi was pretty fresh though. The rolls absolutely no flavor. I wanted to stop eating since I was basically consuming empty calories.

The wait was pretty bad for a Thursday night and it's hard to get parking. It also takes a long time to get your food after your long wait because the place is understaffed. 

The dessert was ok but not memorable.

Nothing really stood out for me here so I'll continue on my hunt for a good Japanese restaurant in the city!
author: Cynthia C.

description: Amazing place to celebrate my birthday! Visiting San Fran for the first time and was definitely impressed with the menu variety and how fresh the fish was. Like butta in my mouth! Jenny our server was a doll and super friendly. Thanks for the great experience!
author: Lexxie B.

description: This is a quiet and elegant place to get some sushi. The black and purple interior is great at setting a mood. The maki rolls, seaweed salad with scallions, and massive hand rolled sushi makes them a popular spot and for good reason. Affordable prices and friendly staff only heighten the experience.
author: Darren F.

description: The sushi was good. I tried the eel, the waiter told my boyfriend and i that the eel was all the way from Japan! We were so excited to try it. The deep fried rolls were delicious and so were the fried octopus balls. I recommend to try and get there about 20 mins before the restaurant opens to get a seat, the wait is a little long if you dont.
author: Diana L.

description:
Really good sushi.  Fun sake bombing times.  

The hostess here is really great.  It's a small place, it gets packed, and she is so accommodating and helpful, always with a huge smile!  Perfect example of how the hostess can make waiting for a table a lot more bearable and not make customers hate the restaurant before they even take a bite of the food.  

If it's raining outside and you're waiting, they offer you tea.  How nice.
author: Alyssa P.

description:
Two stars for ambiance and the server was fantastic. Great service, cool tunes playing. For sure a late night rowdy place to be fun crowd.

The sushi sucks... the rolls are badly rolled, falling apart and the california roll was pretty ghastly with very little flavor reminded me of the horrid Trader Joes Sushi. Futomaki was tiny and lacked any flavor.

Got a unagi roll for $15.50 which was just a gross california roll $4.50 with 4 slices of unagi and 4 slices of avocado, not good. Neither of my friends were impressed by their food. 

Saba nigiri was actually ok.


The only reason to go back is the late night options 2am I believe, oh and our lovely server.
author: Madrone H.

description: Yummy sushi from a tiny hole in the wall we almost missed!  Be sure to be there right when they open, because the line will already be forming.  The sushi was amazingly delicious, the service quick and friendly, and the prices were very reasonable.  Highly recommend!  Easy walk from Union Square, but not too many tourists.
author: Lexi L.

description:
Ryoko's be rockin! Loved the hip hop (featuring local bay area artists), underground vibe, and not to mention the sushi - phenomenal! 

They were sadly out of the giant clam sushi we wanted, and some of the other specials - but the waitress had great alternative suggestions..and it was pretty late in the evening.

Among other choices.. I ordered the special, Monkfish Liver sashimi, it was oh so good.. The foie gras of the sea is the best way to describe it, super fresh, no mineral flavours, buttery and firm at the same time and you can "taste the sea" in it as the birthday boy of the table described it... Instead of the giant clam nigiri, we opted for the white tuna (waitress recommended).. it was the best sushi of the night, hands down.. The white tuna was buttery, soft and delicious with a thin slice of lemon and a spicy dollop of ginger something on top! Wow, this one blew me away. A little taste of sushi heaven..The rice on all the sushi and rolls was done perfectly and served at room temperature.

I was so happy that we had a wonderful waitress! Not only that, but all the service was down to earth, friendly and accomodating.
author: Sara F.

description:
Do you like to eat sushi while listening to dubstep? This place has a crazy good atmosphere and great food. The nigiri and sashimi are super tasty and fresh. The salad I had was also very good and tempura ice cream is never bad.

The line is out the door most nights so be prepared to wait but once inside this place is the shit!
author: James R.

description:
the last time i visited ryoko's was on valentine's day in 2003 or 2004. boy, has it changed since then.  it was SO crowded compared to when i came here in the past. i remember the food being fairly good but it was 10+ years ago so my memory is hazy.

fast forward to now: it looks like they expanded this place? but i'm not sure. there was practically  a line out the door and it was very crowded inside. we ended up being seated right near a kitchen window pick-up area so it was high traffic. this place is like a maze. i think they'd benefit from putting less tables in the space because it's kind of difficult to maneuver and the servers do not always give you the right of way.

anyway, the service was good, no complaints about that. the food was good, though i've had better, but my biggest complaint is that it's overpriced. had it been a bit cheaper i probably could've given it at least 3 stars, but the portions were small, and it just wasn't worth it to me.
author: Kate W.

description:
My boyfriend and I peeked our heads in and wanted to eat here before the show so we went in.  Everyone looked at us like we were a**holes.  Then someone finally said that they didn't open until 6:00.  Okay, fair enough.. we didn't see the closed sign.  We apologized, and not knowing what time it was, we looked and it was 5:57.   

"Can we just wait here?" we asked. 

*Blank stares*    

"Ummm.. okay.. we'll just wait outside then.. "  IN THE RAIN! 

Needless to say, we left.
author: ThirtyTwo P.

description:
"When I'm called off, I got a sawed off,
Squeeze the trigger and bodies are hauled off.
You too boy if ya fuck with me.
The police are gonna hafta come and get me,
Off yo ass that's how I'm goin out,
For the punk motherfuckers that's showin out."

Walking into this spot to be greeted by that classic known as "Straight Outta Compton" by NWA I knew my choice was solid. Who says gangster rap and sushi don't mix? Those naysayers must never have ventured out to Ryoko's on a Saturday night.

I'd been partying all Saturday. By "all" I mean from about noon until midnight, nonstop, yet somehow when I got back to the Loin I had energy to snag some grub and one more drink to cap the evening. That's when the home girl Ting's message popped into my head, "Ryoko is open until 2am every single day..." Hmmm, a little sushi and hot sake really would be a perfect end to a perfect day.

So off I went, strolling my way through the Tenderloin on this fine Saturday night.

Upon arrival I got a good vibe, chill place to hang out late night no doubt. It's below street level, so I rolled down the stairs right into that good NWA which was quickly followed by some 2Pac and Ice Cube, basically all kinds of 90s gangster rap. So good. Sure sometimes it's nice to have a traditional Japanese spot with relaxing music and proper staff, but not in the Tenderloin and not at 1:00AM on a Saturday.

The food was decent, I would not go out of my way to roll through here just to grub at a normal dinner hour. Late night though? Can't beat it. I'd say Sudachi (another later night sushi spot maybe 6 blocks away) has higher quality food but they have different hours and I've been caught in fist fights twice now outside there so I figure that's an omen to try someplace new. The service was very good at Ryoko, the sushi chefs a bit quiet but my waitress was very helpful. I ordered some sort of cucumber salad with "miso" and it came out in some mayo type sauce. I explained the mix-up, I don't do mayo, and she apologized profusely and took it away no problem. No pushback what so ever, she even said she'd put in a note to have the description changed as she agreed it could be misleading.

I downed my sake and light selection of sushi with another veggie salad and that was that. A solid visit, no drama, some NWA, good service and sure as hell available hours. Like I said, perfect end to a perfect day.
author: Justin N.

description: I love the sushi here. For lower nob, this is the only non-divey place to go. Often a wait, particularly on weekends.
author: Jim R.

description:
HANDS DOWN. 

I have found my go-to place in SF if I'm in the mood for some excellently prepared, fresh-out-of-the-sea-taste sashimi.

Yes, it is a somewhat cramped restaurant for the amount of people bombarding into the place. But it's sooo worth the wait. The servers are quick and attentive. The food came out mighty fast. 

The ambiance is upbeat and lively and I liked the fact that there was a grand piano two inches behind me of where I seated. The sushi is simple which makes it even more delicious.

And I definitely savored my sushi roll, gyoza, and sashimiiiii... with a pair of Sake Bombs! ;) 


It's a must for all you sushi-lovers out there. You haven't tasted real sushi unless you've tried this place!
author: Kimly N.

description:
This is a nice gem in the TL. Once we walked down the stairs, we were suprised at how many tables they have in this restaurant. Greeted by the friendly staff, great music, and a nice ambiance, it seemed like a nice place to chill and have some great sushi.

I would definitely recommend the rolls. The fish was fresh and the rolls were well-prepared. We washed down the sushi with some Sayuri cold, unfiltered sake, some hot sushi, and the requisite Asahi beer. 

Before we left, a DJ came in, setup, and belted out some cool tunes. Wish we could have stayed longer. We got here at 7 PM where the restaurant started to fill up. By the time we finished dinner around 8:30 PM, there were 20+ people waiting for a table. 

Hats off to our friendly waitress and the energetic sushi chefs. The checkerboard roll is a definite must-order.
author: Joe K.

description: I had a great time at this place. The sushi was good and fresh. I also tried some fresh oysters and the smoothest sake I've ever had. In addition to good food, the service was great too.
author: C K.

description: we waited about 30 minutes on a saturday night but it was well worth the wait. prices were reasonable for SF and the quality of the sushi was phenomenal! the service was great and the waitress was super friendly. we ordered the golden gate roll, the orange roll, sexy roll, jumping tuna roll and the caterpillar roll. they were all great but i would most recommend the orange roll and jumping tuna roll. those were my fav!
author: Tina M.

description:
We went to Ryoko's at around 11pm after a day in the city. Surprisingly, at 11pm, it was still packed to the brim! Walking into this establishment, I immediately got reminded of cozy izakaya outlets in tokyo. Service was prompt and efficient, the atmosphere and music was right, and the food was absolutely heavenly. There really isn't much more you can ask for in a Japanese restaurant/bar.

The deep-fried baby octopus was amazing, and the nigiri sushi plate gave us an all-around sampling of the fresh fish that the restaurant had available. Wonderful.
author: Clarence C.

description:
Since yelp does not have a decimal system in their ratings, to be more accurate, I would rate this place 2.5 stars. With not very many "good" options late at night within walking distance from Union Square, alas I resort to some good 'ol sushi...or so I thought.

It's difficult not to have high expectations of this place considering the many high ratings on Yelp and high demand of this place given by the long wait. Ryoko's, unfortunately did meet my expectations. The only thing that somewhat impressed me was the DJ that was spinning on the late Friday evening that I was dining there. Gotta love Kaskade! :P

Anyway, the atmosphere was inviting and hip. The food was not as inviting and hip. The salmon in the onigiri I ordered, was cooked, as oppose to it being pickled/dried like in Japan. Not my preference and didn't translate well for me.

The ama ebi (sweet shrimp) was something I was looking forward to but left a somewhat unpleasant taste in my mouth. What was suppose to be a succulent, sweet tasting shrimp tasted unfresh and not as sweet to me. The tuna and the yellowtail were the best pieces of the evening, with yellowtail being the absolute best. The flesh was firm and fresh tasting. 

I appreciate that we received complimentary soy beans but it really could not make up for the quality of the food or the overly hyped expectations. *sigh* I think I just slipped into a tourist trap by dining here. Though I left full, I left unsatisfied. :(
author: Rainbow B.

description: Food was okay. The place is too loud. The wait is too long for very mediocre food. Our waitress showed up once to take our order and disappeared completely. Food is expensive and not that great. Service was terrible.
author: LeTran B.

description:
I was craving sushi and starving after my graduation and we quickly searched on Yelp for a good place to try, and decided to come here with the amount of reviews they had. It was a Friday night, so I wasn't surprised at how busy they were. It was ridiculously crowded, and there was no way I was going to wait outside (as well as everyone else) because it was so cold! Crowded on the stairs, which I'm sure is a fire hazard haha. It was just my boyfriend and I, so we hoped the wait wouldn't be too bad, but it surely was.
