We finally got seated after what felt like hours, and we got seated at the bar, which sucked because I like to sit at tables. Since we waited so long already, I was just relieved to get seated. 

We ordered about 3-4 rolls and some gyoza. I felt like the rolls were quite small compared to other places that I have been to and also quite expensive for the size of the roll. Our food was taking kind of long, but I get that it was a busy night. We asked if we could just get it to go (had another place to go after), but they said it was coming out soon, so we waited a few more mins, and quickly ate as it came out. Overall, I just wasn't that impressed, especially with that long wait.
author: Nisouri S.

description: Fish was very fresh. Had some fried baby octopus, which was way better than any calimari imo. Good atmosphere and they keep the place clean
author: James T.

description: Don't go! Luckily I came early and didn't have to wait, but hearing the quoted times people are waiting for, I would be pissed. It smells like moldy wet towels inside. We spent half of our dinner swatting away flies.... So gross. Sushi was ok, on the cheaper side but cuz portions are not big. Wouldn't come back. Ever.
author: Jenny M.

description:
This place is decent but pretty crowded. The rolls are really fresh (especially the seaweed) but quantity is TINY. I asked her how big their rolls are and the waitress said 'average' - it was literally five small pieces.

Ordered a few rolls overall and it took over 40 minutes to get our food. The line out the door makes this place popular but don't expect great service. It's also in a basement so there aren't any windows so it feels kind of like you're in a dive bar.
author: Eric C.

description:
Great find in a part of San Francisco that I didn't expect a good sushi restaurant.
1. Getting a table.  If you don't want to wait, get there as close to opening time (6pm) as you can.  We arrived at 6:20 and by 6:45, there was a wait going up the stairs and out the door.
2. What to order.  We started with the gyoza.  It was good, but fried. I'm not sure if you can get them steamed or not.  Pretty good either way.  The rolls are reasonably priced.  Pretty standard pricing and sizes for sushi.  Unlike some of the other reviews, I felt like I got what I paid for. All 3 rolls were well prepared and brought out within 15 minutes, even though it was pretty busy.
3. What to drink.  We had an XL hot sake for $10 and pitcher of Asahi for $18 (or close to that).
4. Service.  Our waitress was pretty attentive, even though she seemed to have a lot of tables.  
All in all, I would go back.
author: Lynn T.

description: Never been a fan of sushi but Ryoko's is a really good place. The wait was almost 40min but worth it. The menu had variety and it was all fresh. Service was nice we didn't have to ask for much they took care of us well. Definitely recommended if you're looking for a good sushi place.
author: Krishna V.

description: This place was an amazing find. Sat on the stairs waiting for a table and was worth the wait. Put your name on the clipboard and it won't be long till you have experienced a gem in San Francisco. This energetic place delivers big in taste. ask the staff for what's good and you will be happy
author: Amanda F.

description:
Use to be incredible, now it's only ok.  Use to be the best in San Francisco, now that its so popular, the service and the quality of the food has been on the decline for the past 9 months.

It's also filled with lots of douche bags nowadays.

Most of you assholes reading this though probably think Sushi Rock on Polk is amazing though, so, knock yourself out at Ryokos.
author: Bre M.

description:
First night in SF and we got here around 9pm. Compared to SD there were more places open late night here.

The ambiance is very laid back. They have a live DJ spinning current radio hits as well as some classics. Once you enter the restaurant you go down a flight of stairs to enter. It was pretty dim, but there were a lot of people, most being regulars since they all seemed to call the sushi chefs by name. My bf and I decided to sit at the bar so that we wouldn't have to wait. We were starving!!! The 8 hour drive made us restless!!!

I ordered the Pokemon roll, which I thought was weird, but I was drawn into it cuz it had fresh mango in it and I love mangoes!!!! This would have been the second time i tried sushi with mango in it. Sushi deli 3 in sd has the pico de gallo roll that I love sooo much. The sushi was fresh and made right in front of us. The chefs really care about their customers cuz they would ask us if everything tasted ok. 

This definitely left me satisfied after an 8 hour drive! :)
author: Christine D.

description: I'm only rating the music lol... I had the edamame and some miso soup. Both were decent.
author: Brother B.

description:
We dined here on a Thursday night with a party of 6, some visiting from LA and everyone agreed - the uni here is the bomb!

Aside from the long wait and sometimes confused wait list, the service and variety, freshness of the sashimi are all worth it.
author: Grace G.

description: Went on a Friday night with some friends after work. Didn't call ahead and waited about 20 minutes for a table, which was entirely reasonable.  Other reviewers have mentioned the volcano roll, with good reason. I can only describe this roll, which features shrimp, jalapeño, and peanut butter, as an experience that should not be missed. Only complaints are that the restaurant was uncomfortably warm and the atmosphere left a bit to be desired.
author: Patrick W.

description: Stopped in for a quick bite of Sushi and this was super fresh and delicious. The prices are a bit high and the portions are a bit small. Also, around 6 there was a good 45 minute wait, which I fortunately missed by arriving just before the rush.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
We stopped by for some sushi based on past yelp reviews and we are sorry to report we had the worst sushi experience of our lives.  We eat sushi at least once a week, and on our trip to San Francisco we used Yelp to help us find a great place.

This is where we ended up and sorry we had to beg for service.  Fish was bad.
author: Tom S.

description:
I highly recommend sushi from this restaurant if you are in the area. The prices are decent for very quality sashimi. The portions are generous and the heart is put in the food. I also recommend sitting at the bar because the chefs are quite personable and you can watch them put their work of art together. I love sushi presentation!

It's definitely a casual dining experience, great for groups of different sizes. We didn't wait long for the food at all, but the check took awhile to come. It was no big deal because we just enjoyed the ambiance, listend to DJ Helen, who was really awesome, put out some really good music.
author: Joyce L.

description: Visiting from out of town, we figured we would check out the "hole in the wall" sushi joint with over 1700 reviews.  THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!  Make sure you sign up on the clipboard when you enter, there is no host, just someone that seats people who are signed up. If the line is to the door, they will tell you the wait is "45 min to well over an hour", but I feel like we waited maybe 25 minutes (some people on the list decided to leave as well). It is well worth the wait. Probably the best sushi I have ever had, as well as some of the friendliest service. Surprisingly cheap for the quality of sushi.
author: Tony B.

description: Searched for sushi on Yelp near Union Square. My fellow Yelpers did not steer my wrong. Super fresh, phenomenal sushi. Had sashimi, a few rolls, soft shell crab.  The place is super busy.  Service isn't the best because it's so busy, but the quality of the sushi makes up for it. Expect a wait, but it's worth it.
author: V K.

description:
My husband and I have just discovered izakayas. We love going to them. :)

The izakayas we go to in NYC and Melbourne Australia are awesome...but they don't specialize in sushi. I was a little worried about coming here, since this izakaya seems to specialize in sushi. We are sooooooo glad we had dinner here. :)

The service was fantastic and the food was OMG !!!!!!!! We have never had such good sushi. We also sat at the sushi bar. One of the sushi chefs created 2 rolls for us. We didn't understand what he said, because of his accent. But the sushi rolls were out-of-this-world !!!.

The appetizers were also great. I had the pork-belly and uni appetizers that were delicious.

The service was friendly and quick. 

We dined on a Thursday between 6:30 - 7:00 PM. Soon afterwards, there was a line.

If you like being pleasantly surprised by delicious food and great service, this is the place to be. :)
author: Tina V. W.

description:
Came here for a late dinner with my girlfriends. The place is pretty popular and was packed at 10p.m on a Sunday night. We had to wait about 20 minutes for a table and then were seated in the back. Our waiter was pretty nice and prompt with the food and water. Free edamame always a plus! We ordered: 
- 49er's roll 
- Sexy roll
- Pokemon roll
- Jumping tuna

I anticipated some really delicious and filling sushi, but that's not what I got. The sushi was alright, none of them were my favorite, and the serving sizes were pretty small. As we approached the end of our meal they kinda shooed us out by collecting our plates quite hurriedly before we even got the check. 

I probably won't come back again, but giving it a chance is the least I could do.
author: Jackie M.

description: In town visiting for a conference and I always visit this place when I am. Hip sushi place amongst many other boring ones in the areas.  Street level entrance that leads down stairs into restaurant.  Opens at 6pm, and stays open late.  After 605 there is always a short wait to get in, but not a long wait for time. Tip: arrive at 540/545 and just hang out in front and you'll be the first seated.   Great for dinner for 2, or if you're dining solo like me for a conference, sit at the sushi bar and observe the restaurant.   Great atmosphere with bustling music and scene.  Sushi chefs yell out welcome (in japanese) whenever someone arrives.  Food was excellent albeit slightly pricey, but well worth it.  A lot of unique items beyond your standard japanese fare, be sure to try at least one or two.
author: Miro H.

description:
As for the food and sushi at Ryoko's, it's not too shabby and I enjoyed my meal but I must say, I've tried a lot better sushi. Nonetheless, I still recommend this sushi place to anyone that visits the Bay. 

In my opinion, what makes this sushi spot a popular place and earns it high marks are its late hours, which is always a huge plus especially when on vacation in a city like San Francisco. When the alcohol, or I should say sake, starts pouring -- it's always a guaranteed good time. 

There is a little wait, so be prepared and just remember to sign in right away. Also, it can be a little cramped in the restaurant. Overall, I had a great time there but would have liked to expect more from the sushi.
author: Luigi C.

description:
Pros:
1.  Fun, cozy, nice atmosphere.
2.  Good nigiri ( good quality too!)
3.  Great place for a date or something to grab a few drinks and have good sushi.

Cons:
1.  Popular place so it can be a wait.  (But, it's in downtown SF, go get a few drinks somewhere and come back)
2.  Kinda pricey, but reasonable for SF.
3.  Portions are pretty standard size.
author: Jensen L.

description:
Their sushi is not that good and they're expensive. It's not quite worth the price. The least enjoyable thing about their sushi is their sushi rice. Everytime I've had their sushi (dine-in or takeout), their sushi rice was under-flavored and hard and dry. 

The most enjoyable piece of sushi I had there was probably the ama-ebi nigiri. The shrimp was very fresh and sweet...crunchy but also melts in your mouth. I've tried several of their sushi rolls but they were...meh. Since it's mostly rice and the rice is no good...go figure. They do advertise using fresh, organic ingredients so maybe it's just the sushi rice that needs some extra work. :/ 

My boyfriend always order their steamed clams in sake. Sometimes it's pretty good. A simple, enjoyable dish when the flavors are well-balanced. Sometimes, it's like taking shots.

This place has the ambiance of a bar/lounge. Dimly lit. Loud club-type music. I think they have live DJs sometimes, maybe the weekend. It's especially crowded during the weekend. You're practically rubbing elbows and butt cheeks with the people around you. But you don't have to worry about others overhearing your conversation. The music is so loud you probably can't even hear yourself think. Surprisingly everyone else seems to be able to carry on a very nice conversation with their friends/dates.

The service is pretty good here aside from their enthusiastic hello and goodbye when you come in or leave. The waitresses are all young and bubbly.

I would recommend this place if you want late-night sushi and not too particular about your sushi. Or if you want sushi for bar food. This wouldn't be one of those places where I'd take my out-of-town guests for the meal of their life or out-of-this-world experience. I wouldn't come here regularly myself either.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I just don't think this place deserve 4 stars the sushi was no more than average, and the service was just ok, we has to wait 30 min for 3 rolls,
It's a decent place but there's way better places
author: Dean W.

description: Even on a Monday night it was packed! We had a little wait but it was worth it. The fish was fresh but some of the Maki rolls were a little overpriced.  I loved my caterpillar roll and tuna roll. Would I come back, probably!  Downfall, is they wouldn't let us order takeout to bring back to our room.
author: Linda M.

description: My first thoughts after eating here was that the food was not authentic and there was way too long of a wait. I'm not really sure why people are clamoring to eat here?  The sashimi was good, but it was a relatively small portion for the price. The rest of food, including the miso soup and teriyaki sauce, was sub par.  The seating can be a bit cramped and the noise level is relatively high so not the best date night place, more of a place to go with your buddy if you live in the neighborhood and you don't want to drive somewhere better.  I would also consider the service average.
author: Ken T.

description: Excellent prices, but the sushi itself is mediocre. Three stars comes from the great service, bar, and pricing. The sushi is less flavorful than most places, and you can really taste the "cheapness" in the rolls. I recommend spending a little more for better quality and taste.
author: Marissa H.

description:
Went here on Friday for dinner. Their sashimi dinner and sushi (A roll called Sexy) are on point! This place is packed. The wait is definitely worth it. 5 stars. Their server Marco was awesome. He always made sure we were okay since our actual server is busy running around the restaurant. 

Will definitely come back! :)
author: Joanna D.

description: Came here after a long flight of delays into San Fran. Needed something open late. Wait was short. Music great. Atmosphere cool. Food quick & delicious. Highly recommend whether you're just passing through or a local who's never been.
author: Jacob S.

description:
We got there 5 minutes before they opened on a Friday night and there was already a line of about 30 people waiting outside. Once the doors opened, the staff seated everyone quickly. The atmosphere was nice and the wait staff was friendly. 

We ordered two appetizers and two rolls. One appetizer came out with the two rolls pretty quickly. Once we had finished those three dishes, we had to wait for our final dish to come out. 

The food was excellently prepared, but the restaurant was under staffed for the number of people trying to eat on a Friday night. If you go, plan on your meal taking a little longer than usual. 

I would definitely go back again if I ever find myself in the area.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I have frequented Ryoko multiple times and each time, I come with hope that this time will be better than the last. However, each and every time, i have been utterly disappointed. 

This place is the epitome of a modern trendy japanese restaurant that relies on the hype of being hip and fun. The clientele here are mostly young trendy americans who are here to drink and socialize rather than to enjoy the quality or originality of the food. Don't get me wrong, i love trendy sushi joints like this, that are great for birthday parties, a girl's night out, and a natural starting point to a fun-filled night of drunken shenanigans... only when it's done right.  

My most recent experience at Ryoko prompts me to not give this place anymore second, third, or fourth chances. 

** SERVICE
The host was rude and the server kept rushing us. Understandably, we had a pretty large party of 12, and I'm assuming they only have a few areas that can fit large parties. Another large party's reservation was probably coming up, so they wanted to free the table. However, there are better ways of hurrying up your patrons than coming up every 15 minutes and counting down the time we have left at our table. Talk about stressing a party out. We were celebrating a birthday and their impatience really dampened the birthday girl's experience. 

** AMBIANCE
I knew this place is usually loud but even reservations for the semi-private room could not provide a moment of quiet to hear the companion sitting next to me, due to the constant blast of loud music and drunk chatting from other patrons. 

** THE FOOD
The rolls were unimaginative and mediocre, at best, for a place that does not rely on freshness or quality of the fish. I also ordered many hot appetizers as to avoid ordering too many rolls and sushi. However, the yakitori was inexcusably overcooked and dry, the gyoza was bland, and the chicken karaage was average and sadly, the best dish of the night. 

I've been to modern japanese restaurants where patrons frequent for the fun and up-beat ambiance, alcoholic drinks, and late-night sushi - and it worked (check out The Eatery in Vancouver), but unfortunately, Ryoko is not one of them. 

I don't understand what all the hype is about..
author: Lily S.

description: We came late at night. The sushi didn't taste that good at all. Very old and not fresh at all. My friend got sick and had the runs the next day. I would highly recommend not to go here.
author: Mike N.

description:
They don't accept reservations but luckily my bf and I were able to get our bums outta our hotel room and out for dinner at a decent time. We arrived around 15 minutes after opening and lots of people were seated already! Service was greeaaatt; food came out fast; dirnks came fast (and were good and strong except beer glass wasn't cold); and food was great!

I MUST mention the chicken karaage was the best. Order it!
Skip the beef teriyaki.
Skip the grilled rice ball. Not sure why I ordered it but there's something about rice I cannot resist.
Seaweed/kelp/cucumber salad was good too.
Yellowtail was fresh and cut perfectly.
I forget which rolls we ordered but trust that they will be fresh!

Would love to come here again, and go to Cantina nearby for drinks after. This was the perfect evening, and I'm glad we got here early enough. Within 30 minutes of opening, parties were waiting already. The place is dim, and we left before music came on. Thanks for a great food experience!
author: T N.

description: We stopped here for dinner and I wasn't too impressed. Based on the rolls that I had, it didn't distinguish itself from any other sushi place. The quality of the fish is good (especially the salmon) and the rolls were delicious but nothing special. I'm giving this place three stars mainly because everything here is overpriced. I was especially upset about how overpriced ochazuke was here. They were charging $6.50 for ochazuke, which was baffling to me because it's only rice in green tea with toppings and pickled vegetables. It is a very simple food that involves hardly any cooking and costs almost nothing. I felt like Ryoko's was taking advantage of customers who don't know the real cost of Japanese cuisine. Coming from Japan, this was really upsetting to see. Also, my boyfriend's brother had the gyoza here and it was dripping in oil. It was hard to eat.
author: Hana K.

description: Simply amazing!!! I had a party of four and we had to wait about 45 minutes for a table, but wow was it great. Super fresh and totally worth the time we spent in line.
author: Jason R.

description:
This place is on a hill. You'll have to walk either up or down the hill in order to get here. 

However, the restaurant itself is, in fact, level. But enough about elevation. The level I'd really like to discuss is one of musical quality.  Ryoko's plays the kind of music that throbs in the mind of a sorority girl puking in a night club bathroom.
author: Duna L.

description: Very nice legit japanese joint!  we went around 7 on a Friday and didn't have to wait luckily.  Thei fish was all very good and fresh.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Advice: get a reservation at the sushi bar.  I was seated with full view of Atsushi's station, and it was amaaazing to watch the nigiri come to life.   Amongst the orders were saba (mackerel), hamachi toro and o toro- freshest of the fresh.  Hot appetizers such as fried chicken and beef intestine soup was also a great way to start the meal.  We didn't go for any rolls, but there are plenty of Western-style choices for those who don't really dig nigiri. Maybe next time I'll go for the volcano roll with Skippy :)   

Believe me, no stuffiness here- there was a really chill beat from the DJ booth on a baby grand piano. In addition to the unbelievable food and service, the ambience is fun, loud, friendly, and young.  Bring on the sochu!
author: Miran C.

description: The food was really good, totally enjoyed it. During the weekend the service was a bit slow but you cannot blame the waiters, they were working like crazy. It was a little quieter during the week.
author: Anni T.

description: Wow! At a conference this week and had a taste for Sushi. Happened upon this place and at first glance was a bit concerned but once inside the place was packed with a 40 min wait. sunday evening at 8:30 so the place had to be good. Had a couple of rolls one with peanut butter and jalapeno's with some Fatty Tuna on top...Outstanding. All around great vibe and fantastic sushi.
author: Bob D.

description: what an awesome place!!! when we entered they greeted us screaming, I couldn't tell what they said but it meant "welcome". the place itself is not great, the setup I mean. It doesnt look like a sushi place, I think it use to be a jazz place. my 5 stars review is all about the food. Simply perfect! not cold sushi, but natural temperature, very fresh, very tasty. The best: The sexy rolls with melted cheese on top.
author: Pablo M.

description:
Show up a little bit before they open at 6 pm or you will be waiting. I went on a Friday night and there were 20 + people waiting. 

Sushi is great, service is great, I would come back!
author: Brendan A.

description: I am not a sushi connoisseur.  For that matter I really don't even like sushi.  Given that my co-worker was dying to satisfy a sushi craving I couldn't crash the party.  Despite my lack of interest in raw fish wrapped in white rice, I thought the atmosphere was outstanding and the wait staff was perfectly pleasant and attentive.  The seaweed salad was awesome, and some of the rolls were admittedly tasty.  If I have to eat sushi, I would love to revisit Ryoko's while in San Francisco.
author: Carter C.

description:
3.5 stars mainly for awesome nigiri, but not so great rolls. 

The atmosphere is interesting...there is a DJ right across for the bar, and most people are getting their sushi on before a night out on the town. I think there was also a bachelorette party at the same time that we were there. 

All in all, I think the sushi is good, but not good enough to compensate for the loud and at times, obnoxious, crowds.
author: Alison C.

description: Such a busy little restaurant! The long wait time was totally worth it. The sushi absolutely fresh and tasted amazing. We took the recommendation of our server and got the 49er roll... greatest.decision.ever! One of the best rolls I have ever eaten... so definitely a winner!
author: Meagan T.

description:
Trek up a hill... Check
Man peeing on side of Ryoko's.. Check
Walk into Ryoko's and get a warm Japanese welcome... Check

Interesting place with a (baby) grand piano with a LARGE skull on top of it. Food was great. The Japanese saba just melts in your mouth. Fish was super fresh with different types of rolls that I have not seen in other Japanese spots. Fun atmosphere. Loud music. Great service.
author: Linda L.

description:
Thanks Yelpers, for another great neighborhood recommendation.

The sushi's terrific, the prices are reasonable and the vibe is fun. Now, really, when is the last time you went to a fun sushi bar?

I also liked that a lot of single folks were sitting at the bar and chatting with each other. 

I'll definitely be back!
author: Kim C.

description: Very satisfied with the quality of fish. Fun and small place to come for dinner and always busy. The soy sauce is also above average if you're into that. :)
author: m K.

description: Came to Ryoko's after researching restaurants near the Golden Gate Theater.  Yelp reviews were good, so we had dinner prior to the show.  Got there just before 6:00pm so there was no wait for a table.  The space reminded me of the underground restaurants you find in New York and Boston which is cool, however it does get quite warm in the restaurant.  First thought when looking at the menu was that they do not use real crab.  Half the rolls use the fake crab.  In my mind that immediately put them in the lower tier of sushi restaurants.  We tried chicken karaage (best dish), Ochazuke with salmon (not bad), Toro, Sake and Hamachi nigiri (Meh-bland taste), Jumping Unagi roll (OK), and Spicy Scallop roll (not spicy, pretty slimey). With tax and tip, bill came in at about $35/person.  By the time we left, there was a line up the steps.  I personally would not go back because there was nothing outstanding on the menu besides the chicken karaage, and there are so many more sushi places to try.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to check this place out on a Thursday night. When we walked in, we noticed we had to sign in on this clipboard that was just hanging around. Don't know if that's common in San Francisco or not. It was kind of weird to me to not be greeted by a host/hostess.

Anyway, they couldn't really tell us how long the wait was going to be. Turns out we waited like 45 minutes..........

I thought I was going to pass out from how hungry I was.

We finally got our table and ordered 4 different rolls. We weren't impressed by ANY of them. They either sucked or were okay at best. I thought it would be the most amazing sushi I ever had the pleasure to eat, being that I waited around for almost an hour just to be seated. And the pricing just isn't worth the quality.

This place sucked! I'm pretty sure my boyfriend and I will never come back here.
author: Sandra N.

description:
Where can I eat sushi with peanut butter and listen to Drake club mixes?  Here.

The wait was out of control (one chick actually had a laptop out and was doing homework), but you can order beers from the bar in the mean time and then bring them to your table.
The place is small, crowded, but kinda cool.  And there's a legitimate DJ.  Funny.
We ordered a few things - kinda expensive for how small the portions were - but it all tasted good.  
The Volcano Roll has peanut butter in it.  For $13 dollars I would have preferred it to contain more peanut butter and be much larger, though.  
It's loud as shit in here, like a "drunk girls screaming about how it's their birthday but shut up they don't want anyone to know it's their birthday" sort of thing.  I noticed I was clearly shouting at my friend's face for her to hear me.  
Cute guys eat here.
All in all, it's a lot better quality than most restaurants downtown.
author: Rachelle P.

description: Sushi is so so, sashimi is not fresh for sure. The waitress are annoying and not well trained. Wouldn't recommend. My first time to go there and the last time
author: Cecilia Chen Z.

description: I've been eating at this place for the past three years and used to love it. It is one of the few sushi places that are open past midnight but the quality of their food and service have been decreasing over the past 6 months. I tried it 4 times over the past few months and each time had to justify their poor quality and service by considering it as their one-in-a-few bad nights. They have omitted several of their popular rolls and deserts from their menu, increased their prices and cut on the number of their waitress. It is definitely not my favorite place anymore and I will not come back again. Sorry Ryoko, I had so many good memories at your restaurant  I still can't believe how much you have changed over the past year. Why?
author: Reza F.

description:
I can't speak for the price of this place as I'm used to sushi costing around $40-50 per couple with a few rolls and a few appetizers, but wow what a gem of a find!

If you blink, you might miss this non-flashy entrance on the side of Taylor street where you might not even think much is there. This is more of a basement restaurant sort of, so you do end up walking down a flight of stairs prior to which you will hear lots of people screaming a welcome to you from below. They have a full bar area and they're open late, which is amazing for a sushi place, granted it is in the city. The prices are reasonable and the sushi is delicious. Surprisingly delicious actually, and they even have an ankimo appetizer which is worth checking out as it is pretty delicious!

The atmosphere tho was what got me the most since it was very hip, dark, and kind of club-ish, great for dinner dates and after-bar hang outs for sure!
author: Lorrie M.

description: The sushi is good but definitely don't believe the hype. The sushi is good, step or two above your average 3 star spot but not even in the same ballpark as the better sushi spots. Not sure what these 5 star reviewers are smoking but it must be clouding their judgement. Anyway, it's fresh, yes. Sit at the bar and have the man recommend you some funky stuff. Solid spot but the long lines and hype make this place just overrated.
author: Paul A.

description: Can I give extra stars?? This place is amazing!!! The most fresh sashimi I've ever had.. Uni and hotate are a must try. however, expect a long wait on date nights (Fridays and saturdays)...overall this place is officially my most favorite sushi restaurant in the city
author: Wallace W.

description:
Dining at Ryoko just makes me feel like I've discovered a hidden gem, even though they have over 500 reviews. Is it because it's subterranean? Is it because it seems more like a dive bar and less like a sushi bar? Is it because my seat had me hidden under the staircase like I was P Diddy trying not to be noticed. (Wait. Does P. Diddy ever try not to be noticed? Perhaps replace that image with a different celebrity that does remain incognito.)

A group of us gathered here for dinner on a weekday night and the service for us was quite nice. Perhaps having a reservation helped for that? We immediately got to ordering a wide selection of sushi rolls and appetizers. I think everyone at our table picked two, which meant we had more sushi than a small country would need to fill up. While I can't remember all (or really any) of the names I know we had spicy versions and the "jumping" rolls and something with peanut butter in it. I personally am not a big fan of peanut butter and fish, but hey we've all got different tastes my friends.

The fish was fresh, the rolls were creative, and my plum wine helped me forget all the names of things we ate, so I know it must have been a pretty, pretty good time.
author: Tiffany N.

description: If you are in the city this place is the best! Quality quality! Every time I visit San Fran this is my go to.
author: J G.

description: Food is not bad but the place smells like you are in the bathroom. The service is pathetic. I ordered edamame and she brought it cold from the fridge! Then while I was still eating she asked me if I would order anything else. Then I ordered green tea ice team and had to wait for 15 minutes to get it. She brought it melted and with a dirty spoon!!
author: G. W.

description:
After having had fresh sushi and I mean FRESH tuna and other sea foods at 6am at Tsukiji Fish Market when those sushi bars open in Tokyo, when I lived there a while back, I was forever changed in my approach to sushi! I was headliner at Maduro Lounge at the Grand Hyatt Roppongi Hills and after I came back to the USA, it was very difficult for me to eat sushi in SF or anywhere in the Bay Area for a few years! After being an avid fan of sushi restaurants PRE-Tokyo experience, I believe I have only eaten about 3 sushi places since 2008.

But on Wednesday night, I just discovered Ryoko's place!! OMG!! From the delicious whole (they're small) anchovy-like Spanish mackeral in vinegar with red onions and peppers to the Jumping Tuna roll with it's perfectly light & crispy Tempura coating to their White Tuna Belly special to finale with the SPECTACULAR Waygu Beef handroll (a SPECIAL creation by Gin our Sushi chef) it was an amazingly wonder re-discovery of sushi for my palette! Even the edamame tasted better, sweeter!

Thank you Ms. Ryoko-san...I hope to meet you in person next time I come in! You DEFINITELY have a new fan!!
Carmen Milagro
www.milagromusic.com
author: Carmen M.

description:
Why do people eat sushi?

Most would say freshness. Some would say variety. Others truly enjoy the mouthfeel of buttery or fatty sushi. A select few would say the esoteric varieties that you can't find everywhere.

This place literally hits all the criteria. And it's open late! As Japan's original beer food, who could argue with that logic?

Prices are reasonable for some of the best sushi you can get in the city.

Kurobuta sausages look like fingers and taste like ultra fatty hot dogs. Shit is so cash.
author: Ben T.

description:
I really wish I could give five stars for the food/ambiance, and -5 stars for the "DJ" who was playing on my last visit. 

Boyfriend and I stopped in recently... I hadn't had a good sushi fix in awhile and was so excited. Ryoko's really is one of the TOP sushi destinations in the Bay Area. It's always fresh, they have a wonderful array of different rolls in addition to the standard fare, and the whole atmosphere takes me back to my days in Tokyo. I would say it's a pretty authentic experience all around, with the exception of the massive selection of maki.

So anyway, we walk in on a Tuesday night around 10pm, put our names on the list. As we are waiting, we are suddenly assaulted by the music playing on the house sound system. Not only was it WAY too loud for an eating establishment, but it was DUB STEP. I look around and see that there's a DJ sitting at the piano standing behind a couple of CD-J's, but playing music from an iPod. I immediately wanted to strangle him, but instead I ordered some Saki and pounded it, hoping to drum up enough of a buzz to stop caring that my much-anticipated sushi-gasm is about to be ruined by the worst music ever to be created by mankind.

After about 30 minutes of cracking death-to-the-DJ jokes and wincing at the increasingly bad musical choices coming up in the background, we were finally seated at the bar. More Sake please. STAT. As we made our way through our dining experience, nearly having to yell at each other over the poop-fest invading our ear drums, this DJ decides to throw on some TRAP. As if Dub Step wasn't the most inappropriate choice of music to accompany one's meal, Trap is probably the second most inappropriate. What, am I suddenly going to hop up in the middle of my meal to start popping and locking to this guy's crappy set? Not like he was actually doing any mixing with that ipod action, so I'm not sure he deserves to use the term DJ.

As far as the food, everything we had was great. The American roll is an adventure in fusion - it's a kind of roll topped with baked salmon and american cheese. It kind of tastes like someone put velveeta all over my California Roll, but I can't necessarily say it was bad. Just weird.

Also, the takoyaki was just okay. Back in Japan, I remember it having small bits of squid in the center of a golf-ball-sized fluffy dough ball, but at Ryoko's it was more like a large chunk coated in 1/4 inch of batter, shaped like a sphere. Definitely more chewy than fluffy. The sauce and mayo just weren't quite the same either.

This may very well be my last trip to Ryoko's without a large group to distract me from the awful background music. Or maybe I'll just bring some earplugs along.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Love this place.  I don't come here often enough.

We arrived at 740 and got seated right away, but 15 minutes later there was a line out the door and at around 820 the line was probably 20 deep.  So arriving a bit earlier or later makes a huge difference.

Friend and I came here this past weekend and I now I can't stop thinking about their salmon skin rolls, fresh uni and toro!  Forgot exactly which toro we got, but it was the best one recommended by the server and totally worth it; it pretty much melts in your mouth.

All the rolls I've tried are great.  They're smaller in size which means you get to try more out.  Between the two of us I think we polished off 4 rolls, 3 sashimi selections, and an appetizer.  As for drinks there were a couple order of sake and soju.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Really great sushi, sashimi is super fresh. I like this place a lot but it can get very pricey,especially when your super hungry. They have live dj and open till really late. Great spot with friends.
author: anna w.

description: Good sushi & sashimi, with a nice list of specials (some of which were relatively spendy). Service was fantastic, sitting at the sushi bar. I would definitely come back here if I was looking for late night dining in the city.
author: Jeff M.

description:
In general, this is a good sushi place, but for late night, it's a great spot.  It's just off of the main late night strip on Geary so parking is less challenging, but that's still relative.  This is probably one of the better sushi joints that you'll find around midnight.

It can get warm descending into the "dungeon" as Shiho called it, but that just means it's a good spot for sushi in the winter.  Everything is good and it's a cool place to hang out late.  The DJ's are cool and so is the vibe of the servers.  I always love it that when anyone comes or goes, everyone shouts out salutations in Japanese.

Definitely get what's fresh on the daily specials.
author: Dylan T.

description: 5 stars for excellent food but make sure to come early as it fills up super quit! Plan on standing awhile because there is no area besides the stairs and outside to wait for your table... My advice order a beer or cocktail from the bar while you wait to make time go by faster!!!
author: Ashley H.

description: Great place. Long wait. Fresh Sashimi. Okay Rolls. That's about it. I left unsatisfied though. Didn't want to spend too much money savoring the sashimi so I ordered a few rolls. Did not like the rolls. I agree with other reviews that I couldn't see why this place got so popular.
author: Hoang D.

description: Wow!  We arrived shortly after 6:00.  We were seated, immediately, at the sushi bar.  Our waitress was FANTASTIC!!  The sushi was superb.  We had the blue fin and hirame  sashimi, monkfish liver, Volcano roll, Alcatraz roll, Tiger roll, blue fin tekka and the pot stickers.  All were amazing.  I highly recommend this sushi restaurant.
author: Dominique R.

description: Great fresh sushi, reasonably priced. Atmosphere is very casual; come for the food, not the ambiance!
author: Farrell K.

description:
Excellent sushi!

Really don't need to say much more than that...  the only down side may be the limited seating.
author: Gregory D.

description:
Went there because of all the good reviews but was very disappointed. The sushi is not that great, nor fresh. The restaurant doesn't feel very clean. 

Definitely not worth the wait.
author: Roxy C.

description:
Solid sushi. The rolls seemed on the smaller side, but nevertheless they were good.
I attended a birthday party here and we sat at one of the large group tables in the back. 2 of the seats at the table were broken. We discovered that one of them was broken before anyone got hurt, but our waiter found out the hard way that another was broken and nearly fell over when it broke. It was a pretty embarrassing scenario, and having broken furniture for guests to sit down on is rather irresponsible. They were obviously moments from falling apart if someone stopped to take a look.

I also thought it was unfortunate that the route to their tiny upstairs restroom was such a pain. Everyone's tables are so close together that you pretty much can't help but bump into people or have them scoot in to get buy. I imagine it would be a real annoyance to be seated in that area.

As I said, solid sushi, but I wouldn't say I'd go out of my way to return.
author: Katie S.

description:
I had a nice little dinner hear for my friends going away dinner.  It's a nice little "hole in the ground" that kind of reminds you of a club with its decor.  While we were eating there was a live DJ playing music.

Jumping Spicy Tuna Roll - The roll is deep fried and comes with its own sweet and spicy sauce.  

Dragon Roll - The Dragon roll is my "safe" roll I usually order when I try new places because I know they can't mess up.  Ryoko did not disappoint.  They top the rolls with huge portions of eel which was a delight.

Sake - I finally tried Sake served cold and let me tell you it is a lot smoother than the warm Sake.
author: Danny P.

description: The FOOD was good but we sat near the men's bathtoom where it wreaked of piss. May have been a better experiance besides that..
author: Mike C.

description: A little stuffy, but the sushi is totally worth it! The Spicy Golden Gate roll....drool.
author: Kaili K.

description: Came here for dinner on my girlfriend's birthday. The atmosphere is pretty cool. You walk down the stairs to the restaurant below street level and everybody shouts a greeting. The lighting is dim and it feels very cozy. We sat down and were helped out quickly. We ordered a Moro-Q (cucumber with miso sauce) appetizer, the Sashimi Dinner, and a Pokemon Roll. The Moro-Q was okay, tasty, but the miso sauce was not my favorite kind of flavor. The Pokemon Roll was also just okay, the flavor is very light and rice-y. The sashimi however was good, and noticeably fresh. We also ordered a glass of wine and a small bottle of Sake. We were in a bit of a rush to make a show time, so we probably didn't have a chance to enjoy it as much as we could have, but it was a good dinner. The main downside to this place is the hefty bill you'll acquire, but it's still alright for special occasions =).
author: Jefferson L.

description:
We came twice for my friend's birthday . It is a cool place. We ordered chirashi , volcano roll,the sexy mama, smoked salmon and more! 
The fish is so fresh, and sauce is yummy. When we went last time. This place was super busy so the service was limited. So I have to deduct 1 star for service oooops!
author: Typee L.

description: Somehow we got a seat right when we came in, but it filled up five minutes after we got there, and the line out the door was ridiculous. No idea why everyone was so eager to eat here. Sadly we didn't have the greatest experience. Our server was stressed the hell out. Everyone working was dashing around doing God knows what -- it took forever to get everything -- menus, drinks, our food, even the bill. And the food -- what a disappointment. Way overpriced for the TINIEST little rolls. Ten dollars for five bite size pieces of fish and rice?! Nope, nope and nope. Three stars because the food was edible and nothing about the service was rude or ridiculous or anything... It was just whatever. What's up with the rave reviews? No clue.
author: Elle T.

description:
A solid 3 to 3.5. The atmosphere was fun and the crowd was nice. No reservations are taken so you basically arrive, put your name on a list, and seated in order. Applies to the Sushi Bar as well. The wait was not long on a very crowed night. They managed time well moving folks in and out. 

Food was good. Not particular large or small portons, but everything was fresh. A few small mistakes, never did get my rice and another appetizer that was ordered. On this visit, avoided the rolls and focused mostly on sashimi / nigiri. Overall a good experience and would go back again.
author: Henry J.

description:
A true gem.
Ambience: Very crowded and you'll have to wait for a seat. But because of this it really does have a japanese feel to it. Certainly shouldn't judge it from the pokey outside.
Service: Very good. Though its a little odd to get a waitress who brings you your sushi while you're sitting at the sushi bar.
Food: I came here with a friend and we shared an assortment of rolls and nigiri. Very fresh, imaginative and tasty. Still, I'm used to having free miso soup which was not the case here as other places.
Price: Very respectable.
Goes to the top my list of sushi joints in downtown SF.
author: Geoff A.

description: I was in SF for a day trip and we stopped by here for dinner. The sashimi was AMAZING. The chef's selections include 14 slices of raw, fresh, delicious heaven. I also tried some of their rolls (including that famous Volcano roll), but I think the sashimi was by far superior. If you're craving some raw fish, drop by and you won't be disappointed!
author: Connie L.

description: This is a bar.  An expensive bar.  If you keep that in mind, then it's pretty nice. The food is expensive and in small portions.  The quality of the food is okay.  The music energetic.  The room is painted in ugly blue but I think that's makes it trendy.
author: Byron L.

description: This is a well-priced cute little sushi bar tucked away from the noisy downtown street. The sushi was fresh, the service was friendly except for our waters being empty for a little bit. I got the fatty tuna (yum), a yellowtail roll, and a spicy scallop roll. All three orders were delicious. Besides the staff yelling a greeting to everyone who walks in the door, the place is relatively quiet and intimate. Get there early, because around 8-9 at night a line starts forming out the door. However, we were never made to feel rushed.
author: Kat R.

description: Me and my wife decided to check out this little sushi bar because of all the good reviews we saw on yelp. Overall it was above average but nothing to spectacular. The restaurant reminded me of the sushi restaurants I see on tv because of the small and eclectic area. We were somewhat disappointed in the food because The sushi and sashimi we ordered was just okay, nothing spectacular like the reviews suggested.
author: Peter H.

description: By far one of the worst sushi places ever!!!!!!!! I have no idea how this place ranks so high. I've had sushi all over the west coast and this ranks at the bottom, if not THE very bottom.
author: Oz K.

description: Great atmosphere and fun vibe. Fish was fresh, service and prices were great. Not the greatest sushi in the world, but it's a fun spot and totally worth checking out. I'd go back in a heart beat.
author: Justin V.

description: Ryoko's is one of those places you avoid as someone who lives in the hood, but everytime you go you're glad you did. The rolls are fabulous, the sashimi is great quality...you can choose to eat down, but you can definitely choose to eat up. The party atmosphere is actually really fun. The only thing that bothers me about this place is the feeling that you're being a little pressured to move quickly because others are wating.
author: Monika M.

description:
This place is definitely under the category of hidden gem. I walk by this area all the time for the past year and a half and haven't noticed it once. I came here the other night on a Monday around 11pm and it was full with people. Luckily they had a table available and seated us right away.

The food is fantastic especially for the price, but their service was VERY slow. The waitress said it was because they only had two cooks on duty. I understand that maybe they weren't expecting to be full on a Monday so late at night, but still it took almost 45 minutes to get our food.
author: Andrew M.

description: Great little spot for sushi. They had a nice selection, including a few fried rolls, which my husband prefers. Although there was a little wait for a table, we were seated quickly and they never made us feel rushed once we sat down. Staff was friendly and it was a great experience.
author: Kelsey L.

description: I liked Ryoko's.. This place used to be my favourite Sushi place in the hood but after last night, I won't be back again. The quality of food has gone downhill dramatically. The beer on tap wasn't cold, fish on the sushi wasn't that fresh and the rice was just not done right... This place is still crowded and wait is quite long and I was one of those happy to wait crowd but no more... Service was disorganized too... I'm very disappointed that I have one less favourite sushi joint in SF...
author: Bomin K.

description:
My friend finally brought me here after raving about it so much.  Lucky for her, she was not mistaken.  Ryoko's actually serves the sashimi near room temp, which is how it should be done; so much more flavor can be tasted this way.  Here's what we had:

red snapper sashimi
giant clams
tomago nigiri
white tuna toro sashimi
hamachi sashimi
jumping tuna roll
hot tail roll
sapporo
more sapporo

All the sashimi was amazing, but for me, the toro really stood out.  The sushi was good too, but my recommendation is to order more from the white board specials, since they'll be the freshest.  I'm a sucker for tomago, so it gets no complaints from me.  The giant clams were tasty, but again, I'd rather spring for that toro; it's SO good.  All-in-all, an amazing dinner with a great friend.  I'm kinda craving as I write this...
author: Christopher L.

description: I am creating a yelp account so i can write a review for this place. Don't go there if you want real Japanese sushi and good service. I really expected good food here, however, most of what i wanted to order was already sold out or they just don't have it.  The sushi was sooooooo tiny. really? It was like my cousins pinky toe: extraordinarily tiny and falling apart! Nevertheless, we spent 1 hour waiting for our "feast". More like "famine".
author: Iris C.

description: It was our first time visiting San Francisco and we were craving for a late night dinner! We weren't really sure what we were in the mood for and just wanted to find something that was open on a weekday. I saw that this was rated high on Yelp and seemed walking distance so decided to check it out! It looked like it was dead from the outside, but it was actually very lively inside! Since it was open till 2 we weren't late. It was nice and crowded inside but we were seated right away and ordered. I forgot what we order but it was very delicious sushi! I just wish we had come during happy hour so we could've gotten MORE!
author: Mereen J.

description:
I was really impressed!!!!!

This place is small, but the way they set up the seating really utilizes the space.  Parking is easy after 6:00PM, and the staff is super friendly.  Plus plus plus, the music is awesome!! Think Rihanna, Britney Spears, Akon?? So lively, and such a cool spot.  

Now the sushi, was GREAT.  Huge pieces of fish in the rolls, and I loved everything.  SUPER FRESH FISH!  I can totally dig that.  

We got: 
- Alaskan A's 
- California Roll
- Big Mama 
- Hot Tail 

Everything was delicious, yes even the California Roll was yummy.  And 4 rolls was the perfect amount of food for 2 people.  

And clean bathrooms!!!

New fave nighttime sushi spot -- oh and did you notice?  It's open until 2:00AM.  Yup, 2 freakin' AM.  

Do it!
author: Cora L.

description: Maybe more like 3.5 stars. Good vibe, liked the decor and ambiance. It's actually a neat place. But sushi was just ok. I was expecting to be blown away.
author: Vol T.

description:
Tucked into Taylor Street, this unique little Japanese restaurant has a lot of good things going for it. 

Some of the Pluses:
- Convenient downtown location.
- Cheap, affordable, sushi rolls. 
- SUPER seaweed salad. 
- FULL bar. No specialty cocktail menu, but it's a nice alternative to sake and rice wine.
- Live DJ. Unlike Mas Sake, the music here isn't conversation stopping loud. Perfect volume and a nice background soundtrack  for sushi. 
- Cozy, comfortable, and cool. The restaurant's secluded spot underground creates a sexy, secretive atmosphere. Tables are close, but not claustrophobic and even on a busy night the space doesn't seem too crowded. 
- Fast and Friendly service. 
- LATE night hours! 

And only a few minuses:
- Dragon Roll. I'm usually a big fan, but their deep fried version of this specialty roll is disappointingly awful. 
- No reservations for the same day - call a day ahead if you need to secure a spot. 

Ryoko's is a gem of a restaurant. With it's scrumptious sushi and sexy atmosphere, I'm sure I'll quickly become a regular here!
author: Caroline J.

description:
This place started out a four star for three reasons: 1) freshness of sashimi and 2) generous portions of fish in the rolls and 3) they are one of very few sushi places that have a spicy tuna roll that uses whole chunks of tuna marinated in chili sauce (much better textural experience). 

I downgraded the place for  three key reasons.  1) the service was slow as they are terribly understaffed.  I think there was one waitress working the whole place with one helper and no host(ess). As a result, you waited for the food and waited even longer for the table.  2) the place is loud.  Not sure why they blast the house music because the place is small.  People have to talk over the music which makes for more noise.  Hard to enjoy conversation and the meal.  3) the dessert missed badly.  They had a wasabi mochi but there was no wasabi flavor.  it was seasame but the waitress insisted that it was wasabi.  Weird.  and the Fried ice cream had almost no ice cream.  it was like they melted the ice cream away and tried to back fill it with spray whipped cream.  Very poor execution.

I didnt take down points for the decor, but it is worth calling out.  Bad Bad Bad.  Dont mind that it is eclectic and a bit gritty, but the walls were painted a rich blue. Love the color but not for a restaurant.  There is not naturally occurring food that is blue, so the mind actually can register a drop in appetite when there lots of blue in a dining environment.  Personally I do find it less appetizing when food is presented in blue light or in a heavily painted blue room.  Not to all restaurants---go with a different color.  

I have had better sushi (especially for the prices they charge) and it really isnt worth the wait or dealing with parking in this area.  If you are around and want sushi, its OK, but not a standout.
author: Scott C.

description: Sushi wasn't bad, but wasn't amazing.  Not a huge selection of rolls like you can find in Dallas.   Place was very crowded and loud at 9 pm at night
author: Kendra D.

description: Absolutely terrible. Maybe I came on an off night but the waitress gave us the wrong order, then when we told her we ordered something else, she rolled her eyes and took back the food. When the right food came out, she accidentally spilled water on my friend and didn't even apologize. Ridiculous. :/
author: Yu T.

description: Menu so little, drink menu so little. No japanese menu, not a real japanese restaurant. Server don't speak japanese. It's a japanese restaurant for Americans. Never go again.
author: Shin T.

description:
Overall a 4.5 --

The sushi here is some of the best I've had. I usually order nigiri that's caught that day or been "flown" in that day from Japan and it never ceases to amaze me. Their special rolls are decent as well.. My favorite by far is the 49ers roll.

The vibe is sceney and the music is usually electronica/dance-ish. Often times they bring in a DJ who sets up on top of the baby grand piano. He never plays that loud though. 

Ryoko's would have received a full 5 star rating, but they don't take reservations and if you don't get there early enough (before 715pm) you should expect to wait at least 20 minutes and sometimes up to an hour and a half. It's worth it though - they take drink orders while you wait for seats so it makes the standing/waiting a little more bearable. 

Sometimes the service is questionable, especially if they seat you near one of those pillars that hides you from their view. The sushi always makes up for everything though, which is why I keep coming back!
author: Vamsi T.

description: The best freaking avocado sushi and vegetable sushi in the city.. I went through all the sushi places in san francisco in 2008-2009 and this is the place I settled for for my avocado roll cravings.. I ate there every evening for 3-4 months and every evening i would be eager to eat the food, never got bored.. I had to stop because the white rice and starch was taking its toll on my body.. but if you are looking for japanese dont look further.. second place is Maru Sushi on powell st. but not even close to these guys.. although I can not say much about other real sushis here.. and their mushroom sushi never impressed me much.. and its very busy every day even late at night.. and so its hard to get the waitors attention.. sometimes I had to wait like 20 minutes just to get someone to bring my credit card back.. but 5 stars anyways!!!
author: Nihit S.

description:
My friend told me this place is really good so I picked this place for a little reunion I was planning. It is also only 2 blocks away from where I live

Three of us arrive around 6.30pm and was given a table by the front. The place has dim lighting and blue walls. The decor looks more like a bar than a Japanese restaurant. The only thing Japanese about it was the waitresses. The walls had photos of Elvis and there was a grand piano right in the middle of the restaurant. I thought it was slightly hard to maneuver around. 

My friend order a straight soju while I ordered a soju with lemon soda? My drink was pretty good. My friend's drink was kind of strong. The other two of our party arrived and we ordered to share. I believe we ordered
California roll, shrimp symphony, caterpillar roll, some roll with cheese on top, 3 oysters, at 1.90 each.

The sushi was alright but it was definitely not enough food for all of us.

We did another round where my friend got miso and we ordered a rainbow roll. Also got a beer and another soju. I don't know what the soju is called but it was disgusting. 

Our bill came up to 101 dollars. I could probably have eaten an entire plate of sushi still. I was still hungry. 

I would not come back here.

An update: I caught something from eating here and my friend was constipated the next day. So I'm changing the three stars to two stars.
author: Sarah C.

description: Really good. Order the fresh fish from Japan. Fried tofu is great too. Service is not bad. Don't let the decor fool you. Worth it.  I will come back.
author: Kenneth B.

description: Awesome food and quick service. Visiting from out of town and the reviews were right on. If you're staying in town near Union Square this is a must. I had the marinated scallop roll and yellowtail....amazing!
author: Nik S.

description:
This isn't a super authentic sushi place. But it's a hopping joint that has good energy. It's almost kind of club-y. There are some fun rolls that include ingredients like peanut butter (which is surprisingly delicious), and appetizers that include cucumber with miso dip.

I'd say if you're looking for prime sashimi look elsewhere. If you're looking for fun rolls, hip, bustling vibe come here. The bar is fun, however the sushi chefs don't really take your order so you don't get the classic sushi bar experience in that sense. 

Overall yummy food as long as your expectations are set.
author: Shanee B.

description: Overrated. Came on vacation after being told this place was unreal. The service was quick, but the sushi was just a solid Meh. Not a huge selection of options, nothing original, and the servings were very small. The fish was decently fresh, but I wasn't blown away by any means. Definitely don't feel a need to return.
author: Lauren G.

description: The host was the one of the most crude people I have ever met. I have never been treated so poorly in my life. I have been on the service industry for over 10 years and this is by far my worst experience.
author: Jessica A.

description: I liked the atmosphere and how there is a DJ so it feels like you are eating a club.  The sushi was decent, not the best that I've had.  We got an assortment of rolls including 49ers, pokeman, volcano roll.  The roll size is a pretty small serving and you need about two rolls to get full.  We had a lot of fun sake bombing but the sake was a bit watered down.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I'll start off by saying that the service, though nice, was a bit slow. 

This was the best sushi I've ever had in the city. Get the halibut nigiri if they have it. Hotate, hamachi, sake, tam ago... all incredible. 

My new favorite spot for sure. The music is a bit loud, and it's pretty packed, so be safe and pad in a bit of wait time.
author: Matt S.

description: Really enjoyed the meal!  Felt like I was visiting Japan.  Be warned that the wait can be very long on Fri or Sat night.
author: Julianna H.

description: So good! Checkerboard sushi roll...on point. I almost don't want to post this review and keep it to myself. Total SF gem
author: Daniella Z.

description:
Went here for my girlfriends bday. She loved it and the sushi (this coming from a person that doesn't eat sushi). okay so lets get to the good the bad and the ugly:

The Good: 
Great little place! the music is awesome def enhances the time out and the food (never been to Asia but I would image a restaurant to be something like this)! The food is fairly priced to cheap. Totally forgot I was ever in the city! Felt like I had gotten an experience in a different culture it was cool! FOOD WISE: the sushi was indeed good! I don't think I order the correct dish because it went kind of fast lol. Wish i could tell you what was good but I didn't have enough food to say one was better than another.  The give you drinks of your choice while you wait!!!! The wait staff is so nice I love it!!!!! Much bigger then you originally think. Also thy stay open LATE! BUT! what we had we def enjoyed!

The BAD:
Well the wait was forever!!! If you go make a reservation or be there a bit early (we went pretty late saturday night). Not as big as I would like...kind of compacted. I didn't go but I think there is only one bathroom in there! No bueno!

ALL n ALL:
I would 100% give this place another try on a night out with friends so someone can drive and I can drink SAKE!!!!! hahahaha. This is a cool place if you want to experience something a little different that stays open LATE!!! Prices are fair and it's just a nice find! I approve.
author: marques b.

description: Waited for an hour in the cold to be seated . The sushi rolls are tiny , takes a long time to order and you don't get the same waiter .. overall this place is over priced and over rated !
author: Olivia K.

description: Excellent authentic Japanese food. Great staff!  Great service!  Will be making a return visit soon.
author: Chad R.

description:
It was pretty busy on a Sunday evening. 

We ordered the Agedashi Tofu and a few sushi rolls. The atmosphere was more heavy on the 'bar' then the 'restaurant'; there were people buzzed out playing on the piano. Service was not the quickest, but still prompt; it took longer to get the bill then most.

Overall thoughts : Decent sushi place. Food was fine, most importantly it tasted fresh.
author: Stephanie K.

description: A long wait in line for an average place. The location is not the best. They are in a basement of an old building with some old dirty black soot around of their entrance door!  Their food is okay, good presentation, but much more expensive compare to other good sushi bars.  Their service is slow, and you need to look out for a while, then flag them down to get attention.  We spent about $100 for two people having a couple of beers and two sashimi orders. I don't understand why this restaurant Is rated so high from other reviews.
author: Alex M.

description: Sushi was really good. Fish fresh. Small portions but price matches the portion size. The restaurant is underground.  Dark and cozy. Good music bumping. Definitely not a fancy place. Seemed like lots of locals.
author: Nina M.

description:
Great sushi spot for late night sushi in SF. There is parking down the alley next door to the place, which was nice for "out-of-towners" with a car. The sushi was good. There was a short wait to get seating, and then they took us to a back room that was very hot and humid with little or no air circulation. We sat on step stools, no cushion or backing and we waited probably 45 mins to get our food. The food was pretty expensive, but in SF, everything is expensive. Very tasty sushi and delicious sake. 

A converted basement, so everything is very close together and tight quarters, uncomfortable seating but everything else was delicious and that is what you are paying for.
author: Xen G.

description:
It's a small restaurant and every time i enter it feels like i've been transported back to japan (sorta). since i'm not able to hop on a plane to japan whenever i feel like it, ryoko will be my go-to for sushi. reasons bulleted below:

- their rolls are pretty good, but i go for the nigiri style sushi. the fish to rice ratio is good and the fish is fresh
- they also have specials for fish (but they tend to run out very quickly)
- they torch some of nigiri which makes the fish even more buttery and melt in your mouth good
- the bf likes coming here because they have $12 pitchers.
author: Kimberly F.

description:
Great place for food and drinks after work, and pretty close to Union Square.  There were five of us altogether, but I would recommend only coming here with a max of four people in your party, since the cozy space doesn't allow much wiggle room.  Reservations are highly recommended, unless you like waiting on staircases.

Food:
Edamame - complimentary, but very tasty!
Agedashi Tofu - pretty good.
Tempura - pretty good.
Spicy Scallop - my favorite! Not a fan of shiso, but it was pretty good in this roll.
Hot Tail - delicious.
49'er - my second favorite!

There are probably some other orders we had that I'm missing, but I think that those were the highlights.


Drink:
Hot sake was great. Pitchers of Sapporo were great.  Difficult to get water, easy to get beer.
author: Erica D.

description:
BOMB...and I don't throw that term around lightly when it comes to food!

Not only is this place affordable, its delicious. Like you crave it all the time delicious. Like I would drive 4 hours to get there just to eat at this place, then turn back around and go home delicious. 
Sometimes there's a wait, but sitting at the bar is pretty entertaining,
watching the guys make sushi and getting out the blow torch.

Favorites: Agedashi Tofu ($5), Tomato salad (5.95) the dressing makes all their salads so really any of them are going to be good, jumping california roll ($7.50), Tiger roll ($8), 49ers roll (13.50) Sake: Nigori ($10)

Best part is they are open LATE LATE LATE 
oh and they have a dj.
author: Celine F.

description: Meh... The sushi was bland and the service was blah. I ordered the 49ers roll, the Alaska roll and the teriyaki chicken. None of them blew my mind and I probably wouldn't order them again. They need flavor. I had high expectations for this place but was let down. In a city that's full of such great sushi and amazing restaurants, I wouldn't waste your time here.
author: Kristin H.

description: In town for vacation, yelped to look for a sushi bar and it lead me to this place.  Went to check it out and was pleasantly surprised.  The atmosphere is very busy.  In house DJ, pretty awesome.  Such a cool vibe and great food!  The wait could be 15min to an hour depends if you're lucky!  I would definitely come back the next time I'm in town.
author: Leslie M.

description:
This place make me giggle !!
i only go there for their sushi and nigiri because they are so damn fresh and melt in your mouth. I don't mind working my butt off just to save enough money to let those TORO melt in my mouth .....
author: elly l.

description:
A regular sushi joint in my books.

Place kind of smelled like a bar the next morning after a raging party, which is kind of a turn off for me personally. Sushi was good, but not amazingly fresh and delicious so I don't really get what all the hype is about. Prices were also pretty steep. 

Didn't have a bad experience per se, but I've definitely had better, fresher sushi for less.
author: Ashley V.

description: Delicious and fresh - I tried to chef's choice sashimi plate. The line is very long as the space is small, so make sure to account 20 minutes of wait time before being seated.
author: Gina H.

description:
WHITE TUNA TORO! OMG...*drool*

I'm not a huge fan of toro because sometimes its oily tasting to me. But the white tuna toro I guess isnt as fatty.  It was super fresh and just melted in your mouth. Delish!  This place isnt your typical, proper Japanese place.  It rocks the whole place (which isnt that big) with loud music. So if you're trying to go on a date and have a conversation, this might not be the place. This place gets extremely packed. So if you can make a reservation, I would highly suggest it.
author: Gina S.

description:
Good for smaller parties. (2-3)

Ambiance is good if you don't mind getting cozy with your party.  Otherwise avoid bringing people whose personal space you don't want to get into. Dimly lighted restaurant.

The appetizer's offered here are great.  They have a great selection from surf to turf for the appetizer's.  The monkfish liver was new to me and took two additional bites before it grew on me.  Fried baby octopus was fantastic as was the seared steak. Oysters were fresh and well sized.

Sashimi was underwhelming.  Sashimi cuts were very small when ordered through the "Sashimi dinner".  Can't lie about being slightly disappointed when I was served.  And the sashimi was just ok.  However, the saba and maguro sashimi were some of the best I have had; they were very fresh.  The Nigiri however, was much better.  The cuts were fantastic on the nigiri.  

Hot house sake is sweeter in comparison to what I have had in other sushi restaurants.

Service is fine.  Could see how tight quarters and abundance of customers might make some people dissatisfied with service, but those severs work.

Be careful on your way out the door.  Half way step catches everyone off guard. Almost fell.  Lawsuit waiting to happen?
author: Alejandro A.

description:
Just came back here yesterday with the gf for dinner
we arrive before opening time because i know this place gets really packed
i finally ordered the chirashi. IT WAS GOOD!
but for $30? i dont know.... a little too pricy
gf order the hamachi roll... "so soft, melts in your mouth"
and the philly, forgot what she said , but she like both
i ordered the fried oyster a tad late and i think the kitchen got backed up
so we didnt get our fried oysters till after i was finished with my chirashi
fried osyters were pretty good. i prefer fresh, kinda kills the flavor by frying it

overall great dinner
willing to come back except the location is kinda difficult due to parking
and prices are a little up there.
author: Andi I.

description:
I always see long lines outside this restaurant, so decided to give it a try.

Tried following:
Amaebi heads: deep fried, very crunchy, different.
Ochazuke: this is a rice soup. I had much better ones in other Japanese restaurants. 
Orange delight: sushi wrapped by salmon outside, it is good! 
Toro and Amaebi sashimi: the best sashimi. It melts in your mouth. It is so good, next time I come here, I will just order this, nothing else! 

The restaurant is in a very narrow space underground, it is dark. The staff is constantly yielding something, quite noisy. But the Toro and  Amaebi sashimi just made all worth it!
author: Emmy P.

description:
I escorted my parents into Ryoko's for a dinner because I know they just like simple, unfussy food. Although I had a really good time, I know that much of this was because my parents are just really cool and we were all in a good mood. So therefore I will try to separate this positive bias from the characteristics of the food and restaurant. 

First, we waited a long time to even be acknowledged when we first descended the stairs to the restaurant, so one star there. The place wasn't super crowded, but the hostess just seemed frazzled. She took us to a back area that my parents looked uncomfortable in due to the really low tables and chairs. It was like Alice in Wonderland and we suddenly all grew oversized. 

The hostess sensed our discomfort and offered to move us to a booth, but it was awkwardly placed next to an empty 4-person table that remained empty for most of the meal. It was a Wednesday night and they didn't have too many people pouring in...I think they could have given that larger table up for us. But whatever, like I said - we were in a good mood. 

My dad, the real estate broker, kept raving about how rare it is for a Japanese restaurant in San Francisco to have a full liquor license. All that means to me is  - shots and sushi together?? Awesome. 

In terms of ambience, the space looks like it was definitely a divey bar at some point and not much has been done to change it into a sushi-feeling place. But that makes it actually much more unique. 

We tried the jumping tuna roll thanks to a former Yelp review and really enjoyed it. Actually, all of the rolls we tried were yummy, but the tonkatsu appetizer was waaay dry. 

We were happy and full leaving the restaurant, but later my mom ended up ordering a huge plate of garlic fries and my dad scarfed an apple pie at Lori's. Maybe that was a sign that we weren't fully satisfied?
author: Christina P.

description: Food is decent, but not worth the 1 hr wait to be seated and the awful club music pounding in a small place.
author: Tallymia S.

description: Please go there when you are near union square ! If I am not mistaken, they get their fresh shipment every Tuesday and Friday. The sushi is seriously fresh and good. Make sure you make reservation if you have a large party.
author: Happymom T.

description:
For the BFF's birthday we made plans for dinner here. It was pretty easy getting reservations and I would really recommend doing so, because when  we arrived there was a massive line.

Parking was hard to find. I think they have their own little parking area but it was full so we had to drive around. In the end we just gave up and valet our car in the parking structure across the street. The original price was $30 but since parking was limited they raised their price on us to $50. 

Fun environment with good music, might not be for everyone but I honestly loved it.

The service was excellent but I was a bit disappointed in the sushi. The portions were pretty small and taste-wise...was mediocre. We might come back for drinks next time though.
author: Van N.

description: I loved this place. The sushi was so fresh and I loved everything I ordered- wakame-su, hot tuna, checkerboard roll, tempura.
author: Kathleen A.

description:
If you're in the area and want sushi, this is a pretty safe bet.  The prices are good, service could be way worse, and the fish was fresh.

They have a pretty wide menu selection, first Japanese restaurant I've been to that has fried cheese on the menu (they could just be mozzarella sticks, but I'm sure people who fear sushi appreciate it regardless).

I give this place 3 stars because "A - Ok" is a perfect description.  There's definitely nothing specifically wrong with Ryoko's, but there is also nothing spectacular about it.   Then again I am no expert sushi eater, one of my dishes was the unagi which is hard to mess up - but as I said, the quality was fresh and that makes me a happy girl.
author: Megan A.

description: I really wanted to give this place a better rating. But honestly, "meh - I've experienced better" couldn't be more of an accurate description. Went here tonight with two friends, one visiting from out of town, and was very put off by the smell of pee in the back corner of the restaurant. Granted, it was a warmer-than-usual day, and there were two fans blowing on us, but you know it's bad when you have to bury your nose in your lemon water to feel better. Although the food came out a bit on the slow side, the service was otherwise excellent. Food was great - we ordered quite a few rolls and appetizers - but probably not remarkable enough to entice me to come back anytime soon. Plus, we had three people and it would've been nice to have been told ahead of time that some rolls came in pieces of five, others came in pieces of six. The pee smell eventually went away, to be replaced by a chemical smell. Regardless, when I think back to my dinner experience at Ryoko's, unfortunately, I can't help but think of the off-putting odors   .
author: Dianna H.

description: good food and atmosphere :) Prices were a bit high for my taste but its downtown SF so what do you expect right? The food was a little slow to come out but the waitress was attentive and warned us beforehand that the sushi would take awhile. It gets crowded fast so if you don't want to wait forever, you better get here early.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Kool G. Rap!!! Really??? Oh shit!!! I'm immediately a fan!

That's what I said to myself as I walked down the stairs to the sounds of a cheerful staff yelling their greetings to us and the poetry of one of my top 5 lyricists of all time pumping through the restaurants sound system. 

The vibe of the staffs energy, the music, the comfortable decor, and the thought of sushi and sake put me in a great mood. 

The sushi was awesome as well! The tuna at this place is great! You must have the 49er roll....so awesome. It's basically a California roll topped with tuna and salmon, but it's so fresh. Luckily we beat the dinner rush. As we made our way out, a line of people seated on the stairways leading up to the entrance had begun to form! Get there early if you don't want to wait.

 Good conversation, great company, a little too much sake, fresh sushi, awesome music....if I lived in the Bay Area, I would be there all the time!
author: Jay H.

description:
