This place is like a rave meets sushi bar. We came here the Thursday before Halloween and it was popping. 

I pretty much have nothing good to say about this place. The service was Horrible, it took forever to get our food. My man's chicken teriyaki came out before my sushi and it was COLD. My sushi tasted like it had raw jalapenos in it. Almost inedible. When we tried to modify our order, asking for only broccoli in the tempura, the waitress told us the cook was too busy and couldn't change anything. 

On top of all that, the music was so loud we had to scream to hear each other across the table - and listen to our neighbors conversation as well as they were only 7 inches away. 

Ya, not going back here =(
author: Rachel G.

description:
Definitely not your traditional sushi place, but don't think that means that the sushi will be low quality. Ryoko opened my eyes to how good sushi can be when it's super fresh and prepared well.

If you want to splurge, get the whole grilled squid, the sashimi combo, and a big bottle of Sapporo. The fish has been fresh when I've gone, but if that's really important for you, try to go on a Wednesday or Thursday. Ryoko's gets insanely busy on date nights, and you could easily spend an hour waiting for a table. Make sure to make reservations at least 24 hours in advance.

Later at night the music gets pretty loud.
author: Mike O.

description:
We grabbed dinner here before going ice skating at Union Square. Definitely within walking distance if you are shopping in the area and need a sushi fix. 

We ordered:
14 piece sashimi dinner that comes with a miso soup: The quality of fish was above average and each piece of fish had a different zest/flavor (lemon, ginger, spicy radish sauce...). The zest broke up what can be a monotonous dish (fish, fish, and more fish). The miso soup was good too - (it's miso soup so the quality cap is low) - but still no complaints. 

Spicy tuna roll was delicious - they put shiso (a type of mint-ish herb) in it, which gave the roll a unique kick at the end. 

We shared the Jumping Tuna roll as an appetizer - it was incredibly unique, delicious, and came with a sweet spicy sauce to dip the fried roll in. 

The seaweed salad was small for the price ($5) - but tasted good. 

We ordered a large hot sake followed by a small hot sake and green tea. Sake was good, but expensive for the quality. Tea was a little watered down for my taste but the refills kept coming which was great. 

Why this review didn't get 5 stars: 1) menu seemed poorly organized, lots of options, hard to wrap your head around what to order; 2) service was spotty - our sushi took 6 seconds to come out, the second sake took 3 yrs; 3) there was no apparent drink menu; they do have a full bar, but if we weren't seated directly in front of the bar we would've had no idea. 

If yelp allowed it, Ryoko's would get 4.5 stars -- the ambiance was warm and welcoming and the food delicious. Seeing 4.5 stars aren't allowed, I rounded down because of the negatives above. Definitely no deal breakers, just things that could be improved.  

Total was around $80 with tip.
author: Kimya P.

description:
A fun sushi place, especially if you're hosting out of towners since it's a little different with a full bar, DJ spinning on the piano top, and open super late. The first time I came here was in the mid-late '90s when my cousin brought me here after a night out. It must've been around 2:30am and there weren't too many people at the time. I was stoked about a late night sushi place, but more amazing was this--a few theater/show biz folks came in, someone sat down at the piano and a woman started crooning a few show tunes! I thought it was the best place ever! I also thought that's how every night was, but I don't think so. I haven't seen anyone playing the piano since, just the DJ there, which makes me sad. Let me know if this has changed at all!

Staff is always friendly but the place is tiny and gets packed fast (reservations recommended).
author: Sandra P.

description: My boy friend and I frequent this restaurant. It's one of our favorite sushi places. It's entrance is small and takes you below street level so be careful to not overlook it! The place is always packed and the music is always a flashback for me, in a good way. It's usually a bit of a wait for a table but the food is always worth it. It's so delicious. I also love the special they have occasionally called the potato croquette. The drinks are also pretty killer. Always tastes fresh and delicious.
author: Mallory C.

description: This place is in the tenderloins I must warn you.. If u don't mind bums sleeping in the street or asking you for pocket change.  This is definably a good late night sushi spot. This place can be easily missed if driving by.. I like that the staff is friendly upon arrival they also play house music in the background which makes this place more upbeat. I don't however like that the women's restroom is upstairs, but do try their Sexy roll it's orgasmic!
author: Marina R.

description: Meh, was definitely a cheap sushi joint.
author: Brandon K.

description:
I'm from the Midwest. 
I didnt even eat sushi until I was 22 years of age. 
I don't claim to know all that much, even now...
I visit SF semi-frequently. 
I must eat sushi on each trip. Requirement. 

What I do know, is that every time I venutre out this way...I eat at Ryokos. Sapporo on draft, peanut butta in the rolls, and smiles all up in this basement-chic sushi spot. It just makes me...happy. And obviously, a lot of others as well...as people wait in line for a seat. Always jumpin'. Make a reservation, if you please...or just wait on the steps. 

Yes, I realize a review from a Chicagoan concerning sushi is somewhat...tilted? However, I dig it on multiple levels, not just the fish.  Service is excellent, crowd is eclectic, setting is relaxed, food is top notch, and the fishies be fresh. 

I mean for godssakes they have a roll with jalapeno and peanut butter! What has the world come to? An excellent place, methinks.
author: Colleen C.

description: Yum our dinner came out quick and yummy and the staff was friendly, place was clean. VERY busy!
author: Leigh S.

description: Calvin, Tucky and Ling provided exceptional customer service during my random sushi excursion in the middle of the TL.
author: PJ S.

description:
I don't get it. How does this place get 900+ reviews and a 4-star average?

Went last night. Everything about it was fine. The rolls, sashimi and service were all good. However, it's just not a good value. Everything felt pretty overpriced to me (particularly the $6 seaweed salad that was very small and overly sour and salty). Ended up dropping close to 70 bucks for the two of us, but didn't leave feeling very full. Maybe I've just gotten too used to the pricing at Manpuku in Berkeley.

My true rating is probably closer to 3-stars, although I'm gonna give it a 2 because I feel that their current average is just absurd. The place also has this weird perfumey smell.
author: Nathan C.

description:
NO BENTO BOXES?? sayyyy what??

Ambiance: 

- super dim, can barely read the menu and can barely see our food! We had to use our cellphones for light at one point.
- super duper packed for a really small area. 
-super loud music being played (good music tho) but can't hear conversations at all. NOT a good date place....

FOOD: 

- just A-OK. It's really not special... A bit pricy for the small portion we got, I wasn't really satisfied and was still a bit hungry
- Food came out pretty quick but...its sushi- it should be fairly quick...

SERVICE: 

- we had a party of 15 people and the server kept counting 16 and 17 for some reason and after a minute of counting heads over and over again, we finally established we have 15 ( I think we know how many ppl were in our party....) But that was pretty amusing...

Will I be back?

I think there's way better places. Plus, if my friend haven't made reservations, we would probably have waited forever in the cramped little area.
author: Eileen Z.

description:
After moving to San Francisco, my girlfriend and I wanted to find a sushi spot that was in a convenient location, had great, fresh sushi, a friendly staff and great ambiance. After a lengthy search of places throughout the City, but primarily near Union Square, Nob/Russian Hill, we found our favorite--Ryoko's.

Since finding it, the place has been a staple of ours. The sushi is great--I recommend the Whit Tuna Toru, the Braised Pork Belly, the Dragon Roll and Volcano for lovers of peanut butter. 

They also show all of the Giant's games on the TV near the bar, which makes this my go-to spot to get dinner and watch a bit of the game on my way home from work.
author: Steven W.

description: Love the atmosphere and interesting sushi on the menu. The drinks were amazing and priced right. Didn't eat much, but the few sushi dishes and appetizers were delicious.  One dish, pokemon,  was good and fun due to the set of of the roll. Location was great only being a short Uber ride away from any hotel around union square.  Also loved the time it closes. Got to love any place that open till 2 am on the weekday for those that work weekends on the grave.
author: E R.

description:
I love this place.  Ryoko's is a hidden sushi basement in the heart of touristy Union Square... but just as easily could be a Tokyo hole-in-the-wall given the atmosphere, big menu with lots of variety and stylistic service.

+1 for cheapish pitchers of Sapporo and for seating us before the third member of our party arrived!
author: Megan G.

description:
I've been here a couple times -- once around 10pm and again around 6:45pm. Both times required a wait, but the earlier, the better. 

The sushi is good and seems very fresh. They put shiso in a lot of the rolls, which I had never head before. I like it -- gives the rolls a refreshing, crisp taste. 

The service isn't the fastest, but they are very friendly. They make sure you have a drink in hand while waiting in line (bonus!). There is definitely a party vibe to the place, with a DJ most nights. On warm nights, it can get kind of stuffy and even fishy smelling, but I suppose that doesn't happen often in SF, right? I'm okay with the prices, as they seem to be par for the course. I would not recommend coming here with a group larger than 4. It's tight quarters!
author: Emily B.

description:
Great find my best friend Simon L. 

It was 11 PM at night and we didn't want to stay in our hotel. We decided to walk and head over to Ryoko's after reading it's review. Walked for about 15-20 min and as we got there, a line was formed up the stairs. The place, an amazing atmosphere, cool people, and unique decor, was exactly what was described from the reviews.

With that said, I'm here to review about its Wakame Salad. Something so simple like mixed greens and seaweed in a sesame dressing, blew me away. And the plating was smooth and sexy. If a salad looks sexy, you know its going to taste sexy. One of the best salads I've had by far. This salad really made my night coming out and trying these unexpexted restaurants worth it.

And another thing, while you wait to be seated, you can order yourself a sapporo and mingle and chill.
author: Clark Y.

description: If I could give this place 0 stars I would. I have been here a few times and besides the service always being horrible the sushi was good. As someone who craves sushi once a week, I kept coming back for the good fish. This was NOT the case tonight! On top of the waitress being extremely rude, our drinks and meal were beyond terrible. I ordered a martini and my friend ordered the lemon drop. They gave me a short glass of warm vodka as a martini and my friend got a short glass with a little bit of sugar sprinkled on the rim with what tasted like instant lemonade in her drink. When we asked if we could just send them back and order a glass of wine, the waitress said since we already ordered she couldn't take it off the bill. We decided to just drink water after that. We then ordered 2 rolls and some pieces of nigiri. The salmon, which the waitress decided to just add to our plate turned out to be $18. It was also the worst piece on the plate. Another one of the pieces, which was supposed to be halibut had some sort of weird bone in it. Our total for the meal came to $95 for bad sushi and drinks we didn't even drink. By far the worst meal I have ever had with the least accommodating and rudest service. I will not be coming back and would never again recommend this place to friend.
author: Maryn C.

description:
Ryoko's is near Union Square and all the shops. I almost walked by it but my brother-in-law recommended it. It's a very small, cozy place with solid sushi. The atmosphere is good. The service was efficient and our waitress was friendly. 

They serve you some edamame to start. We had the Pokemon roll, the Volcano Roll, and the Jumping Eel Roll. Everything was very fresh. I loved the Pokemon and the Jumping Eel Roll. I bit in and the fresh fish almost melted in my mouth. They use high quality fish (as they should). 

The Volcano roll was okay but it was a little strange. We ordered it because it had peanut butter in it and sounded interesting. I think peanut butter is best left off sushi. It wasn't terrible but picture a shrimp with a glob of peanut butter on it and you'll get the picture. I wouldn't order the Volcano Roll again. 

I also had a good miso soup and the Karaage Chicken (fried chicken). Both were excellent. The Karaage Chicken was just as Japanese fried chicken should be, lightly crispy with a tasty satisfying little crunch. 

I do like this hole in the wall and will be here again soon for sure. There was a line so make sure you you get there in advance to put your name down.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: My daughter, Kris took me here for a snack . . . wow~this place is hoppin' busy!  Everyone in Kris' party pitched in buying sushi . . . it was an expensive bill, but everyone was happy!
author: Shirley M. J.

description:
Our local friends kept telling me about a sushi place that would ruin any of the East coast sushi I can get in my local area. We joined them and their parents for a dinner one one of our first nights in town to see if their hype was justified.

We ordered a selection of our favorite items to see how they stacked up to our favorite sushi house back home plus a couple of different items. The gyoza and edamame were a good standard start to the meal and from there we moved on to a standout. The whole grilled squid was quite the eye opener. Chewy but not in a bad way it was really fresh and the grilled flavor matched up perfect with the squid. It was easily the best squid I'd ever had at a sushi place. Now that we got warmed up and had our expectations raised we moved on to the sushi.

We ordered our standbys BBQ eel with avocado and a spicy tuna roll along with a couple pieces of toro sushi. I'm not sure I've ever had a bad eel avocado roll but this was fresher than most and was damn tasty. The hot tuna as they serve it was one of the best tuna rolls I've had. Unlike most spicy tuna rolls, they used a spicy marinade instead of the standard spicy mayo to kick up the spice level and it really worked well. I wish all spicy tuna rolls used this technique! The toro pieces were fall apart tender and super rich and flavorful. I've only had it a few times but this was definitely my favorite. Clean and fatty and just fantastic fish.

Highly recommended and my friends were completely right that it was way above all of the sushi in our area. FISH!
author: Chris L.

description:
Love how it's open till late. My friend works late and he was pretty hungry and everything was practically closed, so we came here. 

Service is good, very helpful with the selections he suggested. 

Food: eh, I had better sushi. I don't know it didn't taste like a real sushi place. It was good but not the sushi I like. 

I would suggest it if it's late at night but during the day.. No.. But plenty of seats!
author: Michelle N.

description:
Amazing sushi in downtown SF, not too far from the Hilton which is a surprise given most of the hot spots are in the Tenderloin, Mission, Nopa, and the the Haight. Turns out it has been there for 26 years and people line up nightly to try and squeeze into this tiny spot. I was fortunate to be a party of one and easily get a table right away at the bar. I happened to sit next to the owner of the place who was fastidious in managing all components from her perch. All night she kept an eye on every order, drink, appetizer left unattended or not meeting immediate delivery. The fish I found out is shipped from Japan daily and the owner having been there so long is one of the first ones to get her pick, which explains their exceptional Tuna Yukke. The chefs and staff are very friendly, the atmosphere is a dive bar meets hole in the wall restaurant. The cuts are great. I stuck to sashimi for the most part hirame, ikura, uni, unagi, sake, tako, hamachi but did enjoy the spicy scallop and the Alaskan A's. The owner knows Jiro and regularly goes back to Japan to visit Jiro. She maintains a high standard which is why this place has survived a quarter century in a high turnover industry. 

If you are in downtown SF, Ryokos is a must stop.
author: Bharat W.

description:
This place is the definition of FUUUUNNNNN! 

The atmosphere is so cool (it's practically in a basement) - it's like you're eating in an underground club. 

Everything I've had is awesome! The sashimi is super fresh, the tempura is perfectly battered, the wakeme salad is authentic (real deal seaweed!), the gyoza's are home-made, and of course....the draft Saparo and Kirin's only adds to the festivity!

Hot sake here is deliciousssss here, too. 

And they have a full bar!

Waiters are uber friendly, attentive, and service is fast. 

Long wait if you don't make reservations, but they're real good in making sure you have drinks in hand to make the time fly by faster :).

I've been here twice, and it only gets better!
author: Gail N.

description: We've wanted to come here for years but there's ALWAYS a line out the door. Imagine my surprise when I was told they take reservations! (WHY is there always the line then?!) We ended up having a great cozy table under the stairs, which was pretty good for people watching. The service was excellent. The menu is pretty unusual, but it's widely varied so there's something for everyone. I have to say I didn't like the starters we tried as much (chicken karaage and tonkatsu - the meat had a kind of weird texture, I thought), but the sushi was all great with unique flavors.
author: Lisa K.

description: From the street this is a very unremarkable. But once you venture inside you'll find a remarkably warm environment and fantastic Japanese food.  One of the best.
author: Andre G.

description: What a great little place. You would probably never see it or think of walking in there but its worth the visit. Fast service, amazing fresh fish, fair pricing. My husband and I visited SF from LA where we know what GOOD sushi is and I must say this place didn't disappointed us. Go there while in SF you wont regret it.
author: Yana M.

description: I took a group of out-of-town friends here, and it was a great choice, despite being in a rather sketchy area of town. I like the grungy underground vibe, and it's pretty busy in the evenings. For appetizers, Iidako (fried octopus), fried cheese, and deep fried oysters were pretty good. They have a broad sushi selection, and we ordered a bunch for the table that were all fairly delicious and well packed. We also ended with their fried ice cream and mochi dessert. Service is pretty fast and attentive, but the order that food was delivered was random. Overall, a satisfying meal!
author: Leslie C.

description:
- Reasonable Prices
- Quick Service
- Delicious Food
- Relaxed Atmosphere

Amazing! The staff was friendly and the sushi was incredible. The music wasn't too loud and even though they were packed, we were seated immediately. The only sad moment was when we ordered more oysters and were told there was only one left, which we snapped up. Definitely be making a point to visit any time I'm in the area.
author: Gina P.

description:
Great, super fresh sushi!  

Ducked in here on a Saturday evening to get out of the rain and grab a bite to eat. It's a small place so be prepared to stand on the steps (inside) for a while, but it's worth the wait.  Great food and cool atmosphere.  They have a live DJ on Saturday nights spinning some tunes, but it's not crazy loud so you can still have a conversation.  

This place is a thumbs up in my book!
author: Rod M.

description:
I've been here a few times and really like the atmosphere. The service is pretty good and I can say I've never been annoyed at any of the waitresses (and three visits is more than a big enough sample size to find something that annoys you).

Ramen and sushi were both pretty good but the food is not the absolute best you can find in the area. Still perfect for lunch or giving out-of-towners a little SF personality.
author: Andrew C.

description: It was a Thursday night and I had gone to see my friend DJ at a lounge in SF. At around 12am me and my friend decided we wanted to eat so we could sober up. We were both craving Sushi and amazingly found a place in the city where they served sushi! Boy, was I happy!! The place didn't have the best sushi but it did fulfill my cravings and it is a great place to go at midnight.
author: Lesley M.

description: Giving it only 3 stars because of the long wait and the skimpy pieces of sashimi. We arrived at the wrong time which was when the all the tables were just filled and there were 4 of us. If we were just 2 we could've sat down way earlier. We waited at least an hour which is never my policy to wait more than 30 min. However, my husband found this highly rated place on Yelp and we were visiting SF and did not have a plan B. We were the first party to write our names down. If you dine here, know that if you have to wait for a table YOU have to write your name down yourself and don't stray too far away from the front of the line or else you will not hear your name being called and they will call the next party on the list. I witnessed they sat people down who were later down the list first because the waitress had so much to do. As for the sushi, my husband said its the best sushi he has ever had but you have to know that he is not much of a sushi aficionado. Me, on the other hand (worked in a Japanese restaurant owned by Japanese sushi chef) thought the fish was very fresh but was very skimpy. I do have to say their wasabi was the real deal. Being the place was so busy, the service was very slow. We didn't get a refill of water, didn't see our waitress way long after we finished our meal. There was still a long line out the door after we left and believe me we were ready to leave long before we got our check. I wanted to go get sushi one more time before leaving SF but would not go back here. Not that memorable to wait an hour for a table.
author: Debby S.

description: Great spot near Union Square. About a 30 minute wait to be seated but well worth the wait! My wife and I started with some fresh oysters and shitake tempura.  Then we had a Volcano Roll and Jumping Tuna Roll.  Both excellent, the Volcano is no joke its very spicy, and I'm Mexican! The Jumping Tuna comes with a great sauce.  First SF sushi spot I've ever tried and was not disappointed.  Great service.  You might hear your neighbors conversations since the tables are so close together, but you get used to it.
author: Jose F.

description:
Note to all: must make reservations 24 hours in advance... and if you want to eat at a reasonable time this is a MUST.
Went in at 830 on a saturday night, small place no place to wait the hour they told us it would be to get a table. Luckily the wait staff is so friendly we were able to leave our number and go to the Owl Tree 1 street over for some coctails. Not wanting to miss our reservation we went back over at just about an hour later and were told it would be another 15 minutes. There is no hostess the hostesses are the waitresses and they are BUSY! Its cool though we were able to get some beers and chill on the stairs with the other 20 people waiting. You can even get Saki while waiting too. Once seated we ordered apps and some rolls right away along with saki and beers (they serve them in pitchers!!!)

We ordered gyoza, CHICKEN KARAAGE and fried cheese. all were tasty hot and fresh.

For sushi we ordered- HOT TUNA,SALMON SKIN, VOLCANO, and JUMPING TUNA (which we ended up ordering 2 more of because they are so good- deep fried spicy tuna rolls mmmm).

For 4 people the bill was a little over $100, and that was with a pitcher of sopporo and 2 hot sake's. In a city like San Fran, needless to say we were impressed with the price, but the food will bring us back.
author: Katie A.

description:
The fish melts in your mouth.

The service is quite good -- very nice and friendly and hospitable.

Cool vibe inside too: dark, and intimate, and hip with funky muzak in the background.
author: Catt G.

description: Ryoku's blows every other local sushi place out of the water. While the wait can be long, it's worth it. I've gotten several of the sushi and nigiri platters here, and haven't been disappointed - it's the only sushi place since coming back from Japan that I felt compared to the cuts of fish I had there. My only wish is that they had take-out!
author: Claire S.

description:
So the last time I dined here was with my now current boyfriend. heh. Looking at my last review, it was pretty short - I still remember liking Ryoko's but not remembering it much since I was taken there on a second date on an almost full stomach.

Fast forward months later and while finding somewhere to eat for a friends birthday, I suggested Ryoko's and we ended up there. Seems like a lot of people complain about the long waits - they do take reservations, FYI. But it is hard if you come on a whim since reservations have to be made 24 hours and advance. But if you have a reservation, you will get in easy peasy. (we were even 40 minutes late to our res... oops)

I suggested Ryoko's since I wanted to dine somewhere fun since it was a group dinner. Ryoko's definitely has a fun environment along with great food - it made it even more fun with the live DJ spinning Friday night.

This time around, we ordered a variety of appetizers, rolls, and rounds of hot sake and beer. I tried their Chicken Karaage, Hot Tail Roll, Dragon Roll, Sexy Roll, Jumping Tuna Roll, and one of the specials of the day - White Tuna Belly Sashimi. Chicken Karaage was delicious and all of the rolls were so fresh/melt in your mouth. The special of the day was especially good - once the bf and I heard White Tuna Belly, we knew we had to get it - we ended up ordering two. 

Fun environment, fair service, great food. Love Ryoko's!
author: Tiffany K.

description: My top 3 sushi spot in San Francisco. Super fresh fish straight from Japan. Portions are good. I love their toro and uni. Coming from Texas, where the fish isn't as fresh, this place is a shining star. This restaurant is close to union square as well and is walking distance. If you go during the busy hours, prepare to wait in line!
author: Ann V.

description: RATS i wanted to like this place. RATS i was hoping for so much  more. RATS! oh my gosh this place needs an exterminator.  We were sitting at the sushi bar in this low rent downstairs establishment when we saw the owners pets scurrying about.  The fish is not fresh and service is awful.  be warned eat at your own risk.
author: Jeffrey D.

description: Great sushi and good service.  Don't be fooled by the location and basement type entrance.  Get there early because it gets crowded and you will have to wait. The bathrooms are surprisingly clean (at least the men's).
author: Ed C.

description:
The sushi was excellent and the service was good. The basement feel is super cool..
Highly recommend for a good energy spot late night works for me and this is the place.
author: Benjamin A.

description:
Go Here. The End. 

Seriously, this place is great. Expect a decent wait (20 min to an hour). Its got a great ambiance and delicious food.
author: David N.

description:
We love this place. It's our neighhood go to place for sushi!  But be warned, if you are going on Friday/Saturday night, with more than 2 of you, you better make reservations at least a day in advance! So you don't get to stair at the stairs and spend the previous night waiting for your name to be called. 

First, what I really love about Ryoko is its atmosphere, it is kinda hidden at the corner with a basement location, it almost seems like a tucked away ryokan in the ninja era. But when you go inside, you are brought back into a cozy little space but busy with music and people. I really like the space they have create. Plus, it is like typical old buidling of SF, I love the how the pillars are erected at awkward places. But really add onto the characters of the inside. 

For food, we had the spicy golden gate roll and the sashimi dinner with 14 pieces of awesome fish, scallops and octopus! I will definitely recommend this place! Its just a fun environment with great food and serice! Just watch out for the business.
author: Fung S. O.

description: Incredibly fresh and unique fish flown in from Japan. Great crowd and atmosphere. Was even a line for tables at 10pm on a Sunday night.
author: Phil F.

description: If you're looking for gas station grade sushi served in an unfinished basement, this is the place for you. The boorish waitress smelled worse than the month old tuna, and wasn't capable of taking the simplest orders. Also I heard some guy in the back yelling about how he saw a rat. Perhaps they were serving it. I hope the board of health closes this hell hole.
author: Brett M.

description:
This. Place. Makes. My. Night. It really does.

The boyfriend and I come here almost every week and sit on the sushi bar after work.  Love that it opens late.  They always play wonderful oldies music that you can sing along to(:

The guys behind the bar as well as the servers are very sweet.  It seems that they never have a bad day.  Even when it is the end of the night and they are about to close.  I love it.

We have a tendency to order all across the specials board and the menu.  I can honestly say that we have never had a bad dish here. Ever.  The sushi is ALWAYS fresh.  Love the classics as well as the exotics: shiromaguro toro, amaebi, sake, hamachi, mirugai, aji, etc. If you haven't, you must try the kurobuta pork sausages: they are SOOOO tasty! As for their desserts: the sesame ice cream and tempura ice cream with peanuts, toffee, whipped cream & chocolate syrup is the way to go.

See ya there!
author: Soph T.

description:
A real treat and worth the wait.  The staff recommended a drink to me that coulda been deadly, because it suited me so well I wanted it all night.  The sushi tasted great, and the chefs were nicely interactive.  Now, we sat at the bar and watched the food getting prepared.  Uh-  That was a mistake.  Hand-washing was rare and cross contamination was plentiful.  Touching the different fish, refrigerator, and other surfaces while hand making our fish was not great to see.  I did like how the one chef was certain to smell the fish, before he opened a new pack.

Aside from the handwashing issue, I help this place in high regard.  A real treat.  I will go back, just wont sit at the bar, and will wait for a table.
author: Tim H.

description:
Whoever thought of late night sushi is a flipping GENIUS!!!! This place was sooo close to the last venue we went to (Jones Bar) and they're open until 2AM!!!! Hands down, pretty good sushi with the awesome option of staying late night after you bar hop it up.

I will def be coming back here for more sake and sushi on the late night hype!

And yes.. this is super hidden random from where I usually go but I can appreciate the find!
author: Nichele R.

description: This is our favorite late-night sushi spot. The nigiri is always good, we usually get salmon, toro, yellowtail, and mackerel. The hamachi Kama is good too, but sometimes dry (which defeats the purpose of having hamachi Kama). Usually good though. We usually get seated pretty quickly. Never had bad food here. The service isn't particularly good but the food makes it worthwhile.
author: Brianna C.

description: Great sushi, especially if you decide you need sushi after a night out! the 49ers roll is sooo good as well as the jumping California roll! :)
author: Diego A.

description:
Came here early in the night. It was still very very crowded, had to wait in line for about 20 mins but the waitress, even though she was busy, was nice and helpful. The service was quick and the sushi was very good.
I like the environment. Its a very hidden away place and a great place to check out.
author: Michael K.

description: We went on a Friday night around 7 pm, and the wait for 2 at the sushi bar was about an hour. It's a fun setting - a basement restaurant with low ceilings, columns scattered throughout the floor and a PACKED environment. Service was fast, and the servers were quick and helped each other out which was nice to see. Because it was so crowded, there was a hurried feeling throughout, so you couldn't really relax or have an intimate conversation. The fish was fresh, and the rolls were tasty, but nothing really stood out. I had read so many great reviews that I expected more flavor or "wow." Though the prices were average for a roll, the rolls were small (only 5 pieces) and they weren't wrapped very well, the insides kept falling apart just trying to pick it up from its dish. Cool points for having more than one Japanese beer on tap though! For the price, I'd rather go to Domo or something where I know that quality is still there but the bites are tastier. Good experience overall.
author: Zara S.

description: With all the positive reviews I had to try this place. I have to say that the sushi was awesome!! The house music and atmosphere makes it a complete.
author: Ruben S.

description:
The best damn sushi I ever had, period. 

There is almost always a line, but luckily there are a few bars in the area that you can grab a drink while you wait. If it's almost your turn to get seated, they'll even serve you some beer!

Super nice staff. Very good atmosphere. And as I said, the best damn sushi I've ever had, period.
author: Adam F.

description: Late night sushi with fresh raw oysters.  I was thrilled to find a place like this as my hometown does not have fresh sushi nor late-night anything.  Fun atmosphere for what seemed to be a mostly 20-30 year old crowd.  Went here twice and enjoyed it both times.
author: Shiver M.

description: We got there shortly before it opened, and there was a line waiting to get in. The wife and I were excited; we love our sushi.  Boy were we disappointed. We were seated right by the entrance to the kitchen. We can see how extremely filthy it was. There's this thing called soap and water; use it. We still decided to stay. The miso soup was ambient. The dashi also overpowered it. So I waited for the soft shell crab. Problem was, my main course came out before the appetizer. I ordered the sashimi plate. It came out less than 5 minutes from the time we placed our order. This is only possible if the fish is already sliced. That's a no no in Japanese cuisine. And usually sashimi is sliced thicker than Nigiri, but it wasnt. Different fish were touching each other which is also not the right plating; I don't need salmon oils on my tuna. I was not happy with this plate. My wife ordered rolls wich were absolutely mediocre.  100 dollar tab, and I've never been more disappointed in a restaurant. I've had better sushi in strip malls. Save your time as well as your money.
author: Dean C.

description:
Looking for sushi after midnight? This place is open till 2am. We walked in near midnight and the place was full, however, it wasn't much of a wait to be seated.

Good sushi, Japanese chefs, and good service. Recommend the 49ers roll. 

Best sushi I've ever had? No, but it's still good and it's open after midnight!!
author: Michelle D.

description:
This is my first time in SF. Found this place on yelp. Great spot & worth the wait. Put your name on the wait list and walk to the bar down the street. They have a really good DJ. We got the 49er, philly and spicy scallop roll. All really delicious. The O toro sashimi was amazing but expensive.Great vibe for late night dinner. They have liquor too which is a plus! 

I would say a must try spot!
author: Alexa S.

description: This place is great and really sets the tone for the rest of the night. Pre dine and pre party here! Quality food, fast service, and good drinks make for a great dining experience. Try the volcano roll... Don't be intimidated by the peanut butter, it's amazing! Now I am always going to look for rolls with PB, I'm hooked! The vibe is loud and full of energy thanks to the house music bumping through the entire place. Next time I'm in SF I will def be back to Ryoko!
author: Mike B.

description: We showed up at 5:30 pm to check the place out...as we waited a line started to form. This is probably hands down the best sushi place I have ever eaten at...top notch service as well as food! Bella is the best server there!!! Sake is amazing!! Get there early!! Always a line out the door!!!!
author: Michael E.

description: Good sushi, fair prices, but man is this place busy. They have interesting sushi options you don't see outside of SF as often. The service was pretty bad, hence the -1 star for that item. Ended up seated at the sushi bar which was nice.
author: Jonah K.

description:
I won't go as far to say I'm a foodie (growing up on an array of home-cooked Liberian dishes and kraft macaroni and cheese). But I will say I know what's good. Ryoko feels underground both metaphoric and physically.  Though the musical atmosphere is top 40's, it's a party you're willing to endure. Fresh fish. excellent service and middle-ground prices.  

More:

1. Open late (2 a.m.)
2. Live DJ with booth set up on grand piano
3. Order adult bevs from the crowded stairs while waiting for your table.
4. Interesting and tasty plate presentation.
5. Fast and efficient service.
author: Mennlay A.

description:
Finally, a restaurant in San Francisco that I loved!  Just when I was about to give up too.

I had been craving sushi for weeks, so when I saw that this place was right up the street, I was sold.  We almost stopped at another place along the way too, I'm so glad we didn't.

From the moment we walked in until the entire staff said goodbye, the service was friendly and helpful.  Our server set us up with a great bottle of sake and pointed out their fresh fish specials from Japan.

We ordered several rolls and pieces, including the sea eel special, the uni and trumpetfish.  Everything was incredibly fresh and delicious.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Andrea H.

description: Hip and definitely local. We both got the sashimi, sushi platter, and an order of umi - the sea urchin. Good vibe, reasonable service. DON'T sit at the end of the bar because everyone will bump into you. Sashimi and sushi were very much on the small side, overall nothing to rant and rave about with this place aside from the cool vibe. A good date place.
author: Barb C.

description: Very good! We need more of this in Los Angeles. The place is fantastic on its own and open late is a pure treat! Sushi is fresh, beer is cold, music is good, and overall vibe is fantastic. A must stop if you're hungry and craving sushi
author: Mojito G.

description: For the first time I feel like yelp let me down we had the dragon roll and the checkerboard roll they were both pretty mediocre this place is defiantly a solid 3
author: Anthony A.

description:
We had friends from Germany in town and they had specifically requested an evening of sushi. I knew I didn't want to take them to our usual spots where the specialities are more authentic in nature and don't involve anything like "crab with a k" on the menu. 

I had heard about Ryoko's a while back for its late night atmosphere and liked the central location, so off we went to expose our German friends to SF sushi. 

Despite being a few blocks off of Union Square, the place didn't have a touristy feel, for which I was relieved. The loud music and crowded atmosphere was the perfect party I was looking for. Nothing was too authentic, which in our case, was a good thing and everything we had was solid. 

It's challenging to find late night eats in this city, so it's nice to know there's a spot for those with late night sushi cravings.
author: Lee H.

description:
The sushi was good from here, but my experience wasn't a five star one. It was just, you know, fine. 

The restaurant looks like nothing from outside. You could walk past it a million times and never think it was worth visiting. Inside, it's a like a tardis. The place is really quite big and extends a lot at the back. It's also very, very busy. Locals must really like this place. 

I had a wide range of sushi, nigiri and sashimi - everything from eel to tuna to red snapper to mackerel to avocado to rice balls. The food was all nice and the fish tasted especially fresh and flavoursome. 

But the place was very busy, it was very dark and noisy, service wasn't quick because of it and the food wasn't particularly cheap. So as an overall experience, it was absolutely a-ok.
author: Claire C.

description: Ryoko is a fun, family run joint. If you seek a casual and energetic night out - this is a nice option. The last time I was there it was super hot outside. I'm not sure if they have AC or not or if it was just broken. Could have been a one time deal. They had fans going to try and help. Despite the temperature the sushi was still delicious. Go with friends! They'll enjoy the food, ambiance and music. Promise.
author: Kelly C.

description: What is the all hype??? I REALLY wanted to like this place as it was recommended by a friend of mine. Mediocre sushi and long wait time. We waited over 30 minutes for a table at 9 p .m. The place was stuffy and had an extremely bad sewer smell. Maybe we dined there on the wrong night? I guess the only good part is the reasonable price and upbeat music. Good place if you are looking for late night cheap sushi.
author: K R.

description:
After looking on Yelp to look for a late Sunday night dinner with my coworkers, I decided Ryoko's would be the place to go.

What I enjoyed about this place:
- Great atmosphere going on, and all the workers were super friendly.
- Reservations were quick and easy to make on the phone, the person who did my reservations was really nice.
- We actually arrived 10 minutes early from our reservation time, we were was able to get a table within 5 minutes of us arriving. Though he didn't even ask for my name or anything, I just told him that I had a reservation for a set time?
- Sushi/food is definitely delish.

Why this place is getting 2 stars and not 5:
- Tiny portions! At the rate of how slow we were receiving our food (more info about their service below), we didn't want to order more.
- Slowww and, "meh" service. It's also why we skipped out on dessert. I REALLY wanted to try their tempura ice cream! :( Our server was also... well, long story short: he was a noob (but! he was very nice). 

We sat looking at the menus for about 10 minutes before we were even greeted by our server. On top of that, we had all asked for waters which took another 5 minutes and then finally, our complimentary edamame came out. We had told our server we weren't ready to order yet so he said he'd come back. Waited another 15 minutes for him to come back. 

He was helping our table, and 2 others, one to the right and one to the left of us. He kept getting the orders mixed up for which plate is to which table. He had approached my table twice with a plate that we didn't order. We drank our water pretty fast because of the long wait and I had to grab his attention to refill all 4 of our cups. Eventually a second person came by to refill our cups again later because it seemed he may had forgotten to check our water the 2nd time. He seemed pretty overwhelmed. :/ The girls next to us were also complaining because the server had forgotten a plate they ordered and why their food taking so long.

Our food (total of 4 people at the table) all came out at random times... it was weird. This was basically how it happened:
(15 minutes later after telling the server our order)
1x salad arrives for person #1 *10 minutes later* 
1x sashimi plate arrives for person #2 *5 minutes later* 
1x sushi plate arrives for person #2 *5 minutes later* 
1x sushi & sashimi arrives for person #3 *5 minutes later* 
1x sushi order comes out for person #4 *10 minutes later* 
1x tonkatsu plate arrives for person #1 *5 minutes later* 
1x tonkatsu plate arrives for person #4

We stayed there for a 1hr and 40'ish minutes, mainly because we were waiting for all our food to arrive and not because we wanted to stay longer. I'll probably give this place another shot though, to see if maybe it was just a bad night tonight.
author: Sydney M.

description:
Fun & sweet....place is cute & cozy. Expect a wait if you go during a peak hour, write your name down, go grab a drink elsewhere & return to indulge.

+Staff is very attentive & welcoming
+Location: small, but they have a back room that is perfect for a private small party dinner
+Food: they have a peanut butter roll that just made my top 5 list of sushis. Im a PEANUT BUTTER & sushi lover..so the combination of both made me cringe, but once i tried it...i never looked back. bomb! although the other items were not anything out of this world, but a fun place.


I would love to check this place out during the weekend, after looking at other reviews it seems as if there is more of a "lounge-pregame" feel. will return.
author: Priscilla N.

description: The sashimi here was amazing. There was a bit of a wait. Finding parking was a hassle. This venue is also in the TL. Worth it!!! Hirame is my favorite fish. A lot of sushi restaurants never have it. Or when they do, it's usually out. I'm glad they had some that night.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Drop by now and then... WOW!!! It keeps the HIGHEST rating for me as Sushi place in the city.

FRESH... FAST ... and last night the music was GREAT!!! Eurotrash disco from the late 80s (well.. for Americans was early 90s)... FIERCE!!

Well done.

If you sit at the bar you get to see how they prepare your food.. and trust me.. it is a show :)
author: Gianguido G.

description:
My friend and I waited 40 minutes to be seated thinking it must be worth the wait. There are two other Japanese restaurants right around the corner but we decided on Ryoko given how packed it was and the fact that so many people were waiting to get in.

This was the worst Japanese restaurant we have ever been to. No exaggeration. We ordered the Volcano roll ($13) expecting something amazing but to our great disappointment it looked and tasted like something we could make at home. It only came with 5 small pieces and tasted like peanut butter and rice. The takoyaki looked appealing but the taste was nothing special. 

The whole time we were so confused because we didn't understand why the place was so popular! We wondered if it was everyone else's first time as well and just didn't know better. Overall, it was just a really weird experience because it didn't make sense. We left very disappointed.

If you like Japanese food, don't go here.
author: Amanda L.

description: The nigiri here is to die for. The white tuna toro is so buttery and delicious and the yellowtail is pretty darn tasty. The rolls here are puny and overpriced. I'd only come here again if I were looking for a small light dinner because its was 65 dollars plus tax for 3 orders of nigiri, two rolls, and a small sake.
author: Lisa N.

description:
With an unassuming exterior, you wouldn't really stumble upon this place, and think it was 4-star great, unless they was a line out the door (as there usually is) or you read the hundreds of yelp reviews.  I first came here for a friends birthday, and had never heard of the place before.  Our group was large, and they did their best to keep us all close together.  It is a small space, so we were situated in two adjacent "rooms".  It worked out really well, and the wait staff was amazing for a full restaurant, and our 20+ person party.  The next couple of times, I've gone in, the service has still been amazing, and very friendly... and quick!   Consistency is key!  

Now, regarding the food - the rolls are good, and not very expensive.  I eat a lot of sushi rolls, and they pretty much have the standard.  No one particular roll stood out from the others.  The sashimi is typically sized, nothing overtly generous, but they don't skimp either.  Overall the food, isn't "to die for" as I usually like to rate fabulous food, but it is very very satisfying.   And the food is definitely worth the wait.  Their sake selection is good too!  I'm not a big fan of sake, but my friend (from Japan) chose one that was 2nd to the best I've ever had (the best I've had was at Sebo, but probably cost triple what it cost here).

So, if you plan on going to Ryoko's be prepared to wait (they do take your order for a drink while you wait).  Put your phone number next to your name if you decide to take a stroll.  They will call you when your name is up.  

Eat on!  :)
author: Rachel B.

description:
I do like the atmosphere of this place. I really do. And it's definitely busy and the sushi is good but could have been better had the fish been colder. Our sushi took so long getting to us it was warm meaning the servers let it sit there too long. So yeah. Service was definitely shoddy. Besides taking too long bringing my sushi that it got warm they did the same with my beer. It was warm. Also, when our food finally came they told us that they were out of one of the rolls we ordered. OK. Tell us when we're ordering. Not when we get our food. 

I will most likely come back so hopefully the second time will be better. I will upgrade my review. IF.
author: David C.

description:
I stumbled in to this place around 12:30am. To think, a sushi joint open late until 2am?? Yes please! I love the vibe here. Three words: cozy, divey, DJ. Oh and here are 2 more words...yummy sushi!!! 

Here is what we ordered:
-Miso: greaqt miso, cant go wrong.
-Monk fish liver: YOU NEED TO ORDER THIS!!!! Wow oh wow! Ive never had this before I love to try new things so I ordered it. This tasted like a delicate tofu smoked IN salmon. The flavor is distinct and gives a powerful punch...I think that the sauce it is served in is some sort of ginger and something else. In any case, it was pretty damn amazing! So much so, I ordered a second helping.
-Sashimi platter: I was getting quite full so I was only able to try the maguro and salmon on the platter. The fish tasted just as it should and was extremely fresh.
-Gyoza: The gyoza was not the typical shaped dumpling rather it was nearly pancake flat but delicious nonetheless.
-Asten Roll: Yummy asparagus and deep fried tempura...I call these little meals in a roll lol

To top the night off, our service was stellar and the overall vibe was a great end to a lovely evening. Pricing wasnt bad either...spent around $80 with all the food we ordered...not to mention 3 large sake bottles. 

A definite must visit if you are touring the lovely city by the bay.
author: Catie N.

description: Great find! I was concerned when i walked up to this place that yelp had steared me wrong till i went inside and saw the line waiting for tables. The nigiri was great, ask the wait staff what's good they did not stear me wrong. We also had the 49er roll which was very good and the volcano which should be tried once (it has peanut butter in it :)
author: Joshua F.

description:
My best friend and I came here last Friday night after checking into our hotel a few blocks away. We needed a weekend getaway although we only live 45 minutes away in San Jose. The front desk associate at the JW Marriott recommended Ryoko's as a good late night sushi spot so we headed there and almost missed the entrance! 

Once inside, we waited about 5-10 minutes before being seated. Our server was pretty good but I admittedly don't expect TOO much out of busy spots like this. We ordered the Volcano Roll out of curiosity and the fried California Roll (it might be a different name). Both rolls were great, if a tiny bit small for the price. Our cold sake was nice and smooth and got us plenty buzzed! We also got an order of sake (salmon) nigiri and uni, both of which were fresh and flavorful. Lastly, we decided to try their oysters and had 2 each (they only charge $1.90 per piece) and we were pleasantly surprised at the wonderful taste and size of the oysters. On top of that, we got complimentary edamame when we were first seated. Sorry, this review is all over the place but if I'm in the city, I would definitely go out of my way to come back here again!
author: Krissie B.

description: One of my favorite sushi spots in SF. If they have it, make sure to try to the white tuna toro... so good!
author: Kyle M.

description:
I don't know that I've ever felt so hip in all my life as when I went for sushi at Ryokos.  Seriously, people.  I'm a ninth level dork.  I'm nowhere near cool or hip or phat.  Are you picking up what I'm putting down?

The sushi was spectacular.  They serve toro like I've never experienced before and salmon so beautiful and buttery you will forget ti chew.  The specialty rolls are also great but, leave some room for the sashimi.  They buy great stuff and really take care with the preparation.  A seat at the bar is great.  I love to watch the chefs at work.  Just be aware that you will be at the bottom of the stairway and might catch the occasional cold breeze from outside.  

Some nights they have a DJ spinning.  There I was with no hipster jeans.  Sigh.
author: Chris C.

description:
Only waited about 15 minutes to be seated. Had a glass of wine on the stairs while waiting, and just chilled...the music helped create a fun ambiance that wasn't traditional for a sushi place.

So for the food...

The sushi: Yes, overpriced, but not by much. The checkerboard was probably my favorite, followed by well, anything with salmon in it. Everything tasted fresh, except for maybe the sashimi was a little too squishy for my tastes (could have been fresher). 


The sake: I would be happy with a larger sake selection. They were limited in what they offered, and the quality ranged drastically.

The DJ: 
Sometimes too loud. It's one thing to have a cool dj in the background, it's another thing to not be able to hear the person next to you trying to speak. 

The Service:
Occassionall slow, mildly forgetful, but decent overall. Quick with the rolls once they were ordered, but forgetful when asking to see the menu again. 

Overall:
Yes, it's in a basement. And yes, dirty and grungy as basements are, it was still...kinda spiffy. And I like spiffy.
author: Danielle L.

description:
For all those skeptics out there wondering how can a 4 star yelp rated restaurant can receive a 1 star rating, let me begin by saying I typically do like to not bash restaurants. But....

I have never waited so long for sushi (very mediocre sushi) in my life!  4 nigiris and 1 roll took 25 minutes to fulfill.  Perhaps they had to go fish my sashimi from the ocean (maybe if they did that instead, the food would have been more fresh).  After the TINY portions came, we decided to order another roll, and that took another 20 minutes.  Keep in mind that our table was for 8:30pm, a bit towards the later part of dinnertime.  As if that was not pathetic enough, the bill took another 10 minutes to arrive, and I basically had to take my money to the counter as no waitstaff even bothered to pick up the bill.  

As for the food, mediocre.  We ordered the Pokemon Roll (Salmon, mango, avocado, cucumber, wrapped in soy paper), Dragon Roll, Sea Urchin, Giant Clam, Ebi, and Tako.  The Pokemon Roll tasted alright, but the Eel in the Dragon Roll did not taste fresh at all.  The giant clam nigiri was so fishy that even the wasabi could not drown out the taste.   The rest of the nigiris were okay, but nothing jumps out.

Additionally, Yelp was right in that it resembled more of a dive-bar then a restaurant.  The carpet was stained with dirt, and the entire restaurant just did not smell too pleasant at all.  Add in the fact that the menus were filthy and sticky drilled in the 1 star rating.
author: Jensen S.

description:
I was never a huge fan of sushi, having only grown fond of it in the past couple of years, so when one of my friends recommended this place for dinner I was a bit apprehensive.

However, this place was fantastic! There were six of us and luckily, we had made a reservation in advance (it was a Friday night by the way) so we were seated quite quickly, despite a few of our party not arriving until much later. We ordered about 12 different rolls and an appetizer. The rolls all came out on a giant plate and were arranged beautifully. I loved the Spicy Golden Gate roll, Alaskan A's roll, and the Hot Tuna roll. 

My only complaint would be that it was quite pricey, but it is sushi so that isn't too surprising. I definitely enjoyed the food here and would come back!
author: Cynthia Y.

description: I came here solo and sat at the bar. Very high energy staff, maybe a little shrill but very attentive. I got two amazing-- and kind of unusual-- rolls: one with salmon skin, one "Kentucky" with lightly fried chicken. My third roll was nice to look at but def less memorable. I would def recommend.
author: OJ K.

description:
I'm not a fan of eating near Union Square.  Most of the restaurants tend to cater to tourists and the food ends up being bland and expensive.  I was pleasantly surprised to find Ryoko's.  

You can tell the fish is fresh here.  When the put the plate on the table, I could see how good the fish was going to be, and it did not disappoint, it melted in my mouth.  I've been to a few Japanese places in the city, and this is definitely one of the best when it comes to raw fish.  

They lose a star because their rolls are on the smaller side so be prepared to order a lot of them.

The walk-in wait is extremely long so try to get reservations.
author: Karen T.

description: Delicious beautiful fresh fish, open really late & there's a dj spinning hip hop on the weekends. Not to mention the owner is super nice!
author: Gelina A.

description:
It's always good times getting drunk at a Japanese restaurant. Sapporo and sake, always a winning combination.

Our server was very courteous and was very happy to accommodate all of our (drunken) request. While the service was effective, the food was less than stellar.

The sushi took a while to prepare (even for sushi's standards), and the roll crumbled all too easily. They also didn't have the healthy version (green cap) of soy sauce and this was a problem for one of my friends that is allergic to regular soy sauce.

I'm coming back to Ryoko for the drinks and the ambiance, but for good sushi, this wouldn't be my first stop.
author: Tom P.

description:
Never had a bad experience at Ryoko's

I go there from time to time, since it's very reasonably priced and the food is good.

All the dishes I've had so far are great, though, to be fair, I'm not a big sushi rolls guy.  I usually elect for a combination of appetizers and entrees.

My favorites are the Ika Maruyaki (squid)  and Beef Oroshi.

Also good for a drink, or four.   Don't discount it because it's downstairs in the tender-nob area.  It's definitely worth a visit though I'd recommend going during slightly off-hours because it does get busy.
author: Jason L.

description: Good chef(food), cozy little place. Don't care much for the service though. Waited to be seated but pay at counter? Might be a language barrier..
author: Anil K.

description:
Came here 4/18 after the Refused show at the Warfield.

PLUS: open late night. Gyoza was tasty.
MINUS: Overrated/overpriced sushi rolls.

The atmosphere is hip and dim.  Unfortunate the couple at the table next to us were practically on top of each other which was annoying.

The wait staff were nice, BUT quick to grab our plates, though we were BARELY finishing up our meal.  My BF and I both agreed we've had better rolls for the same price.  Each roll was tiny & only like 5 or 6 pieces.

It may be open late and located in the city, but I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone visiting or even living there.
author: anissa b.

description: Really great experience tonight. Had wonderful and friendly service, and felt welcomed. Got there right at 6pm and there was a few people waiting outside. Sushi was very good. Had the jumping tuna and loved it. Pokemon was good but not my style. Tempura is on point! And can't get better than the EDM playing on a Monday making you feel like it's Friday.
author: Shelly P.

description: Quick service, great sushi that's very reasonably priced. Went on a Saturday at 11:30 pm when they had a DJ so it was really loud.  Had the mochi for dessert and it was perfect!
author: Jenn B.

description:
I wasn't 100% sure if this place was getting 3 or 4 stars after my first visit so I waited to review hoping some clarity would find me....

Visit #2 I realized that their cuts of fish are fresh and yummy. The red snapper nigiri special was mouth watering. Also, the Tiger Roll (shrimp tempura, cuke & mayo) was really good. One shortcoming (in my opinion) was the slight lack of variety in rolls. Didn't really see a lot of exploration into fun combos which left us wondering "what else should we get?"
author: Rachel R.

description: Mmm not my favorite places to eat sushi in the city. Cute atmosphere but a little cramped. They did not have very many speciality items on their menu. Sapporo pitchers are $14 which was pretty awesome though!
author: Taylor F.

description: Seems more like a blues club than a sushi restaurant, but don't be scared.   The Tuna quality was amazing.  The selection of rolls was slightly limited, but that was outweighed by the quality.   Good service as well.  Go early as it tends to get a bit crowded.
author: Candace M.

description: This is a No STAR review, the service is awful, food is gross!! Ordered some food and didn't receive it. Never saw the waitress besides ordering our food! Sushi portions were small and as expensive as it is, left their hungry!! Will not ever be going back!!!!
author: Brittany S.

description: Yummy yummy sushi. We got the Toro sashimi. $6 each but don't miss it (market price). Service could have been a little faster but this place is packed for a reason. Also nicely hidden in a corner basement. Me and two guy friends ate and drank our fill for $104 total. Could definitely be worse. Super loud - maybe not a good first date spot?
author: Sonya Z.

description: I love Frisco. I simply check into a hotel, any hotel, and Yelp my way thru the city. No matter where I go, what I eat or drink, I come away with mentionable experience. Small crowded lil den of a sushi bar with a hip-hop influenced iPod playlist? Really? Good sushi, fast service, and a full service bar. I bestow 5 stars upon thee
author: Mangione M.

description: Fresh food and friendly service. Hidden gem and worth the wait. Intimate seating and limited walking space. The atmosphere is great for social people so don't dress heavily because it gets a little warm in the crowd.
author: Jinnie L.

description:
Now they have great home made :

1, Tsukune - grilled skewered chicken meat 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c1x-dXLJ5U0 
2. Nukazuke - Japanese pickle 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nukazuke
author: Chie J.

description:
Five stars for the house made Gyoza. The pork is marinaded to absolute perfection.

It's awesome that when you walk in the door and leave every employee will shout greetings or thank yous. 

The Humboldt roll isn't made anywhere else. Vegetarians: don't pass it up.  It's so refreshing and filling.

When you have to wait on the awkward staircase by the piano to get a seat, don't fret. The food is all local, organic, and absolutely delicious.

ARIGATOOOO!
author: Bonnie G.

description: A totally fun place to grab dinner. The music is loud, the lights are dim. It seems tiny when you walk in, but it's bigger than it looks. On a Sunday night at around 9:00, we waited about 15 minutes for a party of four. According to their menu, they use 100% organic veggies, which I love. The House Salad (mixed greens with shredded carrots, cucumber, and tomato and a sesame dressing) was tasty. They use shiso in a lot of their rolls, which is an unusual flavor that I really enjoyed. The Hot Tail Roll (marinated yellowtail in a supposedly spicy sauce, with shiso, and cucumber) was good, but certainly not spicy. The Volcano Roll (tempura shrimp, jalapeno, peanut butter, cucumber, and flying fish roe) was quite enjoyable. it didn't scream peanut butter, but it definitely added a nice flavor you don't normally get in a sushi roll! I had the soju with lemon soda to drink. It was incredibly dry....tasted like a vodka soda with a bit of lemon. I'll probably try the soju with Calpico next time.
author: Dara M.

description:
Good sushi in a basement. On my second visit, it was as crowded as I remember it being on my first. There was no one at the host stand, but we gradually realized there's a self-manned sign-up sheet for a table. With a few names in front of us, we had around a 30-minute wait ahead, which would have been easier if there was space to stand (or, hell, sit!) without being in the way of coming-and-going customers.

The first thing to open was a bar seat, and we took it. We were on the very end, and seemed to get a little forgotten because of this. The folks behind the bar did not handle orders, but a separate girl who had a table section on the floor. We ordered three rolls to share and commenced waiting anew. When the sushi finally arrived, we enjoyed most of it -- but frankly, I'm not sure it was any better than sushi places back home (which also often have the bonus of BOGO or 50% off specials). The rolls were on the small side; and my water glass seemed to always be empty. The quirks of a loud, crowded space; the unfortunate bar seating; and fairly inattentive staff added up to a mediocre experience for me.
author: Christina G.

description:
Came here for dinner tonight.  We ordered the Nigiri Sushi Dinner (chef's selection of 9 pieces of nigiri sushi with California roll for $30.95) and the Spicy Golden Gate (spicy salmon, shiso, cucumber, and flying fish roe for $7.00).  Everything was absolutely delicious and fresh.

What was most impressive about this restaurant is that it is dimly lit and they play club music!  LOUD.  I seriously could not help but dance in my seat.  Apparently they even have DJs on certain nights.  Someone should come here in clubbing attire and start dancing on the tables!  I'll give you $5.00!  Or part of my sushi roll?
author: Fei L.

description:
This place lives up to its considerable press. I went on a Wednesday, so I missed out on the DJ. However, I really liked the music they were playing. It was in the trip-hop range. (The friend who recommended Ryoko's said their DJ nights are great.) Even on a Wednesday, expect to wait. The servers are very courteous and offer beverages from the bar as you wait.

My dining companion split the sashimi combination with me. Relative to its size, this is not a cheap dish. The quality, though, is something else! I want to drive back there and eat the same meal again. Right now. (Damn job. I should be there, not here.) The fish is buttery and it literally melts in your mouth. It tastes amazingly fresh. I will definitely come here again. You should too.
author: Delya S.

description:
I spoke with someone from the restaurant several weeks after I lost my HTC Evo 4G here, in an attempt to reach the manager of the store and inform them of my plight.  Unfortunately, the manager wasn't in that day.

Within the hour, the manager, Reiko Kobayashi, called me to discuss what transpired.  I inquired whether or not the restaurant had cameras (unfortunately, they don't) and whether or not there were any leads or if there was anything further that could be done.  Unfortunately, it appears to be the end of the case as the police just stopped by here after taking a report and asked if they had cameras as well, and that was the only interrogation on the part of the SFPD.

The SFPD on the other hand, were also pretty hostile when I tried to inquire about the report the following day.  I spoke with someone who identified himself as an "Officer Wonder," who didn't know anything about my particular case, but presumed that I was asking for "the SWAT" team to go out and find my telephone which was rude, defensive and not at all what I was looking for.  I explained to him that I wasn't familiar with such processes after filing a police report and was only merely looking to gather more information.

Needless to say, the reason I was so persistent in trying to retrieve my telephone, apart from the cost of it, was that there were some photos I wanted to upload to my computer, among them some from my birthday with my aunt that were very special to me.  Those, unfortunately, are gone forever.

On a separate and partially related note, there are concerns that cell phones in your pocket can lower your sperm count.  In any case, keep all this in mind when you decide to 1) own a cell phone, 2) wear it in your pocket, 3) if you are thinking about fathering children or 4) if you're going to a restaurant in public.
author: Sunil S.

description: I am not a sushi fan, but my bf is, and he has been wanting to visit for a long time.  We came in at 7 on a monday, thinking it would not be as long of a wait, but I think that everyone else had that idea, too.  Wa waited about 40 minutes for a table, which is fine, because in SF we apparently wait for everything quality food related.  Anyways, we ordered the fried oysters and raw oysters to start, which were both amazing.  Bf ordered numerous nigiri, and was very happy with the quality.  we also ordered a roll, and i had some unagi.  Service was very efficient, and sake was priced nicely.  Atmosphere is great, would recommend for a date or maybe take some out of town visitors.  Really enjoyable experience!
author: CC C.

description: This place was fantastic! We were a large group (9 people) who showed up at 7:00pm and they were able to get us a room in about an hour. They put us in our own room in the back of the restaurant which was appreciated. When we were seated, they told us we had exactly 2 hours and would have to leave at 10:00pm (a little weird, but okay). The sashimi plate was delicious! I was especially impressed with the mackerel and salmon. The rolls were also very good. They also have a few less common fish flown in from the Tokyo fish market. Overall, very satisfied. Stuffed with amazing sushi for only $38 (tip included).
author: Dr. J.

description:
After a celebrating a friend's birthday on a Saturday night, my entourage and I decided we wanted to eat some late night sushi. One of the best things about San Francisco is that you can eat anything at anytime of the day/night.

At around 12 am we stumbled into this hole in the ground sushi restaurant. The first thing I noticed after walking through the doors was how closely it emulated a very dark dungeon. I was very excited and I could not wait to eat! The friendly hostess led us to the back of the restaurant and situated us in our own private room. It was definitely a plus to be given special treatment!

I ordered the Chirasi and I was surprised at how delicious it tasted! Although my dish was rather pricey, it was definitely worth it! Not only was my dish delicious, it was also very fresh. It is very uncanny to find fresh fish at a sushi restaurant, let alone at 12 am.

I have now discovered a new favorite Sushi restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Viennelyn C.

description:
First things first - Awesome service.  When you walk in, all of the employees shout out a greeting to welcome you.  We ate at the Sushi Bar, and at all times had someone ready to help us.  The Chef had a smile for us and prepared some awesome sushi for us.  The rolls don't have alot of the sauces that some places put on, which I was glad for that.  They let their fresh fish do the talking.  
The place has a real loungey type feel to it, with Chill Electronica playing.

Really liked our dinner here and we will be back.

Also, the full bar was a nice touch!
author: Shane B.

description: I tried to phone in an order.. Lady says "okay, ma'am? You have to come in & place your order now.." Really?! Not only that that was ridiculous but her tone of voice was not nice at all. Literally sounded like I was asking the most ridiculous thing.. Like it was something unheard of. I really liked this place but wow.. Really? You could at least apologize for this inconvenience & hope that I would still do business with you. Any employee that treats their customers like that shouldn't keep their job. If you're miserable please find something else that fits you. Ugh. Anyways I recommend the volcano roll, it's my favorite. I will still rate this place with a 4 but honestly that employee really ruined your rep. Easily I would give 1 star if it was my first time here.
author: melanie t.

description: Looking for a sushi bar in San Francisco?  Check out Ryoko's.  You need to come a little early to beat the crowd.  This place gets packed around 7:00.  Worth the wait?  Yes!  Fresh sashimi, excellent rolls and sushi.  I personally loved the ami ebi, uni, and hamachi... Yum!  Prices are reasonable.  Service is very good considering it gets shorty after opening.  My first experience at Ryoko's.  Overall 5 stars in my book.
author: Sean S.

description: OMFG!!!! AMAZING sushi!!!! Bartender at Hotel Nikko suggested it and being a visitor in the city I was open to locals' suggestions. It's a hole in the wall looking spot from the outside but is very roomy once inside. I always like to ask the sushi chef to be creative and make me an original creation. The first one was a Japanese crab roll surrounded by the spiky shell. Dope presentation and delicious taste! Next was some out of this world creation that included white tuna toro...wow!!! So fresh it just melted in my mouth!!!! Eli and David are super cool cats! I soooo recommend this spot! Some of the best sushi I've had!!! And an added plus is that they stay open till 2am serving sushi!! Beats a dinner for that after drinking meal!!!
author: michael c.

description:
This is the best and most fun sushi place in the city. Sure it is very hard to compare very good raw fish but this place is certainly up there. In terms of the aura its number one. Also its open 6Pm-2AM so now you can get good food late.

Amazing place, great sushi, and super hours of operation.

Definitely 5 Stars!
author: misha f.

description: The only good thing about this place is that you can tell that the fish is fresh, other than that, place sucks, like a vacuum, literally, it sucks. Took about 30 minutes for our food to come out after ordering, and  they don't have as much options as other sushi restaurants. They give you about 4-5 small pieces of sushi per roll, so I recommend you buy more than one PER PERSON. Wakame salad... disgusting, do not order, it is not like the wakame salad like you would get in other restaurants at all. Overall, I recommend you go to a different restaurant, not recommended at all.
author: My T.

description:
It's one of my favorite sushi places in SF. To all the sushi lovers Ryoko's is gonna become your favorite spot.
It has a good vibe and it's a fun place to hang out with friends .
it's always packed so I rather go early.
author: Yass N.

description: My favourite sushi spot in the city. I loved the Spicy Golden Gate and the Orange Delight rolls. Fun atmosphere with a DJ. Quite a long line on a Saturday night though... Expected.
author: Rahil S.

description:
What an excellent experience we had!
We tried everything we could and were not disappointed with a single item.  The Eel roll was perfect.  Loved the Jumping Tuna.
A real hidden gem!!
author: Mike M.

description:
I do love sushi.  Had a good experince.  It was pretty packed at 7:30 on a Wednesday, but the wait wasn't too long.  Sushi was yummy, best unagi i've had in SF.  

And it's open real late.  Def wanna check it out sometime  on he later side.
author: Mister G.

description: Great environment, Delicious sushi at a CHEAP cost. They have a DJ who will take song requests :) what more can you ask for?
author: Melisa W.

description: We ordered a variety, including sushi, rolls, miso soup and gyoza. Everything was good, but not that memorable. I've definitely had better rolls, but the sushi was pretty good.
author: Hana H.

description:
This place is not your usual sushi bar. Great music playing immediately upon entering. Staff are friendly and attentive. They have Asahi, Sapporo and Ryoko's beer on tap. I went specifically to have Asahi but next time will definitely have the Ryoko's draft. 
I was looking for happy hour and the Consear recommend at this place. I would definitely say this is not a place for happy hour but more of having a meal with beverages.there is no special happy hour menu. However I did have fresh sushi and it was quite excellent. They had a large selection of sushi directly from Japan. A definite plus when you have a hankering for sushi. Would definitely recommend this if you're looking for a good place for sushi dinner.
author: Lee U.

description:
While most people chowed down on wings, pizza, chips & dip, candy, etc... on Super Bowl Sunday, I started out my week in San Fran with sushi.  Yes, I watched the Cards almost win the Super Bowl, and then I sucked it up and joined a group of girls for sushi at Ryoko's.

Not sure if it wasn't crowded because everyone else was watching the game, but our party of four was welcomed, seated, and fed right away.  The staff couldn't have been friendlier, and I'm not so sure the sushi could've been more fresh either.  I enjoyed everything I put into my mouth.

We started with edamame, moved on to seaweed salad, and then shared a bunch of maki and some nigiri too.  Some of the standouts were the futomaki, volcano roll with peanut butter, ikura, and dragon roll.  Oh, and instead of guzzling beer with the rest of the world, we washed it all down with perfectly hot and flavorful green tea.

If only I could've continued through my week in San Fran eating healthy like I did at Ryoko's... but oh no - it was all downhill after Sunday.  Oh well - thanks Ryoko's for our fresh and fantastic fish.  I hope to come back to visit you soon!
author: Gabi M.

description:
Me like sushi. Me like peanut butter. Ryoko's have sushi roll with peanut butter. FFFFFFFFFFF. Enough said.

Cool atmosphere, exceptional service, good music (there was a DJ playing old school house), great food. Oh and it's open until 2am. I can't believe I've lived down the street from this place for a year and only just now discovered it.
author: Wayne B.
