description: Ryoko's was highly recommended and exceeded my expectations! I kept it safe by ordering the California Roll, Jumping Tuna, and Shrimp Garlic. Everything was extremely tasty and fresh!  However, I can not wait to return and be adventurous with the menu!!!
author: Kamilah M.

description: Needed a late night dinner spot, wanted Japanese... Concierge recommended Ryoko's. GREAT spot. Jam packed, great vibe, lively; food was fantastic, from sushi to the more traditional grilled fare. Highly recommend. Worth the wait in line.
author: Joyce B.

description:
Still a 5 star for me. I really can't go to any other sushi restaurants anymore, even the places that I used to frequent that had "decent" fish for lower prices. "Decent" just doesn't cut it anymore- it doesn't taste the same (ack, I sound like such a snob). I agree that the portions are a little small for the price you're paying (the sashimi is a little smaller, the nigiri slices are a little thinner), but the feeling you get when you have a super fresh piece of seared white tuna toro melt in your mouth can't really be replicated anywhere else. Besides, the rolls are very very reasonable ($5-$7 for a decent amount of fish). 

My usual approach is to sit at the bar and try to order off the specials menu on the board. I've come upon amberjack, barracuda, otoro, chutoro, white tuna toro, special squid (raw), giant clam, japanese sardine, spanish mackerel and more. The hamachi toro is forever out of my grasp. I think I've been there 5+ times where it is on the board but sold out for the night. The chef tells me it's because hamachi is a smaller fish, so thus has a smaller belly portion- so they run out faster. I gotta get to this place earlier than 9pm some day. 

Another great thing is the ambiance. Its in a basement, which I typically hate, but having bumping music on weekends, cute lighting and a full bar totally turns this place into a great sushi lounge. And unlike other lounge places, you can get buzzed off beer, lounge and snack on high caliber pieces of fish. They are open until 2! Where else can get you a good drink and delicious Japanese food past 10pm? 

I'll usually leave with roughly a $60-$70 bill for my guy and I. Last night we had two Sapporos, complimentary edamame, two miso soups, agedashi tofu, amberjack nigiri, sabagari roll and spicy golden gate roll (our two favorites) and two special salmon skin hand rolls that we got when we asked the chef to make us a "surprise roll." We left full and happy!
author: Emily H.

description: The wait was long, service is slow. Sushi rolls were good and fresh but pretty pricey. Most of all there are BUGS flying around, one got on our sushi, so yea not a great place for quality food.
author: Katherine L.

description:
Three words That I thought would never go together but to my surprise is absolutely amazing....... Peanut butter sushi!

My girlfriend and I arrived around 12am on a sat night. There was a little wait but not so bad. We were seated and asked what the chef recommended. Little did we know and crazy concoction was on its way. 1st came up was some great fresh sushi. 

Their California roll was fresh and made with real crab!!!!!
Then came the valcano roll with was nice and spicy.
Last was the Peanut butter roll!

It was a great experience and when back in San Fran will visit again.
author: Nicholas B.

description:
My new favorite sushi in San Francisco.  I'd give them a 6 if possible, but a point off due to the lack of non-sushi/sashimi japanese food on the menu.

Jumping Tuna rolls were excellent, as were nigiri and the other maki, but the jumping rolls were really stand-out awesome.

It's a little cramped at some of the low tables in the back, and getting up to go home is tricky especially after several bottles of sake and shochu, and at night it can be a little loud, but in some ways that is part of the appeal.  The piano used as a stand for DJ decks is amusing.
author: Ryan L.

description: This place is great !!! I have been coming  there for several years. Their sushi is always fresh and delicious. They play good  electronic music. In addition, they offer  full bar which is not typical for SF sushi place.  Be ready to wait in line if you go there on Friday or Saturday night... I never get disappointed with this spot...
author: George B.

description: Wanted to try Ryoko's since it had all these impressive reviews.  I liked the vibe of the place, cool, funky atmosphere and dimly lit. Looked like a bar more than a restaurant. Selection is extensive and ranged from your basic sushi rolls to elaborate special rolls. Wanted Donburi something with rice since I was hungry, it was limited so instead got the kurobota pork sausage at $5 per sausage it better have been good.  Bleh! Disappointing!  Got the BEEF OROSHI which was sliced seared beef with grated radish with ponzu sauce not bad, it was the only thing I seemed to enjoy in this place.  Nothing spectacular that I would consider coming back for.  I tried the JUMPING TUNA Spicy tuna, cucumber, and shiso rolled and deep fried since it was one of their more popular items.  It was dry, ingredients were not fresh, rice looked old and when I tried it the bite was forgettable and not mouth watering.  Another thing I tried was the Volcano Roll sounded interesting Deep fried shrimp, and jalapeno, with peanut butter wow was hoping for it to explode in my mouth.  Nope just a weird taste I had with the first roll that I was hoping it to have an acquired taste, hopefully the second roll would taste better, FAIL.  For $13 what a waste.  Basically for everything we ordered it was almost $100 I was left hungry, still starving since I barely touched what we ordered.  I would have been happy and satisfied eating Panda Express.  Not coming back here.  Probably if there was no other place to go and my friends wanted a place to drink and eat since they are open late but not a place I would suggest at all.  I am wondering why people were raving about this place.  But gave it a try so there. Just being honest.
author: Maria M.

description: I loved the vibe of this place and the chef's choice sashimi platter was super fresh and delicious! We ended up getting a table right away but we just had really good timing.. everyone that came after us had to wait so be prepared!
author: Molly S.

description:
"Looks can be deceiving" and "You can't judge a book by it's cover" are two phrases that accurately describe my feelings about Ryoko.  Walking down the stairs and into the CARPETED dining area, I was skeptical.  At the bar, a server took our drink order.  My friend and I both ordered dirty martinis, but I requested mine only slightly dirty.  The drinks were made in the same shaker and poured into two glasses.  Needless to say, my martini was heavier on the salt than what I wanted and I was a little off-put that my simple request was not acknowledged.  

Luckily, the food and staff made up for the martini offense.  Throughout the night, every time people walked into the restaurant, the servers and owner shouted out a greeting in Japanese.  And speaking of the owner, she was as friendly and accessible as any of the surrounding waitstaff.  That's definitely not something you see every day.  

The rolls I had for dinner were all fresh, huge and delicious.  The yellowtail roll and the tempura tuna roll were my favorites.  At the end of our meal, a plate of mochi was dropped off in honor of our birthday boy, on the house.

Should I find myself in San Francisco again, I will return!
author: Michelle C.

description:
Such a hidden gem; small, underground looking place. If you are looking for fresh fish a great variety - without going broke on a meal - you have got to try this. Their sashimi selection is pretty good and super fresh. I strongly recommend their Uni, the Spanish mackerel and their fried oysters. 

In regards of the service, I've been there several times and the staff is very attentive and friendly. The only downside to this place is that it's first come first serve, there are no reservations available and it get crowded. Also they have this electronic music on the background which creates an interesting ambience to the place.
author: Alan M.

description: Always packed with a line out the door. This is for good reason, of course, since the quality of food is outstanding. Fresh sushi, creative rolls, and a non-conventional atmosphere are what make this place stand out for me. -1 star for the sub-par service, and more importantly for charging by the glass for soft drinks that come from a soda fountain/gun (passable for cans/bottles, inexcusable for a soda fountain).
author: Braden S.

description: Been here numerous times before and I can say that each time I have left happy & satisfied. The sushi rolls are amazing & the prices are great. The only thing that you should be warned about before going is the 45+ minute wait...but the wait is worth it if you love good sushi as much as I do.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Don't be deterred by the ridiculous line or wait--it's worth it! You definitely need to get here right at opening, before if possible. The line starts forming and it keeps on going. This place has amazing rolls and all of it is super fresh, which is a rarity at most sushi restaurants nowadays. The fish was not watery nor was the taste dulled, two common signs of frozen sashimi. 

My friend and I visited on a Friday night and we split three rolls, the Dragon roll, 49ers roll and the Orange Delight. The Dragon roll is a favorite of mine and it's a pervasive dish, but this was one of the best I've had. They were generous with the fish roe topping; real, not imitation crab and loads of avocado were on the roll. The eel top was not slathered in sauce so the grill taste seeped through a little bit to add another dimension to the roll. The 49ers roll rocked. The slices of fish were not skimpy, both the tuna and the salmon were sweet and fatty. Lastly, the Orange Delight, something you don't see everywhere was our third selection. It was refreshing! The fatty salmon and avocado were cut through by the acidity of the citrus topping the roll. The cucumber as well as the sweetness from the thin slices of orange added more balance to this choice and it was very unique. I really liked it. In general, none of the rolls were overloaded with rice. The fish were the star of each plate and they were never skimpy. 

You will definitely need to wait if you show up past opening, the only downside. I would gladly wait an hour for a seat! On top of it all, for this top quality, fresh fish, the prices are very reasonable.
author: Larry Y.

description:
I don't know if I've had sushi this good since Kyoto.

I found Ryoko's via the concierge at the Hotel Triton. It would be easy to miss this great little place - it's not flashy - you enter down some stairs into a small bar setting. If you're looking for fancy, go elsewhere. This is a small, cramped walk-down-stairs restaurant. Great jazz playing, lively ambience, friendly and knowldgegable staff. Very laid back and comfortable. A lot of couples, small groups of friends eating together, everyone having a good time.

I sat at the bar, as I was eating alone. The server quickly came by, and answered my questions, made some recommendations. I asked him for sake recommendations, and he asked me the right questions - it was the smoothest, best sake I've ever had. He was pretty attentive all throughout my meal without being bothersome.

The miso soup was good, pretty consistent with other places. The tempura was also fine. The sushi and sashimi were outstanding. beautiful cuts of fish, well made, fresh smelling and tasting.

I will definitely return.
author: Dennis J.

description:
I got taken here for a special first date. It was perfect.

Bustling; the energy was great. Though it was busy, we didn't wait more than 10 minutes. Service was very attentive and honest about the food taking a while, but that was okay because the best green tea I've ever had kept flowing and the complimentary edamame showed up quick. All the rolls I tried were on point and balanced; I especially appreciated the use of shiso leaf. We ordered two of the "toros" on the special menu: the white tuna and the salmon-- total heaven, so fresh.

We parked three blocks up the hill and that climb was worth it.
author: Lia H.

description:
The reviews are true...Ryoko is fantastic!  

The sushi is incredibly fresh and there really is a "vibe" to this place.  Not sure how to explain it - but it works.

It does get very busy so it can take a while to get your order - but it is "oh so worth the wait".
author: Darren_Hilarie D.

description:
Went with the girls here for a late night dinner ... called ahead for 12 of us and they were able to accommodate us fairly quickly on a Wednesday night.  

Cons:
- No noodle soups or any really warm foods in the menu.  Primarily rolls.  (This was frustrating for me since I was still nursing a bit of a cold at the time)
- Parking is tough in the area
- Mixed reviews from the girls ... some were quite disappointed at the $25 they paid for a few pieces of sushi on rice.

Pros:
- Open late!
- Service was nice ... if not a bit frantic and scattered ... but I might be too waiting on 13 loud, bossy and drunk women
- Interesting assortment of rolls ... some of which were well enjoyed.  
- I got the agedashi tofu which was pretty good ... and the only warm item I could find.

Probably not a future destination, but spur of the moment it managed to accommodate us.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Holy crap. This place ROCKS! 

Came in here last night around midnight, 1 AM, with 11 of my closest friends from work. Were treated like VIP in the private dining room in the back; always nice to have some privacy with your buds. 

I let my friend Richy do all of the ordering but everything was great. The food, there was SO MUCH, and so many pitchers of beer and sake. 

The sake was nice and smooth, the service was outstanding, and we really had a great time. When all was said and done we had a hefty $500 tab, which was totally worth it!

Thanks for putting up with us Ryoko! See you again soon I hope!
author: Leigh W.

description:
Our group dropped by this place New Years night after the countdown. This place was pretty busy with a dj playing loud music; the energy was pretty high. The servers were all energetic and friendly. 

Our group ordered some food and sake bombs. The food was good, but the portions were pretty small. This was true for the both the food and drinks, the large sake was similar to a regular size at other places.  Overall the quality of the food was good and nice that a place that serves fresh sushi would be open that late.
author: Tran N.

description:
Ok, so first off this is my favorite kind of sushi place: little hole in the wall, disguised on the street, tiny and small and crowded but with amazing food, super friendly staff and an abundance of options! 

So on top of the of the typical items one would find at a sushi place, there are also those specialty sushi items that only true connoisseurs would know to ask for. And then there are the trendy sushi rolls that are on the menu, if not for any other reason to spark your interest: for instance there is a roll with peanut butter in it and another one with a slice of cheese. 

And of course I fell for it and ordered both. Both were okay but a little pale in comparison to the other stand out items on the menu. 

If I lived closer in the city, I would be here constantly.
author: Denise B.

description:
Fish was fresh and flavorful. Tried Spanish mackerel so delicious if u like a fatty oily fish like I do.  The negitoro roll a must.
Dj spun house music, made for a cool and funky vibe. 
Three stars bc the service was a bit slow and wait was long.
author: Jamie F.

description: A bit out of my way and not all that conveniant to get to if you have a car, but this place is cool, underground trendy feel, live dj, sushi was fresh and good.  Cool Spot for every now and then or a special occasion.
author: Chelsey G.

description: Always great sushi, good service, and a cool, funky vibe.  Don't forget to walk to the bottom of the stairs and sign in if there are people waiting to be seated.
author: John T.

description:
Our first choice was closed for the holidays... second choice was packed so we ended up here. I can see why this place was highly rated but wow... talk about going to the wrong type of restaurant to eat at. This seems to be a bar to drink and have some sushi than a restaurant. My party was looking for a dinner and not a drinking place. Service started out good, but just ended bad. The waitress was pretty inattentive and we had to flag her down a few times to get her attention. Tea took a while to be refilled when we asked. Literally a minute after signing the credit slip, a waiter told us to leave since they needed the table for other people who are waiting. Yeah, 1 nub. Talk about rude.

Food-wise: the fish was definitely fresh for sure. The spider roll tasted good and was well made. The pokemon roll was really interesting as it had so many different texture and tastes to it. A party where everyone's invited is the best way to describe it. 
The special wasabi sauce they have is really good. It has really really nice kick to it.

Overall, the sushi quality was really up there and great. The prices were high up there also and the portions given were pretty small. I would've given a better rating if it wasn't for the rude service.
author: Steven B.

description: I'm only giving them a one star since they apparently don't do to-go orders anymore?!!! Seriously?!! I've been coming here for 7 years and all of a sudden no more to-go orders?! Very upsetting! At least have a $50 minimum on takeout!! And it says they do takeout on yelp! I'm just upset I didn't get my sashimi platter! Otherwise I love this place! Why else would I be going here for the past 7 years?!
author: Klara Y.

description: my go-to sushi in the city. not once disappointed other than them running out of their hamachi toro lol. service is prompt, friendly and attentive. Omakase is legendary. Daily specials from Japan will run you a pretty penny but remember, cheap sushi isn't good and good sushi isn't cheap. be back soon!
author: Will F.

description:
Word of the Meal: CHARMING

I really enjoyed dining at Ryoko. As with many authentic, cute, hole in the wall Japanese spots, when you enter through the doors and walk down the steps, everyone greets you. My date and I were seated at the bar very quickly. It was fun to watch the sushi chefs work and prepare various dishes. We were served water and complimentary edamame upon being seated. 

We had the mixed tempura to start and the sake (salmon) and hamachi sushi which came in two pieces each - perfect for you and your date to try. As for rolls, we had the Alaskan A's, the Orange Delight and the Volcano rolls. The fish was fresh and the service was great! 

Hands down, we would definitely return!
author: Sean A.

description:
Love the Shiro Maguro Toro at this place.  7$ for an order (2)  is a steal. 
Sit at the sushi bar or you'll end up waiting 30 minutes on a Monday night.
author: James L.

description:
Came for as a big group for a birthday party. I was afraid there would be no room for 15 people but they actually had big tables in the back of the restaurant. I loved that it was kind of dark. They had a DJ there that night so I enjoyed the music with my food. 

Food: ordered too many but each one was really tasty and good!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Why are you still reading Yelp reviews for Ryoko's? Go there. Now. This instant.

I'm serious. As the night carries on, it gets increasingly more difficult to get a table. Don't plan on coming here starving; the wait'll kill you.

The menu's varied with a lot of signature items and interesting spins on tried-and-true staples. Us filthy hakujin Americans rarely notice presentation of food, but you're gonna have a hard time not noticing that here. The food's always prepared flawlessly and the service is fast.

Of course, that's once you acquire a table or a spot at the bar.

For those with tender dispositions, Ryoko's in in that fringe part of the Tenderloin where you'll still feel safe and okay. Still, grow a pair.
author: J. S.

description:
I can only echo what others have said about this place: the food is great - the rolls were delicious and appealing, the nigiri fresh - but the serving time is ridiculous. I've come here twice and had to wait for my order for 45minutes+, but that seems to be standard. The problem appears to be that their venue is too big for their few-men crew of sushi crew.  I've called in to order take-out in advance and found it to take equally long. 

Their prices seem quite good for some items, somewhat overpriced for others, but are generally in the area's norm. The ambience is "hip," the music loud. 

Would love to come here more if the wait wasn't that long!
author: Tizia B.

description: I went here for my 20th birthday awhile back.  It's a pretty awesome hole-in-the-wall secret in SF.  Exposing it on Yelp is still not enough due to the number of Sushi restaurants in the city.  But this place is in the heart of the Tenderloin.  Don't let that fool you.  It's a safe, underground restaurant that provides amazing service, sushi, and mochi.
author: Sam K.

description: Woohoo! As good as it gets!.......Yelps' 5 stars sums it up beautifully! Read all other 5 star reviews I agree with it all. Sorry don't mean to be lazy.
author: Tre T.

description:
I should know better, as I work around the corner and have been sending people here for the last eight years, but a friend wanted to go, even though it was Friday night and I didn't object. The wait was quoted as 30-40 minutes (not un-reasonable), but as the actual time we were standing in the stairwell exceeded an hour and a half, we were starving and losing patience. Without so much as "a sorry for the wait", we got our seats after an hour and 45 minutes!
The service was prompt, thankfully. The edamame was over salted but we asked for an extra bowl anyway after we scarfed down the first one in record time (we were really hungry!). I had the chirashi sushi combo which would have been good if it were not for the extra sour sushi rice. I thought it was just mine, but I guess all my friends noticed it too. My small glass of water got refilled once by the busser who grabbed my glass from the rim (gross palm all over where I drink from!).

In the end we all left with a literal bad taste in our mouths. 

Why one star? I used to really like this place, but it has not satisfied the last handful of times I've been in. It has become very full of itself: Overly loud electronic music, over-priced everything, and over hyped to all the tourists in the Union Square area, has made it a place to avoid.

Oh, and they charged us for the extra edamame! Ouch.
author: Peter C.

description:
You'll totally impress out of town friends with this low-key dimly lit lair of fresh affordable sushi. 

And even if you forget about this place till too late, no harm done, Ryoko's is big enough - that even with large parties - there is little if no wait. Usually.

Once you arrive.

Get prepared to...

Step into a blue cavernous hole of cool.

Order some sort of spicy fried roll.

Actually... Don't hold back.

Try at least 6 rolls. Try the sashimi. Get creative. Let go.

Pick that menu apart with flying fingers and eager chopsticks.

Soak in the jazz and blues art on the walls.

Listen to the eclectic music  bumping through the place.

And cock your head a little.

Letting those neck muscles relax

As you study that simple bill.

While your out of town guests, try to look over your shoulder.

Imagining frightening totals.

But cooly, cause of course this place is cool.

Assure them it's no big thing.

Because you know you're getting a deal.

A cool, hip deal.

In a cool hip spot.

In the city.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Tried this place because it was one of the few sushi places within walking distance of the hotel I was staying at. For near midnight on a tuesday, this place was fairly packed. The servers were very kind and came around to the table enough to be attentive, but not annoying (as some servers tend to be).

Unlike most places I have been to, the food had a very nice balance of flavor, without overly compensating for lack of taste by portion size, although I must admit, the portion sizes at this restaurant were unusually small. Besides the food, the overall ambiance of the place as comfortable and felt somewhat private, due to the dim lighting. One thing I did not enjoy was the fact that the table next to us was a bit too close (within just a few inches), which made for a somewhat cramped feeling. 

In a nut shell, the food was above what I'm used to in the south and east bay, the servers did a great job, but the dining area was fairly tight/small.
author: John T.

description:
We found this place while looking for a place to eat in SF via Yelp. Everyone was nice and friendly and they all chimed in to welcome us in Japanese. Food was great and they all came out in a timely matter. My only qualm about this place was when my friend ordered the tempura ice cream, I took a spoonful to my mouth and met something chewy and savory. At first I thought well maybe they put red bean or something on the batter to give some texture. As I inspected closer, it was not a red bean as I had hoped but octopi. Yah...that one.
But the dessert itself was great after I took a breather. I ordered their green tea and red bean ice cream mochi. Granted I could've bought them in the local Asian food market, but hey at least they offered something I like.
 All in all it didn't change my opinion about the place. I'm sure that was an accident and they do happen. My main course was great. I had the Pokemon, Tiger and Orange delight maki as my entree.
author: Giselle V.

description:
BIG Chunks of FRESH SASHIMI in your rolls! 
Fave: Spicy Tuna Roll.
 Make sure you switch to your Reebok Easytone and run after you look for parking because this place WILL give up your table  if you are not present by your reservation time. YES, even 5 mins .They do mean business!

PLUS: LiveDJ playing house music.
author: Lisa M.

description: Amazing sashimi and nigiri . One of the best you can find for a decent price . I've came here countless of time and I always go for the chef selection nigiri and sashimi . Our server last night the japanese with short hair and tattoo on her arm is amazing ! Very attentive and friendly . I always spend at least $75 or more per person here including their amazing sashimi, teriyaki and drinks .
author: Alvin C.

description:
This sushi addict wishes she could find sushi this good in Chicago!  

Yeah- the basement atmosphere was cool and the server did a good job of filling the tummies of 10-15 intoxicated people, but it's the sushi that's really worthy of these 5 stars.  We ordered so many different rolls and everyone kept urging me to try it all...they too feel my pain that I can't get sushi this fresh in the Midwest.  The sashimi (especially the toro) melted in my mouth and I was a big fan of the specialty rolls as well.  The sexy roll actually had cheese on top of it, which didn't appeal to me when we looked at the menu, but I was surprised by how good it was.  

We also ordered a bunch of bottles of sake, which looked a lot like milk when it showed up at our table.  I've had my fair share of sake in this world, but apparently I"ve been missing out on unfiltered sake and I absolutely love it...my dining companions can back me up on this after watching me drink WAY too much sake throughout the evening. 

I'm planning on enjoying some more sushi before heading back to Chicago and am tempted to go back to Ryoko, but in true yelp fashion I'm going to try something new.  We'll see if Nihon will have sushi that is this fresh and of course I'm hoping for more unfiltered sake, although first I need to recover from last night's sake craziness!
author: Andrea R.

description: This is probably some of the best sushi I've had in San Francisco so far... and I eat a lot of sushi! The fish was incredibly fresh and delicious. We stumbled on this place on a random Wednesday night when it was late and most places in the area were closed. There was still a short wait for a table but it was well worth it. I will definitely be going back!
author: Tina A.

description: As much as my fiancé and I wanted to give more stars, we had to be honest. First, let me start off by saying the staff is super super friendly, which is always nice. The soft shell crab appetizer was delicious and the service was super fast. As much as we appreciate service being prompt, this was just a little over the top. You almost felt rushed and they flip tables like crazy. I think you actually wait longer for a table than you do sitting and eating. We are from the east coast and sushi is probably one of our favorite things to eat. We were very excited to try this place out considering the amount of reviews, however, we should have paid closer attention to the the most recent reviews where people stated some things that definitely would have deterred us from going here. Definitely wish I could have spent a night out in sanfran somewhere else.
author: Lindsay G.

description:
Date & Time:  Friday September 5, 2008 @ 11-ish pm(My Ideal Dinnertime)
Company:  Sara & Justin & Michael
Crowd:  Packed w/ Rowdy Groups of Scenesters(Guys in Fitted Silk-Screened Tees & Diesel Jeans & Girls in Colorful Little Dresses)
Vibe:  Energetic 
Music:  House
Decor:  Located @ The Corner(of Le Coloniel) Down a Flight of Stairs.  A Small Sushi Bar w/ Tightly Packed Banquettes & Wooden Tables.  Funky!
Service:  Very Slow Waitress
Imbibe:  Sake 
Devour:  Sashimi Omakase
Total:  $186.73
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Ahhhhh yes, hipster sushi at its finest!

But the bonus, it's actually very good. I'm pretty spoiled living in LA and in Studio City especially (home to about 40 sushi places in a 3 mile strip). I eat it alot. I go to really good places alot and what tends to happen more times than not is that the really hipster places, well, just don't really deliver in my opinion. Ryoko's was a totally different story.

Their toro was insanely good. Their hamachi, like butter. Their rolls, which i am normally not a fan of were actually very good. And this place actually got me to eat Eel. I haven't touched that stuff for about 5 years after a really nasty bout of food poisoning, but thanks to Ryoko's I may be a believer in it again.

As for the vibe and decor, it's a bit confusing. I kinda think of it as your creepy ex-sailor uncle's basement meets a smurf blue hideaway on acid. Yeah, that made no sense to me either, but you get my point. I'd definitely go back and have some fishy love again there soon. And it's close to some great bars, so win win.
author: Stephy S.

description:
This place is excellent! I was in a hurry, so I had the Checkerboard roll and a beer. It was a very busy Saturday night - which I think is common. It's a small place, with a grand piano that hosts a DJ! He spins up the dance music while you enjoy the sushi. The checkerboard role was tasty - their rice is done properly (not too sticky or soggy) and the fish was so tender and tasty. The avocado seemed a little overripe - but not disturbing to the overall role.
The service is great - very attentive. I gave this place 4 stars because I have limited experience with their food, but I will come back and bring my friends.
author: Dusty S.

description:
WOW WOW WOW! This place is awesome. My husband and I went on a Monday night. We stopped in SF on a whim and stayed a block away. I am from the high desert in so cal. This place is AMAZING! The fish was super fresh, the rolls were perfectly put together, not too much rice, not cut too thick. The presentation was nice. I love the fact that everything was very simple and was all about the FISH!  

We had:

Fried Cheese (meh, it was OK but I wish I would have spent the money on more sushi)

Special on the wall: Hamachi Sushi  (yellow tail) AMMMMAZING! ( we should  have ordered sashimi it was SO fresh)

Husband had:

 Spicy Scallop roll- Simple sweet and perfect!

Hot tuna roll- simplistic and fresh, great quality fish

I had:

The checkerboard roll: If I could afford to eat this every day of my life I would! This roll was the best roll I have ever had! Even over the sushi we had in Hawaii! Hands DOWN!

The Tiger: equally as delicious as everything else 

Desert: Mochi =)

The wait staff was on top of everything! I spilled some hot sake on the bar and our waitress was mopping it up for me with in a half of a second. It is a little pricey but it is so worth it. We don't go to Ruth Chris Steak House- we have SUSHI!! 

Great ambiance, nice music. We ate at the bar and there was plenty of room.

My favorite part: Anytime anyone walked into the restaurant they all say "SUSHI BUSHI!"

I hope you get to dine here!
author: J B.

description:
Generous portions on the Nigiri.  Super fresh.
Got to show my PDX GF what really good sushi is like.
She will never enjoy the "boat" stuff again.

Only complaint :  this place and just about everywhere else the rice is not
real - "seasoned" sushi rice.-- that has been super cooled with hand fanning 
and seasoned with sweet rice wine to make it sweet and sticky.

SO it's Korean style? :-)
author: Joe E.

description:
Great vibe, great food, great service, great music. I am shocked that I have never been here in all the years I lived nearby.  Maybe because every time we tried to eat here it was super busy...and rightly so, it is a pretty great place and people know about it.  We waited for about 10 minutes but by the time we finished, there were about 20 people waiting on the stairs.  Come early, order anything off the menu and chances are it will be delicious, have shiso in it and be fresh and well-made.  The dinner set us back about $100 for the two of us, including tip and two large bottles of beer. 
Parking was a bitch though, so either cab it or park in a lot.
Cant wait to go back!
author: Nilu r.

description: Awesome place for the cost! Me and my boyfriend got out of there spending less the 40 dollars and full! The 49er roll was the best, hamachi roll, good, golden gate bridge was good- they put lettuce in the roll-creative, but could do without. Staff was friendly and great, 30 min wait. And the man at the door is really nice not sure exactly what his job was but if it was to be a friendly face, he earns an A+.
author: Jackie C.

description:
My go to sushi place in the 'hood. I love the fact that they are open late. I love the fact that when I show up late they run out of fish; the fish is fresh!!!

It is not as pricey as other sushi place for the quality, and they have great fish from Japan.

If you know someplace better, let me know. And if you think it's Sanraku, don't bother reading my posts.
author: Joshua C.

description: Allow time to wait in line after signing up on list....but it's worth the wait! Luuuuuuv the 49ers roll. Sushi is very fresh ! You get a free small bowl of edamame after being seated ! I wish they had takeout :-( but it's dine in only
author: Kristen K.

description:
Came here to get some late night sushi while on vacation in San Francisco, CA. The atmosphere is cool, and the music was awesome (progressive house and lots of remixes). To keep it themed with the trip, I ordered a miso soup, the spicy golden gate roll, and the hot tuna roll.

The spicy golden gate roll was the highlight. It had a minty leaf inside named "shiso" that gave it a true unique flavor. The quality of the fish was mind blowing. This joint is the best late night spot I've been to in San Francisco.
author: Christopher G.

description: This place was 1 block from my hotel. I fell in love with sushi when I was on the West Coast years ago, due to how fresh the fish is. I was only in town for a few short days and my trip was set...no time in the plans for sushi this visit. So...one night we sat down to a dungeoness crab feast around 9pm. We arrived back at the hotel around 11:30pm. I decided I HAD to have a lil sushi. So I walked up the street...alone. My wife was waaay to full from the crab. Was a good thing too...there was a 1 hour wait for a table. I was able to sit at the sushi bar after about 10 minutes. I had 3 rolls and remembered exactly why I love sushi and the West coast. I will be back to do much more dmage to this establishment...brace yourself Ryoko!
author: Frank G.

description:
When my husband responded to the waiters question of how the oysters were, the server replied, "the other table liked them."  (mind you they weren't very fresh...)

Um, okay...

Since he didn't take that off the bill or make any real concerning acknowledgement of that statement, that obviously was a major turn off.  

THAT being said, the sushi was really good and I'd go back despite some shortcomings.

Very good california roll.
author: Krystal R.

description:
A very good friend of mine treated me to this gem. We ordered omakase style, the sake kept flowing, the fish was extremely fresh and nothing disappointed. Young crowd but loads of Japanese 'suits' as well.

Ryoko's is definitely a must visit hot spot.
author: Coco M.

description:
Definitely would come here again. Enjoyed the food. 

Got a bit crowded on a Thursday night, guess it's popular
author: D S.

description:
This place rocks! I love that they are open so late and they serve bomb ass food! We all drank ourselves into oblivion there last night and it was amazing! 

I have been here a couple times and I sorta remember the food being pretty bomb. Needless to say, I was annoyingly drunk both times. Maybe I should try coming here sober?
author: Jamie S.

description: Can you say "hole in the wall"? Those are usually the best. Ryoko's does not disappoint. First remember to put your name on the list yourself. We ordered Jumping California, 49'er, Crunchy Crab, ... All were great. Service was prompt.
author: Pietro M.

description:
We were recommended here by one of the neighboring hotels.  We decided to give it a chance because the concierge called it a "hole in the wall" and we didn't want to be a tourist.

First off when we walked in from a rainy night, the place was warm and we instantly felt better.  Then (probably my favorite part about this place) the WHOLE staff welcomes you with a big "Hello".  It was great.

I was already in love when the food started coming and all the fish was fresh and delicious.  I would 100% recommend people to this place to get sushi. 

It does get loud, which I personally loved, but it would be hard for a quite date night.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Kept it pretty basic with the edamame, chef's choice sashimi dinner platter (which comes with miso soup), rainbow and pokeman rolls, and of course some warm sake. 

Pokeman roll was salmon, mango, avocado, in soy paper. Definitely worth trying. 

Beware the rainbow roll which is twenty bucks, still good though. 

There is tempura ice cream for those who like to finish it off with something sweet. 

Place can get packed really quick, so plan accordingly. Parking is difficult so better to walk or take a cab.
author: Summit S.

description: Get there early...ok...now...we loved it here. If I lived in SF I'd ne a regular for sure. We sat at the sushi bar and tried some old favorutes amd some chef recommendations. The place was packed, but the sushi came out pretty fast. Service was great and the small underground atmosphere was pretty warm and welcoming. It felt like a big social event. Food was outstanding. You will not be disappointed. Prices are high,  but I find most sushi places to be expensive.
author: Alex R.

description: Food was great, fresh taste, well portioned and very tasty.  We were first in line starting at 5:30 and by 6 there was a line around the block.  If you want amazing sushi, you need to get here early.
author: Juan Z.

description: My favorite sushi spot in the city. It's crowded, loud, open late, and has the most flavorful, fresh fish around. Expect a wait, and get at least a couple items off the specials list at the bar. The back room is great for a group!
author: Jessi N.

description:
This place has great sushi and service!  I've only been there twice now with one of my girls, during the week around actual dinner time (7ish).  It can be a little on the pricey side, but it's so close to Union Square so that's not surprising.  

I don't remember what we had the first time we went there, but this time our edamame was cooked and seasoned perfectly, the Toro sashimi (on special) was fresh and delicious, and the 49er and Dragon rolls were super yummy.  We also had our water glasses / tea cups refilled constantly.   It seemed the the servers were working more as a team, which was cool (multiple servers checked in with us ).  I can't wait go back and try some of their other specials / rolls! 

A huge plus about Ryoko's is that it's conveniently located near Union Square, so it's a great spot to grab a bite after doing a little shopping.  It's also a 10-minute walk to the GAMH, which makes it an option for a pre-show dinner! Another after dinner spot it's near is 50 Mason Social House, a cool little wine / beer bar that has live music.  

My advice to you: Plan ahead and make a "reservation" the day before to avoid a wait...otherwise, you'll get to hang with all the other folks who are camped out on the stairs waiting for a table (even during the week).  So, here's how it works: If you call your reservation in, they will simply put your name on the list that everyone else has to sign upon arrival.  When you arrive, let them know, and they cross you off the list and seat you right away!  You only have a 15-minute window (unless you call to tell them you're late), so only make a reservation if you can be on time!
author: Amy B.

description:
We arrived as a large group right before the restaurant opened at 6:00pm. This was a huge mistake. The waitress/hostess seemed a bit annoyed (which is fair, we should have had a reservation), however, our group size did not justify her rudeness for the rest of the night. 

We were put in a dimly lit back room with uncomfortable seating. We turned the lights up a bit and the waitress promptly walked in, turned the lights all the way down, and told us off for turning them up in the rudest way possible. This was also the only time we were able to get her attention - she ignored us all night (we contemplated turning the lights up again in hopes she would come back to take our order). After we paid, it took forever for us to get our receipt, even after asking another waitress where it was. Normally, this would not be a big deal, but for the price to quantity ratio at Ryoko's, there is no justification for bad service.

The only good thing I can say was that the sushi rolls were presented nicely and the fish tasted fresh, despite the fact that half our group watched the other half eat while they waited for their order to come out.

Oh yes - they also add an 18% gratuity for groups larger than 5, which was told to us after we were seated. What a rip off.

Overall:

+ 1 for the food
+ 1 for the polite waitress (not our assigned waitress) who came by to check on us and bring plates of food
author: Marc P.

description: EDM tunes mixed with a lively crowd and superb sushi.  You must see for yourself.  Excellent
author: S O.

description:
Most of the items were good however I think this place gets way too hot for me to feel good about eating sushi in here. Waitress was pleasant and food came out quickly, I just didn't feel great eating the food, which can't be good when the goal of going out to eat is to eat.

You walk downstairs into a place that might make a better underground (literally) bar than a sushi spot. Kind of divey, kind of dingy, music was pretty cool and got me in the mood to hit some bars after. I probably wouldn't go back though.
author: Rhonda G.

description:
This place is dark and feels kind of dirty.  Sort of like... it could be a club during the night and a sushi joint during the day.  That doesn't really sit well with me, but if you can overlook that, the sushi was okay given the price and location (not that it was a hot location, but rather, that there aren't too many outstanding sushi places in the area).  2.5 stars, perhaps.

We had maki rolls and sashimi.  If I needed to choose a sushi spot within four blocks of this place, I would probably pick Sushi Rika or more likely, Dojima Ann first.  Probably Sanraku too.
author: Erika C.

description:
AWESOME hidden sushi gem tucked away in the cusp of Lower Nob Hil/Tenderloin/Union Square area.  My friends and I stumbled upon this joint when we were turned away from Nob Hill Cafe and had a PHENOMENAL time!

It was 7:25pm when we showed up on a Friday night and the hostess told us that for a party of 4, it would be about a ~15 minute wait.  

We said fine.  

Then she came back to us two minutes later and said that if we wouldn't mind being finished with our meal by 9pm, then she could seat us in the "back room" [which had a 9 o'clock dinner reservation].  

Given that we had a concert to attend at the Masonic Center that night, we said, "HELL YEAH!"

The room in the back was secluded, had tons of comfy lounge chairs to sit on and was decked out in an all-blue theme.  We felt like we were VIPs.  

Waitstaff: Knowledgeable, friendly, accomodating, quick service.
Sushi: fresh selection.  TRY THE SPECIALS!!  They were very good!  Ask for the chef's roll, it was DELICIOUS!!  

I would most definitely come back here!!
author: Katie C.

description:
I've been coming here for four years. It's my favorite sushi restaurant in the city because of its combination of ambiance, full bar, good music. It feels almost like a bar or lounge - in a good way.

Of course, the fantastic sushi is key as well, both in quality and portions. Try the tuna yukke appetizer!

I do see a number of disappointed or impatient customers at times because the service can be very slow. If you're on a timeline or have somewhere to be in an hour, you should probably go somewhere else. If you want to enjoy a fantastic meal with a date or a few friends for an hour or two, this is the best sushi restaurant in the city.
author: Derek W.

description:
Good hamachi and dragon roll.

There was a live DJ.
author: Niniane W.

description:
Although one would think its location and decoration would suffice to make Ryoko a great sushi joint (preferably stumbled upon after a tour of some of the Tenderloin's best watering holes), my experience at Ryoko was mediocre at best.

Disregarding the inattentive staff (which is not too big a deal), the sushi here is overpriced for what you get and very Americanized.  Don't roll your eyes here.  When I say Americanized - I mean it. On top of all the deep fried, mayonnaise infested options, the menu boasts rolls that contain peanut butter --- yes. Peanut Butter. With Fish. So there you have it. You know you've hit mainstream.. and not in a good way.

Overall, Ryoko is a fun bar-like late night spot but neither the sushi nor the atmosphere leave a lasting impression that would excuse the long wait.
author: Roxane W.

description: Super sushi and specials, fun staff, good vibe! Thought we ordered a ton with drinks but bill was only $80. Would definitely go back if in town!!
author: Kandace P.

description:
Great place for sushi, sashimi and sake. Their staff is pretty friendly so feel free to ask them about any of the items that might be unfamiliar or how fresh the fish are. 

Appetizers: 
Try the tuna yukke: fresh tuna mixed with the perfect blend of sesame oil, garlic and shiso. 

Sashimi: 
White tail toro: which is essentially a fatty cut of white tail is divine. It melts in your mouth and probably one of my favorite raw fish 
Salmon toro: Salmon is already a pretty fatty piece of fish but it has the skin attached, also amazing 
Amber jack: almost like a cross between white tail/tuna (very good and it was something new)

Rolls: 
Rainbow: pricey but worth it. The quality of the fish was definitely there and unlike some places they didn't slap on avocado just to fill up space. 
Tahoe roll: On the simpler side, tuna with fish roe. They didn't put as much roe as I have wanted, but overall a solid roll. 

CONS: 
Wished they toned down the blaring house music.
author: Amy L.

description: I was invite by a friend and he was raving of the place. They don't take reservation and the wait was a good hour. Place was a bit noisy and music was going. Food was good but on a smaller portion. the oyster was really good. Host and waiters are very friendly.
author: ML A.

description: Nice enough place but not special. Good sushi but not great, plenty of better options in other parts of the city but I wasn't disappointed.  They are particulartly generous with the servings of fish and very friendly with the welcome!
author: Alan S.

description: Cheap sushi...or I ordered the wrong things. This is SF, probably should've gone to a different sushi place. However this was the only one open at 11:00pm. Oh well, lesson learned. Peanut butter in sushi? Tried it just in case...yeah Hell No....just don't do it.
author: chonn n.

description:
Hip little Japanese restaurant that you'll most likely miss if you're not looking for it. The heart of the restaurant is located in a basement-like area, so it's not very easy to glance in and read the faces of the patrons (if you like to use that method to pick a place to eat at). 

It's really poppin' for a Saturday night. We walked in and was greeted to the music that the DJ was spinning on top of a piano. Great way to get pumped for a night out. 

Best sushi to try: The volcano and The sexy mama 

The volcano are for people who are a fan of peanut butter and spicy food. They have a bit of creamy peanut butter in the middle, along with a slice of jalapeno pepper. It sounds like a weird combination at first, but the sweetness and the creaminess of the peanut butter soothes the kick of the jalapeno pepper. Great, unexpected flavor all in one bite. I've never tasted any other sushi like this. Very yummy! 

The sexy mama is a baked roll. The texture of the baked fish on top was very smooth, it literally melts in your mouth. Another good one to try! 

We made reservations and still had to wait 15 minutes. As we waited, a few parties that came through was told the wait would be another 40 minutes. Just be prepared if you want to dine here.
author: Maggie L.

description: Went here about 1 before closing on a Saturday night. Still lively. The servers were very help and nice. Relatively cheap and delicious sushi. Then had a live dj thing with music bumping. Overall good place. I would go here again if I was in town
author: Anthony V.

description:
Ryoko-oooh yeah! I went here on the suggestion of my friend who lives in the 'hood as it was conveniently 1 block from my spin class. So granted, I was also starving but never mind that: this place inherently rocks. 

My friend  had lived in Japan for a few summers and is now a sushi expert; even though he had sushi for lunch he still wanted to come here and I know why: my unagi (admittedly always my favorite) and on-special white tuna toro were mouth-wateringly delectable. My miso to start was perfectly flavored and the complementary edamame were a fantastic healthy appetizer.

The staff was super helpful and friendly and fast. No wonder it was hopping after 8pm (remember, this is SF where people go to bed at 10pm). I would def hit this place up again! Did I read they are in the Ferry Bldg somewhere too??
author: Diane B.

description:
Arrived at 8:30pm reservations. Seated at 8:40pm. Ordered at 8:50pm. Food arrived at 10:10pm. 

WTF?!?

Not worth going there if I have to wait that long for my food.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
I'm definitely a fan of fun sushi joints with alcohol! This is by far the best place to drink cold sapporo or a smooth bottle of sake and that serves tasty sushi rolls. I have always came here late after 10pm and yet it's always crowded. The place is small, but cozy. It seems very neighborhood-y. There was a live dj on the nights I went (which I believe were Fridays) and he played some good music like nujabes style. None of their sushi rolls disappointed me. My favorite is the pokemon roll. Very fresh and unique. The waitresses are also attentive and fun. They're really nice and will chat with you and occasionally drink with you. 

I would recommend this as a fun, not-awkward date place. There's yummy sushi, good music, and alcohol - all the right ingredients for a successful first date =]  just make sure you make a reservation otherwise you'd have to wait about 45 min - hour, unless you go really late. I can't wait to go back!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
This place is always packed. I was in SF for 10 days on a business trip and went there twice! 
Very good quality sushi and cool atmosphere!
author: Vahid K.

description: The food was great.  Service was very fast.  They also have a good selection and interesting dishes.
author: Steve O.

description:
OK, i'm coming back for an updated review. I guess Ryoko's is just like New York City, everything is so everwhelming the first time you go, it just takes a couple of visits  to fall in love. Maybe the loud music and crampped space was just to much for me as a first timer, but i have growned to enjoy it.  I came here all the time, at first because I lived only 2 blocks away. But i couldn't help realizing that this was infact an awesome sushi joint. 

 Its like Cheers, where everybody knows your name--- but a sushi bar. These ppl know sushi should be done. So expect great quality food when you come. They put up a menu of their specialty fish, but I have to say their Toro is perfect. Melts in your mouth. A bit pricy, but sushi is pretty much expensive anywhere. They have a great selection of sake here. Me n my friends always drink hot sake, and we havent found a better sake place.
author: Libby K.

description: The sushi here is fabulous, especially the toro from Japan.  But we experienced REALLY poor service.  After waiting 45 minutes in the anteroom, the three of us were seated that the world's tiniest table.  The Sapporo beer on tap was flat, and when we asked for an Asahi instead, we got another flat Sapporo.  When we brought this to the waiter's attention,  we finally got an Asahi, but were charged for 2 beers, even though we only consumed one.  Luckily, the others in the party were drinking saki.  The service was totally haphazard.  We will not go here again.  We don't need to be crowded in like sardines and then basically ignored.
author: Bernice R.

description: Great oysters, fresh fish, cozy and friendly atmosphere. Perfect chill Thursday night with good DJ.
author: Cat M.

description:
I cannot recommend the salmon onigiri here, and I guess you can't really mess up grilled rice, so I suppose you can say the yaki onigiri was good. I'm not sure how fresh the fish is here, since most of our plates were sushi rolls and not sashimi - so you'd imagine how hard I'd have to try to really deduce whether the fish was fresh. 

There were some pretty interesting dishes, some that I'd wish I had remembered so I know not to order them ever again - and mint leaves in the rolls were a definite no-no. Overall, we had a great time, so that means 4 or 5 stars, right?
author: Angela C.

description: This is clearly a popular haunt, and the price is definitely right compared to a lot of SF sushi joints. However, I found that the price matched the fish quality--I found both to be simply average. Service was very friendly and attentive despite the crowd, which is why this gets 3 stars. But if you're looking for sushi places based on quality of the fish as opposed to inventiveness of the rolls (and you're relatively price-agnostic), I can't strongly recommend Ryoko's.
author: Ben S.

description: Fun place for sushi great for entertaining hosts the only drawback is the price. If you are a sushi lover you will definitely appreciate this place. Nice clean fresh flavors packed in a single bite. This is my second favorite place for sushi in the city cant go wrong here.
author: Phil H.

description:
Still some of the best sashimi in the City!

We had the sashimi platter.  The Maguro-toro, Hamachi and Sake were so fresh the best description is "Like buttah"
We also had the chicken kara-age, and Tuna Yukke.  Oiishi!!  Omai!!

All the items were amazing as usual.  Kudos for the good music, good crowd, amazing sashimi and best of all....i found parking right in front tonight!

Highly recommended to all sushi lovers!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Tonight was another case of the ever present dilemma:  where to eat while in Union Square?  We were headed in the direction of Katana-Ya when I remembered that "underground sushi place", so yelp mobiled it , the reviews looked positive and so we thought to give it a try.

When we first walked in, I thought, "oh noooo...it's some touristy Japanese restaurant?"  The waiter reassured us that the wait would be 10 minutes, max.  It ended up being more like 25 minutes, and could've been even longer since we got passed over for a slightly larger group, that is until the boyfriend protested.  And then they were out of Anchor Steam and Kirin.  Bad, bad start.

But then everything got better.  We ended up in a semi-private room, which I could see being really fun for a birthday celebration or the like.  Our orders were taken right away, tea was kept refilled, and dishes came out pretty quickly.

My first impression was that it was a bit pricey, but we ate a ton of food (mostly rolls, two appetizers), and it still only came out to $25 pp.  

Standouts:  agedashi tofu, hamachi, salmon skin roll, any of the "spicy jumping rolls" (what's not to love about deep fried?), and spicy scallop roll.

Would not order again: onigiri (grilled or plain, both were pretty awful), shitake mushroom roll (bleh), nikujaga (pork stew, really sweet).

Overall, pretty good!  And an easy walk from Union Square too.
author: Joanne G.

description:
So I'm a little hesitant with this review.  Typically, my impressions of restaurants fall generally in line with the consensus view of fellow Yelpers.  In this case, the 700+ reviews for this place skews highly in favor of it.  

As much as I liked the uniqueness of Ryoko's (open until 2am; somewhat hidden, semi-underground location, clubby music), I found the food to be average at best.

Maybe I just picked the wrong things.  But really, 0 for 6?  I have a better chance of winning the lottery.

The  list of appetizers is impressive (and that doesn't even include the special items written by hand above the sushi counter).  The agedashi tofu was fresh and tasty ... but pretty much exactly like what I've had at every other sushi place.  The kurobuta sausages come in four bite size mini sausages and again, this was fine but far from blowing my mind.  There was a special appetizer (pork with carrots), which was actually not good at all meat that was quite tough (seemed overcooked).

We had sushi rolls instead of nigiri (which is maybe where we went wrong as there seemed to be quite a special selection of unusual fish).  The sushi rolls themselves were quite interesting sounding so we went with those.

Initially skeptical of the Volcano Roll (fried shrimp with PEANUT BUTTER, jalapeno, cucumber and fish roe), our server raved about it and said it was the best thing on the menu and was featured on the Food Network.  All right, sure, why not?  I'll tell you why.  It tastes exactly like it sounds.  Having a bite of bland sushi then following it up with a spoonful of peanut butter.  Eh.

Also had the Hot Tuna roll (spicy tuna), which was actually not bad and I liked the fact that it's whole pieces of maguro instead of mashed up in to a tuna paste.  The Spicy Scallop was not spicy at all but I guess it was a scallop so 50/50 there.  Yay.  By the way, all the rolls ordered come with the nori on the outside (very Korean-like) instead of the rice on the outside (picture California rolls).  Thought it strange.

So I've come to the following conclusion.  Those who rave about this place probably fall into one of two categores: one, those who had the sashimi and tried what I hear is fresh fish imported from Japan on a weekly basis (and not the rolls or appetizers); or two, those who are not so much fans of raw fish but are late-night clubbers who like to think they've "experienced" sushi by coming here and having the surprisingly large selection of non-raw sushi rolls (there are literally at LEAST 20 sushi rolls that are either deep fried, just contain veggies or have cooked unagi (bbq eel).
author: F. P.

description: I dined on a Thursday night, arriving at 7 pm. The wait was 15 minutes.The wait is in a stairway.  I sat at the bar. The sushi is good, the prices are decent (for San Francisco) and service good. I have dinned at plenty of better sushi places all over the SF peninsula. The Taylor and Post Streets area is okay but can be a bit scary walking up from Market Street.
author: jd h.

description: The sushi is great here. I bring family, friends, co-workers; no one has every said they didn't have a great meal. The wait is a little long sometimes, but well worth it. The atmosphere is also great for date night, because it feels so intimate and cute. This is my favorite place for sushi in the city!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Hotspot for sushi in the TL. Make a rezzy or be prepared to wait.

We had some off menu sake that was absolutely smooth.

Then we went for an omakase.

Ankimo - delicious
Toro sashimi - awesome
Steamed octopus - soo tender
Braised whole Tai - Excellent
Nigiri of Hirame, Hamachi, Mirugai, Uni - everything was perfect and their rice was really good, good punch of rice vinegar and spot on texture.

-1 star for the crazy bill.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I just have to update my review. Since the last I have frequented here many late nights. And a little under a year ago I discovered the KFC roll. SHUT UP. 
popcorn sized friend chicken. Chipotle sauce. rice and cucumbers (if i remember correctly). So innovated. And so dlish. Might sound gross but PLEASE. Try it.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Okay, I'm in dilemma................ It's in between A-OK or Yay! I'm a fan.

The best thing that I had here was the torikawa, chicken skin skewer, because I just love fat. I've been wanting to try this place, and find out what's the deal with the line... while I'm eating, this girl standing next to me said to her friend "This place has amazing sushi and they open late!!!" The open-late part is amazing indeed.

Great selections of sushi rolls. Amazing service! You'll be overwhelmed by all the greetings upon entering.... the ambiance is great too. Very small, a little dark, but good. 

I am usually not a big fan of peanut butter, but I actually like it with the Volcano roll. The Big Mama is also good.

Interesting music, cute bathroom, and good friend to share dinner with. I guess I can be a fan. $30, and still hungry.
author: Marlis T.

description: The sushi I had here was EXCELLENT! Fish were perfect, not too much rice. Pricier than what I'm used to being from Seattle, but totally worth it.
author: Kayan H.

description: One of my all time favorite sushi places! The 49er roll is awesome! Fish is so fresh... Service is good, but a bit slow. I wish they were open for lunch too! Great late night spot!
author: Nick B.

description: Some of the best sushi I've ever had.  Big eye tuna and white tuna toro are absolute must-have's if they are available.  The volcano roll has peanut butter inside and is fantastic, Pokemon roll is dope too.  Honestly though, their fish is so fresh and perfectly prepared that the next time I go I'll probably just pig out on ngiri and sashimi.  Very reasonable prices, which is probably why there's a wait almost all the time :(
author: Ryan H.

description: Monday night at 645pm and only waited 5 mins.  gf wanted to try this place and it wasn't bad. the food was really good. i think we ordered a lychee martini that was also delicious.  only downside was the service was kind of poor. it was on the slower side. its such a small place.  i cant remember how many times we asked for certain things and they had to apologize.  i would probably consider coming back but i would definitely not wait long to be seated.
author: Wendy H.

description:
A dive-bar interior but very good sushi and service.  I visited with a party of four on a Tuesday night.  We had reservations, and one of us was a regular.  He ordered for the entire group;  I'm not sure what we got, but the fish quality was great (I remember the salmon and tuna rolls and sashimi were very un-fishy).  

They forgot my spicy scallop roll though.  Le sigh.

I'd go here again just to take a crack at ordering myself.
author: Bill H.

description:
I'm beginning to develop this theory that everything in SF tastes 10 times better than what the rest of the Bay Area has to offer. I mean the logic is pretty sound considering that restaurants in SF are in fierce competition with each other for business. And that definitely works to our advantage cause then we can sample premium Sashimi. 

Let me be frank. I have a top list of Sushi places already and this place has just broken every rule in my Sushi list. I mean you literally eat in a basement below grade which is optimal because you're able to control the temperature of the space. It could be a million degrees outside and raining but downstairs, you're in a good spot. Nice and Cozy. Although a bit cramped, it matches the restaurant's vibe. 

My girl took me here last night and it's definitely a hip happening spot with a saturday night house DJ and Premium Toro. There was so much TORO on the menu! But beware, because you're eating at a premium, expect to pay premium. My girl and I are hardcore sushi eaters and this matched what we were lusting after. Superb.
author: Jon H.

description:
I was drawn to this small blue capsule of a restaurant from the second I spotted it. It looks like something that would be featured in a strange & intense movie. Turns out the food is amazing, the service is excellent & the atmosphere is top-notch. Success!

From edamame to wakame salad to their variety of sushi rolls, we were not disappointed. Thank goodness it's on the way to my mister's house. I have a feeling we will be frequenting this place now.

We sat at the bar, which was a treat because we got to watch the chefs make sushi, a mesmerizing affair. Even though the place was packed, the wait staff was attentive. I do love that in a place.

I've been on a long search for the best Sushi place in SF (need a 'replacement' for the best Sushi in the bay area, Hanamaru in Sunnyvale) and this one is looking like it might be a competitive top spot. Can't wait to return and try out more rolls & see if they truly are the best.
author: Tawnee K.

description:
If you like real sushi, this is my favorite place to go. The fish is amazing, the chefs are awesome, and the place is lively. There is usually a wait, because it's that good.

This place is great to moving from rolls to Sushi and Sashimi. Check out their special fish, hamachi toro, king salmon, etc... just amazing.

If you like rolls or bento boxes or baked rolls covered with sauce.. there are better/cheaper places.
author: Luke W.

description:
ENOUGH!!!  ... Fine you win.  This is indeed one of the best sushi places in the city.  I just moved over to this part of the city from the Mission and tried em all and Ryoko is one of the best.  

I have sat at the bar and watched a few time's and every single sushi chef I have witnessed is a top notch professional with traditional style and respect for the art and customer culture.

+ They have a roll with Peanut Butter!!!
author: Shawn L.

description: This place was average to bad. People, let's try and calibrate ourselves when rating sushi restaurants. Five stars means the freshest and rarest sushi in the city. There can only be one or two 5 star places in your city unless you live in Tokyo! 4 stars is for places with consistent fish quality that is always fresh. This place is not a 4 star. This place is not a 3 star because of the horrible service.
author: Chris S.

description:
F#$@!

(Please, excuse my Japanese)

It was a Tuesday night, and most places are not supposed to be so busy when the doors open. I mean, Busy? Really?
This, was a really amazing place. Down a set of stairs leading in to a small space, you are greeted by a roar from the Chef, and then a chorus from the staff. Nice touch. 
We sat at a table at first, though the soap solution they use for the tables was too strong for my olfactory senses, so we moved to the sushi bar.
Very,Very friendly chef, who, somehow, can create masterpieces, while chewing the fat with his bar customers. A feat not easy to do. 
And watching how he and the staff worked so very well together, and the quality control he was in charge of, well, this is my favorite Sushi Chef Ever.

Great, selection of Sake, Really fresh Fish, and great cuts of the fish.
We kept eating until we both looked like miniature blobs, ready to terrorize the city! 
I mean, so good that you just could not leave anything be.

Ever in Frisco? You need to go.
Incredible.
author: MaJ C.

description:
EXACTLY what I wanted. Walking distance from Parc 55 hotel/Union Square. Not too busy, found a table right away; DJ playing cool tunes, not too loudly so we can talk; Servers attentive and friendly, but not suffocating. A perfect Christmas Eve chow-down.

Started with Tuna Yukke, which was excellent. Also had fried baby octopus, also very good. 

Agedashi Tofu was not a hit. I've had much much better. Broth was weak and unremarkable. You can make bitchin' agedashi tofu at home, and you should! This was a real disappointment, because I love agedashi tofu and this was a big reason why we came here. Oh well, only one miss out of an otherwise great menu. Moving on....

Rolls: Volcano was wild but pleasurable. Moved on to Salmon Skin (great), Asten (very good), Alaskan A's (wow), Tiger (very good), and finished with a special order of tuna/roe/salmon skin and yamogobo. Also had a waganori (spelling?) off the special board that was mostly tuna and was also very satisfying.  

By far, the tuna yukke was the highlight. Simply perfect. If you like tuna/toro, this is one to order. 

Pay attention to the special board. Lots of treasures in there. 

Had a pitcher of Sapporo, which was refreshing. 

Overall: Recommended and we will certainly be back. If I lived in the city, this place would be a serious problem for me.
author: Jason S.

description:
Love the environment of the sushi place and its location.  The sushi is average for SF- meaning it is pretty damn good compared to anywhere else.... 

I like the draft beers they have here- go great with the sushi. They also had a good specials menu.  There were two guys eating what appeared to be crab next to me, who said it was an "off menu" special that only they could order.  It looked really good. I was there for sushi, not crabs anyway. Definitely would come back here...
author: Jim B.

description: Excellent Sushi at a more than reasonable price!!! Hole in the wall But that's where the greatest joints are!
author: Glenn W.

description:
After hearing a friend rave about her favorite underground sushi bar, I was pretty excited when another friend who lived in the area suggested that we go here for dinner last Thursday. I discovered that it's only a block away from Le Colonial making it a great spot to go for sushi after dancing as they're open late. My friend warned me that there might be a wait, but we walked in as another table for 2 was paying so the wait was short. 

We shared a bottle of nigori sake, and some of the best sushi rolls that I've ever had ... jumping tuna (the tuna melted in my mouth), hot tail (yellowtail tasted amazing with shiso leaf), and the big mama (to satisfy my friend's craving for both tamago and unagi but the tamago overdominated the unagi and shiso flavors) ... Oishi! We were less impressed by the seaweed salad, which was oversauced in vinegar, and the green tea tiramisu special. Service was friendly, and the dj spun some good tunes on top of the piano.
author: Diana B.

description: I felt extremely bad because I found this place and asked my friend if he wants to go.  Oh, terrible decision because it was underground.  Pretty stuffy in there.  The prices were off the charts.  $7 for 5/6 small pieces of sushi (This would not be a problem if it was actually tasty or fresh).  I will take my business somewhere else.  I do not like powered pepper on my sushi... OR poor quality rice on my sushi.   To top it off the tuna was not even fresh.  I can not believe this place has a high rating.  BTW, no service in here.  It's a dead zone.  Avoid at all cost.
author: Ann L.

description: I love everything about this place! The himachi is killer and they always have a ton of specials for choices.  Have taken my whole family here - all age groups - or go by myself as well.  It works for all sushi lovers!
author: Carolyn M.

description: Such nice staff. We tried to sake bomb and spilled beer everywhere! They were so kind and really put up with our shenanigans. Great place and open late! Keep in mind their menu selection is super limited! Very few rolls and no bento box specials.
author: Suzzette M.

description: I went there with some friends on a Friday night while visiting SF. I enjoyed the food and thought it was well-priced. I ordered their uni sashimi and Hot Tail roll--both were good.  Service was kind of slow, and we got our appetizer after the rest of our food. I give this place a star for the atmosphere, a star for decent sushi, and another for good food prices. Would give it another try if I find myself in the area again.
author: Julie T.

description:
Cheap good sushi offered late into the a.m. in a city that sleeps early is a cause for 5 stars.

I especially like the "hot tuna" because whatever the tuna is marinated in has a good kick and a unique flavor that I haven't tasted in spicy tuna rolls at other places. The underground ambiance is nice too.. charming with a bit of tackiness :)

Oh, and I highly appreciate that they take reservations even though they're a  busy place with more patrons than tables.
author: Negien M.

description: Terrible service. Came at 11pm and put my name on the list. The hostess seated two parties in front of me who came later. Once I finally got a table, the waitress took about 10 minutes to come by to even bring by water. She then explained that any sushi order would take 30 minutes to prepare. Until this place gets its service issues handled, any conversation about the food is pointless.
author: Marc P.

description: had a great time here with the gals.  Sushi took a while to come out, and we got there early before the crowd... fair prices for the area- the music was thumping and miso also delicious!
author: Coco J.

description: Ryoko, Ryoko. What am I going to do without you in LA !?!? I seriously left this restaurant speechless because of how amazing their food is! We ordered soooo much food that I can't even recall everything! Its a bit pricey, but so worth it! The fish just melts in your mouth! Its the freshest I have tried so far! I normally don't like salmon and here, I LOVED it! :D the spicy tuna was actual fish instead of that red mushy stuff you usually receive at other restaurants! Hahah try anything! I bet you'll love it!
author: Rachel G.

description: This place sucks!  After reading all these awesome reviews from Yelp, my friend and I decided to give this place a shot on a Monday night and we found out that it is one of those places where people love it based on its decor and service rather than the food.  The decor is very unique for a sushi restaurant and the services was very hospitable, however- there was tons of fruit flies everywhere (gross!).  As for their sushi, I thought it was barely passable at best and nothing special.  I would even dare say that is my be one grade below the stuff they serve at Kabuki!  We tried the agedashi tofu, 49 roll, and a couple of other rolls that I cannot remember the name.  It all had a strange sourness to it that I can't quite figure out what it was.  Anyways, after this disappointing dinner- we actually walked to Ajisen Ramen because we were still hungry and didn't feel like getting ripped off further.  When we left, there was a line of people chilling by the door.  Color me disappointed.
author: Betty L.

description:
I have great appetite when it comes to Japanese food, so I had the sashimi dinner plate, a dragon roll, Tahoe, and,,,,two sake!
The sashimi there was super fresh, I would definitely recommend that!
But I've had better sushi elsewhere, the dragon roll and volcano roll my friend ordered were just beyond average, for the price like$13.
And we had to wait for like 40minutes for food after we ordered! having sake with an empty stomach is not that a pleasure......
author: Kate C.

description: The place is great and so is the food! The portions are bigger than I thought when ordering and I ordered way too much for my stomach... prices are very fair! Music is very good too! Fish was incredibly fresh!
author: Josana I.

description: Some of the best sushi I've had. Didn't have to wait long considering the amount of people waiting in front of us. Service was prompt and very welcoming. Would definitely recommend and go again!
author: Gianna P.

description:
You would have no idea how great this place is from the outside.

But once you enter through the small set of double doors, you walk down into a great laid-back yet super cool atmosphere. It left me wondering if it would all of a sudden turn into a chic karaoke bar at any moment.

Not only was is it a nicely balanced environment between chic and casual, but the sushi is one of the best in my opinion. Everything was clean, timely, well presented and DELICIOUS. God, do yourself a favor and just get one of everything. My favorite? Alaskan A's. Clean and delicious.

It was so good that this is the one restaurant that got my "anti-sushi" friend hooked. So I definitely have to give it some credit!

If you're in the mood for some sushi, this would have to be my first choice in the city so far. So don't miss this one!
author: Myles T.

description:
Insane. Word.

Sit at the bar counter, if you can. 

Thoroughly impressed, regardless of the wait....at any hour of the evening. 

The BEST presentations, flavors. Satisfied beyond belief.
author: Steve L.

description:
Pretty sweet house beats. I didn't hear a single bad track the entire time I was there.

Too bad their taste in music doesn't transfer onto the plates. Their food.... was do-able, but holy-crap they have an expensive rainbow roll. The table next to us actually asked the waiter if there was a mistake on the bill (I guess they ordered it without realizing how ridiculously over-priced it was).

Wouldn't mind coming back for some evening pre-game action, but not for dinner.
author: Meuy S.

description: This place is so convenient! Since i tend to eat late at night, the fact that they open past midnight is already a superrrr plus plus for me!
