The mix of spice from the jalepeño, which is tamed by the creaminess of the peanut butter, and the crunch of the tempura battered shrimp makes for an interesting yet scrumptious treat. 
The quality of the fish is impeccably fresh. The sashimi is so fresh that biting into the fish takes no effort as the morsel falls apart in your mouth like butter. I love the salmon nigiri and white tuna nigiri. The portions can be small and they run out of some fish sometimes, but when they have white tuna it is a must-have. I love to order the 49'ers roll with white tuna substituted for regular tuna. The crunchy crab is another one of my favorites. 
The place has a disc jockey bumping music on the weekends so the ambiance definitely caters to a partying-type crowd Friday and Saturday nights. The wait will be long on the weekends and the place will be packed with people. They DO however take reservations. 
Basically if you're looking to visit Ryoko's and you want a calmer setting with no wait a weekday night is your best bet.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Amazing sushi quality for good prices.  Everything I ate that night, from fried oysters to the shashimi was amazing.
author: Hieu H.

description:
I was really hungry.  I was "my head hurts" hungry.  I was "did that coughing guy behind me on the plane give me swine flu or am I hungry" hungry.  I didn't know what to do.  My first inclination was to go to Walgreens, stock up on medicine and plan revenge.  Luckily for me, I was with two folks who had a much better idea.

They brought me to Ryoko.  The place is pretty tiny and not at all trendy.  I was dubious.  I already had swine flu.  What if I picked something else up at this hole-in-the-wall place?  Well, I did pick something up: deliciousness.  

I started with an endless cup of hot green tea.  It was the perfect remedy for my ailment.  Before we tore into novel pieces of maki, we started with an appetizer.  We had fried cheese sticks.  Fried cheese sticks at a sushi place?  I _know_!  They were like fried mozzarella sticks, but served in wonton paper and accompanied by a spicy sauce.  I didn't try the sauce because it was mayo based, but the sticks were flavorful and unexpected for the locale.  That was the preview.  The real deal were the maki.  We got six different rolls.  My favorite was the spicy scallop - but we ate gigantic rolls topped with avocado, tempura, roe and other wondrous things.  My diner companions raved about a roll that had peanut butter in the middle of it.  I tried it.  I didn't kill me...but I don't think I ever need it in my life again.  I loved eating maki in a city that sits on the Pacific.  Everything tasted fresher and I enjoyed the fish that much more.  The service was friendly and helpful and my experience was a good one.  If back in the neighborhood, I can see myself being up for a return visit despite my Jeremy Piven-borne fear of raw fish.

Sushi devoured, we made leave of the restaurant and I went to my hotel room quite satisfied that I would survive my coughed/sneezed on experience.  But, I still went to Walgreens.  Hot green tea is aces and all but...better living through chemistry.
author: Johnny T.

description:
Visiting S.F. we decided to get some sushi to take out as we had our dogs with us in a very high end hotel and didn't think it wise to leave them on their first night in the room alone. We called Ryokos because the reviews were great but they would not take any orders over the phone, even with a credit card. After walking some 12 blocks I was told there would be at least a 45 minute wait. The extremely nice and personable hostess, after sensing my disappointment (displeasure) made an exception and told me she would get the kitchen to produce in 15 minutes. I was really happy with that and ordered a beer while I waited in the tiny (overstatment) entry way. The place was busy, loud and looked like a lot of fun. A very ecceltic scene that was populated by a younger crowd of people who looked like they had been there before and were enjoying themselves.
As I waited 3-4 more parties walked in and they were told that it would be 45-75 minute wait. With no place to stand they stayed on the stairs leading down to the dining room. They didn't seem surprised. i did like the atmosphere.
After the wonderful hostess sent me on my way (she received a nice tip) I noticed that the bag seemed pretty light. Once I got back to the hotel I found out why. The portions were really small. This certainly isn't the only sushi place to scrimp on the size but it is always disappointing to me and why I either avoid unknown sushi places or eat close to a burger joint so when I'm done I can get something to eat. We had 2 hot dishes, garlic prawns and fried octopus. Both were excellent, wish we had more. The flavors were wonderful. We had 3 rolls. One was bad, something about a Jumping Tuna. It just tasted foul. Our dogs did like it. The other 2 rolls were very good. A volcano roll and something like a checker board with 2 different types of tuna. Certainly good choices.  I gave the food 4 stars even with 1 bad dish, hostess gets a 5, refusing to take a credit card for to-go orders a 1 and value a 2.5 For $70 I just want  more.
author: scott s.

description: It didn't live up to the hype for me. Average sushi - I don't see what all the fuss is about.
author: Paige T.

description:
This is a very solid place for sushi late night!  The venue is almost like a lounge, so it's perfect to sit around, drink, eat, and socialize.  The staff is super helpful and friendly.

I ordered the Chirashi Regular.  It was pretty fresh and tasty, but also pretty standard to my expectations, but a bit more expensive than others in the area.

I'll be revisiting this a lot
author: Richard L.

description: My makeup guy told me to come here, and he said it was the best tuna he ever had.  Yeah, I have a makeup guy and I'm not even famous!  "She ain't a rock star, but she got boobies.  She ain't no actress, but she make movies.  Who dat girl?  Who dat girl?"  Ok, Ok, I'll get into review mode.  It's a short walk from Union Square.  You're greeted by the Chef and staff in Japanese when you come in, walking down the stairs to enter the restaurant.  The tuna was really good.  My fellow good Yelpers said to get the Volcano Roll, and it was outrageous!  It was deep fried shrimp, jalapeno, peanut butter(yes peanut butter), cucumber, and flying fish roe.  Oh God!  Oh God!  Oh God!  Yes!  Yes!  Yes!  Oh Oh God!!!  So, I liked it!!!!  The Sexy Roll wasn't bad either!  The service was great, the fish was fresh, and the Chef was very cute.
author: Blondie R.

description: I like the ambience of this basement sushi joint. Fish is always served at the right temperature (not cold) and cut despite the obvious fast turn-around.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Disappointing.  I went to this place after seeing it on Yelp for the rating and the number of reviews, but this is NOT a 4 star place.

We waited about 30 minutes.  I would expect this for a really good restaurant, but this wasn't one of them.  There was quite a long line, and nothing was really turning over, and I think it is because the staff, while very kind, wasn't exactly speedy with the service.  Looks like there were a lot of out of towners, so I can see tourists seeking this out because of its convenient location.

Once we sat down, we ordered quickly, but then just sat.  Things just took a while... like no refills on the water glasses until we asked... they also completely blew off and lost our appetizer order.  We asked about it at the end of our meal, and they asked if we still wanted it... and somewhat of a half-hearted apology, so we ended up just cancelling the order.

We ordered some rolls.  They were fine... about average for a sushi restaurant.  The fish was pretty fresh.  The Volcano was popular on Yelp reviews.  It was just... fine.  The peanut butter part was a little strange.

It looks like theres a special menu behind the sushi bar with stuff from Japan; that might have potential, but the regular menu looks like nothing special.

Bottom line, I can see tourists liking this place because of the location nearby lots of hotels... but please, let San Francisco leave a better impression on you and take a cab to a better restaurant!!!
author: Jon S.

description: Here's my review - The food is no good, fish is not very fresh.  They served raw oysters on a bed of ice that is used for ice water, so the oysters were not chilled.  Oh and if you are from NY, the food is a reminder of Ave A meh.  I left after my trial 4 dishes and ate elsewhere.
author: Jan Y.

description:
Really? 4 star average rating?

There's nothing worse than eating super-fishy, mushy sashimi & flavorless rolls that have been served to you without wasabi. Even the avocado in the rolls just tasted like bland paste.

Add sour hot house sake to the mix, and a dank, dark back corner with ottomans too tall for the tables, and you'll feel utter discomfort.

To top it off, be prepared to make a run for the bathroom, stat. Both my girlfriend and I got sick. What makes things worse - the sushi here wasn't even cheap. I've had MUCH better quality sashimi for the same price elsewhere.
author: Gina C.

description:
Ummm, it was just, meh... for me. The sushi was ok... I could have gotten the same quality from the Safeway deli, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but if I'm going to a restaurant for sushi, I want it to taste better than the grocery store.

We got edimame (which I'm not a fan of, but the partner in crime loved it), California, Dragon and Spider rolls. All of them were just ok for me. We didn't finish everything, and didn't bother to take anything home for the hour later hunger strike.

I liked the ambiance... the people were very friendly. We got a hello and a goodbye from a lady working the bar. The atmosphere is cool... 

I left wishing the food was better, and this would have been an instant fav.
author: Ashley J.

description:
I have been hearing good things about this place, and finally I had the chance to try for my good friend's B-day dinner.  We were able to reserve a private room for seven people on busy Friday night from 7 to 9.   But if you are walking in, get there early as this place is quite popular.

The menu items are pretty standard (i.e. Americanized), but tasted all yummy and fresh.  All the servers are very friendly and attentive to your needs.
author: Kioko O.

description:
Tasty sushi - caterpillar, spicy crab, tekka maki, seaweed salad, hamachi....good stuff...
Sapporo on draft too
author: Mark K.

description: Ryoko's is an extremely average sushi place. I think the 4 star rating with 1600+ reviews is probably due to the ambiance of the place, which looks like a piano bar. But the food and drink itself are very average. The two rolls I recommend are Sexy and Dragon. Volcano was pretty good too.
author: FoodLover Z.

description: Good food, and great variety because they have import fish from Japan (I.e. Fatty Tuna, eel) but the prce is way toooo much for this ambience (hole in the wall). Price for 2 is $140 (food and 2 beers and 1 bt sake)  and we are not even full yet.
author: Talia S.

description:
Ok, I live in the neighborhood for 4 years and walked by this restaurant over hundred times and I never thought to stop by and get dinner there. However, I decided to go today with my date since the restaurant is rated 4 star...and the conclusion is, I should have kept what I was doing each time I walked by this restaurant - just walk pass it.

The service is great but the sushi/sashimi is really bad. And it's not cheap.
author: Dennis P.

description: Fantastic sushi in the tenderloin district. The place was busy and loud, and it took a while to receive our sushi rolls, but it was worth the wait. We tried the Pokemon which was salmon, mango, & lettuce in a soy wrap - something different and surprisingly good. Also had the California roll made with fresh crab - fabulous!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Great little place but given the cozy atmosphere, it takes a while for tables to free up! The food was nothing to complain about - except maybe the price. Some creative sounding rolls and definitely good portions, however. It's a little hidden, but that probably contributes to an authentic feel. I would recommend booking if you can - though I am not sure what their policy is on reservations. When I called earlier that afternoon, I was told it was "walk-in only" but then saw some tables had been reserved. 
Overall, I'd definitely return.
author: Aletta K.

description: ryoko's is tight. i took a seat at the counter and ordered a sashimi platter. watching the dudes cut the fish nice and tight was mesmerizing. you can tell they care about the quality and craftsmanship of the food they were preparing. its tucked away in the hill so you feel like frodo baggins stooping in to eat here.
author: John B.

description:
After watching 'Wicked', we were in the mood for Japanese, this place had hundreds of rave reviews and opens till 2am.

The restaurant is downstairs, and the entrance is tiny. We arrived past midnight and it was crowded. Service was slow since it was packed, waited 10 minutes to be seated and 10 minutes to order.  We enjoyed the music and the cozy feel of the restaurant. 

We ordered a few appetizers and a roll. Recommended by the waitress, I got a cha-cu with calpico drink, it was yummy and strong enough (which doesn't take much) to give me a good buzz. :) They give out complimentary edamame to start. The orange delight roll was just so-so, nothing special. The best dish we tried was the Tempura appetizer, which came fresh out of the batter and the dipping sauce had a distinctly unique flavor with ginger and dashi. The tempura was lightly breaded, the way it should be! 

Overall, the food was average, though the menu has a good selection of appetizers. They get an extra star for the lively atmosphere and late night hours.  If you crave Japanese food and sake late at night, this is the place to be!
author: Caroline S.

description:
I love this place.  Great sushi, great service (considering how busy it can be), and most importantly, a kicking atmosphere.  

It can be a very easy to pass by on the street, so pay attention or you might miss it.  The entrance is very discreet and it looks pretty boring from the street.  Once you go inside and walk downstairs its a different ballgame.  Its dark, loud, lots of people, christmas lights hanging everywhere, and techno pumping.  

As for the sushi, its great.  Though not the best I've ever had, but it is for sure in the top 5.  Dont pass up the Jumping Tuna!!!
author: Will W.

description:
If you want sushi late at night, this is a good option. But there are much better Sushi places to eat at when everything is open. Cheaper, cleaner, less techno music. 

Remember this little jingle. "If it's after 10 o'cluck, Ryoko's won't suck. If it's before that time, go somewhere else, pay less money, eat better fish, and avoid the tenderloin" (Sung to the tune of Old McDonald)
author: Sir M.

description:
I came here a while ago after a night of dancing at The Wine Bar.  According to Yelp, it was the nearest sashimi-serving venue open at 2AM.

Somehow, I spent over $100 on sashimi and a few rolls just for myself.  Despite the price, I don't remember the food being exceptional--in fact, I remember the tuna on my sashimi platter being rather dry--but it's late-night sushi that satisfied my craving at 2AM on a weekend night.

Would I come back?  Sure, if I were nearby and having an after-midnight sushi craving.  Otherwise, there is certainly better-tasting sushi to be found for same (or lesser) price.
author: H W.

description:
The food was decent.  But the fact that we had to wait for over half an hour for the food was not cool, especially when I went up to the waitress to ask if they can do anything about the wait.

Also, it's just a little too dark, to the point that it's hard to read the menu.
author: Elena K.

description:
I should've written this review a long time ago. I've been eating here for years and to date it is the best sushi place I've ever had! Nevermind that this place isn't a fancy restaurant with white table cloths and silver chopsticks - I'm there for the good sushi! If you're indifferent about the quality of sushi, then you can find plenty of places that will serve you average sushi at a cheap price.

I love the variety of fish and the different styles of sushi that the chefs serve up.  What I love is the variety of flavors you get from high quality fish. Bad sushi tastes the same no matter where you eat. But here you're in for a treat. What looks like a basic piece of nigiri is never that. For example, the salmon's flavor is spiked with some lemon zest and other cuts of fish will have their own individual flavors. Amazing! In addition, if you are brave you can allow the chefs to put your order together. They will often make things that are not on the menu or give you some rare cuts of fish.  These special meals are always delicious.

Ok, yes, this place is located in a basement. It does not look fancy, but like I said, you're paying for good food not fancy decorations. Expect to spend a lot here - good fish will cost you. In addition, the food here is addictive! Believe me, it's all worth it. My favorite, Spanish mackerel.

There are two types of good sushi places:

1. A "good" sushi place where you get a lot of mediocre sushi for cheap;

2. A great sushi place where you get high quality sushi that tastes amazing and will get you hooked on their fish.

This place is #2.

Special thanks to Chef Atsushi for introducing me to some great food!
author: Carlos R.

description: Great sushi, we ordered 12 rolls and they were all delicious! The grilled octopus was incredible, cooked to perfection! The spicy yellow tail roll also really stood out, and of course the saki bombs were great =)
author: Sareena N.

description:
My favorite sushi spot in the city!!
One can come here as soon as it opens or late late night and still have an AMAZING time. I have sat in the front for a quiet dinner and all the way in the back with a large group saki bombing and getting crazy. 
The sushi rolls are great...the asten, the jumping vegi and jumping california are some of my favorites...ohh and the clam miso. Everything is super affordable and so yummy.
The service is usually solid and I have never had to wait more than 5 minutes for a table.
author: Kathleen E.

description: I love this place!! It has everything Sudachi is lacking and more. It costs a little bit more but it's so worth it. The atmosphere is perfect late night underground sushi awesomeness.
author: Amy W.

description:
I think the only complaint my friends had about this place was the fact that since it's underground, there wasn't enough cell service to check in on foursquare *cough*NERDS*cough*.

Fresh off the free-drinks-but-no-food high of the Yelp Holiday Party, and snazzily dressed for a Monday night at 10pm, we decided to try Ryoko on Tinna H's suggestion.   It didn't disappoint - the prices were very reasonable, the service was prompt, and the sushi was delicious.

I had the Pier 39 ($5, crab and asparagus) and the Jumping California ($7, crab and avocado, FRIED-oh-my-god-have-I-told-you-how-I'm-a-sucker-for-anything-fried-*drool*).  Pitchers of beer are $12.  I couldn't finish my two rolls, as delicious as they were, so definitely a good value for the money.

As with all things that arrive late at night (people trying to take someone home at last call, cab drivers, unsolicited text messages from exes), you never know what you might get.  Wandering into Ryoko was the equivalent of waking up from a three-day post-finals bender finding that you have a fairy godmother that cleaned your apartment and supplemented your closet with a few awesome new outfits.  In other words, yay!  I'll be back!
author: Jennie K.

description: Authentic japanese small dishes. Specials changes frequently depending on what's in season.  Sashimi specials are flow in from Japan - as fresh as it gets.  I usually get the sexy roll.
author: cin y.

description:
Very Good food and excellent service.
The atmosphere was excellent as well.
I recommend the Jumping Tuna and the Ryoko's Signature Beer after the meal.
author: JD B.

description:
After searching and searching for a sushi spot while vacationing in SF this past weekend we stumbled across this jewel. EVERYTHING we tried was amazing. The waitress recommended the Volcano roll and at first i was skeptical of peanut butter with sushi but man it was AMAZING. The Albacore melted in my mouth and the Hot tuna roll was soooooo good. 

Try the flying california roll, add cream cheese and jalapeños to make it amazing.

This place was so good that we went two nights in a row!
author: Eric T.

description:
We enjoyed the ambiance, the food and the service.  We wrote ourselves on the list for a short wait but were sat at the Sushi Bar very quickly.

The Sushi chefs were friendly and if you like Peanut Butter, try the Volcano roll.

I definitely will be coming back here.
author: Raymond A.

description:
Saturday night, probably the worst possible moment to try to get into a  crowded sushi restaurant such as this Ryoko, but my perseverance is rewarded after 15' of waiting, not too bad. I stay at the bar, looking at the two guys preparing dozens of interesting rolls with juicy fish tails and eggs sticking out from the rice.  

But, this time, I'm tempted by the chef's choice of sashimi and I go for it. What I get is rather disappointing: 14 small pieces of good quality fish (especially the mackerel and the yellowtail), but not the best choice in consideration of what is on display just in front of me. But, ehi!  for 30$ I would have expected much better. No scallops, no albacore tuna, no fatty tuna, no shrimp. Ridiculous.  

As dessert, I take some balls of green tea ice cream, which are partially frozen, ordinarily good and surely not unforgettable. 

I like the young and noisy atmosphere. I'm sure they can offer much more on the culinary side. Next time, I'll go for the wonderfully looking rolls and I'll probably feel luckier and add a star to the review, following the general trend.  I'll be back in any case.

For now, I'm still looking for my favourite sushi spot ...
author: Andrea L.

description: This place adds instant "cool" to a night out. Walking down steps lined with people waiting for a table you can hear music from the DJ bumping in the dimly lit space. The service is friendly and fast, the sushi is always fresh and the prices are reasonable. The only downside is expect a wait if you don't make reservations (which must be made at least a night ahead).
author: Cb E.

description:
I went to try Ryoko cause of it's 4 stars review.. 
how the hell did this place get a 4 star rating??? 
I admit that the place is cute, but the sushi is blargh... 
tried the salmon and hotate sashimi. hotate barely tastes like real hotate. the salmon was borderline okay. 
I'm sorry but I don't think I'll be coming back here to eat traditional sushi anymore.
author: Miss C.

description:
Me: How the hell did this place get 4+ stars!?!   

Myself:  I think everyone must come here drunk after the bars because this place SUCKS!!!  

Me:  We need to never come here again!

Myself:  This mackerel tastes kind of funky.  I wonder if it sat out in the sun for a few hours?

Me:  Ehh...  I'll eat it.  I'm starving and it cant be bad!  This place has 500+ reviews...

Myself:  Those cheese sticks were pretty good but damn this $40 plate of craptastic sushi is well.... craptastic.

Me:  I cant believe they only have 10 or so types of fish on the menu.  At least its dark enough in here that I wont be able to tell what I'm eating.

Myself:   The music here is awesome!  I wonder if they thought about ambiance instead of food quality when they came up with the idea for this place.

=======   Cut to the next morning, (Enter Bathroom Right)  =======

I:  Oh man...  I don't feel so good.

The Comode:  Oh man.  You dont look so good, and what is that smell!!!

I:  What was I thinking last night.  I think that fish was bad!

My wallet:  I feel really empty inside.  I think I need prozac.

My bank account:  Me... Are you taking out money again!  You just took out like 60 bucks last night.  

The commode:  When will you learn?

I:  Its ok commode.  I wont EVER do that again.  Remember when I got too drunk and said that...  oh wait, bad example.

============  End Scene ============

This has been a reenactment.  The names of the parties involved have been kept the same so you get a real sense of what this place is about.

Food = 1 star
Service = 4 stars
Selection = 1 star
Ambiance = 5 stars (I wish they put some effort into the fish)
Food-Bourne Illness = 0 stars

I had a flight back home the next morning and lets just say I feel bad for those sitting within a 5 seat radius.  Thanks for nothing Ryoko...

ps. Dont park in the white zone across the street.  I got an 88 dollar parking ticket.  Most expensive stomach ache I have ever gotten.  I could have eaten in one of those shady China Town spots for $2 dollars and gotten the same effect.
author: Matthew K.

description:
One word: Nigiri. 

If you love fresh fish that practically melts in your mouth, Ryoko's does Nigirl better than just about anyone in the city. They also have an incredible variety of fish and make their selections very carefully each day based on what's available at the market. Also, the sushi chefs are very friendly and love to chat when you sit at the sushi bar. If you have a slightly bigger budget, it's fun to just sit there for awhile and let them pick out some choices for you.

The only minus I give this place is their use of the japanese basil. It has a strong, almost curry like flavor and is incorporated into a lot of their dishes. It's probably just a taste I have not yet acquired!
author: Erin B.

description:
The sushi here was good, but I've had better.  Nice place, good atmosphere, but the sushi was just average.  The rolls were good, but not that creative or tasty.  Pleasant meal, good service, but nothing special.  I'd eat here again because it is close to my daughter's apartment, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.  

They did have an interesting roll called the Volcano roll. This roll had peanut butter in it.  The roll was very good.  The Jumping Tuna roll was also very good, but it was fried and a bit over battered. Sort of tasted doughy.  Kind of heavy.  I think we left two or three of them on the plate.
author: Brad F.

description: Amazing sushi!! Best place we've eaten. Dragon roll and baby octopus were great. Our server even suggested a special salmon sashimi that was delectable!! Amazing!!
author: Anne-Marie M.

description:
This place is very refreshing, especially having just move from the east coast where it's a struggle to find special maki that isn't deep fried or covered with some sort of mayo sauce. 

They have a great selection of both rolls and fish, so this place should sate any type of sushi lover.  Especially impressive is their selection of simple yet creative maki.  For example, I ordered a variation of a spicy tuna roll with shiso leaves, a salmon and caper roll with shiso (I love those leaves!), an eel/tomago roll with spicy roe, and a smoked salmon roll with avocado and asparagus. 

Each roll was delicious and fresh tasting, made with melt-in-my-mouth fish.  We also got a fried rice ball that was salty, crispy, hot, and awesome!  I had a seaweed and cucumber salad that used a much better and fresher type of seaweed than I expected, but I found the dressing a little too straight-up vinegary...it could have used just a touch of sweetness, imo.  Next time I'd skip the salmon rice ball.  It was unfried and wrapped in seaweed with a little pocket of cooked salmon in the middle...not at all what I expected.  The plain fried one was so delicious and filling that there was no need for it, and it paled in comparison.  I can't have milk products, but my boyfriend insists that the mochi he had for dessert is the best he's ever had...and he's quite a foodie, so I trust that assessment.  

The service was very quick and attentive until we were finished.  We had to wait around at least 10 minutes after we were done eating before we could catch a server's eye to ask for the check. 

There were two of us, and we got out of there for less than $50, which is a huge plus for us!  I could see this becoming a "go to" spot.
author: Aja S.

description:
Had my wife's birthday dinner there on the 21st and everybody that attended that was not familiar with the place said the place rocks!  The service was excellent and they even brought a little birthday dessert dish for the birthday girl which was extra nice!  The DJ was spinning 80's hits and her selection was on point!  I had no problem making reservations for 12 people and everyone that attended said it was great!  I personally have been here before so it was a no brainer to choose this place and best yet, it was just a short walk from our hotel we were staying (Parc 55).  We will be back....
Oh, the sushi was probably four stars, but the service, atmosphere and the whole shebang made up for it!
author: Dan Z.

description: I adore this place. Not only is it merely blocks from my apartment, but it is delicious. I love a warm/inviting atmosphere and I've found that sushi restaurants are often lacking in this respect. Not Ryoko's! It's dimly lit, cozy, always full of people. The waiters are really helpful and sweet, they provide complimentary edamame and the fish is always fresh. I'm obsessed with nigiri and not a big fan of fancy rolls, but they seem to have a good selection. This is the kind of sushi that melts in your mouth and prompts you to empty your wallet all over the table and say, "More." It's also fantastic that they have a full bar. Go. Now.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
We had a really late dinner.  The venue is small, but luckily not to crowded as we anticipated from other yelper reviews... We figured it was a week night..we would be fine and did not make a reservation. WE were greeted and seated with in 5 minutes. Cool!

This place has a nice vibe to it. Good music, good bar. Mix of peeps. It a great spot to come and meet with friends or even just a casual date for some good late night eats. They are open till 2am. 

Among the three of us we ordered:

Pitcher of Saporro
Sexy Roll (crab and avocado)
Grilled Crispy Rice Roll
Chicken Karaage
Gyoza 
Rainbow Roll

Overall, the meal was pretty good. I would definitely return again, I figure Friday and Saturday nights would be poppin! This place reminded us of back in the days when we used to all hang out in the city and eat right after a whole night of clubbing and getting wasted on the weekends...!! BTW, this place is also Zagat rated...
author: Gladys B.

description:
MoshiMoshi!!

MoshiMoshi!!

Is how you'll be greeted by the _entire_ staff when you step through the door and head down the stairs into this gem of a little sushi place in civic-tender-nob-square. ( .. and you'll continue to hear it for every single person that steps through the door after you as well ... )

I went in solo on a weekday evening and was seated at the bar promptly.  The atmosphere is sort of a mixture of bar and sushi restaurant - and includes plenty of dark tucked away seating.  There is club music bumping in the restaurant which made the whole experience feel kind of "young" and "edgy".

I ordered a mid-priced sake which was served in a rocks glass - literally on the rocks - with a lemon.  This method was a first for me - but it was good!  You get a complimentary dish of edamame and that one soup as well. (brain fart.  you know the soup.)  Nice to tide your tummy over as you wait for the main thing.  All brought out very quickly by an exceptionally polite server.

Food:
My main event was a "chef's choice" nigiri, 7 piece, and a california roll.  (The california roll came with my combo, otherwise I'd not have gotten it.)  The nigiri was a pretty typical selection and included some fatty tuna, some eel, some prawn, and a bunch of other stuff that I don't know what it was.  The rice was not the most exciting - it seemed a little crumbly and dry - but the fish was definitely fresh.  The california roll was only so-so - but then again, I don't really ever order these so maybe it's just me.

The wasabi was the bright green kind (read: cheap) and the soy sauce was pretty salty (read: cheap).  These did not contribute to an overall thrilling experience for my tongue, but the fish on the nigiri was fresh and that goes a long way for me.

Dessert was green tea ice cream mochi --- which was a delight!  They brought it out chopped into 8 wedges and supplied whipped cream and cherry (not necessary at all, but oh well).

Impressions:
Ok, it's not a top of the line authentic sushi experience, but it was totally legit and the atmosphere was kind of campy and quaint.  Coupled with fresh fish and totally excellent service, I would definitely consider Ryoko's if you are in the area.  I would NOT try to impress a sushi snob here - it wouldn't work out, but the prices are pretty low for what it is - and you'll most likely walk out happy.

Give it a shot - and get the green tea ice cream mochi!
author: Michael E.

description:
jump! JUMP! jumping everything, hell, jump the broom. anyways, i very much enjoyed this restaurant. it opens late, it has a full bar, and when you want something fried half way down your seat, they got your fix real. (don't take the review out of context, i was not drunk when i went in or when i left.) fresh fish, and fresh ingredients always makes exceptional sushi. the type of sushi that's hard to find in a city wit ha 2am last call.

just a personal favorite, jumping a regular avocado roll. just try it!
author: Victor W.

description:
First we didnt try the food this review based by their services and attitude.
we have a baby travel ling with us, i really want to have some nice Japanese since we are in SF, so i called , i told the lady we have a baby if it is OK to bring the baby to the restaurant because in yelps information it says not good for kids.
She said it is just because it is noisy there but if we arrive before 8PM before they started the DJ we will be fine, so we took a cab to the restaurant, 
then the lady who saw us walk down the stair with baby ..you should see the way her eyes shows her emotions.....first thing she said to us is 
 this restaurant is very small...
i said what? you meant you dont have table now?
she said yup you need to wait for 30 mins..but i meant this is a small restaurant....
the way she acted and talk shows she doesnt want us in the restaurant because we have a baby with us.

then we just walked away, took the cab to the next restaurant..
i meant if you dont really want us bringing the baby why the hell they tell us it is ok ?
just tell us its not good for us bringing the baby..so we dont need to feel pissed and wasted our money to take a cab there!!

i can still remember the way she acted and looked at us at the first second we walked in to the door!!
author: Cindy T.

description:
I went here for my birthday last week because a friend suggested it would be good for a large party. I have to say he was right! I showed up on time for my reservation for 12 with one of my friends. We were seated right away, even with only us 2, which was awesome since some places make you wait for the whole party, and with 12 people some are bound to be late. I was told over the phone that I would have the area for 2 hours, which seemed reasonable. 

The rest of my party finally trickled in and we ordered quite a few drinks. I like that this place has extra large sakes and pitchers of beer which is nice for big groups of drinkers like my friends. I ordered to jumping tuna, which was a spicy tuna fried roll. It was decent and had a yummy dipping sauce. 

The only little bit of drama we had was the waitress informed us we had to leave by 9:15 but my reservation was at 7:30 so I didn't know why we lost that 15 min I was told we had. After going to back and forth with our waitress she finally said we would get the check at 9:15, which made more sense. I think it was more the manager, not the waitress, because she was really sweet. She even brought out a free desert for my birthday. The total bill ended up being only about $30 a person (I didn't even pay). I was shocked it was so low because we ordered A LOT of drinks.

Basically this place is really great for large groups and if you're going to be out with friends, I'm not sure it's for people looking for the freshest sashimi or sushi connoisseur. But the food was decent and I had a great bday experience there.
author: Christine C.

description:
This place is a hidden gem, it's so cutty, imagine a basement dimmed lit japanese restaurant with realllyy weird decor.

The sushi rolls are really good, a bit above average pricing but it was still very good. They have some strange rolls too which i didn't try like peanut butter roll? i will next time. 

the also have a lot of appetizer, finger food type deal. the chicken wings we're really good. Juicy and very saucy/

Another pro is there's private rooms where you can have larger parties, great place to have a fun  bday dinner(imagine karaoke rooms).

This is also the first place i seen a SAKE DISPENSER! i think thats what it was. Downfall, this place gets pretty crowded quick, so make a reservation or go earlier then planned.

BOTTOMS UP! ENJOY THE TECHNO MUSIC while your there, haha UNCE UNCE UNCE UNCE UNCE
author: Tam T.

description: This was a great place to have dinner and drinks. Food was tasty and well portioned. Marco, the busboy was specially attentive and gracious. Our waitress,  Taki (or mophi. Could not tell) was also very good and though you could tell she was way too bussy, she managed. Expect to have a long wait on a Saturday night, but the food and ambiance will make it all worth your while. :)
author: Celene G.

description:
Let me start off by everything that I write is through my personal experience only. I was invited to a birthday party here and this place was picked due to their high rating and good reviews. But honestly after eating here I would never return, even if its for someones birthday and I had to show face by going. 

We started off with a small room for our party of 8 people. Maybe this place wasn't too well set up for parties but I felt a little claustrophobic in that small room that was stuffy and nothing but a costco type fan to circulate air. Our waiter started us off by asking us what we wanted to drink and we replied by tea for now as we were looking at the menu. He informed us it as a 2 dollar charge for each person. Well that was a complete turn off after he said that. 2 dollar charge each person for the same type of tea that any other japanese restaurant serves for free. Maybe I would understand if it came with the tea bag but NOT EVEN. I'm sorry but the two major things that I think should be free are tea and rice from how I was brought up in san francisco. And for those ridiculous prices they couldn't even give us the tea for free. Sad again it wasn't even a tea pot. . . they just refill your cup whenever you go low. 

So some of us etched for tea and the others got water instead. We had ordered some sushi plates and sashimi and in my opinion they weren't worth the prices they charged and they were very stingy on the wasabi. Even one of my friends had said that "I guess wasabi is a scarce thing around here". Lets just say we had to ask him for more wasabi more than once. I have eaten at a lot of high end sushi places and it was worth the expensive prices they charge but this place I have to tell you wasn't horrific tasting, but simply not worth it. But one dish got my blood boiling when it came out. We had ordered a dozen fresh oysters. I enjoy eating fresh oysters once in a while but I usually get them at happy hour for 1 dollar a piece. This place was 2 dollars and 50 cents which I was totally fine with IF it tasted good. When he brought them out they were dinky little pieces. . . I mean the size of a pinky. Some of the oysters wasn't even a whole oyster. It was a simple sliver of slime masked with as much sauce to cover it up as they could. I tried not to make a big deal due to the fact that it was my sisters birthday but enough is enough. I complained to the waiter and he was baffled in how to find an excuse for that repugnance display of an oyster they had in front of me. All he could say was that he had to speak to the manager. So I expected an apology or something, as a business which makes a mistake should, to save an unhappy customer but all I got was "we will refund you for the oysters you did not eat". No sorry my apologies for trying to cheat you, or don't worry about this dish all together for we will not charge you for the half that you ate, but a cheap way of cutting their losses. I mean what kind of business sense does this place have? I have gone to chevy's with better service than this and this is suppose to be a higher end restaurant? 

I was so outraged at the type of service and food they had that I had told myself that I refuse to eat anything else in my own mind. As the mid part of the meal started to come everyone decided on their own that they have had enough of this place as well and we planned to go to another restaurant to have better and more food. For 300 dollars plus worth of food that we had ordered here didn't satisfy any of us. So I said I was going to ask for the check and to get our cake that we had brought in for the birthday girl back so that we would have a more enjoyable environment but my friend saw how upset I was with this place that he opt to do it for me. Unfortunately he misunderstood me and instead of asking for the check and wanting back the cake he told the waiter he wanted to eat the cake now. It was ok because it was a simple mistake so the waiter brought out our cake and we sung happy birthday to the birthday girl. What was missing you ask? No cutting knife or serving plates. He just brought out the cake and spoons. Again fully disgusted at the service. What did he expect us to do? 8 people eat the cake off the serving plate with spoons like neanderthals eating a boar after a kill? We were so exhausted with all this bull that we just told the waiter to bag the cake because we didn't even want to eat it there anymore. We got the check and paid for it and had to go to another restaurant to resume our night. I was so appalled at this place that I wanted to make it better or at least inform the manager of our experience. The manager was really nice and apologized for our experience but I had told her that it was unfortunate but we would not come back ever again and that the time that they could have saved our unhappy experience had passed.
author: Joey P.

description: this place is great, i went there twice when i was visiting, and the food was great and reasonably priced. then while we were sitting there pretty late they didnt rush us out or anything and the owner even said hello and ended up giving my gf her necklace! (which she now wears all the time!) thanks guys!
author: James D.

description:
Definitely a pretty good sushi spot in Union Square.

Late night, and live DJ. Pretty cool spot for a large party too.
author: Jae A.

description:
This place is brilliant. 
I wasnt much of a Sushi foodie.. But after having food at this place. Sushi means a whole different thing.

People who serve are very friendly. They even give u a small yay kinda shout in Japanese when u enter or leave the place.

Food is veryyyy reasonable.

Best time to visit is over the weekend . They hav a really nice Dj playing awesome techno and house music. Something u can never expect from a place this small. 

Stongly recommended if you wanna take it easy on the clubbin but wanna enjoy music with good food and reasonably priced Drinks. :)
author: Vish G.

description: I love this place.  It is open late and they have so many different kinds of sake.  The fish is fresh and the atmosphere is fun and funky.  Most people don't even know this place is here.  You go down a steep staircase to get there.  So much better than a pizza run at 2AM.  =)
author: Christina D.

description: best japanese food I had on our trip. I just wish they didn't run out of so much food. I really enjoyed the stuff that they did have though!
author: Eugene T.

description: BEST PRICE IN TOWN FOR SUSHI no better value and everything is delicous! must try their ika bbq!
author: Caesar H.

description:
elegantly prepared rolls. very fresh fish. but kinda pricey. 
i was little surprised by the menu because they have all of your usual americanized rolls. but the guy next to me was conversing with the chefs in japanese. so i knew they had to be doing something right. i was sitting at the bar, so i was staring at the pile of raw fish in front of me. the fish all looks very fresh (nice happy-looking color), so i had a very good feeling about the place coming in. 
i got golden gate roll and dragon roll. (very authentic, i know...) but they were both beautifully rolled. the fish tasted fresh and not so fishy. the eel was nicely cooked. the avocado was fresh. probably the best (americanized?) rolls i've had. 
i paid $25 including tip for my meal and left happy and somewhat full.
author: Te R.

description: I really like this place. The atmosphere is fun and trendy. The sushi is absolutely fresh and amazing and they have one of my favorite, most unique rolls..the Volcano roll! It has fried shrimp, jalapenos and peanut butter! Before your mouth drops in horror, it is REALLY good. For some reason the peanut butter totally make the roll tasty. It's weird. Their fried octopus is yummy and the sashimi is super fresh. This place is awesome!
author: Jennifer J.

description: The food is not authentic, but I still like it. The atmosphere is pretty cool. I went there on Friday night and I enjoyed the food and the music there. It's a nice place to hangout with friends.
author: Emily R.

description:
Love this place!  Was looking for a good sushi spot for dinner and went to Ryoko. 

The food comes out really quickly, and everything was fresh and flavorful.  We tried some different rolls and nigiri, and everything was delicious.

I loved the small tables and cozy atmosphere.
author: Kirsten S.

description:
Ryoko is a like a hidden place in the city if you don't know the area much. It is a family own restaurant and bar closed by downtown. I would not say the food at this restaurant is 100% traditional Japanese dishes, but they are tasty!!! Full bar is available and my favorite drink at Ryoko is Sakura. Staff are very friendly and truly care about your experience there. 

Couple things about this restaurant. Towards the end of the week, sometimes they will have live DJ which means it features heavier background music in case it is something that you are not looking for. They don't take same day reservation neither and they tend to be busy throughout the week. Therefore, plan your visit at least couple day in advance or else it will depend on luck.
author: Lianna D.

description:
This would be great place for an after-bar snack. (Also, they have a full bar) They're open late, but not a great place for dinner. The sushi is good, but I think a bit expensive for the value. 

The service is snail slow. It took us 10 or 15 minutes just to get the check. Considering that they always have a line outside, it would seem like they would be more interested in turning over tables more quickly. 

If you're not in a hurry, and you want a full bar, Ryokos is a good place. Otherwise, go somewhere else.
author: Kealie G.

description: I love this place..the food is a B+ but I love the atmosphere..the servers were super nice, I love the under ground location, authenticity of things and the DJ playing all my favorite 90's jams.  The hours also make this an awesome place.  This is definitely a place in rotation for me.
author: Helen C.

description:
Open till 2 on Friday and Saturdays which is amazing. They are always pretty busy but they do a good job of clearing tables and getting people in and out of there. 

Whenever someone walks in they give a little holler. It is nice. Kind of like Cheers (Japanese style). Even though they don't know my name like Norm, they act like they know (and like) you. Everyone is friendly. They play loud music which I like. The crowd and decor are eclectic which is refreshing. I like the volcano roll and the spicy tuna hand roll, but everything is good. I can't wait to go back. I wish they were open for lunch because I would leave work and go there today.
author: Lily M.

description:
This place was awesome!  There was a DJ, which made the mood very fun and upbeat.  When you are waiting, DO NOT leave the area toward the bottom of the stairs.  The hostess will simply call names and works through the list QUICKLY.  You can be very fortunate if you're close to the bottom, as you will jump ahead if others aren't paying attention.  

Apps: 
Gyoza - Awesome! 
Agedashi Tofu - Pass on this one

Rolls: 
Spicy Golden Gate - Order 10 of them for yourself.  Fantastic! 
Cali Roll  - Don't overlook this one... really good with great texture
Hot Tuna - Definitely worth while
Pokemon - Great roll with the Mango
author: Scott H.

description: Looks small outside but pretty big inside. Poor parking.  Friendly staff.  Decent quality sushi.
author: Bryant C.

description:
I come here from Los Angeles when visiting the family in the east bay. Traditional Japanese chefs who are young and very hip. Amazingly fresh fish with an environment unlike any other place I have been period.  That SF house/lounge music playing in the back while the taste of heaven enters your mouth, (sockeye salmon belly, blue fin toro, amaebi live) fish is flown in weekly from Japan also with local fresh fish giving it a must eat spot when in the City. I been to many sushi restaurants, over 150, and nothing compares to the overall experience you will have when eating at Ryokos. It's worth every cent. 

I miss you, and will be seeing you in the summer. Much love always.

Gavin G.
author: Gavin G.

description:
So I came here on a late night with some girlfriends (who also apparently Yelped this place on the same day...funny...).  I think it's one of those places that are kinda cute and slightly dive-y that people like to go because it's open late.  Food may have been much better if it was more late (and so I'm more desperate for a place that's open) and/or I was more drunk (and can't tell the difference anyway).

Perhaps I am too harsh.  Certainly not the first place to offer "so-so" sushi at way more than "so-so" price.  I can see how the place might be popular for people who seem attached to certain items (and only order those items).  The spicy tuna roll is quite spicy...one may like that...  The big mama roll was not big...but decent tasting...  The pokemon roll was good....but not necessarily enough for me to go back.

As you can see from my wishy-washy comments, I am rather indifferent to the place.  However, I think my feelings have been skewed by the awesome company of the evening.
author: Fontane L.

description:
Ryoko is a pretty darn cool spot. It's like an underground club for sushi fans and they have a bar - not just sake and beer which is a serious plus. What really makes this place is the ambiance - good ecclectic art n stuff, blue walls, kinda dark, and hidden. I dont think many tourists go here.  

The quality of the fish isn't the best, but some selections are top notch like hamachi and saba. I'm not really a roll person, more into nigiri, so maybe there's more tell there.

The apps are pretty solid fare. Prices are decent.

The wait staff are super friendly and the orders come out in a timely fashion. 

All in all, Ryoko is sold option for sushi if you are in the union square or tenderloin area.
author: Jerome, Jerome T.

description: Visiting from out of town, but have eaten Sushi in many places - from Paris and London, to NYC, LA, SF, Texas, etc. This was my best Sushi meal anywhere that I can recall for at least 10 years. I had the Sushi platter with California roll. Every single piece of fish was so fresh, it was softer and more tender then cream cheese! California rolls were superb. Unagi was fantastic as well. If you are visiting SF and have not had world class Sushi for a while, let me save you from a bunch of mediocre meals - come straight here! Of course, prices are not cheap, but probably average for SF. There are likely 100 restaurants within walking distance of Ryoko's that also serve Sushi, but I can't imagine many are this good!
author: Mitch C.

description: The fish here is scary, sit at the bar and look at how they keep the fish. I give the place 1 star for being open late.
author: Hugh G.

description:
Walking into this restaurant, which is below street level, is intriguing.  You feel like you've walked into a well-kept secret.  Except with over 400 glowing reviews, it really isn't.  Having been here twice, I'd like to say as well that I really love this place.  That being said however, I think this place is just an ok in my book.

First, the positives.  I have to give this place some props for the ambiance.  It's got some energy to it.  Definitely a good place to catch up with your friends to recap in full gory details last weekend's bar jaunts.  Though as with most places in San Francisco, this place is small and I wouldn't recommend going with a group of more than 4 or 5 unless you don't mind waiting.  We went pretty early on a Thursday night (630) and we were seated pretty quickly.  However, by the time we left (745) there was already a line.  At dinner, you could tell they were trying to push us out of our table as quickly as possible (minus points for that too).  

Their specials were appealing - they were serving all kinds of exotic fish.  They even had fish flown straight from Japan.  I will note that to self next time I'm back.  Seeing as its open until 2 am, despite my not-so-glowing comments that follow, I can definitely see myself coming back.  

So as for the food itself - the first time I came here was for a large group birthday party (they seat you in the little back room and you all get to sit on the floor like kindergarteners) and while it was definitely nice to be able to try a bunch of different rolls that way, nothing really stood out to me.  They definitely have a lot that you can choose from but overall the food here is just average.  Last night I decided to go with my usual.  And at $24, their Chirashi is $10 more than it should be for the quality of the fish.  Their fish selection was no spring chicken.  It had that defrosty flavor/consistency to it.  I know there will be a next time here, I'm not going to completely cross this place off in my book.  But I don't think it should take 3 visits before I find something I like on this menu.
author: Jean A.

description:
Food: 7/10 tasty rolls. but too much choice. 

Service: 8/10 appropriately friendly staff. 

Atmosphere: 8/10 nice decoration. good buzz. turn down the music just a little bit, and turn up the lights just a tad. 

Try the sake, distilled in Berkeley!

un abrazo ;)
author: Sebastian C.

description:
Good resonably precied sushi.  I am honestly not the best sushi critic, having only tried it 4 or 5 times now.  The food was fresh though, the environment was good, and it seemed very un-pretentious compared to some sushi joints I have been in.  I had the Spicy tuna roll and a Kirin.
Made for a nice light dinner that didn't leave my wallet empty (that was reserved for the boliled crab on another night).
author: Troy S.

description:
i was really stoked to try this place because i had heard such good things about it. i wasn't exactly blown away but i wasn't disappointed or anything either. i definitely would want to come back here to try some more dishes. the sushi is definitely fresh and they have a lot of specials. when i went they had hamachi belly which i had always been meaning to try. the menu's quite large and there are a lot of interesting rolls to choose from. id recommend just picking a bunch of things from the menu and sharing with a friend. 

something i really didnt like about the restaurant was that it's sooo dark in there! im all for mood lighting but when i have to grab the candle from the table and hover it over the menu as im reading, it's a little much.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
10:30 on a weeknight and the same dilemma as always.  Where do we eat?  After a panicky day and then a few hours of climbing to relieve the stress so my head wouldn't explode, I was starving.

When Ryoko's was suggested, I was sold since it was sure to be open late and I'd heard good things about the food.  I almost called Dan V. to ask him for his recommendations but I restrained.  We had a number of rolls, a grilled squid and an onigiri.  Too much food but everything was good.  The squid was perfectly cooked, not chewy at all, with a nice grilled taste.  The onigiri was too big for me, as usual, and, no, it was not because I have a small mouth.  

My favorite rolls were the spicy scallop with shiso and the spicy hamachi.  The fried spicy tuna roll was also quite tasty, even without the shiso.  

The music they had playing was a nice soundtrack for our conversation and it kept us awake as our adrenaline levels returned to normal.  It's open late and it's tasty so I know I will be a repeat customer.
author: Seong P.

description: Ryoko's is my (so far) my favorite sushi restaurant. The fish is always fresh and the rolls can very from the normal to very different (such as the roll with peanut butter in it, which actually tastes AMAZING). I am always trying to hop around and explore different sushi spots and this is the only place in the whole bay area where I have never been once disappointed. The atmosphere is great, the service rocks, and of course the sushi is perfection. The only thing I don't like about it is how expensive it is.... but good sushi costs good money, so whatever. Definitely recommended if you're in downtown SF.
author: Alaina K.

description:
Love this sushi place! A bit of a long wait on a Saturday night but worth it. 
Tried this place for the 1st time last Saturday after a long day at Stinson Beach.  The Toro Nigiri was uber fresh and fatty, melts in your mouth. The Hamachi Sashimi was buttery and delicious. The Pokemon roll and Hot Tuna roll were excellent as well. 
It was the perfect meal to end a perfect day. The DJ was playing 90's hip hop, which made the whole experience that much more enjoyable.
author: Anica S.

description:
I wouldn't come here if I were drunk...because I'd be afraid of falling down the dimly lit stairs to my death on the way in.  The drink selection is good and the place really has a bar feel.

If there's anything that really makes me a bad environmentalist, it's how much I love tuna...and this place has a lot of choices for tuna.  I will admit that the people ordering blue fin all around me hurt the experience for me.

The miso soup and all of the rolls we ordered were good...but definitely not better than what I've had elsewhere cheaper.  I've had sushi that I felt justified in paying this much for...but this just wasn't it.

Please check out:
http://www.montereybayaquarium.org/cr/cr_seafoodwatch/download.aspx

...and they have a mobile site too!
author: PrincessPeac H.

description: My friends and I ran into here for a quick dinner before a show at the Actors Theatre. I got the hama roll and the eel roll. Everything looked good and smelled good. The joint definitely smells fishy from the sushi and greasy from the fryer.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
This is a great neighborhood spot.. not to mention they are open late! It feels like a dive bar that happens to serve tasty sushi. They are usually playing music pretty loud and some nights there is a DJ which is kind of funny to me because the space is pretty small. 

It might not be the most aesthetically pleasing restaurant but the service has always been good and I've never had anything to complain about. Definitely a fun place to go with your friends.

Also, they do accept credit cards but there is a $15 minimum.
author: Kristin P.

description: There's always a line out the door at this place! The atmosphere is dark and nothing to write home about, but the fish is incredibly fresh, and we always try the specials. The chef prepares special dishes for us because he knows us, and they are excellent, just like the other items we order off the menu. This is one of the best sushi places in the city, filled mostly with locals every night. It's worth the wait if you like sushi. There's music later in the evening.
author: Cathy P.

description: I became privy to this spot after we stopped by the Clift Hotel to catch Blood Orange. I think you'll be a lucky sun of a gun if you can find another laid-back dive bar with a DJ and fresh sushi. Small, busy joint that still managed to seat our party of 8 without much of a wait. The standout was uni that tasted sweet, buttery, melt-in-your-mouth aah-mazing and this is coming from someone that usually describes uni as "what one would imagine fish poop to taste like." Plus another point for ingenuity on a roll with peanut butter. Everything I wanted and never even thought to ask for in one place, Ryoko has earned a permanent spot in my SF rotation.
author: Amy L.

description: Top 4 sushi places I've been. Great textures and super fresh. Highly recommended.
author: anna v.

description:
A warm welcome when you come in and fond farewell when you leave. It's what any Japanese place should be in my book. I was pleasantly surprised to find this little gem tucked away just a few blocks from Union Square. More credit to Yelp for finding great places I may never go to otherwise.

I booked a spot for 9 people and they were very good about getting us to our table in the back of the restaurant. I'm usually a fan of places with windows, but with Ryoko's being in the basement of a building, I had to make do with the mood lighting in the place, which I actually got used to by the end of my visit.

In terms of the food they have here, it was great. Everything I had was fresh and I think the biggest test was that I had some first time sushi eaters with me and in this critical juncture in their lives, I got a tasty nod of approval from all of them at the end of the night. Success!

Their selection is great here, they have a crazy variety of rolls here, some experimental, but everything still seems to work. And my favorite part is that the prices are extremely reasonably, I think our bill came out to about 10/15 a person and we were all satisfied with what we got.

Come late and enjoy the DJ as well! The music is again another nice touch for this overall great place.
author: Roland C.

description:
This came as a recommendation from a friend's coworker's friend's cat sitter's sister's manicurist or something.

The staff was great, they were patient, got our orders right the first time and in general very accommodating -- even for our large party.

The rolls are the way to go here, the chirashi was way over priced and not worth it.  Some things seemed to be a little over priced (rainbow roll for $20?) but other things were reasonable.

I think it's a good late night restaurant when you need some rice to soak up some of the alcohol from a successful night.  I wouldn't mind coming here again now that I have a better idea of what to order.
author: Van W.

description:
This is my Fav Sushi bar!
The tempura ice cream is delicious and i love the fact its not so traditional.
For a night out in the town with your friends this is a great place!
author: Daisy Z.

description:
I've been wanting to try Ryoko's for some time now, and I have to agree with others: it's late night gem of the best kind, and a true sushi connoisseur's must-try. So authentic I almost expected the sachiko statue in shibuya square to greet me as I made my way out out the door, after one of the best spider rolls of my life.

I've paid a higher cover for worse DJs than I did for the superb house beats here, and got an equally fabulous dinner to boot. Perfect service, perfect ambiance, perfect meal. Very, very impressive.
author: Alex B.

description:
OH HOW I LOVE TRYING NEW SUSHI RESTAURANTS!!! Thank you Rich!

This place was really fun and delicious! The sushi made my tastebuds dance! I even enjoyed their hot sake, which typically I reframe from drinking hot sake, but with a little nudge I drank a few cups and was happy to do so.....maybe the alcohol made me say that. I'm telling you there's something special about this place.

The best thing about it was that it felt like an underground elite restaurant. You just have to experience it yourself to know what I'm talking about!


Happy Eats!
author: Janine P.

description:
We came here at the recommendation of our driver at the amazing Pleasant Limo.  Arrived at about 6:30, and got a table immediately.  The service is fast, the sushi very fresh, and overall, a wonderful experience.  

The interior is kind of dark and funky but I liked it.  Our server recommended a couple of sushi items I'd never tried - and I thought I was a sushi veteran - and they were heavenly.
author: Kitty K.

description: Service was super slow and they not only screwed up our order but the table next to us as well. Food was good but not even worth 4 stars. 1 for service, 3 for the food.
author: Brooke B.

description: The sushi here was OK.  I tried the Volcano and the Pokemon.  The Volcano roll does not look like a volcano and the taste does not remind me of a volcano.  It has peanut butter in it.  It taste different.   I ordered the Pokemon roll hoping that the roll will look like a pokeball.  It did not look like a pokeball.
author: Pete C.

description: 3.5 Stars.  Sushi was good especialy the Volcano roll, which had peanut butter.  Now I really know peanut butter goes literally with everything!  We were a big party and had a reservation.  Upon arrival, we were told that we could only stay 2 hours, which actually is information I appreciated having and of course understandable.  I would definitely come back here for the volcano roll alone and to try other things on the menu.
author: Paige J.

description:
I had my doubts about this place, as my friend drove up all I saw was a small little corner walkway, it seemed pretty sketch. What a gem. We walked in and down the stairs and there was a line of people sorta milling about and sitting on the steps. 

After we got sat I noticed we were sitting really close to the other tables on the side of us, this was a little annoying since it seemed like everyone could hear my conversation.

The service was great, the drinks were strong. My friend who is Japanese spoke to the owner [?] who was an older super stylish Japanese woman and gave us her recommendations on what we should eat, we took them. Everything was DELICIOUS. After I ate I was hoping I'd get hungry again later that evening so I could go back before they closed!

Needless to say I was super impressed and I will be taking my friends there for seconds and thirds!

-m.
author: Marie M.

description:
So... went to this place because it was recommended by Yelp as a good place for sushi. Well... it wasn't good.. it was OK!

My first mistake was to follow people's recommendations. Do not order the rolls... they weren't good. Lots of people recommended the jumping tuna roll.. not good! 

However, I did find the Nigiri sushi good and fresh!
author: Claudia H.

description:
I was pretty pleasantly surprised by Ryoko's.  The look of it is somewhat unassuming/grungy, but the food stands strong.  Don't come here expecting a swanky experience, it's a very homely, intimate joint where they seem to know your name.

The sushi was legit, the edamame wasn't undercooked and was salted, and we had this delicious seared beef appetizer that was super tender and perfectly cooked.  The spicy scallop roll in particular was really good.

I was surprised to see that they have a full bar, too.  I'm taking mental note of that-sushi spots with a full bar are few and far between in this city.  Keep this in mind when it's 1:15am on a Saturday night, you're drunkenly stumbling out of some bar and in need of some food and that one last drink you think you need.  You KNOW what I'm talking about.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
What can you say of a place that satisfies your need of decent food at 1AM ? 
Will def come back.
author: Vince A.

description:
Oishii! The food is awesome and presented beautifully! I love the ambiance and the energetic staff that really know their stuff.

I highly recommend going to this place for sushi! It's also a great date spot as well.
author: Michelle C.

description:
As I was writing about this one crappy restaurant that opens till 2AM, this amazing restaurant came to my mind. This restaurant is simply amazing!!


Appatizers, rolls, sushi and even hot sake were very fresh and tasty!! and a big plus for very friendly staffs. They are very kind. I would definitely come to this restaurant for late night sushi instead of one that is located in outer richmond district.
author: Jon S.

description: Okay, despite my last review I went back. We arrived just as the place opened at 6PM and the staff was almost capable. Lowlight included the waitress slamming into my arms, cracking my fingers, and then skeeving me out rubbing my arm and shoulder to apologize. Highlight included the food cause it's just too good.
author: Ivan L.

description: Hadn't been in maybe 8 years, and it's still hopping even late night. (They close at 2am!)  Literally underground and coolio vibe with dance music and sweet servers who wear t-shirts like "I heart chunky & funky beats".  ps They use organic produce. :)
author: Melanie C.

description: Hands down to Ryoko! A good friend recommended this place and I'm hooked! I won't go any other sushi place besides here.  On a busy night their could be a line but it's only because they serve really good japanese food.  Their sashimi and nigiri are really fresh! I've tried other japanese restuarant and this is by far my favorite.  Their prices are a bit on the high end but you get what you pay for...and that's always been my motto for a good japanese food.  Make sure to arrive early or make a reservation because they do get really pack.  I love the ambiance and the fact that they also have a full bar! ;)
author: Vanessa E.

description:
I went up to San Fran with some friends just to mess around and found myself what I believe to be one of the coolest sushi joints I've ever been in. The atmosphere and the DJ were both very cool. My friend and I beat the evening rush by 5 minutes and boy did that place just fill up.

I can see why it gets so busy, The mackerel was great and so was the Fatty Tuna. I'll recommend this spot to any sushi lover hitting the Bay Area.
author: Jeff F.

description: Not bad, but very busy.  I have had better sushi anyway.  I didn't think of it to be very special.  I thought their volcano would be an interesting thing but I hardly tasted the peanut butter.  Also tried the pokemon and was hoping for "pokeballs," but they just looked like "Pikachu."  Nothing special.  Meh.
author: Angelica D.

description:
I was excited to try this place after all the reviews, and it was a huge letdown. I ordered agedashi tofu and a tempura veggie roll. The tofu was really bland and lukewarm, and the roll was very plain for $8. My friend wasn't impressed by his fish and shrimp, either. 

I was also shocked to see a SF restaurant serving bluefin tuna sushi. It's one of the highest-profile overfished species on the planet, and also one of the more likely to go extinct soon (see http://www.montereybayaquarium.org/cr/SeafoodWatch/web/sfw_factsheet.aspx?fid=60 and http://www.guardian.co.uk/environment/2013/jan/09/overfishing-pacific-bluefin-tuna, for example.) I know Ryoko's doesn't make any promises about sustainability, but SF is pretty food-conscious and a lot of high-profile sushi places have stopped serving bluefin. I'd much rather eat sustainable sushi someplace like Tataki than ever come back here.
author: Alexa F.

description:
LATE NIGHT AWESOME SUSHI JOINT IN SF!

Visiting from LA (where besides Japan we RULE in sushi/sashimi spots) I was super satisfied after having my raw fish cravings tamed at Ryoko's!

Thanks to Yelp I located Ryoko's which was 3 blocks up from my hotel.  To my great joy I discovered they are open until 2am!!!!  For a tourist that is a MAJOR bonus!  

Ambiance:  Intimate.  Secretive.  Cool.  Think Tarentino-esque.  I felt like I was dining a dark underworld of sushi ecstasy!  From the outside, you can barely notice the restaurant/bar but when you step inside you're like Alice who fell in the rabbit hole...you're greeted the traditional welcome from the (young) sushi chefs and Lenny Kravitz fills the room.  This place is trendy so old folks should not enter unless you don't mind eating in the dark with the the random drunk chatter that surrounds the small cave.

Food:  REAL Japanese food!  REAL TRADITIONAL NIPPON CUISINE!  A variety of appetizers, rolls, entrees for your pleasure.  Fish that melts in your mouth!  Big chunky slices of fish in your rolls (5 pieces)!  I had halibut and scallions, spicy tuna and salmon n' cream cheese roll...all delicious!  Avoid the raw oysters- they were too big, served room temperature and left a bad oceany aftertaste.

Staff:  Waitress and waiter was as nice as can be.  

Price:  Very affordable- especially for being in Downtown Union Square area.

Warning:  It gets warm in there so don't go wearing a sweater!
author: Ann C.

description:
Fantastic!!
My husband and I LOVE sushi and found Ryoko's during our first trip to San Fransisco/wine country last year.  We made sure to spend an evening in San Francisco so that we would be able to go to Ryoko's.
The quality of the fish in incredible, the rice is perfect and the sushi chefs are a lot of fun!  
Don't miss this place!!
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Wow!! Wow!! The fish is incredibly fresh. So yummy. Atmosphere is edgy... walls painted dark blue and music poppin'. Framed pics of musicians on the walls: Sinatra, Dylan, Etta, etc. Tables are small, but great for small parties or a date.

The jumping Tuna roll is amazing... along with everything else. Great Miso. Great sashimi. Ill be back here... probably next week!
author: Betsy F.

description: My favorite sushi in SF! Full bar, great music, fantastic service. must try the volcano roll, and jumping unagi.
author: Bobby B.

description: Best sushi I had in several years. Similarly good from what I remember from Japan and even the tuna, which is usually always bad, was great!
author: H K.

description: Fun place to go with friends or date. Good food. Love the environment especially when they have a DJ. Good place to get your night started or end up.
author: Jones E.

description:
I often try to defend Yelpers as the voice of the average urban dweller, and not as the 20 to 30 something alcoholic degenerates, with an over inflated sense of worth, that so many people claim we are. I generally believe we have more to offer than some crazy shit show after one too many on a Thursday night. 

Most of the time. However, after seeing how highly rated Ryoko is, with so many reviews ignoring the actual food, and instead siting the DJ, the crowd, the sake, the beer and the fact that they stay open late so you can eat sushi instead of pizza while fucked up, I am starting to question if I give this online community a little too much credit. 

This restaurant is in a basement and, if you did not have your beer goggles on while dining, you would realize that the dim lighting can not hide the fact that it is pretty run down and dirty, just like a...... basement. You might also notice, if you weren't  juiced up on late night sake that probably was a follow up to any number of deadly cocktails, that the prices vs. quality and quantity are something they could only pull off for tourists who do not know any better and late night drunks.

So, fellow yelpers, I know this place is open late, but really, 4 and 5 stars? Even I have fallen victim to a few late night rolls here, made with ingredients that are more suited for a third graders bag lunch sandwich than anything that should be paired with fish, rice or seaweed, but lets not let a little drinking problem taint reality. 

This place is mediocre at best.... and that is after a few too many drinks.
author: Drue C.

description: I used to live in Japan and Ryoko's has the best sushi I've had outside of Japan... maybe even better than Japan! My taste-buds were in heaven! Excellent staff. Quick and friendly service.
author: Monika W.

description:
I was pretty excited about my Sushi Bistro experience last week, but Ryoko has now made that pale in comparison...

First off, the venue is amazing - you walk downstairs into a small, cozy room with no windows, a great ambiance with a DJ spinning music. At past midnight when we left, the DJ was still going strong and it made me wonder if people stay at the bar until closing time. 

Second and perhaps more importantly, the food was AMAZING. Everything I tried was extremely fresh, full of flavor and extremely tender (well, the sashimi at least - the octopus was appropriately rubbery)! I highly recommend the rolls that they flash fry in oil - it's just lightly fried on the outside of the rice, not heavy at all, and the inside is perfectly warm (which was delicious with the unagi & avocado combo in mine). I'm not a tempura person or a huge fried food person, but this was simply amazing - cannot recommend it enough. The other two surprises were the monkfish liver pate (if you like foie gras or liver, give it a try) and the fried baby mackerel, which were like grown up fish sticks, if you will. 

This is the first sushi restaurant that I've been to in SF that truly inspires me to rush back soon - especially late-night because of its good energy from the DJ. The venue is pretty small so it's probably not the best for a huge group but it would be good for meeting a friend or two or a a first date.
author: Kara A.

description: Loved this sushi spot. Got the agedashi tofu and tuna natto. Agedashi tofu was great- not too fishy; tuna natto was great too- not too funky with lots of flavor. We tried just about every sashimi/sushi option and loved it all except the urchin. For rolls we got spicy golden gate, mackerel with pickled ginger, salmon skin, and volcano. Spicy golden gate was yummy but not very spicy. Mackerel was great. Salmon skin was good but I thought it had a little too much going on with the baby carrots... The volcano roll.. I never would've thought it would be any good. My bf said its way better than it has any right to be. Fried shrimp, jalapeño, roe, cucumber and yes- peanut butter. Someone was ridiculously stoned when they came up with it, but it works somehow, even if you're stone cold sober. Great place with large selection of fish, sake, and other alcohol. Recommend it.
author: Laura N.

description: Found this place on yelp. To say it is crowded would be an understatement. Great sushi and sake worth the wait.
author: Punkin P.

description:
I have to agree with the Yelpers who rated this place just OK cos frankly, it really is just OK.
