The venue is quirky and the DJ's a nice touch but I'm here to rate the sushi... and it's not 4 or 5 stars. I tried the maguro, hot tuna, jumping tuna, yakatori, and sea urchin and the sea urchin was very good like butter on the tongue! The rest was not bad, but not memorable either. 

So, I guess if you are nowhere near a Jack in the Box or a Dennys or any other late night restaurant then yah, Ryokos would be cool... but if ur looking for any of the above chances are that you are too drunk to care where you eat anyway.

Bottom line.. average sushi at above-average prices... but hey, there's a DJ!
author: Elise D.

description: Sushi was amazing, the service was okay. There was about a 45 minute wait which turned into an hour and a half (on a Monday) but the hostess was cool enough to take out phone number so we could to the Owl Tree and get sauced up before dinner.
author: Daniel F.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE the place.

We sat at the bar and loved how everyone worked so aggressively...with a smile! I feel their focus is more on the food and service rather than trying to be too hard to be trendy or contemporary--like a majority of houston's sushi places.

- bartender was awesome
- atmosphere is friendly and laid back, which got us into the mood for 3 bottles of unfiltered nigori
- food arrived at appropriate timing. sashimi were fresh--the yellowtail was especially awesome

wish they have a spot like this in houston!
author: Mindy P.

description: not satisfied . I was full and asked for to go box , they refused due to some policy and refused to refund
author: Wesley R.

description: Took my girlfriend here this past thursday and I honestly can say we both enjoyed it. The food was really good as well as the service. I liked how they had a live dj and the prices were not bad at all. Had an overall good experience I plan to come again.
author: Tyler T.

description: I came here around midnight on a Monday night just because it was open and near by. It was pretty busy for that time, so I had a good vibe going in. I only needed a snack, so I ordered the hamachi, some sort of fried tuna roll, and then followed it with amaebe sashimi. Everything was excellent.
author: Victor T.

description:
Thursday night around 7-7:30pm.   There was a slight wait for a table, but bar seating was available so we grabbed two seats nearest to the entrance.  Blue walls.  Dim lighting.  DJ spinning good house music.  Lovely waitress.  Pretty good sushi (slightly on the expensive side).  I'd come again for another fun date night.

Come before 8pm if you want to beat the dinner rush.  There were quite a few people hanging out on the stairs waiting for a table soon after we were seated.
author: Lynda N.

description: practically the only sushi late at night.  sat nights with DJ at the piano.  anything with toro in it sold out early.  the fish is fresh, and the rice more vinegary and on the drier side but otherwise decent, good gari.  negihama wasn't really chopped up.  don't recommend karaage -- fried once and sliced (unlike a sumika style)
author: Rob C.

description: Was staying at a near-by hotel and used Yelp to direct me to Sushi. This place was exactly what I was looking for. Great atmosphere, service and Sushi. Highly Recommend!
author: Gary F.

description:
Went here based on a recommendation from my best friend. It was close-by and the wait wasn't too horrible. But it is a smaller place so the tables are pretty close to each other. My boyfriend ordered all the raw stuff and loved it. He even ordered the uni, which he said was "on point." I, on the other hand, do not eat anything raw so I ordered the spicy beef teriyaki and deep fried oysters. My food didn't come out until my boyfriend was nearly done with his food. The table next to us also ordered the deep fried oysters (I know because their table was so close that we couldn't help but talk to them the entire night). We talked about how their raw food came out so much faster than their cooked food. I think it wasn't until the end of our meal, when we were about to ask to cancel the order of fried oysters that they came out. And they were not worth the wait. Not much flavor. 

Everything else was yummy.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Ryoko's is a very cool sushi spot and I can understand why there is always a wait. We put our name on the list at the host stand and luckily were seated much quicker than I had expected. We ate at the sushi bar (49ers roll, assorted sashimi, sake etc.) All the fish is very fresh and the service was efficient. The menu is a little pricier than most sushi places, but definitely worth it. The ambiance was very cool. Have not encountered places like this before, but definitely recommend to first timers.
author: Marcie D.

description:
Ambiance- We stopped by here on the earlier side of dinner thursday night. The entire thing is underground, and the atmosphere is slight divey turned sushi bar, with pumping techno music. I was a bit surprised at how loud the music was. We were seated near the back of the restaurant, where there was  constant noise from a vacuum?? air conditioner? Not sure. There weren't many people there at the time, so the noise was more noticeable to us.

Food- As far as the food goes, our overall experience was just okay. The edamame tasted off- large, but not particularly tasty beans. They were okay. The chirashi I ordered was fresh, and tasted good- though the bit I enjoyed most were the rolled eggs in the chirashi! They were delicious, with just the right sweetness for me. I thought the price point for the chirashi was about right, at ~20 dollars. We also ordered a 20 dollar rainbow roll, and we were expecting something amazing from a 20 dollar roll. While I admit the presentation was really pretty- artfully arrayed on a big square black plate with various decorations- the rainbow roll was disappointingly ordinary. It was just a regular rainbow roll that we could find at our local sushi joint in oakland, though it was double the price. and on par with rolls from our local sushi joint for less than half the price.
author: J C.

description:
Yelp doesn't give me half stars and it bugs me, I would give it 3.5 stars which seem the perfect score for this cozy place in SF.

Nice lil Japanese style restaurant/bar, if you're out beginning your night out with a few friends, it's nice to stop by and get the party started.  Definitely don't come here with a big group, as the place is about as roomy as a WWII bomb shelter.  The restaurant itself has a very welcoming atmosphere, and the food (coming from a Japanese guy, if it counts for anything) is authentic and decent Japanese fare.

This place is perfect for a group of friends about 3-5.  Don't expect a spectacular meal or a full-scale party, but a fun place to start off your adventures for the evening.
author: Hiro K.

description:
Gotta love the late night sushi!

- First star for charming subterranean atmosphere.  It's romantic, yet very festive all at once
- Another star for being open until 2 am, and super-conveniently located on my way home (or on the way out, I guess)
- Third star for really nice staff and good service even with a packed house
- Last star for good food/drinks menu, reasonably priced and tasty when other places are closed
- No fifth star due to the longish wait (although it was fun to sit on the stairs and the hostess was doing an awesome job managing the wait and keeping us posted) and I wasn't  totally in love with a couple of the rolls we got
author: Jaimie M.

description: Nothing was great, but its not bad either. Its the perfect place to go if you want to eat late, have drinks and eat non-shitty sushi.
author: Wakako U.

description:
We must have come on a bad night.  It was friday, so I understand a bit of a wait, but not an excuse to make sushi rolls that fall apart.

We waited over 1 hour to be seated.  My bf complained to the owner that the chicks were seating others before us, even though we were above them on the list.  She compensated with free beer which did nothing for me since I chose not to drink that night.

I do like the atmosphere and the dj, but the place is way small and the sushi was mediocre.  I had been here years before and the quality I remember was much better.  Tempura was delivered 20 minutes after all the rolls came out, which I thought was weird.  Garlic shrimp was overcooked.  

Should have went to Japantown.  I won't be returning to Ryoko's.
author: Marcia D.

description:
Ryoko's has been a late night sushi standby for years. Make sure to try the tuna yukke and idako appetizers. The yukke has just the right amount of spice and the idako is perfectly done, not greasy.  

The service is a little slow when it's busy, but after some sake you won't mind so much.  Plus with the house music pumping through the sound system you can always do some chair dancing while you wait for your food.
author: Dawn L.

description:
ambiance- fun. food- delicious. service- on it. 

I went here on a Saturday night for an early dinner and had one of the best times.  The atmosphere is very casual but vibrant.  The food was really good, I highly suggest trying the Spicy Golden Gate, it had just the right hint of spice! A few Sapporo's later, many different dishes later, we left full and satisfied!  I love that this place  is kind of a hole in the wall and it's down in a basement, but yet the crowd is mixed between locals and many tourist... mullets and all! Great place to come!
author: Alexa V.

description: Love love love the volcano roll. Pb and jalapenos. Two of my favorites. Intimate size place, but tons of fun. Based on the entrance, you can't tell how much fun you'll have inside. The food was delicious as well!  Definitely worth trying!
author: Dinah S.

description: I have been to this place several times, the first being in 2008.  I fell in LOVE with the place!  The roll selection is great and I really like that they have a daily fresh fish selection.  I will say that the past few times that I have been to Ryoko more recently it has been MUCH busier and lost a little bit of its hidden charm.  Its a little pricy for the size of the rolls as well.  Nonetheless, good food with a trendy dive feel!
author: Liz B.

description: Sushi was good. Somewhat like eating in a cobalt blue underground dive bar...but i heard politicians eat here? Whut? There was a wait. My cute date probably made it teneble. I'm not a sushi buff.
author: Micah J.

description: Fresh fish! Good atmosphere! Sake! I love this place. And they have gluten free soy sauce! So much awesome.
author: Alexis B.

description:
Retro much? Loved the late night, crushed-blue-velvet atmosphere and the conversation starter that is the grand piano that cramped up the space. 

But I've got a but. Maybe it's because I'm spoiled with Vancouver sushi - but I've definitely experienced better. The rice -- a little wet. The flavours -- a little too mellow. Even the wasabi lacked something for me. 

PS. How'd that grand piano got down there in the first place?
author: Crystal H.

description: I stayed at hotel Monaco, so this place was less than 5 minutes away. I ordered the jumping tuna roll, crunchy crab roll, fried octopus, tofu salad and sho chu (vodka mixed with either peach tea / oolong tea / caplico?!). Everything tasted really great, except the portion was a bit tiny! Haha. The tofu salad only had two pieces of tofu, but the dressing was delicious. I will definitely return if I am in the area, and friendly staff.
author: Kosmo Z.

description: Can I give this place 6 stars please? Best Sushi Joint In the City (yes, with capital letters), freshest fish, friendly staff, excellent sake. Sometimes a line, but worth the wait. Sit at the bar and order off the specials menu. Thank-you - that is all.
author: Jordan V.

description: Im a frequent sushi eater and have been to various sushi restaurants and this is by far the worst! First of all, they don't allow you to order food for take out, even if you are eating there and you want to take your leftover food to go, they won't allow you, the most stupid rule ever for any restaurant. Then you have to wait on a staircase until u are seated right next to door that doesn't close, so your forced to wait while you are freezing. Then when you finally order your food, they take long as if they are perfecting your order before serving it to you. But when you finally recieve your food, it looks as if they got it out of package they bought at Safeway, and it tastes that way as well. Bottom line, if you enjoy good sushi, please save your time and avoid eating here. Btw I snuck out my leftover food just because they didn't want me too, and that no takeout rule is just the most ridiculous thing I ever heard! Save yourself and eat elsewhere!
author: Branden S.

description:
ooo its sushi heaven! i am so glad that this place opens until 2am. i can get my late night/after clubbing sushi fix. i took one of my out of town friends here and we immediately knew that this place has good food. there was a clipboard at the bottom of the stairs with 5+ people ahead of us! this place is like a hole on the wall. who knew it was so popular! me and my friend walked past this place the first time around in search of this place and kept walking up the hill :P

want to try something totally different? go for the volcano roll. it is sushi with peanut butter. yup- you read it right- sushi with peanut butter!

so why only 3 stars? the food was delicious and the price was comparable to other sushi restaurants in san francisco. the only thing that bothered me was that while the price was similar to most sushi places, the serving sizes were definitely smaller than most sushi restaurant. i was sorta of disappointed. so sad.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
I think I get why this place gets such great reviews, because initially it charmed the socks off me.  But after mulling over the experience for a little while, I realized that my initial jolt-o-love that I felt for the place should really be tempered with some deeper reservations.

PROS: 

Atmosphere!  Talk about a surprising little hole-in-the-wall... this place had to be some sort of crazy lounge before it was a sushi joint.  The layout is unique, the walls are bright blue, and there is a piano in the middle of the front room. They play CDs straight through (we made it through the best of New Order and began on Green Day's American Idiot before we left).  It doesn't feel like a sushi restaurant so much as a sushi scene.

Service: Several waitresses helped us, and each one was incredibly friendly.  There was never a wait between running out of roll/sake and being offered more.  My boyfriend arrived at the restaurant five minutes before me, and when I got there, there was already food on the table.  Ka-Zow!  These guys are good!

CONS:

Atmosphere: The carpet is old.  Like, skeezy old.  And dirty... stained with the smoke of  a thousand cigarettes from the time-before-sushi.

Food: The rolls we had were tasty, but nothing special.  They were a little greasy (and I'm not talking the deep fried ones) and a little fishy.  That is to say, the fish didn't seem to be incredibly fresh.  Overall, it was nothing special... and ultimately, you don't go to a restaurant for the blue walls and the New Order album - you go because you want the food to blow you away.  Or at least be something special.  Unfortunately, this wasn't.
author: Mariah M.

description: I have been interested in coming here for a long time. Ryoko's has a very sort of urban feel. It's quite a hip spot, really. Unfortunately, it's down-to-earth vibe wasn't complimented either by the portions or pricing, which I found too small and too large, respectively. A bit expensive, but, it's near Union Square, so I shouldn't be suprised. I'm sure they make enough money there (it's very popular) so maybe they could give a little back by holding off raising prices for awhile, particularly considered the portions aren't huge. Thanks to the manager for hooking me up with a table, which I coerced because I used to be a concierge, and, to be fair, had sent many people here over the years.
author: Nate L.

description: 5A grade uni. Need I say more? Freshest fish I've had at any japanese restaurant. I love that it stay opens late! I love the nigiri and gyoza - I also love that it's not a crazy extensive menu - stick to the best, stick to the basics. My new late night spot, for sure. Especially after along day in the kitchen, tickle my senses, PLEASE.
author: Sharon L.

description:
My husband and I arrived around 7:30 pm on a Saturday night.  There were 2 groups ahead of us.  The place is very tiny and there is no "lobby" area.  Basically you wait on the stairs that lead down the restaurant.  The sushi bar wasn't full, but they didn' allow us to sit down.  A waitress finally told us to write our name down on the the clipboard the was attached to a podium. One of the groups waiting ahead of us was upset because they didn't know this either. We got seated before them, but it was because we were a party of 2 and they were a party of 4.  Most of their tables are suitable for 2.

We ordered the Agedashi (fried tofu) as an appetizer.  It was very good.  It wasn't greasy at all.   We were happy that they had the Moro available.  That was absolutely delicious!!  But is was $18.00 for 2 pcs!!  The hamachi and maguro were pretty tasty.  The miso soup with clam was also very good.  

Not so good: The sushi rolls were not that tasty.  We also ordered the teriyaki chicken, which was extremely disappointing. 

I may not go back simply because it's just so tiny and there are other places that sell more than just good nigiri.  And for a dinner bill for 2 people of $125.65 I expect everything I taste to be good.
author: Diana o.

description: Place is the bomb. Enough said. Compared to all other sushi joints in the city, Ryoko's is definitely in the top 5. Funny how most of the people writing bad reviews about this place come from destinations where their food selection is pretty much shit or they are used to not eating FRESH fish. Go back to your processed meats idiots or learn to appreciate good food.
author: Bustin J.

description: Don't let the dicey location, the fact it is in the basement of a building, located on the edge of the Tenderloin, cramped and the sometimes noisy atmosphere keep you away. The food is that good and the service is great! The sushi rolls are not too big, but not to small. The fried tempera is excellent and make sure to order a bottle of unfiltered sake when you stop by. I try to eat here everytime I visit San Fran. It is usually crowded, but the food seems to always come in the right amount of time. There is one drawback: when leaving, there always seems to be this musty, moldy smell at the top of the stairs just before exiting the building. I've learned to hold my breath and walk out with a :-) on my face and a full belly. It is worth the trip. Enjoy!
author: Bryan B.

description: By my snooty New York standards, this place falls a bit short. It's a divey sort of place, as others have mentioned. The ambience, however, I don't really care about. The fish is what matters most- and here it falls short. We ordered amaebi, oysters, hamachi, sardine, tuna, and the apparently popular checkerboard roll. I've missed my California amaebi (this is where I landed by FOBby ass after-all) and this seemed...not bad. Could have been a bit sweeter and fresher. Everything else was not memorable, somehow. Oysters fresh but had fresher. Tuna good but had better. Checkerboard...not worth it. Is this a problem...scratching my head. Trying to re-adjust expectations. Ok. So, this is probably a good place for weeknights, and I think the crowd there was doing just that, enjoying a normal night out. Not a destination by any means. It's A-ok. I think that's the definition of 3 stars?? I think definition of four is "would return". I don't think I will, but if this is your neighborhood joint, sorry for offending you!
author: Ken W.

description: Nothing I've had here was "amazing".. And for San Francisco that's a bit below par.  But in the neighborhood I'm sure it's one of the better choices and the service was great!
author: Nick M.

description: The people that work here are so friendly and attentive. Great impression right as you walk in since you feel so welcomed. They always play music here so it never gets dull and it opens til 2am! Only thing - the sushi rolls are pretty pricy since they only come with 5-6 pieces....I mean it's good, but your bill is gonna add up if you're planning on coming here with a huge appetite. I've only been here twice, but it's nice knowing the server remembers me....I think if I were to come here it'd be fun with a big group....There's a section where you can have your own room and close the door if you feel like.
author: Diane L.

description:
I started out with 5 stars...as I usually try to do with all places.

After the Estelle show at the Mezzanine, we needed something open late, and sushi...especially sushi.  So, we came to check out Ryoko!

Here's the progression of stars: [note, the time stamps aren't exact]

~11:20pm [5 Stars]
"Ohhh, here's a place open til 2:30am!!!"
"yes!! let's try it!!!"

~11:30pm [5 stars]
"whoa..there's a DJ...nice.."
"The place is nice, I like the arrangement and initimacy of the little nooks..."
"yay..no wait"

~11:50 [4-5 stars]
"hmmm...i don't know what I want to eat..."
"WHAT?? only 2 pieces of sashimi for about $5???"
"peanut butter?  in sushi?? what??"

~12:00 [4-5 stars]
"let's get the deep fried soft shell crab...volcano (because i really have to try the pb in sushi)...flying unagi...and hot sake!!"

~12:20[4 stars]
"Volcano.....flying unagi....hot sake...wait, where's our appetizer??"
"Damn, that sake is strong!!! NICE!!"

~12:25 [3 stars]
"ummm...hmm....not really feeling that peanut butter in this..."
"ummm....not really liking the soggy frying unagi...too much batter...not enough unagi..."
"yea..that peanut butter is not working...."
"I like the strong sake though!!"

12:45 [2 stars]
"WHERE is that appetizer????"
"Excuse me, we ordered the soft shell crab appetizer...."

12:50 [2 stars]
"soft shell crab isn't that great...tastes old....too greasy...."
"at least the sake was good...."

conclusion:

+'s
Sake was strong
place was intimate and lively
open late

-'s
-prices were too much for what we got
-sushi wasn't good (**biggie**)
-appetizer was late and tasted greasy
author: Jac T.

description: Great late night eatery. The food was very good, the staff were still friendly at 1 am on a Saturday night. The DJ kept the vibe going with great music all night. This is a cool and fun late night spot.
author: Andre O.

description: Went here last night and sat at sushi bar. A little crowded, but great food & service! Had fresh oysters, blue fin, white tuna toro, amaebi, hamachi Kama, and the "sexy roll"! All very fresh & delicious. Highly recommend.
author: Bob L.

description:
I came her last night with a group of friends for a going-away dinner.

So much fun! Ryoko was actually there (reminded me of Yoko Ono, haha) and one of our group made friends with her and she allowed him to bust out some songs on her piano and serenade us for a bit. 

The food? Awesome. Which I guess is the most important part. One of my friends described the uni as unicorns and rainbows in your mouth. 

All in all definitely a great night spent at a great place, we sent our Dasha off right :).
author: Melissa B.

description: Stumbled across this place by accident when my friend and I were looking to get a bite late night. Fresh fish and pretty cool decoration-definitely different. We sampled a bunch of different items on the menu but what stood out was the volcano roll. It's a shrimp roll with peanut butter. I was hesitant to try it because I felt like it was such an odd combo but I was such a fan! The crowd is pretty cool too...we went on a weekday night and the energy was good all the way up until close. Check it out for sure.
author: Angela C.

description: The food was really just okay, just sure why there was a very long line for the wait.  I have no plan to revisit this place again.
author: Tina C.

description:
We went to Ryoko after my event at Rug Jones last night, because Katana-Ya had a little bit of a wait for a table...

Two reasons I'll wait for the table next time:

1. Even though it seemed like there was at least one employee per customer, food (3 rolls, simple ones) took forever to get made.

2. I like Katana-Ya better.
author: Jason R.

description:
The freshest tasting sushi in all of california!

If you like REAL sushi, this is the place to go to! It looks kind of like a hole in the wall, but that's probably why this is one of the best sushi spots that I have ever eaten at. 

The sushi is fresh and its definitely good! If you are down with sea urchin, they have one of the best, if not THE best, tasting I have ever had. 

I usually judge a sushi restaurant by how they prepare their ami-ebi (sweet shrimp). This restaurant has probably the best ami-ebi rolls I have ever tasted since I have gone to Japan!
author: Langdon N.

description:
this has got to be one of the better places ive eaten sushi at in San Francisco. I've been to this joint quite a few times and heres a list of the reason why I find myself suggesting to come to this place every time someone asks me to eat sushi with them...

-EVERYONE is always friendly. never had I had a bad experience with any of their employees in the years ive been coming here. SERVICE is always great...
-GREAT sake...
-EXCELLENT sushi..
-ROCKIN music! literally...

=GREAT FOOD, FUN EXPERIENCE... =)
author: Sally d.

description: Went to Ryoko on Saturday night for the 2nd time. The food is always good and reasonably priced but the DJ spinning the 90s r&b music is what did it for me. Apparently he spins there on Fri & Sat nights from 9pm to close. I'm def coming back this Friday!
author: Vinny M.

description:
This place has some of the best sushi in town.

Yeah, so if you're looking for "ambience," this is probably not for you. It's boisterous, fun, cramped and LOUD. Also, the tables are kind of low. Not a date night spot or Marina joint.  

But the sushi is FRESH. Food is excellent. Price ranges from moderate to pricey, depending on how you order. I had an excellent meal there and will definitely be going back
author: Kay H.

description: I'm a huge sushi fan - but this is by far the best sushi I have ever had. The uni and ikura in particular were amazing.
author: Chris C.

description:
Ryoko's is the best sushi Union Square / Trendy Nob has to offer.  Nestled on the same block as Le Coloniale in a swank urban cellar, this sushi joint dances the fine line between classy and seedy.  Ryoko appears rough around the edges in comparison to the Sushi Grooves and Okozes of SF, but it has tons of character.  They are open late, they have a DJ spinning some loungey tunes, and their staff is all smiles.  

I would suggest Ryoko's as a launch pad for a crazy evening.  It's perfect for a cozy dinner date or for a crazy group of 8.  The atmosphere is versatile and most importantly, the sushi is fresh, delicious and affordable.  

I gained some street cred by name-dropping Ryoko's when I went sake tasting at Corkage.  I got a smile and wink and the following response:  "All my friends work there.  That place is F-U-N!"
author: Kerry D.

description: I came here on a Thursday night and was NOT a fan of the ambiance. I felt claustrophobic--like i was trapped in a hot, crowded basement--and I couldn't hear my self think! It was too loud to go for an intimate dinner and too crowded and small to go for a group dinner. It has more of a bar feeling than the restaurant/lounge that I sought. These shortcomings didn't even give me a chance to rate the place on the merits--its food, which wasn't bad, but definitely wasn't great enough to redeem my opinion of the place. Will not go back here.
author: Djamila D.

description: A restaurant with sucky service and uninspiring ambience can still win me over with their food alone. Ryoko's service and ambience were good, but their food portion to cost ratio is completely disappointing. I'm not entirely sure why this place has 4 stars, but my boyfriend and I walked away from this restaurant feeling scammed. We ordered 4 dishes (sashimi and a couple of sushi rolls) that were incredibly tiny and left my 4'11", 95lb-self still feeling starved--and this is coming from someone who can eat despite their size. There were about 5-6 pieces of sushi per roll that looked no larger than a quarter. The sashimi pieces were also equally meager in amount and size. Seriously? We paid about $45 for mediocre sushi at best and left still feeling hungry. Luckily we found a spot called Cocobang right across the street and filled ourselves up the right way with wings and soju for a decent price. Sorry, Ryoko, but I can't recommend this spot to fellow Yelp-ers.
author: M. M.

description: Super-Fantastic Sushi spot...They get busy pretty early....all the rolls are delicious and so fresh...great local spot!  I dream about it!
author: Kiki A.

description: Very cool ambiance set by modern Japanese interior design and a DJ to keep the flow of the restaurant. Very good sushi but if you're a fan of gyoza you should definitely order some. It's crisp and hot. Like any other good restaurant in the city it may take a while to get seated but the food more than makes up for any wait time.
author: Brandon C.

description: Wow...quite the selection on the menu.  Try the "Big Mama" and the "Jumping Unagi" .. it is off the hook!  Great ambiance with good music too bad you can't dance inside.  Definitely a hip and trendy place to go to.  The sushi is excellent!  Don't forget the sake!  The staff is great and tends to you quickly probably because the place isn't too big and they need to move people in and out quickly.  It is tucked in a small area and not easy to find however YELP navigated us easily through my mobile app...love it!
author: Ferdmeister V.

description:
Pros:  Cool spot to drink sake and beers.  Live DJ when I came on Saturday.  Rolls were tasty, nothing to brag about but it hit the spot.

Cons: cramped dining area but it won't bother you after a few drinks.
author: Jay V.

description: Eh! Not a bad place. There are better places for good quality, but the atmosphere is fun. It's located underground and they have music and a bar. I probably wouldn't go back again cause I think once is enough.
author: Godzilla C.

description:
We were shopping in Union Square looking for a place to eat before heading to the theater. Used Yelp to find a new place to eat and came across Ryoko's. It was a quick walk, about a couple blocks, from Union Square and really close to ACT and the Curran if you're going to see a show. We got there around 6 and there were already quite a few people there, but we didn't have to wait for a table (though thirty or so minutes later the sign-in sheet at the front was being used). The place looked a lot different than I expected; it used to be a bar and didn't have any of that tacky pseudo-Japanese decor. It had more of a lounge-y feel than a restaurant. There's a small sushi bar converted over from a regular bar and there's quite a bit of seating as well as a (baby?) grand piano. 

The food itself was priced fairly. We ordered an order of chicken teriyaki, two rolls, and the tofu salad. The chicken teriyaki was surprisingly good. The chicken wasn't dry and the portion size was substantial. The tofu salad was great too. Loved the dressing, though it could have used a bit more tofu (there was only two pieces). The rolls were great though! They were fresh, and the fish and eel in them were both great quality. I would say the rolls were a little on the small size, but they weren't awfully expensive either, so I guess they were fairly priced. Definitely should have ordered more food. We left a bit hungry, but didn't have time to order anything else as we had to head to the theater. The service here was great. The waitress was attentive and they have quite a few workers there to take away dishes and refill drinks. The beer was a steal too. Four bucks for a pretty large glass of tap beer. 

I'll definitely be back! Service was great. Food was delicious. And while I will say it's not the cheapest Japanese place I've been to, it's definitely worth the money (plus, there really aren't many cheap eats in Union Square...).
author: Jon S.

description:
Thank you Yoshi, Atsushi,Reiko, Bianca, and everyone else for being there for all these years.  I feel like I'm home when I eat at your place.  

For the uninitiated, order from the board.  A California roll is not a basis for judgment.
author: Stu M.

description:
This place is great for late-night sushi.  My boyfriend and I came in at 10 or 11pm one night, and we liked the ambiance.  The restaurant is actually below ground level and very dark.  It's a good place to go eat if you feel like having a more private dinner, without people staring at you.

I really liked the Jumping Tuna sushi, a deep-fried spicy tuna roll that comes with a spicy/sweet/sticky dipping sauce.   

I also liked the Albacore nigiri, which was garnished with a little bit of grated ginger, ponzu sauce and green onions.  The fish here is very fresh, and the owners are all Japanese!  

They tend to use Japanese mint a lot in their rolls so if you're not a fan, you might want to ask them to not include it.  I actually like the juxtaposition of cold sashimi and the subtle mint flavor.  The one thing I don't like about Japanese mint is that it has a rough texture, and this roughness is accentuated when paired with the buttery, smooth texture of raw fish.
author: Jen Y.

description:
This is definitely one cool Japanese restaurant!  Very hip and trendy... I love the atmosphere.  It feels like you're having dinner at a bar, but instead of eating greasy bar food, you're having great sushi!  The music was kind of loud in this place, but that's part of its charm.  It's also not so loud where you wouldn't be able to hold a conversation with someone.

I really liked the sashimi... the fish was fresh and delicious.  We also ordered a dragon roll, and it was really good, but I've had better dragon rolls elsewhere.  Did I mention, however, that the sashimi is really good??  

I also love how this place has a full bar, which most Japanese places don't.  I ordered a Shocu with peach tea (Japanese vodka, according to our waitress), and it was okay.  I think I was expecting something different, which is probably why I didn't enjoy it as much.  But it's nice to know that the next time I come here, I have a full bar of drinks to choose from.  :)  And I will definitely be back here again!
author: Claire H.

description:
OMG HORRIBLE SERVICE!!!!

Came here with a party of 12 with a two-week-advance reservation and still had to wait AN HOUR long for a table, and the service was horrible! We waited another 20 minute for someone to come around and take our orders and the food came out sporadically... by the time we all got our food, another hour had passed. Oy.

The sushi is good but not spectacular, and there are so many better sushi places in SF... but the green tea is good. That's pretty much it.

I'll be back if I'm ever shit-faced hungry at 1:30AM but otherwise, ta-ta, Ryoko!
author: Cheryl F.

description:
had a great time tonight dining here.

most of the nigiri we ordered were awesome. only a bit underwhelmed by the salmon (not wild). 

their checkerboard roll is awesome too, and dragon.

it is not cheap but worth a visit :)
author: Danielle A.

description: The food are great but very small portion and expensive. I am glad they open late and   the service is good.
author: Suabot J.

description: Mundane. Expensive. Rip off. This place has a different vibe than other Japanese restaurants, with the music and the energy and stuff, which is pretty cool. But the food was mediocre.  Not a go to place for sushi or Japanese food lover. Ok to come for the atmosphere and beer I guess. For two people, it cost us a hundred dollar for a sushi plate, a roll(Eli spicy tiger roll, charged almost twenty dollars with the same taste of a supermarket spicy tuna roll), a rare beef appetizers(a little bit overcooked), some out of the refrigerator tofu and ice cream.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Thursday night, out of town visitor, the third official date. Where to go, where to go...? Ryoko came to my mind. Low-key, check. Great food, check. The basement location that examplifies the essence of Lower Nob Hill, check. 

We went with the chef's choice, at a quote of $70/person, and my LA guest was thoroughly impressed with the price and the quality of food. We had just about everything on the special board: Uni, aji, kanpachi, toro, and blue shrimp (a sweeter version of regular amaebi), as nigiri and sashimi. The pony-tailed sushi chef was friendly and extremely skilled, as the waitress was warm and attentive. 

Finished up with tempera and mochi ice cream, it was one ghetto fabulous dinner in our own cheese-free romantic way.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
I just got back from a great meal here! When you walk in, you're greeted by a chorus of hellos in Japanese from everyone who works there...slightly cheesy, but it makes you feel welcome. 

Our meal for two included: edamame, two miso soups, two ice teas, the Pokemon, Dragon and Hot Tuna rolls, and finally green tea mochi ice cream. Everything was awesome. We payed $27 each, which was very reasonable. I'm definitely going back here again!
author: Emma C.

description: I love this place..one of my favorite sushi spots in the city. But I'm writing this review to warn everyone that the wait (almost always) is from about 1-2 hours! Which almost kills the dinner. To get to the sushi bar,  you have to walk down stairs, and there are only about 10-15 tables inside. There is usually loud music playing and the service is pretty good. Not to mention the amazing menu and food! But don't go hungry! Try to get there right when it opens, or maybe have a late lunch so while you're waiting, you're not starving.
author: Heather E.

description: Great, hip sushi restaurant down in a basement. DJ's, cool decor, and not too pricey! Delish food too. Great experience!
author: Rachel A.

description: Excellent sushi, in a basement, with blasting house music. The atmosphere is awesome, it's always crowded in a good way, and there are always unusual and excellent selections on the fresh sheet. I go here EVERY time I go to San Fran. My only, minor, complaint is that they don't pay too much attention to the sake list, but the approximately 5 house sushis they have are each quite different enough from one another. So, while brief, the choices are well-selected.
author: Celeste T.

description:
Wow! Ok, here is my completely unbiased review of this (fine)establishment. I'm from L.A., and to most don't know s**t about anything. Unless ur from here too and then u know some of us actually  have half a brain. 
The service is amazing! From the chorus of hello's u are welcomed by, to the unwavering  attention that is placed on ur quickley tilted beer or saki vehicle. Attractive faces present and always a plus. Very cute waitress/servers.
The sushi was, at least today GRADE A! I'm sorry I don't want to misspell any of the items I sampled so here they are in English:
-Soft Shell Crab deep fried, light crispy crust with nice dipping sauce.
-White tuna belly.....Holy s**t no doubt the single most ,melt in ur mouth delishousness I've had in my sushi mouth(at least for the next 20 min. or so)
-Gooey Duck clam, u know the "nasty" looking one. It was the texture that's unique here. Very firm, almost crunchy, like undercooked artichoke stem and mild and tasty.
-Sweet shrimp. I always get this because I LOVE the bonus tempura heads! The shrimp was super fresh,sweet, and melted on first chew! with the subtle pop of fresh rowe to follow....dang.The Heads: brainy, and meaty, and crunchy goodness!
-Sea Urchin....my first.....I had no idea! I am now baptised! If u like sushi and have yet to try this gem of the sea, u better get urself here when It's as fresh as my new sushi chef friends said this was. This is now the New! single most piece of creamy delishousness I've ever eaten! GET IT! AT ANY COST!
-Finally when I told the chef of my luv for taco(octopus), asked to make me something "taco special". Super super fresh octopus(sashimi), according to directions, first dipped in a green tangy, salty powder dip?, then in a lemon/saki bath. Aaahhhh I was DONE! That with several Sapporos and my night was perfect! Thank u Ryokos! I'll be back!
author: Asv S.

description: Ryokos is super cute inside and the staff were nice and friendly. But the fish was just sort of meh.  Not bad, but not super good either.
author: Miss Information X.

description: Love this place! One of my favorite sushi restaurants. The sushi is okay. What really makes this place is the ambiance. Love the DJ and the great music. Always a good vibe and eclectic group of people--hipsters, yuppies, tourists, etc.  $12 pitchers, great! And it's open until 3am. Definitely a late night must.  Taking off a star because the waits are ridiculously loooonng. I'm talking waits of 10 parties deep all sitting along the stairs waiting to be seated. Ergo don't arrive there super hungry or famished. And there are only 2 teeny tiny bathrooms (1 for the ladies and 1 for the gents). They could benefit from a larger space.
author: Ohns O.

description:
This is one of the best non-traditional sushi places I have been. Right away, they make you feel special by shouting hello when you arrive and goodbye when you leave. Their menu is full of unusual sushi rolls including one which marries shrimp and peanut butter. That may not be your thing but no matter what, you have order a roll from the "jumping" series. Apparently, fried sushi is the way forward. Wrapped in a crispy breading instead of seaweed, you will be pleased as punch with the experience. Especially after you douse your roll in sweet chili sauce. They also fry their green tea ice cream here. There are also loads of vegetarian options for those who don't dig on fish. 

In the evenings, they often bring in a D.J. to liven up the place. Best of all, they are open till 2am to help you soak up a hard night out.
author: Jessica B.

description:
5 stars for the sushi itself.
-1 for the wait and slow service.  I actually think that our server just forgot about us last time we were here because I've had decent service before.  

Just make sure you don't show up starving because by the time you get your food you'll be dying.  The food is well worth the wait!
author: Laura S.

description:
I recently celebrated my 21st birthday.

*stink eye*

That's right.  Twenty-one.
Speak. Not.

I had initially planned to celebrate myself at an upscale Mediterranean restaurant in San Francisco.  

But at the last minute, a little voice inside me said "I gotta have sushi!"  

When I gotta have sushi, I gotta have sushi.
Like serious gotta have it gotta have it.  
Like Nola Darling  gotta have it gotta have it.

My go-to sushi in the East Bay is Angelfish.  It's the best around here, in my opinion.  But for my special day I wanted something different.  And more importantly, I wanted a real cocktail.  Just sake was not going to fly.  This was my 21st birthday, after all.

*stink eye*

Speak.
Not.
(Bitch.)

And so I turned to my Yelp friends to lead me in the right direction.  In a matter of minutes the phenomenally fabulous Frisco J. and sexy cybergoddess Jessica V. turned me on to Ryoko's.  I didn't question the decision for a minute.  I knew these two would make sure this nubile nymphet was satisfied on her special day.

When I arrived at Ryoko's it was kind of early in the evening and I was a little surprised at how understated the place was.  We were seated at a little table near the bar and promptly ordered Grey Goose cocktails. 

It was so cool to finally be able to drink as a legal adult!

*stink eye*

(Bite. 
Me.)

When the sushi came it was really good.  Definitely as good as my beloved Angelfish.  Actually, it was probably even better.  Everything from the hamachi to the kampachi was on point.  I tend to think a sushi bar is only as good as its uni, and let me tell you, that sushi chef  at Ryoko's served up the coldest, sweetest, creamiest, most aphrodisiacal uni I have ever had in my life.  

Within about twenty minutes of our arrival the feel of the place began to change.  The tables filled quickly.  There was a line out the door.  The twinkle lights that lined the walls came on. Donna Summer began to play. "Bad Girls" piped through the speakers.  I started to feel as though I was in some hot little niche in the floating world of Tokyo.  

Hey Mister!  
Toot toot!
Beep beep!

I was having such a lovely time there at Ryoko's, drinking my legal Grey Goose cocktails, sipping my legal sake, savoring the firmness of the giant clam in my mouth,  when something happened.  

The "Bad Girls" track ended.  
And then...

Mac. Arthur. Park.  

Kill my buzz why don't you, Donna?
And before I even get to eat my muthafucking cake.

MacArthur's Park is melting in the dark
All the sweet, green icing flowing down...
Someone left the cake out in the rain
I don't think that I can take it
'cause it took so long to bake it
And I'll never have that recipe again
Oh, no!

That bitch. 
Talking 'bout I'll never have the motherfucking recipe again.  
Tears filled my eyes.  I felt old.  
Fuck you, Donna!  This is MY 21st birthday!!! 
(Eat.
Me.)
HOW DARE YOU?! 

But being twenty-one (bite *stink eye* me) and kinda drunk, it didn't get me down for too long. By the time "Last Dance" came on I was enjoying my night again, begging the Japanese girls with the permed mullets at the table next to me to hold me, to scold me.  Cuz when I'm bad I'm oh so bad.  

That night I acted pretty silly for an adult.  If it hadn't been my 21st birthday, it might have even been inappropriate.

But I got away with it, you know, because you only turn twenty-one once.
author: Tsada K.

description:
Thanks Ryoko's for being one block away from my work and being able to feed me even if it's midnight on a Tuesday night and I have been working since 9am and all I'm craving is a hot date and 4 orders of Agedashi Tofu. 

Thanks Ryoko for feeding me some FREE delicious edamame while my hot date and I are patiently waiting to get served our even more delightful food. (By the way sorry for starting an edamame food fight with my hot date every time I'm there.. Those things are just so much fun to squeeze..I'll try to only hit my hot date's face next time, and not our neighbord's forehead..)

Thanks Ryoko's for having a carpet floor and dark color walls and playing some non cheesy music from the 80s, making me feel like I'm in an underground joint in the middle of Ginza every time I walk in, making my date even hotter.

Thanks Ryoko for hiring awesome staffs that greet me and my hot date as soon as I step in, making me feel like I'm special or something, with or without my hot date.

Thanks Ryoko!  YOU are hot.
author: Margie B.

description:
this is not the best sushi in San Francisco but it is the best sushi place! 
the ambiance and the experience is always vibrant and cool. If you go there by yourself it's fun and you can even meet people, if you go there with a group, it's a very decent experience and the taste of the sushi is great. 

I have been there over 30 times and never have they disappointed me with the experience. 

The waiters are a bit rushy sometimes and may forgot some things but they are very good overall. I even got to meet the owner one time, she's a very cool Japanese lady that takes her business very seriously.
author: Honor G.

description:
This place is literally a hole in the ground. But it's got a great retro vibe. I met up with two girl friends who are regulars here for dinner. They were there just the night before - that's how much they love the place. 

The sushi is amazing, and though I normally stay away from raw fish because it makes me break out in hives, I couldn't refrain myself (plus I didn't break out in hives!). Between 3 girls, we were able to devour 7 rolls. The spicy jumping tuna rolls, which are quickly fried in tempura but still keep the tuna from being fully cooked, are a must order. The spicy scallop roll melts in your mouth. Be warned that their spicy rolls are SPICY! One friend's eyes were watering so badly and the other's nose was runny! But they still loved it. The Tiger roll, which is shrimp tempura with mayo, was so good that we ended up ordering another roll of it. The delicious California roll has fresh shredded crab in it. The rolls average about $10 each, so although this place is kind of divey, you really pay for the quality of food you're served.

Make sure you also get a few bottles of Nigori sake to go with your meal. We must have taken 10 shots each of that awesome sweet sake. With the techno beats they were playing, we were in a food coma and a trance at the end of the night!
author: Connie C.

description: A good find! I had never heard of this place but wanted sushi and was in the area and used my Yelp app to help me find a place. Walked in and was surprised to see a crowd waiting for a table at a restaurant I had never heard of. Interesting vibe: you head below street level and may order drinks from the waiter while you wait on the stairs. The walls are a deep, bright blue and there is techno music playing. Most importantly, the fish and sushi were good, as well as being reasonably priced. I think it's a fun place to go when you want something a little different from your sushi restaurant.
author: m t.

description:
Probably one of the best toro sashimi I have had for a while. They got the whole vibe going on tonight and all of the stars were aligned perfectly. They had the dj playing some house music, got a full bar, and the sushi was great. 

3 ketle 1 vodka and tonic 
2 orders of chicken kaarage ( it was good.  had to order another one because we tore the first one up pretty fast.  I think it might have been the alcohol wanting the fried food)
Toro Sashimi (excellent) Salmon Sashimi( sake) ( ok) 
spicy tuna roll (below average) 
spicy scallop roll (ok) 
california roll( I don't know why but I just always have to order this one. It was above average.) 
Some fried roll ( wasn't all that so I didn't even want to remember it's name.  Just don't get the fried rolls here.

115.00 

The only reason why they get an extra star is because they are one of few Japanese restaurants that opens til 2 am and our server was awesome. It was close to 1230 when we arrived and the place was still packed. I probably wouldn't come here for a regular dinner but it's great place for a late night snack when you are craving for Japanese food.
author: jason g.

description:
I live around the corner from this place, I love it and totally recommended. The fish is fresh, the sushi is good and its pretty creative, if you ask me.Today, I had a roller coaster ride-- a thrilling experience full of ups and downs. The peek of the ride was the volcano roll, which I thought It was gonna be gross. It had peanut butter and fried fish, I know it sounds really disgusting, but is not. The peanut butter coated my mouth  with a sweet and salty creaminess, which was contrasted by the crunchiness of the fish. The downer was the uni roll--the taste was briny, like getting splashed by a gallon of  seawater in your mouth; and refreshing, like a crisp morning onshore breeze, but the texture, uhhggggggg, its like eating a curd of green phlegm, from your grandma, barfing material. Seriously, its and acquired taste. Next time I try it, I'm to not going get it sashimi-style, maybe the cooking will solve the texture problem.
They also, have a full bar, which is always a big plus!
author: Angela R.

description:
Good sushi place in terms of location and atmosphere, but very basic and the sushi was okay. Maybe I was too excited about this place and expected too much based on other reviews. Service was good - our
waiter guy was very friendly and he was good at recommending today's special fish. So thank you for that!

The day's special - Wild Saba (mackerel) was very sweet and fresh. We liked it right away and so ordered more. But other items we usually order which are; scallops, hamachi, unagi, white tuna, ikura etc... they were okay but didn't "wow" me much. We waited for a while for our Kaku fry (deep fried oyster) appetizer, and it was warm (not really hot) and we got our sushi right after we got our appetizer....

Totally convenient location when you are near Union Square, and this place opens until 2am!? Grrrrrreat! No more pizza at midnight, McD's french fry, or 7-Eleven food. Now I can have some sushi after midnight! Yay!
author: Tomomi S.

description:
tucked away in a basement in the TL... you'd never expect to find more delicious food!! i try to come once a week with mr. L ~ and the staff is so awesome and helpful... they recognize us, seat us in the same seats, know what we like to eat and drink.... 

the fish is so fresh amazing. always go with what they recommend too! my faves are the shiro maguro and big eye red tuna. the hamachi kama is always yummy too when im craving something hot. 

ryokos.. cant wait to see you again this week! you complete me!
author: Bobbie L.

description: This is a great little sushi joint.  Every element is pretty great and makes for ultimately a good dinner.  The vibe is small, cozy, and fun.  They spin some great tunes which makes the atmosphere kinda buzzy and fun.  Even though there was a wait it went really quickly and the staff was really keeping close tabs to make sure people got seated as quickly as they could.  They made sure they knew our name and took our drink order (which never happens at places when you're waiting to be seated and there's no bar area to sit).  Once seated we had excellent service.  The service is 5 stars all the way.  The prices are really, really reasonable.  Infact it's really inexpensive all in all.  The sushi is good, fresh, and solid.  I wouldn't say everything melted in our mouths but it was good.  So if you're in the area and looking for an easy and fun night this is an awesome option!
author: Tracy R.

description:
Generic Japanese sushi joint. I appreciate that it's not trying to be americanized. But the food is just ok...I judge a japanese restaurant by the quality and variety of sashimi they offer. And...it's not really.

Solid place to go though if you want fresh sushi and good rolls.
author: Yuchi C.

description: I have went there today after 30 mins of waiting, service is friendly, price is normal range. over crowded place.
author: Nomin A.

description: Excellent service (a la Moe's Southwest Grill), they will greet you in Japanese as you walk in. Sushi was unique, fresh, and fantastically tasty. This place is very eclectic, almost like a dive bar. Downtown San Fran sushi-lover must.
author: Ross W.

description:
Friday night and the restaurant was packed. The DJ on top of the slick black piano was setting the mood for folks who were surely going out after dinner.

A friend's birthday celebration had about 15 of us in the back. There is a long big table with low bench seating and also an attached room for more people.  The servers were pretty attentive to us given that the restaurant was so busy; we were rather pleased.
The sushi was fresh and solid. The mackerel was some of the best Ive ever had. The yellow fin tuna belly was awesome as well. I had some of the rolls the table got which were also very tasty and fresh. 
I am excited to visit Ryoko on a late night craving for sushi as they are open late!!!
author: ella a.

description:
This is place is so cool and good sushi! Usually I come here after drinking and I get the munchies or just hungry. I belly up to the bar and always get a warm greeting. Their sushi is really good. They have a grand menu and the service is  friendly. 

They always play great music, like Techno and classic Rock and Roll its always different. When its down time for the servers they usually join you in a drink. 

This sushi dosen't BLOW!!!
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
The best thing about this joint is the atmosphere. As you come in you walk down into the basement of the building. There's a really long, dark bar. There's lots of dark wood. There's a grand piano. There's little tables, jammed close together. There's larger tables with cushiony seating along the walls. There's a waitress that acrobatically climbs the bar to reach the plates on the top shelf. There's a relaxed air to the joint that you only find in places that serve good food unpretentiously.

The staff is friendly, certainly. The fish is fresh, surely. The rolls are inventive, obviously. Solid sushi place all around. In a great atmosphere.
author: Cris L.

description: Food was good and well seasoned. Not a place to go if you're super hungry though. It's more of a light eat w/ drinks on the side. Nice cozy place. Oh, a plus is that they're open late. :)
author: Jazzlynn L.

description:
You walk into the easy to miss doors of this place, down the stairs and everyone greets you.  This was my first Japanese restaurant that had a live DJ playing house music.  It was a little dark in the back where the lower tables are so it was hard to see the texture and colors of the food we got.  But regardless of the flicker of the candlelight illuminating our food, everything tasted great.  

Very fresh, buttery and soft the sushi was perfect.  The o-toro was so good I wanted to swish it in my mouth for a bit longer.  The service was fast and the waitresses were nice to talk to.  Looking at the menu, this is would also be a great place for izakaya.
author: Raymond L.

description:
Drinking started and 1pm and ended at 9pm. 

I was happy and sloshed by the time the sun had gone down and we were aching for food.  

What is the food choice of inebriated hipster yuppies in SF?!?!?

SUSHI!!!

A group of 8 drunkies and we were sat in the back room.  We were served quickly and efficiently.  

Totally passable sushi.  There really isn't any authenticity factor to any of the rolls.  The wakame salad came with actual lettuce....so not cool. Either way...it works for food when you are trashed!
author: Jay H.

description:
I read a bunch of reviews and I agreed with most, but I feel compelled to write a short one of my experience.  

First, place is dark and hot!  I had to prop the door open with a board to keep the place somewhat cooler...it worked.
Second, food was good and about normal price for sushi in my experience.  It could have been a little bit bigger portions and I would have been super happy.
Third, Service was amazing!  Made quick friends with Waitress/Bartender, a real cutie who hooked me and my lovely lady up.  This was the selling point.  Beer (Sapporo), Saki, and even some delicous dessert...gratis.
Went during the week so crowds came and left...good music and overall great experience.  
My GF thought the bathroom situation was strange...she had to walk upstairs and Mens was about 15 feet away.

I will go back next time I'm in the City.  Oh yeah, and I love that they stay open til 3 a.m.!
author: Andy A.

description:
I've had two very different experiences here.  The first was at a table for two (a date! with a boy!), the second at the sushi bar.  I'll start with the negative and end on a positive.

The date: pretty shoddy.  Not only was our little table positioned awkwardly near the huge piano in this dungeon, but also the 6 inches of space between me and the piano seemed to be needed as a major thoroughfare for the waitrons.  But okay, it's Friday night and it's packed.  I'll accept that.

But i definitely won't accept ordering sashimi along with a number of other cooked items and rolls, and getting the sashimi item LAST, and only after repeated reminders to that effect.  no, just wrong.  The order of operations in a japanese dinner is always:  sashimi, then cooked fish, then whatever else.

I can't even remember if the food was any good that night, because I was so put off by the service.  But I must have given 4 stars for a reason...

...oh right.  I came back here a few nights ago by myself, in search of a few hits of uni and aji.  I tell you, sitting at the sushi bar interacting with the oft-mentioned "rock 'n' roll sushi chef" is the way to go.  Even better is when this guy's buddies show up and start heckling him in Japanese.  And if you happen to know Japanese yourself, well!

The food definitely did not disappoint.  I will spend the bucks for geoducks, so to speak; on this particular occasion I splurged on the sashimi and nigiri a la carte.  I was pleasantly surprised when the generously-heaped uni came wrapped in a strip of halbut. sugokuoishii!  amazingly great.  

I like how they usually have a few special fish that came from special places -- like this time I had blue fin tuna from Italy (!?).  Even the Salmon Skin roll, which I sort of offhandedly ordered just to fill me up, was something special.

Hip atmosphere?  Dunno about that.  I think fellow reviewer Shiho got it right when he called it "Japanese 80s vibe".  The neighborhood draws in a lot of suits as well as late-night revellers, so it feels to me like a high-roller hotspot straight out of an 80s action flick.  Slip on the loafers and throw out your socks, boys.
author: Naomi M.

description: Came here past midnight on a monday night and it was great! Jenny was super nice, helpful, and funny! The music us upbeat and catchy. The rolls are cut into 5-6 pieces and the prices are really reasonable for sushi.The pokemon roll which has mango in it was surprisingly good. I will definitely come back!
author: Diego M.

description: I am really happy my friend recommended this place to me.  Everything we ordered was simply amazing.  This is my favorite place stateside so far and I think it will be hard to beat stateside.   Can't wait to go back.  The amaebi and white toro were my favorites but everything else from the Uni to the hamachi was awesome.  My friends loved the sushi and sashimi there also... My friend said it was the best mackerel he ever had... He isn't as picky as me but he is still dayem picky!  The whole vibe there is great... I will be back there next time I go to the bay!
author: Joe W.

description:
Ryoko is delicious.  I didn't have a chance to try their monkfish liver, but I did get some killer unagi, great octopus, sea urchin, dragon roll, volcano roll, jumping tuna...


....So you're going to quickly understand why I will rave about this place.  Do NOT be afraid of the dodgy basement, it is actually a magical portal to a delicious world of fresh produce and sushi, served to you expertly with fantastic portions.  Do not be afraid of the small bathrooms, electric blue, or close proximity you will have with your neighbor.  

Embrace the sushi.  Fight your urge to run away to the nearest sushi place frequented by mostly white people (a sure sign you're onto great sushi...kidding), tourists, and people who think eel is icky and fake crab tastes real.  

"But Max!  You speak so highly and yet...only 4 stars!"

Yes.  Well, I understand a small establishment often has problems adequately staffing their space but I do not understand why everything else can be brought to a table EXCEPT a Coke.  We didn't want to badger but we did ask nicely 3 times over the course of our 75 minute meal for them to please bring the coke.  We got it with our bill.  Also - I don't mind waiting 15 minutes for a table, but do NOT tell me 5 minutes and then keep saying," 2 minutes only".  Just say 10 - 15.  I'd prefer that to regular (and incorrect) updates on my table situation.

That said - GO GO GO!
author: Max A.

description:
unpredictable dining experience here. always so busy, but def had better elsewhere.  first time, we had pretty good sushi rolls (sexy roll was nice) and fried chicken was money. 
second time, our food was not the best, but prob cuz we sat next to the men's room and someone deuced something ungodly.  had to leave.
author: Roy N.

description: Excellent experience with the sushi being fresh. service is great. place is over crowded. very little room.
author: ali a.

description:
Service was mediocre at best. Food was ok but pretty expensive for what it was.  Monk fish liver was microwave defrosted so came out warm.  Server also tried to get us to order toro sushi. Sashimi platter was ok at best, nothing to rave about.  Aji sushi was thinly sliced with lots of garnish.  Uni sushi was fresh and portion was good. All other starters were just ok but overpriced. 

Wouldn't repeat
author: Tim L.

description:
I am going to be very frank with you.  There are two Japanese restaurants I have eaten at that merit 5 stars: Sushi Ran and Akaoni.  There are 2 other restaurants which have the possibility of achieving the bvu coveted 5 star ranking: Zushi Puzzle and Tekka.  In getting this 5 star award and an e-pat on the back, every detail of the meal must be perfect, and by perfect, even the wood that rests my laurels.

A much anticipated winterbreak for the  toy puzzle giving, timidly salacious strumpet led her to take the bus to meet me and my office of employment where we'd trek down Union Square in search of the perfect interview/work shirt.  After going through many departments when we should have just gone to Style & Co., she remembered a sushi restaurant that her brother had been raving about.  Yelping it, we followed googlemaps to Ryoko.  It seemed like a hotspot as it was around 8 pm and there was a throng of people outside, waiting to be seated.  Walking into the dimly lit den, I was immediately pleased by the aesthetics.  It has a lounge like atmosphere with seductive lighting and plush seats.  It screams sake sake sake.  We were tenth on the list, however, the kind waitress who asked the person in front of us to pronounce names on the list seated us in about 10 minutes.  Showing us our table, we literally shared it with another couple.  We were separated by nothing; I could listen and chime in their convo and they could mine...we were so close I could have forcep'd a piece of their sushi with ease.   The waitress gave us edamame on the house and was very attentive with the surface.  We ordered:

1.  agedashi tofu: this tofu was not very good.  it came already drenched in the sauce and it was soggy and not crispy at all.  also, there were only 3 measly pieces.  i am a big tofu fan and this was sub-par.

2.  philly roll: this was very good.  it was unique in that they didn't wrap it with another layer of rice.  their scruples are up to par with mine in that they don't try to cheaply fill you up.  

3.  jumping tuna: this was my favorite roll.  it was a deep fried roll and came with a type of dipping sauce...a kind of sweet n sour sauce.  it was delicious.

4.  crunchy crab: i read on yelp that this was a fan favorite.  however, it was my least favorite.  it tasted rather ordinary and dry.

5.  orange delight: this roll was a little bit more expensive and i could see why.  you can tell a good sushi restaurant by the quality of the fish they put on top of their rolls and the sake tasted just like the sake sashimi i ordered.  it was buttery and most savory.  

We also ordered the sake and toro sashimi.  Both were buttery and the toro just melted in my mouth.  The serveurs were very prompt and came to our table in a timely fashion to check up on us.  Everything was nearly perfect except for the tofu, yet, those three pierces proved to be their downfall in achieving the coveted bmeister 5 star co-sign.

Upon leaving, there was still a line and even a couple sitting on the steps drinking asashis.   I should have stuck out my cup and asked for a pour. Ho ho ho and a bottle of rum, a pirate's life for me.  Everybody should frequent a joint where they allow hooligans to toss back a brewski and not even be seated.
author: Brian V.

description:
Great little sushi place in the nob. The prices are good, the waitstaff is friendly, and the food comes super-fast (like, unsettling fast). And of course, the DJ mixing beats in the middle of the joint is super fun.

BUT! The wasabi sucks. Really bad. I kept adding atrocious amounts of wasabi to my soy sauce and still couldn't get that wonderful kick-in-my-face that I love. Finally, I took a *huge* piece of it and popped it in my mouth...nothing. Not only was it not hot or flavorful, but it had a grainy dry-mix type flavor. Like it came from a box. Instant wasabi!?!
author: S F.

description:
This place is hip and great for late-night drinking and a little nibbling. Prices are expensive pretty pricey though, but I guess it depends on what you order. The raw beef (beef carpaccio) is so good! We also had the extremely overpriced chicken karaage, which was okay. It didn't have any sauce though :(

We had 4 rolls, 2 appetizers, 2 hot sakes and 2 glasses of kirin = $100

Everything was alright, I loved the beef. It was super packed so we sat at the bar. No biggie, they had hooks under the bar for your coats. Service was okay, our waiter was sweet and bubbly.

The patronage was mostly young hipsters, probably drinking before a night out on the town. A perfect plan!

Did I mention they have a roll on their menu that has peanut butter in it...?!?!?! PEANUT BUTTER!!!!
author: T L.

description:
Honestly. 

SUSHI AND HOT SAKE SERVED UNTIL 2AM. EVEN ON SUNDAYS.

Does anything more need to be said about this place?
author: SheRat R.

description: This place is amazing. Seriously some of if not the best sushi I've had. Checkerboard, Rainbow, Dragon and Flying Tuna are are all superb. 5 out of 5 without a doubt.
author: Andrew J.

description: Awesome atmosphere and very fairly priced. Can't think of any way to improve this place.
author: Matt M.

description: Love the idea of late- night sushi and these guys execute it really well. The place was packed but no waiting on a table, which was nice. Good bar and *bonus* they had fresh oysters on hand. The live DJ is a cool touch. Parking is a bitch, but that's true for all of the City. The place was pricey though -$120 for two people who went in for a late night snack - but I'll be back again. Hopefully someone else can pick up the tab.
author: prior O.

description:
The sushi was fine. Had I been more sober I would have been able to comment more on the quality of the fish.

It's a good atmosphere. I like the underground feel and I think the lighting is perfect (a little dark). 

They take their time in preparing the sushi, so it's not a good place to go eat when the place is busy or if you have a big group, unless you plan to wait dearly for your (good) food.

The tempura was pretty bad. I had a piece of sweet potato tempura and it wasn't cooked fully. I do appreciate semi-raw sweet potatoes but not in tempura! 

If the service were faster, the place less crowded, and the bill less heavy, i'd give it a better rating. I would come again after winning the lottery.
author: Jae K.

description: I loved this place. There was a great vibe. It's a little loud if you want to have a serious conversation, but for a fun night with a group, this is a great place. They have a live DJ on Friday nights. The music was upbeat and fun. The service was great and the food was perfection. Even their miso soup tastes different than other places - more subtle and less salty. The sushi was high quality and I enjoyed everything. Our group ordered a variety of rolls and none disappointed. If you're into sushi, definitely go here.
author: Jackie T.

description:
Very good sushi. we like to come over to Ryoko. the sushi is always fresh and tasty.
the vibe is great and there is a nice music. I like the ice cream at the end of every meal.
The only bad part in this place is the line. you have to wait t least 40 minutes at any time.
author: David S.

description:
I'm no sushi connoisseur by any means but I know what I like. And yes this place looks like an unassuming hole in the wall. But interestingly enough it was packed when we walked in. Apparently this little hole in the wall in not a well kept secret. 

We ordered two rolls one of course with Unagi pouring out on all sides. YUMMY! And the other had this soybean wrap with mango, lettuce and salmon. It was really fresh and different. Like I said I'm no connoisseur but I'm getting better! We got edamame on the house and the sake was oh so necessary so I had a good time. I would definitely go back if i was in a pinch and needed to eat late. Its always a good idea to find your late night sushi spots.
author: Brittany D.

description:
Best sushi outside of Japan. 
We were the only non-Japanese in there, you know its authentic cuisine when the atmosphere attracts the its own culture. 
Sushi hasn't tasted as good since.
author: Meggie M.

description: My husband and I ate here while on vacation from New Jersey.  We have had a lot of sushi from all over the tri-state area and this sushi rivals the best of them.  Get there early because even on a Monday night the wait had to be at least 1 hour and the only waiting area are the steps leading down into the restaurant.  However, once seated, they don't rush you out.  We had an assortment of rolls and some sushi - all excellent - and the pork pot stickers as a starter are definitely recommended (they make them homemade and cook to order!).     Service was friendly and attentive, although the number of seats is limited you won't feel crammed.  Highly suggest checking them out!
author: Elysa S.

description: Before our food came, a roach scurried across our table. I have never seen a roach on a table before, but now I have. Eww.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I went to Ryoko last night with a couple of friends. We were looking for a special place as we were sending someone off to the Southern Hemisphere. Super excited about eating sushi, I'm always a bit apprehensive but the service was spot on, very knowledgeable. I have a complete gluten intolerance and came with my own tamari sauce in tow.  I explained this and everything i ordered was perfectly acceptable to my finicky digestive system.  
I ordered the checkerboard and the hung fin (?) which were absolutely delicious. My friends had the volcano roll (who knew crunchy peanut butter with raw fish is the bizness?) and various pieces of nigiri. The albacore tuna nigiri was amazing. So amazing in fact that I decided to go ahead and eat that 3rd piece. I do suggest that you do not eat this unless your entire party is as its HEAVY on the garlic but oh my its tasty. 

Also the nigori is delicious, and at $10 a bottle (10-12 shots) its pocket-book friendly. 

Good times had by everyone and I'll definitely make it back.  Oh yea, its open late!
author: Samantha S.

description:
My roommates took me here for my bday dinner.  The wait was about 45 minutes and we got there at 8:30pm on a Wednesday night!  Good signs, good signs..

We were seated and greeted with a very small narrow place.  We sat in the way back..service was so-so.  We had to take the initiative to ask for menus and order.  They were obviously understaffed this night!

The sushi rolls and sashimi were all pretty good.  I'd say its slightly above average in SF, but not quite as good as some of the top places in SF.
author: Yup S.

description:
Went in on a week night and waited over an hour to get two orders of rolls. The place was half empty yet just as staffed as it is on weekends so I was kind of confused. We asked two different people  why it was taking so long and they tried to tell us that they were understaffed at the bar and it would be ready any moment. 

I've been there enough times to know that the sushi chefs are the same guys that are there on Friday nights during peak hours. They simply forgot about us and were trying to cover their a$$es. 

Finally we just decided to leave an hour and a half later, still no food, just pay for my friends beer, and she made us wait for the bill for another ten minutes. No offer to let it slide since we waited so long. 

I used to come here because it was open late and pretty good. But this is not in my area and not worth the bad service. 

I'll stick to Sushi Zone or Cha Ya.
author: Erin D.

description:
Very mediocre sushi... The main highpoint of my visit is that it wasn't too crowded, even on a Saturday night. However, that's not always a good sign! The service was relatively friendly but on the slower side, and it took us a while to get our food.

I tried the jumping tuna roll, as per other yelpers' suggestions, which was indeed very delicious. However, the nigiri (I had the hamachi as well as wild Spanish mackerel) were rather bland and boring. I also had a roll with avocado, unagi, and crab (I think...). The hamachi was average and the mackerel was severely lacking in flavor. For 3 of us, it came out to about $40 per person (including tip), which I found rather steep for average sushi. The jumping tuna roll really saved the review from being 2 stars.

If you're in the neighborhood and dying for sushi, go for it... Otherwise... go somewhere else.
author: Jill M.

description:
The best sushi that I've had - EVER. 

I had been here once before and I thought, "oh this is cool". Underground, low key, reasonably priced, fresh, yummy. 

Clearly I had come with the wrong peeps. 

I came here again last night with some co-workers that are in the know. My experience was completely different than the first and it was seriously insane. We started with the usual: Sapporo, Nigori and edamame. The second I tasted the Nigori, I knew this would be a brilliant evening! Best Nigori I've ever had. Small white bottle with Japanese characters and flowers on the front. I hope I can recognize it the next time I'm there. Once we got warmed up the festivities began!

Apparently Tuesday's are when Ryoko gets their deliveries and the fish is the freshest. The head of our table (although a NY native) was clearly recognized by the chef. He told the chef to bring us whatever he liked...A plate (practically the size of a boat) came to us covered in nigiri. I'm not sure of everything that was on there, but I can say that it was all unreal. Some of the most buttery, delicious sush that I have ever tasted. When the plate arrived, we didn't think we'd be able to finish it and it was gone in like 5 minutes. The next plate came out and it was covered in Toro and White (fin?) Tuna. OMG. OMG. OMG. If I could live off of one thing for the rest of my life, it would be the toro and tuna that I experienced last night. 

The service was excellent and it's official - I'm in love. Huge props to the sushi chef who treated us with his culinary delights!
author: Jenny S.

description:
How disappointing!!! Did I imagine that I would spend my dinner in the dark basement filled with paintings/photos of lesbians and a gigantic signed RENT poster? Well, I got that but not a lot more.

First sign that the place sucks...

1. Young American tourists that probably know nothing about sushi.

Second sign that the place sucks...

2. It's a dive bar...a dive SUSHI bar.

Food: -1 point. 
Service: 4 points.

The service was pretty decent. I got a free bowl of terrible tasting miso soup, but it doesn't make up for the fact that the food is utter crap. I didn't get food poisoning but I probably would have since my sushi seemed off. The tempura was disintegrating in a chalky mess that had fibers (wood, perhaps?) while I tried to dip it in the sauce.
