I'd rather go to Sushi Rika which is one block away.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Burp into a pink balloon and smear lipstick on it. I dated the human equivalent of that. Anyways, i got this place from my female confraternite like that scene in romancing the stone where Michael Douglas snatches a ruby from the belly of an alligator. 

subterranean by design (~pm dawn), you step past some hanging Noren curtains and down a long, narrow-boarded flight of stairs into an indigo whalebelly of a restaurant, greeted by a smiling staff, softly buzzing diners and... overbearing gym music? it feels hip and out of touch at the same time, just like the piano that sits inexplicably in the middle of the restaurant - it's presumably to class up the joint, but they top it with a bowl of dum-dum lollipops that wouldn't be out of place in a Supercuts. It all manages to be amusing more than detracting.

they're not traditionalist. one of my favorite rolls may have been designed by a 12 year old: peanut butter, jalepenos, GI Joe legs. otherwise, hot sake, edamame and "jumping tuna" should start you off well, and if the owner (the only older chef) is there, you should sit at the bar and ask him to invent something new while you oggle his daughter at the other end. she's the guy with the ponytail. give it a tug.

the only downer is that the crowd can be iffy, given that tendernob people seem to be broke & half-backwashed versions of marina crowds sometimes. but you'll probably be too engrossed in the food to notice.
author: C S.

description:
A few reasons why Ryoko's is my neighborhood favorite:

1) Really, really good rolls
2) Specials flown in from Japan
3) Nifty kitchen menu
4) The upbeat, laid-back vibe.

It costs as much as the next sushi joint, maybe slightly more, but I never feel like I'm stupid for not knowing completely and well the Japanese sushi-consumption etiquette, and I never feel like I'm eating alongside uptight sushi connoiseurs. The walls are blue, the lights are dim, and the staff shout (friendly) at each other, and the service is very friendly and energetic.
author: Y K.

description: Hands down my favorite all time Sushi restaurant!!! EVER!! The jumping california is my favorite. But then again, everything here is delicious! Noisy as hell sometimes, but great place for first dates.
author: Dee L.

description: Great sushi and fun atmosphere on the weekend.  Young hip crowd.
author: Lisa V.

description:
After a night of boozing it up at Bourbon and Branch and looking for a place for dinner and you already had Indian food for lunch this is a great place to go. I have actually been going here for many years especially when I lived 4 blocks up. 
It is large room. Great for groups. Fun and lively music. Friendly waitstaff. Best to sit at the bar and/ order the chef specials. I was impressed that they had Aji ( my fav spanish mackeral) However, they would not fry up the skeleton for me like Shin does at Sushi Bistro. 
Overall fantastic experience. Perfect place to dine after 1 st Thursdays.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Ryoko is easy to miss.  It's located at the corner before you enter Le Colonial...and you do have to descend down some stairs...but when you do..get ready to taste the freshest sashimi/sushi ever in the town of San Francisco.

Also, sit at the sushi bar, you'll get to see the chef in action.  (he's young, energetic and plays the guitar on his days off)  Weekends are busy as heck but if you go on a slow day (ie: Monday and Tuesday) you'll be able to taste some of his best work.  The daily specials are also a great start because most of the fish is imported from Japan.

This place is just plain amazing...you've got to try it.
author: Alice H.

description:
fish is fresh enough that you probably will not get sick, but...

they would not take my to-go order over the phone.  on a weekday.  annoying.
author: eshwar k.

description:
We came here for dinner on Monday night to fill our sushi craving.
The place was half full, dark with a very laid back scene.  The music was blaring but we were able to have a conversation. The service was good and the wait was not that long for our food.
We enjoyed two bottles of sake, two beers along with a spicy tuna roll-good, spicy scallop roll-good as well but neither was spicy at all.
Spider-very good and jumping tuna-very good.  Overall the fish was very fresh and we enjoyed our meal.  
We intend to return and try some other items on the menu.
author: Lizete S.

description:
My experience:

We get there at about 10 on a thursday night, it's pretty busy. We aren't greeted or acknowledged until about 15 minutes of standing there. We're told to put our name on a board, which we do. About 3 parties of 2 are seated before us (we have 4). Ok.. sure I understand this is a small place. So we wait for another half hour. While we wait my friend and I watch the owner at the sushi bar chatting up a girl. Well feeling her up also. She seems okay with it so whatever. Then the waitress comes up to serve them some rolls and he full on grabs her ass! She seems okay with that so whatever I guess. 

Finally after about an hour of waiting the server comes to seat us. As we're walking to the table the owner walks behind my friend and grabs her ass !!! My boyfriend grabs the owners arms and says HEY! And the owner tells him to hit him?! WHAT THE F. 

After all that waiting we just leave. Why would we want to give our money to this sleazy, dirty old man? I haven't had the sushi here but after this experience I would never want to. I have no respect for business owners like this one. Open a club if you want to do crap like that, not a restaurant, and have some respect for your patrons.

NO STARS.
author: Chelle T.

description:
Best sushi and sake bombs in town. The flying unagi roll is like an orgasm. Its better than an orgasm. I want to go there now. Their food is the best.

An additional bonus, they have a great atmosphere and don't mind very loud and drunk people. And they are open late! AND they are reasonably priced. 

I fucking love this place.
author: Slasha S.

description: The music is so loud here that it kind of ruins the food. Crazy techno music plays non stop. There were a lot of loud and rowdy young people here. Service was good.Sushi was good, but not amazing. Tried a lot of sashimi and specials, but nothing to write home about. will try another place next time.
author: Candice A.

description:
Disappointing. Dark. Read reviews and was really looking forward to the Volcano roll peanut butter-but it was gross. My bf took me here for a special occasion and we almost turned around after we saw the discusting red carpets. He said, "They serve raw fish here?" and I said, "Health hazard much?" It was filthy. But we were starving, and I insisted we stay. They sat us next to the door and an employee door which is not ideal, you are mostly ignored or getting walked around. We had to wait for soy sauce and water so long that we got up and got it ourselves. Lame. Suggestion: Go here drunk and have conversations you could care less about remembering.

update: drove by here tonight and couldn't stop laughing when I saw the ripped up rolls of red carpeting and carpeting pads outside of Ryoko Sushi sitting on the sidewalk! Couldn't help but wonder if the San Francisco Health Department paid a visit.
author: Jaynel G.

description:
Wander down the steps and it feels just like you're entering a little izakaya in Tokyo (except it's not drenched with smoke happily).  

Ryoko is charming, cozy, and quiet.  It's larger than it seems and we didn't have any trouble accommodating a spontaneous group of 7.  The food is respectable although be aware they favor fried rolls over more traditional sushi.

As a side note, I kept trying to practice Japanese and I got a lot of very strange looks.  The sushi masters definitely understood what I was saying but I'm either so out of practice as to be incomprehensible or I was just startling the wait staff and hostess... whatever the cause it shamed me back into English.
author: David K.

description: There are really not many places in San Francisco that are as authentically unique as Ryoko's. Sushi at 2am in the morning with music from a DJ? What's not to love about that. Prices are good, the food is good, the atmosphere is entirely different from the many fancy/straight/simple Japanese places in the city. This is vibrant, noisy, happy and fun.
author: Matt K.

description:
Ochasuke... so hard to find in San Francisco.  I can't even tell you if it's great, I was just so damn happy to have it at all.  I got them to put pickled plums and salmon in mine for an additional charge of $1.00.

How I have lived three years five blocks up the hill from this place and never have eaten here is beyond me.  I mean, I love Japanese food--sushi, ramen, izakaya --AND this place is open to 2 a.m.  

It's not the best sushi I've ever had, but it's pretty damn good, and very satisfying.  The quality of the fish is top-notch.  The subterranean feel transports me back to NYC with all those slightly below ground Japanese joints with their cotton candy machines.  The energy, the vibrancy, the feel of the place--everything about it made for an ecclectic experience.  

This place has all kinds of people: businesspeople still in suits, tourtists, even, possibly, a tattooed prostitute (she kept referring to Johns and naming prices after that--what am I to assume?), students, hipsters--really, all kinds.  That kind of diversity reminds me that I'm living in a city, and so often, I do forget San Francisco is a city because of its small town feel.  

While I liked, even maybe loved, everything I ordered, I did not care for the tempura ice cream.  Meh.
author: Tangerine L.

description:
Once again awesome food saves day for poor service. Non-ethnic waiters in SF, you fucking suck as always. After 3 years of dining in SF I'm always underwhelmed. If the food wasn't so damn good to back you up no one would eat out. BTW the Japanesse wait staff rocks. All the white guys/ girls that work there should go work at the Spagetti factory. Please stop working at ethnic restaurants. 

Great sushi, great ambience, great location, free lolli's after you finish yer meal.
author: Joe G.

description:
Nice ambiance, good tasting food, a little pricey for some rolls but worth it.

The place is totally not "authentic" if you're looking for a true Japanese restaurant but the sushi rolls are good. The decor and dimmed room is somewhat lounge-y with an Asian touch, and the music is chill -- good for a low key dinner. a favorite of mine was the jumping unagi, can't go wrong with deep fried rolls right?!?
author: Jennie L.

description: Excellent sushi and easy on the wallet.   Waited approximately 45 mins, but worth the wait.  Would highly recommend.
author: D M.

description:
5 star just for the white albacore toro. Oh AND the house music with a DJ is def a plus :)

We had:

White albacore toro
Hamachi sushi
Orange delight roll
Kurobuta pork katsu
Dragon roll
Ikura
Big eye tuna sushi

A bottle of Kikusui

The best one from the top. The toro... I am not a fan of toro normally but this one...it was not so fatty but just perfectly melts in your mouth like heaven! It is torched for a sec by the chef right before served so it is slightly warm.. mmmmm.  
I think hamachi was the second best, very fresh. 
Orange delight is a roll with fresh salmon in top. I think it needs sliced lemon for perfection but it was still very tasty. 
Pork katsu was actually a bigger portion than I expected, thick juicy cut of kurobuta. I've had better in Japan in my own hometown but probably one of the best in SF. :) Dragon roll had good eel, which is important part of this roll. Normally dragon comes with ebi tempura but this one comes with crab... oh well.  
Ikura was... just OK, actually not good for the price, and for the fact that they had it up on the board as special, it should be damn good, but it wasn't at all. It was too cold and the flavor was meeeeh...  
Big eye tuna was the most expensive sushi on the menu- $8.5 or something even above the toro, and it was just an average. They really shouldn't have that on the especial board as if it's the best stuff, when it's not!

Overall I think it is a 4 star restaurant, but like I said just for that toro it deserves 5 stars and I wanna come back there just for that ;)
author: Cartman P.

description:
Heard a bunch of raves about this place, so i decided to give them a try.  Overall their okay, We went here for my bday dinner which was a smash success.  There was about 10 of us and we had the low table near the back, not so comfy for some people, especially with long legs, but a great place to be a bit loud and obnoxious.  Service was friendly, great and attentive.  I liked the lay back decor, and i thought it was neat that it was underground and a bit dark, kinda romantic.  
Food on the other hand was not so memorable, i remember the hamachi not tasting so fresh which left me a bit bummed.  We ordered a bunch of apps and rolls , some which were good and others okay, but nothing that left me salivating for more.
author: Tara B.

description: Japanese casual bars with yummy foods. Their square pot stickers are their signature dish. Fresh sashimi and lots of traditional Japanese dish. Our recent great find.
author: Yoko S.

description:
This place is great. The only negative thing I can say about it is it's a bit small and the decor could be improved but it really does have a cool vibe inside. There is often a DJ and they are open late which makes it a good spot to stop by after a long night. In some of the reviews below people mentioned that this place is not very Japanese, however I would beg to differ. Based on my experiences in Tokyo, Ryokos feels like many of the tucked away sushi bars I went to that in Tokyo. I think its pretty authentic to the feel of some of the more hole in the wall places in Japan. 

Ambiance aside, the main reason this place rocks is the fish. I don't think I have found a sushi restaurant in the city with better nigiri. They have a great selection and man, you have got to try the Fatty Toro. If they have it on the menu, order it and don't think twice. Although it's expensive, I'll bet its some of the best raw fish you have ever experienced. I will keep coming back here for sure....
author: Nick J.

description:
Top Notch sushi place. Maybe it was because I hadn't had good sushi in awhile, or maybe I was just in a good mood, but this was one of hte best and fresh sushi places I have frequented in a long time. Coming from Chicago which is turning into a very popular sushi town, it can not be overstated enough: Living near an ocean really does make a difference.


In our group we tried a few rolls as wel as a chirashi and some other individual pieces of fish. I highly suggest ordering some of the specials, while they are very expensive, BUT they are also very fresh and tasty. 

Aside from the fresh fish one other point of note that I want to make with the bay area sushi: the FRESH avocado really makes a world of difference. I think people take it for granted here, but the avo in other places is much more hit and miss.

The service and decor/ambiance was spot on...great date place.

Overall: Great sushi place, highly reco both rolls and straight sashimi. Highly suggest ordering off the daily specials.

Value: It could have been a lot pricier...? It certainly was not too bad, around $30pp, which for sushi of this quality (and a sapporo) is pretty flippin good.
author: Andrew K.

description: In a word ..... Amazing sushi ? Great service ,.. Fish fresh and wow , can not wait to come back ...
author: peggy c.

description: Open late night. Food is good and decently priced. I really just love the ambiance of the venue. It has a basement lounge feel. The music is awesome -- lots of hip hop if your into that. Good food, good music, good company and you are set for a friday evening before heading out to bars. Or maybe you wanna take a break from bar hopping. There's alcohol here too which is awesome!
author: Nathalie N.

description:
mmm, mmm sushi...Ryoko is one of my favorite sushi joints in town. Once you get through/around/under the blue sushi awning and get into the dark basement of the building you are rewarded with fresh flavorful sushi. We ordered a variety plater and every piece was great ( I wasn't the one that ate the eel or squid though). Even the rolls, which can be bland and boring were very good.
While there are a lot of sushi places in the area, Ryoko is one of the best I've been to and worth going to - Just look for the giant blue sushi awning
author: Russ C.

description:
How is it that I *just* found about this gem?  I love my sushi, and I lived and schooled within blocks of this place for years, and only now have I finally discovered the joys of Ryoko.  I can't tell you how many times I saw their sign, but never bothered to check it out.  The location - meh...  The food - awesome.  

So, this place is a little off the beaten path, and even if it's on your path, you might have to look a little to find it.  Trust me, it's worth it.  That is, if you are into super-delicious sushi that is made to melt in your mouth.  

No, it is not traditional Japanese food.  It is a sushi joint with the techno, and the wacky, fun staff, and all of the bells and whistles.  Bring friends, and bring your smiling happy face.  In fact, even if you don't bring that smile, I'll bet you will leave with one!
author: J Liberty S.

description: Solid 3 stars. Fresh sushi, fun atmosphere. Service was good even though it was super busy. We got sashimi, 2 rolls, nigori sake, and one small Sapporo, which came out to around $100...a little pricey considering the rolls were a little smaller than other sushi places.  So far this is probably the best sushi place in the hood, but I'm still searching so we'll see how long Ryoko's holds that spot....
author: Mao K.

description:
The secret to great food at Ryoko's is to come early in the evening on a weekday, before the place turns into basement-sushi-rave-techno-dance-party. Sit at the sushi bar and have the chef (the tall skinny rocker guy) put together a plate for you. The quality of their fish as evidenced by their nigiri and sashimi is outstanding... as good or better than anything I've found in the Bay Area (and believe me, between my wife and I, we've eaten ALOT of raw fish at many, many places all over the Bay...).

If you're a person who prefers rolls and other sushi-for-beginners to sashimi or nigiri, there's nothing here to impress you, but if you like super high quality fish sliced and presented with art and skill, I have yet to find better in the Bay Area.
author: Russ T.

description:
+
Fresh fish

-
Super slow service. Took maybe 45 minutes to get four rolls of sushi
Really dim lighting--we had to use our cell phones to read the menu
Uncomfortable seating if you're at the low tables and stump seats in the back. My back was hunched over the table and it was awkward eating sushi in this position!

All in all, I wouldn't come back. Looks like this is a great place to eat but I couldn't stand the tables or the unreasonably long wait.
author: Stefi C.

description:
I found this place by accident but it has become a staple since. I had my 40th birthday party here and that seems to be a popular choice judging by the numbers of other people also having birthday parties there.

The sushi is excellent - so much so that when I took UK relatives there they declared that the place had ruined them forever because they couldn't face the processed crap they had to pay for back home.

It's a basement bar with a DJ playing light techno that doesn't drown out conversation. The miso is pretty good, but the sushi itself is a wonder. I ended up ordering three rounds of saba the last time I was there because it was so good my stomach just wanted to cuddle me all night for feeding it such a wonder. There's an excellent specials menu as well.

The restaurant also has excellent, and reasonable, beer - something SF restaurants usually screw you over. As for atmosphere a Japanese friend said this was the closest he'd come to an authentic Kyoto sushi joint.
author: Iain T.

description:
Meh.

Sushi was mediocre at best.  When I have to say the California roll was the best of the 5 that we all ordered - there is something wrong.  The people were lovely, and the place seemed like a chill spot to be on the weekends.  And, a bit overpriced, in my opinion......$20 for a Rainbow Roll?  Seriously?  with the smidge of fish included in  the other rolls we had, I highly doubt that it would be worth it.  

Eh, maybe it was just an off night - but I will tell you, for the money spent and the ambient dissatisfaction among all of us - it makes me regret not just going to Safeway......
author: Saraah M.

description:
I'm starting to get affiliated with the late night cuisine scene in SF, and what better way to start off than with sushi at 12am on a late Saturday night.

Not surprisingly, this place was still pretty packed around this time.  A couple of friends and I sat down and quickly ordered some sushi and sake.  Lo and behold, our offerings were not only delivered promptly, but it tasted pretty damn good too.

And even more surprising, the vegetarian rolls weren't too bad either.  I rarely order veggie rolls, but in this case, I had to order more along the way.

Oh, and my huge selling point?  The awesome trance music in the background while you eat.  And with a DJ too!

Truly, a great find if you love sushi on a late night, and with some techno/trance to go along with it.
author: Ren L.

description:
Another one of those Saturday night end of service experience's think we need to do this every week.  They are awesome!! So we were exhausted and hungry, imagine that, and one of the servers suggested Ryoko.  We walked in, and told them we might have up to ten people show up, but had no idea how many would show up.  They said no problem and they could accommodate us, which is definitely worth 1 star.  They led us back to this private, "VIP feeling" room, and we chilled out and waited for people to arrive.  I thought that was pretty damn cool.  The server came in and really tried to get one over on us.  I was like, what's your best roll.  She was like, Toro, I said, "Haha, I know what you are trying to do, and no."  Toro, by the way is tuna belly and always very expensive.  She also told my friend she was out of the sake she wanted, but the MOST EXPENSIVE one was just like it.  I thought it was funny, I thought it was service that I would expect from a dim sum server crossed with a used car lot attendant.  Whatever, she did let us order a little after their last call, which I can appreciate and was constantly checking on us.  I think she added a 1/2 star to the experience.  The sushi was meh, some were good, some were not.  Didn't help that one of my friends dropped Sapporo on one of the rolls...*EPIC FAIL + FACE PALM = beer dropping on sushi* Also the miso soup had a metallic flavor.  I would actually subtract a 1/2 star for the food.  Overall we had a great time, it's nice to get out of the restaurant and chill with your people, going over things that piss us off and how we can improve. 2 stars added for friends enhancing the experience. 

So if my math adds up, 1+1/2-1/2+2 = 3 stars for Ryoko...I am however starting to notice a trend for restaurants in the city, a proverbial shit ton of mediocrity..I expect to be surprised next time...
author: Shaun C.

description: The sushi was good but it was all just fish and rice with none of the unique favors I have become accustomed to. The fish was fresh and you get about 5-6 pieces of sushi per roll. I felt the seafood was a little lost in the roll as opposed to the seafood being the highlight of the roll. I've had better sushi in rural Michigan.
author: Brooke C.

description:
Hello, My name is Michelle B, and I'm a wussy sushi eater. I didn't want my life to consist of being the girl at the table who orders California rolls (but what's not to like about crab & avocado) I wanted to be the type that shovels down sashimi and moans over toro melting on your tongue, but that's just not the way my cards were dealt. 

So, going into Ryoko where everyone was raving about how authentic it was lead me to believe I would be eating edamame beans for dinner. Because generally when a place does traditional sushi really well they tend to snub the rolls (understandably so) and you end up with crap.

Not so at Ryoko! They had everyone in our party swooning - from the snobbiest of sushi snobs (you know who you are) to the least adventurous (Ms. I won't even eat a roll if it's fully cooked) and I landed somewhere in the middle fully enjoying the entire experience. 

Except the blue carpet, the odd music selection (ok I enjoyed it), and the odd placement of the Grand Piano in the middle of the cramped dining room. The basement location left something to be desired, but did lend a discovered feel to the place. 

Oh well, give me a good roll any day and I will shut my eyes and enjoy the way my spider roll melts on my tongue!
author: Michelle B.

description:
Honestly, I've had better sushi in other places, and for better prices. But the other night, I didn't mind... because I wasn't paying! Hehe. 

But I do adore the atmosphere. Dimly lit, cozy places to sit, and a great DJ. I must've recognized more than half the songs that were playing. It's like PopScene for dinner. The DJ makes this place a great pre-club place.
author: Aromy X.

description:
They are all so good.. Yoshi...Asushi.. interesting people
A good place to hide with no cell phone reception
author: Jonathan C.

description: I am not a big Japanese food fan - given that I am Indian, we like our food drenched in heavy spices - this place has changed my outlook of Japanese food. Its clean, fresh and very tasty. The atmosphere has a great pump to it and the service is good as well. Definitely one of the best places to eat and entertain in San Fran.
author: Sameer S.

description:
Horray, a late night restaurant.....................except this is the absolute worst sushi I've ever had in my life. I've never had more bland food at a sushi restaruant ever.

I don't even know how they made it so bland. I mean gees!, nigiri sushi is mostly just fish and rice and yet some how their hamachi and shiromaguro was seriously the blandest I've ever had. They even managed to make their unagi tasteless. Their nasu tempura had aboslutely no flavor. Even the tempura sauce was tasteless. How do you manage to make tasteless sauce?

I even tried one of their speciality "Jumping" rolls (deep fried sushi) thinking that would be interesting and yet they some how managed to suck all the flavor out.

And to top it off it's HUGELY expensive. I don't mind paying if it's good. I've been to $100 per person sushi places but gees, this place wasn't even as good as some cheap Chinese or Korean run sushi place in a strip mall in the south bay.

DON'T GO HERE!
author: Gregg T.

description:
My dinner companion puts one of two amaebi (prawn) sushi rolls in his mouth. Looks at me with a pained look, whispers "Don't eat the other one."

Umm, yep. Sums up the meal. Mediocre food (crappy roll creations, not fresh seafood, bland appetizers), divey & crowded environment (which would be cool but it belies the state of the food and slows service down to a crawl...), kinda pricey.

Maybe the money goes to the DJ that was there on Friday night (great music), cuz it ain't going into buying fresh fish.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
Let's just say...I got food poisoning on my first visit to Ryoko.  On the second visit, the hostess said I will be seated in 5 min; somehow the 5 min wait ended up being a 45min wait.

Despite getting food poisoning and waiting for 45min, I still think this place is a decent place in the city.  It is open late, the location is good, the portions are fairly large, and the vibe is cool.  

But 2 stars for the food poisoning and long wait.
author: Cam N.

description: Think I may have been at the previous joint for too long and had too much fire water... and then got hungry, really hungry, for sushi. Good, late night, GREAT late night sushi. It was, I remember.
author: Bill E.

description: I hate to let the cat out of the bag but I liked it so much and I would want them to do the same for Monarch! Amazing sushi until 2 am, it's a mile up from my favorite club Monarch..I will be a regular in no time. Great energy,  classic DJ, great service!!! THE PLACE WAS CRACKING!
author: Shawn A.

description: 2AM underground DJ sushi bar that is delicious (Golden Gate roll), and not over priced. Good for dates, bad for kids and elderly. This is a great and unique place to show out of town guests or convince friends that early AM sushi is a good idea. They don't take reservations, but that kinda helps keep the vibe less pretentious.
author: Alexander S.

description: This place is really popular.  The sushi was ok, but nothing fantastic.
author: Alf O.

description: Looks a bit of a "dive" from the outside (and it is - in a good way!) but the atmosphere is young and energetic - without being over the top. Great sushi artists really put on a show if you are lucky enough to get a spot at the bar. The sushi/sashimi is generously sliced - the Toro is simply amazing. Prices lean towards the higher-end but it is money well spent.
author: Cameron B.

description:
There is a reason why we don't put peanut butter in sushi rolls. Or American cheese that comes out of cellophane. I'm not even sure that if it was PB that was the problem. It was probably the combination of PB & HS (hot sauce). ...

If you're looking for sushi suggestions for your next visit to 'San Fran,' then there you go. There you go.
author: D'arcy N.

description: Me and my hubby love this place! The atmosphere is very nice, and the waiters are friendly. They are open late night. Try daily special sushi for sure, especially halibut. Jumping veggie is delicious as well, and don't forget to order tempura ice cream as soon as you reach there:)
author: Maitai N.

description: Awesome Sushi - great service. Oysters are HUGE
author: Stephan R.

description:
great for a date, if u dont wanna hear anything theyre saying! ;)

sushi is SO good, prices are pretty reasonable for the time that they're open. (id suggest finding a better deal elsewhere, if you're looking for sushi at a cheaper price)

they play HOUSE MUSIC. so, if youre into that kinda thing, go for it, i think its the most annoying thing ever so i eat fast and get outta there. or i order take out.

food is always good, anddd they have a full bar! ;)
author: Lisa N.

description:
Ryoko's is definitely a staple! I went to Ryoko's for the first time a few years back for a friend's birthday. It was a very large group, perhaps twenty of us. I went back with a slightly smaller group the next time, with twelve, maybe. 

There are two large areas/rooms towards the back that still allow you to see and hear music/DJ without ruining conversation. 

It's great for both large groups and intimate dates. 

The staff is nice, always greet you at the door upon arrival and departure.  The service is great. Their sushi is to die for! Moderate pricing.

Beware, though... can be a little hard to find!
Street Level door practically hidden leads downstairs to restaurant.
author: MJ T.

description:
If your friends jumped off a deep fried maki roll, would YOU? YEAH.

I remember when this place was sleepy and all they played was Coltraine.

Recently we went in and started eating, and they told us our next sushi order would take an hour. It's pretty packed now, but still worth a try.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: Tried jumping tuna, grilled mackerel, soft shell crab and a customized hamachi roll with avocado and jalapeno added. All of them were amazing! The seafood is very fresh, prepared elegantly and very delicious. Highly recommended. The only downsides are, it is small and cramped and usually there's a line to get in.
author: Mel T.

description:
Think dungeon sushi. My boyfriend says this place totally reminds him of the movie Blade Running. 

Went here last night and was surprised how crowded it was. Had to wait for a table for about 10 minutes.

The place is funky and hip, with pretty cool music to groove to.

Thought the food was great. I had the Kentucky Roll, very tasty! Also be sure to try the Fried Cheese as an appetizer.

The only gripe I have about this place is how long it took to get our meals served and our check. We were seriously there for 2  hours!

So don't go here if you're in a hurry.
*************************************************************************
This place went up a star my second time here. The sushi was totally fresh and super exxxcellent! We came here on a Saturday night around 7 and it wasn't packed at all. We ordered the fried cheese as an appetizer again because it's sooo damn delicious! Gyoza was also served even though that appetizer was meant for the table next us. This happen the last time we were here at Ryoko but it was a different appetizer. I would give it another star but the staff as nice as they are still can't seem to get orders right.
author: Ericka A.

description:
I just wrote the review for this place and accidently pressed the BACK button,so I lost it!
Now I feel like I was way too harsh the first time and something is giving me another chance!
So,okay!I'll do it!
Back to my point of view on Ryoko:Look I've been here a lot of times and I always left satisfied!It's just that tonight it was not the same!
Sashimi was not that good,Jumping Tuna roll was as good as always though!Service was good.
And you know I have always liked the electro-chill kinda vibe,but the dust on the railing to the ladies' was like a dry mackerel on your sashimi dinner.
I'll go back anyways,I am not that easy to give up on one of my most favourite places in the hood!
author: Sabina A.

description:
This place is THE scene for hipsters on a friday night. Very small, good DJ, a kooky old lady (Ryoko) who will kick people out if she doesn't like the look of 'em. But best of all is the rock 'n roll sushi chef, with like 1000 metal bracelets that make lot's of noise when he prepares food.   Ok, the sushi: good, but not great, you are going for the low prices and the cool atmosphere. Take a date (but only if she isn't a sushi virgin).

UPDATE!: If Atsushi (the skinny, rock and roll chef)  is working, have him make you this roll: Tempura asparagus, salmon, and lemon. It's the best EVAR!
author: Dan M.

description:
Ate here the other night with a large group of friends.  They have a couple of very large tables that are in semi-private rooms, so perfect for your special occasion.

We slammed a few bottles of sake to go with the meal, so were in pretty good spirits.  At $10, you can get a damn tasty bottle of large unfiltered sake.

There was a DJ spinning the entire time we were there and he played pretty good music.  Maybe this is a regular weekend thing?

As for the decor, the place seems a little dated and is carpeted, which always seems a little nasty in a restaurant.

Finally, as for the food, the sushi was nothing to write home about.  The one highlight was a first for me at a sushi restaurant.  While eating one of the rolls, I came upon a rather large (~1 inch) piece of bone/cartilage.  This was definitely disturbing and makes me question how good the guys behind the counter are...
author: Brian J.

description:
Sapporo on tap? SCORE! This has got to be one of the coolest sushi bars that I've been too. The atmosphere is part yummy sushi restaurant, part hip lounge. Only con is that it gets stuffy here if you don't manage to sit next to a fan.

The fish quality is really fresh here but it's still more of a sushi roll japanese place - favorite rolls were the jumping tuna, jumping unagi, spicy golden gate, spicy scallop, and the pokemon roll! Even though it has lots of crazy rolls, don't pass up on the sashimi and nigiri sushi. Last night there was yummy chu-toro and two types of uni - one local and one from Japan (note: the fiance and I both liked the local one better).

Appetizer wise, the steamed clams were so so good and the fried baby octopus was both cute looking and deeeelicious. 

Usually, I find that when a place that has a lot of specialty sushi rolls doesn't have the great fish quality that I really really want when I eat sushi. Luckily, Ryoko has both so I can still have cool creative rolls AND fancy uni from Japan! Now if they could only figure out what to do with the ventilation...
author: Karina G.

description:
Wowzers, I am giving Ryoko the highest rating based on the freshness, large portions, fast service, and not-overly-swanky atmosphere. 

Last week, a friend and I split one order of "the Checkerboard" and one order of some sort of tuna roll that was far above and beyond the regular, boring tuna roll I'd expected. It's twice as big as a typical tuna roll, which I'd normally never order in the first place, and it comes with spicy/sweet chile sauce. 

Highly recommended for a more intimate, affordable, pants-busting sushi experience.
author: Heidi G.

description: The people were extremely nice and attentive. The fish was fresh but the one thing I must complain that I didn't enjoy was the sushi rice. You HAVE to have sushi rice on sushi. Regular white rice doesn't do.
author: Kim B.

description: The sushi was outstanding and service was quick. Quite crowded at the bar, even arriving early. Nice they let us order drinks while waiting for seats though. I'd come back in a heartbeat but wait for a table if on a date. Highlights were the big eye tuna sashimi, some roll with tuna and asparagus, and the very surprising sour plum roll. Everything was very very tasty.
author: Aaron S.

description:
This place is simply good times. Yes, the food was good, but that one was only one of many factors in my experience last Friday night. Why was it great?

1. The raving kids. When I say kids, I mean kids -- little tikes. A family was dining at one of the back booths. It was late, and the music was bumping. The parents' two toddlers were strutting their stuff around my table. They were better than a lot of the caged dancers I've seen in clubs.

2. The waiter, who was obviously a homosexual, let me flirt with him. He let me hold his keepsake GI Joe action figure.

3. I had a lot of sake, and some beer. That shouldn't be a surprise, since the nature of this review would lead one to believe that I was completed sauced during my dining experience.

4. The food was really tasty!

5. It was on our way to Le Colonial.

Try this place. You won't be sorry.
author: Cleo B.

description: My friend and I came here for a late night dinner, and although it was on the pricier side, the ambiance was a nice change and the service was superb.  I've never had such a friendly and attentive waitress.  She always walked by about every 5-10 min so that we could easily ask for anything and she would ask us periodically how the dinner was going. Will be coming back here for those late eats.
author: Jayme N.

description: After asking several locals and perusing thru Yelp, we landed at Ryoko's for sushi. As predicted after reading several reviews, the line was insanely long and completely covered the stairs leading into the joint. However, a crowd this big is usually a good sign...so we penciled our name on the clipboard and waited...and waited...Skip this place if you are pressed for time. We arrived half an hour after they opened and still waited 1 -1 1/2 hours. The place is TINY! But, all that being said, the sushi is definitely worth the wait. The fish is very fresh and the rolls are very inexpensive considering the quality. Definitely worth checking out!
author: J C.

description: omg... they have great sashimi. Their rolls are pretty good too. I wish I can give them 4**** but my second visit here disappoint me greatly. Me and my 4 other friends had to wait forever for the food to come. We finished our food while half standing because we need to catch a performance at the Orpheum theater. It was such a bad dining experience and I felt bad because I was the one who recommend this place. I will think twice before I recommend Ryoko next time
author: Cliff T.

description: We were in town last weekend and was looking for a sushi spot open after 10, Yea I couldn't believe how dead this city is and everything closes so early but this place was open so we went. I really liked everything about the place and the food was amazing.
author: Jimmy S.

description: Jumping tuna - crispy deliciousness, fresh fish, with sweet/spicy dipping sauce. Yum :)
author: Andrew M.

description: Fun sushi place with fresh yummy food. Sometimes they have a DJ playing at the restaurant, which is fun.
author: Haleh H.

description:
excellent. Who doesn't like a cool underground tavern. Even better, a cool underground tavern that serves sushi after midnight.
really nice and attentive service. good sushi selection -- including incredibly tender toro. 
we went there at 11 or so on a friday evening. Good mix of people across a range of ages so didn't feel too trendy or hipstery, just relaxed.
author: Margie L.

description:
Not much else I can add. Important things to note: 

Watch your step when you enter, it's a basement.
It's open late, very late.
The food is ok. 
Great service.
The iidako is good.
The sushi is hit or miss. 
If you like shiso, this is a good place for it.
Did I mention it's open late? When you're sick of KoT and there's no hot dog cart in sight, try here.
author: The Sock S.

description:
Ugh.  Super crowded, lousy service.  We were seated and waited 15 minutes before our order was taken.  We then waited another 45 minutes - table next too us got their food and they were seated after us.  Ditto the table on the other side.  Got sick of it and asked for the bill for our beer.  The waitress was apologetic and assured us the chefs were "decorating" our food, we asked for the bill.  We paid the check and the waitress insisted on giving us our packages which were "on the house."  - Turns out the packages were a handful of edamame.  
Will NOT be going back.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
Found this place on Yelp. Have walked by it a million times and never noticed it. What a surprise to arrive at the address and see where/what it is. 

The place is hopping busy because it's so great. We sat at the bar and had a fabulous meal: Uni, Saba, Sake Toro, Tuna Yukke, Chawanmushi, tons of shiso leaves and all served on green tropical tea leaves lining the platters (nice touches, in other words), and much more! We lived it up! 

It is so wonderful to "discover" a new sushi place that has been there all along (25 years in this location) and have such a great meal.  The music was 80s dance, ballads, fun!

We will DEFINITELY become a regular and count this as one of the greats in town.
author: C. S.

description: One of my fav Sushi place in SF.  They fly fresh fish from Japan regularly so check out the daily special. This place is busy everyday so be prepared to wait before getting seated.
author: Diesel M.

description: Love this Place (Overall). I like the Dark, Hip, Underground-kinda Ambience. The House Music Beats make me Happy. The Food is Good too :)
author: Andrea Y.

description: This is a nice location in downtown SF with really fresh fish. The rolls were delicious and the selection was pretty good too. We had the Hamachi belly, hot tail roll, and golden gate roll. My favorite was the hamachi and hot tail. The fish was rich and tasty. On the plus side, it is in a good location so there is plenty to do after eating dinner. Seems like it's pretty busy all the time.
author: Heather D.

description: We made sure to get their early but really didn't need to on a Tuesday night. Love the feel of the whole place, despite the heat (but it was unseasonably warm that day so it was a bit stuffy at the start). Our rolls were quite good and we enjoyed the deep friend rolls the best. Their eel was delicious and beer was cold. I can see why it is ranked so highly. We were in and out fairly quickly as they move people in and out a good clip. Not sure what they all shout when someone walks in the door but it made for interesting conversation as we all debated what it was they were saying.
author: Steven G.

description:
Yummy! This place is absolutely delish! 
The wait staff is very nice and attentive. Sake bombs are definitely a must when you go here. I eat my weight in sushi everytime. They usually have a DJ, which makes the atmosphere that much better. 
From the outside it looks like a little hole in the wall, but when you enter it's like you have been transported into a different world...your own little Japanese nook..haa!
*Ladies be careful of the stairs, especially in four inch heels. I've almost eaten sh*t  everytime I've been there. I'm sooo classsy!
author: Anna S.

description:
After cramming into Le Colonial, a cramped sweaty club a block away, I decided to check out Ryoko's.  My decision was based on your yelp reviews, so thank you very much.  The service at Ryoko's was extremely accomodating to my group of friends which grew from a table of 5 to a table of 12.  The crew from the club slowly trickled in.  From the pitchers of beer, hot sake, and tasty uni we ordered, I can honestly say that none of us regret ditching the club.  

The back area of the restaurant was pretty cool and definitely nice for larger parties.  Since they open until 2am, I will be back!  Oh and don't forget their unlimited supply of dum dums! yes the tasty lollipops...though the only flavors they had left in the bowl was banana(blech) and mystery flavor.  Check it out, but don't come here expecting fancy japanese.  Come here to kick it.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
Favorite sushi bar in SF so far (given I've only been here for a year). But this was one of the first places I went to eat using Yelp and thoroughly agree with the reviews.

I would suggest though that if you would like to get the full experience, go with the mindset of spending a lot of money. Unknowingly we just went with the server's suggestions (friend of the owner who knew her stuff as well was very nice and personable) caused our bill for 2 to come out to $100. haha however we got two bottles of beer that was $10 each. Definitely need to go back soon.

And best part is that the vibe is that it's underground and very intimate setting. I noticed that there was a grand piano shoved in there in the middle, so my assumption is that they play it at times. Also, they are open until very late!
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description:
Low ceilings and hard to get around in this place is worth the visit! The service is friendly and accommodating. The Sushi is wonderful I had so many things here I thought I would explode! The deep fried sushi is just as good as the raw.
I really like the fact that you have to go down stairs to get in; it's totally romantic! You feel hidden away from the crowds and like it's just you and that special somebody. I can't wait to go back!
author: Kim S.

description: NYC feel, California grade sushi
author: Tony D.

description:
Pretty awesome downstairs sushi bar, very friendly staff.

Swung by here on a Monday night around 7pm, surprisingly there were a lot of other patrons, but we got a good seat.

Dinner for two was $72, a fair amount, but typical for sushi, sake and a few beers. We had 4 of the maki rolls, some sashimi and nigiri. The food was delicious, and the place stayed pretty full the whole time.
author: Joseph T.

description: I am definitely a fan.  Warning this place is small, so if you are at a conference and trying to eat with 6 other people there will be a wait on Saturday night.  There was an hour wait to be exact.  But we just gave our name and number and were called when our table was ready.  No call ahead seating, but we headed to a neighborhood bar to chill and wait.  It was worth the wait.  I have no idea how 4 people gorged on sushi and wine for only $80, including gratuity.  But we did.  Whoever invented fried cheese is a genius, not sure this is authentic, but it was amazing.  I also discovered inari (sp?), which is tofu skin wrapped around rice.  Went with a Japanese colleague and my go-to friend on all things Asian.. and we were never afraid of what to order.  Lots of vegetarian sushi options.  Unassuming entrance, be careful you might just walk by it and never know about the amazing sushi you are passing up.
author: Louise A.

description:
Went here last night with a buddy. tripped going down the stairs cause we were already wasted and then fell into exactly what we needed at midnight on a wednesday.


Fatty Tuna was good and the unfriendly servers allowed us to be as drunk and obnoxious as we wanted to without giving us any dirty looks. 
Just the sort of place that needs to be close to drinking establishments. 

Thanks Ryoko!
author: Tom V.

description:
This subterranean dive of a sushi bar is exactly the place you should go to if you are looking for a casual, fun, uptempo night. Sure, the service is occasionally spotty but their volcano roll (shrimp tempura, fried jalapenos, PEANUT BUTTER!) makes up for any shortcomings ten times over!

I am a huge fan of their spicy tuna and spicy yellowtail rolls. Oh and if they are doing Fried Oysters, you best order some of those, too! 

There is a baby grand piano in the middle of the restaurant. Rumor has it that Ryoko put it there because he has a good friend who likes to play the piano. I hope I am in the restaurant when Ryoko's buddy shows up to play a tune or two.

Oh and to the nice lady with the ginormous coco chanel sunglasses that works there: your energy is infectious!

I refuse to sake bomb anywhere else in this city!
author: Harrison M.

description:
It's funny how people wrinkle their nose when I bring them to this place. 
- Is it in a basement? Seriously? Let's keep looking.

But wait, after the smiling waiter puts Pokemon and Dragon rolls on the table, they all seem to shut up. 

This place often has DJ's entertaining the guests. Not to say I'm a huge DJ fan, but some of those jockeys actually made the meal even better. Spare me the hardest techno though. Please.

The food is always spot on. I've never experienced bad fish at this place.

Most people I brought here didn't even have the hots for sushi, 
so I guess that makes these guys pretty damn good. 

Don't forget the hot sake. This is a great and forgiving place to get juiced up and sloppy.
author: Aleksander S.

description: Great sushi. Great Miso soup. Great service and friendly employees. Glad I found this place. I was looking for a sushi bar that was open late and Ryoko's delivered all I could have expected.
author: Jared M.

description: Really friendly staff, awesome sushi!  Since I was from out of town, the waitress suggested the Sake Toro special which was absolutely delicious, so much so I ordered another one.  Other sushi I ordered was on par with some of my other favorite sushi places.  Definitely a good find.
author: Jessica L.

description: Amazing sushi!!! Highly recommend it!  excellent service and relaxing atmosphere. The oysters are excellent the monk fish is to die for and the octopus cocktail is amazing. Too much to mention everything here is exquisite and fresh
author: Kyrene G.

description:
This place is fantastic.  It's a great place for having a delicious dinner, listening to great music from mostly female DJs and friendly staff.  Every time I've eaten here it's always been fresh and tasty.  About two weeks ago I came  with friends who are self-proclaimed sushi snobs and they were satisfied.  It's close enough yet far away enough from downtown for me. It's also close to the Owl Tree for drinks after!  Yay!

Sometimes there's a line and you can't make same day reservations.  It can be hit or miss as far as the wait goes.  I'd recommend making a reservation if you know you'll be dining there more than 2 days in advance.
author: Carmen S.

description: Hi, full bar at a Japanese restaurant just a block away from my apartment?  Awesome.  Always have decent food there, great atmosphere, fun times.
author: Yingjue C.

description:
I went there tonight.  Its a very small restaurant with very weird seating.  There is one room that is in there and against a wall and one of the seat literally blocks the entrance.

The quality is food was decent, but not spectatular.  Price is slightly pricey, but its SF DT japanese food so its not out of the ordinary.  It has SUSHI, SASHIMI and Many appetizers.  The food is good with alcoholic drinks.

Couple of gripes I have:

I ordered a roll, I cant remember what is what b/c they combined all the sushi into one big plate.  But the sushi was poorly wrapped as it came apart afew times.  

The seating was weird, and the guy next to us was dead wasted and b/c it was so small they came over to harass us.  The dingy place had this weird smell, and i suspect, its either puke or vomit.

They were placing very hip hop music and club music, but I dont feel it fits cuz im eating... sushi?

Food portions was on the small side.

Service was decent.  

I would NOT recommend this place to others, but I wouldnt say its a terrible place to go.  If you are in the area and looking for JP food, I would go.
author: XiaoG 8.

description:
A great late night Japanese restaurant that has pretty good sushi.  Once you go in, you have to go down steps since it's a basement level restaurant.  I heard a bunch of great things about Ryoko's prior to going.  "The best sushi" etc... I think they over hyped it for me.  The sushi isn't bad but it isn't stellar either.  

All in all... a great late night sushi fix.  And since I'm a sushi fanatic... that's a big plus in my book.
author: Melissa M.

description:
My coworker and I had wandered away from work, admittedly tired but still anxious to find Something Fun to do, see, hear, or eat. We were having trouble finding that Something, as both of us were totally new to SF. As we walked, the neighborhood started to feel a little bit residential, and we were drifting toward the Tenderloin, so we turned and started bumbling down a steep hill toward Union Square instead. We were astonished to suddenly see a quaint doorway on our right. We both paused, looked at each other, and, nodding assent, pushed our way through the doors.

The narrow stairs led down into a dim, cavernous sushi restaurant, with patrons perched at a bar along the left. It was 9pm, maybe, so it wasn't jam-packed (yet). My coworker and I sat at the sushi bar, ordering rolls one-at-a-time over a single, cheapie bottle of Nigori sake. Each roll was delicious, and--somewhat to our surprise--the goofy music had seemed to attract a hipster clientele, although many of the folks there were just foodies. We remembered it as a pleasant evening, and raved about it the next day at work.

Now we always go back there together, and I've also taken coworkers there to celebrate. It's just pricey enough to be tasty, but cheap enough for this wage-earner to take her friends out. Everyone says the same thing: "That was pretty good!" When I'm with company, I've also come to rely a bit on the appetizer menu--it's easy to find something for everyone. There are a few "designer rolls," and while a couple are a little weird, they're basically delicious.

However, I've discovered that the seating away from the bar is sort of sucky (except for the time I actually made reservations; that time, the table was less wobbly and near a wall). The Philadelphia roll manages to disappoint, even though I always warn my dining guests against it. Thank goodness there are two or three rolls that kick my ass every time--spider roll's definitely one--and the straight-up nigiri is really great. There's also a roll or two that is made with just a wee dab of mayo. Don't be scared! Those rolls are the best! The Tiger roll might be my fave.

Edit, a year and a half later: Now that I am a dining expert, I am bumping up my Ryoko's review to a full five stars. I have since taken advantage of the 2am closing hour; I highly recommend sitting at the sushi bar; if you go with vegetarian and vegan friends, steer them toward the Jumping Veggie rolls, which are even better (!!) than the Jumping Tuna rolls; the cheap, cheap Nigori sake will delight both hardened sake aficionados and sake newbs alike; the atmosphere is at its best when the music is awful; the peanut-butter-and-jalapeno-and-tempura-shrimp rolls are nice to share but don't make a meal on them; the cute sushi chef with a ponytail is my favorite. The bad: when you're wrapping up your meal, Ryoko's will ignore you and never bring your check, unless it almost 2am. I am convinced that they are trying to get you hungry again, so that you order one last sushi roll (it works).
author: Jenn X.

description: EXCELLENT SUSHI!! My husband and I loved it!  We sat at the bar and let the sushi chefs give us what they love and we loved it all!  Very creative food and very fresh!  Would highly recommend.  We're just visiting San Francisco and wanted to come here because every time we passed by the location, it looked packed.  When we got there, we sat down right away.  Right after us, there was a line that traced out the door.  Would definitely come back!
author: Acsanna G.

description:
My sister was in town and i was stressing where to take her. She suggested we just ask the bartender at the bar we were at. What a novel idea!! I got the beauty she got the brains. Hopefully she never reads this review too. 
Anyway. We had a hard time finding the joint and when we finally stumbled upon it we were reluctant to go in. Looks like a sushi bat cave from the outside. We were immediately greeted by the staff and were lucky enough to get a seat right away. We got there early (around 7) and by the time we got our first drink there was a congregation waiting for the few tables that are here. The sushi is great. Fresh and inventive and the atmosphere is funky and fun. From the DJ pumping out techno to the owner buying everyone beer this place has it all. I would definitely suggest a reservation if you go on the weekend or later in the evening on a weeknight.
author: Stephen K.

description: Used to come here during my late college nights. Fantastic place for late night dinner. This was where I started my sushi adventures. All I ordered was chicken teriyaki rolls and cucumber rolls, but it was the best I ever had.
author: Vonn L.

description:
I found this place by chance (after clubbing at Le Colonial) and am now a huge fan of Ryoko! Not only does this place close late, it carries authentic small dishes/rolls and has fresh fish.  Just note that the later you go--the slower the service (only 2 servers were available for the entire restaurant at around 1:30am) so if you're the kind of person who gets grumpy when hungry--keep walking! 

Some may not like the decor (the inside looks like the place was a former cheesy karaoke bar) but you easily bypass this small factor when you realize there's probably no other sushi bar in SF that can carry it off with rave reviews.  I give this place 4 stars instead of 5 because of their prices: some rolls are worth the value, but others are surprisingly steep.  You can say you were cautioned now.  =)
author: Valerie F.

description:
Interesting decor.  Feels like it used to be a bar, got bought out, turned into a sushi restaurant and someone thought, "Maybe if we leave behind the pseudo-chic decor behind, it'll be artistic."  Who am I judge though?  

Gives the place a kinda interesting feel though.  Oh yeah.  When we went inside, they were also playing ABBA.

Swedish music, American decor, Japanese sushi.  Fusion is cool.

We had their hot sake (it's alcohol.  it got me drunk.  we have a winner).  This restaurant is all about the sushi rolls and they delivered.  Not great enough to warrant a five-star rating but thoroughly enjoyable.  Ended up costing $30 per person which is a little high but still at the high end of "Moderate."

So you can still technically call it "Good Eating at a Moderate Price."
author: Aron L.

description: Great late night spot.  Always my number 1 choice for late night sushi.  And Ryoko is a great host.  Bravo girl!!
author: Alex R.

description: Incredible place! Fresh, tasty, good portions, super friendly, lively, excellent customer service, and they even gave me some complimentary edamame to start!
author: S C.

description: To be honest, I thought it was over priced for the 'experience' and for quality.. Sushi was cut super thin, so not much fish there.. Ukane (Salmon Eggs) sushi came out round about he size of a quarter super small.. yet paid top $ for two pieces.. Anyway, just not the experience worth the $$..
author: Ma J.

description:
One of my favorite Japanese joints in the city. I like the subterranean location and divey feel inside. It looks more like a divey Jazz lounge/bar than an authentic Japanese restaurant.

The sushi is fresh, the rolls are in generous portions and they have grilled shisamo (grilled fish filled with roe). Yummmmm. 

Great place for late night eats too... like when you're shitfaced drunk after a night at [enter local bar name here] and want something better than fast food to satiate your alcohol-induced munchies....  Of course, I'm just speaking hypothetically....
author: lily l.

description:
My friend suggested this place so the four of us ventured over for some fishies. I was pleasantly surprised to see that there was a line 10 minutes before opening time: a good sign for a restaurant. 

The ambience in this subterranean dining establishment was very cool. A mix of Japanese art and whiskey ads gave off a unique vibe.. quite different from many sushi restaurant i've been to, where they tend to keep decor on the traditional side. The soft hallogen glow of the sushi bar lamps and the (Christmas lights?) that wrapped around its wooden beams were a nice decorative touch; in my opinion, it seems like a good place to take a date. The low ceiling and a bit cramped interior may be an inconvenience during busier times, but is cozy. Onto the food.

The four of us got the following. 

Sakepper roll: Capers, shiso leaf, and salmon. My friend said it was an interesting mix, and he liked that the capers added a unique saltiness to the roll.

Spicy scallop roll: scallops, shiso leaf, and cucumber. I thought it was quite good, and very fresh. The scallops were not too spicy which is great because the taste of it wasn't masked. The shiso leaf adds a great refreshing note to the roll. 

49er roll: The cuts of fish were very generous. If you want something simple, go for this since it's just salmon and tuna on top with a basic CA roll underneath. 

Uni (sea urchin) nigiri: This was awesome. I recently found out that there are 3 grades of Uni and this uni was excellent. Bright yellow and buttery with a slight taste of the ocean.. what a good uni should be. 

Salmon toro (Salmon belly) nigiri; This was the star of the night. My good friend got this, and his orgasmic reaction to taking a bite of it convinced the rest of us to order our own as well. He wasn't kidding. I wish i had a whole slab of salmon toro in front of me. They torched the skin slightly so you get just a hint of that richer salmon taste you get from cooked salmon. The rest of it melts in your mouth, but is substantial enough that you get to taste the salmon before it slides down to your already satisfied belly. 

hamachi nigiri: Nothing exceptional but very good since it was fresh.
ikura: My other two friends shared this and they both really like it. They mentioned a slight smoky flavor to it so maybe it's house smoked? Either way didn't know too much about this but if they say it was good, i trust them.

Service was friendly and fairly quick. I would say once the restaurant became packed it slowed down a bit, but it's understandable. In saying this however, they might do better with one more sushi chef. 


In an area full of Japanese restaurants, this is a great option. If you are out shopping along Powell or in Union Square, take the short walk over to Ryokos because it'll be worth it. In a city known for Japanese restaurants, this one stands out among the best I've tried.
author: Jim Y.

description:
The outside of Ryoko's does not immediately invite, but once you pass through the curious draperies and descend the stairs, you will  be greeted by an outburst of Japanese pleasantries from the waitstaff as well as corny 80's music, and you'll be glad you chose this hidden gem of a sushi spot.

I love the environment here, with its dim lighting, low seating, tiny nooks for larger parties, and as mentioned before, the fabulous 80s music. When I was here yesterday they played the widely known Rick Roll'd song from YouTube, followed by the song from the Venus razor commercials. I loved it.


As much as I love the environment, I love the food. Their deep-fried rolls are seriously amazing. The jumping tuna and jumping california are incredible, priced extremely reasonably at $7.50 per roll, and are served with a delectable sweet dipping sauce. I fell in love with them the first time I had them.

This is purely a personal preference, but I don't like the mint leaves they put into some of their rolls. I had the hot tuna roll last time, and I wasn't completely satisfied only because of the taste of the mint leaves. Everything else about them was very tasty.

Good sake. Good miso soup. Overall, Ryoko's is a great place.
Plus they always shout out what I assume is parting words when you leave. Of course I'm not sure what they are saying, but I appreciate the gesture.
author: Ashley B.

description: This place is awesome. We were directed to go there by a chef walking the streets to work after the SF Giants & Houston Astros game and what a find. The food is super fresh, the decor is awesome and the Sushi chefs are very personable. Say hello to Sushi Chef Wataru and tell him Robb says hello as he is awesome.
author: Robb C.

description: I ordered take out from them one night. Service was good but the rolls were just so so. There are much better options in the area.
author: Alfred L.

description: I felt like a Japanese hipster heathen in here.  I loved everything about it, save for the seaweed salad, which was combined with cukes and too doused in soy sauce. The quirky service, the hot clientele, the fried cheese, kentucky, pier 39, and tahoe (the tuna was notable) rolls were all stellar in an incredible dark, retro, trendy, funky, underground atmosphere. No wonder this was the sushi restaurant of choice for the cast of Rent. And, open til 2 am. The only thing that upset me was why I had never heard of it before, which made me feel out of the loop.
author: Andrew K.

description:
We went here based on Yelp reviews. Even though the sushi was great, the service left us with a bad taste in our mouth. 

When you enter, you have to put your name on the list and then stand awkwardly on the stairwell in front of the door, waiting for the hostess to call your name. We didn't have to wait that long, so that was good. 

We were both incredibly thirsty. My husband ordered a diet coke and I ordered the iced tea and a water. For dinner, we ordered two Miso soups, the tempura, Pokemon roll, and Golden Gate roll. She brought us our drinks right away, but I never got my water. The rolls came out before the Miso, which was odd. When she set down the rolls, she didn't notice my empty tea glass. I thought I'd ask her for a refill when she came to see how our dinner was, but she never did check in. Instead, I had to flag down the hostess and ask her for a refill. I saw her ask the bartender for the tea and then she walked away. For the next ten minutes, the tea sat on the bar, totally ignored. I finally walked up myself and said the tea was for me and could I just take it. I guess word got back to our server, b/c shortly afterwards, she came to our table and asked my husband if he wanted some more diet coke, which he did. 

The rolls were good. You can tell the sushi is a good grade. 

When we got the bill, we were surprised to see $8 worth of beverages. Apparently, they charged us for the two refills. I personally think that waitresses should tell you when there is a refill charge. 

To make matters worse, they took forever to bring our check to the table, even with my husband holding his credit card in his hand as a signal.

So, good food and a neat atmosphere, but the service just made it not a place I'd want to re-visit.
author: Ambs W.

description: My favorite sushi spot in San Francisco. Must go. Make a resv. if you can.
author: Holly H.

description:
I feel like maybe we missed something, or perhaps it was an off night, but the food here is just ok.  I've had amazing sushi in Chicago and LA, and this place just didn't have the mind-blowing melt-in-your-mouth quality that I've come to expect from a top rated sushi place.  

The fish was definitely fresh, it was just kinda bland.  The service was good, but not exceptional.  We started with the clam miso soup, which was ok, the clams were still in their shell and were kind of hard to get out.  The sashimi dinner came w/ 5 different kinds of fish--all were ok, just ok.  We ordered one of the specials, kinmedai, which was pretty good.  And we had 2 rolls, also just ok.

Sorry to the folks who rave about this place.  It just wasn't for me!
author: Jessica H.

description:
Do you enjoy dark lighting so you can eat by candle light?  Do you like enjoyable music while you eat slightly overpriced sushi?  Do you appreciate a very attentive and good spirited staff?  Want somewhere to take a date?  Looking forward to putting lots of exclamation points and question marks in your future Yelp review of this place?  Go to Ryoko's!!!

I had both the 49ers Roll and the Alaskan A's roll, both of which were delicious.  Oh ya, they're open until 3am!

-1 Star for the sushi prices being higher than other places.

I'll definitely be back though!
author: Patrick T.

description: the jumping california roll was delicious.  The place is small so expect s wait.  Overall, completely satisfied.
author: Dan L.

description: This place is unexpected and awesome.  A little hole in the wall (or basement).  If it has "Jumping" before it on the menu, GET IT!  We made two separate orders it was so good.
author: Daniel W.

description:
I heard great reviews of this place from friends, and I was finally convinced to check it out a couple nights ago.  We ordered several rolls, including the special (volcano?) roll with peanut butter and jalapenos.  Everything was much too expensive for the quality.  The nigiri was chewy and definitely not fresh, and we were told to come on wednesday specifically because that is the day they get their shipment.  And if that was their fresh shipment?  Erhhgh..

I also really didn't like the decor - just trying too hard to be hip.  There were some drunk and obnoxious 30 year olds at the bar giving the sushi chef a hard time (not the restaurant's fault, but maybe added to my disliking the experience and imagining the kind of people this place attracts..)  The music wasn't great either.

My friends were really surprised my boyfriend and i didn't like it, and I would have considered giving it a second shot - if only the cheaper and more satisfying susi rika wasn't one block up...
author: Rei E.

description:
I came here with twenty people for a birthday.  The atmosphere is perfect for big groups because 1) they are sake-bomb friendly, and 2) you can have your own private party in the back room, which seats 5-7 ppl (should call to reserve for private parties).  The service is a little on the slow side if you come on a semi-busy night.  Nonetheless, very fun!

The rolls are mediocre, but sashima and nigiri are what you come here for!
author: Lily T.

description:
Cockroaches .... 
We went there a month ago with a group, and enjoyed the food and ambience.  Went there yesterday, and neither of those were the same.  On top of that, there were cockroaches walking on the walls.  After seeing the first one, we asked to be moved.  We saw another one at our second table.  We should have just left then.... The food came, it was ok, but not what it was the first time.  On top of that, we were all bracing ourselves for another cockroach.  The owner came by and apologized for the cockroaches, which were due to construction in the upper floors.  She was nice, but I think the second you are aware of such a problem, shut down for the night or let people know.  She promised a "huge discount" and  just shaved off $20 of a $100 bill.  Should have just walked out after the first cockroach.
author: Abraham Y.

description:
I've been here twice now and I've come to appreciate this hole-in-the-wall sushi-ya.  Last night I met a friend at Union Square and we made the short walk to Ryoko (always a plus considering the difficulty of getting to good food from Union Square).  The place is down in a basement of what looks like an old blues club, and there's a piano sitting ominously in the middle.  I resisted the urge to bring out the 1337 skillz0r.

The sushi is pretty reliable and fresh, and there are some imaginative rolls on the menu.  I had a Volcano roll, which is tempura shrimp, tobiko, tempura jalapeno (?), and peanut butter (?!?!11).  Even given the unorthodox ingredients, it was actually pretty darned good.  And my shiso-loving companion was in hogs' green heaven.  Best of all, we ended up getting full for under $40.

Not the best sushi in the city, to be sure, but it's imaginative and priced to my liking, and the place allegedly stays open pretty late.  I think I've found my Union Square sushi place.
author: Mike O.

description: 5 star non-traditional ambience (tucked underground, slightly grungy bar-like setting with tables and booths, Ella Fitzgerald posters and jazz everywhere), 5 star cooked and raw menu, and 5 star prices. The service is friendly and we didn't have to wait in a long line (before 7 pm). Can't wait to go back.
author: Sumi Y.

description: awesome!!   came here after midnight.  service was friendly, food was delicious... especially the tuna tataki salad and rainbow roll.
author: Maria S.

description:
Check in before going in! The restaurant is downstairs so AT&T and T-Mobile have no service. This may be an issue to some people or if I was eating here with family but it was perfect for date night.

Boyfriend and I were shopping at Westfield for work uniform for me on our 5th month and the day before his birthday. We agreed to eat sushi for our celebratory dinner so we yelped up this place and started walking there. This could be a walk for some people and it's uphill for some part so keep that in mind if you're planning to take Bart to Powell and walk up. It's fine if you've had to go around on public trans and on footmobiles for the majority of your life.

Inside, the place is very dim with a full bar and TV's going. SFG game was on so score! We were seated right away (Friday night btw) near to a staircase so I'm guessing there's an upstairs part of the restaurant? Someone correct me if I'm wrong. We ordered a bowl of miso soup, chicken teriyaki, a bowl of rice, shrimp and veg tempura, a dragon roll, and a 49ers roll. Sucks that the chicken teriyaki didn't already come with rice and there was no offer for it to come together  "/ which is a sore spot for us; $1.50 extra for the bowl of rice. The chicken teriyaki and the shrimp tempura were good but the rolls easily were the highlight of the meal. Waitress was nice and didn't bother us that much which I liked. I don't like stressing out while I'm trying to eat and a waitress is trying to push us out. Took a while for us to get our bill but that wasn't too bad of an issue since we weren't trying to go anywhere soon. Total was around $52 for the two of us before tip.

Overall, before going inside be prepared to be cut off from the rest of the world. Not a good place if you don't want a sit down meal with your friends/others. Be ready to walk uphill for some blocks (2-3 SF type blocks). Have fun, chill out, and relax while eating. :)
author: Danielle Cheri R.

description:
(Warning, reminiscing follows...)
I heart Ryoko! This isn't your cute little zen sushi shop. I lived in Japan for a year and this place is like a direct transplant from the best sushi dives in Osaka and Matsuyama. Smaller and div-er the better! The sushi is exactly at the level you pay for and this place always fulfills my hankering for good SakeNigiri. The have a fantastic menu (OMG ONIGIRI) great staff and even the Jazz-twist of so many of those restaurants of my time overseas. (yet another annoying cultural note: Jazz is pretty big in Japan with the older crowds).
author: Leslie C.

description:
I used to live in a studio above Ryokos and it's the first sushi place I literally craved in the city. The atmosphere is dark and eclectic -- there's a piano by the front door with turn tables on top. I feel like house and/or electronic music is normally playing but never too loud to have a conversation. There's a back room that looks pretty cozy and the staff is super friendly. 

The food? Awesome. While not the cheapest in town, the fish is fresh and the Jumping California roll is so good! Overall it's a great place to get comfy, have some good sushi, and the people watching is not bad either. Afterward, hit up the Owl Tree across the street for a drink T-Loin style. RIP C Bobby.
author: Jen W.

description:
Of all the sushi places around this place has character. Pass it all the time as i walk through the neighborhood.. never really think of going in as its shady looking entrance, is not all that welcoming, and that it is the basement. Got a nice young staff that is totally on the ball.. was refreshing and enjoyed the friendliness and intimate environment . Music was fun and different, totally not one of those places. Went for Dinner on a Sunday, not to crowded but seemed like their were a bunch of locals, which is plus in my book, as it is downtown hate getting generic flavors.  

We had a variety of fish from rolls, Nigiri, to  sashimi all was tasty. Left stuffed and totally satisfied, really enjoyed the creative approach as well as the traditional menu options. 

Saw they had a back room, could be fun place for little party, or just large group!! Only down thing was they were not out of scallops, and something we thought of ordering.. understand not the best day for sushi (sunday) as it is the end of the weekend and prob not the caught of the day but still a big of a downer that they did not have a full menu...Hoping they will next time I go there..
author: Danny B.

description:
Yum!  Need I say more?  

This place grew on me.  It wasn't love at first.   During my first visit, the setting struck me as very Blue, Weird, Tokyo, and Hip.  The place is still all that, but I Love It and have been back many more times.  For a fun start to the evening in the area, head to the Hidden Vine for a beverage (or two) and then head on over to Ryoko.  If you're at Ryoko late enough on a Friday night, a DJ will be spinning in the house.  A must try is the PB and chili roll, can't quite reminder the name, but it's addictive and you will be thinking about it for awhile.  A GF and I were talking about food orgasms recently.
