As I'm writing about the roll.... ooh, here it is....just close your eyes and imagine the sticky PB in your mouth with a twang of spiciness..... Yum!  Now, don't let you head go into the gutter!
author: Uimuim B.

description:
Location: Super divey, underground dungeon-like setting.  Don't go if your claustrophobic.  I took my mom and there was drama.  Someone was smoking in the kitchen - the whole dining room smelt it.  More drama from mom

Food: Ok - price point was a little high for the portion and ambiance 

Service: Friendly but SUPER slow.  The waitress was smiling and apologizing all the time, but she continued to forget our orders. 

Will I come back?  Maybe...but only when its late and sushi options are few.
author: Clarice V.

description:
Ryoko's is less than two blocks from my place and it has a unique (for a sushi place) underground ambiance going. I so desperately wanted it to be good, but alas -- you can't always get what you want.

Seriously, they're serving up some stinky fish here. Yeah, you probably won't notice if you're drunk and stuffing your face at 1am, but Ryoko's won't be getting rave reviews from anyone with a working palette.

oh well... it's not like there's a shortage of sushi places around this area.
author: Chris M.

description:
Love this place. Full bar and good sushi, open late, and DJ playing music , too. Sushi is great with high quality (very fresh) fish. 
I like how the place isn't traditional and that it has an edge to it. Cool place to hang out with friends.
It can be pretty crowded, should call b4 you come.
author: christy l.

description:
Best sushi restaurant/bar I have been to in my whole life!  I am their #1 fan.  Ryokos is seriously the reason that I got Yelp!  I want to share with others the joy I get from this gem of a restaurant.  I recommend people to go to Ryokos nonstop because it is fantastic. 
I'm lucky enough I live up the street and go all the time.  Sometimes multiple nights in a row! 
Here are some reasons why:
1.  The sushi itself is exceptional.  Always so fresh & perfectly prepared. Big, diverse menu & daily specials.  The fish is delicious, the marinades and sauces are always spot on. The sushi ranges from simple classics to more complex/ interesting & all are very flavorful. So satisfying!  Quality ingredients and you can taste the difference.  The Tahoe roll is my absolute favorite (tuna, avocado, rice, seaweed, fish roe). In my opinion, the perfect roll.  The chefs know my order by now :)
2.  Always provide edamame on the house! How nice is that?  It's yummy too. Perfectly salted. And they also provide hand wipes- if they aren't in front of you when you sit just ask for some. 
3.  The presentation of the food is lovely. The chefs take real pride in their art & it shows. Wood blocks for the sushi, nice china soy sauce dispensers & saucers, etc. 
4.  The staff and customer service. Excellent excellent excellent.  I love sitting at the bar so I can watch the chefs work their magic. They are friendly & will answer any questions you have.  They are seriously very cool guys.  The waitstaff is incredibly accommodating, quick to serve, & also extremely friendly.  Chefs, waiters, runners, bussers-- always smiling.  I have gotten to know the owners daughter, who is an absolute sweetheart.  She is often working there, ensuring everyone is totally cared for.  She does an excellent job!  Ryokos is a family owned and operated business and the warmth and genuine care for customers reflects this. 
5.  Every single patron is cheerily, verbally welcomed (in Japanese) upon entering the restaurant  and thanked when they leave!  Makes you feel good about giving them your business. 
6. They have a full bar.  Awesome.  
7. The environment!  The outside is rather simple, yet you walk downstairs and you just feel relaxed & like you've entered a fun, happy world of sushi!  Its cozy and cool at the same time.  There is nice low lighting, great array of multiple sized tables, bar seating, back room area. A DJ even plays on Fridays and Saturday's!  Upbeat/ chill music always throughout the week.  An absolute perfect date spot! Or place to dine alone at the bar (plenty do, including myself most often!) Or come with a small group of friends to eat & drink. I've enjoyed Ryokos in all these ways & every experience is perfect. 
8. They are open until 2am! Amazing.  SF needs more real restaurants open late. 

Ryokos, I love you! You make San Francisco a better place.
author: AR S.

description:
(+) very fresh sushi, though relatively pricey for the portion
(+) best tamago sushi I've ever had
(+) the sushi chef prepares sushi like he's making art
author: Wayne T.

description: Great sushi, awesome hip atmosphere!!!
author: Ricardo C.

description:
Blink and you'll miss this place, but this intimate little joint fairly close to Union Square shopping has the freshest ingredients and well crafter sushi rolls

Specialty Rolls: The Volcano: Jalapeno & peanut butter - surprisingly delicious

Also had regular rolls: California and Spicy Tuna, and just seared Tuna sushi, and everything was fresh & tasty!
author: Aditi K.

description:
By far my favorite sushi place in the city.  Not that there's not better sushi, but there's definitely not nicer people, friendlier owners, sexier chefs, better music or later hours.  I've never been when it was 1 in the morning, but I hear stories.

The sushi is the bomb, but you must, MUST order omokase.  Another tip to those going for the first time is to sit at the bar if possible.  This is true for most sushi restaraunts, but as a regular here, I notice even I don't get the same service if sitting at a table.  The complicated fancy pants rolls are awesome, but there's nothing on the menu that compares to the fresh fish made how the chef feels necessary.  The only thing I ever order from the menu is the Jumping Unagi.  HOLY CRAP!

Atsushi the chef is to die for gorgeous and rocks my roll.  Yoshi makes the best food. Everyone there is so polite.  Adorable hostess.  

This isn't a place to go if you're in a hurry.  That's usually the point of sushi.  Takes a while, which gives you time to drink up some nigori and chat with the chefs.  

Bestill my raw beating heart.

OH! And once I had cod testicles there.  They were good.
author: Erin D.

description: Got there at 12:30 after a long trip from Chicago.  We weren't into thinking about what we wanted so we left it to counter servers to order for us. We were not disappointed.  Sushi tasted fresh and flavorful.  We will be back.  Also, having a DJ mixing tunes in the background was a nice touch.
author: Dan S.

description: The vibe in here was the best, and I'm pretty much in love with Royoko's now. It's in a basement so it's dark, but not dingy. Dense with tables, but we got one in a little nook along the back wall, which was ideal. Plus the electro-trance-ambient music was PERFECT. Sushi was great.
author: Erin G.

description:
Simply one of my favorite places in SF.

Its epic sushi, but some may say they can find better...but I dont care...this place is the isht. Theres something about this place, about the fish, about the variety in the menu, about the CBGB style bathrooms, about the people being here in the heat of lunacy, about the DJ that plays his decks on top of the piano....this place walks the line between super hidden classic and hipster knobhead gathering place...and it does it brilliantly, eat the import of the day
author: Matt K.

description: Who would have thought that  hamachi, peanutbutter and jalapenos would be so good together? Or a fried chicken roll would be so tasty. Ryoko that's who. Oh and they have really good sochu (not to be confused with soju).
author: Mateo E.

description: I was in town for a conference, and hear a lot about this place. I went with a group of 9, and used the company card. Therefore, a lot of food was ordered and tasted. Everything i had was great. I will be coming back to this place. As we were leaving, the were people waiting to get in. It is a popular place.
author: Abraham J.

description:
I've been to Ryoko's twice and both times I had a great time.

I am Japanese and I took my parents there when they came and visit me this weekend. They have been pretty disappointed about Japanese food in the city, but they were really happy at Ryoko's. 

The restaurant is little dark to see the menu at times, but the all the staff who helped my table at both occasions were really nice and helpful. The DJ who was spinning was also helpful the second time I went as it was a really busy night. He asked the waiter to come and ask an order when the restaurant got really busy. The music was little too funky for my parents age, but my parents were really satisfied because of the food.

First of all, not many Japanese restaurants have good hot tea to start with. All of us were really pleased to start a meal with a nice hot tea followed by a good miso soup. Some other dishes my parents particularly liked were agedashi tofu, edamame, miso soup, and wakame-su. We were not so thrilled about the uni, but over all our experience there was great.

It is a popular spot, so if you go on a busy night, like Friday or Saturday, it might be a good idea to make a reservation ^^
author: Sayaha A.

description: One of the most accommodating Japanese restaurants ever.  I've been here a handful of times and I'm always immediately greeted, no matter how busy they are.  The place is located below street level so there is a somewhat dark undertone throughout the restaurant, almost chlostrophobic (but, in no way bad).  The food and portions are good for the price.  They also have a good selection of sake, hot and cold.  I recommend going in for dinner after a day of shopping in Union Square.
author: D. E.

description: This little hole in the wall is fantastic. Good service and great sushi. It's become a regular spot for me.
author: Ashleigh C.

description: The sashimi and rolls were good, however I didn't find that it tasted nearly as good as what some of the other reviewers are claiming.  Great ambience & music though.   Prices were ok, given the fact that this was in SF.   I'd like to come back and give order some different items and update this review.  Right now, I'd give this place 3.4 stars.
author: Jeff L.

description:
I love that this place is open later than most restaurants. My boyfriend took me here after my flight landed at 10PM. I was starving after the 7 hour flight, and I did not want to settle for Carls Jr or In-N-Out, which is what I normally get after landing past 10 on a weeknight. 

This place was still packed when we arrived, but we were promptly seated by the friendly waitstaff. We ordered two rolls, a chicken teriyaki, yakitori, gyoza, rice, and a drink for a grand total of $50. Not too bad, especially since I come from NY, and even the unauthentic Japanese food here is ridiculously expensive. Our waiter was great, and I really enjoyed my time here. This might end up being my new go-to place when I land.
author: Mich Y.

description: It was about 1:00 am in the city after a reggae show and before a long drive back down the peninsula, I needed to eat.  Yelp to the rescue: clicked on nearby and filtered open now.  Found a sushi spot 3 blocks from the club.  When we opened the door, it looked really cool as it was in the basement and there was jazz playing and had a full bar.  Everyone was friendly.  I ordered the volcano roll and a few other specialty rolls.  The volcano rolls is amazing mainly because there is peanut butter in it.  It is bit of a dark, sexy place.  I call it a late night sushi speakeasy.  Only in SF do you find places with character like this.
author: Leah C.

description:
I was recently in the Bay area when I had Ryoko's and was not impressed.  Although the restaurant looks very hip and fun, the music was pretty terrible and didn't fit the ambiance they were trying to portray.  The wait staff was terrible.  The place wasn't that busy and it took forever just to get our drinks.  We sat in a really cramped space as well and were sweating in the cubby hole!

As for the food, the sushi was nothing amazing.  We had omakase which is supposed to be the chef's picks and was utterly disappointed.  The toro was so warm and the rice was too!  We also had spanish mackerel which lacked in flavor and was chewy.  Then they offered us soggy tempura shitake(not a misspelling) mushrooms, a martini glass filled to the top with ponzu with great octopus but couldn't enjoy it because of how much they drowned it in the ponzu.  Then they gave us chicken skewers that were mushy and we completely had enough.  Chef's pick!?  Forget about it!  

Food was terrible, presentation lacked, the service was poor, they took over half an hour to give us our check, it was expensive for terrible quality and I would never go back!  

I did however have a nice glass of plum wine.  

The end.
author: Moni L.

description:
Fresh fish in a funky clublike environment. Pitchers of beer available.

We arrived at 8pm and waited for aabout 10 minutes. The place was pretty killer and the indonesian waiters were nice and fast. We ordered white sake, Asahi big beers, tako, hamachi, maguro nigiri and a few fried tiger rolls. All were large and fresh, but I prefer my tako boiled. The experience was worth the $60. We'lltake our friends here when they visit.
author: Rod C.

description:
I think this definitely must be a converted bordello with the low ceilings and dark faux velveteen interior.  It's definitely seen the darker days, as the well worn carpet I'm sure has many tales to tell.  Not that I'm listening.

I was curious about the large black grand piano sitting not so innocuously in the middle of everything as if somehow Asian classics would suddenly start to flow from it's core.  

We came late though which was the main redeeming factor at the time and likely missed all the hub-bub of crowds, singing and karaoking by the piano-side.  Which was perfect.

Sat at the sushi bar, ordered a few of their specials and a few appetizers.  It was all de-lice.  They were out of hamachi toro, but the sake toro was melt-in-your-mouth buttery goodness.  And the pokemon role wrapped in the oddest yellow skin was perfectly fresh with mango and sake.  And the fried tofu was light and not greasy in a flavorful sauce.

The best part was the great repartee the sushi chef was having with two other local chefs about various foodie things about town and in L.A.  Loads of good tips to go!
author: Lara L.

description:
Simply put, AMAZING sushi, great Sake, over-the-top friendly staff and sushi chefs, upbeat music...just about the perfect restaurant..

I travel well over 50% of the year, always seek out a good sushi joint, and Ryoko's has become my absolute favorite of them all. It's the first place I think about when I know I'm making it back to San Fransisco!

Don't let the sign or underground entrance steer you away!
author: Drew G.

description: Ryoko is pretty much my favorite sushi bar in the country.  I've been to more sushi bars than I can count, even the stupid high-end ones like Nobu.  But Ryoko is above and beyond the best around.  I've never had tuna so tender, such great service, such an amazing variety of rolls, and such a great decor and environment.  I got turned on to this place by a colleague a couple of years ago, and have been here 3-4 times since.  Every time they are so nice, they take excellent care of you, and, well, hands down it is the BEST FISH EVER!
author: Paul S.

description:
Quality over quantity for sure. The sushi is small but good. Ambiance is real intimate. Lighting is low and they have a dj. Good for a place if you're looking for late night sushi. 

Def would come here again but def not my top faves.
author: April L.

description: Sushi is okay, I've had better sushi in L.A., however the Fried cheese sticks were so good. Me and my gf ordered some to take to our hotel. The restaurant is really small.
author: peter k.

description:
Ryoko's has great service staff. It opens until 2 am and has a full bar. Dance music is played all the time at a volume that makes normal conversation slightly inconvenient. And against all the rave reviews, I have to say, the food is okay.

They do not have a large selection of fish. A true sushi connoisseur would find it lacking. This is not the place if you want nice nigiri sushi or chirashi. Don't bother to order the deluxe chirashi. At it's $30 price tag, I expect something more than a few slices of Maguro, sake, saba, tamago, unagi on rice flooded with ikura. The tofu in the miso soup tasted sour and the rice ball (onigiri) is nothing special. On the other hand, if you are with people who love Americanized sushi rolls late at night, I guess this is the place to be. 

I have to agree the atmosphere is great for social gathering. It's cozy and has tiny rooms for groups of people. It is a nice experience at Ryoko's, but I have to say the place does not deserve a five stars rating for its food.
author: Eugene C.

description:
The sushi is good but unfortunately, the service wasn 't good last time.
We waited about 45 min to be served... They didn't even apologized.
I was really disappointed because it was a good service at the bar.
author: Cafe A.

description:
Best fish.  Ever.

Oh wait, I just came remembering the my last visit there.  

Oh yeah, it's that good.
author: T-Bag S.

description: I wasn't as impressed as the other reviewers were.  This definitely is a "sushi restaurant" because all the menu had was rolls, fish, rolls, fish and more rolls and fish. The other food was on the appetizer menu.  We settled for a salad, miso soup, tempura, the jumping tuna roll and another roll (I forget which one).  Me forgetting what it was is a big bad sign because that means I obviously wasn't satisfied enough to come back for more.  Mehhh!! I left this place with a $40+ bill and still hungry.  Didn't think it was worth an extra $12 for another roll....eh not my type of sushi bar!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
I came here for my birthday with a group of about 15 people (made reservations, but damn, it is hard to get them on the phone!), and thought it was quite good. I had never been here before, but a friend of mine had, so I decided to give it a chance.  I also really wanted to have sushi, but found it hard to find places that can accommodate large groups.

The service was pretty good, several servers came to our table to see if we wanted to order more food and drinks (most of the time we did). 

I though the food was tasty, I ordered several appetizers (tempura fried cheese!!), and found the rolls I got to be fresh and creative. They also brought out a tempura fried ice cream and sang happy birthday to me, which was cute.  

I could have done without the annoying techno music, but whatever, our group was loud, so we kinda drowned it out. 

All in all, I had a wonderful birthday dinner here!
author: Kelly L.

description: The other reviews are correct even for early dinner there was about a 30min wait.  Very well worth it. Nice touch they offered to serve a beverage while you wait. Service was great and super fast!  We live in OC and found the price very reasonable compared to the places we normally go at home. I highly recommend, everything on the menu was amazing.
author: Mark S.

description: I LOVE this restaurant!  When it's late at night and you're in the mood for some sushi, Ryoko's is the place to be!  Located near one of Academy of Art's housing accomodations are, there are a bunch of young people that go there.  The service is great, the food is great, the atmosphere is nice.  I tried ame ebi for the first time and like it!  If you have a big group with you, they can accomodate you since they've expanded a room for large groups.
author: Allie P.

description:
What can I say about this place... Long wait to be seated but it 's worth it because this place is awesome. Ive been coming to this place since 08 :)
love the Fried Cheese ;)
author: nancy v.

description:
Eating uni at Ryoko's is like playing Russian Roulette with your butt hole. Yes, sometimes it's firm and fresh. But last Saturday night, it resembled a used condom: deflated and oozing goo.

But, I was enjoying the sake and Sapporo a little too much. And when that happens, I have no judgment whatsoever. So I ate the uni. And I ate my boyfriend's too. "What do you mean it tastes funny? If you won't eat it, I will!"

An hour later, at some bar whose name I never did catch, the uni struck back. In it's determination to reach the sea via the sewage ducts of San Francisco, I spent 3 hours in the bathroom, clutching my middle and whimpering.

Moral of the story: the fresh seafood at Ryoko's is a hit or miss. I'll still go back because their back room is a fantastic place to hang out with a group of people before going out hard. But it's much safer to stick to all things American: dragon rolls, spicy this or that roll, something called the Sexy roll that comes with melted cheese on it...you know, American sushi. 

Oh and make reservations. They get packed.
author: Jenn L.

description:
We were told to go here by a local, who obviously didn't know what we meant when we told her we wanted REALLY good sushi.

I had the volcano roll, which was good but nothing special. My boyfriend ordered the 49'er roll requesting no mayo and they said okay. We got our order, mine was fine but his came with mayo. He told the server it had mayo in it so she took it back.  The server came back and said the crab is already mixed with mayo so he would have to order something else, now don't you think that is something she should know?  I proceeded to eat my roll while he waited for his new roll for 20-25 min!

Overall the food was average and the ambiance made it worse.
author: Kali M.

description:
I love the 'ambiance', namely the feeling that I'm going to hang out in my friend's basement.
I went on a first date here, have taken my family here and never been disappointed.
While their sake selection leaves something to be desired, the sushi & sashimi is YUMMY. Oh, deliciousness.
Sometimes the service is slow for no reason but I usually don't mind because I'm easily distracted with the good music they play.
author: Claire S.

description:
Ryoko's is one of my favorite late night sushi spots. The vibe and the people really makes this place worthwhile.  The sashmi is consistently fresh and the prices aren't that steep either.

Last time I was here Sean Penn sat right next to me.  That definitely made my sushi experience there 10x more enjoyable.
author: Rochelle B.

description: Decent sushi at a decent price. The quality of fish was good and the combinations a plenty. I don't remember exactly what we ordered, but it was all tasty and fresh. The wait staff was very attentive with refilling tea and friendly to boot. It's not at the level of some of the top sushi restaurants, but neither is the price. Nice neighborhood place!
author: Briana S.

description: If I could give this place zero stars I would.  Called in to place a takeout order.  They told me that the only way to place a takeout order was to come in in person.  So I walked over and the wait staff was extremely rude.  After walking past my polite "excuse mes" for about 10 minutes, I finally got one to notice me.  Upon asking where I go to place a takeout order, she told me that it would be 45 minutes at least to get and order FOR TAKEOUT!  Pretty ridiculous considering the wait time to get a table was about five minutes.  Go elsewhere, these people suck.
author: John O.

description: When I think Ryoko, I start craving 80's music, great sushi, a blue house, and a Sapparo buzz. It can get super packed at night and the service can be somewhat lackluster during these times. If you can, try sitting at the bar. Best sushi in Union Square.
author: Rick W.

description: My friend just celebrated her quarterlife bday din-din here recently. I'm in love with this place! Good food plus awesome choice of music played by the dj. Looove it!
author: Sheryl D.

description:
Very good sushi and one of the few places where I've seen Umeshiso makizushi on the menu.  We ordered a bunch of sushi and appetizers and everything was good.  The staff was very friendly, lots of Japanese working there (always a good sign).  Also there was a DJ spinning some lounge music on their big piano.  

One complaint that the portions were a little small for the price.  

I would go again, good for a date.  Be sure to make a reservation when we left there was a pretty long line out the door.
author: Peter W.

description: Probably the best sushi ever! LOVED LOVED LOVED it! Cannot say it enough. I loved the ambience, I loved the food and I loved the people.
author: On The G.

description:
I was a virgin to the city when I used to come here, my DJ friends used to spin here on Saturday nights and it was the best. One night we had all these Russians playing their utensils and glasses to the beat of good house.......
Another night this big cool black dude showed up late and tickled the ivory and sang for his adoring big white mamma. It was the cutest thing I'd ever seen. 
Oh and the sushi was really good too, I can't recall the food as well as the fun but I do remember how the feeling was to first move to the city and discover cool holes in the wall like Ryoko's.
author: Lisa J.

description:
I love this place - it's fun, tasty, has music, and is open late.   It kind of reminds me of some of the izakayas in Tokyo where you walk down stairs to a dark, small and narrow bar.  

Ryoko's has amazing ikura and toro.  You will find friendly service with staff who speaks Japanese and English fluently.  The place is fun yet relaxing with a mixed crowd.  

I now live in LA but whenever I come back to SF I usually make a visit to Ryoko's to eat and drink sake, of course.
author: Jillian B.

description: Great place for late night sushi!  It's a small place, underground.  You might have even passed by it a few times without even noticing it.  I love coming here for their appetizers, rolls, and drinks.  Some nights I really can't stand how they blast the music though.
author: Sandy J.

description:
A late night sushi spot that plays good music with a quirky staff and interior to match? I couldn't ask for much more. 

I've been here on a quiet night with a friend, a not-quiet night with a bunch of friends, and even a surprise sake party with a large group-- no complaints at any time, and I always look forward to returning.
author: crystala t.

description:
Had the worst restaurant experience in San Francisco. Waited three hours to eat, including 45 minutes just to get the bill, when it was not very busy (read: half the restaurant was empty). We entertained ourselves well, but the waitress simply wasn't paying attention to us. 

By the time we had nearly died, famished, the food was spectacularly mediocre. Barely passable, even though we were starving. On top of that, we were double-charged for the tips, because of the ineptitude of the waitstaff.

This place is really bad, I am sorry to say nobody should eat there.
author: Aris V.

description:
Stumbled upon Ryoko after walking around the mall. When you first go in, you'll go down a flight of stairs into a dark but cozy little sushi bar. We waited for a while because there's not much seating, but it was worth it. I have to say, one of the best parts of this place is their water. It's got the perfect amount of lemon flavor in it, with no other dirty flavors, not even in the ice. I must have drank at least 10 cups of water, and the waitress kept my glass full while juggling about 15 other tables. 
Sushi was delicious. We sat at the sushi bar and watched them make it; fish was fresh and that avocado on the Dragon Roll...so yummy and creamy, melted like butter. 

You can get good sushi at many places, but for me the two things that made Ryoko's stand out were its customer service, and the music. You'll probably have to wait for a while, but the waitress definitely goes out of her way to make you happy. And in the hour and a half I was here, the beats were amazing. Just wanted to dance and eat sushi.

I'll be back here. So much good.
author: David C.

description:
Food: Ok- flavor was good, we ordered the Sashimi meal and and a roll. The fish was fresh and flavorful
Portions: Below average, not great
Price: Overpriced for the portion
Service: so-so, they were really busy when we went on a Friday night
Wait time: Long wait time on Friday night
author: Josh C.

description:
My friend and I wandered around for about half an hour looking for a good place to eat. I used the Yelp app on my phone and there are two sushi restaurants right next to each other. They both had a similar rating so we chose this one.

Why I like this place:
-EVERY employee says that inaudible Japanese sushi greeting when you walk in. 
-I'm a thirsty guy and I drink a lot of water. My glass got refilled before reaching the halfway point.
-They play great music.
-The food is good.

What I didn't like: 
-If you're sitting on the couch side, it's comfortable. The stools that sit opposite are not comfortable at all.
author: Chris K.

description:
This place has a really neat feel.

It's downstairs (below street-level) and intimate, reminding one of the belly of an galleon or some sort of little jazz dive like you'd find in an east-coast city.  The fish is wonderful and the wait-staff are friendly.  Despite the close-quarters, the tables are still intimate.  On the night I went with my friends, there was a DJ spinning some housey remixes and the place was packed, but comfortable.

A perfect combination of food and venue, in my book.
author: Conor T.

description:
I held my bf's surprise birthday dinner here on New Years Eve.  For a party of 10, we were given a private room in the back, which was cozy but still open to others for people watching.  It was PERFECT.  The drinks were decent, service was very attentive and polite, and the food was quite satisfying, and the atmosphere was very festive.

Based on previous reviews, I was afraid the food would be less than stellar and more of a "cheesecake factory-esque" main stream quality.  However, we were pleasantly surprised.  Even my bff, who is a critical foodie, and my bf, who is from Japan were both loving the fresh fish.  My other gf, who isnt into fish and ordered the chicken teriyaki also thought her dish was great as well.

All in all, great times were had thanks to a festive atmosphere, perfect seating, and wonderful food.

(Minus one star because there is only 1 teeny-tiny stall for the ladies room.)
author: Ebiru S.

description:
We went here for a friend's bday and I wasn't completely impressed. First and foremost, I felt like I was sitting at a little kid's table. Since we had a lot of people our table was pretty long, but the last four seats were on a different level. Which made us feel like we were at the kids table. 

Their sushi rolls were good, but not the best I've had. They did have an interesting roll with peanut butter in it called the Volcano Roll. Pretty good for being sushi + peanut butter. I also ordered a salmon nigiri but the salmon wasn't very fresh and very small. 

The ambiance of this place was nice and seemed fun and hip. If you go here, I would stick to rolls and smaller groups.
author: Jaein L.

description: My favorite sushi spot! It's underground, open really late, and has high quality fish. Highly recommended.
author: Shannon R.

description: I was referred to Ryoko's by a friend because it was close to where we were planning on ending the night. It's in the TL just a couple blocks from the Square (which we walked from) so we knew it would likely be an interesting place. It was packed so I was confident we'd be happy with our meal. Unfortunately once we sat (on pillow stools - almost like an ottomon), it took a while for our server to get to us. We knew what we wanted when she asked what we wanted to drink yet refused to take our order until she came back - 10 minutes later. The two of us shared 5 rolls but only one was memorable - it had mango and salmon. Awful service as I had to stop someone three times to get refills on my water (their spicy rolls are SPICY). Despite my craving for sushi, I should have walked down to Blondie's Pizza for a slice-o-pep.
author: Erin L.

description: Great underground spot with a slighty dive-y feel and excellent food. Genuine Japanese food with a great menu and awesome staff. Recommended for many different occasions.
author: Phil D.

description: After reading a lot of reviews on Yelp I had to check Ryoko's out because it is in my neighborhood and I would pass by it all the time.  I think all of the other reviews have pretty much nailed it.  It's a hole in the wall but they greet you when you enter and leave which is a cool touch.  They also have some different rolls that you would never find anywhere else and they are good.  I'll definitely be back to try some of the other rolls.
author: Blake B.

description: It's one of my favorite restaurants in SF. They have very nice Toro there. I like going there in weekend when the DJ is there. Drinks and food always are good together.
author: Tammy L.

description: Ryokos is on Taylor St, near Post. The restaurant front is small. You basically duck under some low-hanging Japanese banners and walk down a staircase. Once you're at the bottom things come alive. We went there on a Monday night and the place was hopping. We had to wait 15 minutes for a table. Once seated you're bombarded  by different sake handouts and menus. After deciding that reading all of these descriptions was just too much after a long day at work, I opted for the plain hot sake. Nothing special about it but a large bottle is $7, which is a pretty good price.  The food menu is pretty extensive with a lot of Japanese cuisine options, even for those crazy people who don't like sushi. The sushi selection is pretty good, with one full page for nigiri/sashimi selections, one for standard maki rolls and one for specialty maki rolls. They automatically give you an order of edamame on the house when you sit down. We ordered the miso soup, which was nothing out of the ordinary. We also ordered a house salad to split. Usually house salads are served in the same small bowl size as miso soup but this one was gigantic, a great deal for $5. The table next two us had the gyoza, which smelled delicious so we got an order of that. It comes with this spicy dipping sauce instead of the standard soy, which was a nice change. For sushi, we for the spice scallop which was listed as a standard roll when a lot of places charge premium prices. And it wasn't a weak spice, it was actually so spicy that the friend I was with couldn't eat it (which means more for me!). We also ordered the rainbow roll, which is a choice you can't really go wrong with as long as the fish quality is up to snuff. I would definitely recommend checking out Ryokos if you want good sushi near Union Square (although my favorite will always be Sushi Toni).
author: Larisa J.

description: It's all about the ambiance. The rolls were not good. We didn't stay for sushi. Overpriced if you're going there just for dinner. More of a place you go to for afterhours in need of something to snack on.
author: Nay S.

description:
I have never eaten sushi before. It was my first time. I'm not afraid to admit I have a western palette when it comes to food. Not really a big fan of fish either!! 

So why did I end up going out to this restaurant? 

Well, my wife and friends have been bugging me to try sushi for ages and I finally agreed to give it a try. If I didn't like it, there is always a McDonald's on the way home right? 

Well, I have to say this place is great! People were waiting on the sidewalk to get a table (which was a good sign) and it had a real club feel to it with a house DJ spinning tunes while you ate. It is a small place, low lighting and the tables were packed tightly together and the place has a really cool buzz to it. 

They serve a mixture of hot and cold food. The sushi rolls are great, lots of choice. Definitely reccommend the Volcano Rolls. Peanut butter with tempura shrimp and jalapeno peppers! Everything we ordered was edible (don't forget this was my first time!) and they have a full bar too. Beer by the pitcher, sake by the bottle. No complaints there and the price was reasonable enough. 

Ryokos had a great atmosphere and a cool place to spend the evening with friends. I will be going back there again.
author: clive w.

description:
Ryoko's is one of the very few Japanese restaurants that opens late, so  we decided to come here after 10pm on a Saturday.  Even at that time, there were still 20 people ahead of us, so there's usually a bit of a wait.  

Once you go downstairs, you'll find a dimly lit restaurant which felt more like a bar than a restaurant.  I'm sure it's catered more for the late night crowd since there's even a live DJ.  

I've been to Ryoko's several times, but this was the first time I sat in the back room which had a very low table with square ottomans as seats.  I have to say the seating arrangement was rather uncomfortable.  I would've have preferred the regular seating.  

Now on to the food.  My friends ordered a bunch of cooked rolls (yeah, I know) and agedashi tofu.  I had the chirashi since I wanted my raw fish fix.   Presentation wise, it looked nice, but I have to say the sashimi in the chirashi was just above average.  At the price, you would either expect higher quality or bigger portions, but for me, I would've preferred better quality.

Ryoko's is a perfect late night dining spot if you don't want to go with the standard greasy late night eats.  If you just want Japanese during regular dinner hours, there are probably better options in the city.  I give it 4 stars just because the food is decent and it opens late.
author: David T.

description: Awesomely dark, underground atmosphere with late night hours. Fresh, delicious sushi, friendly staff, and cool music. Dj's on weekends. A+ for Reiko, the manager/owner who hooks it up for when I have larger parties there! I love getting the private room for up to 6 people or when I had a birthday party there she helped me set up the private room and the whole back room to my liking. Thank you Reiko and Ryoko's staff for always making me, my friends, my family, my bf and his family happy every time we go there. :)
author: M L.

description: Wow!!! Talk about putting a modern spin on sushi. As others have said the volcano roll was fantastic. Actually everything we had was great. It was a bit on the pricey side hence the four stars instead of five but I'm probably just being picky.
author: Chris G.

description:
This jazzy spot is great for parties or get togethers... The owner is amazing and she will tend your needs.  The sushi crew behind the bar is also amazing.  You will love the food and the prices are pretty good!

Oh and the sake!  haha! So many times you will just keep coming back for more.  It's just so good you cant resist it!

The decor is very hip and cool.  It's hard to miss so drive slow but there is valet so that helps.  Parking is a nightmare if you're looking for street parking so don't even try it.

Make sure you tip well and say hi to the staff because they are hilarious and the food is just too good!
author: Harry H.

description:
This place is fun! I love sushi restaurants that don't make you roll your eyes when you step in the door. no exotic plants - check. no bamboo and paper lanterns - check. no zen mood music - check. no bubbly happy asian waitresses - che...oh wait, that'll always be there. 

this place is great because it's a basement hunt - semi dark, and with a nice bar strategically placed right at the base of the stairs. it's a relaxed, fun place to grab drinks and get some quality sushi. a bunch of us got several orders of everything, all of which were amazingly fresh. don't bother with the rolls - go straight for the sashimi!
author: Jeni Y.

description:
This is a hype sushi place and has great music on weekends. Ryoko has Japanese people there so it must be authentic. You can check out a related review at: http://www.triangletrip.com/2009/04/14/sushi-san-francisco-union-square

These guys put a great summary for Ryoko. I vouch for this.
author: Louie D.

description:
A little bit pricey but a good eclectically decorated sushi bar with a relatively imaginative menu.  A hidden gem with a funky atmosphere..  Great music & vibe and open late..
Big fan of the Pokemon roll..
author: Rose C R.

description:
Open late, open late, open late!!!

Their sushi could taste like pond fish and the wakame salad served frozen, and I think I would still give them at least 4 stars just for being open late.  2:00 am every night, if I remember correctly.

But they're getting 5 stars because the sushi is also pretty darned good, and the atmosphere is cool.  They have a lot of interesting rolls which are quite tasty.  We ordered a couple of the fresh fish specials as nigiri, and these were good too.  I like the basement setting, the blue hues, the piano in the middle, the music, and the staff calling an enthusiastic greeting from across the restaurant to everyone who walks in the door.  Overall, someplace I plan on visiting pretty regularly, especially after midnight.
author: Carolyn B.

description:
Perfect late night sushi joint. Upon immediate seating, you are served a bowl of edamame. This always throws me off because I never order it and it is part of the appetizer menu. To solve all wonderment, the edamame is complimentary.

The appetizers and rolls are more extensive than most sushi places. I recommend the Pokeman roll, sake with large slices of mango, avocado, and lettuce wrapped in soy bean skin and the salty yet puckery umeshiso roll (takes a fine palette to appreciate this!) 

This place is tucked away in the basement and occasionally has a DJ spinning and the waitresses grinding. Seems to have plentiful Japanese business men as patrons who like to bump into girls "accidentally." Felt like I was back on the Japanese subway during rush hour, if you know what I mean. There is an element of hip with a dash of sleaze.
author: Cathy H.

description: Great Sushi found here!  Looks like your headed into a dive, then you get this great presentation of sushi with club dance music.  We enjoyed sitting at the bar and watching the creations plated.  The service was good - the atmosphere was great.  They stay open late too.  The quality was as good as I had in San Francisco.  The main difference seemed that the employees really were having fun and the guys behind the bar were lively upbeat and entertaining - artist that love their craft.  I will go back.
author: Robert B.

description:
I like their sushi so much that I can even stand a long wait, uncomfortable seats (depends on table), bad air and bad 90s music destroying any change of conversation. Despite of all of this, I am willing to give five stars.

And oh, the service is pretty good, if not great.
author: Janne K.

description:
So here's what you do: take a lounge-y club (Hendrix posters on the wall, dim lights, dark decor, grand piano in the middle), add a ridiculously friendly hostess and wait staff, and top it off with some very, very good sushi.  And there you have Ryoko, now in my top 2 or 3 Japanese restaurants I've been in SF. 

I had a couple rolls and some of the nigiri specials (big eye tuna and salmon toro) and all was incredibly fresh and good.  The large house sake was decent, too, especially for $7.  

I think my favorite thing, though, was the hostess (or was she the owner?).   She greeted everyone who came in as if they were old high school friends with whom she was ecstatic to be reunited after years apart.   Her friendly vibe permeated the entire place, making dinner not only tasty but all-around fun.  

In short, a great place to stop by after work, after a long night of drinkin' in the neighborhood, or with out-of-town guests you want to take to a great, local sushi joint.
author: Eric S.

description: Classic hole in the wall, sushi joint. Discovered it a few weeks ago with friends. Sushi was outstanding, prices were very reasonable...no ambiance though... Just great sushi
author: Shirin O.

description:
Here's the thing about Ryoko's: it's got great hours, great service, space cowboy jazz atmosphere, plenty of steaming green tea, but it's got a cherry-picked Japanese small eats menu that qualifies as somewhere between rock bottom to standard.
When it comes down to it, Ryoko's appeal isn't the food at all. It's the place itself, this underground odd space filled with the scent of pickled ginger and sake, with a bright space heater and pillows in small mysterious enclaves--all available into the wee hours of the night. 11PM? The night's too young, and Ryoko's offers itself as a convenient pit stop in-between late evening prowls or as a final destination for those who have finished their hunt. This being San Francisco, it's hard to resist even sub-par sushi when it's available made to order with clock past midnight and well on it's way to 1.
So, keep an eye out for Ryoko's as a haven from the outdoors on your Friday night journey, but not as a gold star first-class sushi-ya.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Ace Racer is a real guy!! He's wearing his scarf, blaring DJ Shadow and Aerosmith classics, and serving up sushi until 2 AM at this Tender Nob haunt.

Sounds stupid to say, but the most important aspect of a sushi joint is the quality of the fish. But in this world of maki fever, I find it surprising how many cookie cutter sushi places serve mediocre fish by rolling it up into spicy, tempura, or other crazy rolls. I know they may taste okay, but people trust me you're eating crap and paying dearly in many cases.

Not here. Ryoko's a breath of fresh ocean air. The fish is always fresh and the chef who's direct from Tokyo always strives to have seasonable specials on hand to keep regulars happy. Eating sashimi and nigiri here and nothing else is an exciting experience.  Indulge confidentally in "Omakase": put the menu down and ask "Ace" to craft a meal for you and just see what happens.

The atmosphere is a wonderful unique hybrid of Tokyo kitch and San Francisco dive. Think dark plush piano bar where the members of Voltron chill out and recap their missions. Impress your cool kid friends from out of town, show your date how fun and down to Earth you are, or crash in the back booth late with friends after concert at the Great American Music hall. 

Oh, and yes, they still have tons of fantastic inventive rolls made up of mostly oringinal creations. Try the "Jumping Tuna"!
author: Brian S.

description:
I just got a new go to place in the city for sushi!  
I've been there twice now and last night convinced me.  Yoshi, the owner was there last night and made the night even more enjoyable (he is there sundays and wednesdays).  Had the fried cheese(order it with jalapenos, suggested by Yoshi), tuna natto, tuna likke and uni among other things.  All of it was very tasty and fresh.  I am now one of the many fans and will return.
author: goldberg d.

description:
I've been here several years ago and recently had a late dinner after a night of drinking.

The space is interesting and below ground.  There is really no decor to speak of but there is definitely a regular type scene there.

The sushi chefs all looked under 30 which in itself is not a good sign.  Fish was fresh enough but everything just seemed a bit sloppy.

Perhaps I've been seriously too spoiled by Ino Sushi, but I had higher hopes for Ryoko.  Authentic, yes, but does not make the top 25%.  It may have once before.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Despite the presence of better sushi places, I eat here fairly often.  I agree with other posters that Ryoko's is more of a hang out spot rather than the setting of a date.

The selection of fish is fairly average, but if you order off the specials board (there is usually uni flown in from Japan as well as big eye tuna and some form of mackerel), you can do quite well.  I'm also a big fan of mame aji, which are whole, pinky finger-sized deep fried mackerel that you eat whole.  The "creative" sushi rolls are somewhat smaller than other places, but have a higher fish to rice ratio.  The quality of the knife work and rice in the sushi can vary, but is generally acceptable.

For what it's worth, you can also get beer in pitchers.  Speaking of beer, I came here once with a large group for a birthday and Ryoko ended up comping a lot of our booze, even though there may or may not have been a cake fight.
author: Suo L.

description:
For sure Ryoko's downstairs, cozy, softly-lit, blue & black atmosphere sets the stage for delightfully prepared sushi treats. I enjoyed the miso soup, spicy scallop roll, special fatty tuna roll & special nigiri sake toro. All of it amazing.

Sitting alone at the bar is a great way to experience this place. There I met Ryoko herself, an inspiring transplant from Japan, and must say that it will be an honor to return to her establishment as a regular!
author: Mars H.

description:
Best sushi hole-in-wall (low mantenace) in SF.

Casual and fun. A place I could go once a week. 
Related- to sushi restaurants  (out of 5 possible stars)
Venue- 4
Service- 5
Food factor- 4
Overall exp- 4.3 Stars  
Drawbacks- I really like this place. The owner made time for us to feel at welcomed and everything was great.
author: C R.

description:
I'm afraid to Yelp Ryoko's in case it gets busier.  This is my favorite place in the city if I want to eat amazing raw fish.  Eat off the board for incredibly high quality sushi.

The miso soup with clams is good too, as are most of the things on the menu.  Rolls are yummy.  It's a fun place.
author: Leo C.

description:
This place is pretty excellent. Good quality fish that is well prepared. Be sure to ask about the seasonal specials for a little something you might not see all the time. The barracuda was especially tasty last night. The izakaya style dishes from their kitchen are worth a look too.

My only complaint is that when we were in there last night they had a dj going and the music was too loud to be able to carry on a conversation without yelling. I'll still be going back though.
author: Jesse C.

description:
Now let me tell you, this is one of the coolest Sushi places I've been too. EVAR. While in San Francisco earlier this year, my friends and I happened to be staying about a block from Ryoko's and we decided to give it a go. I'm so glad we did!

The wait was really long, but it was well worth it. The place was packed to the brim and it was full of so much energy! The ambiance was cool. Lot's of different people were there, mainly a crowd of young adults. It had almost a club feel to it, which I didn't mind. There was a DJ right in the middle of the restaurant playing some great house music. I think maybe it was a little too loud, but then again, we ended up sitting right next to him. Regardless, it made me want to dance while eating dinner. The restaurant is a little cramped and it's located downstairs below street level, but that doesn't matter. The decorations are pretty neat too.

The sushi itself was very very good, as were the sake bombs. Probably one of my favorite places. If you're in the area and you need something to do on the weekend, go here! I'm definitely eating here again next time I'm in SF.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
This place is pretty cool.

+Open LATE when you're been to Ruby Sky, to Slide, or just drinking your butt off in Union Square this is a great Diner alternative.

The rolls were pretty good.  3 rolls plus salad was just right for 2 ladies.  The quality was normal not great not bad.  This place has really interesting atmosphere.  Blue walls, musty warm basement feel.  Not really a gourmet sushi experience, but still a very cool spot.
author: Sonya C.

description: Went here because it was the only place I found that was open late and close to my hotel. I went with two my girl friends and the wait for a table was not that bad, but the wait on ordering and getting the food was. It took a while for the server to approach us and get our orders. On top of that, the food took a while to come out and the sushi was ok, I had better. Also, the place is very dim and they have a DJ that plays loud music, which makes the restaurant noisy and hard to see the menu.
author: Stacey D.

description:
I was not expecting to eat sushi the night I ate at Ryoko's.  

The group that I went with had an individual who was well seasoned in the Ryoko's atmosphere and decided to order the "Chefs Special".  
The sushi was very good and fresh, but the price tag of almost $100.00 per head which is quite ludicrous especially considering when I walked out of Ryoko's I was still hungry!

This restaurant for what it is: expensive for the lack of fish you get.  There are better sushi places in San Francisco.
author: John C.

description:
This place is one of our favorites and we often take visitors there when they come. Heartily recommended for food, atmosphere and service! 

I lived in Japan for a couple of years, and Ryoko's makes me feel like I am transported back there. Everyone is greeted with "Irashaimasen!!!" walking through the door, the specials are always authentic, fresh and creative, and the service transports me back to those wonderful days. The kind of undergroud-ey feel to the place is also cool, and it's great to enjoy the music while you wait for your meal. The only thing on the menu that could be avoided is the gyoza- it's a bit greasy and very "meh" compared to the rest of their food. 

Overall, this is a great place.
author: Bruceroff U.

description:
I am a really big fan of Ryoko's. 

The sushi is yummy. I usually go for the Jumping Tuna. It's  a deep fried roll, with spicy tuna, cucumber, and something else...can't remember some other kind of veggie. They serve it with a sweet sauce which makes a lovely mix between the spicyness of the tuna. 

Last night we also had the Toro which was really fresh and just melted in your mouth with buttery goodness. 

They've even begun to brew their own beer. The thing about it, is that they only brew it in small quantities. Which is why we couldn't enjoy trying it last night because it was all gone.. call the Waaaa-mbulance! I'm whining about it! : ( 

The environment is really fun. It's date appropriate, girl/boys night appropriate, bring your not uptight family place. They are also open until 2am every night! Which is really really awesome! 

What am I missing...cute sushi chef's. Super nice wait staff. 

The music sometimes is questionable. But, we can't always agree on everything, can we? No.

Try the Checkerboard.

Don't miss the daily specials board! They have really good, just from Japan plates too. 

Just...GO!
author: Marivel M.

description: This is the BEST Hamachi Kama I've ever tasted!!! And I've traveled everywhere including Japan for sushi.  Let's just say Nobu in Vegas is considered fast food sushi to me.  Back to the Hamachi Kama, it was so succulent, fall off the bone, with huge portions on top of it, and very reasonably priced at $17.50.  I would have paid more too for that taste.  The rainbow roll, hamachi and Hamachi Toro sushi was perfectly cut and super FRESH, along with great flavor.  The only downfall is that it took forever to get our drinks which was understandable given that I probably came hear on the busiest night (New Year's Eve) celebrating 2015.  The fact that they didn't compromise on quality for such a busy night speaks volumes.  Eli was an excellent sushi chef making the Rainbow and Hamachi sushi cuts iron chef worthy!  Not only did it look magazine quality it was backed up with the taste!  Will definitely come here again.
author: Donna K.

description: This place is overrated. The atmosphere is unique but it isn't worth the wait. Went there for my daughter's birthday and was seated near the kitchen. I ordered Hamachi Kama, it was very large and some of the best I ever had. I was enjoying it until I found a long black hair under it. Because it was my daughter's birthday, I didn't make a scene or send it back. I also ordered Amaebi with deep fried heads. The size of the shrimp didn't match the size of the heads. It looked as if the heads didn't actually come off the body I was eating. There was black gooey stuff inside one of the heads that I have never seen before. I have eaten this dish 100's of times and never saw this inside. It tasted bitter and I didn't finish it. The portions of Nigeri were very small and dried out as if they were prepared hours ago. They were out of Maguro and Toro. My daughter is a vegetarian and ordered the Vegetable Medley. It was stuffed with way to much basil and she couldn't finish it. The menu is limited and doesn't have pictures so you had better know what you want. There were five of us and we spent a large amount of money. The service was good but you could tell that they wanted to turn the table as fast as possible. As soon as you finished a plate, it was gone in less than 30seconds. We ordered Mochi for desert and felt they were rushing us to get out by hovering over our table. I don't think we would dine hear again.
author: Leonardo P.

description: Ryoko's was a great place for sushi, not just late-night-only-sushi-available -sushi. I would very happily go back at anytime. All of the fish was incredibly fresh (even at 1 am!), especially the tuna and yellowtail. Dragon Roll was perfectly spicy. We were disappointed that they were out of scallops so we might just have to go back before we leave SF.
author: Alberta U.

description: Very good. We had to wait about 25 minutes for a table on a Sunday night, but everything we had was good. A lot of students. The check was around $100 for 2 orders of sushi, 2 orders of cold sake, 1 beer, 1 cucumber appetizer, a salad, 2 miso soups, and a tempura ice cream. The prices were reasonable but the sake was more than we should have spent.
author: mike b.

description: The sushi is very good here and your bound to make a friend or two. The atmosphere is fun and friendly and the food and drinks will not disappoint. Definate good times!
author: Lisa S.

description: Went here for a friend's birthday.  The place is very cozy, strongly suggest you make reservations ahead of time as the wait time is pretty long.  Food is really good but expect to dish out some serious duckets.
author: Hitesh B.

description:
The most chillest sushi place I've ever been to. It has a cool vibe- they play good house music and have cool art on the walls. 

Met up with some friends from Canada late at night and we were looking for a place to get sake bombs, which my friends have never tried (whaaat). This was one of the Japanese places that were open. They were busy, but we were able to get a table right away. Good food and good service.

Got drunk, ordered a Pokemon roll, and made new friends :^)
author: Cassie O.

description:
From the outside you may not want to come in because it looks kind of seedy. You go under the blue awning that hangs very low.  You descend down the steep stairs and take a look around at the "interesting" decor. But still you stay because it's walking distance from your home and you need sushi.

Pros: Fresh fish, interesting and tasty rolls (Jumping Unagi, Tiger-yum!). Organic ingredients. Friendly service. 

Cons: It is often quite warm inside and the music will remind you of your clubbing days (which you've been trying to forget). Sometimes slow service.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
Just like an izakaya on the outskirts of Shibuya. 

Friendly, bilingual service. Tasty food. And a nice eclectic mix of people. 

A little pricey, but worth it.
author: Madeline N.

description:
I love Ryoko's.  I've come here on many Friday nights after comedy shows at the nearby SF Comedy College and Clubhouse and even though it's expensive, it really hits the spot.

Ryoko's is open late, which is hard to find for SF restaurants, let alone Sushi joints.  And the fish is really good - I always get at least one hamachi and one big eye red tuna nigiri.  When the toro is available and not ridiculously expensive (this past Friday is was $19!!), it's an incredible experience in itself.

Yeah the techno music doesn't always do it for me, but I still like the atmosphere.  Service isn't bad, and the drinks are reasonably priced - I recommend the $10 bottles of nigori sake.  The free edamame is a nice touch, and the rolls are good and well-priced (except for that $20 Rainbow Roll, WTF).
author: Joseph N.

description:
decent quality. Slightly over priced. I ordered teriyaki chicken and roll of my choice. Both were good but overly priced. 

my friend ordered chirasu. what a rip off! they barely got any fish at all- and it was very small pieces. you can get full miso soup and appetizer and more for that price and have it be amazing. 

perhaps i am used to more ma and pa places that serve very fresh things. this seems more of a "pop" japanese- more focus on the atmosphere less on the food.
author: oth k.

description:
A dive sushi bar?
Coming in on a friday night come early (before 9) because the place was packed... there was literally a line of people waiting/sitting on the stairs about 15 deep when we left at 10.

The sushi was alright but wasn't as good as Sanraku up the street (a little bit cheaper here). My date had the side order of teri chicken, which I thought was going to be an actual "side" but turned out to be a full sized dish, which didnt taste half bad either..,

1 star for seating us right away
1 star for the talented DJ 
(yes there was a live dj that night... a first for a sushi place for me)
1 star for the food...
= not a bad place if you want a quick bite around union square
author: Brennan M.

description:
I specifically went here because a friend of mine recommended it.  (I figure, he's Japanese and eats a lot of sushi so he knows what he's talking about, right?)  This place is a dive, through and through.  We nearly walked right past it and we all thought, "I'm not so sure about this place."  It was completely empty when we arrived for dinner at 6:00pm.  Again, a little scary that it's so empty.  Plus, our server started off on the wrong foot.  My friend asked if they had any special drinks, and the server completely disappeared.  She came back about 15 minutes later to inform us that they do not have any specials.  I asked for a Long Beach and she didn't know what that was, so I had to explain it to her.  We're all looking at each other like, "This place might totally suck."  But it got better.

The rolls were fantastic.  They were different than any others I have tasted.  The Volcano Roll was incredible, as was the Jumping Tuna.  Many of these rolls used shiso leaves, which tastes like mint.  We had a few other rolls, but I don't remember their names as I had another Long Beach and started to get a little tipsy!
author: Emily N.

description: Definitely one of the best Sushi Restaurants I have ever had. Came here for a TV recording of a new show on FLN, called Midnight Munchies. Still received great service as the cameras were filming. Had the chef's choice, so they pretty much brought out everything on the from Japan menu on the wall. The quality of fish they used was excellent. Wasn't too fond of them bring out escargot, but it turned out to be pretty tasty. Seems like a great place to hang out and knock back a couple of drinks, or 10, with the low lighting lounge like atmosphere, full bar, and DJ.
author: Jerry T.

description: 3 and 1/2 stars, the sashimi was quite good but the sushi rolls were only ok. Tried the volcano roll which taste just as it sounds....peanut butter and rice, a little weird. There are definitely better sushi places in the mission and marina area. But good price and cute ambiance for being downtown.
author: Sunny C.

description:
I've been going to Ryoko's for many years and it's my favorite sushi place in SF.  I go there on dates to set an intimate mood and with large groups of friends to get stewey; the environment suits both. 
We kicked off my 21st birthday there 2 years ago and it was great.  

The steep stairs,  dim lights, blue walls and subtle jazz theme are unique and set Ryoko's ambiance apart from any other sushi spot that I know of.  The grand piano in the middle of the room hardly gets used, unless the DJ is set up atop it or I'm drunk enough to bust out with some "Night in Tunisia" or "Cantaloupe Island."

The Food is phenomenal.  The fish is always the freshest, and the sushi is always prepared and presented beautifully.  The tuna melts on your tongue like butter.  There are things that you can order that are not on the menu, just ask the waitresses if there are any "secret" rolls or dishes.  A great example is the flash fried tuna jalapeno roll.  Unbelievable.  They also have an amazing selection of Saki and other beverages; their bar is fully stocked.  

The service is awesome.  The worst is on busy nights, you can expect to wait up to 25 min for all of your rolls if you are in a large group, but i have never waited longer, and on average the food usually arrives in no longer than 15 min.  The waiters and waitresses are always friendly, knowledgeable and are never far, as the place is so small.  

Aside from the fact that it sometimes gets really hot in their, I can't find a thing about Ryoko's, or any other sushi spot in SF that would make me stop being a regular.  I love this place :-)
author: Dima K.

description: The girlfriend and I came downtown for some holiday shopping and spent a good several hours on our feet walking around and buying gifts for the friends and family, so naturally to rest our incredibly sore feet, we figured sushi and sake would be the perfect cure, but the major question was: "Where to go?" Being as spoiled as we have been with pretty amazing sushi, we had to turn to yelp to help us decide between some places to go. Ryoko was the top choice for us and seeing the amazing reviews, we had to try it out. We got there around peak dinner time (around 8pm) and didn't even have to wait more than 10-15 minutes. (Not bad for a really good sushi spot if you're willing to sit at the bar.) Their prices were a bit steeper than your average sushi restaurants for the dinner meals, but if you're sticking to rolls and sashimi for your dinner, then it's not too bad. The ingredients were so amazingly fresh and delicious that we wound up ordering more food after we were done and who doesn't love a good hot sake with your meal? The music was also really amazing too. Hard house, great sushi, and sake? We'll definitely be coming back here with friends!
author: Michael N.

description: This place form the look outside and the neighborhood really hide the remarkableness of this place.  We had dinner here with a group of business friends while attending GDC 2011.  The sushi was plentiful and tasty with each plate being more than we could finish.  The help is relaxed but professional.  It can get a bit crowded as you feel as if you are in the hull of an old schooner with the main room being in the basement.  I will be back as often as possible on my many trips to San Francisco.
author: john B.

description:
where do I begin? 
Service: Spectacular. Our waitress constantly came and cleared our dirty dishes, she asked us if we needed anything. My cousin was pregnant, so she relocated us at a table with back support.
Atmosphere: It was great. Busy. There was a dj. The walls are blue. I really dont care about the decor, but it's clean, that's all that matters. 
Food: My favorite. It was delicious!!! Well priced. Fresh sushi and sashimi, great selection. 

Put it this way, I'm not gonna get into a fancy essay. This place is the best sushi restaurant I've been to in the city. 

There, I said it.
author: Miss P.

description:
Ryoko's food is fresh and tasty. It's good and not expensive.
They are open late, that's great. However it can be pretty crowded.

There are two drawbacks. First the music is usually ridiculous. However yesterday somebody played a couple songs on a piano. It was actually a great relief.

Second, It tends to be too loud. A Monday night is okey. A Saturday night would be a nightmare for a date.

This is a great place to have dinner with your friends.
author: Marc L.

description: A real hole in the wall. Open till 2 am I went late at night after picking up a friend from the airport. Didn't care for the sushi which had thickly sliced salmon chunks. But the wonton cheese appetizers were really good.
author: Rimi A.

description: Great sushi...   although we sat very close to our neighboring table.
author: Lisa M.

description:
the atmosphere is fantastic. nice staff, cool music, shweet vibe. everything tasted really good.

we all got sick. boo!
author: Bad Ass Chic K.

description:
So disappointed!
I wanted ti try a new Japanese restaurant in SF!
I should not and go to my "canteen".
Food is not good.
Service is very slow.
An very expensive.

I suggest Sakana and Post @ Taylor, few steps for these place, which is much better!
author: Ana R.

description:
A great atmosphere , with a great selection of Japanese based dishes and even with the restaurant's slightly over priced sushi, you cant help noticing it does not matter because of the wonderful WONDERFUL staff. 
There is even a piano, which you can play to impress any girl.
Overall, the quality is 5/5, employees 100/5, and food is 5/5, but prices not so much

Ryoko is situated in a cave-like den where you feel like a ninja in Batman's secret cave and they take requests, too. 

P.s my profile pic is at Ryoko(Me with a Ryoko Waitress)
author: Jimmy K.

description:
So it's a little stuffy in there, but hey it's one of those unique hang out spots that you'd want to go with your friends on a Friday and/or Saturday night. If you're lucky you might experience a live band or a DJ.  

Pokemon roll rules!
author: Lily T.

description:
2.20.07
10:30PM

I come here a lot...i mean... A LOT.  Arguably the BEST Japanese food in The City....but it's not for everyone.  I personally come here for the food (sometimes just to get hammered) since their booze menu is quite limited...and EXPENSIVE.  $10 Patron shots, $8 Large Saps, etc, etc, etc.  They have a couple wines by the glass (house red/white), sochu, and sake.  

To the fact of the matter: if you like izakaya style Japanese food, EAT HERE.  

Eat this stuff: the GYOZA (when they have it = the best), iidako (fried octopus), karaage (friend chicken), ika maruyaki (whole grilled squid), beef oroshi (beef tataki with drated radish), & Kentucky Roll (AWESOME)....just to name my personal favs.  They also feature nightly sushi specials which you should definately try....fresh.

The downside?  The place can become a cluster fuck...and feel as if the blue walls are closing in on you....i could have sworn they have on a couple of occasions.  

Fianl thoughts:  AWESOME DJ spinning house on Friday nights and it's open until 2am....but it's definately a goat show!!
author: William R.

description:
Def not a typical sushi spot. The place is tiny, service is mediocre, and it's not super clean. 

You come here, only if it's late at night, and you're craving sushi. 

The end
author: Charles K.

description:
I went here because a co-worker told me it was the "BEST SUSHI EVER".

Well, she was right about that.  And for someone who has lived in Japan and got to taste the best of the best over there... I have to say that this is the best and most authentic tasting (i.e. tastes like you'd be eating it in JAPAN) sushi I have ever found in San Francisco yet.

However, there are some downers - I am NOT giving this a 3 star because of the sushi, no way (their appetizers are pretty "Japanese" too, i.e. not typical at every other ho-hum Japanese restaurant).

It's the atmosphere.

It ruins any kind of Japanese experience you'd have.  Maybe I am biased because I chose this place for a first date (and a blind one at that!).  DO NOT HAVE YOUR FIRST DATE HERE!

This is a place to hang out with friends, a boyfriend/girlfriend, or just have a drink and eat by yourself.  Not intimate AT ALL.

Sure it's dark, and there's a piano smack in the middle (but it's a bad choice, takes up too much space, and isn't played).  But the music isn't suitable (enjoyable in other environments), and unless you are lucky enough to get a table by a wall, you are too close to other people's tables, and lord help you if you are sitting next to the loudest talker in the place (unfortunately it did happen to me...)

I also got a crappy table crammed next to the piano as well the second time I went.

Next time I'm going, it's sitting at the bar.  You get more attention from the sushi chefs and you aren't feeling confined by the almost claustrophobic space that the tables and chairs (and piano) make.
author: Kitty O.

description:
Man, I dig the rap and general music selection in this hidden away gem of a sushi place.  A recommendation from a friend who lives in the tenderloin, this is his sushi place.

Great rolls.  The salmon skin roll had a fabulous crunch and toasty-ness I dig, along w/ the superbly crunchy cucumber.  They cut it fresh, and the rice to other ingredient ratio is spot on.

Blue Fin Tuna special just blew us away.  Fresh sushi at a decent price.  The spicy roll was a nice balance of spicy.  It did not overpower the taste unlike some other sushi places do.

Wait staff was super attentive.  Weird ambiance, though not necessarily bad, but it's like a cavernous cave dwelling but overall the music and food is great.  Looks definitely like a hang out spot for the after hours.  We'll go back to try the other stuff, for sure.
author: Mary Ann K.

description:
Not the greatest sushi, but fantastic/authentic atmosphere. Remined me of a few dark, late night fun places in Tokyo.Very good in house D..J, full bar, open late and the owner is this hilarious old  battleaxe that sits at the bar,gets very boozy ,and barks orders at everyone...A serious character..I really wanted to knock back a few rounds with her and chew the fat. Next time perhaps.....

In short, go here for a late night bite and a good time, go to Kiss seafood for serious sushi.
author: Tim E.

description:
First Japanese restaurant where a DJ spins cool downtempo records!!!

Granted, yes it is a bit expensive, but if you're on vacation and you feel a bit spendy, this is the place to go. The ambiance is great- it's very cozy, intimate, warm. It'd be a perfect place for a date, or a girls night out in the city with a few shots of sake and some sushi. 

I got the following food: Pokemon, spicy salmon rolls, California roll, dragon roll, donkatsu. Now, the donkatsu here (sauce especially) is one of the BEST donkatsu I have ever had. I could tell they probably replace the oil for the deep frying machine frequently, for it was very crisp and refreshing. The sauce was also very fresh and flavorful. 

Pokemon roll has mango + Salmon, and before you bust out with the "EWWWW", you HAVE to try this dish. It's absolutely delicious. The service was great, we were recommended some great dish, they came frequently to check up on us. I will definitely definitely go there again/ recommend this place to many many people that roll by the great city of SF.
author: Mihae J.

description: The sushi here is excellent, super-fresh and super-tasty. Besides the menu, check out daily dishes from the whiteboard. White tuna is yummy, so is monkfish liver. The waiter kept on forgetting to bring me salt I asked for the grilled green peppers, but that's ok.
author: Konstantin K.

description: Was recommended to me by the bartender at our hotel after we befriended him and he told us it was the spot locals always take their friends.  Took us a while to get a table but the food is amazing and I have never had fresher fish.
author: Brian S.

description:
ive been to ryokos a good number of times now and i have to admit, this place is pretty damn nice. this place throws out the theory that if you see more round eyes than slant eyes dining at a sushi joint, its not going to be good..... but perhaps theres such be a clause if the folks working the sushi bar and the majority of the waitstaff are japanese.

to the food. though i was i bit annoyed many of my favorite were not available my last visit, the stuff that was, wow. each bit was a little mini disneyland parade in my mouth.  hell, even their spicy tuna roll was good. i normally wouldnt eat that because its usually made with scraps (nothing wrong with scraps!) but many places use subpar stuff masked with sauce to hide the inferior fish. ryokos doesnt. they use nice long big pieces of tuna where you can taste the fish, but they accent it with some heat. 

will i be back? im already thinking about going tonight! i think ill order about five orders of the sweet shrimp and just gorge out when the fried heads come out....
author: Euge L.

description: I walked up here from my hotel.  While there were quite a few people waiting, I was lucky to be by myself and they had exactly one seat open at the bar.  This place is busy!  The guys were busy as could be behind the sushi bar and never seemed to slow down.  The waitress was very kind and apologetic that it was going to take a little time to get my food out.  Seeing how busy they were I wasn't surprised, and I also wasn't in a hurry so that didn't matter.  Once my food came out it was great!  The fish was fresh, seaweed was still crunchy and you could tell they had just finished rolling it (I'm pretty sure I watched them do it).  It was a fun atmosphere, a bit dark, but I think that is how they want it.  I watched a lot of people come in during the time I was there.  Sounds like they do take reservations since the woman warned me that I would need to be out by 8pm for a large reservation she had.  She wanted to be sure that I wasn't going to feel rushed out.  All in all the food was great, the servers were very polite and I look forward to finding an excuse to return.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Ryoko's is freaking great, I love the atmosphere, the DJ's often playing are cool, and the Jumping Unagi is fabulous. The service is good if not extremely personable. Free edamame when you sit down. Hell yeah.
author: Aubrey F.

description:
awesome sushi. fresh nigiri. cheap pitchers. great staff. open late.

lets make babies!
author: Ryan L.

description:
My rating is based on the most recent San Francisco Department of Public Health inspection score:

5 stars = very clean  (received SF DPH Symbol of Excellence)
4 stars = clean  (SF DPH score of 91-100)
3 stars = could: be cleaner  (SF DPH score of 86-90)
2 stars = not clean (SF DPH score of 81-85)
1 star = dirty  (SF DPH score 80 or below)

As of the date of this review, the most recent health inspection date and score per the SF DPH website were:

Date: Dec 2010
Score:  96

Received Symbol of Excellence

http://www.sfdph.org/
author: Cleanliness M.

description: This place was recommended by the concierge at our hotel. We were really in the mood for some good sushi and were hopeful we found the right place. Being from Chicago where there is a sushi restaurant on every block, we know our sushi and know good sushi. This was not it. The ambiance was great--it was busy and loud but the good kind of loud and overall had a great energy. We didn't have to wait long to be seated but once we were we wanted to leave.
