First of all, the restaurant floor is carpeted which I would not recommend to any restaurant owner. We were seated right next to the restroom and could tell, er I mean, smell. The smell of urine was so strong that we had to be moved. They were very gracious about moving us to another table. The portions were small and not the best. And they seemed to put mint in every roll.  Overall the quality of the rolls was ok at best. If you've never had great sushi before, this place is perfect but if you've been spoiled (like me) and know good sushi, keep looking because this is not the place for you. I'd give 4 stars for service but only 1star for food.
author: maggie r.

description:
w/ over 700 reviews lemme just say...

i think this is the new favorite late night sushi spot!  EVERYTHING ordered (deep fried oysters, karaage, agedashi tofu, wakame salad, miso soup, jumping tuna, & salmon skin hand roll) was very good.  either that or there was somethin hypnotic in that shochu & lime soda.  cant wait to go back.
author: Lady K.

description: OMGosh!! I finally found an AWESOME Sushi joint in FRISCO! Better yet, the restaurant is open till 2am? I know! WHAT?!?! and it's only down the street from Wyndham Canterbury (our Frisco destination). I live in SoCAL, and I'm so surprised to have discovered this place. My parents and I were out walking late one evening, ready to head back to our hotel. It's 12am! I saw this couple crossing the street to this off the wall Sushi joint, located in  a residential area. We decided to follow them and check it out for ourselves. You get to the door and you see stairs leading to a basement. Went it, walk down the stairs, got greeted by everyone, Music was ravin'! the place was packed at 12am. Luckily, we were seated at the sushi bar. My dad has never been to a real sushi restaurant, just all you can eat. It was a real treat for him since it was also his birthday! I ordered everything on the the board. Some Nigiri pieces were directly from Japan. Pricey but well worth it! Will definitely hit up this place again....
author: Irl A.

description: This place was alright.. A little to overpriced for the special roll that they gave. We ordered the sexy roll and tiger, we were in n out of that restaurant in a matter of 15 minutes. But thumbs up for staying open late..
author: Rosalyn T.

description: Great food and awesome staff. For unbelievable service sit at the sushi bar at the end (next to bar service area). Make sure you try the roll with jalapeño and peanut butter.
author: James E.

description:
very good japanese food.
Very nice atmosphere, like a bar, surprising for a japanese place.
Really great, with a DJ, nice music...
author: armelle p.

description:
Ryoko is great
My favorite sushi joint
Don't forget sake
author: Jenny S.

description:
Ryoko's or BUST!!!

I have to say this is one of my favorite places to go for sushi! The fish is always fresh, the wait staff is always on their toes, & everything on the menu is o so tasty! The decor is a bit weird with the crazy blue walls, but I guess it makes me feel closer to the ocean and the fish that I'm eating! :)

Late night DJ's, Sake, Sushi.... You can't go wrong here!
author: James E.

description:
My first favorite sushi bar!  I used to live three/four blocks from this place and it had an effect on my bank account!

The first time I went there...I went too early.

The owners were there, preparing catering orders.  They were very polite and even gave me two free orders of sushi.  They are so nice and cool.  I see them almost every time I'm in there. 

The hours are great, open late!  You often see other service industry people in there.  

My favorites:  the jumping unagi, the volcano roll, the pokemon, the california roll (which is great for those who have friends that don't like to experiment with sushi because it's the best CA roll ever.)  all with a big glass of plum wine! :D  Also, don't expect lip-glued-to-butt-cheek service here.  If you want something, you'll have to wave someone down for it!  If you're alone, pay attention to the credit card usage restrictions that are posted at the bar.  Great music too.
author: Cat A.

description:
My first visit here was uneventful. My friend who recommended the place raved about how great and quirky it was, and talked about an Elvis-like owner who played the piano (still waiting to see this person). Regardless, I remained ho-hum. It wasn't like it was terrible, it was just that I was expecting a lot more.

My second trip, 3 years later, was surprisingly good. This time, I spent time sifting through the very original and unique menu, and trying all the interesting things you can't find at a run-of-the-mill sushi joint. One roll in particular had peanut butter--weird but well-balanced in a way I would not have expected. We tried all the specials and were impressed (and often surprised), by what came out.

My third visit--on a Friday night at 10pm--was excrutiating. I expected that it would be busier, and that we would have to wait, but from getting seated (this in itself was an ordeal), to getting our food, I estimate we were there almost 2 hrs before finally eating our appetizers. If you are wanting a clubby atmosphere with tons of loud, drunk, overly skanky, and obnoxious people, then seems like this is the best time to visit.

It is a seemingly hole-in-the wall place, hidden in the basement off a busy street, but inside, the atmosphere reminds me of what you'd expect to find at a locals only NYC restaurant. The best thing about this place is that it feels authentic--from the fresh food, to the 1970s jazz bar decor, to the people. But best of all--it's open LATE--like until 2am--which is when I suggest going--except on a weeknight when you are most likely to enjoy your meal.
author: Sabine S.

description: The atmospere and the sushi are both wonderful.  I get to San Francisco relatively often, and this is the most fun I have had with sushi, and darn good, fresh sushi at that.  Yes, it is "hip", but think Anthony Bourdain rather than tragically hipster.  The staff is wonderful at explaining the options.  Decor is eclectic and dark in a good way.  Not your "traditional" American sushi experience.
author: Leighton P.

description: Awesome food (must try the Jumping Tuna), great atmosphere, good prices.  What else do you need?
author: Dennis F.

description: Best sushi place in the whole city. Sexy roll is the bomb. I send guests from the hotel here all the time and they love it so much. I wish I could eat here all the time. I subtracted 1 star because the people who answer the phone arent friendly.
author: Gina S.

description: When Sanraku is closed I hit up Ryoko's for late night sushi.  They are open until 2 a.m.  You can't beat that.  Their tofu appetizer served warm is amazing.
author: Ikey S.

description: Ambience gets 1 star, waitstaff gets 4 & food gets a 3.  Crowded tables, lousy loud music and poor floorplan make it difficult to enjoy even the best of sushi.  The specials were the best.  Don't go for the 'jumping' rolls...awful mushy texture served with bottled dipping sauce.  Note to owners....the music stinks.
author: T C.

description: Hands down, the best sushi in SF. I always recommend it to visitors and locals alike. The best part is, they're open until 2am!
author: Lianne S.

description: Great sushi, great people, fun time over all. A good bang for your buck with some nice Japanese beers on tap. Friendly servers and a solid menu. I love the flying tuna!
author: Thomas C.

description: Great music and definitely try the roll with the peanut butter. Sooo good. Sashimi wasn't the freshest but was fine. Fun place for good sushi.
author: Kimberly L.

description: The live dj and ambiance of this place  makes for a great place for big groups to dinner together.  I had tons of fun sake bombing at this place with good friends.  Downside of the restaurant is the food in general...the sushi was mediocre and not that fresh.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Its somewhere around 1:15am.  As my friend and I were stumbling up the hill after several glasses of wine at The Hidden Vine and a couple cosmos at the Owl Tree, we found this totally awesome place.  

We paused in front of the door, and saw that not only was it a sushi restaurant, but that it was open until 2am!  I think we fell in love right there.  
I turn to my friend,
 
"Do you wanna get some sushi and sober up a little?". 

 "OK!"

This place has a cool atmosphere.  Kinda dark, hip, and comfy.

Oh, and the sushi was delicious.  I had the dragon roll and unagi and my friend had chicken teriyaki and this deep fried calfornia roll that was ohhhh so good.    I cleaned my plate, and then proceeded to help my friend clean hers.

The service was good.  Food was yummy.  And its open till 2AM!!!  Awesomeness.  

Is it a coincidence that this place is nestled in between two bars...I think not.   It's all part of the plan you see.  Get em drunk, then they'll get hungry and wonder around looking for somewhere to eat...and then aha!  Sushi till 2am!  It's perfect.  

I will be back here.
author: Jennifer S.

description: The ambiance is awesome! Was very busy on a Weds. night. The music was pretty good and set at a volume where you can enjoy it but still carry a conversation. We ordered about 4 rolls and that filled up 2 people. The sushi to me was just ok...my bf loved it. He still raves so we definitely will be back!
author: Chauanh D.

description:
I'll echo some earlier sentiments: the food is good, worth three stars, but the prices are crazy. I went with a group of 12 people and ended up paying over $40.

For less money, I can go to Nagano (which has four-star Sushi :-).
author: Paul S.

description:
I also didn't know the name of this place, even though I've been here quite a few times... I didn't wan't to know either. But I had to figure it out in order to yelp about it!

This is sushi heaven!! We only sit at the bar and never order rolls (we've overheard people being yelled at to sit at a table if they want them... awesome). We always leave it up to the chef and we are never disappointed... the sashimi here is like crack! I get a major buzz from it. 

Yes, the atmosphere is a little grungy and we walk out with lighter wallets, but it's worth it. Best sushi I've had in SF by far... plus they are open late.
author: Bethanne S.

description:
The fish is fresh and the recipes are well done to bring out the flavor without overpowering the fish. Ryoko's has been at their underground location for 30 years and they know how to make sushi!
There is usually some hip hop or electronic music, it's dark and the buzz is good. Everybody is friendly, it's loud, slightly raucous. It's fun.
Don't miss their Jumping Tuna roll, it's the best deep fried tuna roll in the city, I go there just for that and have middle of the night cravings in between. They cook it just right so it's crispy hot on the outside but the fish is still raw and serve it with a sweet and sour sauce that's just the right balance. You won't want to share it, get one each. My next favorite is Hot Tail, a delicately spicy yellowtail roll. 
Another bonus -- they're open late, seven days 6 pm to 2 am. Yes you can get great sushi after midnight!
author: Suzanne J.

description: Good authentic Japanese food... I like the atmosphere, although some say it's a little dark for their taste.  Little pricey, but worth it.
author: Peter N.

description:
I travel to SF every couple of months and always seem to end up at Ryoko's. Having lived in Japan for three years (Osaka and Tokyo), I appreciate the authenticity of the food and experience.

They're open late for unwinding and their sushi (try the deep fried), sake, and Japanese beer are a perfect combination to end the day.
author: Steve O.

description: Authentic charm and carefully crafted food
author: Travis N.

description:
Really tasty sushi and appetizers. This place has a distinct "cozy" feel....kind of like underground club meets sushi restaurant. The music on the weekends is pretty loud, so if you are not in the mood for a lively atmosphere, this is not your place. 

Overall great food with a fun vibe. The only significant downside is that it's frequently packed to the gills, so be prepared for a wait on the weekends.
author: J M.

description: Its official- everything on the menu at Ryoko's is amaze-deicious! You all know its open until 2am but if you get there around 6:30 you wont have to wait in the mile long line and the service is fast! Among the many things I love, the highlights are: Asparagus roll, Spicy salmon roll, Pikachu roll, soft shell crab appetizer, and CHICKEN KARAAGE!!! I cant wait to go back here again, its pricey but worth it!
author: M K.

description: This place definitely had a cool atmosphere. I'm giving this 4 stars because of that alone. The DJ was cool and played some good music which added to the vibe. The rolls were decent, I personally thought they could be more creative. There was one roll that really impressed me, it was the volcano roll which had peanut butter in it! ingenious!
author: Eric A.

description: Great atmosphere, great service, delicious food. AND they have a live DJ with some very interesting Japanese Pop playing. Not sure who was the DJ, but I really wanted to ask what tracks she was playing the whole time, shazam couldnt figure it out.
author: Truong N.

description: This place rocked as a late night dinner choice this past Friday. Sushi delicious, staff attentive, solid DJ. I'm a fan and def recommend. Will be back, for sure.
author: Elle N M.

description: Ryoko's is a nice and hip place that plays house music all day long. Enjoy food and alcohol anytime during the day with club music in the background! I went on a Sat. night around 9pm, the wait was quite long. But we got seated in the private room in the back, so I was quite happy. The food was ok, we had quite a few rolls and appetizers. The sea weed salad and edemame are just average. chicken karaage was good. The big mama roll and the volcano roll were somewhat a disappointment. Traditional rolls such as the spicy tuna and salmon are above average though. We also ordered wild yellow tail as nigiri pieces, they were delicious! so try that if they still have it. over all, a nice hang out spot, decently good food.
author: Ruilin X.

description: Favorite sushi place. So fresh, reasonably priced, and their "jumping" (read: fried) rolls are AMAZING. Also, free edamame. It can get pretty busy on weekend nights; I prefer being there right when it opens on a weekday. It's way quieter then also. The atmosphere is beautiful as well. I take all my friends who come out here to visit me to Ryoko's. Even my grandmother who was afraid of sushi loved it.
author: Miranda M.

description: I have never bobbed my head to the dance groove so much while stuffing my face so fast.  Upbeat vibe grabs you as you walk down into the world of Ryoko.  Apt place for romance with sig. other, a bite with a bro, or even a quick solo meal/drink at the bar.  Very good sushi
author: william b.

description:
I've been going here for over 4 years, and I always get a warm welcome as I'm walking down those steps!  I love Japanese food (it'd probably be my last meal on earth), and been to dozens of Japanese restaurants, and they still don't compare to Ryoko's.  They've been running this place for over 20 years...now that says a lot--they are doing something right!  I'm like a vampire, so my sis and I (and now I take my boyfriend!) would drive out there just to get a late night snack  :-)   It's definitely way healthier than going to Denny's.

The reason why I keep eating there is simple:  good sushi!  The gyoza is made from scratch!  My favorites:  soft shell crab, gyoza, agedashi tofu, steamed clams in sake broth, shiro maguro, spicy tuna handroll, volcano roll, tiger roll, dragon roll, catepillar roll...just to name a few...

I don't know, I guess it's a special place for me...it always seems like everyone I take with me there, we'd always have a good time, despite that weird DJ mixing on top of a baby grand piano...heh heh...geez, I've even took my mom here!
author: tiffany m.

description: Not a traditional sushi place by any stretch of the imagination, but always good. I always have fun when I come here, and the food is always good. The sushi chefs are tons of fun to talk to, and the sexy roll is great. and they are open till 2 am on the weekends. Get out of Slide or ruby skye a little early and get some sushi before you go home. You will not regret it.
author: Thomas E.

description: I was pretty disappointed when I took someone from out of town here Saturday night. Last time I came here I was very impressed with the place, but this time the menu seemed limited and the rolls kinda weird. A roll with peanut butter? The seaweed salad with lettuce? Ugh. What a bad rep I gave to SF sushi.
author: Polina S.

description:
Ok, so I hit this spot before I went out to the exotic erotic ball and this was by far the BEST sushi experience I have ever had!!!!

I am a huge Sushi junkie and this spot gets a 10 out of 10.

The music really made it a unique experience for me, great DJ on sat nites.

The fish was fresh, as it should be, and well prepared. The service was fun and vibrant and the decor was just right, to say the least.

The house Sake was very satisfying and I can't wait to go back.
author: Nick O.

description:
ambiance - hip
food - great. we ordered many dishes, and they were all so tasty. i highly recommend the sake and saba sushi.. the yaki onigiri is so tasty. the rolls are all so good too. really you can't go wrong with anything you order from here.
the restaurant is open til 2am! it's probably a good idea to make a reservation because it gets busy.
author: Jenn O.

description:
Not the prettiest looking sushi in town but damn tasty.  

Fresh fish = Great sushi

Unfortunately it's seeming hard to find 'pretty' without 'pretention'.  

Thinking about it - maybe that not only applies to sushi...
author: Tanya Q.

description:
The sushi, service, and service are all fantastic here. Their prices are definitely reasonable and they have a large variety of sushi to choose from.

Open until 2 am, this is definitely a place to hang out with friends during dinner or late night.
author: Carlo V.

description: The sushi is delicious. Recommended. I got there right when they opened at 5:30, and I was greeted and taken care of very quickly. It took a little while for my order to arrive, but it was worth the wait. However, once I was finished it took the waitress at least ten minutes to bring me a check, and then at least 10 more minutes to come back and see if anyone brought the check back to me. It began to get frustrating as I waited longer and longer. But overall, recommended. Get there early.
author: R N.

description: The place is underground, had a nice vibe, good food and good music. We ordered the seaweed salad, Tiger roll, cheese sticks and potato croquettes, the bill turned out to be $26. Its open till 2am and a good late night spot for sushi and drinks. I have no idea what type of cheese or sauce it was but the cheese sticks were delicious, but they were kind of small and I'm not sure it was worth $5 for cheese, wonton wrappers and sauce.
author: Alison L.

description: fresh amazing sushi!! I haven't been in about a month and Im over due for some checkerboard sushi!!!
author: Marissa E.

description: I came here tonight with three friends. We were told that the wait would be about 30-40 minutes...TWO hours later we were finally seated at the bar. Our order of edamame came quickly enough, but it was just smothered in salt. I love salt, but even for me the amount of salt on there was a little overkill. I ordered a simple vegetable roll and an order of inari. Despite my order being the simplest, it came out way after my friend's food. The rice in my food was way too vinegary, and it left the most unpleasant taste in my mouth that lingered long after I left the restaurant. I am Japanese, and the one thing I can not stand in a Japanese restaurant is when they can't even do rice properly. Rice is the backbone of Japanese food; I ate rice at every meal growing up. Rice is the simplest thing to make, so to mess up rice so tremendously is appalling. On top of the bad food was the bad club music playing loudly and the fact that I was constantly getting bumped by people walking by. We also had to ask for a refill for our water, which is my friend's biggest pet peeve. At a good restaurant, your water glass should automatically get refilled without asking (I have never had to ask for water at Sakana). I was going to originally give this restaurant two stars since the service wasn't good, but it wasn't awful; until I found out that when my friend mentioned the wait time to the hostess, instead of apologizing to him, she told him that he should know better since it was a weekend! My past experiences here have always been mediocre, but this time it just pushed me over the edge, and the fact that my stomach is still uneasy from the food isn't helping. So thank you Ryoko's for reminding me why I never come here and why I should always eat at Sakana right down the street instead. Seriously, go to Sakana where they have the best server in the city, the food is cheap and very good, and the atmosphere is pleasant.
author: Melissa A.

description: It looks like a hole-in-a-wall joint - something that you could call a secret - but once you're actually sitting down and enjoying your meal, the hole-in-a-wall feeling disappears and you realize that everyone in the city knows about this place. This is the place to be if you're into late-night, good-quality sushi in an upbeat atmosphere. Loud music and lots of people. On the pricey side, but that's sushi for you. (I prefer Korean-owned sushi restaurants though - bigger portion, cheaper, and closes just as late.)
author: Jonas T.

description:
food - 3.5 stars
service - 2 stars

As far as food, Ryoko's has the good, the bad, and the so-so.
Good - the "jumping" rolls, pokemon, spicy yellowtail, grilled rice balls
Bad - The otoro was super-sinewy/gristly...like, I-couldn't-chew-through-parts-of-it sinewy.  It tasted good, but I've had plenty of better otoro other places at comparable prices. Other nigiri is hit or miss.

The service is super-friendly, but you have to wait FOREVER for your food and it never comes out in any logical order, nor with any regular time interval between them.  Depending on the night, you may also have to wait FOREVER for you waitress to even take your order.  I also caution against sitting in the back "lounge" room.  I'm short, and even for me, the tables are too low compared with the height of the stools.  My knees kept hitting the table.  I'd imagine for people of average height, their shins would get in the way instead.  The wait can also be long.  I think people here tend to linger more, since it's more of a bar/sushi restaurant.

In a nutshell, I go to Ryoko's when I'm specifically craving a specific ROLL (not nigiri or sashimi) and only at certain times, because I'm not always certain it's worth the long wait.
author: fi l.

description: This place is more known for their sashimi instead of rolls; their rolls are pretty simple and typical (dragon, caterpillar, etc). Pretty pricey I might add. My b/f and I ate a bunch of sashimi, but it was so hard to tell the fish quality. For some reason, they top each sashimi with some kind of teriyaki or sweet sauce. That really takes away the original flavor of the fish. Therefore, the experience was a little bit disappointing. However, great ambiance.
author: Nhung T.

description: The food was delicious.  Sushi was all exquisitely prepared and the fish was fresh and tasty.  Loses two full stars because of the staff's incredibly annoying policy of yelling Japanese welcomes to the patrons.  I arrived at 6 PM sharp and our entire meal was punctuated with 4 employees simultaneously shouting at each and every person who walked through the door.
author: Carlin E.

description:
I have been here 4 times and have never had a bad experience.  There are hundreds of sushi places in the city and many choices, but it is a family run business and feels like a neighborhood hang out.  It is small and the wait can be daunting, but it is worth it.  We always sit at the sushi bar and the service is perfect.  Last night we sat next to the owner, a beautiful lady (her daughter looks just like her and works there) and very humble.  She told us she has owned the place for 26 years and in any town that is a feat, but in San Francisco, that is unreal.  
The music is hip hop and played on a Mac by a young lady.  My first trip I brought my 17 yr. old son, he loved it.  We sat next to a Japanese couple and they were amazed how much my son loved sushi.  They ordered for us and nothing we ate was on the menu, making it a unique experience.  I highly recommend this place if you are looking for a low key, fun place to enjoy an authentic meal!
author: JR R.

description: Despite the long wait time for food (we had a party of 13) and intense heat (random heatwave in the city & we were seated in an area without a fan), I would definitely come here again with a smaller group. We tried a ton of rolls & small plates -- particularly loved the Orange Delight (salmon, cucumber, avocado... other stuff...) & sake sashimi. I also like the house music & quirkiness of Ryoko's -- it's fun!
author: Miss H.

description: Fresh, flavorful and fun. Staff was working hard and friendly. They didn't sacrifice the quality of food for how busy they were. We went there a little after 6pm and by 6:40p the line was out the door - a sign of a good place and it was. Don't worry you can order a drink on the steps while you wait and watch everyone enjoy themselves.You'll have a good time. Daily specials were listed above the sushi bar.
author: Tasha O.

description: Nice, trendy little basement sushi joint. I've been here twice, and both times they've had a DJ playing some decent house electronic music, which really sets the mood. Friendly staff (they all say hello and goodbye to people as they are coming and going) and decent prices on decent sushi. They tend to get a little busy, so it's really best if you go in a small group. Definitely worth checking out if you want to feel cooler than you ought to!
author: Adam D.

description: A Japanese restaurant with Japanese chefs. This place rocks my world. Homely, intimate joint open late nights. Really unique sushi rolls that won't disappoint. Order the pokemon roll and the peanut butter roll. Generous portions. Fresh fish. Decent prices. Small and loud with high energy music blaring. Not the best place for conversation. It's a "go-to" place for anyone in the neighborhood. Keeps you coming back for more.
author: Alex H.

description:
Checked it last night for dinner before heading out for a bit of holiday revelry. First time here, liked it. Definitely. The underground look and feel was great for a drizzly dark evening. The music was up, and so were the staff. Very friendly service with a comfortable vibe. It's cozy. No pretentious decor or clientele, just folks needing to get their sushi on. Good times.

Loved the Crunchy Crab and the Pokemon. Tasty and fresh.
author: Eric B.

description:
I would like to meet the genius who decided to put peanut butter in a roll with shrimp Jalepeno and cucumber. You are truly my hero! delicious!
I came here for girl's night last week and it was  a lot of fun. The have a DJ and are open pretty late.
author: butters m.

description:
Used to be a regular at this place and for some unknown reason took a long break.  Was happy to see the food hadn't changed but the speed of service has greatly improved.  Went in on a Friday night, got seated pretty quickly.   

Fish was fresh.   Sake recommendation was perfect. Had a couple of specials which we really enjoyed.
author: John C.

description:
i love this place.... the food is fresh and amazing.... the price is comparable to all sushi places or cheaper....  the servers could be better but definitely not horrible  

David G. is trippin-   sounds to me like someone trying to say i "know" the owner and then when he didnt get the service he thought he "deserved" he came here to talk
author: andrew h.

description: I live for sushi and let me tell you this is the best sushi place in the city. Good prices for incredible rolls. Later at night there can be a wait but its totally worth it. The hot tail roll is by far my favorite!
author: Sarah Y.

description: Nothing but great times had here. Love the atmosphere, and the food is fantastic, the tea terrific. The only reason I'm not rating Ryoko's with 5 stars, is because I cannot - as a real, Zen "fanatic" - endorse the consumption of alcohol and flesh of sentient beings. Otherwise: 5 stars! ; )
author: Jeanne M.

description: Not cheap. But you get what you pay for. Service was good. Seen some of the other posts about bad service but can't say I experienced the same. I came in at 12:30am on a Monday night. The food was wonderful. The music was just right. I am coming back.
author: Maybe Milan B.

description: This is an amazing place! Me and my girlfriend went in on a Sunday night after an amazing weekend in San Francisco and Napa Valley... We got absolutely everything we could have asked for and our bill, including a generous tip, was under 100 dollars. My favorite roll was the spicy tuna accompanied by a nice large Asahi. The Saki was very good as well... What intrigued me the most about this place besides the great food was the atmosphere itself; dim lit and warm, my type of place... Our waitress was very professional and made recommendations on the some food items that were excellent... I will definitely come back to this place next time I'm in the San Francisco area...
author: Miran T.

description: Anytime I think sushi, Ryoko's comes to mind.  I love the sushi here!  I like the variety and the quality.  I like that they fly in fish from Japan and I get to try something new along side my favorites.  After coming here twice, I think I'm a full blown addict.  Ryoko's can get crowded and a little loud, but it's all part of the ambiance.  It's trendy and open late.  It's on a basement level and very easy to miss.  I probably would have if my friend didn't bring me here!  They even make their own brew!
author: Lidiya B.

description:
I had been drifting through life aimlessly, pondering if I would ever come across another techno sushi bar like the ones I loved so dearly in Vancouver BC.  Just as I was beginning to think all hope was lost, I stumbled down some stairs and was led into the promised land.  Thank you Ryoko for letting me bring focus back into my life.  

The sushi here kicks ass!  My favs are the jumping unagi roll, and the caterpillar rolls.  DJ's on the weekends spin a good mix. I've only had slow service here once, and it was really busy.  Plus when you leave, everyone tells you goodnight.  It kinda makes you feel like Norm from Cheers (I have a feeling he wasn't much of a sake fan, though).
author: Jason L.

description:
I was referred here by my conceirge at the Westin. I have to admit I was a little shocked when I arrived and even thought about hitting the other place down the street. But I decided to go in and check it out.

I HAVE TO THANK THAT CONCEIRGE!

This was exactly what I was looking for! It was a cool neighborhood place that served some really great fish. If they have the SAKE TORO (Fatty Salmon) order it!

Also if you are worried that you don't think it is clean, take a look on the wall and see the 100 they scored from the inspectional services!

I sat at the bar and was entertained watching the sushi chef do his thing and how much care he took preparing each plate. I'll be back there again very soon!!!
author: Sean O.

description: Ryoko's is one of my favorites.  We went there last night for dinner and order three rolls, all of them were really good.  We liked the jumping tuna the best.
author: Sabrina S.

description: wow, my new love, fish really fresh & yummy!
author: Cali G.

description: The food is pretty good. The ambiance is great. The service is great. The price is just alright. 3 starz.
author: John F.

description: THE. BEST. SUSHI. IN. SAN. FRANCISCO.  Hands down.  Try the "jumping tuna" in addition to everything else you order.  I know that's not really authentic in the least, but it's wonderful too.
author: Mason G.

description: Came here for a birthday dinner... not a great place for a large group.  We were seated in the back and there weren't enough faux chair/stools so half the table had to use the wall ledge as a bench.  The service isn't that great either, not very attentive and the music is blaring house/rave music which doesn't give it that great of an atmosphere to dine in.  I had the chirashi which was just okay... i've had better and fresher fish elsewhere for probably half the price.
author: Kymberli C.

description: My new favorite Japanese restaurant. The line can be long but it's worth the wait. The fish is so fresh. The dish presentation is excellent. They have great music. I love sitting at the bar. Get them to make their best sushi. I trust them!
author: Do L.

description: This place is cool! Kinda dark and can be romantic if its quiet. Food is good, and service is great! Very very nice people! Worth checking out!
author: Chasity C.

description: Ryoko's is a great neighborhood sushi bar.  The fact that the sushi chefs greet you happily as you make your way down the stairs makes up for its dark, underground environment--although that's part of the allure, too.  I ordered okra tempura, pot stickers, yellowtail, and deep fried california rolls.  Everything was fine.  I particularly liked the pot stickers.  I also really like that their cheap house wines are good.  The service is a bit scattered since the waitresses barely speak english and someone keeps coming around asking if you need anything even though you ordered something two seconds ago.
author: catherine g.

description: I love sushi and used to go here maybe every week!  First couple of experiences were great we would order alot of food and service was great... but then being that we were regulars,and new workers... we  slowly noticed that they forget to bring out some of our orders, forget to give us water,  and we always had to ask for refills or check if our other orders were on its way... forgetting to put some orders in... so we just cancelled it and ever since then never went back:(
author: Shirl C.

description: Subterranean dining is awesome. Sure you can complain about the quality of the fish, or the unskilled cuts. Or the decor being uninteresting, weird and a unpleasing shade of blue. Lament about how the nikujaga has pork instead of beef. But I'll tell ya what, beotches. I'll be merrily stuffing my face with their sushi at 1:30 in the morning, and the picky and pretentious, well, they'll just remain hungry. Don't be dissuaded.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
This is a good solution when Sakana (xoxo) is closed on a late Sunday. 
I kind of feel dirty going (literally) underground right across the street from my num. 1 sushi spot, but hey, if I'm craving sushi and my love cannot deliver, I still gotta get mine, ya heard?

The food has never wowed me and is kind of pricey, but it does offer a larger menu with relatively better fare than other sushi restaurants in the area. (Except Sakana, did I mention Sakana?)

Ryoko's seems like that popular 'come to be seen' spot in New York with its set up, low lighting and slightly gimmicky vibe. 
It also seems to have some lesbian undertones based on their paintings. 

ARIGATOU GOZAIMASU!!!!
author: A W.

description: Late night sushi till 2am, a full bar, plus great customer service!  Ryoko's you complete me!  =)
author: Abraham E.

description: Honestly, I don't understand all the positive reviews on this place. I was there last night (Sat) and it was indeed very busy. For all the tables in the restaurant (its not as small as it initially appears) there were 2 staffers, the crazy owner woman and a waitress. One of  our appetizers was forgotten, it took 30 minutes to order, and maybe another 30 before getting any food. Prices were odd, some rolls were cheap while others were over-priced (Spider Roll is $18). The place is a dive, my chair actually broke during dinner and I had to sit crooked. They had a live DJ spinning, setup on the top of a grand piano. The boy had bad house and 80s going at an ear splitting level. The sushi itself was odd, the ingredients were of high quality but the preparation/presentation was strange. Rolls had the fish laid on top, also the cuts weren't very skillful, i.e. clean. I'm a big fan of any fantastic mom and pop dive, but this place certainly doesn't fall into that category.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
the best place to sit for a party of 6+ is the second room to the back because there is a strong ass fan you can sit right next to (esp. on crazy hot nights like it was on Sat) and being that it is somewhat removed from the rest of the space, you can hear eachother talk with ease, but still allow for some spectatin' of others.

i hate to sound like a f*ckin broken-record...
but dan v is my go-to japo dining homie.

experience was always incredible for me here, but again i tried at least three dishes that seemed to be off-menu specialties and i got to eat some of atsushi's killer eats.

aaron!  great work on making a lasting impression by keeping the door unlocked so judy can walk in on you while you are whizzing...classy mofo!

great vibe, dope beats from the dj and goddammit we had some hawt chix eating with us!!!!  YATTA!
author: omar b.

description: The bloom is off the rose. My last two visits to Ryoko's were sub-par. I sense a case of "resting on one's laurels"  with a decrease in quality and overall vibe. The fish wasn't up to the standard I've had in the past and the room just felt murky, unclean and unappetizing. Ryoko's needs to bust out the dust buster and step it up a notch.
author: wendella a.

description:
Joy loves SUSHI!
The Brownie walked me to this place about a year ago after her friends kept coming here as a late night hangover place-they stay open late! To tell you the truth I keep coming back and getting the same feeling of deja vu-of decadence, naughtiness, and sequins. Maybe I was a flapper in a past life.
The front entrance feels like a speakeasy that could possibly had a gorilla protecting the front door during the DRY Prohibition days,
But when you make it down the stairs, you are transported to Japan and oh boy! Ipai! The Kirin and Sapporo runs freely. This is definitely a WET bar. There is a large bar that greets you and the seating is interesting, like my favorite seat is the Mob Boss seat which is in the middle and next to the wall. A good place for an intimate meeting, eating some great sushi rolls of varying flavors, intensities, textures for the epicuriously inclined, with tea, beer, or whatever else your fruity heart desires. My favorites are the tempura shrimp rolls, a good size portion of edamame. The one think I'd skip is their gyoza. Everything else is open season. The waiters are pretty chill and the music is good. I'd say this is one of my favorite sushi joints. Ryoko is to go with friends you give a shhh about and want some place kind of different, speakeasy like, like it's a dirty little secret. My other favorite is Ten Ichi-the place I'd bring my parents. When you go to Ryoko's just don't forget your pinky ring.
author: J A.

description: Definitely a solid sushi place, that's pretty reasonably priced. It's got a nice atmosphere with the piano DJ booth, but it's not overdone or too loungy. I don't trust really loungy sushi restaurants. We've never been disappointed by a sushi dish. The Ryoko salad is really good, too.
author: Laura A.

description: Eh. I guess I was expecting this place to wow my socks off based on a few other reviews (Yelp and non-Yelp). It was alriight. The food was decent and affordable, but I've definitely had better sushi in the city (Tsunami on Fulton - take a bow). However, the Sunday night soundtrack was off the charts - 6 stars for that. If you're in the hood and want some sushi in a pretty unique (read: funky/divey) atmosphere, this is your joint. But probably not worth a special trip.
author: Kate S.

description: I feel kinda bad giving Ryoko's 2 stars, but I guess it balances out the excessive number of reviews with 4+. On the good side the place was interesting in an underground divey sorta way, and the staff was really nice. Unfortunately the fish was far from fresh and of poor quality, and the miso soup tasted like it was made from instant soup powder. With the number of sushi places in the city I doubt I'd go back to Ryoko's. Sorry!
author: Will A.

description: Ryoko's serves good (but not great) sushi in an energetic club-like environment.  The subterranean restaurant was loud and crowded on a Friday night, but I suppose that's a good sign.  I would say that most of the patrons were Asian and in their twenties.  For what it's worth, my male companions seemed to enjoy the eye candy.  Anyway, if I'm ever craving sushi past midnight, I will likely head to Ryoko's.
author: Grace W.

description: Very fresh sushi, unpretentious crowd, tucked away in what used to be an old bar. They have a piano player on some nights.
author: Nish N.

description: Ryoko is a cute, underground-type of dive with a cool scene and pretty people to see. It's atmosphere includes fanciful decor and a nice sized sushi bar. Unfortunately, we had to grab second best at a table in a corner. I ordered the usual sashimi, nigiri and a special roll which was a delight. When the waitress placed my sushi tray in front of me, I was impressed to see the fish slices were cut generously thick. The fish is fresh and the sushi rice is sweet. This is not the best sushi I've had in the bay area, but it comes pretty close. If you're looking for a two-for-once place with good drinks and food, check out Ryoko's.
author: Penny K.

description:
I've been here twice and had sushi both times and was disappointed both times.

The fish was average at best, but the price was completely unjustified for what I was getting.

For what they're charging, it's better to go to, say, Ino.
author: Derek D.

description: Perhaps the best sushi in the city now that my beloved Kansai in Japantown has vanished.  Wonderful variety of well executed rolls and nigiri/sashimi.  Good sake selection.  Not a great wine selection however.  The only drawback about this place is the ambience.  It appears to be a former nightclub, the layout of the tables is awkward and the lighting is blue and lots of gaudy mirrors everywhere.  Oh well, maybe just try to look at your food while you are there.
author: Ash T.

description: LOVE this spot. Very unique. If you're looking for a low-light, chill place with a dive bar atmosphere to enjoy sushi and other Japanese dishes and cocktails, this is perfect! I've never sat in the back, but have really enjoyed the bar and front room - especially when there's a DJ. Chances are there will be a wait, but push your way down the stairs and get your name on the clipboard. :-) I love to order the nigori (unfiltered / served cold) sake here because they have bottles from Japan. Most places only carry the Berkeley variety (not that there's anything wrong with that!).
author: Jessica M.

description: I love that it is open late, sometimes you need a spot that's open past 11. The first time I ate there we got a great spot in the front of the restaurant. The second time we got taken to the very end of the restaurant. It was super hot, and the table was a coffee table and the stools are the same height as the table, it made me want to sit on the floor. I'm alright with chopsticks so it wasn't a real big deal for me but a couple of my friends were using plates under their chopsticks in case they dropped the sushi on the long trip to their mouth. It was fun but I would prefer cusions on the floor or a normal table. I also felt it was a bit dark, I couldn't really see my food. We had the 49er, golden gate, and spicy tuna. Our favorite was the 49er. The fish is good quality. I wanted to give this place a 3.5 but no half marks so 3 it is because of comfort and service wasn't that great, fairly slow. We ordered mochi at the end and it was stale, when we told them they looked at us like we were crazy, we had to ask the waitress to try one. They wouldn't take the mochi off the bill instead brought us a different flavour that wasn't stale. We also had the imported unfiltered cold sake, very good! All in all if it's late and I can't go to tataki I will come again.
author: stephanie w.

description:
What a difference, not sure if it is the place or me but I've become quite fond of late despite the high prices and years of scorn.  The fish can be very good and the service vibe has improved.  It's gives off a comfortable but hip and funky neighborhood feel all the way with the full menu until 2AM every night.  The DJ is intense and good.  Staff has been quite friendly.  The rolls are kind of boring and tend to the non-fraw fish.  Nigiri, though limited on the regular stuff, always has a intriguing list of specials - all the way from fresh octopus to otoro for $18.  There are quite a few appetizer dishes that are not exactly comfort food but are not the common sushi bar fare either - four kinds of korokke, a rice and dashi soup, tuna natto, fried smelts, a very nice tako wakame.  The sushi chefs actually assemble some of these even though they aren't sushi so you get a careful, fancy presentation.  Which actually makes them taste better.  That's what shines here, the appetizers.

== Old review - 2 stars ==

Late on a weeknight and the place felt it. . . this cramped basement hideaway had a rock star after-the-party vibe going, a nice turnout but not crowded. 

There seemed to be a lot of politics going on behind the counter, sour looks from the waitstaff, not to mention serve-yourself drinking, gum chewing, and eating in front of patrons.  The sushi chef took a long time to do 2 pieces of nigiri and a hand roll, slow in the hand compared to what I'm used to seeing, and some slow talk with other diners.

The atmosphere is cozy downtown neighborhood speakeasy.  A grand piano, some nooks, a staircase leading up to nowhere.  Dark, no windows.  People don't come here to love the fish, they come to eat it.   A noisy time with friends. All that would be forgivable, fine, perfect -- very New York -- if it all came together.  But I've been here several times and it always seems to fall apart for me, late hour and the night drags, especially because of high prices for low to middling quality food, atmosphere, and service.
author: Gil S.

description: wow!  great place, but you definitely need to sit at the bar to get the full experience!  I went with a "chef's choice" plate and was not disappointed!
author: Mike G.

description: Very authentic Japanese izakaya (late night restaurant/drinking place) in an unassuming location. The fish is seriously fresh. It doesn't even need to be dressed up in rice, seaweed or soy sauce. It's just the real stuff. The restaurant is intimate and a little funky; the piano adds a lounge feeling to the space. Ryoko is a little pricey for me, so I rarely go here for a full dinner. It's the perfect place to end up late at night to enjoy some sushi and sake. It transports me to middle of the night Tokyo.
author: Yumi T.

description: Sigh...it's just a sad fact that any mid-priced sushi place in SF is going to be far and away better than any mid-priced place in New York.  Minus a star because the decor could use a bit of sprucing, but the sushi was tasty, fresh, and plentiful.  Frankly I'm surprised there's anything left there because it seemed like we ordered 12 of everything.  All the rolls I sampled were absolutely delicious, service was snappy and friendly, and my chirashi (the true test of any good sushi place) was fresh and yummy.  The sake flowed and rolls kept coming and we were a bunch of happy Yelpers.  I'd come back here anytime.
author: Sam P.

description: Was not a fan on a recent stop, if you are looking for Sushi avoid this place, its all about rolls and while some are different from your average sushi joint, none were really all that good. Might be a good place for a drink, but I would not eat here again.
author: C S.

description: Very good sushi. Fun, funky atmosphere. Great staff, service. Not sure I'd call it $$. More like $$$, but worth it
author: Saul E.

description: I like this place a lot just because they open till 2am again, plus the environment is cozy and packed. It is hard to find parking on weekends but it is in downtown so expect that. Price is a bit high but where can you find good deals on late night sushi tho. I think the best thing here is the pot stickers. they are superrr good, and i think its house made, not the package ones like all other Japanese restaurant. Totally recommended for some late night sake sushi date. : )
author: Sandy L.

description:
I must edit my review because circumstances have changed.  This used to be a charming, not-very-trafficked sushi joint.  In the last few months, the place is crawling with Marina yuppie scum who are taking a break from styling their hair or putting on a spaghetti strap top to go get sushi.  Granted, they have good taste, but the influx of Marina idiots has been disheartening to say the least.  Please Ryoko's, leave this trash at the door.

I love this joint.  The food is above average, but the ambiance is pretty dope.  The service is sometimes spotty but the girls at the bar are usually friendly.  The rolls are mad creative:  shrimp tempura, roe, deep fried jalepeno and peanut butter.  Who puts peanut butter in a roll?  Maybe I'm a sushi novice, but I thought it was creative, and more importantly, it worked.  The nigiri is fantastic and always fresh.  The toro is a great great piece of fish.  

But, the ambiance is what makes this place great. It's an underground spot, with blue walls and a DJ.  It's very unassuming.  When I was single, I thought this place to be a great place to weed out a girl.  If she was into it, she would work for me.  If she thought it was below her or not her style, it was a quick dinner and she was out the door.  Now that I'm in the best relationship of my life with the girl of my dreams, it's no surprise she's a ryoko's fan as well.

P.S.  They once had a depeche mode night.  hotness.
author: Jerry T.

description:
Very reasonably priced, good fast service and excellent Sake...three great things that make a good experience.

The Sushi was very good and the waitress was honest with her recommendations.  Will definitely be coming back.
author: Matt B.

description: Cool art, basement hipness, totally Japanese owned and operated. Comped edamame and miso soup with my cherashi. A bit slow and picey but worth it.
author: Greg B.

description: why is this place 4 stars?   really?!   selection of interesting fish 4 but quality of those fish 3.   it is okayyyyy...nothing special except maybe the beats
author: Rob C.

description:
i'd give it four stars just for staying open late but read on.  

i'm still not on sf dining time even after moving from nyc over 2 years ago so i dig any place that serves late.  my pet peeve is when the kitchen closes at 9:30 even though the place closes at 10.   well no worries here.

it's a little cozy for very big groups but laid back and fun if you are all going out and hankering for sushi in that neighborhood after a movie.  the food is ok, average and i do recommend you look at the specials.  you might have to circle the block for side street parking or else pony up for garage parking.
author: Anh V.

description:
first off, this place is not a "hole-in-the-wall" like i originally thought from the reviews.  it is in fact a dungeon (dirty, dark, in desperate need of remodeling) with tons and tons and tons of trendy people dining around.  also, you would think that because it's in the 'loin, it will be easy to find parking, but no.  street parking here is ridiculous.  (if i was homeless, i'll just start holding spots to sell.)

we got here at 11:30pm on a friday night, and there are 5 couples on the wait list in front of us.  we didn't get seated until after midnight, and there's no waiting area.  you wait on the stairs leading down to the dungeon and occasionally get kicked in the leg by glammed up girls passing you.

there is a live dj, who was blasting beats way too loud.  (well, it could be because i was shoved into the back of the bar right next to the speaker.)   but wtf, he was mixing fucking emo music with techno?  

anyways, it definitely gets one star because their caterpillar roll cost 20$.  completely wtf.  it wasn't like this roll was super huge or super good.  it was like any roll i can get for 7.95$.  this goes for all their rolls.  a simple tuna roll cost 7$, and it's tiny.  (do not expect to come here if you're hungry.)  

think of a mediocre sushi place.  now think of a mediocre sushi place but twice as expensive with a wee bit smaller portions.  that's ryoko.

i also ordered an appetizer because we were starving, and it arrived AFTER we finished all our food.  i ordered a soda as well, which meant i got a glass filled with ice.  seriously, i had 2 oz of soda in my cup, and since it's a bar, there's no refills (or i paid another 2 bucks for another 2 oz of soda).  completely retarded.

only come here if you're looking for a trendy spot to take a date.
author: H. L.

description: Truly one of the best dining experiences I have in years of world traveling. I sat at the sushi bar and chatted with a friend. Service was informal, but very friendly and attentive -- the sushi chef asked me what I wanted and prepared it for me, and the tuna and the roe were both fresh and succulent. The green tea was rich and flavorful, and the green tea mochi dessert was much more complex and subtle than what I've had elsewhere. To sum it up, the food was great, but the cozy atmosphere and truly attentive service (while we sat and chatted for more than two hours) was special. This is not a flashy or elegant place, but very genuine.
author: Karen A.

description:
Visiting SF we went out searching for food at 1am on a Thursday night.  Low and behold we find this place which was a few blocks from our hotel (thanks to Yelp).  Let us just say we were very impressed from the second we stepped in the door.  They welcomed us with open arms (yes at 1am) and the service was impeccable.   So much so we both agreed it was some of the best we have experienced! The sushi was also excellent and came out very fast.  We felt right a home and would HIGHLY recommend this place to anyone looking for great sushi and service in the union square area of SF.  We will definitely make a point of going back next time we are in town.

P.S. The fried ice cream is a great  dessert if you make it that far!
author: Christopher C.

description:
Love Love Love this place. My only disappointment is that more and more people have found out about it and it now takes a while to get a table. 

The food is excellent, unpretentious and very reasonably priced. The staff are friendly and service is quick.
author: Sean O.

description:
okay sooo.... if you are reading this I do not want you to think I did not like the food. The sushi rolls, sashimi, and nigiri are delicious and the green tea is strong-which I like. And the service is usually fast and good.

I am writing this review because I have been here many times. Probably about 20 different times as it is one of the only places my girlfriend and I save our money to eat at-that is how much we used to love it. 

After last night though, I think it will be a while before we cool off enough to come here. So the night begins-it is 8 o'clock and busy-this is fine we expected that. We were seated quickly for the amount of people that were there. We have always sat in the front room and had great food and great service and we were excited to see that they were taking us to an open table in the middle room (not the way back-which is maybe a private party room?) which is more private and we always wanted to sit back there. 

Our waiter came quickly and took our drink order. He delivered our water, sprite, and miso relatively quickly and told us he would be back shortly to take our order. He then took a drink order from the table next to us and when he returned with their drinks we expected him to take our order. They told him they were ready to order-he took their order and proceeded to inform them it was going to be a very long wait for the food would they like more appetizers. A strong, powerful Columbian woman at the table next to us asked him why and said they did not want to wait for a very long time and it was not usual that they should (she had also been here several times). I unfortunately did not hear this conversation and my girlfriend told me later when we were discussing the wait. Instead of coming to us right away to take our order he put there order through and I practically had to wave him down just to take our dinner order. 

We ordered flying tuna, 2 flying veggie, a volcano, and a 49er and all were delicious except they were ruined by the 45 minute - 1 hr wait -I did not have my watch or phone and neither did my girl-this was supposed to be a celebration night for us as we had just finished college with straight As and wanted to treat ourselves to something nice. I know it took a VERY LONG TIME TO GET OUR FOOD though because the table next to us that had ordered many more appetizers, drinks, and more rolls (but a few were the EXACT SAME ROLLS as our order), and beers, were completely finished with their food by the time ours came. 

I tried to trick the food into coming by using the restroom but it did not and on my way down from the restroom I saw a couple that had come in two parties after us who were also completely finished with their dinner BEFORE WE EVEN GOT OUR FOOD. At least bring some more edamame!! Do something! The waiter was so rude he barely acknowledged us and both my girlfriend and I stared him down at different times yet he still did not come to apologize for the wait or see if we needed something else. When I was in the bathroom my girl gave him such a dirty look that another waitress even tapped him and pointed her way, he waved it off and STILL did not even come to check in with us. I used to love this place and we have in the past been able to eat for about 45$ for both of us. 

Last night I walked in with 100$ since it was a particularly special occasion and had fully expected to leave a 20% tip because that is how good the service usually is, a smile on my face, and a hunger for some of the best sushi in town. I walked out after leaving literally a 5% tip and fuming. This is one of the only reviews I have ever written on yelp and that shows you how pissed I was and still am to have had a perfect night ruined by an asshole waiter. So to recap: we got there before the table next to us-they ordered before we did, they got their appetizers and their food and had completely finished eating before we got our food, a couple that had come in two slots behind us had also COMPLETELY finished their food before we got ours. I guess I should have also put up a fight with the waiter-but that just is not my personality. I usually try to give the staff the benefit of the doubt and hope for the best because I understand the stress of working in a restaurant. We walked in at 8, were seated by 8:20, ordered soup, salad, and 5 rolls and did not get out until 10:40---That is Wrong, especially when others are not being treated like that. What? was it because we are gay women? I mean this is San Francisco so you would not think there would be an issue but it seems like maybe this guy had a problem with us in particular. or else he was just lazy and does not want his job.  

Ryoko-it was the male waiter in the back rooms last night (wednesday June 1st) around 8-11-- I have had WAY BETTER service at a deli. He NEVER EVEN APOLOGIZED ONCE FOR THE WAIT.  This is supposed to be a restaurant and it is expensive enough that I should not have to wait an hour to get my food
author: julia n.

description: So far the only joint ever to serve uni that doesn't need nori to hold it together. Now that's fresh! Bonus points for always serving up some type of crustacean/mollusk/fish I've never heard of. Eclectic music selection, and if you're bold enuf you can even go bang on the beat up piano.
author: Sherry W.

description: This is one of my favortie Sushi places in SF ! the atmosphere is fantastic ... they staff is great  and the food is so good.. If you have any friends that arent big on sushi i suggest bringing them here ... it will make them love it ! Ryoko is such a wonderful woman very nice always in there greeting the guests meeting people.
author: A R.

description: I had an amazing time at Ryoko's. As soon as we walked in, Ryoko greeted us warmly and apologized profusely for the 20-min wait. We were more than happy to stand around, drink a Sapporo and listen to the DJ spin the top 40, knowing the sushi would be pretty authentic. We were not disappointed. The food was excellent and the service was super friendly. I wish Atlanta had hip, real sushi places like this one!
author: Brooke B.

description: Extremely fresh sashimi! Gem of the city. The restaurant needs to be renovated, you may even be turned off, but the food is incredible. Enjoy.
author: Maria M.

description: sssshhhhhhh....... Love this place. Especially if I'm working late or seeing a show downtown. Full bar and good sushi, open late, and rarely crowded. What more could you ask for.
author: Ruth S.

description: The sushi isn't crazy yummy but it's good and I like the AM-Bee-YANCE of this subterranean, sorta hipster-ish place.  The crowd is always so nice and laid back and unpretentious. So is the staff. The rolls are good but the nigiri is better.  I RIKEE a ROT~
author: Joyhan S.

description: I'll give them five stars for making even the white staff tell the sushi chefs their orders in Japanese.  The sushi is quite good here and the prices are reasonable - some nice choices you don't get elsewhere too.  I love the ambiance as well.  Have walked by this place before but never walked in - definitely give it a try!
author: Gene X.

description:
the only good thing about this place was their mochi (which was quite good). 

the 1-star rating isn't because i hated this place, it's just that it was sooo not worth going to considering the price and service

- our food cost 25% more than other sushi places while their rolls were about 30-40% smaller. 

- the waitress didn't take our order for more than 20min and then it took half an hour to get our appetizers. we couldn't get low-salt soy sauce without asking 3 separate times and then upon getting food without having the soy sauce actually getting up ourselves to go retrieve it from the bar. while this abysmal service was (not) happening i was watching the wait staff just stand around. 

- when they did notice us, they were very friendly, but the flat-out lack of service was unacceptable to me, especially for an expensive sushi place. 

- the rolls weren't that good and they were not only small, but with fewer pieces (4-5 instead of 6-8). the table next to us got the $20 (!!!!) rainbow roll which was the size of my kappa roll. i felt really sorry for them. 

- dirty carpet and tables that were soooo low that your legs actually might not fit between the chair and the table.
author: lisa w.

description:
summary:
do not go.  bad sushi.

went with some friends and ordered sushi omakase and some appetizers. The fish was old and stale.  The appetizers not worth remembering.  I left hungry and out lots of money.  Heck, for the same amount of money I paid, I could have eaten at Koo.  Or better yet, Gary Danko.  Seriously.
author: Marc Y.

description: The best sushi and most authentic atmosphere I've found outside of Japan.  Granted, I'm no connossieur, but tucked-away underground duck-under-the-noren-curtain is the right vibe.  I had a most fabulous spontaneous date with my boyfriend of 4 years here, and while we should have been more adventurous with our selections, EVERYTHING was so fresh and delicious, I'd be game to try anything.
author: Katie C.

description: this place is still my "go to" in the neighborhood. The fish is fresh. The service is good and besides the piano cramped in the middle of the room I'd say its comfortable. Make sure to ask how much the special is before you are tempted to order it.
author: Sarah D.

description: I only learned of this place via a certain elite yelper. Awesome Sashimi. Go for the Big Eye if they have it. Yes it's on the list of fish not to eat, I say so what. I am not fish PC. Global warming is another story, it effects my snowboarding. Go for the deep fried oysters they may or may not be an aphrodisiac. Try the roll with unagi, peanut butter and jalapeno, you might be surprised. Techno with you dinner, minus one star.
author: Rob H.

description:
A hotel manager recommended Ryoko's to me both for being delicious and being open long after every other restaurant shuts down around Union Square (they're open until 2am most nights).  I arrived around 11pm and found the place very lively and completely full.  I waited 15 minutes for a seat at the bar, and despite the large crowd the service was prompt, courteous, and unusually forthcoming.  The servers gladly answered all of my questions and did so honestly, especially those relating to health concerns (I am allergic to shellfish).

As a regular sushi eater limited by my allergy, I greatly appreciated the variety of Ryoko's menu.  I had miso soup, "hot tuna" hand roll, Spicy Golden Gate roll, and tamago, as well as a small bowl of edamame which they serve in lieu of a bread basket and iced oolong tea.  The soup came very hot and was a bit too savory for my taste, while the edamame could have benefited from a bit more salt.  By far the best item was the "hot tuna," distinguishable from the traditional spicy tuna by the addition of shiso, a spicy and sharp Japanese herb.  It was absolutely genius- the best hand roll I have ever had both because of balance of flavors and quality of ingredients.  I believe it included both ahi and albacore tuna.  The Spicy Golden Gate roll contains salmon, shiso, cucumber, and flying fish roe.  All in all it was satisfactory, however it hardly seems to warrant "spicy" as a modifier.  On that note, however, the wasabi packed much more punch than I usually find in restaurants, which I very much appreciated.  Only a small bit was enough to make the Spicy Golden Gate roll deserve its name.  Something about the tamago was unusual but I couldn't figure out what it was.  I would definitely order it again, though, as I always end with it.

Presentation was somewhat lacking and the rolls tended to fall apart quite easily, perhaps due to the large volume of rolls to be made, but Ryoko is less about the presentation of the food than the overall atmosphere.  The clientele ranges from teenagers to grandparents, even late at night, although the club-like decor, edgy style, and live DJ mixing techno beats seem to favor the 20 something crowd.  Drinking seemed to be the order of the evening for most guests, but plenty were there just to enjoy the incredibly fresh seafood and hip atmosphere.

The rolls are conveniently ordered by price on the menu, starting as low as $4 and maxing out at $20 (the most expensive rainbow roll I've ever seen).  The rolls get more interesting as they get more expensive, but most were priced comparably to other places I've been.  My total bill was the lowest I've ever had at a sushi place- $23 including tax, and I had more food than I could eat, although had I chosen different rolls it would have been a very different fiscal story.  By the time I was done eating, the place was almost empty (10 after midnight), but for some reason the servers became much less attentive and it took a very long time to get my check.

I will definitely return for the hot tuna, the atmosphere, and the fun staff.  I don't think I can be satisfied with regular spicy tuna ever again.
author: Katrina R.

description: Tried Ryoko's based on Yelp feedback and was not disappointed. We ordered four rolls and all of them were fantastic. We just made it before the dinner rush. Service was fast and quite friendly. The location was just a couple of block from the hotel. Prices were quite reasonable and probably even cheap for San Francisco. It is a good sign when there is a line out the door and the other sushi spot around the corner is half empty. They are doing something right.
author: Brooks G.

description: came in last night with two friends that wanted sushi, i like my dinner cooked, so i was smart and asked the waitress what she eats. i also asked for their beef dish which is not on the menu, smart me.  it was effin dericious!  $150 for dinner and drinks.
author: Pickle R.

description: I really really really like this place.  It's a cozy little stop to end/start your night.  It's a museum of curious things, bright hues and the booths are comfortably tucked away to create a sense of separation and space.  I love ogling the quirky thrift-store-bought paintings while I'm struggling with my shiro maguro and throwin back some sake.  Yeah, my chopstick skills are a disgrace to my grandma.  You may be a little taken back by the prices if you're going during the day, but somehow I don't mind when it's 1am and there's nothing else open.  Fun, curious little spot.
author: Xandria S.

description: This has got to be one of the best late night sushi spot in the city.  You have to try all the Jumping rolls because they are truly heavenly.  The staff there is great and very likable and the music is cool to but they need to let the DJ play some light hip hop. Some digable planets or tribe called quest something.  Other than that the spot is dope!
author: Karim R.

description: Ryoko's atmosphere is lively, but the sushi is average, nothing blew my mind. The service was good and we sat at the sushi bar which was fine. We had kampachi sashimi from Japan (special item), which was tough and lacked flavor, the tempura spicy tuna roll with sweet sauce was the favorite, orange delight (?) avocado and cucumber inside and salmon on top - ok, and a standard tuna roll, which again, was just ok. Prices were good, came to around $50 for two people (two beers, three rolls and one sashimi). Probably won't go back, but always great to try a new place in the city.
author: Jenn D.

description: My FAVORITE late night sushi joint! It's a small spot but has a great atmosphere. They always have a dj and lots of sake. Make sure you get the back room at least once. The owner will come in and drink with you.
author: Ajinder P.

description: Been going here on and off for two years.  Service is good and the ambiance is fun food is so so.  It's tiny but I think that's a part of the experience. Doesn't open until 6pm so if you arrive a little early you can always grab a drink at the owl bar across the street.  They take amex!
author: K W.

description: Sushi was good and decently priced. Only downside was the miscommunication with the staff. We were told one thing over the phone and then told we couldn't get a table when we got there. Luckily, the waitress tracked us down as we were leaving and we got seated. Owner was super nice and greeted all the clients.
author: Kimberly B.

description: Great sushi, and appetizers that you don't see in most Japanese joints (try the nikujaga - beef and potato stew).  Cool underground location.  Lively and casual.  Rather slow service.  Gets pretty busy into the night.
author: Russel S.

description: Awesome hole-in-the-wall spot for downtown Japanese fare. I love that you get a nice selection of different Nihon eats besides the obligatory makimono menu. Plus, you can't beat the decor and ambiance--very tasteful but slightly off-beat. It's nice and dark and would be great to bring dates to, or just food with friends.
author: Patrick G.

description:
Amazing sushi! The wait was long, but so worth it. The Volcano roll and Jumping Golden Gate were my favorite. They both had so many incredible textures and flavors. 
I didn't think they were as pricey as other reviews noted. Our party of four with 7 sushi rolls, miso soup, and sake came out to about $85. Really, not bad for a sushi place, in my opinion. 
Our server was friendly and service was quick. I am allergic to eggs and informed our server upon arrival. She seemed very helpful, even going back a couple times to check with the cooks on ingredients. Still, later that night, I had hives. My allergy is not severe so just one star removed for my discomfort. Somebody with a more severe allergy  would have been in big trouble. :(
All the food was so fresh. The menu also stated they try to use organic and sustainable ingredients where possible, which was a definite plus to me. Again, awesome sushi! Some of the best I've had. Also great vibe here. I loved the dj, who got us dancing in our seats. :)
author: Catherine V.

description: Decent fish but over-priced.  With such high standards in this city for sushi you better come ready to play instead of just exist.
author: Chard M.

description: Really great environment...love the fact that it's a hole in the wall and the atmosphere inside is low key and chill. Love the vibe! Sushi was a bit pricey...but the quality of the fish, the presentation and the quantity were all well worth it. Like the fact that they give you free edamame (kinda like when you get chips and salsa at a mexican restaurant)!
author: Stephanie J.

description:
Several people in SF have referred me to this place and when I finally went, I was not disappointed.  

The servers greet you in Japanese when you come in and sit you at a table.  Everyone is friendly and the service is fast.  The dishes they serve the food in are fun.

We ordered 6 different types to share among the four of us and it was plenty of food.  The fish was fresh and did not smell strong.  One kind we ordered with sour plum sauce was especially goodl

I can't wait to go back.  Love the atmosphere and the food.
author: Brenda B.

description:
Eat here if you're trying to break your sushi addiction... this place will do it.  Would probably taste better if you found a dead fish in the bay, wrapped it up in toilet paper, and took a nice big bite.  Enough said?  

Oh and drinks aren't even cheap to comp for the terrible food... market price.
author: Nic R.

description:
An unassuming venue playing cheap euro-techno but boy was the sushi good. We let one of the chefs prepare an omakase, which turned out to be really delicious: very lean king salmon, delicious wild snapper, nice wagyu and a made-to-order otate+uni+shiso handroll.

Overall a very pleasant experience, sitting at the bar, comparable to good places in New York (where I reside).
author: Alexis L.

description: I came here for dinner before a play at the ACT. The place is a bit hard to find, the outside is painted a dark blue and then you duck under a banner and go down stairs to the basement. It looks like a bar...and some bars are better to tolerate when its dark...so the decor didn't exite me much. I ordered some apptetizers: the fried cheese and the sliced beef with horse radish. Both were tasty. Then we had the spicy golden gate and the Pokemon...the GG was spicy and good, the pokemon was fun, but bland. For dessert we had Mochi icecream...Very yummy. I will come back here again.
author: Conny F.

description: The chef is a big baseball fan - especially of any team with a Japanese player.  He gets very emothional.  We used to go here to watch Mets playoff games.
author: Todd B.

description: This place has gone downhill since a few years back. Tonite they actually ran out of a variety of sashimi selection and can not serve the combination. No uni. The salad they served me was oxidized brown around the lettuce edges and wilted. Had to send it back. No apologies. The edamame that was once upon a time moist was dry and over salted. They served the main entree well before the salad and shrimp tempura appetizer. The shrimp tempura was way too oily and left a huge oil stain in the paper, it used to be airy and fluffy. The waitress never refilled my tea or water, and the head sushi chef whose been there forever and many times served me in the past asked everyone how their dinner was except me. Guess he didnt want to know based on the look on my face. Lol. Very disappointing. Yes, they are popular but when you go here and pay even higher prices than in the past and get below par dishes than in the past, it is really nostalgically disheartening.  Take your money elsewhere like Ninja Sushi nearby, the suhsi quality is close enough and they'll be sure to have what u want and not leaving u hanging.
author: E G.

description: My favorite sushi place in the city -- always fresh, excellent quality!  The staff greets you when you come in and is always courteous.  They often have a DJ spinning on the weekends.  The price is very reasonable.  Call the day before on weekends to get reservations as Saturdays get really crowded.
author: Ben Y.

description: Cool spot - they gave us our own little room in the back - with a good scene and service, but the sushi just isn't great. The rice had too much vinegar, the fish wasn't cold enough, blah blah blah. A fun place to go as long as you aren't too much of a sushi snob. (I am, apparently.)
author: Tea H.

description: Ah Ryoko... where else can you get late night sushi and groove to good house music? The only real complaint I have is that when it's busy, for whatever reason it takes forever to get your check... then an eternity for them to actually run your credit card and it's hot like a sauna down there... all the time. Other than that, the staff is always really sweet and accommodating. Also conveniently located less than a block from the Owl Tree and Sugar Cafe! :)
author: Donna V.

description:
Quality = Good
Service = Painful
Service Speed = Even more painful

Perhaps it's only me, and maybe I'll be the only one who gives an asshole-esque review, but it's coming straight from the heart baby. This place is apparently cool, has a dj and it's all groovin' inside and whatever other hip words come to mind. My experience was a bit annoying. The food was rather good, but the service was shite (Rusty Sherrif's Badge style). I came with a friend and were seated about 10 minutes later (it was a little busy) on a saturday night (no problem here). We were seated up front and then forgotten for about 15 minutes, no drink order, nada. Then the waitress came by and appologized for the delay "we are very busy" she says. Hey, no problem, it happens. So she takes our drink orders and we get them a few minutes later. Then about 20 minutes after we get our drinks, my beer almost gone, the waitress stumbles by again to take our orders. We order, then about 20 minutes later my friend gets her sushi and nothing was said about my food....so we waited and waited. My friend was being kind enough to wait to eat until mine arrived. About 20 minutes after that... (I have a lot of patience...but it finally wore on me, and I was a little mad...just a tad).
