I didn't want to have to get up, to find the waitress, but I had to....this was getting ridiculous. She was outside hanging out there for awhile, then came in and seated other people, then took other peoples orders etc etc. She came back and forth by our table and never asked about anything or how things were, or oh your meal is coming....nada. So I got up and found here and said, "Um, excuse me, my friend already got her meal, I've been waiting a long time and I haven't gotten mine yet". She looked really surprised and looked around, "I'm so sorry, I'll get it right out to you." She came back a few minutes later with my food and a new beer on the house. She appologized again and said that it was her restaurant and her name is Ryoko and she hopes we come back. Of course I appreciated the free beer and the waitress comping my meal as well but the whole ordeal took waaay longer than it should have been. I think the waitress just had her head up her butt that night. I'm sure this is normally a great place and that they are normally on top of it and "head-in-ass" free. But I'm reviewing based on my experience, and I just don't want to have to get up to chase down the waitress to ask where my food is and why its taking so long while my friend has already been served. It's silly. "2 stars". Next time try harder.
author: Mike S.

description: One of my favorite Japanese restaurants, hands down. Great food, great music, & great service. The best tempura rolls & soft shell crab in the city!!! I also recommend the Beef Orishi! Highly recommended!!!!!
author: Andre B.

description: Cruised here last night around 10ish, it was packed! I was kind of concerned that the atmosphere was all this place had. I was so wrong! Our waitress was so sweet, patient and helpful with my numerous questions about what to get and what was good. The fish was so FRESH!!!! Everything was fab. We sat right next to the dj he was spinning some great beats. Everything was flowing. All I can say is get out of your hood and check this place out. It rocks!
author: Michal E.

description: An interesting little spot with some really good fish. All of the specials were outstanding: sardines, red snapper, spanish mackeral. We also tried some of the more unusual items: fried cheese (wonton was the wrapper of choice), the kentucky roll (fried chicken), and even the Uni (which was apparently really fresh that day, but I'm just not a fan of testes). Probably the best fried roll i've ever had was the spicy tuna. They used really large pieces of albacore and regular tuna and only lightly fried the outside. The Kampachi was a little disappointing, but the Unagi made up for it. Several pitchers of Kirin and many bottles of Nigori added to the interesting atmosphere as the DJ spins some techno and you bask in the wood and mirrored walls...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
just gorgeous sushi in a funky, cool, dungeon-like setting. there isn't a bad choice on the menu, but i can particularly recommend the soft-shell crab, a personal favourite of mine. 

it's a great place to take out-of-town (and especialyl out-of-country) visitors, because i feel it showcases the best that san francisco has to offer - an eclectic setting, authentic food but with a local twist.

a top choice in the city.
author: Niko V.

description:
best !
its late and you want to munch and continue drinking and this place has the best atmosphere and friendliest staff! sushi was delish, plenty to choose from. definitely a hidden gem
author: Samantha S.

description: Soo Good!!  I can't believe that I live so close and never noticed it before!  So here is my experience:  The mood was dinner time lighting with a live DJ playing in the middle (Playing good house music ...I wanted to get up and start dancing).  A little pricier than other spots around the area but its definitely worth a shot.
author: Maria E.

description: My wife and I went here after being referred by the bar back that worked at Jillians.  This place was great.  Okay to get the bad out of the way.  The reason I gave it four stars instead of five was because of where we were seated.  our table got a rush of cool air every time the front door opened.  Also we were right behind the office door and people kept going in and out of the office.  We even asked if anyone would be going in and out and they told us no.  So my advice don't sit at the table next to the office door.  Okay no on to the good.  The atmosphere of this place was awesome!!!  We were greeted as soon as we walked in the door and seated and served very quickly.  Our server was awesome as well.  The food is fresh and very good.  Go to this place and at least try it out.  We will go back for sure.  Try the Jumping Tuna and the scallops.  They were so good!
author: Ronald G.

description: Ryokos can be affordable if you don't order the designer rolls and alcohol. I loved the colors of the walls (a deep sapphire) and the music New Order, Green Day etc. The wait staff are friendly and attentive. I had the house saIad and it was a nice size with the perfect amount of fresh sesame dressing. I did forget my laptop under my chair (must have been the SAKE!) and when I went back it was waiting for me behind the hostess station. So how can I not Love Ryokos!? I'll be back!
author: Joshua M.

description: Freshest Sushi in SF!  Just like in Japan they greet you upon entering and exiting.  Deep Fried Oysters were amazing!  Jumping Tuna a must--tempura fried tuna, Awesome!  The Nigiri is just so fresh it tries to jump off the plate.  Great if you're downtown late at night and even easier to be seated if you get there at 6pm on the dot when it opens.  Friendly staff and great specials.
author: Dave M.

description: This is a cool place to have sushi on a late night. Its small but cozy. Its best to park in Union Square Parking garage and then walk over. Trying to find parking is almost impossible. The service is excellent, the servers are good at greeting you at the door and checking on you once you are seated. You have the choice of sitting at the bar or at a table. I've been on a Friday and Saturday night and there's always been a DJ spinning house and some hip-hop music that kind of sets the mood of the atmosphere. Appetizers good, all the sushi on the list are good. If you are sitting at the sushi bar and watching the chefs making a sushi you haven't tasted. Just ask them what are they making and take a chance and order it. Nine times out ten its good.
author: Baseemah R.

description: 5/3/08,  it B-Day party for my wife's friend Sun.we meet at my home at 6pm headed for Ryoko's for dinner. The first thing you must know is parking is difficult but luck will always fine a space ,so go early we had reservation for 4 at 8pm. Ryoko is a very popular restaurant for people who are REALLY into  sushi its also know for a sake bar were everyone drinks and laughs. other things you should know is that its a very small place, not sure how they fit the DJ in but I did see him. the food is very good to excellent, I'm not a big sushi fan so I order teriyaki chicken(very good) and ate some california rolls. the sushi was a little pricey but its the real deal. side note the wait line headed out the door and I didn't see any sign of recession in this place.
author: Howard J.

description:
The fish here is super fresh and the service is prompt & friendly. They normally have fish from Japan and it's expensive but worth it. I've been here multiple times and each time did not disappoint. Some of my favorites: spicy tuna, hamachi, beni-toro, baby squid, etc.
They close @ 2AM so it's great when my husband & I are craving sushi late in the night.
author: Xuyen H.

description:
They have so many great reviews, I hate to give them 3 stars.  But damn....i feel like i am going to puke after eating here.  Here is what I had:

- fried crab: greasy as hell with pieces of shell still left on it.
- sake and ebi sashimi: actually, these were both awesome.  VERY fresh.
- some albacore thingie: tasty, but just ok.
- miso soup: just ok
- o toro tuna: ok, here was the kicker....because my buddie had something he didn't like, he complained to the server.  they knocked off 1/2 off the bill and gave us this tuna to make up for it.  O toro was supposed to be the best of the best.  but it was horrible.  i almost barfed right there!  maybe it was just me.....

Overall, the place is a cool joint with friendly people.  I will come back again.  But will order normal stuff next time.
author: James B.

description: oh yea.. Try the Volcano Roll. don't let the peanut butter fool you; it actually works very very well.
author: Sean L.

description: One of the best places in town to get sushi.  I'm told (contrary to popular mythology) that Sunday is a good night to go there for fresh fish.  Even on non-Sundays the food is stellar.  Be sure to check the specials board.  They fry the amaebi heads up nice and crispy and the ambience is relaxed and low key.  They also play good music, if not a little loud some nights.
author: Shu W.

description:
let me start by saying i do not like sushi.  specifically, any type of seafood, cooked or otherwise.  however, my boyfriend loves sushi, and i can only say no so many times before i start to feel bad.  so when we met up with an old friend who suggested this place for dinner, i was a little put out and was already resigning myself to a dinner of edamame and horrible teriyaki chicken.  (why is the only cooked, non-fish item always teriyaki chicken??)  

but i LOVED this place.   they have a ton of veggie options, all of which were delicious!  i was amazed and surprised and had a really great time at a sushi place for the first time in my life.     

other pluses:
-right around the corner from our hotel (on union square)
-busy, but not too crowded
-reasonably quick service
-friendly & efficient staff

all in all, a great place & a wonderful first visit to san francisco.  we will definitely hit this place up again on future trips.
author: gretchen o.

description:
I usually don't eat raw meat but got pressured into eating their Pokemon roll (w/ raw salmon).  I must say...it did not taste "fishy" at all and was actually pretty good.  Apparently, they only use fresh organic ingredients so that's probably why I didn't spit the thing out.  

This is a lively and casual place.  Great hang out for Friday nights when you don't feel like getting harassed at the clubs/bars.
author: Sally Trung N.

description: Over-fuckin-rated!   Far too expensive for the mediocre-quality ingredients and poorly executed, unimaginative specialty rolls, but, if your parents are already spending 7 grand a month for you to party and go to art school, why the hell not?
author: The I.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant! It's a great place for a relaxed dinner. The servers are bit slow, but very friendly. The prices are quite reasonable, the sushi is outstanding, and its a cozy atmosphere of blue walls and light euro-type techno music that Japanese restaurants have seemed to adapt. It's not loud, though there is a buzz that is almost early night bar-like. It's a great place for a date as its located near a slew of entertainment venues, bars, and nightlife.
author: Matt D.

description: Late night sushi downtown SF, I would recommend.  I was suspect with the Waitress not speaking Japanese and then most of the patrons were not Japanese, for me that is 2 strikes.  But once we started to talk to Atsushi, the Chef it all changed.  The group I went with was from Japan and it makes all the difference in the world.  I am writing this review 2 months later and I cannot remember specifics but everything he suggested was great!  I am now am uni fan which I eat once in awhile and will definitely go back to Atsushi-san for specials
author: Toby N.

description: Ever since first stumbling into this nook almost four years ago, this spot is undoubtedly my first recommended restaurant to late-night travelers/revelers to the City and is my own personal favorite sushi joint. Subterreanean location, open till two A.M, Jumping Unagi rolls, piano backdrop on certain nights, and the lack of parking in the area...what's not to love? Watch the steps while going down though.
author: Ramon T.

description: Just got back from dinner.  Disappointing compared to the reviews.  Didn't keep water or "free refills" hot tea full, "Jumping" rolls re just deep fried with too much breading.  Crowd is yuppies and tourists.  "Hot Tail" roll was actually good, shiso and nice white tuna (enough to hang out the ends) with some spicy sauce.  Tuna was not "marinated" as the menu says.  Gave us a "freebie" of deep fried shrimp heads with nothing added but breading. Gross.  Shrimp sushi was uncooked, my companion wouldn't touch it.  I ate it and was unimpressed.  Salmon sushi smelled fishy...not good.  Rolls are nicely packed, presentation is less than other sushi places, edamame is pre-cooked and cold.  OK sushi place, but nothing special.
author: Lauren J.

description: I like this place for what it is.  Imagine eating Japanese finger food in a dungeon, add some hand-cuffs and you're set.  It's dark -  you're basically in a basement and it has a unique Japanese '80s vibe.  If you are in the mood to sit back and enjoy a shouchu or chu-hai with your friends in a very casual atmosphere then hit this.
author: Shiho F.

description:
good sushi with a great atmo. 

i've definitely had better sushi, but never in a cooler  place.  definitely the place for you and yours if you fancy the idea of eating your raw fish to some pumpin' techno being played by a dj who seems like he missed his last fix.  service that is friendly and attentive during the week and friendly at least during the weekend.

それを試みなさい!

(man, i go to the trouble of looking up, "try it" in japanese and yelp chokes on the the japanese characters...damn it...that was going to be awesome)
author: eric g.

description: Let me start off by saying that I eat sushi at least once a week, so I know the difference between good and bad sushi. This is a great affordable sushi place with fresh fish and so much more. Great for late night dinner with some sake before going out on the town. Loved the fried tuna rolls, caterpiller, albacore sushi. Everything's fresh. Full bar including sake. The waiters are very friendly and helpful. The atmosphere is great for hanging out with friends before heading to a bar. It's underground and has dark lighting. I will be back. If you're looking for a pretentious meal dressed in a suit and tie, this is probably not your type of place.
author: I. C.

description: The food may get three stars (maybe), but the price in comparison to the food gets one star at best.  I showed up hungry, I left hungry, and they ran out of the sake we were ordering.  The best part was that it was warm inside.  The cozy temperature did not quite make up for my overpriced supper that left me hungry.   The coolness factor is slight compensation.
author: Amme P.

description: This hole in the wall sushi bar is damn good. Its open till late night 2. fresh sushi, warm sake, friendly staff. Jumping Unagi and California Rolls are yummy...
author: Jose S.

description: Sorry, Yelpers, but you led me astray on this one.  Unconventional sushi I'm okay with, but this was just poorly executed.  And I'm no fucking expert.  But the rolls were just not well made and the pieces weren't even cut the same size!!  My friend's roll came out about 15 minutes before my food, which left an uncomfortable period of time with her eyeing longingly at her food, but not wanting to be rude.  Then the freaking waitress brings us the wrong check and takes forever to correct the problem.  Plus it was soooo hot in there.  Geez louise.  Very disappointing.  However, my nigiri seemed to be of good quality, and the staff seemed pretty pleasant.  So they have that going for them.
author: Coco D.

description: Wow, I can not believe the earlier reviews... This place is great! I am new to the area and let me tell you I will definitely be back! The sushi selection was great and the specials were even better. This is a great place to bring friends and a fun place for a date. I can't wait to go back for another try!
author: Miguel V.

description:
I am really surprised at some of these reviews that I have been reading, since this is the second best sushi place in the city in my opinion. I may be committing the ultimate in taking away my "foodie cred", but it is worth it.
A few of the reviews claimed that the food was expensive (one said that it was the MOST expensive in the city..wtf?) When I can go with a group of 4 people, and have 3 pitchers of beer and be full...for $20 a person? 
I eat here at least once a week due to its cheapness, great atmosphere, and fresh food.
I have yet to have anything that I thought tasted a bit unfresh, or was sub-par, and everyone I have taken to Ryoko's has been back numerous times. When you add in the very attentive, and fun staff, along with the DJ that spins great toons and $12 pitchers of beer....you just simply cannot go wrong.
The only downside I can honestly say is that sometimes the wait is pretty long, although nothing compared to Sushi Zone.
author: Jason D.

description:
This is officially my new favorite sushi place in San Francisco. 

Then again, I think we got particularly lucky on our first visit to Ryoko's: we were seated at a great table in the middle room, so that it wasn't too rowdy (like some of the tables next to the bar) but still comfortably surrounded by others, especially as the crowd trickled in; our waiter was friendly, cordial, and helpful, with a good sense of humor and a lot of grace; and he (wisely!) recommended the Aburi Sake (salmon belly) nigiri, which, as we were pleased to discover, is the most delicious, buttery, tender fish imaginable. Suffice it to say that we ordered three more pairs. The mackerel (aji) nigiri was likewise delectable and very fresh, although definitely stronger in flavor than the aburi. We also had a couple of rolls, but as many of the other reviewers caution, these are pretty standard (and a touch small)... it is truly the nigiri and sashimi that blows you out of the water. We topped it all off with a couple of Sapporo's and some green tea mochi dessert, and raved about the whole thing all the way home. 

Add to that reasonable prices, the whimsical underground dive bar feel, and all-around friendly service, and you've got an amazing experience at Ryoko's. I do advise going early or on a week-night (we went on a Thursday) because the waits were already substantial, so I can only imagine what weekend evenings must be like. And enjoy the music! We caught some Destiny's Child on our way out... goooood times. 

BRILLIANT.
author: G. J.

description: they are closed for renovations and went to Sanraku on Sutter.  We were glad we did.
author: Hoku A.

description: Best Sushi in town. Reminds me of some random alley Sushi restaurant in Tokyo. It may not be as hip as Sushi Groove, Ace Wasabi or Blowfish, but the chef rocks. Open until 2 am so the fish craving can be handled. Don't go on Friday and Saturday during prime hours and be sure to sit at the bar.
author: Raymond M.

description: This place was okay... I ate something majorly fucking spicy that almost ruined all the other rolls. I think it was something in the cold tofu appetizer I had, but fuck was my mouth on fire. 2 beers and half a large of hot sake didn't help... What did help was another order of edamame. Anyway, I found this place decent but not awesome. We had the big mama, hot tuna, hot tail and some salmon roll. The tuna, hamachi and unagi were slightly dry in each roll. I also didn't like that they wrapped the seaweed paper on the outside and had some kind of green leaf on the inside of the roll. My favorite roll was the salmon one we had because the salmon was a little more fresh. I'm going to take a wild guess and say this restaurant was previously a bar given it's infrastructure. Appropriately so, this place is good for getting drunk at and listening to classic rock and 80s pop. Probably wouldn't return unless I was looking for late night sushi in the tenderloin This place doesn't close until 2am!
author: Jessica N.

description: My friend recently introduced me to this place and now I love it!  If you don't know where it is, you might miss it.  The atmosphere is hip and the service is excellent.   The prices are slightly higher than other places, but it's definitely worth it - they are generous with the fish and it's always fresh!  They're open late too, so if you have a midnight craving for sushi, this is the place to go.
author: Shannon E.

description: I eat here every time I need a sushi fix.  They've made it impossible for me to go anywhere else.  Family owned and operated they take enormous pride intheir fresh high quality fish.  I'm a straight sashimi person, so I can really tell the quality levels.  Sit at the bar, drink the good sake- it's worth it.  Oh- and try the cheese filled deep fried wontons- they're delicious.
author: Dina A.

description:
Ryoko is my favorite downtown sushi spot.  It is located in a rather bizarre space on Taylor north of Geary.  You walk down a flight of stairs and enter into a sort of basement space with low ceilings and low lighting that's made even dimmer by the dark blue painted walls.  These elements to my mind make the place unique among the countless sushi bars I've eaten at in the San Francisco bay area.  Another plus is the fact that it remains open until 2am on week-ends, and features a dj.  I've sidled up the the sushi bar at midnight and had a simply grand time listening to beats and watching Atsushi the rockstar sushi chef slice up cold, raw slabs of hamachi many, many times.  He literally is a rock star, playing in a band called The Thunder at places like Rockit Room on Clement.
     The Japanese food here is very good.  Keep in mind that I an individual who's been to Japan several times and who eats almost exclusively sashimi, that is, raw fish only.  The only items I get with rice is unagi, which has always been good here.  My standards are hamachi, hamachi kama, toro, salmon, ebi, makerel, sea urchin, blue fin, sea scallop, octopus, and just about anything on the board imported fresh from Japan.  Granted, one pays extra for these items.  For the quality and taste, one must.  Yes, if you wish to get filled up, if you're merely eating to fill the belly and satisfy your hunger, then eat rolls till you're satisfied.  If you're interested in experiencing eye-rolling tastes, flavors, and textures, go for what's raw and what's fresh.  
     I ate some of the best fatty tuna I've ever had one night there awhile back when I tried virtually everything on the board.  I was there alone and decided to have Atsushi challenge my taste buds and serve me up whatever he wished or dared.  He didn't disappoint, and Ryoko has never really disappointed over the years I've been frequenting it.
     Also very good here besided sashimi is the cooked foods, what's known as izakaya or country type cooking.  The grilled squid is always good here, and some of the seafood stews, too.  There are other grilled vegetables that are well made.  Oysters can be also quite tasty, depending on the time of year.
author: Roland C.

description:
Like MTV for your mouth.

This place is all image and hype. It's not a bad sushi spot- and I had a good time here- but the cool venue, DJ spinning on top of a piano, and funky roll names don't even begin to make up for the tiny portions and just-okay sushi.

Unfathomably long wait times. I can't even begin to imagine what they're doing behind that sushi bar that could take so long, given that it culminates in a roll about the size of the one I keep handy for parking meters.
author: Jay S.

description: Had a really good time at this place.  Ambiance was hip and food was good.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: Came here for the first time in some years and I wasn't impressed by the service.  What happened to this place?  The owner wasn't there this night - maybe the owner needs to be there to crack the whip, keeping the servers in line.  Oh well, I guess I need to find a new favorite sushi bar.
author: Nathan V.

description: Went to Ryoko with friends and our two young children. They were very accommodating, service was prompt and efficient, and the sushi was very good. Portions a little small, but not ridiculously so. We'll probably come back again next time we're in town!
author: Barbara B.

description: I'm not too sure why this place has a solid 4 stars. Maybe because it's open late and everyone comes drunk or comes here to get drunk.... I came here sober, and left sober. The sushi isn't  great. I tried the infamous peanut butter roll, which is unique and has decent flavor but, it's a been there done that item now and it's definitely not worth visiting just to try it.I don't find anything there too exciting and there are many other places I'd rather try before returning here. That is unless I'm hungry and tipsy in Union Square and everything else is closed.
author: chelsea b.

description: This place is the joint that got me to love sushi. The late night vibe is awesome, full of house music and a friendly staff that doesn't pressure you to leave no matter how many rounds of rolls you order. It's tucked away in a funky area of the T-L so it has a great "this little place I know of" feel. Good sushi, and occasionally they'll make you something special if you come around often enough. Also, their fried cheese is a nice addition that you don't find on many sushi menus. I nice spot I like to treat myself to from time to time (more often than not, since it's so affordable!).
author: Angela W.

description:
Food: 1 Star
Decor: 4 Stars (gotta love having a DJ in an underground sushi joint)
Service: 3 stars
*Ratings adjusted according to price

Wannabe sushi connoisseurs unite and review Ryoko's on yelp, apparently. 

It's exactly how everyone describes it, Interesting ambiance, semi hidden, lounge feeling complete with live DJ, young attractive crowd and open till 2AM. Everything is pretty much ideal until the food arrives and you realize that it's all a facade.

It's as if people come here, see the place is full of people, see that it's "hip", observe that it costs as much as good sushi should and figure that this is what good sushi must taste like. People who can actually tell the difference may notice a few basic things that won't change from night to night such as that they don't carry real crab or that their fresh wasabi isn't really fresh wasabi at all and tastes far worse than the standard wasabi that they serve you. Other than that, the quality of the fish itself seemed fine but ranged from not properly prepared (unagi had almost no eel sauce) to not properly stored or handled giving the fish a fishy smell and taste. Service gets 5 stars just for serving sushi till 2AM and minus 2 stars for allowing me to eat something off the menu.
author: Michael G.

description: Feeling a bit adventurous?. Want Sushi, but not a typical sterile sushi environment? This is the place you've been looking for. Underground Sushi bar in Tenderloin district. A bit dark with a constant beat of techno music. Expectedly crowded at 930 pm on a Friday night, but the wait was less than 15 minutes. The food was excellent. We sat at the bar and ordered the usual rolls and nigiri sushi. We also got recommendations from the chef's (a highly recommended way to order sushi if you are somewhat of a novice). Nice selection of sake. We tried a couple of dessert recommendations which did not disappoint. After dinner, we hit a couple of local bars.  Be aware of your surroundings -- the hissing street people, hookers and Trannys... welcome to the 'Loin!
author: Steve E.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi places in SF.  Very fresh, very good.  I've had better, but not by much.  The setting and atmosphere does it for me here.  Its in the basement of the building which Ioved.  I miss that about the midwest(basements).  Fri and Sat. they have a DJ. The vibe is really chill but social.  Like many places in SF, you could either wear a hoodie or a suit and no one would blink.  Can be a bit pricey, but its San Fran right?  There is valet parking available just down the alley.  It's for a different restaurant but still at your disposal
author: Ryan T.

description: Oh, Ryoko's! So dangerously located just around the corner from my apartment. I've been coming here for more than five years, and I am excited every time for the delicious food. The staff is perhaps the friendliest restaurant staff in the city... that and the PERFECT miso soup keep me coming back!
author: Ashley O.

description:
I've been going here since the late 90's and it's consistently the BEST food and atmosphere around! I'm blown away buy how popular it has become!
I wonder if anyone remebers the secret smoking room with milk crates as seats and a hole in the wall for fresh air???
As someone who lived in Japan, this places is as close as it gets.
author: Sunny M.

description:
The atmosphere is particular for a Japanese restaurant, with a DJ playing dance music, but I personally really liked it: it makes it more lively, more trendy. 

The atmosphere is otherwise pretty authentic, the staff being mostly Japanese and very cordial.

The food is really good and very fairly priced.

We had to wait some time before to get a table, late Friday night, as it was pretty packed.
author: Laurent C.

description:
Love it.

Came here last night. It was late and my boyfriend and I were CRAVING sushi. We initially went to Sakara, but they closed right when we got there. The manager saw us and suggested we go half a block up, to Ryoko.

The atmosphere is very "hip". DJ, grand piano, dim lights.

EXCELLENT food! Jumping tuna was delicious. They have a wide selection of special rolls with interesting names, we tried the pokemon, big mama, and some others. The menu was so exciting!

It was a fulfilling night.
author: Diem V.

description:
late night sushi amazingness!!  i was brought here by a friend and had such a great time.  yes a great time.  the sushi is on point.  nothing spectacular, but very, very good and fresh.

what was more impressive was the general atmosphere.  i'm big on that.  the place is seriously small but it's quite lovely that way.  when i walked in and saw the piano/dj area i immediately got worried that it would be a horrible night of bad karaoke and asian remixes of pop songs.  wrong.  there was a serious 80's marathon going down!  people all over the place were dancing and singing...even waiters.  

i had such a good time.  id definitely go here over other sushi places with just as good sushi and not as good vibes.
author: nzingha s.

description:
They automatically get a million star for being open till 2 am.
It's a dive and unrefined, but they always have awesome house/techno playing.  The fact that it's underground and that REAL japanese people go there makes you feel like you are in some tokyo dive late at night.  Fri and Sat they have a live DJ.
The unexpected rolls are th main attraction.  The Sexy roll is the reason to go.  I can't remeber all that was in it, but you will know it by the CHEESE on top.  yeah i thought it was wierd too, bu then i ate it and MY MOUTH AND A LITTLE ORGASM. I've had quite a few rolls and have yet to be dissapointed.  The sahimi is fresh and while the service is disointed durring peak hours, it eventually gets to us.  It's a place to go after a night of hard drinking.
Reservations are encouraged durrign peak times and if you have more than 4 people.
But really, you don't want to be here untill after hours.  it's much more hip that way.
author: Natalie R.

description: This place seemed to be a run of the mill sushi joint.  From what I've heard it's selling point is the fact that it stays open late.  The sushi was ok, atmosphere = I kind of felt like I was in the hull of a ship.  The service was great.  All I had to do was make gestures from across the room and they understood, amazing.  i only did the gesturing for pitchers of beer.  The mix of people dining there was nice as it appears to be a place where anybody will enjoy themselves.  Spoke Japanese all night, ate sushi, and drank sapporo beer.  What more can a man who just moved from Japan ask for.
author: John B.

description:
there were 3 of us. all hungry as bears.  20 minute wait? yea right; we skipped the sign in sheet, and just made ourselves at home at a cozy romantic table off to the side. it was a little dark where we were. a little romantic.

the service wasn't bad. took a while to get a menu but the food came out at a normal pace.

we got 6 rolls and a bottle of sake.  the rolls were all very good except for the one with the salmon skin. it was not very good. not at all.

the best of the 6 was the deep fried eel something or other. oh man. that was like an orgasmic explosion in my mouth

the rolls were not very large though. we weren't even full after all those rolls and had to order more stuff. the place was pretty well priced for SF but expensive in terms of items i've purchased before. thats why they get da 4 instead of da 5
author: Victor B.

description: I used to like this place until I got food poising.  Great food but don't go late on Sunday night
author: Glenn P.

description:
This hole in the wall rocks. 

If your party is small, try and sit at the sushi bar and eat whatever the sushi chef throws at you. If you must sit at the table, try the deep fried baby octupus and the scallop roll. Oh, and the cheek...the hamachi cheek is really really good...
author: Gina S.

description:
by far my favorite sushi restaurant in san francisco (im still very sad that the old kabuto isnt really around anymore), but for many other reasons far beyond simply the food.  white people tend to like sushi and therefore you will get many non-experts spouting various opinions about many things regarding sushi. i don't care to make an argument against any of that non-sense. i can understand why many people have wildly mixed reviews at sushi restaurants.

if you have anything bad to say about this place i will punch you in your face, just AIM me at "ambientempire" and schedule your beating.  if you've eaten at Masa's in NYC or at Urasawa in LA or Tojo's in BC or to Kyubei in Tokyo, keep it to yourself, obviously great and expensive sushi exists all over the world, and i agree with that. I've eaten basically all sushi everywhere.

i'm giving 5 stars to the kubiyashi family that owns this restaurant, i love them as my own because they have been more than wonderful during all of the years that i've known them and to yoshi for being truely talented, knowledgable and passionate about food and many other things and to ryoko and reiko for putting up with yoshi.
author: christopher a.

description: The sushi was good but it was a bit expensive and the portions were small. I have found better in this city. I probably won't come here again unless I am desperate.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
i think what sets Ryoko apart is it's atmosphere...it's fun to head downstairs into this restaurant and just enjoy a somewhat hip and trendy place to get some good sushi.  the nite my buddy and i rolled thru was a saturday and they had a dj bumping tunes.  

definitely a somewhat unique experience...and the fact that it's a bit trendy doesn't really detract from grabbing a good meal.  good sushi as well...of course without good food no way it gets 4 stars.
author: Looey P.

description: Great little place with a different vibe. They have some crazy rolls, ie. peanut butter and jalapenos! Fish is always fresh,( get the specials) and service always friendly. Sometimes on the weekends they get a dj in there and it can get pretty loud. They also have a piano.
author: nadia w.

description: I don't want to give this place a bad review, because they were super nice.  The food however, was boring, uncreative, and definitely small for the money.  I usually don't know what other people are talking about when they say the fish isn't as fresh as they'd like because I generally think that places I've been have been okay and they always taste fine to me --- but I could definitely tell there was something janky with the salmon on my Checkerboard roll.  (I changed it from tuna to salmon)  The roll was wayyyyyyyyyy small for $13.50 an kinda unacceptable because it wasn't that good.  My roommate ordered the spicy tuna and the Philly roll which were both pretty generic and they didn't really get it right.  She liked the miso soup though.  I doubt we'll be going back, even though we wanted to like.  I'm so disappointed that Yelp rated it so highly because we just moved into the city and we chose this place.
author: Josephine C.

description: Last weekend visiting SF my fiance & I were in the mood for sushi, thanks to all the great reviews on Yelp we ended up at Ryoko's & can't wait to go back!  We absolutely love crazy designer rolls & they have a great selection.  I think it was the volcano roll that had the peanut butter, sooo good!  We also had the jumpin California roll & ended up ordering a second one it was so delish!  The entire waitstaff greets you on your way in & out which is a nice touch.  They also use all organic veggies which is a big plus!
author: Toni L.

description: Favorite Sushi place in San Francisco.  We love the fish.. and isn't that the most important aspect of a Sushi restaurant?  I highly recommend you give this place a try.
author: Joanna and Ryan L.

description: 4 stars for atmosphere AND food.  Try the fried cheese, gyoza and fried chicken.
author: L C.

description: Yummy yummy yummy. I came here once before, but completely forgot where I was, and only knew that it was close to le colonial. I was craving soup and the bartenders at Cantina recommended this place over sushi-man. So, we headed there Friday night and had to wait awhile for a table because it was packed! It was also sorta slightly stuffy since it's sorta underground. The rolls came out fast and things were reasonably priced. I ordered the fried eel roll, which was delicious. I'll have to remember this place if I am around the area and crave sushi.
author: Natalie S.

description: This place is divey looking for sure, and the prices certainly are not, however, the sushi chef is really passionate, and if your up at the bar he'll feed you some of the best sushi morsels in the city. The last time I was there, he insisted on choosing for us and i was very glad he did. make sure to ask and see if they have fresh wasabi, it's a revelation.
author: Stellah D.

description: A diamond in the ruff Tender Nob! Yummy creative sushi and rolls. Casual and warm atmosphere. Might be hard to find only because this is the first "subterranean" sushi joint I've been to. And the big plus is that they're open late!!!
author: Anne E.

description: Very NYC. A little too big for its britches, maybe and they spared money on the decor, sure but asking the chef for a handful of what was best and it all was absolutely beautiful.
author: patrick g.

description: Amidst all the touristy (read: boring and expensive) sushi places near Union Square, Ryoko's stands as a cut above. The sushi list is exhaustive; it's hard to not find something you don't want. They also have croquettes and other nibbly things that are fun and tasty. I wasn't so wowed by the shabby-chic, "we were once obviously a basement lounge" look, but the good music helps to make it all work. Service is fairly slow, so don't go if you're in a big rush. Overall tho, the food and atmosphere make Ryoko's a gem among the Union Square banal.
author: Aaron L.

description: Ryoko.  I love you.  you are open late.  and you taste great. okay enough cheesy rhymes.  but all of them are true. I love this place for those reasons.  And it is right around the corner from my apartment.  It does get busy and if you want quick service, like Rachael Z said, you are in the wrong place.  But how can you not love it on a Friday night when the DJ sets up his turntables on top of the grand piano which sits in the middle of the tiny underground sushi bar.
author: Alexis M.

description: Through the "SUSHI" drapes, down the stairs, and into an electronica-filled Japanese paradise we descended.  Cool setting, loud music on Saturday, plentiful menu full of appetizers and sushi/sashimi delights.  We had the beef appetizer (lotsa slices, rare, flavorful), the yakitori (delicate and scarce but grilled to juicy perfection), agadashi tofu (light and crispy drenched in fishy soy goodness) and dried squid (my first try for this stuff- it's salty and chewy and served with greens and mayo!).  Followed that up with four sushi rolls (don't remember which but they were top-notch) and sake/beer.  Four of us ate all of the above for $30 apiece.  Not too bad.  I'd come back for sure!
author: Eric S.

description: I had a lot of fun here! I found this place one night while out wandering with a friend. instead of the usual Irish bar, we stumbled onto this late night sushi den, complete w/ DJ playing music and low mood lighting. The sushi chefs were awesome, drinking beer and telling jokes while deftly tossing veggies and fish every which way. The portions are small but the taste is great, and the service was prompt and friendly. Definitely a nice date place or a late night sake slam w/ friends.
author: Heleena H.

description: Shady place with mediocre food. They put items on the bill that we didn't order and after bringing it to their attention they still didn't take it off and ran my card anyway. I was obviously annoyed that they screwed up twice And told them they still didn't fix it, they told me that we were charged for water. They agreed to fix it after the third mess up and recharged my card for less but never canceled out the first error transaction (after they specifically told me they did cancel it out). The sushi was just alright on top of it all.
author: Michael A.

description: Late night sushi at its finest. Great fish and amazing atmosphere. Has that underground, kind of speakeasy feel to it. Would be a great place for a birthday dinner.
author: Megan Y.

description: My friend and I dub this place as "basement sushi" -- I never remember the actual name - Ryoko because of that.  This is a great place to grab fresh sushi and a large Sapporo after 12am.  The place is ran by real Nihon Jins (Japanese) and not other asians pretending to know how to prepare sushi.  :)
author: Sherman H.

description: I love this place, underground (literally), not too pricey, and the fish is really fresh.  I have dreams about their Jumping Unagi Roll and the sweet sauce that comes with it.  Also the back portion is nice to reserve for a party or big group of peeps.
author: Katie M.

description:
the service here was *TERRIBLE.*  yes, we went on a friday night, and yes the sushi itself was relatively good, but there comes a point when that doesn't matter.

i saw several people seated around us wait awhile for their server, bill, etc, so i was kind of expecting it.  aside from the fact that our server hardly checked on us and we had to literally get up and track her down to ask for our check, it took 20 minutes from then to actually GET IT (and another reminder).  then another 10 to process it and get it back to us.  i don't care if the food is good (which it was- and why this place isn't getting one star), or if it's a busy friday.  that's just unacceptable.
author: Alexis W.

description:
Ryoko's is on Taylor and Post, on your way to Le Colonial. I've always noticed it on the way up and they have a red lantern outside and you can't help but look through the glass doors to see the stools at the sushi bar taken up and people drinking and eating something delicious.  You go down the stairs right into the restaurant of royal blue walls and there's a baby grand piano in the middle of the place. Sweet.

It was a warm night and perfect for sushi and sake.  I think Ryoko's place is an izakaya with it's own San Francisco twist! (Royal blue walls, grand piano.) Pretty lively for a Monday!  We sat down and ordered drinks - sake, beer for the three of us and a chu-hai (sho-chu) with peach tea for me.  (I'm such a chick.)  Ryoko's has quite a variety of cooked dishes, rolls and the more traditional sushi and sashimi.  The chicken kara-age (fried chicken) and beef tataki were really good.  I love me Japanese fried chicken!  The nikujaga (beef and potatoes)  was tasty with large potato quarters and beef, but I would have liked something a little more hearty than brothy as they prepared it here.  We also had omakase sashimi (chef's choice) which included kanpachi, akadai (red snapper), mirugai (geoduck or giant clam), sake (salmon), white mackerel and tobiho (flying fish) which was the very first time I've ever tried it. The sashimi was nicely presented, but the pieces of fish were a little small. In the end with everything else rolling around in our bellies, we were just right.   We also had hotate (scallop) nigiri and uni (sea urchin) nigiri. The uni was fresh, creamy and sweet. 
 
The last time I was here, it was about $50 a person.  I would say they are fairly reasonable since I've been eating basically the "top shelf" of their sashimi and sushi each time I've been here.  They have interesting sashimi here to try, as even our Japanese companion commented that flying fish is very rare to find in Japan.  Next time, I think I will order on my own instead of omakase because I did miss my hamachi and shiro-maguro (albacore). There is quite no other place that has that San Francisco uniqueness and great sushi.

Mmm.. I think being unique also scores them points with me!
author: Betty L.

description: This place is absolutely top notch for nigiri and sashimi. The specials board is always chalked full of super fresh and nicely presented / prepared fish. Best Alaskan wild kind salmon (rod caught) I have ever had was here. Another highlight was the Spanish mackerel they had for a period of time last year. The place is lively and open late. It can get loud if they have a DJ (usually techno/house). The servers here are on point and if your lucky you will be able to bask in the glory of Ryoko herself.
author: Justin B.

description: We made our way out here for a friend's birthday.  It was amazingly loud in there, hence docking one star.  The pounding music and everyone basically yelling just so they can have a conversation... makes it kind of hard to enjoy the experience.  I'm almost thinking I'm at a nightclub, and not actually having dinner.  The food itself was pretty good... had various sushi nigiri and rolls (loved the Kentucky roll... haha), and also had some appetizers (loved the karaage, not so much the gyoza).  As we were sitting in the back of the restaurant, almost felt kind of neglected by the wait staff.  Asked for some tea, and ended up with one cup of tea.  Sad.  Or maybe the wait staff couldn't hear us as well.
author: Irene C.

description: This place is fun.  It's a little dark, and the music is usually loud but the fish is fresh and the large hot sakes are $7.  They also have these deep fried rocknrolls (jumping unagi) that come with sweet and sour sauce.  definitely awesome.  service is always good and they serve food until 2.
author: Allison C.

description: This place is the ultimate sushi dining spot in SF. Its the best sushi & sashimi I've had the pleasure of trying in San Francisco in my many many years of living and eating sushi in the Bay Area. The restaurant's ambiance is the best part! Music blaring & cozy underground atmosphere as you enter descending a flight of stairs to this hidden gem. Go right at 6pm or late past 10pm and you should have no problem getting a nice table. Its not a place to drop sake bombs but hey.. everyone can start their own party. A must try for anyone living or visiting the city!
author: Francesca L.

description: What a weird atmosphere at this sushi place.  It almost feels like an old wood paneled restaurant you'd go with your grandparents.  Until you hear the music (there's a DJ!) and see the old posters of Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin on the wall next to the Super Lucky Cat statues.  And then of course there's the sushi -- uuuuhhhh, YUM!!  Really delicious, so fresh, many many choices.  Also -- a great date place.  Lots of conversation starters and it's really comfy and chill.  Run, do not walk to Ryoko.
author: Kate C.

description:
i thought service here has always been great,  but i always try to sit up by the sushi bar and rounds of sake with the sushi chefs.

it's literally my favorite 'underground' sushi place.
author: Alan N.

description: My boyfriend, his parents, his sister and nephew and I all ate here for a feast of sushi for under a c-note. I love this Nob Hill sushi-fest and highly recommend sampling each dish. The ambiance is simple with the minimalist decor you come to expect if you frequent sushi establishments in this sushi obsessed city. While the restaurant lends itself to romance with low lighting, the overall vibe is still family appropriate and the tables can be squished together to accommodate a larger group.
author: Jessica D.

description:
this is a yelper's wet dream.  the front looks bare and small, the place is down stairs and has a neato layout.  the food isn't horrible, trendy people go here.

it's hot in here tho, i recommend you blow out the candle at your table.
author: Ameer N.

description:
i used to live next door and only originally tried it out of desperation.  who wants to go down in a dungeon in a semi-grody neighborhood for sushi?  not usually me.  at least not for sushi.  the place was a great surprise.  they had a dj and good sushi.

this is how my boyfriend summed it up one night.  they are the only place he's been to where the seaweed isn't chewy.  and seaweed is important.  it's what holds the whole roll together.  if it wasn't for the seaweed, it would just be a donburi and it would not be as acceptable to eat with your hands.  although i'm not sure sushi is generally accepted as finger food, but i tell myself it is when i'm running into chopstick trouble.  

so my boyfriend didn't actually say all that, but he did mention the non-chewy seaweed.

bottom line, they let you do saki-bombs, have a dj, good service and good sushi.  most places you're lucky to get one of these!
(and i'd say all this even before the saki-bombs)
author: jen b.

description: This place has excellent Japanese food in a range far beyond your typical photographed sushi menu.   And the atmosphere is great.  You walk down stairs into a cheery space with festive lighting.
author: Melaina E.

description: Fun spot. The grilled whole squid appetizer is really good. Comes with some aioli that you put this spicy powder mix (Shichimi Togarashi) on. The sushi was good. Packed and noisy. The sushi chefs yell out some kind of "greeting" whenever someone new comes down the stairs...loudly...in unison...pretty entertaining. I'll have to check out another reviewers fave Sakana if only because sacana in brazilian portuguese means like two-timing trollip or something.
author: Darren K.

description: Interesting set up, decent service, AWFUL FOOD. Hamachi nigiri was inedible- it was poor quality and awfully cut. We ordered 4 sushi rolls; one was worse than the next. The tuna in one of the rolls was flat out not fresh and even the edamame was old! Dinner came to about $70 for 3 people.. So not worth it.
author: Marianne C.

description:
This place exudes authentic Japanese cuisine/dive bar.  The food is awesome, their sushi has to be the best I've had in San Francisco.  I also had the chance to sit and drink with the owner's father - really cool guy.
Definitely try the omakase and sit at the sushi bar for the best experience ... couple bottles of sake won't hurt either ... assuming you're of age!
author: Dannie C.

description: I love this place!  There is something about it that just calls to me as being the coolest place in the city.  I'm not even a big sushi fan, but this place keeps me coming back because I enjoy the atmosphere there.
author: doug s.

description: It's funky (having to walk down a flight of stairs as soon as you enter, no, IMMEDIATELY after you enter) but I like it. It's painted dark colors so you feel like you're in someone's basement but the staff is cheery and the sushi is alright. Yes, it's cramped inside and the music is funky but you're bound to hear something you like. Save room for the frozen strawberry (eh?)
author: Alden C.

description: Come to  this retreat first for the atmosphere--a novel mixture of lounge, piano bar, and sushi restaurant--and second for the food, which is tasty but not amazing at its price point.  A grand piano sits opposite the bar in a cozy but trendy basement space; presumeably the baby grand is home to a pianist or DJ later at night on weekends, but I've never seen one during the main dinner crowd.  The sashimi is not the greatest in the city, but it is some of the better stuff around Union Square, and the long, inventive roll list should satisfy those looking for less authentic Japanese fare.  The staff is quite polite and the charismatic owner/manager often makes rounds to check up on her customers.
author: MScott S.

description:
I am so sad to be writing this sort of review- I think because of the pains from my bitter disappointment are still being felt...
I've been here twice now. I went back after a horrible first experience because I wanted to believe in this atmospheric little jem. But, alas, twice scorned, I will never return. 
The service is marginal although friendly. The first time we went a couple was seated ahead of us. Usually not something that bothers me terribly, (I've worked F/B) but we had been waiting for 30mins and they had just arrived. And this last time, we ordered something off the special menu that was no longer available and when we asked for a few to reconsider our order he disappeared for 20 mins and ignored any attempt to grab his attention. 
But ultimately, the sushi is average at best. Much of our fish had a one day too old texture to it, which although expected when you eat supermarket sushi, is not acceptable in a restaurant.
author: kristin n.

description: ok ok so i love sushi bfd anyway this is the place i can never seem to remember the name of but i do enjoy eating here. Not my fave sushi place but def comes in the top 5. A good selection of fresh fish daily and a large selection on the menu. Never a bad choice to come here but beware when they say spicy, they mean SPICY. A bottle of sake can solve anything. I heard the hot tail (spicy yellowtail) is good, might wanna get yourself a piece.
author: Farrah S.

description:
**Update** yea Ryoko's you earn back your fourth star ;) Had dinner recently and service was back on track. yipeee I'll be back.


I've always liked this place but recently the service has kinda sucked?!? I'm the first to be cool when its busy but sitting for over 15 min without even a "I'll be with you in a min" not so good in my book. 

Rolls are decent, like the fact that its not all fussy fancy and its close to my house but the service needs step it up a bit. Better service and I'll give ya another star Ryoko ;)
author: Rachael Z.

description: If I always judged on appearances, I would not have had dinner here.  However, dinner was good.  Had only nigiris and sake.  Highlights were the Hamachi, Kanpachi and the Sake.  My least favorite was the Ike, but I think that's because I don't really like Japanese Shiso (but I love Korean Shiso).  Tried torigai for the first time, not sure if that's a keeper for me.  I felt like their cuts of fish were a little bit bigger than some of the places I've been going to lately.  A bit of warning, they're really heavy handed with the wasabi.
author: J I.

description: Love, love, love this place. It's definitely one of my fave places to chow down on some delicious sushi. The waitstaff is always friendly. So much tastiness, so little stomach space *weep*
author: S ..

description: Loud music, back room where you still on stools and crates covered with cushions. Decent sushi, decent prices (for the City) and you can be as loud as you want, which is good when you are really hopped up on sake.
author: Kali D.

description:
it's all true. this place is truly great.

i discovered ryoko's about six years ago and did my best to keep it a carefully guarded secret. it was and still is a great place to bring visiting friends and family for the ambiance and truly good sushi. it's just not a place i would let just anybody in on. 

but, now the word is out. really out. expect a wait if you arrive after 10pm thursday through sunday.

great selection of sake and shochu as well.

the sushi is for the most part delicious, i've had only few off meals here. presentation is superior as long as the place isn't jumping. once, the rush comes the service, presentation and quality suffers.
author: Timothy F.

description: Although it's a little crowded I liked the feel of this place. When you first walk in you come down a set of stairs into a dimly lit room with a decent size sushi bar to the left, a piano to the right (which a dj had turntables set up on the night I went in) and a smaller room with a table for bigger parties in the back. Sushi was of good quality but nothing to write home about really. Where Ryoko earned their stars for me was in their service. Because the place was pretty packed when I was there it took a second to get my order out, but they made sure I had some edamame to munch on and would refill my miso soup when I finished it, which I thought was dope. The atmosphere and people were pretty cool also. All in all I wouldn't rush to come back to this place but not a bad little sushi joint by any means.
author: Tommy P.

description:
5/2/08-
Went back to Ryoko last night.  Awesome!  We had to wait it being a Friday night and all...but it was well worth it.  Every single thing we ordered was fantastic.  We introduced a couple to the restaurant that also loved it.  Complimentary edamame.  Creative rolls.  Fresh fish.  All yum!

4/16/08-
My husband has been wanting to check this place out so we finally got a chance to last night.  They gave us complementary edamame, which was nice.  The tofu appetizer was not what we expected and was sort of bland but interesting.  I did not like the miso soup I ordered - each the stock, seaweed, and the tofu had little flavor and was not like any other miso I have ever had.  The salmon was awesome though!  With each bite it just melted in our mouths.  We shared the salmon nigiri and I had the 'sexy' roll that had cheese, salmon, crab, and avocado.  My husband's philly roll was also very tasty.  Our meals were excellent.  The place itself was very nice inside and unexpected - downstairs and kind of dark.  The bar was lively and different compared to many sushi bars in that people were actually enjoying themselves by talking, laughing, and drinking.  We will be back soon to try more!
author: Rise G.

description: This is a raucous, underground sushi joint open till 2 AM on Nob Hill.  Bring a bunch of friends here for good late night sushi when you're drunk.  Also, get the garlic shrimp appetizer--not very Japanese but delicious nonetheless.
author: Dan A.

description: Ryoko's remains one of my favorite Japanese places. Part sushi bar, part club, part date night and part sports bar! Depending on what you're in the mood for, sit in a romantically mood-lit corner or right near the DJ. Or make new friends at the sushi bar! I was also able to watch the Olympics here. So, you get it all. AND, the dishes are creative, enjoyable and nice quality. The consistency has been good, I've been here about 5 times and never been disappointed. There most likely will be some sort of a wait. And service can generally be slow once you are seated. But the host usually takes care of you, have an Asahi while your table is getting ready. It's worth it!
author: Lisa D.

description:
shuts at 2am
perfect place when on a night out after a few ales
cool vibe to the venue
food is fresh and fairly priced

i use it as my secret sushi place.... and everyone always loves it
author: david s.

description: great japanese  food, bad interior , dark and bad music.  the service was good, this place gets really busy and crowded.
author: Susie S.

description: late night sushi!!the fish is always fresh, i LOVE their ankimo! i hope i spelled that right. Along with good sushi, Ryoko's has some yummy appetizers. their fish is always as fresh as their sake is cold. whenever im craving sushi after work, this is the place to go.
author: Rebecca Q.

description: this is a cute japanese bar/restaurant with live music. sushi is super fresh. minus one star because it was pretty dark, i could barely make out which roll was which (but i guess u could add the star back if you were on a first date - it helps so that ur date cant see that youre struggling to chew a big piece of sushi while trying to still look cute) another downfall, parking would be a pain - take a taxi, then u have an excuse to drink more sake.
author: Denise L.

description:
Loved the loungy vibe, its perfect for when you want to go out, but not do anything too crazy.  Im a vegetarian, so I'm usually limited to veggie and cucumber rolls, but they had this japanese squash roll that was by far the best sushi ive ever tasted.  How something that small could be packed with so much flavor is beyond me.  I ordered another roll too based on the waitress' recommendation.  I didn't like it, it had plum in it that sounded interested, but I think it was just me not liking the flavor.  I'm sure other people with different tastes would have liked it.  The 3 friends I was with ordered a lot of food, i tried their seaweed salad, which was amazing.  I'm not sure if the place is terribly expensive or my friends just ate a lot, but it came to $50 a person.  My bill was only $25, including beers and sake, I guess that's just the luxury of eating vegetarian at a sushi restaurant.

I loved this place, I definitely plan to frequent this place when I'm craving sushi!
author: Sarah I.

description: Does the idea of eating sushi in a den just turn you on?!  Then go get your S&M gear and eat here!  On a serious note, this place is great.  Fresh sushi and beautiful waitresses.  Prices are a bit up there for me but the freshness definitely makes up for it.
author: Doogie H.

description: I've been here twice so far and it was pretty decent both times, good fish and good service.  It can be a bit pricy for some items but then again what sushi place doesn't have their pricy items.  It's best feature is the late night hours and it helps that it's just right around the corner from my new place.
author: Derek D.

description: Amazing sushi!  Don't even ask for a menu - sit at the bar and let them prepare for you.  Not a fancy place, but the quality of the sushi is great.
author: Russell W.

description: fresh fish and creative rolls.  Good spinning late night.
author: Rachael O.

description:
A bit of a divey restaurant, but such great fish! Very fresh!

We didn't order, but left it to the chefs to serve us their specialty's and it was awesome.  A few dishes had a little too much spice/hotness, but great flavors overall.

The service is a little lacking - forgotten waters...

...and no desserts were able to be ordered on our visit - we were mochi-less!

The price = great! 5 of us ate for $210...you can't beat that!
author: Pam W.

description:
Disastrous - and after spending a lot of time on YELP to choose a good sushi bar within walking distance of my hotel, quite disappointing.  I'm not a sushi snob but I have been to Tokyo 12 times and have had some damned good sushi in LA -- and I'm sorry Ryoko's fans but...this sushi was just okay.  Fresh but not the freshest, prepared a bit sloppily.  All forgivable.  But...the service was dismissive, rushed, put-out, and at one point rude.  Slow slow slow, and after waiting 10 minutes between dishes and asking nicely of the whereabouts....suddenly there was a shout over my shoulder.  i looked, my server was scurrying away...and my dish was sitting off to my right, somewhat closer to the diner 2 stools over.  Was it his?  Was it mine?  If it was mine, why not put it to my left between me and my dining partner?  It was mine.  After waiting too long for dessert, we said please forget it and we'll take the check.  Of course, the dessert was on the check -- more drama to get it removed.  And finally...the drunk woman diner stumbling from patron to patron, trying to drink their beers, and punching us in the gut as she passed by.  This went on for 15 minutes and no one in the restaurant staff tried to stop her or talk to her, leaving angry diners to fend for themselves.

Just a miserable experience.
author: Curtis B.

description: Ryokos is hands-down one of the BEST restaurants I have tried in San Francisco. I have never been treated so nicely before. Reiko, Ryoko's daughter has become a friend and always goes out of her way to make sure I, and my friends are happy and taken care of. I have never had a bad experience here, even they are crazy busy. The whole staff gets 100 stars from me. I cannot stop raving about this place. They made me fall in love with Sushi!
author: Natasha T.

description: One of my favorite sushi places in the city.  The fish is always so fresh.  Honestly, like butta!
author: Michelle K.

description: I went here after my prom. Of courses i mad reservation early. So when we went there we got seated immediately. We had a table of ten. This place is amazing. It's place looks very nice and the DJ was cool. we order our food and got it as soon as possible. We had a time limit since we had a limo. But we were able to finish on time. The waiter was wonderful. I would want to come back here again! i loved it. it was a great place to go if you want sushi early in the Am's! :DDDD LOVE THIS PLACE
author: Virginia L.

description: Great place, we were a group of 6 and got the back room which was super. The sushi was great and the agadashi tofu perfect. My mouth is watering just remembering. The spicy rolls were a bit too spicy, it completely drowned the other flavors but I am not a fan of spicy rolls anyway, usually for that reason. Great place
author: K O.

description:
The funky cavern is ideal for the alternative crowd staggering out of the Roppongi district of Tokyo at 3 am.  Ok, it would be quite a trip but you get the idea, if you've spent too many nights in Roppongi.

I think the intentions are good, but I cannot recommend this place for a dinner.  The music is too loud for a conversation, and the food is pricey for the quality.  However, if you're here after midnight, those wouldn't matter anyway.
author: Anonymous M.

description: It's all about the great service and banter with rockstar sushi chef at sushi bar. Table service less than desirable but still good...
author: Raul L.

description: Best everyday sushi spot. The atmosphere is a little trippy. You feel like you are eating sushi at your grandmother's house in iowa or something. I don't know...there is a piano with candy on it...horrible green carpeting through out and a 'living room' toward the back with a tv...very odd. Somehow I never seem to care, becasue the sushi is so fresh and delicious.  It also serves til 1:00 (maybe 2am)...so great spot for late nite dining.
author: Allison H.

description:
After eating at Ryoko's, I refuse to dine sushi anywhere else in the city. The food there is great and the place.....hmmmm.....VERY LIVELY, especially Friday and Saturday nights. I'm not a fan of raw fish, but the fishes from Ryoko's are an exception. The fishes have a very clean taste, making it very enjoyable for me to eat. After talking to the owner, I found out that they only use ORGANIC food...that's right....everything's organic. 

Besides good food, another reason why you should go there is because it's lively. On Friday and Saturday nights, they usually have a dj's spinning until closing, which is around 2am. In addition, the people there are quite interesting. Quite a view....lolz.

I give this place 2 thumbs up if you're trying to find a place to eat late during the night.
author: Jimmy T.

description: It's fun.  The rolls are interesting.  The service is great. The chef is cool   The decor is cool. All around good sushi place.
author: Heidi P.

description: I love, love, love the Volcano roll from here...hello- it has peanut butter in it!! Anything with peanut butter is good in my book. Also, the Jumping California roll is bomb. It also helps that this place is part of the United Dining Program, so you get triple miles if you're signed up...getting me that much closer to a Euro vacay next summer :) The service- ehh...I feel like they are always running around stressing themselves out way more than is necessary. A restaurant staff should always maintain composure even in busy times...eaten here several times and at least 3 of the 8 times or so, I have sworn I'll never come back because of the service. But then a month passes and all I can remember is the peanut butter. Definitely worth checking out if you have a little patience!
author: Erin F.

description: Ryokos is so damn good. Sushi is creative and super fresh (unexpected for this neighborhood) and the servers are really friendly, and best of all, they're open late night and nothin's better than late night sushi. I took a star away because the service can be spotty and downright slow, and sometimes its way too loud, but overall, it's solid and i keep going back for more
author: Lauren B.

description: Love the energy of this place. Awesome service, great music and  good food... and they're open until 2am...  The perfect place to go after a long night of drinking... and dancing.
author: Monica C.

description: Very average.  I expected a lot more from San Fran sushi...Portions are kinda small
author: Boris S.

description:
I've spent thousands of dollars here. I'm not rich. This place is just that good

Sometimes service isn't super speedy but it's because the place is always booming. My girlfriend and I go there all the time and can never get enough of this place. Boss lady is super nice as is the rest of the staff.

big eye, checkerboard, and blue fin..... soooooooo goooood!

go to this place. bring your friends. you will love it
author: g m.

description: Without fail, the coolest sushi place in the city. A combination of traditional sushi place with hip hang out. Darn fine sushi, some great rolls (their famous Volcano roll must be tried at least once!). The staff is very friendly and welcoming, the owners are very open and talkative to the patrons. And of course, how can you go wrong with a sushi and sake joint that's open past midnight??
author: Mike L.

description:
This is my first review on yelp and I feel like it was my duty to create an account just to write this and help out others avoid a lot of stress.

The food *may* be delicious, but we never made it to that point. I would highly suggest not going in a group of more than three people. The number of medium and large tables is severely limited. Our group of four arrived at 7PM for dinner and put our name on the list with only 2 other smaller parties ahead of us. Every few minutes, the greeter / waiter would tell us that it would only be a few more minutes before our table was ready. This continued for an hour at which time a table for us was being made available. At around that time, another party of four comes in and states that they had a reservation. Whether this was the truth or they were more keen on what went on at the restaurant, I cannot say. We waited for another hour, all the while parties of two were getting seated before us.

We ended up waiting 2 hours and leaving to go eat at the Japanese restaurant down the street. Suffice it to say the experience was horrible and I was rather looking forward to the food. The decor was uniquely 80s along with the music played. Note that this is more of a cold food place - rolls and sake/beer.

Sorry Ryoko, but that was my first and last visit.
author: Ed H.

description:
Having moved from Tokyo recently, this place that serves sushi past midnight near my apartment is my favorite place for sake and sushi.

The first time I came, I couldn't believe it was possible to eat sushi at 11 in San Francisco. Sat at the bar, asked for omakase, and my brain stopped working for a full five seconds when the toro hit my taste buds. Completely surprised, and incredibly happy that I'd found a reminder of Japan (I've been to other sushi places around Union Square, and always been disappointed).

Best nights are Tuesdays are Fridays when the fresh fish comes from Tokyo (sourced elsewhere too). It does get crowded, so either come early, or (much, much) later.
author: Josh L.

description: This is the perfect place to take your friends who are visiting from out of town, or just go for a late night bite by your self and watch the master chef do his thang. The music can be a little loud sometimes, but the food and the atmosphere is so very very very wonderful! I love this place and you will, too!
author: L T.

description:
best sushi I've ever had (try their sexy roll!)
the tea was served in big mugs and just kept coming
the salad was extraordinary

our Japanese waitress seems quite thrilled to tell us what her her favorite and then gushed when we ordered everything she said she loved

wonderful dining experience
author: deborah l.

description: best.sushi.evar. i will go here on every trip to san francisco no matter what. heart. heart. heart.
author: Matt M.

description: This is a late night treasure for sure.  The oysters are some of the best in town and the creative "From Japan" items are even better.  Great full bar and the service is so friendly.  Not the usual late night drunk crowd, but rather a full house of polite people.  Bar is interesting and the chefs explain everything and make recommendations that are superb.
author: Geoff D.

description: This place is a little cramped but a great spot for a bunch of energetic and chatty friends.  It has it's positives and negatives compared to other places in town like Tsunami, Ozumo, Sanraku, Blowfish, etc but so do they all.  This place is in a good spot downtown that is accessible to other things on Nob Hill
author: Jim S.

description:
Ryoko's is a must-see, must-experience for Nob Hill residents and San Francisco visitors alike!  The setting is so hip and trendy, with live music and an awesome DJ on most nights!  It has very late hours every night, so it is definitely the place to be for night-owls or the party crowd.  They have a good number of seats, and they're usually always able to accommodate large parties.  Great for taking out the employees for drinks (not great for business meetings because of the loud music) and love it for birthdays or celebrations!  You're allowed to be rowdy and have fun, and the atmosphere is so lax that other customers love to join in on the fun as well =)  I've had a lot of great fun at Ryoko's, and it's perfect for first-days.  My and my boyfriend went there almost every night for 4 years.  It can definitely get expensive, but trust me, it's worth every cent.

When they lose a couple servers, service can get very slow, but they usually rectify it pretty quickly.  There are a couple waiters who are slow at giving the check because they assume you want to stay, and we usually do!  Expect to spend a lot of time here, and money.  Once you check the place out, you'll be going back frequently!
author: Melissa C.

description: Great experience! Everyone is greeted at the door with shouts from all staff. We had the miso and several rolls and sashimi. The sashimi was a fresh from Japan fish that we won't remember, but trust your server's advice about what is fresh. All of our rolls were above average. The place quickly filled up as we ate at about 7:00PM, so watch what time you go if you don't want to wait.
author: Mike B.

description: This food is excellent. They have done a great job with the space available. Their bathrooms are weird, but their spicy tuna roll is great. Price is higher, but you get what you pay for. We usually don't wait long for a seat or food. My husband and I went for Valentine's Day last year and they were very busy, but got us right in and did their best to keep up with the rush. Good job Ryoko.
author: Aaron L.

description:
One of my favorite places.  I live nearby, so I'm somewhat of a regular.  I usually just post up at the bar and ask Atsushi to give me whatever he recommends.  He always hooks me up with some damn good sashimi.  

They also have a few standard izakaya foods - agedashi tofu, chicken karage, saba shioyaki - that are all decent.  The prices do tend to add up.  I don't usually get out with a bill less than $100 (that's for two people - and I drink lots of beer and sake), but then again, this is sushi.  I really dig the atmosphere.  It's chill, not too bright, always lots of people to talk to at the sushi bar, sometimes they have a DJ spinning lounge music.  Cool place.

My only complaint is that they need to add more to the sake selection.   But, that small complaint is completely off-set by the fact that you can get pitchers of Sapporo.  Damn!
author: clifton s.

description:
soo good!!!
i like how there's music and this place is very hip. 
it's always pack on the weekends!
very fun!!!
i like the sushi chefs! they are so awesome!!!
author: sarah m.

description: My friend and I wanted to try a new sushi bar. So I read some reviews for Ryoko's, and decided to try it. Not a good idea, maybe we just went on a bad day. We wanted to sit by the TV because there was a Warrior game coming up, little did we know we were sitting by the back door that kept on opening! It was freezing in there! We told the waiter about it, he closed it but for some reason it kept opening every 5 min!. We couldn't enjoy our food or the game, so we left. I have been to amazing sushi places and this one just didn't do it for me, I don't think I'll be visiting this sushi place again.
author: Alma C.

description: Sardine sashimi - original - good- but still a sardine.  The rest of the sushi was great...REIKO was very hospitable, sweet and accommodating.  Reminds me of an  "off-the-beaten-path" sushi dives in Tokyo - "for locals only" fare...however, a very enjoyable city experience.  Very loud music - not a good place to chat - but a great place to enjoy Japanese fare with a big group...4 or more.   I will definitely go back!
author: Lou E.

description: We went to this crowded downstairs restaurant last night.  On a Saturday night, best to make a reservation or you'll be waiting for well over 1 hour.  Luckily, my sister's boyfriend got a reservation for 4 at 8:30pm.  Although, we drove around for 20+ minutes looking for parking, we made it to the restaurant before they got mad about the reservation (although half the party was there arleady)  They play loud techno music on the weekends, so it kind of attracts a hippie/punky crowd.  But the atmosphere is casual.  We ordered a bunch of rolls to share include the umeshiso,hot tuna, jumping eal, golden gate, volcano, checkerboard and dragon roll.  I have to say the added shiso leaf to teh hot tuna made it taste quite unique.  The fish on the chekcerboard was also really really fresh, metls in your mouth!
