The rest of the rolls were ok, most of them were rolled very loosely so they kind of fall apart really easily but  All the rolls tasted super fresh.  The portions were't that large, six small-ish pieces per roll.  After that, we decided hat wasn't enough for the 4 of us so we ordered some chicken kaaraage and fried octopus and a onigiri (fried rice ball).  These items didn't really wow me or anything.  The chicken didn't taste like a traditional chicken kaarage and the fried baby octopus was really just too chewy.. i chewed for like 5 minutes on tha thing!  The fried rice ball was ok but it only came with 1  .. kinda of pricey for that. Also got 3 beers and the bill came to $125 including tax and tip.  The wait-staff are pretty responsive since its a tiny restaurant.  The only things I would really complain about is the noise level, stuffiness and small portions.  Otherwise, the fish is really fresh!
author: Margie C.

description: Okay so the sushi's just ALRIGHT, but the atmospehere is Awesome! Chill waitress'. Open till 2AM! Need I say more? Oh yes! It's totally affordable! I found this place a year and a half ago, and I go there often. I have yet to have a bad experience. Complimentary edamame. If you're not in a large group, I'd suggest sitting at the sushi bar and chatting it up with the sushi masters, not guaranteeing anything but, I've gotten some free tasters! Like I said, excellent service... nuff said!
author: Tiff S.

description:
I've read a couple of other reviews and i actually saw somebody write that the sushi was okay.  Wow!  That person obviously would rather have some over priced, pretentious looking, lower grade fish.  Take it from me, a real sushi king, the fish that Ryoko's gets is far better quality than anywhere else in the city.  The prices are reasonable considering the rising cost of quality fish these days.  But if you'd like, you can go somewhere else and get some fish thats been sitting around because they don't have enough customers to go through it.

I'll finish by recomending this restaurant to everyone.  Just don't expect anything except fresh, delicious fish all the time.
author: big d.

description: All I have to say is Pokemon Roll and Sake Bombs baby!  This place is so fun...it feels like you are stepping into Japan when you enter, and though the lines can be crazy it is always worth the wait!  This is my Sushi place in San Fran because the crowd is cool, the DJ is perfect for the place, and the chefs are so creative!  It is always fresh and so yummy!  And one more time...sake bombs!  Gotta love a pitcher of beer and warm sake.
author: Sweet C.

description:
Ryoko's is a cozy underground sushi place.  I eat there at least once a month because of:

-  the impeccable service
-  some of the best quality sushi in the bay
-  the atmosphere is perfect for a date or an intimate group
-  you never know what kind of music you're going to hear

Highly recommend it, especially over Sanraku which is just around the corner.  I haven't explored the new menu, but I haven't been disappointed with any appetizer, sashimi, maki rolls, or anything!
author: Brian M.

description: Three stars for this one.   When we first walked down the steps into the restaurant my first thought was "Bond. James Bond."  It's dark, the music is loud and hip, and it's very cool.  We were seated in a corner that felt private, even though the next table was only a few feet away.  Bathrooms were nice and clean (i'm only vouching for the men's though).  My only complaint was the food.  A friend ordered a plate of teriyaki chicken for an appetizer that we all shared, and that was delicious, but when our sushi came out it was warm and the flavors were too subtle for my taste.  The ingredients tasted like they had been sitting out for a while...and in a sushi restaurant, that's a bit unsettling.  It's worth going once for the atmosphere, and in their defense, it might have just been a bad night for the restaurant, but I probably won't be going back.
author: Philip G.

description: The rolls here is good but not best.  I'm giving this place it's fourth star for being open so late and having a really cool vibe.
author: Ryan N.

description: Do not judge this fabulous sushi restaurant by its sidewalk entrance!  I had the best sushi of my life--the rainbow roll and then the Tahoe roll with bluefin tuna.  WOW!  The sushi chefs were fun and interactive, which was nice because I was traveling alone and sitting at the bar.  The house wine was just that...house wine.  Drinkable.  But I wish I had gotten the Kirin on tap--yumm.  The service was excellent, and I love how they shout greetings when you walk in and call out when you leave.  Very charming!
author: Jillian H.

description: super fresh sushi and sashimi...the place is cool without trying too hard and can you say open late :)
author: Tom L.

description: If you order online, I recommend double checking the prices with them.  I order recently, and a couple of their maki rolls changed in price.  Otherwise, it's pretty good.
author: Daniel P.

description: always seems to be crackin every time i go , waitresses are cool , food is awesome and they are open late ( 2am) . last call is at 145) live DJ on weekends , sweet place for dinner with friends or a first date.
author: Wei W.

description: I hate hipsters.  The evolution of the emo took a wicked turn for the worst.  With that said, I still dig Ryoko's.
author: Sina A.

description: i have been coming to ryoko for years..... i'm not going to say its the most stellar sushi on the planet, but i've always been pretty happy with my food. what do i mostly like about ryoko? its in this cave-like basement space- and they have a DJ. not your typical sushi experience. i always, always sit at the bar. very entertaining.
author: Michelle I.

description: I wish I could give a 0star review. We came in early (7) to beat the rush, and were there for 1/2 hour before we got our order taken then an additional hour for three people to get their rolls. The appetizer and fourth persons rolls came 20 minutes layer when everyone was already done. When we asked the waittress where the fourth person's roll and app were she explains that they come from the kitchen and therefore take a very long time. Not apologetic at all and I stress that the place was not crowded. No one in there seemed to be eating though so we're all waiting for food!? I got the jumping tuna. Gross too much tempura and bland. Other people got Tiger rolls and unagi and I have to say for as long as we waited it was a pretty bad experience. In a city with so many sushi joints they really need to step up their game.
author: C W.

description: Ok, I'm going to be like totally honest w/ the down low on this. If we were giving the stars for atmosphere, sure I'd steroid boost the rating. Foody-wise, you've got to catch this place on a good night, which can be hit or miss.   Miss: You climb down some Hobit-unfriendly stairs to a cellar and you feel like you're in a a comfy den of late night thieves. The sushi chefs are friendly.... if they know you. Waitresses busy, and sometimes forget your order. There's no on-da-house here, you walk out after a couple of Sakis paying through your nasal cavities. Saturdays a dj cranks the hip-hop at club level; "This ain't Ruby Sky Dude."   Hit: Wednesday or Thursday night. Sushi's fresh. Chef's talkative while slicing.  Interesting and unique dishes pop up here and there. The after hours restaurant working crowd likes to come here and mix with the Academy of "Arteests" for some late night grub. Good mellow people watching. The food comes fast at the table, but better to sit at the bar. If you're lucky Yosh might sing some Sinatra.   There are always going to be better places, but they won't match this sushi joint for overall experience.
author: Johnny C.

description: I am perplexed by the bad sushi reviews.  Ryoko's is one of the best sushi places that I've ever been to.  Yes - their prices are expensive.  My boyfriend and I walk out of there every Friday night for what amounts to a payment on a compact-sized Honda - but it is an experience unparalled by most sushi joints.  Atsushi, one of the sushi chefs, is very friendly, young and hip.  Most importantly, he makes amazing freestyle dishes.  If you're lucky enough to get a bar seat, ask him to make you something of his choice, but be aware that he will use ingredients that you may never have seen or tasted before.  I think people who have given bad reviews are simply getting California rolls and thinking that this is a good way to go.  I recommend the specials on the board above the bar.  When they have it, get the:  octopus, bluefin tuna, Spanish mackerel (the only mackerel I can eat; this fish is uncured and not fishy tasting), yellow tail... it is all amazing.  As for rolls, the jumping unagi is a deep-fried eel with avocado and sweet dipping sauce delight.  The D.J.s are great and friendly, although often the music reaches volumes not condusive to small venues, and are told to bring it down a notch.  All in all, between the music, the atmosphere and the taste of bluefin melting my mouth, I'd rather be at Ryoko than anywhere else.  It's where my boyfriend and I went on our first date and we've been there almost every Friday night since.  Just don't take our 2 seats by the door.
author: Shelley T.

description: Brace yourselves yelp.  "I hate sushi!" Yeah thats right, I said it. Watcha gonna do? Huh? Wanna make sumthin of it? Its little, its not filling, its expensive and soy sauce and wasabi are the most grody flavors ever. Yeah I even said "grody".   Why would you take mild flavors that are as delicate as they are subtle and pour two pungent, overpowering, rancid, acid reflux inducing chemicals like those over the top?!  It makes no fucking sense. Who the hell back in the day decided that that was the way to go. I can understand pouring that caustic stuff over fish that was rotten to mask the flavors but how does it enhance the flavors? It doesnt.  ENTER: A mild raspberry vinagrette left over from a previous night's salad. Do you have any idea what an orgasmic epiphany I had that day? And after kicking it at Ryokos for a couple nights and stuffing myself (full even!) for about 5 dollars a roll I was sold. I closed a door and opened a window in to the new new demension that space navigators and versed hitchhikers call..."okay I like sushi now."  As an added bonus they are usually spinning some fresh beats and have a DJ on the weekends. The service is as good as it gets and everyone is hella friendly. And I hate the word "hella" so you know it must be. As soon as you walk in everyone on staff is yelling hello to you and then they all chime in on a good bye when you walk out. I don't speak japanese but I would have to assume that is what they are yelling. Although, honesly it wouldnt matter if they were all yelling "go fuck yourself cracker!"... i would still eat here nightly.
author: Dru P.

description: i LOVE this place. excellent sushi served in a dimly-lit little hideaway with live djs on some nights. groovy vibe, full bar, good service. did i say the sushi was excellent? probably my fav sushi spot in town.
author: Jill L.

description: Pretty good sushi most of the time, I go here a lot because it's very close and it's one of the best sushi places in my immediate area. The downside, and I wish this downside didn't exist, but you get any restaurant open late closed all day, below ground level, it's almost to be expected... they do have cockroaches. Yes, I've seen them, yes, I do keep going back, maybe that's inadvertently a testament to the sushi. It's pretty damn good.
author: Lex m.

description: SO good I have been testing lower nob hill for sushi and still Ryoko's has my vote. No one has topped it yet.
author: Jasmine G.

description: i had been going here for quite some time before i finally knew the name of the restaurant. why? it never mattered- everything i had tried was great. i take visiting friends and family here knowing they will like it. the atmosphere is cozy and the service is friendly and fast- considering how busy it can get here. tasty-mctastersons.  oh, and they have onigiri-  i love onigiri.
author: eddy c.

description: This restaurant is absolutely fabulous.  I was brought here on my first date with my boyfriend and I was quite impressed.  From the outside, the restaurant seems like a hole-in-the wall, but proved to be anything but.  The service is great, the ambiance is fun, and the quality of their fish is unparalleled in San Francisco.  They have a DJ spinning music that is appropriate yet edgy.  Food-wise, I recommend their nigori sake, jumping tuna roll, yellowtail sashimi and Toro nigiri (our favorite).  When in doubt, go with any of the specials, as their fish is super fresh.  I'm always in the mood to go to Ryoko's!
author: Rachel S.

description: I went here with a large group of co-workers last night around 8-9ish. It was packed and appeared disorganized. There wasn't a real host/hostess so we stood around for a while trying to figure out if a table was being set up for us or if we should grab as many bar spots as possible. After about a 20-30 min wait, we crammed into this table in the corner with mini cushion cubes to sit on. We proceeded to order a bunch of beer and sake. The pitchers of beer were convenient but the house nigori was blah. We ordered an initial round of sushi, anticipating to order more once we figured out how hungry everyone was and what the hits were. Unfortunately it took foooooorever to get the sushi and we were reluctant to order more because we'd be there till dawn. Two hours and $400 later, in a drunken blur, I remember the gyoza as disappointing, tempura as heavy, nigiri as average and jumping tuna roll as drenched in the same heavy batter as the tempura. Additionally, the basement was ugly and claustrophobic, and they kept playing bizarre salsa music. Wow, it's been a long time since I've thrown out a loner star.
author: Susan L.

description: decent sushi. close to my apartment. haven't been in a while, but i should go back here soon. i've had some fun times here starting off the night with friends getting drunk on saki and then going out after.
author: James J.

description: this is my favorite neighborhood sushi restaurant...it looks like a hole in the wall restaurant but when you walk in its more spacious than it would seem. the sushi rolls are delicious and the ambiance is fun and friendly...its a good place to go with friends for sushi and sake!!!
author: Vanessa C.

description: Out of all the sushi joints in this city I truly think this one is the best!  The setting is a combination of hip and dangerous and the fact that it's underground only adds to the atmosphere and gives it a since of mystery.  There isn't a bad seat in the house and if you have an opportunity to sit at the bar I'd take it-it's fun to see everything going on and watching the sushi get prepared.  The service is fast and friendly-everyone is so nice and there wasn't a moment where my tea or water was not being refilled.  To begin with there is no passing up the classics, miso soup & a wakama salad (seaweed and cucumber)-both only enhance what's yet to come.  As far as the rolls go, I would say it's a must to try the 'Pokeman' (salmon, mango, avocado) and the 'Hot Tail' (Yellowtail, Shiso and a spice)-both are wonderful!  I would stay clear of the 'Pot Stickers' though, they have way too much oil which really makes them unenjoyable-but hardly worth giving this place any less than five stars because it is that good!
author: Steven K.

description: fresh fish, dark dining, pretty cool. good sake
author: Mickey Z.

description: the atmosphere is quite casual and relaxing, a great place to unwind after a long day. the food is good and the service is kind. beware though, they absolutely don't open the doors until 6pm on the dot!
author: Hae-Jin K.

description: Have to admit I was disappointed by Ryoko's.  I got a pricey sashimi platter with mediocre fish and tempura for takeaway, and it was just not satisfying.  The tempura batter was beyond sub-par -- I've had a fair amount of glue in my childhood (well, not really) but that's how I'd imagine it would have tasted if I ever had to gulp Elmer's.  To top it off, it took about 20 minutes to pay and they didn't bother giving me utensils.  There has to be better options out there...
author: A C.

description: this place is so cute. thins the wallet a bit, but the selection of rare fish is so good and fresh it is worth it, as was the kobe beef sashimi....oh wow.
author: Nicole H.

description: ok the only reason why we go, because they're open late night. After a night of drinking yourself silly, come here. they have a dj, and the scenesters arrive. but the food, not to die for. Atmosphere, a ok. minus the mildew and ciggertte smell. but the owners Yoshi and his wife are gems. Who can't love the chipper japanese lady in tinted jane fonda glasses that drinks sake with you from 1 til 3. she'll definitly drink me under the table, no doubt. Not many ladies can do that, belive me...more power to you mama! sake to me
author: t f.

description: The atmosphere was very cozy and nice. I enjoyed the blue walls and the bold colors despite what others said in their reviews.  Our waitress was absolutely amazing, she seemed very busy rushing around but she never once kept us waiting for anything. It was very impressive actually. The sushi was awesome, the fish tasted fresh and not fishy at all. It was the best sushi i have ever had. While finishing up our food one of the women working came and asked our names and introduced herself and told us this was her family buisiness and asked how we enjoyed everything. If only every buisness cared about their customers as they did! There was absolutey no flaws, from the dance music to the inviting happy employees, and of course the amazing food. I can't wait to eat here again! And they have a big candy dish on the piano!!
author: Amy A.

description: yummmmmm......mmmmmy!!!!!  i love this place!  they have grade A raw fish.  the toro is delicious and so is the hotate (i love scallops!).  very fresh, great atmosphere, awesome music, super friendly staff.  it's kind of a dive, which is why i love it.  plus, sushi 'til 2 am???!!! :)
author: Jennifer K.

description: Food was decent. Not outstanding sushi by any means. The atmosphere is cheesy (there's a freakin' DJ). And they SCREAM at you in Japanese when you enter and leave. I assume they are saying something along the lines of hello and goodbye, but you never know.
author: Jeff R.

description: We went to a birthday dinner with 7 people. I've been here a couple of times before, and I have to say, I was very disappointed this time. Since we were a large group, we were told that we had a 2 hour limit on a Saturday, which seemed reasonable. We ordered seaweed salad, a couple of rolls and a mass of sashimi, all at once. The rolls came before the sashimi (which was odd) and they were good. The problem was the sashimi. All of the sashimi had the skin on. ALL of it:  butterfish, himachi toro, shiro maguro, salmon, maguro. Also, everything except the salmon had hot sauce on it - sriracha!! Why would you ruin good fish with that?!?!? Also, they put lemon between each piece of the shiro maguro (my favorite) which was a nice presentation, but I am allergic to citrus. I have never seen shiro maguro (albacore) with lemon on it, and I order it everywhere it is on the menu. Under normal circumstances, we would order a bit, then more as the night progressed, but we were given a time limit and was delivered a bunch of (to me) inedible sashimi. Some people in the group didn't mind the hot sauce, the rest of us had to scrape it off and dunk the fish in the soy sauce to "rinse" it. Everyone complained about the skin. We ended up spending around $50 per person - which is excessive for the small portions (smallest sashimi I've ever seen). (On a side note, the last time we went there, we spent like $80 per person - this difference was a reflection of the fish). I went home and had a snack instead.
author: Cat U.

description: I love this place.  A thousand little critters could crawl all over the table and I'd still love this place.  It has tons of character, and I'm told it's cool (I personally am not the best judge of all things hip, so I'll reserve comment).  Yes they fly in fish from Japan, but there are better places to get traditional sashimi and nigiri (like J-Town).  Go to this place for the non-traditional rolls and the awesome appetizers, which go great with a large bottle of nigori or Asahi or whatever alcohol happens to float your fancy.  As for apps: they make their own gyoza, provide free(!) edamame, and have the best karaage (fried) chicken in town.  If you're craving some cheese, they also have provolone wrapped and deep fried in wonton wrappers.  Updated childhood bliss.  Their rolls are pricey, but worth it.  The futomaki (traditional "large" roll of veggies, egg and crab) is another "best in town" item.  Now for you comedians, they have tons of "Flying" rolls--rolls covered in batter and deep fried (get it?  "Flying" instead of "frying" Still cracks me up.)  They even have inari.  Call ahead and reserve a table to avoid sitting for ages on the stairs.  Their service is always friendly but slightly harried, though they have never rushed us out, even if we're lingering and it's a weekend night.  Figure about $50-60 a person if you're going to completely pig out and drink like a fish.  It's so worth it though!
author: melissa g.

description: I don;t understand the love for this place at all. Sat at the bar and saw them peel our fish off of a BIG BALL OF PRE-CUT FISH IN A ZIPLOCK BAG. Disgusting.
author: brad m.

description: great for late night eating, ryokos gets big points for food + hip atmosphere. ive also been told the upstairs neighbors run a bordello, which is always an added plus.
author: jenna p.

description: My husband and I ordered take-out from here after reading all the glowing reviews on yelp.  The food was disgusting. The quality of the fish was poor, (fishy and tough), the spicy tuna roll had horrible texture, and my husband ended his meal with a final bite full of scales.  We will never return again.
author: cybele p.

description: great, late night (after 10pm) sushi spot.  low key atmosphere, friendly service.  private rooms for larger parties.  fish is fresh and the chef's are trained in Japan.
author: Greg T.

description: enigma. royksopp. just some of the retro/techno music that's played here all the time. i have had better sushi elsewhere, but ryoko's makes up for it with great atmosphere... and sometimes free drinks! (omg. the owner is SO COOL.)
author: AJ M.

description: after a night of partying... and leaving a club a bit early (around 1ish)... i wandered around the city with friends looking for a late night pizza place. who doesn't like pizza to soak up the alcohol? the place across the cellar on sutter was closed though... and i randomnly saw an 'open' sign a few steps away. sushi? at 1 am??? usually, late night places have something greasy. but man sushi hit the spot tonight.  the waitstaff was pretty cool that they gave a heads up there was last call for food. so we quickly ordered a bunch of rolls (about $6+ each). i kind of wish they had bento boxes but can't complain really to have sushi available that late.  sushi was actually good for what it was and no need to be tipsy to enjoy it.
author: ally o.

description: I've only gotten sushi here once, when I was with a friend in the neighborhood. The sushi isn't great--I remember a warm roll that tasted nice. Otherwise, Ryoko isn't a place to rave about, other than the fact that they sometimes have promos for bonus miles on my United Airlines milage card.
author: Travel Swagger R.

description: excellent everything and great fresh fish from Japan - I loved it and we even saw the guy from seinfeld who plays elaines boss.
author: Nick S.

description: Stunningly good! every time i come here! and i come here a lot. Expensive, but worth every penny.
author: anna k.

description: surprisingly good sashimi, sushi and other japanese food in the tendernob.  food is fresh and pleasing , and the atmosphere fun and lively albeit rather crowded on popular nights.
author: melita s.

description: Yes, it looks a bit like a hookah bar or a massage parlor, but the quality and freshness just about make up for it.  The uni, toro, and ankimo are to die for!!  Unagi, hamachi, and the rolls could use a bit of help though.  Overall, I'd come back just for the three suggested(even though a bit pricey, so worth the love affair that goes on in the mouth!!).  =)
author: R L.

description: walking down into this sub-level secret is enough to make a girl miss new york. sushi just as good, prices far more reasonable. old school staff spend more time on the food than on you, so order your saki and saporro in bulk and be thankful their priorities are in the right place - in your stomach.
author: Kristina P.

description:
Starting off any sushi experience with a bottle of Nigori sake is the way I like to roll.  Speaking of rolls, I didn't have any.  Instead, after said bottle of sake with friend, we stuck primarily to nigri.  I was really impressed.  The sashimi list was excellent.  There were a lot of varieties you would not see at your typical sushi restaurant.  We ordered Spanish mackerel, fatty tuna, mackerel, and couple of other varieties.  When our platter arrived at our table, I was surprised how large the portions of beautifully cut fish were.  At most sushi places, I will just stick to various tuna varieties because lower quality species like mackerel can sometimes be on the fishy side and the texture can be a little tough.  But I let our server do the ordering this time, and I'm glad.  Each variety we had was really splendid.  Each variety had a super buttery texture, and it was the freshest sushi I have had in years.

This perfect sushi experience took place in some rather bizarre surroundings.  The restaurant is located down an obscure set of stairs. Once inside, the whole place is dark and purple with a big piano in the middle; with all the nooks and crannies, it looks like a Japanese mafia hangout or something.  It is kind of kitschy and pretty awesome.  The one thing I would have really liked was a piano signer.  Then, my hazy, purple experience could have been complete.
author: t l.

description: with all these reviews, i'm still going to act like it's my own special little place no one else knows about. been going for years. that said, the food is top notch and love the inner city underground vide. can have an extravagant meal without the high prices of other places. the specials are always fresh and awesome. it seems like few places can you get bonito in season and it taste like it should.
author: matt n.

description:
loveeeeeeee loveeeeeeeeee loveeeee
best sushi in town and best people!
author: Pamella P.

description: The Food is good! you get house edamame and quick service to be seated. The setup is interesting because you walk down steps into a dark moody bar under the building. The seats felt really low the ground which was a little strange. i enjoyed the sushi i ate from here and definately will go back.
author: Sha A.

description: This place is totally hip!  The food is good, the atmosphere is good, and the servers are very friendly.  I went on my boyfriend's birthday, and they gave us a cake and a song along with dinner.  Good price, fresh, and fun!
author: Mitch S.

description:
I went to Ryoko's for the second time this past Friday as part of a friend's birthday celebration. It was as good as the first time.
After a short wait, we took a seat at the bar and watched the staff at work.
We started with a bowl of edamame given to us on the house.
We both loved the Toro sushi and sashimi (we ordered it both ways).  We also had the Unagi and the Hamachi sushi. Yum!!
The fish is so fresh it is worth the wait it sometimes takes to get  your order.
We also tried the Volcano roll (the one with peanut butter) and the Dragon roll. Even though I am not a huge fan of peanut butter, the volcano roll was delicious.
The owner was behind the bar and chatting with customers as she worked with the staff to ensure smooth service.
We were also given a plate of mochi ice cream, with candle, in honor of the birthday boy.
Everything was good and at a good price.
This is definitely a place I will return to.
author: Jenny J.

description: Awesome.  They handled our birthday party the best.  Really knew how to help us out, very attentive.
author: Michael B.

description: A great little place to go for sushi and Japanese food in the city centre - well located for downtown and not too pricey. I loved the hot tuna roll and the agedashi dofu... not so sure about the fried rolls but then they're really not my thing - everyone else seemed to love them! Still, it's a great option for dinner shared with friends (especially when everyone has different likes and dislikes), they have reasonably priced pitchers of beer and great music on Saturday nights. We felt like our server rushed us a little toward the end perhaps... but then this is a popular place! Would definitely go again.
author: Laura J.

description: disappointed due to the precedent reviews i thought it was unique...quality of the fish just acceptable, expensive for that type of quality,ambiance music I like so ok but if you don't, no choice it is loud.It is open late this makes the difference maybe...
author: afura a.

description: sorta felt like i was crashing the cool kids party on my first visit here. everyone seems like a regular, which is understandable, after my first experience. the vibe is definitely funky, it's a sushi joint with carpet (old carpet) and it feels more like an old jazz lounge than a japanese restaurant, but the sushi was fresh, the prices were fair, the kitchen looked clean and the staff was very friendly. soon, i too, hope to be one of the cool kid regulars...
author: Kate M.

description:
i thing this place is great,for food i usually set at bar ...like to see sushi preparation ......so i give 4 star for food ...but service is very bad 
servers don't really know about menu and they have bad attitude !
0 star for service
author: ana t.

description:
i give 3 stars to Ryokos for the quality of food and prices.  The rolls we got weren't THAT impressive.  we even tried the peanut butter roll and to our surprise, none of us hated it.  the other rolls seemed kind of plain, nothing special.  don't get me wrong, i love sushi, and it was good, but nothing extraordinarily good.  and it was a little pricey because their rolls were pretty small.  we ordered three rolls to start, and they all came in the same plate, thats how small these rolls are!!  (slightly dissapointed by that!)  i LOVE their agedashi tofu, the best i've ever had. 
i'm giving Ryokos 4 stars, however, because of the ambience of hte place and the service.  we ordered two nigori sakes but our server suggested that we start off with one and when we were done he would bring out the other so that it'll remain cold.  and he did, without us even asking!  nice.  we were there for almost three hours, two hours ordering and eating and then an extra hour just hanging around talking.  and they didn't rush us at all even when there were people waiting for tables!  nice.  there was a dj playing loungey music.  overall i think we paid for the ambience of the place, but not for the food.  it wasn't a bad experience and i had a lot of fun by the end of the night.
author: r r.

description: This is my favorite place in the city. I have gone in here several times and every time they were fantastic. I would recommending that you not take a menu and just ask them to make what they have fresh. The chefs are really well trained and love to create things just for you. I would not call myself a regular, but they remembered me and created a special menu and it was fantastic. I would go more often, but it is all the way across town and not very kid friendly. Everyone who wants good sushi in the city I always tell them to go here. Nothing is better!
author: Aaron S.

description: I loved the music playing in the backrgound and the dive-bar interior but the space is a little cramped and poorly configured. That's pretty much the only bad things I have to say though. My wife and I dined there on a Sunday night. The place was packed, the service was good and the vegetarian options were plentiful. The Jumping Vegetable roll is amazing! Highly recommended, and not touristy at all.
author: Vihar S.

description: Lots of choices and all of them great. The kitchen does a great job but the trip here is the "specials" board. Open late night and it is always busy.
author: Jeff B.

description: limited menu. lack of variety. average quality fish. overpriced.
author: Q C.

description: Do you want to eat with the COCKROACHES?  If so, you should go here.  I went for the first time with my sister, her husband and a couple other friends who always go there and always spoke highly of it up until yesterday.  We were seated at a table and before we even got our food I looked up at the wall to see a cockroach crawling right beside me.  We all were in awe at what we were seeing when suddenly it landed on the table.  We all jumped up in disgust and told the waiter.  He sat us at another table and although we were all pretty grossed out at this point, we decided to give it another chance when moments later while we were eating a second cockroach proceeded to climb up the wall.  We told the waiter a second time and he was very apologetic and after he killed the insect he went and told someone, not sure if she was the manager/owner but she came over and was very apologetic (the sincerity  was questionable).  She also said that they were not aware of the issue..... ummmm.... how are you not aware that your restaurant is infested with roaches.  That in it of itself is either a lie or plain scary.  She gave us a pathetic discount and we still ended up paying around $100 to eat at this place.  We left disgusted, not satisfied and upset.  Needless to say none of us would ever go back.  I have been to a restaurant where a similar issue occurred, but they had the decency to take care of the whole bill and all we left was the waiter's tip.
author: Theresa P.

description: sushi served subterranean at its finest accompanied w/ dj spinning a'ight beats atop a piano- it's hip and well visited by repeaters. having been a customer for years, it's now def' packed on most weekends, so arrive early, or be prepared for 10-20 min wait.  the fish has always been fresh, and served quickly, and is pretty reasonably priced. my fav there is the 'fatty' toro toro cuz that's how we roll ;)  you'll enjoy the evening if you don't mind the music and low-lighting, its cool ambiance for a date. don't be afraid to challenge the chefs with your creative requests, they're always prepared to surprise you. enjoy!
author: Ken S.
